reviews.review: Thumbs up. Go to this place!!! Wait in line but worth the sight. Book in advance is key for the next visit. Take a group and plenty of patience.

Really fantastic views - it's so tall you will be flabbergasted . We visited the Sky Tree and would recommend highly for a visit if you go to Tokyo. We went early before 10am and the queues were short 5 mins to get in. Would recommend as we heard that queues get very long in the afternoon.The staff were all very friendly and helpful and the place is very clean and modern. Also attached to a nice shopping Centre so something for everyone.The views are breathtaking so make sure you visit on a clear day to make the most of it. You can buy tickets on the day so you can choose when to go. Admission is a little pricey and they are a little cheeky in that if you Wu she to go from 350th floor to 450th you have to pay another £10 each which is the reason for the 4 out of 5 stars. However if you can afford it it really is fantastic. If you suffer from vertigo however you may want to give it a miss as I do not but got the collywobbles walking around the top as it is so high.

Impressive tower. Not a very clear day for a visit but we went anyway. The views are predictably outstanding in all directions, but the overwhelming impressions we were left with are of unacceptable levels of noise from the uncontrolled school children (several groups all as bad as one another) and the poor signage to get in and out of the complex.

What a view. What a view even on a cloudy day.For foreigners there are 2 types of tickets. The normal one for 2060 Yen and an express one for 3000 Yen. The express one allows you to bypass the rows.The tickets allow you to go to 350 meter. If you want to go up to 450 you will need to buy an extra ticket of 1000 Yen on the 350 floor

Fantastic view and not crowded. I think the best time to visit SkyTree is in the morning, before the atmosphere becomes misty. It was a fantstic view and it was possible to see far away. Fuji-san was visible but only a the top, due to clouds. Tokyo is a very large city. The facilities was very nice, plenty of space and very short waiting time.
Super high!. It's not only tower! It's a combined museum and mall, and unpredictble.. Park on 5th level (if i'm not wrong). Clean and amazing.
Great View!. We are from Toronto, so of course we compared it to CN Tower. Honestly quite similar. No view from elevators going up but wow is it fast! 600m/min. Great views and interactive view maps.

Limited queues for international visitors even a Saturday. Skytree is sort of a must see in Tokyo, and in my view also worth visiting, although Tokyo has no shortage of other places with spectacular vistas, some of which are even free, which Skytree certainly is not. But what if you can't get enough of gazing at this peaceful, sprawling, yet dense megalopolis from above? The views from both 350 and 450 are amazing so no disappointment there, at least if the weather is fine as it was on our day there. What would have been even greater would have been access to an outdoor balcony (like Empire State in New York, several other top spots around the world, and occasionally Mori Tower in Tokyo itself), but I suppose there are safety issues and so on to disallow it. And especially the top 450 m. platform is designed so you at times do feel closer to a free view than in some other closed structures.The fast track counter for international visitors is really helpful to beat crowds, we had no more then max 10 minute waits either for tickets, to get up, or to get down and this was on a fairly clear October Saturday mid morning, but I can't promise it wont be worse some days!

Flying visit around the sites of Tokyo. I visited the Sky Tree on a Wednesday morning at about 8.20am as I hadn't booked in advance.It was very quiet and I had no queues to endure which I suspect build up later in the day given the area roped off to manage queues. There is a lot of staff on hand to direct you every 5 yards or so, trust me there is no chance you will get lost or become confused on which turn to make as staff are everywhere. The staff are helpful and extremely courteous as you would expect in Japan.There are two levels to the experience, the 2nd level is only payable when you reach the first level and have the desire to climb another 100 metre's. Views are amazing as you would expect given the height of the Sky Tree and there are plenty of views and opportunities to take photos of Mt. Fuji and the the vast Tokyo skyline. Well worth the trip and my only tip would be to get there early to avoid the queues if you don't have a pre-booked ticket.Enjoy the Skytree!

Make sure to visit on a clear day. After getting into Tokyo we dropped our luggage off at a storage place below the Skytree and thought we might as well go up - great view and a very cool piece of engineering. It was pretty smoggy and foggy the day we went up, definitely recommend going on a clear morning perhaps in winter - would probably be good at night as well!Staff were helpful, there was even a (slightly more expensive) fast-track counter for foreigners to avoid the queues. Luckily didn't need to use it. Souvenir shop has some interesting stuff, and the cafe in the observation deck was surprisingly good quality! Also a massive mall at the foot of the tree for those who are interested in some shopping.
Average day out.. . I'm a bit synical about tall building attractions. It gives you a nice view of Tokyo and that's about it. Average standard facilities and a bit expensive for what it is...

Experience the best view in Tokyo. The Skytree is an impressive sight both inside and out, night or day. The surround area is full of awesome restaurants and shopping. Inside the tower you will see a variety of mall shops with nearly anything you could want. You can find a museum, an aquarium, the upper 360 city view, multiple art exhibits, several floors of restaurants (all types of food are available). At night the tower lights will change colors and patterns making for a great photography backdrop. The JR line goes right to the entrance, about two floors below for easy access.

A bit disappointing, expensive. Was a bit disappointed, as this is quite an expensive atraction. The views are of course greatbut most of the tokyo highlight buildings are quite far away.There are better options for less money (eveb free).

A Good Visit - Plan well for a good weather, avoid long queues and enough time. Generally, a lot of these attractions (tall towers, observation decks, viewing galleries) are more or less the same. However; Tokyo Skytree is worth a visit since it is Tokyo after all. The location is quite central. It can be a walking distance from Asakusa on a good day else you will be tired just walking to the location. First, plan well. Choose a good day with good weather. Must be bright and sunny so you can have a good view. Don't take chances. You will waste both money and time. Secondly, get there early. Recommended that you get their first thing in the morning, say around 10:00AM to beat the rush and possibly a brighter viewing. Foreigners have a special line but you pay extra. Credit cards are accepted. Plan for ~2 hours to make the most of your time and money.The elevators take you to the observation deck in less than 2-4 minutes. It can be crowded. At the observation deck, there are coffee stalls and restrooms. However; as with these places, everything is expensive. You are allowed backpacks so carry water, drinks and snacks.There are also restaurants at the ground level - McDonald, Denny's... But beware that Denny's here has almost no vegetarian food. If you go to the basement there are many other places to eat as well buy snacks and drinks.So if you reach around 10:00 AM, you can then eat lunch at the bottom and then go to your next attraction. And you would have made a good use of your morning time.The attraction is expensive. If I remember correctly it is about US $30.Sorry, don't have recommendation for night time viewing as I visited during the day time.

Dreadful weather but helpful staff. I got the shuttle bus here on a rainy day and was pleased to find somewhere indoors! It was incredibly busy on the shopping floors and there were queues outside most of the restaurants. The Skytree itself was efficiently run and staff were keen to help with pointing me in the right direction and offering ticket advice. Far from touting more expensive tickets they explained it would be better to go to the normal counter instead of the fast track. They even showed footage of how cloudy it was and how bad the view would be before I committed to buying a ticket.To make up for the poor view, a video was played of the view on a good day. Staff members were on hand and were offering to take photos of visitors wearing the headdress of the Skytree mascot. As a solo traveller I really appreciated this and it helped turn around what could have been a very disappointing visit. I could see a little of the view and took a turn on the glass platform on the way down. The lift had a pretty light display. I found the layout of the lower floors a bit confusing and much as I love shopping, it all started to feel a bit enclosed and overwhelming. The shortage of windows and busyness some how made it a rather tiring experience and I didn't buy anything. Very nice loos though!

Great experience but long queue!. We have arrived here in the late afternoon and we had to wait a lot to get the tickets (¥ 2060 for 350 m platform and additional ¥ 1030 for the platform located at 450 m height). The view is great and of course Tokyo Tower will be the most lighted building of all. There is also a souvenir shop and items sold here are not cheap. It's a great experience not recommended to those which have sick of heights.
This is good. Please bring your passport if you want to get up there and also the rides are really crowded also every thing is good but I didn't see my fu ji
Breath taking view. This was my 2nd visit and went higher observatory section. I could see the all the way to Mt. Fuji. If you want to see Tokyo, this is the place.

Different experience . It's my first time to such high tower, I was lucky to get the ticket from company so didn't have to wait for very long queue, the lift speed is impressing, and the view from top is wonderful, do not miss the part with the glass floor.

Incredible location and views. Visited the Skytree Tower. Incredible location within the city of Tokyo, however make sure you book ahead as this makes it much easier to access the tower. The basic ticket will get you up to the first level at around 365 metres but you can purchase another ticket while you are up in the viewing tower to access the second viewing tower which is about another 100 meters above.The first level provides all that is required to view the whole of Tokyo and on a clear day you can clearly see Mt Fuji, however on our visit the mountain was completely block from view by haze from the city. Vehicle you are This level you can access the two lower levels where there is a coffee shop and a glass floor to stand and take some quite scary pictures.

Very busy, especially waiting to get back down - view great!. We were limited for time so paid a but extra for the express ride to the mid point.
Didn't get to go to the 450m height, but 350 was enough to get a great view of the entire city and surrounds.
Trip up was fast, facilities great.
A little pricey but still a great experience

Amazing views. Easy to get too by subway with just a short walk. Tickets are sold on the 4th floor. We went on a week day and there were no waiting in line. As with everything in Japan, things go quietly and efficiently. Suggest you go all the way to the top view platform. It costs a bit more, but worth it. The views are spectacular. Once you are done there is a nice shopping area and food court on the lower floors where you can eat, plus a fantastic supermarket with some of the freshest seafood/fish, sushi and sashimi I have seen. The Tokyo Skytree is worth the visit.

Great view of Tokyo . Easy to get to and very well organised despite the crowds. Excellent view but mt Fuji was in clouds. We ate at the restaurant and had a fantastic meal. It normally requires booking but we got in without. Well worth it.
Beautiful at night. We went on our last night and it was absolutely breathtaking. The night was very clear and you could see for miles. A MUST for all who visit Japan!

Lets go to Skytree!. As the highest observatory tower in the world, Tokyo sky tree does not disappoint. Ticket was $20 was a little pricey but if you want to have a 360 panorama view of Tokyo, don't miss out! The elevator up to the top floor was so fast and they have nice music as well, you arrive at the top in no time. They have a lot of displays that you can be photographed with however they do charge you. Got on a clear day to see Mount Fuji.
Night view amazing. Unbelievable views over Tyoko. We did an evening viewing was incredible. We visited the top area and was worth paying a little extra for.

Great views,go towards nightfall to see the change from day to night.. We got some great photos by going towards the end of the day. We paid the extra to fast track in instead of waiting in the long queue and I think that it was worth doing that. We also paid to go to the very top, which was less crowded and also has the glass floor. I am not generally a lover of heights, but was able to walk on this floor because we were so high up that the tiny vehicles and buildings below just didn't seem real.

Excellent and well worth the money. Firstly, I must clarity we visited this fairly early on a weekday morning, which, I imagine, it one of it's quieter times given that it had got significantly busier by lunch. Having said that, I never felt it was over crowded. Going to skytree is expensive, but if you want great views of the largest urban area in the world from the tallest tower in the world then I'd say go for it. The views were spectacular. We had a clear day and could see Mount Fuji in the distance. It was definitely of one my favourite experiences in Japan.

Amazing views!!. Visited the Tokyo Skytee during our trip to Japan in September. The tower is situated in busy shopping area with plenty of places to eat & drink. We visited quite early due to our busy schedule and there were no queues. I think if you visited at busy periods you may have to queue for a while although with Japanese efficiency I'm sure it wouldn't be long! Awesome views from the 1st observation deck with plenty of room to look over the Tokyo skyline. We paid the additional fee to go to the 2nd deck which had equally good views.Would recommend visiting at night as the lights of Tokyo would look amazing!

Worth a look. Went today with my husband and it's pretty impressive. Totally recommend paying a little extra for a fast track ticket (15m wait rather than 60m) and paying the extra 500 yen to go to the very top as its much less busy- also- if you're going to the tallest tower in the world surely you want to go to the top!? I've been to the CN tower and One World Trade and I have to admit I found them more impressive - I think they let too many people up to the top of Skytree at once so views are restricted (but waiting times are great) also - Skytree is so tall compared to the rest of Tokyo it feels like you don't really see much! The surrounding area is pretty cool and it's not far to walk for lovely traditional shrines and restaurants.

Go up to the very top and in general on a sunny day, not on an overcast and cloudy day.. Everything looked so drab and dank and it was hard to see and get good pics of the city view from even the highest vantage point.

Wow - you must go!. I expected great views, but at night this was just insane. Not only were you lifted at high speeds in the worlds most sophisticated lift (seriously, it was so quiet), but the physical building is a sight to behold. I would seriously recommend paying the extra 1,000¥ and go up to 450m, it's less crowded and the view is just a tiny bit better! Didn't manage to check out the cafe as we were in a hurry but don't be hesitant due to price, it's completely worth the price of admission. Bring your camera!
Tokyo skytree. The place was awesome also the ground staffs was so helpful I really appreciate the place.i advice all tourist must visit the skyscraper.

Great tower but very busy!. We decide to visit the tower in the early evening to see the lights of Tokyo, but had a twenty minute wait in the queue. A fast option was available for international tourists, however this was much more expensive and gave not discount for the kids. After waiting, we were packed into a lift with about 30 people. Once up to the 350th floor we arrived to find the floor packed with people. Although the views were great, we had to work our way to the windows through the 4 deep crowds. Were were surprised that some of the windows were blocked off by displays, meaning you could not see around all sides. We managed to see some nice views, and loved the see through floor, however the experience would be better at a quieter time. Beneath the tower is a large number of shops and restaurants. Overall a nice visit but for views and a quieter visit we preferred Tokyo tower.

Amazing view and Great Shops. Skytree is best known for it views but I enjoy the special exhibits and shopping. They have had Disney, Star wars and other amazing exhibitions. They have many specialty shops that are fun to browse.

Gorgeous and Highest View in Tokyo. Best observation deck in Tokyo and actual highest tower in the world (as in observation tower and not building), across the river from Sensoji Temple in Asakusa. Open until 10pm. Try to time going to the tower to enjoy the view both in daylight and nightlight which we did., and pick a beautiful day to be able to see Mount Fuji from deck. Go to Asakusa station in the afternoon to visit temple and Nakamise Dori--old shopping street leading to the temple and best place in Tokyo to buy souvenirs, and then get back on same line to Oshiage station. There is a big mall at bottom of skytree. There were no lines, so no reason to pay more for expedited tourist line for which I believe that you need your passport. We did not pay extra to visit the highest deck which other reviewers said would have been redundant, and we believe it is accurate. We were about to leave when the cool "window cleaning entertainment show" started." It is fun, check schedules on web site. Do not buy anything at food or drink stands on that floor (coffee was so mediocre and no place to sit), as there is a better spot, a nice little cafe one floor below with stairs where you can sit comfortably to enjoy the beautiful view. We were surprised that the food tasted that good. In the interest of time, since Tokyo is so big and it is all in close distance from each other, go to Ryogoku in the morning to see sumo training sessions, especially if there is no tournament at the time of your visit. And that will be a well spent day.

Expensive but worthy for the views. Went on a Sunday and could not see the end of the queue. Thankfully they have a shorter queue for foreigners that cost just abit more but you get to bypass the queue for both buying and the initial elevators.One of us took the birthday sticker to see what happens but was mostly just greetings from every staff who saw it. Views were great, and remember to look up while on the 2nd elevator to the top. Was told by many we were lucky as this was the first sunny day since 2 weeks ago hence the massive crowd. Sadly Mt Fuji was feeling shy that day.Had a drink and a cake on the lower deck. Surprised at the quite average prices on the menu. Desserts were delicious and drinks were refreshing. The views helped too.Long wait to get down so do time in that if in a rush.

Great views of Tokyo and interesting structure. Currently one of the four lifts is closed but that didn’t cause too much delay. We opted for the normal priced ticket rather than the fast pass as we were not in too much of a rush and didn’t have to wait long anyway. This was around 10am. It was slightly overcast on our day so we didn’t bother with the level 450 experience as we felt we have seen enough on level 350. Well worth a few hours of your day and we’d certainly go back again at dusk to see the sun set across the city.

Stay aground, and that's good enough!. Skytree is hard to miss out, and people who came all the way from their home countries to this very landmark would like to pay to get to the top. Not everyone, and I was one of those people. Personally, I'm not really into seeing the cityscape, although Tokyo is without a doubt a mesmerizing metropolis. After coming back from Fujikawakujiko, my head was still teeming with the magnificent mountainous view. So, instead of paying the entry fee to reach the top of the Tree, we stayed on the ground and enjoyed the view looking-up.

360 degree View of Tokyo. Located near Ginza is the tallest tower in the world (over 2000 feet). You can visit the basic tower about 80% up the allowable distance or pay a few more yen for a visit to the top level. Not much difference of the view. Many school children were visiting the tower on the afternoon we toured the tower. Entrance to the elevators is fast and the staff very efficient. Dedicated elevators are available for the handicapped and those with strollers. The view of fantastic on a clear day. At night the view is further enhanced by the beautiful lights of Tokyo. Many souvenir shops are available on various levels but the shop on the ground level is by far the largest. Many restaurants are available nearby. Expect to spend about 60-90 minutes during the visit. Kids will enjoy the experience which includes a glass floor which provides a view of the scenery below the structure.

What a View!. We walked here after seeing it afar from Asakusa. I believe this tower is the tallest in the world. Fortunately the crowd was smaller than expected. We bought tickets to the floor 350 Tembo deck as well as the floor 450 Tembo Galleria. Combo ticket was 4K yen. We started at 350. The view was simply magnificent. It's was dusk and a bit hazy outside although we could still make out the key buildings. The 450 level with surrounding bars made picture taking of scenes outside a bit difficult. There is also a glass floor for one to look straight down. The sumida river digital picture scroll on the lower floor was an interesting. On a clear early the view must be even more spectacular.

Very impressive, but expensive. There are two observatories - one 350m high, the other one 450m high (for some reason, the signs say "350 floor, 450 floor"). I purchased a fast-track pass, which saves time only on the first line up to the 350m observatory. Don't expect Manhattan-like views. Central Tokyo is very far a way, and in the afternoon sun was completely in the haze. The glass floor on the lower (350m) observatory is fun, but it's very small.
Plenty of activities to do here. Shopping, good food, the view from the tower, aquarium, and many more! Good tourist option with hours to spend in this attraction.

Pricey and overated for a panoramic view. While I can understand the joys of viewing the city from on high, the sad thing is that this is all it has to offer. Don't misunderstand, the attached malls are a joy to wander through. However, the Skytree itself is expensive and if you want to get the highest view, you'll need to pay extra. Yes, the architecture and technology is impressive, but I feel I could spend the money on something more interesting. Tip - don't go for the 'express ticket for foreigners' - it's even pricier for the premium 'quick entry'. All it does is just zips you through the next elevator up. Just enjoy the ambiance of lining up to the normal ticket booths - it's part of the experience and the line moves quickly anyway.

Wow!. Visiting the Skytree was on my husband's "bucket list" for our time in Tokyo. We arrived just after sunset and although it had been raining earlier it cleared up just before we went to the top - so we got crystal clear views of the city. It's very easy to get there by train. Not sure what it would be like during the day, but this time of the year it's difficult to get clear views of Mt. Fuji due to cloud anyway.

Good attraction!! . If you want to have an interesting experience come an visit Tokyo Skytree Tower. The view is amazing and you will be able to do some more visits, like the Aquarium and the Mall. Pretty worth it!!

Great views, nice technology. Very similar to Toronto CN Tower in height and layout, main pod at 350 m. Level, higher pod at 450 m. Fast elevators and smooth quick ticketing process. About $20 for the basic, another $10 to get up high. Nice panoramic windows with ledges, for those with small tripods you can get good time lapse or long exposures. Worth it got tower fans, would go in evening next time. Cafe at top has simple dishes to take a pause and enjoy the scenery.

Best view of Tokyo . The skytree offers a trip up to two observation decks. The first one is at 350m and costs ¥2000, the second is at 450m and is an additional ¥1000. From both decks you get a full 360 birdseye view of Tokyo, but the lower deck is more crowded that the top one. There are also restaurants avaliable in the skytree (unfortunately I did not eat there). For me this was a spectacular attraction,and would recommend this to people going to Tokyo.

SKY-TREEEEEE!!. We visited the Tokyo Skytree on our first night in Tokyo. It was a lovely experience. It is a high-rise tower and offers amazing views of the Tokyo skyline. There is the option to have your photo taken in front of the skyline and with some kitschy Japanese cartoon characters. The photographers ask you to say "SKY-TREEEEE" instead of "cheese" so that will forever more be the first thing that comes to mind when we reflect on our time at the Tokyo Skytree!

There's a Ghibli Shop!. Apart from dining, shopping and enjoying the view from the observatory, there's also a Ghibli shop! My friends and I didn't manage to purchase the ticket to Ghibli Museum and it was a huge blow. The tickets were sold out when we tried to get it from Lawson. But when we were at Tokyo Skytree, we made an amazing discovery - Ghibli shop! In there, they sell various original merchandise and there's a cat bus in it :D enjoyed my time browsing through the shop. If you're a fan, I suggest you drop by.

Great views. Can be accessed at the end of metro Z line. A complex of eateries and the tower. There is a charge to go up, cost depends on which level you choose to visit quite expensive so go on a clear day or you will not see much of the city.

Amazing view! No building in Tokyo can beat it. I know there are other viewing points in Tokyo that costs less, but none of them give you a view from a 450 m hight. And, yes, it's worth the money to buy an extra ticket for it. It is the second tallest building in the world we're talking about.My husband and I went before the sunset and got to see the city in a day light, enjoyed a beautiful sunset and an amazing night city view too. We expected a long queue, but it actually was very short and we got in very fast.They also have a glass floor there, but all you can see it's the base of the tower. It's nothing spectacular, but it's free so check it out anyway.The price is 2000¥ to go to the 350 m level + another 1000¥ to get up to the 450 m.

Tokyo Skytree. Awesome! Arguably, the tallest monument in the world. Go to the top to get a panoramic view of Tokyo. On a good day you can see Mt. Fuji. There are gift shops and opportunities to take souvenir photos. The views are breathtaking!

Fantastic view of Tokyo and beyond.. This is Tokyo's highest tower, which rises to 634 metres. It does get busy but the wait is worth it. There is a fast track for foreign visitors, which must grate with the locals but the Japanese are too polite to complain. The lifts whisk you up to the first platform so quickly and easily that when you first step out you cannot believe that you are so high. There is another level (additional cost), which takes you up a further 100 metres. The views are magnificent and apparently Mount Fuji can be seen on a clear day. The view is marred somewhat by the outer tubing that is keeping the structure in place. This is a rather churlish remark as the structure itself is a magnificent piece of engineering. Do try to visit the tower in the morning as the sun is in the right direction for taking pictures of central Tokyo. Our visit was mid-afternoon and we suffered trying to take some good pictures with the bright sun in the wrong place or is it the case that my photographic skills are lacking? Of course, the view must be absolutely splendid at night.
Too expensive... There are lots of free viewing places in Tokyo.. do your research before spending a small fortune...

Expensive but worth it. I am a fan of towers, so for me this was a no-brainer. It was interesting to see the "state of the art" in observation tower design-- by this I mean the huge glass windows offering a seamless view all the way around. Observation decks on older towers were limited by clunky window frames; here you truly feel like you are in the clouds.

Fantastic view, a little expensive. We went all way to the top. It was interesting experience. We have been up in Eiffel Tower, Willis Tower and the one in Vegas. This was the most extreme one. Everything below were TEENY TINY. It was a bit foggy though which distract from the value. Might be good idea to verify before actually deciding to go up. On best day you can see to Fuji but we could not.There were exhibiton of Ultraman up on the top floor. It was in Japanese text only which is natural as Ultraman was/is essentially a Japanese show. But it was still neat to see the detail of the camp 60's show props.The staff were extremely polite and nice!!

Worth it!. Best views, even on a cloudy day. We only went up to the first level (345m) but this was amazing. There are a couple of cafes to get a drink and cake and enjoy the views. Reasonably expensive but definitely the best skyscraper attraction I have been up anywhere in the world as it is much higher than any others I have been to and Tokyo is such a huge city that you can just see buildings for miles. Fantastic.

One of the best observations in the world.. One of the best observations in the world. Don't miss it if you have time. Not cheap, but worth it. Try to fix it with a visit in Asakusa.Check the tower's web site before going to there, you can find the expected waiting time on the lines for tickets or for the elevator. On the base decks you can find shops and restaurants. Basically, a mall.The tower offers two observation decks. The main decks at 340m+350m. The higher deck is in 450m. Tickets for the higher deck can be purchased on the main observation deck.It is recommended to prepare you camera before entering the elevator. Try to get a shot of the main screen showing the elevator speed at 600m/min.The main observation deck offers some photo assistant or professional photography stands, which can also print it on the spot for you. at these decks you can also find cafe, however the line often tends to be quite long.On the higher deck there is an option to option to take an external professional photo.

Bring a zoom lens!. It was fantastic to be up so high, I was super lucky as we had a point and shoot camera that had an incredible zoom lens. I would suggest trying to grab one before your trip if you plan for this to be one of your highlights. It's also a cool adventure just to get to the sky tree itself. It had awesome Ghibli shops down below, as well as an awesome food court/aquarium. I would recommend this to anyone. I'm super scared of heights, so I couldn't walk through the area with the glass floor, but I wish I did now. Only thing I would say against it, is that it's a little bit pricey, as we didn't want to wait the 4-5 hours to get up there. Next time we will be going up at night.
Expensive, but worth the money. Yeah, it's not cheap, but the view makes it worth it. Just unbelievable, for a guy coming from the countryside like me, to see only houses for as far you can see.

Great views of Tokyo . A recommendation for anyone that is considering paying to go up the Skytree, I would aim to get there for roughly 5/6 pm as the views over Tokyo when the sun is setting are just phenomenal, and it seemed to be a little quieter than other visiting times. Any later than that and the queues are extortionate. Although the entrance fee was a little expensive, once you see the aerial view of the city it is definitely worth every penny!

Incredible views from the tallest tower. Visited in May this year, getting out of the train station we couldn't believe just how enormous it really is!The elevator to the top was quick and spacious, didn't feel like we had ascended so high.The views at the top are absolutely incredible, you can see out across all of Tokyo and pick out the key landmarks. On a good day you can even see as far as Mt Fuji!The upstairs was quite busy with schoolkids visiting and lots of tourists but not overly crowded, they had a nice gift shop.The area at the bottom of the skytree is great for shopping and restaurants.

TOKYO SKYTREE Great symbol of Tokyo !. It's a great place and easy to go by JR and train system, you can pay for high lv view to Tokyo city. otherwise, there's a mall and plenty of stores or restaurant down at the lower floor that you can take time's to enjoy your shopping experience!
Top of Tokyo. Very exciting place and a must visit place in Tokyo. You can see Top view of Tokyo from here . Even journey in elevator is awesome .

Do go all the way to the top! :). My advice - don't stop at Tembo Deck at 350 m, but go all the way up to Tembo Galleria at 450 m, and you'll find it "absolutely worthwhile" with higher windows offering better views than the ones on Tembo Deck. And yes, "phenomenal" is the word when it comes to the views especially those to the south with the highest buildings of Tokyo on the west side (so to the southwest from up here) and the waters of the Tokyo Bay on the east side (so to the southeast from up here); pretty much directly below the Tower on the west is the Sumida River with so many bridges spanning over it along its whole length, and at some distance to the east from the Tower (the distance most likely the outskirts of the city on its east side) is the Arakawa River which joins the Tokyo Bay as it flows south.The restaurant & the café on Tembo Deck (not at 350 m that you get to when going up, but at 345 m & 340 m that you get to on the way down) both seemed overpriced, but there are a number of eating places way down (like on levels 1F to 5F) & KFC just outside level 1F (to your left after leaving the building). But I do suggest visiting the gift shop on Tembo Deck on your way down (at 340 m, on the same level with the cafe); I bought a coin keychain and you can get "your name & the date you're there" engraved on the back of the coin (free of charge) either on the 5F (the return level) or on the 1F (the ground level). Also, just before coming down by the return elevator from 340 m to level 5F, you might want to take a brief look through the glass floor on that level (340 m), but it's just a small area that the floor encompasses and the view is nothing much to speak of.If you're at the Asakusa area (like I was), it's a walk of just about a total of 15 minutes to here by first crossing the Sumida River to its east side (the red bridge is the best one) for about 5 minutes then turning left for about a 10-minute walk to the Skytree building. There's also the train (Tobu Skytree Line) between Asakusa Station and Skytree Station which I believe is right under the Skytree building or pretty close to it.Lastly, get there "early" so you won't have to line up or have to go into the foreigner lane costing more; I got there at like 7 30 in the morning and even had to wait for them to open at like 8! :)
High, high!!!. Highest building I have ever been! Amazing feeling. Amazing desserts in the coffe shop! Must visit!!

Better to say you've been then to actually go.. This is a good thing to go to to say you've been to the tallest tower in the world. If you go on a good day it could be amazing. On the wrong day and it's still good, but not as good as my imagination tells me it could have been.

Amazing view from at 451.2m. The entrance fee was expensive but it was all worthwhile above. This is the second tallest structure in the world. The view is a real life google map. Buying ticket tooks 20 minutes. I suggest to try and go to Tembo Galleria at 450m level (additional payment at 350m). This is one of the highlight of our Tokyo Trip. A Must Visit in Tokyo.

The queue is too much. We arrive at almost 4pm and there are absolutely too much of a queue to get in. We manage to take photo of the Sky tree and shopping. The shopping is great and most likely enjoy more than Sky tree itself!

Great views of Tokyo. Although enshrouded by low cloud in the morning, the skies cleared enough for us to decide to go up and see what we could see. Probably because of the weather, there were not many people, which was lucky, and we had great access to all views. We only went to the 359 floor level but the views down and over Tokyo were wonderful. It gave us an appreciation of the city's detail and different precincts and we also enjoyed looking for various landmarks we had already visited. A night visit would be rather special, I imagine. However, the daytime visit was well worthwhile and enjoyable.

Amzing views, busy and expensive.. Managed to get some awesome awesome photos from this place. Could really take in the sheer vastness that is Tokyo from up that high. Unfortunately, you do pay and pay again to go higher, and I think it was over ¥2000 for the two of us to get up from the ground to main observatory section. Not a complaint as I was thrilled with the view. Unfortunately as with most tourist spots they are getting overrun with tourists and you can feel from the staff it's wearing them down. I am getting sick of following tourists to a counter and them being unable to say hello, yes or thank you in the native language. Really can't learn 3 words to just be a little but polite back to the staff? Please people don't just say "thanks" in English or worse just stand there and wave the money at the staff, the japanese are super hospitable but show some tiny incentive to say thank you. End rant. This place is worth the visit and the money just be prepared for the line up and crowds.

Skytree Tower. I thought this was fun, interesting, and great views of the city. There are glass floor areas that don't cost extra to stand on. It's very popular, but there is a separate entrance along the side for foreign visitors. I had my passport with me, but they did not ask to see it. You will be sent up ahead of the long line outside, no waiting. It might have a discounted price, I don't remember. But definitely look for this. Very nice service. It is an observation tower, but you can stand away from the windows if you don't like the edge feeling.

Amazing view. Definitely prefer Tokyo Skytree to Tokyo Tower. The view is definitely more magnificent, worth the expensive tickets. Go there early to avoid the queue and crowd. Was there at 9am with no queue and it wasn't crowded. Gets more crowded at around 11am and saw queue forming at the ticketing reception. There is a cafe whereby you can enjoy coffee with a piece of cake and enjoy the view.

Sky tree. Visited Sky Tree today and it is a must for a view of Tokyo and the surrounding districts.....not too badly priced for the pleasure. The speed of the lifts is excellent at about 600 metres a minute you can't see outside but your ears will pop very quickly.......

Amazing City!. The view from the Skytree lets you see just how expansive Tokyo really is! Incredible views! It is 100% worth buying the ticket for the higher floor! I couldn't believe how much more the view opened up! Even the elevator is fun and fast! Really an experience worth having!!!

Wonderful view. I was kind of scared to get there so I payed only 2000yen to the floor. It was already too highest to go up the building for me. Everything so small from the sky tree and I forgot all bad things. I thought Tokyo is big city that I didn't know till I go up there!!!

Must do! . Visiting the Tokyo skytree was amazing. We paid a little extra to go higher up, where it was much less crowded, so a better experience could be had. Would love to do this again at night time to see the city lit up.

Nice view !. Finally had the chance to go up on the Tokyo Skytree! I spent about ¥2100 and some change to go up to the tembo deck. I didn't go to the very top cause it was an extra ¥1000 and some change....(glad I didn't cause it was partly cloudy that day) The place was super clean, the elevators were super fast, and the employees were extremely helpful. I went during the day time and the view was great, bit a bit hazy in the distance. I think going at night or on a crisp day would be a lot better. There's a small cafe that over looks Tokyo. The food was fancy looking but tasted ok.

Now this is a view. The elevator gets you to the first observation deck 350m up in what seems like seconds. So fast and smooth. From here you can see as far as Yokohama and Mt Fuji on a good day. You realise how huge and sprawling Tokyo is. Buy another ticket and you can be whisked up to 450m. Fewer people and somehow view seems even better. If you have the cash to spare (roughly $10 more) then do it. Transport here is easy with a subway station below (Not a JR pass line. Couple hundred yen for a ticket). Excellent mall and food stores. Loved the fake plastic food shop and man selling hand made knives.

Tallest Tower in the World. At 634 m, it is the tallest tower in the world and the tallest building in Japan. It has phenomenal views from the 350 m and 450 m observatories. Although, the prices to go there are expensive, but they are worth as you get to see the panoramic view of Tokyo and beyond. There are cafes in the observatory as well if you can spent money. Combine Skytree with Solmachi mall (and Aquarium) to get the best out of the place.

Amazing veiw . We visited it with my family in tickets area they told us the waiting time around 1 hr but it was 30 min it has a cafe and sitting area up and restaurant the view was amazing especially if you go before sunset and enjoy the sunset view but during hot summer it is good place to visit during afternoon
Great place to be mesmerized by the sight of the city. Even Mount Fuji is visible.. Tokyo Skytree is a great place to be if one does not mind spending the money as the ticket is quite pricey.

Great view, very crowded.. Tokyo Skytree was fairly crowded and we had to wait around 30 minutes to get in. This wasn't an issue although personally I felt the ticket prices weren't worth the entry. Aside from this, the view was incredible, looking out from each window allowed you to see how large Tokyo really is although after about15 minutes or so, we got bored and decided to leave. Overall, the prices weren't worth the entry but the view was the exception.

Awe-inspiring view. Visited around 5 pm on a Monday evening in time to catch the sunset. We thought we would have to go through fast lane for international visitors but they told us to go normal as the waiting time is less than 5 mins. When you get to floor 350 (where everyone gets off) you have the option to buy tickets for the Tembo Galleria which is access to floor 445 to 450. It was worth the extra money as the view from there was absolutely breathtaking. The wraparound Galleria was also a sight to be seen. The commemorative photo at an added cost was a nice treat. Watch the sunset from here and as the city lights up you realise the magnitude of how big tokyo city really is. As you leave on floor 340 there are 2 glass floors areas where you could stand on and take photos. There are some cafes/restaurants on the top. As you descend down you realise there is actually a shopping center for a few floors. The food court was so clean and spacious with variety of food including ramen, takoyaki etc. Don't forget to check out the Sumida River Digital picture scroll on the ground level or (1st floor as they call it here). Amazing piece of mixed art. Overall well worth the money spent just to give you a birds eye view of the magnificence and the sheer size of thia beautiful city

Amazing building and experience. Really is a great opportunity to see a city the size of tokyo- as long as the pollution isnt too bad.Its about the one negative in the whole experience if your there on the wrong day you can have a limited view, otherwise your see mountain ranges beyond the city as the sun goes down!Price was fair, staff were amazing.

Shopping mall with Tourist attraction. They sell everything from branded stuff to cute souvenirs and so much more such as Onitsuka, hello Kitty world, Lego etc. they also have food court with variety of japanese cuisine from street snacks to a set of mealsFurthermore, you can visit the tower for sightseeing across Tokyo. I'm not sure how much is the admission fees but I suggest to come early since I was there in the afternoon, the waiting line was so long! So i've decided to not to enter to the Tower (such a waste :( ) maybe next visit I will try to enter the skytree tower

What A View. Had to come here, after hearing so much about it! The lower floors full of stores and a Pokemon Store as well before you head up to the viewing floors in a very nice lift and the views of Tokyo! Worth it all the way! Pricey but you just have to accept that Main Attractions just cost that much to see...you don't go all the way to somewhere like Japan and then go...'Nah, to expensive' Have fun regretting that choice on your flight home! I loved the views so 10/10 from me

A view out of this world. There are two different entrance fees you can pay to visit two different level sky decks. We went to the lower one, and it was not a let down. The observation deck runs in a circle, with glass from floor to ceiling the whole way. The views are absolutely breathtaking! We watched the sunset from there, and it was really a sight to behold. Tokyo is a massive city, and I did not appreciate its beauty until just then. A few levels below, there is actually a glass floor spot which is quite cool to check out as well. The staff are all so polite (it's Japan! Everyone is polite). Would HIGHLY recommend!!

Tokyo below your feet. The first thing you see is people, mostly locals. Don't panic, tell the staff that you are an overseas tourist and you will be directed to the fast lane. (Of course, you could get tickets online.) It is worthwhile to purchase the "combo-ticket" so you can go to the second deck, and from there, you can get to the highest point of the observation decks by a spiral ramp. And don't forget to pick up some souvenirs that are sold exclusively at the second deck. You get to see the cityscape of Tokyo when you are inside the tower, but if want to see the Skytree, you must see it from afar especially when it is illuminated.
High up there. One of the high buildings in the world. Really a must and an ikon for Tokyo. Enjoyed the view. A great atraction that I recommend

The second highest tower in the world. The tower is easy to find (visible from far) and to visit. The great organization and information for non-japanese tourists. Breath-taking view of this gigantic city is worth spending the money. Night view is probably more impressive.
So amazing!. Awesome awesome awesome view! Was a huge line up to get up there and abit expensive but worth it. Can see for miles.

Amazing view of Tokyo. A must visit when in Tokyo. Has the best view of all of Tokyo. On a clear day you can even see Mont Fuji. The elevator is so fast but you barely feel it. Has a nice glass floor to city the city from above.
Amazing view of Tokyo. Sky tree is the highest point in Tokyo where you can really see all the city. On a clear day you can see Mont Fuji. It's also nice to visit at night and see the city lights

A great perspective of a most incredible city. . Beautiful vista of one of my favourite cities. Well worth a visit and relatively cheap too. Only went as high as the first platform (350m) as we were running short of time.

Amazing night views, but quite pricey.... We very nearly didn't go up the tower as it's quite expensive, and we only (only!) went to the 350th floor rather than pay extra to go another 100 floors up. However, the views were pretty breathtaking, the lift was amazingly fast and smooth, and all of us enjoyed the visit there. You needed do the tower itself if you're afraid of heights or counting your pennies - just standing below it looking up is impressive, and there's a large shopping mall with lots of shops, food courts, a Pokemon centre and things to see and do without paying to go up the tower.We went at night, and with Tokyo lit up it was very beautiful.

Beautiful view . We really liked the view up here. We went to the 350m spot to save $20 USD. Not sure what else you could see from the 450 spot but our view was great. Would have even been better if it was a clear day and you could see Fuji. Worth the money. They don't have a ton of information in the platform like the space needle or Empire State Building do. May need to read up on notable things to find and then see if you can find it from up there.

Watched the sunset. We were reluctant at first to do this... but were amazed when we got there. We paid extra to get to the top floor b/c there were way less people (easier to get photos) and skipped the line. Both were very worth it. Go early to get better photos and try to stay for the sunset... it was breathtaking.

New and Aspiring Symbol of Tokyo. Built of concrete and steel, this modern structure recently claimed to be the tallest building of Tokyo with 634 meters. It also happens to be the 2nd tallest building on the planet, as we speak, after Burj Al Khalifa in Dubai. There is a no-waiting special entrance for international tourists, slightly more expensive though. The elevator ride is fast with some animation on the ceiling. Try the 450th floor which is a separate elevator ride from the 350th floor. There is a nice mall underneath, plenty of food outlests and a nice Sake specialty store.Recommend seeing especially for tower-mongers!

not to be missed if you are in Tokyo. It is a must for those who love heights and desire to have a bird's eye view of the place they visit.The tower offers great views of Tokyo city. The ambience up there is pleasant and holds many surprises including live show in night which is pretty entertaining showing the cleaning staff with the help of light projection on the viewing glass. The tower offers stunning views of Tokyo tower, bridges, rivers and other attractions in the city. It is worth visiting in the evening hours still left with some day light and then staying upto night when the city is fully lit.Great times!

Great view.. We were waiting for the evening to come to see all the lights in Tokyo. Unfortunately cause of darkness it was impossible to take a pic. The view was great but, in my opinion, not worth the price.

MUST VISIT!!!. The view of largest city in world "Tokyo" from the second tallest man made structure in world is absolutely breathtaking. You can see all the greater Tokyo region and beyond to mt. Fuji. The view from top is totally different from what you normally would see from regular skyscrapers. You must see it for yourself to explain the view.

Wobbly Legs. My second visit to the top of the Sky Tree - at 634 metres it is the world's tallest tower. Sensational views that give fantastic perspective of the massive metropolitan footprint that is Tokyo - we could pick-out Mount Fuji easily. Like my last visit I was a little stricken with wobbly legs - and remained well clear of the glass outlook throughout. The lift whisks you up to 350 metres floor in an instant, where you transfer to another lift that takes you to 450 metres floor nearly as fast. There are cafes/restaurants, a shop and other points of interest in the upper galleries.

Worth the Money. There's a special foreigners ticket that gives you expedited, line-cutting super powers, and it's worth it to splurge on the top floors, if only for the interior decor and ambience, as the view is substantially the same. If u do, try to get to the back of the elevator and look up.

Worth going to. Think Google Earth and it's 3D!. As an international visitor you can get a special pass and faster elevator access to the viewing areas of the Skytree. Worth the 3xtra cash to see the higher floor as its a little less crowded. We visited on an over cast day and watched how it rained in parts of Japan then quickly lifted. It was like remarkable looking at the weather on a city. Looking down on Tokyo was like Google Earth. Buildings, toads, rivers, trains etc as far as you could see. After the Skytree, every other viewing level cannot compete!

An amazing view of Tokyo. Being one of the tallest structures in the world, Tokyo Skytree offers an amazing view of the city. I did not book my ticket in advance but managed to get it within five minutes when I went there on a Monday morning in late August. The staff was helpful and made the experience really great.You'll find many shops there and can get nice souvenirs for your family and friends (definitely check out their Pokemon store) and got some sushi / cooking ingredients in the Food Marche there, prices were really good.

Great views but not worth the bother. We decided to go to the sky tree at the end of our first day in Tokyo. The sky tree is on the edge of the city and seemed to take us some time to get there and multiple changes of subway train (that will of course depend on where you get on, and where you set off from). There are two prices for the sky tree you can go up to floor 350 or you can pay extra and go to the highest level. We really didn't see any point in paying more. The views are amazing and you can walk around and view the city 360degrees but I'd argue it's not worth going out of your way to do this

All Day Shopping with Indoor Comfort. 7 floors of shopping and dining, in full a/c comfort. Free access to the 31st floor viewing deck. The Pokemon Centre on the 5th floor, the amazing tsukumen on the 6th floor, plus all the other buying and eating options. Think of it as a more comfortable, upmarket Ameyoko with year round access. Highly recommended, will definitely go again. It's right at the Oshiage subway stop.

A great day out. Fantastic views. It was quite busy but that's to be expected with it being one of Tokyo's premier landmarks. Staff were helpful and spoke excellent English. The mall that is joined to the sky tree is also worth a look

a view from the top. My family really had fun visiting Skytree.
360 degree view of tokyo.
At the time of our visit, not to many visitors so we had a great chance of looking around.
Staff are really polite.

Great landscapes. Worth visiting to see all great Tokyo. Especially spectacular in the evening, at sunset, when the streets get gradually enlightened.
One drawback - there is no open terrace, only glass covered 360 degree deck, which slightly interferes with taking photos, especially at night.

Magnificent Monument . I really wanted to tower when I was in tokyo , my friends who visited this tower said I have to see and experience it . Well the tickets at not cheap , it's the centrepiece of Tokyo Town in sumida. The hight was 634 meters and it's the tallest building in Japan . This tower also has a large shopping complex and and aquarium located at its base . The best thing about the tower was its two observation deck which the view is just simply breathtaking . It's has broad Windows that simply offers the best views of the city . I was there at night and it just so beautiful . The time I was there in February , the deck was having the star wars exhibition and believe me I was so lucky ..... The middle floor has a souvenir shop and a sky restaurant which serves a French -Japanese cuisine . Well I would love to tell you more but it's best you experience it so get ready your finances when you plan to visit the skytree . It's worth the money and you will have an experience to treasure .

360 Tokyo panorama.. Well worth it - stunning panoramic views of this 40-million people city. If you're lucky, you can see Mount Fuji on a clear day.Expect to wait in line for an average of 30mins, you can also select the premium fast access option. Lifts are proper high speed - not for the faint-hearted! :)

Fantastic for sunset. Perhaps we just struck lucky but we queued for less than half an hour for our fast track tickets on a Friday evening in July, and then walked straight into the Spring themed lift, it really wasn't as busy as I had expected. We had plenty of space to enjoy the fabulous views at sunset and the city lighting up at nighttime, we decided to buy tickets up to the higher level, and enjoyed the spiral walkway with it's fans and chimes, strangely peaceful. Well worth the expense, we spent a good couple of hours just marvelling at the views. Plenty of choices of good places to eat in the shopping malls below and easy access by rail.

Excellent place to see Tokyo from Top. We took tourist ticket and thank god we took that. It was weekend and Q had 3 hrs waiting. It is must go place even if you are in Tokyo for short time. You can see how big is Tokyo.

Great views of city. Most of our tour decided to visit the Tokyo Tower but we were on the way to the Sensoji Temple and saw the Skytree. Great views of the city and surrounding countryside, even Mt Fuji on a very clear day apparently.Good coffee shop. Would be excellent for kids.
Tokyo Skytree. Excellent place to visit in the night. Exciting ride towards top. Beautiful sky view of Tokyo City and river crossing city

The Tokyo SkyTree. This was told to me as the tallest tower in the world. But it is very high. There are two observation level at 350m and 450m. There is a special ticket counter for a non Japan passport holder cost you just a bit

Worth the visit. Really nice views of the Tokyo area. It is a little distance from Shinjuku or Shimbuya but it is worth the trek out here. Their is an attached mall you walk through to get to the ticket counter. In the day time, there may be a wait but on Saturday night the line was shorter than I would have expected. The views of Tokyo are really great, different from the other observation sights in town. Since this place is further from 'downtown' and the other tall buildings, the views better of the metro Tokyo area are great. There is a light show at night that is projected on the window. It is ok. There is a glass floor where you look down and see how high you are. It was packed with tourist and is not that big. The only complaint I had was that it was hard to take night photos with the window glare. Overall, well worth it.

Great Views!. Had online reservations at 2:30pm, arrived early in the area, and I mean by 11:00Am, and tried to get in at an earlier time, but could not. There is a big sign that actually states the rules. It was packed so it made sense . So make sure you pick a time and do not arrive early, they are very prompt.Went to the first level, 350M.above ground, great views of the city, it had just stopped raining when out time came . We were hoping to get a good view of Mount Fuji, but that did not happen. However, the city buildings appeared jam packed as if you had Legos display all around. Kids had fun taking pictures and there was interactive glass display of panoramic picture of the city, with the touch of your finger you can change it to night view of the part you are looking at or just zoom on it. It was great.Did not find it necessary to go to the higher level, additional 100M. You can buy the additional ticket at the top, no need to buy that part in advance. Which is actually good.

Must visit. Great place to get a real view of how big and incredibly clean Tokyo is. It has different levels at different heights and many stores and restaurants to hangout in the lower levels. Definitely a place to visit if you're sightseeing.

Must do while in Tokyo!!. This is a MUST DO while in Tokyo! We almost decided not to go and so glad that we went! This is a breathtaking view and the experience has been an unforgettable one. We went at night but I imagine the day is as equally as cool! The experience going up the elevator was really neat with the music and lights. Your ears will pop as you go up quickly! I didn't realize as a foreigner to Japan, that we could have skipped the line to a non-Japanese passport holder. That is important to note as it could save you a lot of time! If you go to Tokyo make sure you do this!!
Terrific view!. MUST VISIT attraction of Tokyo, really not to miss! From here you can really understand the greatness of this amazing city! and by night the tower assumes nice colors by the lights.
Stunning!. As non Japanese passport holders..we get to ride faster than the long lines... Extra ¥¥¥ of course...

Family Visit to Tokyo. Well, to start while planning our trip to Japan I can say that I did not know about the Tokyo Skytree. I am not sure how I missed this tower since it was completed J. 2010. During our recent visit my family asked if we wanted to take the kids to the Tokyo Skytree. They then proceeded to describe the tower and of course we said yes. We have visited observation towers in many cities however this was the best experience. The height of the two observation decks are what makes the tower unique along with a view of one of the most crowded cities in the world. The only negative that we experienced was the lines however that is because we visited the tower during the start of one of the largest holidays in Japan...Obon. The themed elevators are smooth and extremely fast. The circle walk located at 450 meters provides an amazing view. The wind chimes (fans blowing on them) add to the experience. We recommend the Tokyo Skytree Tower.

Top of the world feeling!. It was fantastic to view the whole of Tokyo metropolis from 350m up high! I went at night and the twinkling lights of the city made it look like I was viewing a galaxy. The attraction was well-staffed who spoke good English and the direction well-explained. Certainly, it was crowded with visitors, but I reckon the upper deck of 450m might be more comfortable.

Best in Winter!. Enjoy a stunning view over Tokyo. Best to visit around 1630 in Winter time. You will see Tokyo and then have a wonderful sunset and nigh view. Winter for the dry weather and the resulting view!

Incredible. Just an incredible experience to lift up at 450 meters above the land, sightseeing is impressive, had the luck to enjoy sunset. Highly recommended, even if not cheap taking the Fast Track (only for international visitors, 4.000 JPY).

Fabulous view of tokyo. If you are not Japanese you can get international tickets by going to the west side of the building. It will save you at least an hour of waiting time. Fantastic views and very courteous staff.
7 floors of shopping mall. There's 7-floor shopping mall under the skytree tower. Plenty of shops, local food and restaurants. You can spend the whole afternoon here alone.

Great view of the metropolis. You have to go up in Tokyo to realise quite how huge the city is. We were lucky that the clouds parted as we arrived and we were able to get a great view of Fuji-san. It's worth paying the extra to go to the highest deck if the weather is good as the views were fantastic. We went during the week and it was busy but the queue moved quickly and as ever the Japanese staff were polite and efficient.

Unbeatable. I'm terrified of heights, but the views from the Tokyo Skytree is worth the shaky legs and sweaty palms I got. I originally just planned to go up to the 350m floor, but after getting over the height and facing my fear head-on, I went to the 450m floor and embraced downtown Tokyo from a truly surreal vantage point. A must for any visitor to this great city!

Great view. It is worth the visit!. The highest tower you will be in Tokyo has an amazing view from the whole city. First deck 2060 yens (regular line) and 3000 fast track. If line is not that big, save some money. When you get to the first deck (350m) you have the option to pay an extra 1000 yens to get to the second deck at 450m. This second one is just another observation deck with no place to seat. Just higher windows to see the city.

Great view of tokyo. This is worth a visit as the views are amazing of Tokyo. However, at the weekends it's crowded...very crowded. So if you plan to visit at the weekend, my advice would be to book your time slot in advance. For same tickets, you have to first queue to get allocated a time and then join another queue to buy the ticket...before then finally joining a final queue for the lift...when you return at your allocated time! Alternatively, if you are foreign (so not a Japanese national), you can buy a fast ticket which allows you immediate access. There is a price difference (normal 2,060 JPY compared to 3,000 JPY) which is well worth it if you have time constraints. The other point worth noting is the above price is for the 350m level. You can pay another 1,000 JPY to go to the 450m level but my honest opinion is it's not worth it! The views are good enough at 350m.There is also a restaurant at almost 350m but we did not try that as it was out of my price range.
Ok to check out. I would recommend going over to Asahi since its free to go to the top floor. You'll need to grab a beer but the views are good and you can see the Skytree from up there.
awesome view of Tokyo. Feels like you are a god/creator in the Sim City games once you ascend to the top. Can see as far as Fujisan if the weather permits.

nice place to see around tokyo. If you wanna see tokyo city clearly (but sometime little bit foggy), you can go in the morning/afternoon. If you wanna see glamourous city light...go in the evening until night...;)Ticketing window for foreigner was the west side (for express line), but you have to show your passport. Little bit expensive, but worth it (you don't have to be stuck in line for hours)

A little too crowded at the weekend. Try to avoid going during the weekend. If you do go at the weekend, and are visiting from abroad, you can go to the International ticket desk to reduce the wait. The views are great. I'm a bit afraid of heights, but the elevator was very fast and smooth and I felt very safe up in the tower. The shops in the lower tower are neat.

Great way to see entire Tokyo below your feet but very busy. The waitingline (aprox. 1 hour) takes up more of your time then the actual visit. It is a fun way to see Tokyo below your feet but it might be a bit to high up to truly enjoy the city skyline. The Asahi Beer Tower, located next to the Skytree, is a cheaper way to enjoy the Tokyo skyline. It will cost you the price of a beer or soft drink but being lower (22th floor) the view is more stunning as you can see details better. From the Skytree most of the views are grey-ish.

An incredible view of the city lights!. We went at night and it was spectacular! The elevator up is so fast your ears pop, but so smooth you can barely tell you are moving. There was live entertainment at the observation level, a section with glass floor so you can see how high you really are, and for an additional fee, you can go even higher. We did not take that option as the view was already great. Well worth the trip, and I think not as crowded at night.

Spectacular view . Last month i was in Taipeh and visited the 101 tower. It was ok but i was not over exited. But my daughter insisted on doing so. So we went up with the fast pass. A bit more ecpensive but well worth as you had to wait otherwise 90 min longer. The view was spectacular. Mount fudji. The Tokyo bay and all its suburbs. Great. It was a bit weird that the fast pass did not work when going down....

Beautiful Views. I have been to Seattle Space Needle, Eiffel Tower and I have to say Skytree was the most spectacular! My husband and I went on the weekend. I would highly recommend not doing this, but if your husband cannot get off weekends from work you will probably pay the $80 necessary to express pass up. If you are not a visitor to the country than this option may not be available, but if you can show a passport from some where other than Japan you can purchase express tickets for both decks. The other line was an hour long from less expensive tickets. It was worth it to see top deck. Middle deck was very overcrowded.
Amazing view from the top. Great experience! The only drawback is that you'll probably have to wait quite a bit before being able to go on top.There's a lot of people there waiting for the elevators…

Crowded but amazing views. Having dined at the adjoining Solamachi Centre, we waltzed in at our booked time. We were packed into an elevator and taken hundreds of metres up. The floor was extremely crowded, despite visiting on a Thursday, yet the views were breathtaking of the entire Tokyo conurbation and we even (thought we) saw Mount Fuji! Prices were reasonable and the entire experience was great.

Breathtaking views. Tokyo from the sky looks really amazing. The floor at 350m is as crowded as many other similar high places worldwide (at least to those I've seen in NY, Chicago, Shanghai or Europe), but the floors below (345 and 340m) are way better. Unfortunately we could not spot Mt Fuji, although it was a pretty clear day, but we could see as far as Yokohama - actually there is a paper showing what one can see around in that day.Also, free wifi, available from the entrance line.Definitely to check out while in Tokyo.Recommended to go in late afternoon, for the sunset...

Amazing view of Tokyo A must place to visit for all tourist . Great overall experience . It's advisable to visit by 5pm so that one can see day and night view from the top. 2 levels of entry. It cost around 2060 yen for us to level of 350meters and additional 1030 yen for top level of 450 metres view. Open till 2100 hours for entry tickets and up to 2200 inside view. Ideal to travel by metro.

Beautiful!. Excellent place to visit if you want the full view of the city. I went at night so I could see all the lights. It's quite pricey and I'm still trying to decide if it's worth it. I think when in Japan everything is worth it but if you're on a tight budget, it's probably not for you.

Summer Festival and Bon Odori Dance. Every year, during the first week of August, there is a “Matsuri” or festival during which a traditional Bon Odori dance along with Taiko drums takes place right under Sky Tree, and visitors are free to join in as well. Upon hearing about this event, I attended this year and really enjoyed the event. It was nice to see lots of visitors learning the dance and participating as well.

How far can you see?. This is Tokyo's tallest structure, and the views from the two viewing galleries are breathtaking. (Not all that much more so from the higher gallery, but it seems a pity to miss it.) It's well organised - if you book a timed ticket in advance, you shouldn't have to queue for long. The downside is that you won't be able to predict the weather! In general, the views are best in winter, when the sky is clear and you have a good chance of seeing Mount Fuji. But even in summer you can usually see for miles and miles. Don't miss the section of glass floor with vertiginous views straight down beneath your feet!

Wayyyy UP!. I am actually afraid of heights.. but I had to do it! I was visiting my twin brother in Japan and he took me to quite a few attractions. I had to go to Tokyo! This was the most modern place we visited that is for sure. Kyoto was incredible! So much history! It was just fascinating! But back to the Skytree.... A lot of fun.. but it happened very quick! The elevators shoot you hundred of feet into the Sky and in seconds you're at the top! (Don't forget to plug your nose an blow when you get there). As you make your way around the top, there are panels with information describing what you are looking at through the window. Having a reference point was great. We could see Mount Fuji which was pretty awesome! Although it was a bit of an overcast, it was still slightly visible. The fact that we could see it was just so neat. There was a glass floor....yeah.. Freaky! I stood on it and it was such a fun time just getting over my fear. We were VERY high up! I'm not one to do many "touristy" type activities but I'm glad I got to see this view from atop the Skytree... From atop of Japan! Arigato twin, for the fun time.

Be prepared to queue up. The concept is quite smart. First you need to get a ticket with a time slot that determines when actually you can get to buy your ticket. In our case we had to wait for two hours, so what to do? Of course spend your time and money in the vast Skytree shopping mall. Then finally we could queue up to buy our ticket, and then up to the elevators to go down. It must be said: the view is amazing. But then again queue up for the way down. So in the end it took us more than halve a day for a short view over the city, even though it was an amazing view...
Family vacation trip to Tokyo ( Feb 2016). A magnificent view of Tokyo surrounding from the top deck. There was a long queue especially on weekend.

Up the sky tree. The sky tree gave great views over Tokyo however it could have been any city anywhere as there were no actual sites to see from the top just a sprawling city.It was said that part had a glass floor however this was just a few panels of glass that you could look through at the structure below. The lifts were impressive and travelled incredibly fast.Overall I'm glad I did it so I can say I did but I wouldn't bother to do it again.

Incredible views. There are many similar towers in the world and we've been up a few but this one beats most (only the iconic Eiffel Tower is better to my mind}. Being 450m above Tokyo, which you get to in a lift which peaks at a speed of 600km is pretty impressive. You understand the sheer size of this sprawling metropolis with skyscrapers clustered all over. It puts in perspective the geography of the city and also all you here about the size of the population. As with everywhere in Japan, despite the crowds, it runs with incredible efficiency. We went at 11am on a weekend so there were masses of people but foreign visitors with passports can go to a fast track queue where you don't have to wait for what could be hours for your turn to go up in the lift. There is a small additional premium of ¥400 per ticket for this privilege but it is well worth it. Tickets to go to the first level only at 350m are available but well worth the extra for 100m more. If you want to eat in the restaurant bookings are essential as it fills up quickly but worth it. A lot of other things to do in the precinct as well.

A Wonderful view of Tokyo !!! Do not miss it ! Take fast ticket.. We went there on a sunny day. You can take a fast ticket (special for tourist) and avoid a long wait in queue. The top reachable is at 450 meters, and the view is amazing.

One of the best views of Tokyo from over 1,400 feet. Great place to visit if you ever come to Tokyo. A view of Tokyo from their lookout at 450 meter (1,476 feet) is just stunning. Not recommended for anyone who has acrophobia though.
Awesome tower. This tower is really high, awesome tower. Beautiful view in the night. And also they have a small show on this tower. Recomended for visit and really worth it

Panoramic views of Tokyo. This is a relatively inexpensive (about $20 an adult) way to get a real sense of the expanse that is Tokyo as well as the numbers of waterways that run through it. We were lucky to visit on a clear day, when Mt. Fuji was in the distant background. The wait for tickets was about 30 minutes, but the line moved quickly. We then had to wait another 5 minutes to go up in the elevator. We only went to the 350 meter deck, as the 450 meter deck cost another $10 per person. One thing that surprised us was that it took about 20 minutes to descend from the viewing deck. Be advised that, when you take the escalator down to the next floor, there is no return. You then descend another floor via escalator to stand in line for the elevator that takes you back to the ground floor.

1,000,000 yen view. Visited on Monday morning 8.30am and it was nearly deserted, which made the 750 staff almost comically superfluous. I've visited space towers all over the world and this one is definitely in my top-3. The view is spectacular, windows are clean, space is well designed so you do not feel crowded. If you want, pay 1,000 yen more and go to 450m, see the extra ultraman exhibition and feel like you've got it all to yourselves.

Go on a sunny day!. Our experience wasn't the best because it became very cloudy when we were up at the tower, but it's all so well organised that one still gets to enjoy some of the views and have touchable screens to pla with the views and have a more fulfilling experience than just watch the views.Also, if you're travelling with kids they have a fun games of collecting badges (that even us adults ended up paying.. :) )

Nice view.. I went up this tower only because I stayed at a hotel close to the Sky tree. You get a really nice view over Tokyo when you choose to go the top off the tower. It's really cheap if you want to wait inline for 2-3 hours, otherwise it's 4000 yen to go to the top. You can choose if you want to go to 350 meters or 450 meters. The 450 is a 1000 yen more expensive and I think it's worth it. The Sky tree has a huge shopping arcade in the 1-6 floor. Take your time to check it out, it's worth it!.

Nice modern observation tower. It's an observation tower so you pretty much know what you're in for. Take a fast elevator to the top and enjoy fantastic views. Pay a bit more and go up to the even higher observatory. The facility is new, modern, and stylish. It is predictably filled with retail shops and places to eat.There is a glass floor you can stand on but it was fairly small and had a very intrusive double layer that took away from the effect in my opinion. Overall it is the best view in Tokyo and you will pay for that view, but I would say it is worth doing if you haven't done it before. After all, it is the tallest tower in the world.
nice tower and mall. nice tower and mallwith lovely entrance and fountains for kids to playthe mall is hugeincludesfood courtsalong to the aquarium the best is the lovely [passage

Great views of Tokyo. One of Tokyo's must do sights to see, great views with total 360.Try and avoid weekends and public holidays as it is generally very busy with long wait time.You travel 350 mtrs in 50 seconds in the elevator, so smooth.There are also plenty of shops, restaurants & bars next door

2nd tallest in the world. Loved it! Offers great views of the city.Foreigners are entitled to buy a fast pass to get in shorter queues which I totally recommend, worth every penny to save your time.And if you can afford it, go all the way up to the 450m level. It's fantastic' Has some nice shops and restaurants around which you can enjoy after.
