Excellent Views across the city!. We visited in early July and was very busy. Don't be put off by the queues though as it is well worth the wait. The views across Tokyo are spectacular and you are not rushed to leave. Just take your time to soak in all of the views from the various points around the viewing platform.

Great views and plenty of shops.. The location seems a bit out of the way if you are visiting the local shrine Senso-ji in Asakusa, but it's worth the trek. There are plenty of shopping options, there's a Pokemon center in there as well. You can actually go to the top of the tower, the cost varies depending on where you bought your ticket, expect to pay somewhere around ~3000 Yen. If that's not your thing, enjoy the view and get a drink at the bar that's at the terrace.

Second Tallest Building on Earth... What Else must I say. Go see it! Stand on the glass floor 340 meters above ground... stand on the observation deck 350 or 450 meters above ground. Shows Tokyo as far as the eye can see. You dont see Tokyo like this... real world observation of Tokyo is from street level or subway level... you want to see Tokyo from above? This is the way to do it. Period.

Most Unique Shopping. I was not planning to go tho the sky tree because it seemed out of the way. Wow, it was worth a trip on its own; we did enjoy Asausa nearby also. The skytree has many unique shops that are different from the rest of Tokyo (for example, one shop was making handmade candy sculpture when we were there; there is also a Totoro store, etc). We did not go up the skytree but rather enjoyed the food and the shopping.
Perfect view. The first deck at 350m provides a perfect view of Tokyo with its slanted windows! Highly recommended.

High price but worth it. I've been in several skyscrappers in Japan. This is a pretty beatiful one, but sorry to say, not the best. I'd have loved to go to the restaurant in the 345 F and then my experience would have been fullfilling. Anyway, is a must-see and you'll pay 1.800 Yen for something in Osaka costs 1.000.If here's a cloudy day or the contamination is heavy, you'll see nothing worth seeing.

Great views (on a clear day). Tokyo Skytree is classified as the tallest tower (not building though) in the world, and it certainly does tower over the rest of the Tokyo skyline. Visible from Asakusa and Ueno the Skytree is now a recognised part of Tokyo.Top tips: DO book your tickets ahead, this will save you 1-2 hour of queuing up to get your ticket!If you can early morning or evening visits are best as the view from Tokyo is often hazy. But it is still a great place to visit.

Good View from Above. To name a few world-renowned towers/buildings, say, Taipei, Hong Kong, Macau, Guangzhou, Dubai, Kuala Lumpur, Toronto, New York, Seattle, together with Tokyo Skytree which I just visited earlier this month, each of them has its own distinctive aspect of attraction. I was extremely impressed by the peaceful and orderly atmosphere at the public queues of the box office entrance there, and in the crowds on top the viewing platform floors as well. One would no doubt admire the pure Japanese style of simple and gentle etiquette shown in public.

Highest building in Japan. first stop after arrived, we went to Tokyo Skytree! The highest building in Japan. its so crowded and you can see all building getting smaller. its so hard to took a picture from the above.

Highest tower in Japan!. This is a must place to go to when you're in Japan as you can see the view of Tokyo. 350meter deck is the default, but with an additional low cost you can go to the 450meter deck (which we did).

Excellent way to see Tokio, day or night. I went to Tokio Skytree at afternoon and I went for the night to tale amazing photos of Tokio. It was a raining day but still was beautiful. The display of Astroman bring me good memories. A must to do in Tokio.

Extremely expensive and poor views. We went during a weekend. It was extremely crowded and we could not see anything; not because of people but because of the exhibits they had all over the windows. We paid extra to get to the higher part and it was the same. Not worth a single yen

Nice tower but nothing really special. Came here at night and I wasn't blown away by anything. The tower looks quite nice when lit up outside at night. Inside, you're dealing with long queues and nothing really spectacular awaits you at the top. Skytree is located quite some distance away from downtown Tokyo proper, so you end up not seeing much of the density of the urban skyline. The view is not the greatest and there's no outdoor observation deck. Some neat exhibits and random dances/performances happen though. But given its distance from everything else, I would have been fine skipping this on my trip. Some neat shopping in the area -- that's worth mentioning.

Amazing view and fun place to shop!. Although the wait was pretty long, the view at the top was totally worth it! Very polite and kind staff, and great photo opportunities. There is also really cute shops around the area as well. Wonderful place!

Fantastic view . At the 350 m platform you get a truely amazing view over this gigantic city. Well worth the money. Buying a ticket to the 450 m platform is not really necessary though, the view is just as good from the lower floor. I rekommendera going here in the late afternoon so you can sen the view both in daylight and darkness. On the bottom floors there are lots of resturants where you can have dinner after you've been up in the tower

Impeccable Service and Great View. We stayed at the Tobu Levant Hotel so visited the bar of the 24th floor to catch the view. The staff are great and it's a wonderful place to have a cocktail and admire the view. Prices are high but not exorbitant.
Shopping!. I bought a lot in Tokyo Skytree. If I'm not wrong, there's Disney Store that sells Disney Tsum Tsum, and disney merchandise! I also bought Tokyo Milk Cheese Factory here!

A bit of soylent green, perhaps, but a real treat. We went on a weekend which may account for the hordes of people at this mall and tower. But it was a fabulous time. As a foreigner, you can purchese (for a premium) tickets that get you to the top with almost no waiting. The views from up there are spectacular. And the facility is clean and modern and tasteful.
Great view. Modern tower in north Tokyo. Go with the extreme fast elevator to 350m, and again one level up to 450m. On clear days even with view to mnt. Fuji. But in most conditions worth wile.

Unique perspective. Having visited the Tokyo Government building earlier in the week for one view of the city Skytree this was a different experience and great view of the wider suburban sprawl. Unfortunately the haze didn't allow us to see out to Mt Fuji, which would of been good. They made that clear when we first went in the morning so we delayed the ascent until later in the evening when it cleared a little more. This was well worth the wait and made it a better viewing experience. It was relatively crowded but not uncomfortably so.The mall at the bottom was also good, a bit expensive but mostly in line with expectations for a key tourist attraction. It was easy to get their via subway and was close enough to other attractions to get a shrine visit in as well.Would be really good on a clear day but that's the breaks when your on a tight timeline.

There's a trick. There's a sneaky trick to avoiding the the usually huge lines to go up Skytree. If you go around the glassy front entrance, past the vending machines and lockers (or go up the escalators from the TV Character store), there's a little desk. At this desk, you can speed up the whole Skytree process. It will cost like 800 yen extra, but it allows you to join a sort of "Foreigners Only" quick line that gets you in, in my case, within 10 minutes into the lift going up to the main observation deck. Make sure you have your passport on you for this, cause you need proof of being a Foreigner. But 800 yen extra to save HOURS of wait time, I think is an okay trade off.

Great site to visit, even at night!. We went to the Skytree tower at night after walking from Askusa, and even at night, it was a cool place to go! Not only were there less crowds overall (in the ticket lines, on the top floors, etc.), it made for a more enjoyable experience. Sure, there were still a lot of people at night, but I can't imagine what it's like during the day when the line queues are super long! At night, you get the same great view with a more relaxed feel. There's a quick 10 minute dance show on the first major top floor that's pretty cool and fun to watch, albeit blaring lay loud, but still enjoyable. You can get a photo taken of yourself by their photos there and then buy it afterwards, but we decided not to and just enjoy the views. The gift shop up there is a perfect place to buy stuff that they say can't be bought on the ground floor. Overall, a must see place day or night. Just be prepared to wait when crowded. Oh, and they pack you in like sardines on the elevators going up!
Great views, great shopping . Had a lot of fun here. Unique shops, unique views and nice atmosphere.Definately go up to the 31st floor to see the city at night.

Great views, big fun. Thought this would just be a tourist trap but was surprised at how much fun it was to visit this attraction. The views are spectacular and the technology used to transport you from the ground floor to the top of the tower is incredible. In addition to the views,the experience of sharing this with so many people who have come from all over the world makes this experience even more enjoyable. Highly recommended!

Great place to look over Tokyo nightview. My friend in Japan and I went here at night, and have a fantastic beautiful nightview and Tokyo skytree. It is hard to describe the amazing feeling when you look at the nightview. Shall come here if you have time.
It is very beautiful and romantic. Remember to bring your love one here.

Great tower, but long queues and poor views. The newest and tallest free-standing tower in the world. Very long queues (1 hour plus) for the regular price of ¥2060 up to 350m level, in a fast 'shuttle' elevator with no views. A separate ticket for ¥1030 for must be purchased on at 350m to get to 450m, but this queue was short when I visited. International visitors with passport can use a separate entrance with a much shorter queue for ¥3000 for 350m and ¥4000 for both 'shuttles'. The higher-level elevator does have views. There were long queues for both lifts coming down, particularly from 345m to ground.Next to Oshiage metro train station (A20 on Asakusa line), the Skytree is easily reached from Narita airport (Access Express trains use the Narita Sky Access Line directly to/from Narita for ~¥1100, or US$10.50, on top of the 24-hour metro pass).Views from the top look promising but were practically non-existent when I visited due to smog.Bonus exhibition of 'Ultraman' for those familiar with the Japanese superhero.

Great views if it's a clear day. A little pricey (about $50 per person) to go up to the top floor. The first landing is $40, then another $10 to go to the top one. Tons of Ultraman things. Very clean, very efficient, like everything in Japan.

Awesome experience . Visited the Tokyo Skytree during our vacation. It's absolutely worth it. You can decide not to go to the top level and stay at the one at penultimate level. The super fast elevator is too good. The view from the top is breath taking. One can easily spend around 30 min here taking pictures , going through various videos available to watch and eating at the restaurants. The shopping complex at the bottom is also good to spend time.

Nice visit, well organized - but if it is cloudy you may not see much. The visit itself is very, very well organized. There are several things to do up top, like photo opportunities with figures, explanations of the views...but it was cloudy and we were not able to see many of the views.

Disappointing. The shutter offers a ride up to 350 or 450 meters to get a panoramic view of Tokyo. The view is OK although ours was marred by haze which limited distance. There main problem is cost and time and there incredible lines. Cost ranges from $20 at the shorter height to$30 at the higher height with a wait of 60-90 minutes in line. Pay an extra $10 and the line is shortened to 30-45 minutes. To go up to three to requires another $10 and a second elevator with a shorter wait. Coming down from 450 to 345 meters requires another 15 minute wait, but coming down from there takes another hour. All in all our party of five spent $200 and two and ones half hours using the express line. I liked these ideas of this attraction but it is not worth the investment in time. I will never be a repeat customer.

Good but too crowned. Tokyo sky tree is a tallest building in the modern era in Tokyo. However, you must spend time for queue for more than 45 mins, but go and back. This also has no historical landmark, and no interesting site except who love bird eye view.
Tokyo skytree. The tower is not that high, but it has a good view of the city and all the neighborhoods. Wait times were bad though, but that could be because it was busy season

Amazing Views from one of the tallest structures in the world!. This was a amazing experience for me! I love tall buildings, and getting to go up so high and see the views, was just so much fun. The elevator is a experience and then the views are just breathtaking. On a clear day, you can even see Mt Fuji and the whole city. Definitely recommend as a fun tourist activity, but it can get very busy. Try to get there early or at least buy your tickets in advance if you can. We waited about 20 mins to get the tickets and then another 20 for a elevator. But so worth it!

Loved!!. Get there early before the line starts! We got there shortly after it opened and only had to wait 15-20 minutes to buy our tickets. When we were done, the line was very long!! Anyways, We really enjoyed our visit here! Great views from the top! I bet it would be beautiful at night too!

Great Observatory . During mt stay in Tokyo I visited many observation decks, one of then being Tokyo Skytree. I saw the Skytree at night and during the day. There's an aquarium and Skytree Town all by the tower. The Town has lots of restaurants and places for souvenirs, but there are more restaurants then shops.
Breathtaking. Views from the top took my breath away, especially the night sceneries. A tat on the expensive side but worth the visit. Don't miss it!

Amazing Tokyo city night view. great city view. you can buy fast pass at peak hours. you can also buy advance pass to access higher floor. there may have a more excellent view. I just access the 350M floor.there is shopping center and aquarium under the skytree. you can find good foods, souvenior, many entertainment out there. if you like shopping, you can spend a day at skytree.

Fun place to visit with great views. We got there before 6 so it wasn't too busy but we hung around until it got dark to enjoy the night lights. It was a pretty smoggy day so we couldn't see as far as mt Fuji but the views were still pretty epic. Lots of interactive maps to learn about areas of Tokyo. There's also a glass floor that you can stand on and see right through to the ground. I found it terrifying but lots of people enjoyed it.
AMAZING VIEW. Visited on my second to last day in Tokyo. Such an amazing view, but I wish it was clearer when I visited, we could not see Mt. Fuji, so plan for the best day!
See the whole tokyo. You can basically see the whole Tokyo from this tower but there are not so many skyscraper. One japanese said it is because there are a lot of earthquake there

Great fun, great views. I way somewhat reticent about going to the Skytree - but my daughter wanted to go. It was quite a surprise. Tremendous structure to look at and the view from the two different observation decks were fantastic. You can really appreciate the great metropolis that is Tokyo. It was a beautiful day and the city looked crisp and clean. There was a little haze in the far distance so Mount Fuji and Hakone etc could be seen in outline but not with any clarity. The elevators were beautiful and you could look out and up as you traveled to your destination, The queues moved quickly, however, in hindsight we should have prepurchased our tickets on the web. The female staff were beautifully dressed and very friendly. It is worth looking at the animated digital streetscapes whilst waiting in the initial queues. Note, you do need to purchase a second ticket to move from the tembo deck at 350m to the Tembo Galleria at 450m. There are less people on this level, so it was worthwhile. It is also worth noting that there is some great shopping in the building, as well as a food court. We ended up patronising a number of stalls (rice crackers for my husband, clothing for my daughter and paper products/stationery for myself, as well as the obligatory Hello Kitty souvenir). Also had some great icecream and lunch. Allow plenty of time for shopping and browsing as well, There is also an aquarium. It was a fun day and I was really glad that I went. Highly recommended.

Beautiful view, lots of fun activities at the viewing area. Had been to Chicago and seen the view from Hancock tower, and was reluctant to go as I thought this would be more or less the same.But, although the view was similar, the neat setting of Tokyo could be appreciated, and more importantly for the kids, lots of fun activities were being held at the viewing deck.There were seats to sit and relax, and lots of snack parlors.Do visit, the ticket price is worth it.TIP: No need for express ticket, if you are going on a weekday, and not in the vacation-season. Waiting time is around 20-30 min, which goes off in a whoosh.

Review of the area around skytree. If you want to do some people watching and some shopping the area around the skytree is great. The mall like area was one of the few places where I could find good quality souvenirs. Its crowded as heck, but what place isnt in tokyo. Nice food court type area as well to try different foods without the sit down pressure.

Completely worth visiting. Long lineup in the beginning to go up the SkyTree but it's completely worth it. The staff are friendly and many of them are fluent in English. They are very open to questions and always try their best. The tickets are a little on the expensive side, but you won't regret going.The view is stunning and the sheer size of the building is breathtaking. It's an icon of a modern Japan and it can't be missed!

Great way to cap off our visit to Tokyo. Our trip started at the Tokyo Government Building during the morning. Four days later it ended at the Skytree at night. Perfect bookends to our trip in this amazing city. You see the Skytree from virtually everywhere you go in the city so you almost have to check it out!
Worth it, must see!. This is a must see when you visit Tokyo. I love the fact that I've been to the tallest tower in the world! You can see the Tokyo metropolis. What a view!

Nice place to start your visit to Tokyo. If you plan to visit Skytree it is highly recommended to arrive the in the early morning at least 30 minutes before the opening. Usually there will be a very long queue if you get late. Best scenarios can be enjoyed on a clear day. Ticket you buy at the entrance is valid only to visit 350m level. if you want to travel the top observatory at 450m you need to buy another ticket at the counter in 350m level.

Great views of the city. Great way to start off your time in Tokyo. We went here first and it was fun to see what we'd soon be traversing. Our first ice cream cones in Japan were sold at the top. Ice cream, unless specifically said other wise, is just that, iced cream. No flavour. Good though!

Great View. We went on a weekday at around mid afternoon and there wasn't many people there at all. There are two levels one at 350 mts and one at 450 mts. If you want to go to the top one you pay on the 350 mtr level. The day we went was a bit cloudy/smoggy so we could not see Mt Fuji but still a good view anyway. I thought it was worth it to pay the extra to go up to the top level. We had a guide for the day so we had no trouble finding it. The price for adults which includes both levels was about $50aud.

Amazing. This is definitely worth going to! The queue wasn't long at all for us, maybe 10 minutes, and we went there around 18 o'clock, just before the sun had set. The view was amazing, obviously. And not only that, they had a special performance ready called Wipe Up, which was a hologram, dance and musical performance. It was very well made and very fun. Two floors down they have the see-through floor, don't miss that one out!It wasn't even that expensive like everyone said. For university students it costed 2,000 yen, and for adults a little bit more.

Worlds second tallest building. The Tokyo Skytree is the worlds tallest structure and the worlds second tallest building behind the Burj Khalifa.It is expensive to go up but if you have made the effort to get there and made the effort to go to Tokyo in the first instance then do it. The views are great of this massive city an you can see for miles around.

The second highest tower of the world. The Sky Tree Tower is the highest tower of Japan and the second highest in the world being 634 metres tall. The observatory deck is 350 metres above the ground level and gives a panoramic view of the city. The tower attracts large number of visitors every day.

crowded and expensive. I went on weekend- day (Sat), the mall was super crowded, and by the time i got to the tower entrence 'I was told to wait 90 mintues (launch break-my bad, and typical 30mintues wait) and aprox. 2000yen entry fee. I could skip some wait for the more expensive ticket ~2800yen, but it was already too much for me.

Worth a visit and fantastic views from both observation decks.. Well worth a visit while you're in Tokyo. There's two observation floors. One at 350m and the other at 450m. A bit expensive to go all the way to the top but worth it. There'a glass floor section at the 350m deck. Also a cafe at the 350m deck serving some nice drinks and ice cream. Make sure you visit on a clear day. If there is a bit of wind they can close it down until it passes. Remember your camera as the views of Tokyo are stunning. Concrete as far as the eye can see. Amazing.

Truly amazing !. Wow !! What a view !! I had very little queueing time - like a few minutes ! It wasn't crowded at all as a thunderstorm was passing by. I couldn't believe how the view changed in the hour I was up there. It was quiet foggy when I first arrived, to big dark black clouds & to finish with sunset. No view of Fuji as the dark clouds were in the way. Totally worth the trip up - such a massive dense city !! Amazing !!

Tokyo with a view!. It was something I wasn't sure about doing as I knew it would just be a view of the city. However I decided to as I had such a beautiful clear day and I am happy I did! The view was breathtaking especially if you're not from a big city it's pretty spectacular. Since it was such a clear day you could see my Fuji too! Also it just shows how big Tokyo is. I really enjoyed it and as a tourist I paid a bit more for a fast pass ticket. It was about 500 jpy more but worth as you don't have to wait in the que. I didn't go to the top platform just the standard and felt it was enough as I wouldn't have stayed very long at the top and you have to pay more. There's things to do on the main platform, food and gift shops. If you have a crap day weather wise I wouldn't bother as you won't see much and it wouldn't be worth it.

Amazing . We came at the late afternoon on a weekday and had no long waiting time. Actually only 20 minutes. The sight is absolutely amazing and the money worth. If you lucky, you can watch a nice musical there too.

View of the concrete jungle. Well worth the long wait to get up there. With the Earthquake activity that this city has, it is quite the site to behold. Thousands of low storey buildings as far as the eye can see, with green spaces scattered throughout. Really makes you appreciate the magnitude of Tokyo. There is plenty to do and we visited during the daytime.

Really high, 634 meters!. I didn't realize til we got there that this was the tallest building in the world. It's huge. You can pay one price to go to the 350 meter floor. We paid extra to go up to the 450 meter floor. And I am glad we did, you can see Mount Fuji from that high. They also have windows in the floor so you can look straight down. A truly awesome sight.

Hours of fun!. I thought our visit to the skytree would be quick, but luckily my brother, who lives in Japan, knew to allot plenty of time! Though the price is steep, we went up to both the Tembo and highest observation levels. It was a little cloudy, but we still saw a lot of interesting views. The staff was very friendly and took many fun pictures for us. My favorite part, however, was visiting all the shops around the skytree (I think it's called Tokyo Solamachi?)! This is the perfect place to buy gifts, see what's trendy in Tokyo, and sample delicious snacks/treats. I only tore myself away reluctantly because we had to meet someone for dinner. Highly recommend checking it out! Try some cheesecake and buy some character moisturizing facial masks!

360 degrees view of Tokyo city. A short train ride from Asakusa. It's worth the effort.The views are incredible on a clear day! There's plenty of viewing platforms and room to move around. Take your time to soak it all in. There's lots of restaurants on the 6th floor before you leave.

You pay for the vertigo. Ever wanted to pay ¥2,060 for the dubious pleasure of being 350 meters high in a nation well known for tectonic activity? Then Tokyo Skytree is the place for you! Jesting aside, the view from this place is just..WOW. There is also a glass floor on the bottom level of the first observation deck if you enjoy staring into certain death. Wait I paid for this?
Great View. For forein turists you have a fast lane to skip the long line. Must pay a little more. I loved the view but in June you cant see Mt. Fuji.

very good way to see the city. once atop you realize how big of a city Tokyo is. I then googled it and not only is Tokyo the largest city in the world it is the largest city in the history of the world. great views. very impressive city and a great way to see it.

Impressive and very pricey views. My wife and I went to the Skytree half an hour before it closed. We read many reviews that when it is packed, the experience becomes less enjoyable. For us, there were only about 10 other people up on the observation deck. We rode the elevator alone to the top.So, if you like the views but don't like the crowds, go there just before closing time.The Tokyo Skytree is not in the center of Tokyo, so pretty much all you will see is the huge sprawl of buildings and houses. This had more a Los Angeles kind of feel and not a New York one. There are mid sized buildings and houses lined up as far you can see but not many tightly packed sky scrapers. It is impressive nonetheless, but on a different level.The tickets are quite pricey in my opinion. You will only spend about 30 - 45 minutes up there and the tickets will cost you about half of what a ticket to Disneyland will cost you.I don't regret going up there because seeing and experiencing anything from that high up is quite impressive. But I will admit that it wasn't as special as I envisioned it to be. There is something missing in the experience to make it special and I don't know what it is.
Very awsome!. I was there with my Girlfriend and had a very pleasant time. The view of Tokyo is impressive and the stares show was comical and fun!

See all of Tokyo. Great views even though it was a bit overcast and foggy. The interactive zoom map gave details about the surrounding areas which was interesting. Service and guides makes visiting very streamline and efficient. It was a good experience. Tickets costs approximately $25.00Aus each. Coffee on floor 350 was expensive - 2 coffees cost about $13.00 for two but then again coffee seems more expensive everywhere in Japan.

Great views of the Tokyo skyline.. The Tokyo Skytree Tower is the worlds largest free standing broadcasting tower standing at 634 metres tall.On a clear day you can see Mount Fuji from here. We went to the lower of the two observation decks on the advice of some locals, as the view from the higher one is going to be the same. pretty impressive structure from both the outside and the inside. The views from the observation deck are spectacular if your lucky enough to have a clear day. You can have an official souvenir photo taken as well, which thought was well worth doing. It has the usual gift shops and small food/drink places too. If your in this area of Tokyo you must pay a visit to this tower, it gives you a different perspective of the Tokyo skyline.
A must.. The view is stunning and you get a little feeling for the size of the city ! Everything vas very organised so even if there were crowds it was not any problem.

Breathtaking views. From my hotel room in Asakusa, I can see, towering in the distance at 634m, the Tokyo Sky Tree. A mere 5 minute walk from Oshiage station, you can’t get lost finding this giant needle in the haystack of Tokyo!The queue wasn’t too long, approx. 45-50 mins at 10am. Well worth the wait if the weather is clear, you can see as far as the elusive Mount Fuji.Far better views than Tokyo Tower, plan ahead for this one though (weather wise).

Ugh, OK. So we did it. This seemed like such a fun thing to do. But if you have a few options and you are weighing what to do--I would go elsewhere and have yourself an expensive dinner instead.We visited late morning and used the fast lane, which meant that we gladly paid an extra 800 yen on top of our individual ticket price of 2000 yen to speed past the long queue. So about 28 bucks apiece for the ticket. We waited about 15 minutes to get tickets and then another 15-20 to load the elevator..which was an experience. They packed so many people on the elevator that it wasn't safe. A lady literally cried out that she was afraid her baby would be squished as they packed is beyond sardine level. Once off the elevator we got the main observation deck. We did not purchase tickets to go further up. We didn't realize that once we left the main observation deck to go down to the two lower decks that we would essentially be standing in a line for the next hour to get back on the elevator for the return trip. So 28 bucks to be squished in an elevator and then about 15 minutes of viewing and then an hour in line to go down as we walked in line through the lower observation levels. Our son really liked the part where the floor was glass. The staff never used English even when talking directly to our family which I found odd in that they were conveying very long messages and apparently thought we understood. We we constantly encouraged to pack in lines as closely as possible. I just found that being a cow in a line for slaughtered wasn't very much fun. To be really honest the view was not all that appealing...Tokyo has the tallest tower but not much to see from it--the mountains are rarely viewable. It was a check mark off the list of tourist possibilities but that's about it.

A modern Engineering Marvel. This 600+ Meters monument was a great place to visit. Almost the whole of Tokyo was visible from this monument. This is today the highest monument on earth, but still I felt in terms of aristocracy, it is far below Eiffel Tower.

Good view but expensive. My take: The view is awesome but for a person like me who gets bored easily. This sight is only good for 15 mins. A few clicks and snaps and i am good to go. If you want to see the city lights of tokyo then go here at night.. they are open till 10 pm. The tower is about 450 floors. You need to pay more than 2k yen to get to the 350th floor and another 1.3k yen to get to the 450th floor. For me its day time robbery and there nothing much to do above except to see the view.How to get there: Theres a train going directly to the sky tree station just loom for it.

Fantastic views. Great views of the city and suburbs. you get a very good idea of how well spread out Tokyo is. there is an express system but I managed to go at lunchtime on a Thursday and it was pretty quiet. Underneath are great variety of shops and easy access to subway.

Great stuff on a clear day. I really enjoyed this. It was a busy Saturday when I visited so I paid for the express ticket. Made it quite expensive but boy the views are super. Tokyo looks great from above! The queue to come back down was long. If it is busy and you are claustrophobic you might find the lifts a little uncomfortable but the trip up and down is VERY quick. It was windy on the day I visited and you can feel the movement in the tower. The glass floor wasn't as exciting add others I've been in. Great visit. Recommended

Worth spending 3000 Yen. You can almost see anything from this place in Tokyo. Nice view from the top. Better to go this place than Tokyo tower. You can also buy souvenirs from the shops. Don't forget to watch animated cleaning on window. Must visit place if you are in Tokyo.

Awesome view!. The view from the top of Skytree is nothing short of astonishing on a clear day... Well worth the not-insignificant cost. But give it a pass if it is hazy out...Foreign tourists should look for the much shorter line set aside for them.

THE ＳＫＹ TREE. i visited with my friend last year. we spend the whole day ..we have a lunch there. till dinner. we rode and went at the top to see the views .around tokyo.it was really beautiful. especially the sky tree tower at night.it changes the

Get there early!. We got to the Sky Tree at 8:15am just after it opened and walked straight in. The staff were delightful. All dressed very smart, well organized and friendly. The space age elevator whisked us up to the 350th floor Tembo Deck observation level in seconds. The views were incredible, albeit disappointing initially as for the third time on our trip Mount Fuji alluded us because of haze. That aside this was a fascinating experience. After exploring all around the deck we paid to go up to the Tembo Galleria on the 450th floor. It was the same views just higher up but you've got to do it. The observation deck is another futurist design. It has a spiral ramp around the observation deck. The first thing that hits you coming out of the elevator is the enormous windows. The Sky Tree is the tallest building in Japan and second tallest structure in the world at 634 meters, second only to Dubai's Burj Khalifa. When we got down to terra firma the line was huge. So get there early!
Looks impressive. Tokyo Skytree was closed due to bad weather when we turned up but it did look impressive from the outside, especially with it lit up.
Beautiful . The view is amazing. We went on a hazy day and could still see a lot. If you go on a clear day you could see Mt. Fuji.

Good place to visit. I think it is a good place to visit for someone who like to go super high for a view.But its very crowded and if tou not purchase a fast track you could have to wait for 2hours to go up
Great views at the top. Very interesting tower. Huge shopping mall inside and once you get to the top there are some great views to be had.

Pricey, but worth it for the view!. We decided to opt for the Skytree over other free options that our hostel had flagged for us, simply because it was the tallest option and we needed to burn the yen we remaining before flying home the next day!Sitting at the bar in the Skytree, on our last night of 3 weeks in Japan, as the sun was setting. Pointing out all the places we'd visited in Tokyo far below. Spotting Fuji in the distance. I'd have paid the same again for it.Just don't expect to eat at the restaurant without a (well in advance) reservation. But you can find a deep fried Skytree to eat in a restaurant right back downstairs again anyway, so we weren't too disappointed.Don't miss out on the glass bottomed floor, before getting the lift back down again!

Amazing inside and out! Day and night!. I have viewed many aquariums in the world but the one inside the Skytree is magnificent! Being able to view the huge structural girders both inside and out keeps you in touch with the immensity of this piece of engineering.

Great Views. I didn’t originally plan on going up to the top of the Skytree but since we could spend a few extra bucks and use the Foreigner/Tourist line and skip the wait, we decided to do it. It’s basically the foreign tourist version of a FastPass at Disney. We waited on a separate line that was much shorter than the regular line. The ride up to the top in the elevator was fast and smooth – no jolts at all. The only thing that alerted us to how high we were going was our ears popping! Since the Skytree offers a 360 degree view of Tokyo, you walk around in a circle until you reach the section you want to see. Each section corresponds on the map to a part of Tokyo – I think section 7-9 provides a view of Mt. Fuji on a clear day. Unfortunately, it was cloudy and a bit misty the day we went so no Mt.Fuji in sight! We went around 5pm so we were able to see the sun almost setting. The view was really spectacular! Even though we were so high up, it didn’t feel like it was and therefore, people who are afraid of heights might not necessarily feel it so badly. Be sure to check out the Skytree Solamachi on your way down from the Skytree – there’s a lot of stores and delicious restaurants!

Whole day activity . If you can try to book tickets online to avoid long queues as there were thousands of people waiting in line just to buy tickets. Having said that, if you're a foreigner you can take the fast lane if you add another 8 euros (approx) to the normal fare. Why? If you want to buy the regular rate, you can wait up to 1-2 hours before you even get to the ticketing counter. You then have to wait to enter the lifts. We bought tickets at the fast lane counter and it took us about 20 minutes from the time we had the tickets to the time we got on the lift. So yes well worth the extra cash. To go al the way up, you'll have to add another 1000 yen (about) once you're on the 350 th floor. Shame you can't just buy the 2 tickets at once instead of having to queue again. Once up the tower, it's no different from any other tower in the world, only the panorama changes obviously:)! There's a little souvenir shop at the top but a much bigger one once you come down so probably not worth carrying bags with you during your visit. All the way at the top there's a 'Ultraman' museum and not much else. The whole visit lasted about 4-5 hours but we didn't shop around the mall and shops. We had to wait until late to have something to eat as there's no restaurants at the top (closed for lunch funny enough). Good day out but choose a day when it's clear outside to be bale to see Mount Fuji and other landmarks
Excellent trip up the Skytree. Went here on business trip sightseeing tour. Really enjoyable, went to stand on the glass floor where you can look down to the ground.Well worth a visit.

Ordinary but amazed about the queue culture. I would describe the Skytree observatory nothing different from other tall towers. However, the queue was very organized and staff spoke fluent English. The souvenir were well designed and creative. Restaurants and shops were also well selected, resembling good quality and characteristic. If you want to experience the Japanese modern culture, this is the place to come. Ps, kudos for fast skytree ticket! We spent only 15 min to get on the elevator, whereas the regular ticket holders had to wait in line for at least an hour. The fast pass costs only 800 yen more per adult.

Is it worth the money. Yes!! It is a marvel of human engineering from down below and top down. It is the tallest tower in the world. I wasn't expecting the glass floor so that was a nervous treat. When all said and done it is $20 in anyone's language. It is an absolute must see thrill. It is a great way to put the size of Tokyo into perspective. On a clear day you can see Mt Fuji so keep an eye out.

Expensive Entrance Ticket. I am not the kind of person who enjoy the street view very much. Have been Petronas Twin Tower in Malaysia, 101 Taipei and Tokyo Tower. Found all views are almost the same. Decided to go up Tokyo Skytree again was hoping to see the Mount Fuji. Unfortunately we hardly can see it during Spring/Summer time. If you are same with me, would advise no need to pay so much expensive ticket to go up to the tower. We took a lot of nice pictures of the tower downstairs. I would think that the ticket fees are very expensive. We just spent half an hour up there. That's all, nothing much. Not worthy it to pay so expensive tickets to go up to the tower.

So Tall!. It was a novelty going to the tallest building on the planet, but I'm starting to feel like "go to one building in a huge city and its all the same". Noteworthy is the super fast elevators. Also- I could feel it swaying; and I don't think I was imagining it because I don't have a fear of heights...though I did get vertigo in this building! I wanted mostly to see Mt Fuji but it was hiding. I hear it hides much of the time. We could only see the front range. But if you're in Tokyo, you should go there to get an idea just how massive the city is from a high view.

Breathtaking Views. Tokyo skytree was situated in a massive mall/entertainment complex. There was also several shops, an aquarium, and a planetarium. The tickets to up to the "tembo deck" cost around 20 dollars for adults and around 15 for high school students. Overall, the price was pretty high, but I feel it was still worth it. For the ticket, you got a comprehensive pamphlet that showed you exactly where to find landmarks and famous locations. You could stay up there as long as you want, but usually most are done after 1 - 3/2 of an hour. Definitely bring cameras, but nothing else Is really necessary. I really liked the view, the guides and environment, but the cost could be a bit lower

We didn't come here for the tower view.... as we had read it was expensive and underwhelming with long queues to go up to the top of the tower. But we did come here for the shopping in particular the official Studio Ghibli shop selling lots of Totoro goods...I was in cuteness overload and loved it. I ended up buying lots of gifts in here for myself and others. The food hall is also amazing and you'll get dazzled and if not seduced by the delicious displays of sweet food on offer...as we've discovered, the Japanese have a sweet tooth.
Fun with the family!. We went on a family trip with two young adult children. They enjoyed seeing how large Tokyo is. So well organized and a clean facility. Lots of staff and clean bathrooms!

A tower like any other... What is it with men and their fascination for tall towers? The Tokyo tower is just another one of the series that I have seen across the globe. Yes, it is a broadcasting tower. Yes, it has an observation devk and a cafe..but apart from that, it is a steel tower. Looks totally out of place in the neighbourhood of Sumida.No point coming to see it specially. If you are visiting this part of town, you will automatically see it.

Expensive and underwhelming. Went on a fairly clear day but I found the entire experience underwhelming. It is quite expensive and the lines are long. Even in the early evening, the entire viewing deck was packed with people. As Tokyo isn't a city of renowned architecture, there wasn't much of interest to see from the sky. I think the SkyTree is better enjoyed from the ground!

Skystruck!!!. Visited here alone before my tour commenced and had a lovely day, it was hot and the queues were long but the photo opportunities and the fabulous structure of the Tower made it worthwhile; everyone was so happy and friendly as the sun was shining. Pity you have to queue twice, once for the first section of the Tower and then again for the 2nd section but it is worth the wait - but get there early to miss the crowds and go to the top straight away. Then you have to queue again to get in the lifts to go down but the cherry blossom was out and it was a great experience, not included in my tour itinerary - maybe because it is expensive.

The tallest tower in the world with magnificent sightlines. This is a broadcast tower which also has two separate observation decks – each with a different fee, restaurants and photo opportunities galore. It’s a true 360 degree view of Tokyo and on a clear day – you can see Mt. Fuji. There is a separate line for foreign travelers if the place is very crowded. We expected to go in this line but a nice person said that the volume was low and we should just stand in the regular line since the wait was less than 15 seconds. The foreign traveler line allows you to bypass the big lines but it’s slightly more expensive. The tower was built in 2010 it rivals other observation towers like the Mori Tower and the Tokyo Tower. The Skytree has two observation levels, one at 1,150’ and the other a bit higher at 1480’. The higher is an additional cost but there are less people. There are plenty of photo opportunities and there are many displays which help you locate landmarks as you circle the path around. We came during the day but you can also come at night when the tower itself is lit up and you can see the landmarks and lights of the city.

panaromic views of tokyo. really beautiful , especially at night when its lit up. costs around 2000 yen to climb 350 mts which is really expensive .1000 yen to climb 150 yen.lots of crowd in the evening , but really worth d wait. sight from top is really beautiful .
Nice visit, view of Tokyo. Nice visit, good view of Tokyo, nothing special. Combine with a visit to the aquarium and meal in the shopping center.

Amazing views of Tokyo. The views of Tokyo are amazing but the elevator ride to the first viewing deck is impressive. The elevator moves incredibly quickly but yet you feel like you are hardly moving. There are 4 elevators that transport you to the first viewing deck and each elevator is decorated with one of the four seasons. We rode the spring elevator up and the winter elevator down, both were beautiful inside. We also opted in to ride up the upper viewing deck for an extra fee, that was worth it. The views were amazing and there were lots of great places to take pictures. Don't miss the glass floor on your way out.

Panoramic view of Taito . Went there on a weekday 8am, so it was quieter than usual. The views were decent (see pics) but this part of Tokyo doesn't have much historical architecture you can see from high up (due to WWII aerial bombings). Practically all you see are concrete buildings and no particular natural or artificial landscaping. (It was just around the start of cherry blossom season when I got to Japan, but as you can see from the pics there were no cherry blossoms to see in that part of town.)

Amazing views. We visited Tokyo Skytree on wednesday the 8th of June. Ticket fare to reach up to 350mts costed us 2040 JPY each.If you want to go 150mts higher have to pay 1030 JPY extra.The views are amazing and its reallly wortha visit.

Soar high in the sky over Tokyo.... Wonderful viewpoint to admire the extent of Tokyo Metropolitan area and on a bright sunny day you will be able to catch a glance of Mt. Fuji. Foreign visitors can queue up much faster with a premium ticket on the way up. Do visit and enjoy!

Really great skyline views with lots of viewing space!. We visited the SkyTree in March as part of a bus tour of the area. I wasn't too excited as I've visited other tall buildings in New York & expected the same thing. However, the SkyTree really does offer breathtaking views & Tokyo is such a beautiful city that it must be seen from above. There is ample space across both levels to take photos and watch the sunset. We didn't pay the extra for the top level but many others did. We had our photograph taken and purchased it for a decent price. The whole experience was enjoyable and the staff were very welcoming. As we left we had ice cream in Cold Stone on the ground floor & were treated to a song by the staff there. A lovely way to end the day.

Breathtaking Views from the Skytree. It was a breathtaking experience on top of the Tokyo Skytree. At 634 metres, this is the second tallest building in the world. Tourists can climb on the building at 2 levels, one at 350 metres and the other at 450 metres. There is an entry fee to the building but its worth every penny of it.The climb to 350 metres costs about 2500 Yen, an additional 1500 Yen would be needed for the climb upto 450 mts. Tickets are available for sale in the Fifth floor. There are some super fast escalators which carry visitors to the top in a matter of seconds. There are many staff members helping out tourists at designated places thus making the visit hassle free.The view from the top is superb with a 360 degree coverage of the Tokyo city and its adjoining areas like the bay area, the river and the high sky rises. If lucky, one can catch a glimpse of the Mount Fuji as well on a clear day.

Fantastic View. This is one of Tokyo's best spots to visit on a clear day. Try and check the weather before you go, because otherwise you will not get the full impact of how far you can see on a clear day. On a clear day you can see Mount Fuji which is approximately 82 miles away from Tokyo. The entrance cost is around $25.00 USD and there is an additional fee of about $10.00 for going up to a higher level. We went to the higher level and enjoyed it very much. Try and go as early as possible, to avoid the long lines. It also has a glass floor area (about 10' x 10') on the lower level, although it is not a very big. All in all, it is a very nice place to get a great view of Tokyo.

Stunning But Expensive View. We met some relatives staying near the Skytree and since none of us had gone up to see the view, we decided to go together. The lines (which must get long at times, judging by the numerous line dividers) were a little confusing - we tried to buy a ticket, but apparently it was the group line (our group didn't qualify as one) and were told something about an 800 yen discount. It turned out to be the daytime ticket, which is still over 2,000 yen per ticket. This ticket is good for the Tembo Deck, the 350 meter level; there is a separate ticket to go to the top level, the Tembo Galleria (450 m). A group was herded to crowd into a dark alcove (all of us were puzzled - were we already in the elevator?), and eventually, elevator doors opened in front of us and we moved forward. The very smooth and silent ride took seconds. In addition to the views, the Tembo Deck also has electronic displays that can zoom in to a particular area. I am not sure that the views would have much meaning for those who are not familiar with Tokyo and the surrounding regions; it is a bit far to see some of the more familiar tourist areas, and perhaps observatories or views from tall buildings closer to these areas would be more interesting, even if they don't approach the height of the Tembo Deck. The deck also has a cafe and a restaurant. A few levels down, there are two small areas that have glass floors. All in all, like they say about scaling Mt. Fuji, it was good to go once.
Spring visit is always awesome there. That place is good to see Tokyo from sky also it is crowded with schools students don't forget to visit the aquarium down there

Tallest building in Tokyo. Tokyo Skytree is the tallest building in Tokyo, with an observatory and restaurant at its higher levels overlooking downtown Tokyo, and a large shopping structure at lower levels. Expect long queues, however you could get a priority pass. There is a nice cafe at the top with a great view of Tokyo.

Wonderful evening visit. . Wife and I visited around sunset and it was absolutely beautiful. Tokyo becomes a sky full of it's own stars at night and it's totally worth the price of admission to see it from the sky. There are some souvenirs you can only find in the 345m shop so it might be best to wait to do your shopping up there. For any foreign visitors the express tickets are worth considering as even around 7pm the wait for regular ticket holders was around 30minutes and for express tickets it was only 5. A must see whether you visit during the day or at night. Don't miss this wonderful view of Tokyo.

For tourists but worth it. . Normally I like travelling to places off the beaten track on my own. This place was extremely busy, queues spanning down the road. Elevators (for which there are many) were packed and as an anxious person I found this quite difficult. The views once at the top were fantastic seeing all across Tokyo. On a good day you can see Fiji. Not a fan of the glass bottom floor!

It's tourists but totally worth it.. Usually I like to travel off the beaten path but this tourist attraction is worth its weight in gold. I went to the very top and spent the evening watching the sunset then drinking coffee. During my visit they had a star trek exhibit. Point being, go to the top, go all the way to the top, and watch that big beautiful sun set over mount Fiji as you fight the crowd for a spot to take a picture and sigh to yourself thinking "wow, I really made it." Because that is how you will feel.

breathtaking experience. We really enjoyed the visit to the Skytree. The elevators have a beautiful decor (each representing a season of the year) and the main deck has a great 360 view of the city. We got the tickets using Voyagin which was a bit expensive but allowed us to get the tickets for a specific day and time. We chose to visit during the night to see the city lighten up and it did not disappoint. The staff took pictures of us and were super polite and nice. We did not go to the next / highest deck since it had an extra charge and we were happy with the main deck view. I totally recommend to visit at least once since it is a great experience. We even saw a live show with a projection over the windows.

This Tallest Tower in the World is the Latest Icon of Tokyo!!. This is the tallest tower in the world and the latest icon of Tokyo. I now take most of my foreign friends, if it's sunny, but it's better to visit in the morning to avoid the crowds. From Tokyo station, you take the SkyTree Shuttle Bus directly to the SkyTree, or JR Sobu Line(underground) to Kinshicho and then Metro Hanzomon Line to Oshiage station. From Shinagawa, you take Keikyu /Toei subway Asakusa Line to Oshiage. From Asakusa, you take Tobu SkyTreee Line to Tokyo SkyTree station. After the SkyTree, it's nice to visit Senso-ji Temple, the other traditional icon of Asakusa, by walking or taking the Tobu SkyTree Line from Tokyo SkyTree station(one stop) to Asakusa.

Great view...and you can make a reservation. I enjoyed the views from Sky Tree. I was part of a group, so we made a reservation and totally avoided standing in line. As with most attractions in Tokyo...good to get there early before the crowds build.

Fast Elevator to Great View. The superfast elevator with interesting decor made the trip to the top very brief. The tower has a couple of floors for you to enjoy the view from. The interactive panels were also a good feature. The vinegar inspired drinks and ice-cream served at the refreshment bar were not to my palate. The tower's lower observatory level also features a glass bottom floor. Overall an enjoyable experience, a pity that it was slightly foggy on the day.

Looking down from Skytree is like looking down at a different world.. One thing I do in every city I visit is "hit the top of a tall building". I did that in Tokyo, by visiting Tokyo Skytree. Mind you, I was staying at the Park Hyatt, which is also one of the tallest buildings in Tokyo, but the view from here was breath-taking. The shape of it allows you to virtually look straight down, which not many towers and spires allow you to do. I got some PHENOMENAL photos from up there of all parts of Tokyo and surrounding areas.When you enter Skytree, you will see a LOT of people. I'm not sure why, but there was no line for the top if we paid about 800 Yen extra each... which was well worth the 1-2hr wait for all of the other people. ALWAYS look for a faster way to the top.Other than that, it was a typical tourist trap, but a good one. Tokyo is a breeze when it comes to mass transit, so getting here isn't hard as long as you have a decent Subway map. It took about 35 minutes to get here from Shinjuku.

Don't miss it. . I went in late afternoon on a cloudy day hoping to see some color at sunset. Was not dissapointed. Had a beer and snack with a 1000 foot view in front of me. Then went to the upper area for sunset. I stayed well over two hours.

mall with quaint stores. got tired of big department stores and so this mall was a breath of fresh air. The stores were conveniently located along the corridors of the mall and each had goods that would interest both tourists and locals alike. Foodies would enjoy the varieties of food choices in the area, during our visit there was actually an international beer festival held in the open area of the mall. All in all a nice experience for the family.

Must see. Visited the site on day-time. The building is huge & imposing, the surroundings & the shops inside the skytree very interesting. A very nice place to spend a morning.It is consedered one of the greatest tourist attractions of Tokyo and I would recommend too!

Astounding. The employees, service, exterior and interior structure were breathtaking. I would definitely recommend visiting if you are on holiday. The only problem was accessing the building when you only have a JR Pass! I ended up walking most of the way which sucks because you'd think that the location would be easily accessible for tourists! Regardless, everything about the skytree itself was beautiful , even the elevators! Once you arrive to the observation deck, you are greeted by dancers and a small show which really puts a smile on your dial. I visited on my last day before I left the country which was a wonderful way to say goodbye!

Mind blowing....though I'm scared of heights. We visited Asakusa Street and could see the Skytree so I figured we could walk there...until our friend pointed out it was kilometers away....we took a train and when we got there it was HUGE....I was very wary about the height and tense as the elevator whizzed us up. With some reservation I stepped out of the elevator then was mesmerised by the incredible evening view over Tokyo....The lights stretched to the horizon and we walked slowly around the deck trying to take it all in...I found I was able stand at the edge (and hang onto the handrail) and take photos, totally surreal though I wasn't able to go too close to the glass floor looking down the 1000 feet to the ground.We found the cafe and a table next the window and stared and stared over a coffee and cake.....Next time I'll go up the extra 300 feet to the top deck!

Awesome view, decent value. Have been to Tokyo a few times since the Skytree opened, but 2016 was my first visit. Certainly an impressive view of the Tokyo area. Really good if you can go on a clear day. Value for money wise, it's ok but it's not the cheapest. Would still recommend it for a once off visit.
My favourite Spot in Tokyo!. Excellent panoramic view of Tokyo! I could also see the Mount Fuji from there! Very friendly staff and definitely worth every cent spent.

First time in Tokyo. We enjoyed this area very much, the shops are unique and all the restaurants have a big verity of specialty goods.
Our family enjoyed the trip to the Tokyo Skytree.
My favorite visit in tokyo. Really love this attraction is just amazing being in one of the highest and tallest structure in the world

Not bad. The sky stree is an awesome spot to visit but I recommend to save your money and stay on the first level, the top area is nowhere as nice specially during a cloudy day since the tower is so high up that the clouds can easily block the view of the city.

Free deck on 30th and 31st floor. Really enjoyed the mall area of skytree, the restaurants and the food court (lots of free dessert samples handed out - yum). We went to the 30th floor to check out the view and grab a drink/snack. Lovely view of the city. There is a free observation window area on both the 30th and 31st floors if, like me, you don't want to pay to yen to visit the top floors of skytree but still want a nice view.

Spectacular views . Spectacular views from the Skytree. We only went to the first level. It costs more to go to the highest level. If you are a foreigner you can skip the 60-90 minute wait. They have an express lane for non Japanese visitors. . Try to go on an exceptionally clear day so you have the potential to see Mt Fuji. We had a sunny day but it was hot and hazy so could not see it.

Ok. Went with family I hadn't seen in about 20 years and some I had not yet met. Went at sunset so it was quite nice but view is all a little hazy. Probably nicer once it got dark.Overall the place was packed with people but shopping-wise there's probably something for everyone. Hard to restrain.
A Must Go. Sky view of Tokyo is simply gorgeous! 4th Floor of Sky Tree is a nice place for you to buy souvenir and snacks.

Good rainy day option for the shopping - not the view. Difficult place to rate. I didn't climb the tower because the weather was awful, but the shopping and souvenirs downstairs were actually worth coming for. The food court is quite nice and there is plenty to do and see. A good rainy day option if you're in Tokyo for more than 5 or 6 days. Also great for families. The suburb is a bit quiet and there isn't too much to do, but the whole complex is built directly above the train station. Easy to do and see, but probably not for everyone. I'm sure the view is stunning on a clear day. About a 30 minute walk to Asakusa

A must but not amazing. It's the symbol of the new japan, meaning: is the new "Tokyo Tower". Is one of the most crowded attractions so it would take like a couple of hours to get to the top. But if you enjoy taking sky view pictures, this is your place.

The Great. I have ever been there twice but it is the first time that I can went up to the top of Japan.It was very appreciated that I can stay and stand on the top ten highest tower in this world.I can look around Tokyo city at there.If you can visit there please do not miss to go up to the top of this tower.

great views but botherso. We liked the views frol 400+ m hight, this is a unique experience and panorama. It is victim of its success however and queing for almost 1 hour several times is not woth it. Maybe a good time without crowds is possible; to be inestigated.

Worth it at Least Once. Aloha everyone, After many visits to Tokyo, I finally went to the Skytree about a year ago. After three subsequent visits to the Skytree, I figure it's time for a review. The Skytree is accessible by Tokyo Metro or by the Keiyu Skytree Line. The Skytree line costs about $1.50 from the Asakusa Station. The Pasmo or Suica cards will get you there too. The Skytree complex is fairly large, with plenty of shops and restaurants, including McDonalds for some cheap eats (try the Ebi [shrimp] Filet!). Ticket lines for the Skytree are long but do move briskly. Tickets are roughly $25 and an extra $10 for the upper level. They do take credit cards. The lines for the elevators are long but also move quickly too. Probably takes about 20-25 minutes from queuing to arriving at the first viewing level. I have purchased the additional ticket to go up to the highest (second) level, but I've found that the first level is plenty fine and the views are great. Do find the Plexiglass floor and stand over the open view about 1000 feet below. Freaky, slightly unnerving, but cool. It takes about 20-30 minutes to get your fill of the Tokyo horizons and then it's time to go. Very worth it, slightly better than the Tokyo Radio Tower, but they're both good. I'd definitely recommend a visit if you have time, but if you're pressed for time, stay on the ground and see the sights from there. Aloha!

Most impressive view is from the street level looking up!. We went on a Thursday in May around noon, it was crowded but not bad, the ticket line was about 5 to 10 minutes and the elevator wait was about 15 minutes. The views are amazing even though it was cloudy, but we could not see Mt Fuji. If you want to see that, go on a clear day if you can time it. There are a lot of restaurants and gourmet food shops in the basement so don't fret about not having food options if you don't use the cafe at the top. Lastly, if you are traveling on a JR Pass, you can get all the way to Kinshicho Station using the JR Pass, which is just one station away, then you can take a subway for one stop to Oshiage Station for 170 yen, then walk to the SkyTree from there.

Sky's the limit. A money tree for Tokyo. There are so many tour groups that visit each day, the place is always throbbing.Instead of the standard ticket, you may wish to go for the foreigner ticket which helps you jump the tour group queue.At 350 we went straight up to 450 and spent most of our time there before coming back to 345 and going up to 350 again. and then down to 340 for the lift down. A bit confusing, but it all makes sense once you're up there.A must see when in Tokyo, really great views and very well organized. Good souvenirs too.

An amazing experience for city lovers. Tokyo is one of the most impressive cities, especially if you are a concrete and glass fanatic like I am. The Sky Tree has two observational decks that offer a fantastic view of the whole city from two different altitudes. I recommend going to this venue on the last day of your trip, as you might find it pleasurable to recognize the places you've been to from above. The attraction offers a few cafeterias and gift shops, a pop-up photo souvenir for a few yen and an interactive map containing the names of all the observable buildings, but the most memorable thing is the view itself.

Great views over priced.. I thought the views of Tokyo were outstanding but the tickets were really expensive. On the observation deck the staff tried toSell other stuff to the tourists. I would not go again

Expensive worth a visit. The view offered by Tokyo Skytree cant be compared to any other building or tower at Tokyo. At 340m there is a glass floor for having a glimpse of height from ground directly under your feet.Luckily the day I went was a clear sunny day and it did offer spectacular views of Tokyo city. Rainy day would limit the visibility.For a normal ticket the wait time can go upto 1 hr+ but there is an option of Fast track ticket which gets you into the tower within 20 mins. It is expensive with fast track ticket but worth the view.

Felt a bit like cattle but good view . Too many people per slot. Made you feel like cattle being rammed in. Difficult to get a good view just to the large amount of people there. When we eventually managed to get close enough to a window to see, the view was amazing! I should think it is for how much entry costs! Being up that high makes you appreciate how big Tokyo is.
Good to say you've been. I've been here. Was it anything that I would list at the top of my list in the future - probably not.

Tickets are expensive but worth it. Relatively, Tokyo skytree is expensive as compared to metropolitan tower where you dont pay to get the view. However, the shops, amenities, staff service and other features make the experience worth it.
If you are willing to pay extra, i suggest to make this part of your itinerary in Tokyo.

Nice view, but the hype is overrated. On one day, we tried to just get there and buy tickets to go up. As there were a lot of people there, we were told to get in line to purchase tickets for an entrance in 2.5 hrs.We then asked, if we could buy tickets for the next day and were send to the 7eleven.At first, we couldn't find the 7eleven and asked around in the lower floor at ticket counters and so on. On the last one, some tourist ticket booking company, they told us that we can go back up (to where we started) as asked for a quick pass which can be handled to foreign tourist. Well, at least that's what I understood. And on the website, you cannot buy any tickets as foreigner (you would need a Japanese credit card I believe from what has been translated by google translate).After some walking around, we found the 7eleven. They have a ticketing machine, but you can only buy tickets for the Skytree, when the language is set to Japanese. Unfortunately, there were some people in the store and the lady had to leave us to get back to the cashier.After clicking around, we were stuck and had to bother the lady again. At the end, we needed to write our names in Japanese to get a voucher, that we had to pay to receive some temporary tickets with a timeslot for the next day.Next day: Everything went well with our prepurchased tickets. No waiting line, we could just get in. It was a good idea to get there at 10 AM, so all the viewing decks were not too busy.The view was nice, but then, the day before, we went to the "World Trade Center Japan", paid some 600 yen and the view was much better.With this experience, we found the Sky tree as overrated. But then, when in Tokyo, this seems to be a thing to be done.But be prepared to get the tickets beforehand.

Phenomenal views. Not very expensive, and a great view of Tokyo. In true Japanese style there are monitors around the top floor that let you zoom in on areas you can see from the top and get info and history on that area / building which is great. There are staged photo opportunities, shop, restaurant and cafe and a glass floor which even though I knew it was completely safe still made me legs go! For the £15 it cost me, it was well worth it, and if I returned with the kids, I'd do the aquarium and Asakusa as well. A good day's itinerary.
Fast and enjoyable. To see Tokyo from above, this is surely the best place. The queue was none exicting, so we spend our time to see the city.

Nice view but crowded. They have 2 different ticket type. If you want cheaper. They have ticket for allocated time. If the more expensive ticket you can go up on the spot. Queue was massive.Up there.it was pretty crowded. Need to be patient to get to the front to see the view. If you want to go higher it's extra cost.Around the tower there's shopping center too.

Honest review. Was worthwhile doing, however thought it was expensive for what it is and then to have to pay extra to go up further. Queues are long so worthwhile fast tracking and paying extra or booking advance.

A little disappointing . A friend recommended the sky tree, the tickets are quite expensive but we were looking forward to seeing the view of Tokyo. We visited on quite a cloudy day so the view wasn't that clear. It was very busy when we visited and at times you couldn't even get to see the view there were so many people. I think this would have been a better view at night but unless it's a very clear day I wouldn't bother.

Beautiful view of the city from the top. Very beautiful view on a good day. The ride up to the top was really fast and the lift was nicely decorated as well. The personnel were orderly and helpful in directions and there were plenty of space to walk around even though it is packed. Always opt for the express lane for tourists as the regular queue takes at least 3 hours. The express lane was another extra few hundred yen. Worth the money. The view does not disappoint. It can be a romantic spot for viewing the sunset.

Visiting Skytree Across the Lake. Our Japan tour stopped to view the Skytree across from the lake, which was a park. Some cherry blossoms were blooming and some were having a picnic, sitting on tarp since there was no grass.

Tall tower, long line. Waited about an hour to get up here (it was a weekend) but it was probably not worth waiting much longer than that. Nice enough view from the regular deck that we didn't feel the need to go up to the top level or whatever they call it. VERY CROWDED! Don't bother with the gift shop in the tower, they have a bigger one with the same stuff at the base.

Wonderful place & very impressive service. Our Tokyo trip of five days was fully packed and Skytree was not originally included in the schedule. We were keen to visit but was dampened to read that online bookings close before 4 days and bookings at 7/11 joints also fully booked. We took a chance to try at the place.We were pleasantly delighted to learn that there is a fast track line for foreigners and available at short notice. We were amazed to get entry in half a hour !The service and courtesy are seen to be believed, far beyond even Japanese standards!

Amazing Views and Worth the Trip. Amazing views and a must visit if you are in Tokyo for the 1st time. We came here first thing in the morning when they opened at 8am. There was no line at all for tickets and was a quick elevator ride to the top. Once at the top it was just a handful of people. We were here on a relatively clear day and took some amazing pictures. It is a full 360 degree view of Tokyo. They also have a glass floor, gift shop and a snack bar at the top.

It's ok. Bring your passport so you can buy the express pass and skip the huge lines on the way up. There is no express line on the way down though. Once up there I thought that it was quite small, took about 10min to walk around. It was an ok experience. Wouldn't go back.

Total Blast. I love heights! If you are also into it, you will definitely love the way to the top!The elevator ride will take you to the highest point in just a few seconds.The view from the top is absolutely amazing and breath taking. The Star Wars theme made the experience even more memorable. Hope on my next visit it would be during night time. Looking forward to it already!

Beautiful in the evening. We took a trip to the tower during the evening around 8pm. The gigantic city of Tokyo looks beautiful from above. There is a show which was quite funny to watch. I would recommend going to the second stage (450m) as well, much less people and more time to look around!
Great view!. A must do when visiting Tokyo, the line is usually very long but they do get people through quite quickly. You can book online to be able to get in that little bit quicker.

Amazing experience. The view from the Tokyo Skytree Tower was absolutely amazing during the day time. At sunset the views were even more amazing as the bridges and buildings began lighting up. There was a glass floor below the viewing deck which was fun to walk over and see below. There were also shops at the bottom of the tower which had interesting food, items and souvenirs to buy. There were also restaurants, cafes and fast food places to buy meals. It was an amazing experience :)

This was just Awesome. If you like tall towers and views to infinity you'll love Skytree. Going up in the elevator was a thrill in itself as it blasts up hundreds of floors in literally a few seconds. At the top it is a bit cramped and the viewing windows can be heavily used as a lot of the space up there is set aside for cafes. If you are a tower fan, it is worth paying the extra to go to very top where the viewing areas are much, much better. A tip for foreign visitors - ignore the main entrance and use the VIP entrance for foreign visitors which is a bit further round from the main entrance and you will avoid all the queues. It is expensive but well worth it as a once in a lifetime chance to visit this incredible building. Easy to reach by public transport. At that height the building can sway a little bit which does feel rather odd at first.

They need to improve their tourist guiding. The Tokyo SkyTree has become an iconic town that draws thousands of visitors.When we visited, it was packed with young bubbly locals due to an exhibition of some of their favorite cartoon characters that seem to have become and artform in Japan.The views are terrific but what troubled us, as we gazed through the huge windows at the panoramic views, was the total lack of information or pointers about what we were looking at!Maybe Tokyo is a massive metropolis with thousands of anonymous buildings and too few focal points on interests but it would have been nice, even instructive, if at each window there would have been a panel pointing out points of interest.The cost of the visit was 2060 Yen.In short, we came, we saw, and left feeling we hadn't seen anything!Pity!

Afraid of heights. I didn't want to go up into the sky tree-my family talked me into it. I'm so glad I did-it was a great experience. The elevator takes you to the top in under a minute and all I felt was my ears popping as we flew upward. The views are phenomenal-I saw it at night and you could see for miles.

Higher point of view on Tokyo. On of the numerous photo spot of Tokyo, certainly one of the higher. To reach the top, you have to pay access to the first plateform (350m), then, if you wish to go higher buy a ticket to the top floor (450m).

Views and people watching. This tower offers great views of greater Tokyo, and it's also fun to watch the (mostly Japanese) tourists and school groups going through it. If you have your foreign passport with you, you can pay a bit more and bypass the sometimes lengthy line. It's also connected to quite a complex of shops and restaurants.

Tall towers are always worth a visit. The highest building in Tokyo built to resist earthquakes gives you a panoramic view of this awesome city, with refreshments available on the main stop off try the 'blueberry vinegar' it's much more refreshing and tasty than it sounds. Book in advance to avoid massive queues. A colourful stained glass window accompanies you in the lift one the way up and down. Glass see through flooring allows you to take a long look down. And of course it's air conditioned

Lines, and Some Lines. Also. Lines. . On the one hand, the SkyTree does offer great views of Tokyo, but of course it does. It's a tall tower. Basically my wife and I found it to be not worth the money, as it's obviously crowded, but we did not expect lines at the top to go down a floor for things like the glass floor. Also a disappointment as it was crowded, and small. Basically enjoy views from the plane, or on the ground. Or hotel bars.

Amazing. The fast access Skytree ticket is worth it if you don't want to stand in line for a while. But it does add to the cost of the experience. If you are going any way, might as well go up to the top into the Tembo Galleria.

Definitely worth the visit. International travellers can avoid the queue if there is one by entering the ticketing area via a different door (see the signs). There was no queues longer than a couple of minutes however when we went. We went in at 16.30 in order to see the view in the daylight, dusk and nighttime.
