After purchasing a ticket (approx 2400 pp) a huge lift takes you to the 350th floor, the floors must be very small however or by floor do they mean metres?However, great view over the whole of Tokyo including Fuji if the weather is favourable.Take the escalator down one or two floors from the main viewing floor as it is quieter and there are a few seats.You can get another ticket for approx 1200pp to go higher again but I don't think this is necessary.

If all you want is a view, go to Tokyo Tower instead!. Yes, the views from the Skytree are amazing (we did not go to the top, just the main deck). The lines were LONG so either buy your tickets in advance (we saw a line for people who pre-purchased, we did not and the regular line was going to be 40-60 minutes) or purchase tickets from the express line, it was more expensive (only about $8USD more though, if I remember correctly, so totally worth it) and we were escorted to the front of the line and it took only about 5 minutes. (Ask for directions to where to buy tickets for the express line, it was a bit tricky to find.) Once on the main deck, you had to wait in the regular line to go to the very top (and pay more), so we did not do that and can't comment about the views up there.The main observation deck was very nice. Clearly it was built to provide guests with good views. But it was very crowded!Prior to visiting the Skytree, we were at Tokyo Tower (we basically went there by mistake). In all honesty, we had not originally planned to visit the Skytree (and definitely not Tokyo Tower), but it was such a beautiful day we decided to go up a tower for a view. I asked for directions to Tokyo Tower when I was wanting the Skytree. Anyway, since we were at the Tower, we went up. There were no lines, and we went all the way up to the top (had to buy extra ticket) but the views were beautiful, it was cheaper, and you didn't have to deal with the lines (which were 40-60 minutes long)! We would recommend the Tower over the Skytree, unless you just "have to" see the Skytree.

Great views, terrible queues!. Yes the Skytree offers great views of the city from literally new heights. No denying it.However, the biggest problem is in a way its own success and that it gets very busy. You will have to queue for everything. Even if you have an advance ticket you will still queue. You queue for tickets. You queue for security. You queue to go up in the lifts. You queue to go down in the lifts. Of the 3 hours we spent there we easily spent 2 of these queuing.The other slight issue is that although it offers 360 degree views, some of the 360 degrees are occupied by shops and cafes and photo-ops, so if you want to see better from those areas you need to spend more money.Certainly go for the views, but be aware its an expensive day and you *will* spend a lot of it queuing unless you find a way to miss the usual crowds.

I try to stay off the beaten path - but, sometimes you just have to do the tourist thing.. I try to stay off the beaten path - but, sometimes you just have to do the tourist thing. Pay the extra money and buy the tourist ticket and cut your wait in-line and go all the way to the top! BTW - The World Beer Museum is nearby!

Save your money!. Total bore. Yes, the views were spectacular, but you spend 2 hours + in a slow moving queue the whole way round. There are several other places to get a good view of Tokyo and for much cheaper too. Unless you don't mind slow queues, spend your money elsewhere.

Visit in the mist. During our visit to Skytree at night time by late April this year, we were disappointed because the weather was poor, misty with light rain and we could not see much during our stay there. Only 4 of us purchased the tickets to go up that time. Anyway it was a good experience to climb up the 634M high tower despite that we could not have breath-taking views up the Tembo Gallaria on 34F this time. For new comers, do purchase the entrance ticket on 4/F level and see the queue there to match your time constraints in good weather.

Stunning views across Tokyo. Well worth a visit up to the first observation deck. You can pay extra to go even higher, but no need as this is plenty high enough. On a clear day you get 360 deg breathtaking views of Tokyo and great photo opportunities. A must see, if you are ever in Tokyo.

Definitely worth a visit. Tokyo Sky Tree which inaugrated in 2012 as the world’s tallest ‘free-standing tower’ at 634m, is a must visit in Tokyo. Get yourself the entry ticket from the 4th floor and step into the super fast elevator! There are two observation decks, at 350m and 450m. We visited the tower at night and we are in awe of the panoramic view of dazzling, lit up Tokyo city!Don’t miss the small section of glass tiles, where you can see right down *dizzzzy*. Make sure you take a picture, where the staff will happily click a picture of you with your camera (for free) and with theirs (at a cost)! Once you’re done, shop for some keepsakes, have a meal or simple lounge around at the ground level.

Worth visiting at least once. It is high, indeed. But It was a pity I didn’t enjoy breath-taking views asit was cloudy.The view from the glass floor was still really scary though. The way of taking care of a huge number of visitors was very well organised. I was too late to buy a ticket online and I expected I might not be able to enter or have to wait in a long que, but the numbered ticketing worked so well that I could spend the time enjoying shopping in the shopping mall nearby. So don’t worry even though you fail to get tickets online just go there a couple of hours before the time you enter the tower then you will be ok.

Spectacular. A great attraction if you like to see things from a birds view. I visited the tower on a foggy day so I could see Mt Fuji. But you can really see how big Tokyo is. i went there around 11am and there was no queues at all. The elevator to the first viewing point had a speed of 600m/min but you could feel it started or stopped at all. A must do in Tokyo due to the hight. Recommended in good weather conditions.

wonderful design. A huge tower, the second highest building in the world. Panorama of the city from 450m is great. Of course the view from Tokyo Tower is great too.Tokyo is the city ​​without skyscrapers so the view of the city without end is amazing. If you dont want to stand in a long queue, go there in the evening to fast track. Tickets are little bit more expensive but you dont loose lots of time.

Once was enough for me. You certainly don't want to miss it because it is one of Tokyo's biggest attractions but once was enough for me. I mostly went because I wanted to experience the elevators which takes you to the viewing platform. It is incredibly fast, very beautiful inside and surprisingly didn't make my ears pop. It definitely allows for a very panoramic view of Tokyo but unfortunately we went on a slightly hazy day so couldn't see Mt. Fuji or even all of Tokyo. Maybe it would have been a prettier sight at night. It is expensive with the fare to the first viewing platform at about $20 and additional $10 to go to the top. If I were being honest, I would just be happy with Tokyo Tower though the shopping/restaurant complex underneath Skytree is well worth the visit.

One of the greatest view all around to the city!. Went here with my classmates around early spring of 2015. It is about a 10 or 15 minutes walk from the asakusa shopping center and offers a great sorrounding views to several of Tokyo's wards. Went during the day time when the day and sky are clear versus after monsoon season when humidity can cover the panorama. This venue is a must along side Tokyo tower and the Government building in Shinjuku.

Great view. View from the sky deck was not disappointing, captured the sunset over Mount Fuji. Unfortunately we were not allowed to take tripods onto the sky deck. We also purchased tickets for entrance for Roppongi Hills and the sky decks, then briefly left to eat then came back and told we had to purchase tickets again despite the ticket clearly displaying the right date

Genius Architect build to enjoy the bird eye view of Tokyo.. To enjoy the panoramic view of Tokyo, I went to the second part of the Tower. From there you can buy another ticket to go to top of the Tower. Very crowed and needed to queue a long time to go up.

Beautiful structure. Standing below and looking up, this is an architectural wonder. Stunning is the first word that came to mind. Great panoramic views of the city. The numerous stores and restaurants easily make it an all-day affair. Go there early, as tickets are issued quickly and you may have to wait a few hours for your "reserved" time. The queue once inside to make the ticket purchase is lengthy.

Night or day, it is worth it.. I have now been twice, once at night and once during the day. Both were amazing and I can't say one is better than the other, maybe try and get in about sunset...I have heard the lines can get crazy so both times I have gone during the week to try and avoid the lines and it has worked. I think my waits in line to go up have only been like 20-30 minutes.

Very impressive tower, but very expensive too.. Very impressive tower, but very expensive too. Going up to the top, you will have to depart of around $30Very expensive !!But it is very nice and under it, there is a big shopping mall with many good restaurants and they are not expensive. If you come with a car, they have a parking under the tower, which is very convenience.

Great views but very crowded. I really loved visiting the sky tree!It's a great spot for view of the city of Tokyo. Big queues and wait times can be long. Once upstairs it was very crowded and again another long queue to get back down.But if first time in Tokyo I would definitely recommend a visit.There is a nice skytree gift shop also.

Skytree - worth it if cost is not an issue. If your on a budget then perhaps the Tokyo tower would be a better choice, but we were in the area and not too bothered about the cost so went to the top of the Skytree.The views are of course amazing, if you have a top of the range camera you will get some amazing shots. I only used my phone and photos were still decent quality considering.We saw places for refreshments, one was a cafe with tables that didn't look too good, instead we went to the cafe bar (Skyward Eye deck floor 350).If you are a tourist there is a 'tourist ticket' where you dont have to join the long line of people. We must have arrived around 2pm and were at the top of the tower in 15 mins. This was early April and a week day, maybe we got lucky but it didnt feel too crowded at any point of the visit.Afterwards go to the ground and lower floors where there are shops and food outlets.

Gorgeous View of Tokyo but Not Worth the Time and Price. They say that the Tokyo Skytree is one of the must-see places in Tokyo. If you have the time and money to spare, then go for it. If not, forget it.We went there on a Tuesday and the place was crowded. We had to line up to get a ticket to enter the building. This ticket indicated the time we had to come back to get inside. Inside the building, the people still need to line up to buy the ticket to get to the top of the tower. We came in around 11:30 in the morning and the time on our ticket was 2:30 in the afternoon. Those were 3 hours wasted on waiting right there. (Well, should have been. Will explain below why.) I must say though that the system is very organized because at least people don't have to waste their time while lining up to get inside.To kill more time, we just roamed around the area. You can shop for souvenirs around the area. It is like a big mall. If you are hungry, I suggest that you go eat at the food court because their food is so much cheaper as opposed to restaurants. Plus, you get a variety of options.While walking around the mall, we accidentally found another entrance to the tower. There was another counter to buy tickets to get to the tower. However, these tickets are for international visitors only. For additional fee, we can get VIP treatment wherein we skip the long line and get into the tower quickly. We showed our passports and paid ¥2,820 per person. I think it's worth it to pay the extra fee because we saved more time. We only had to wait 15 mins in order to get to the view deck. (We didn't need to use the 2:30pm ticket we had) Once we got to the 350m high view deck, the view was awesome but there's not a lot to see. There are not a lot of tall buildings closer to us that stood out. I was pretty bummed out too because we didn't see Mt. Fuji. It was probably because it was a little bit cloudy. Anyway, we spent around 30 mins at the top and 2.5 hours to enter and exit the tower. By the way, if you are looking for a snow globe, I think Tokyo Skytree is the only place where you can buy it. Whenever I travel, I always get a snow globe as a souvenir. I was looking all over Tokyo and I only saw snow domes which are too big for my preference.Overall, I enjoyed the visit but I don't think I'll recommend it to my family and friends.

Crowded, overpriced and disappointing.... After waiting 25 minutes in the ticket line I was told by the customer service staff that if I paid $35AUD that I would get the express line to go to the highest level. (450m). I bought the ticket and was put in an elevator to the lower level (350m). I thought that I would then be able to catch the next elevator up at no extra charge but they informed me that I'd need to pay another $15AUD to go to the higher level. Unfotunately, it was forecast to be cloudy and rainy for the whole week I was in Tokyo and the views were really quite below average due to this. I thought it seemed a bit ridiculous to pay a total of $50AUD to see very below average views so I decided to leave and had another 20 minute wait in line to go back down to ground level. I'd travelled all the way across Tokyo via the metro and walked another 20 minutes from Asakusa station. So including the walk back, the whole thing felt like a waste of half a day.
high. the Skytree is one of the newest attractions in Tokyo, offering spectacular views from two observation decks, even as far as Mt Fuji
Look from outside!. I does not spending money going to the top. Walking around it, is also a pleasure. Shopping inside also fun!

Beautiful views. You have got to admire, this place is organised so well. There are what seems (and probably are) thousands of people queueing, but it does not feel that crowded and you do not wait for the elevators for long either. Compared to going up places like the Shard in London, this was quick, nice and easy, and the price is very reasonable. I would recommend pre-booking tickets to get to the first 'stage' (you cannot book advance tickets to go all the way to the top, but again, the queue to get them is quite short upstairs). The views are really amazing. We waited until the sunset to see Tokyo at night from the top and it was worth the wait. Once we went down, there were quite a few shops and restaurants catering for all budgets- we opted for the food court as it has quite a few cheaper options and ate some great takoyaki. It was a great evening out, so can recommend visiting.

What a view!!. A great view from the viewing platform, with quite a bit to do/interact whilst walking around. Just a shame we couldn't see Fuji the day we were there, although we were thwarted 3 different times trying to view Fuji - even when we travelled right around it - damn weather!!

Look up. Look way up.. The Skytree is an amazing structure. Much of the design is based around the pagodas which have graced shrines for centuries, and which have withstood earthquakes for centuries. Indeed, the Skytree was still under construction in 2011 when the big earthquake struck. As we can all see, it stood up just fine.Getting there on public transort is straightforward as it is very well served by subway and commuter rail. Because this is such a very popular site reservations are required. Be there a bit early so you don't miss your turn. This is a smoothly run operation: getting the visitors lined up, marshalled and into their groups, get on the elevators, and whisked to the observation decks. The view is amazing. And fascinating. It is worth lingering over.

Overly Hyped. The views are obstructed, every 5 feet there is a big pole. Also, their "glass floor" is about 2x4 feet of window pane that is blurry and also obstructed. There are definitely better views of Tokyo than this- Park Hyatt being one of them. This is good for kids for sure, but as an adult, I would pass.

Amazing site. I had 3 hours free, and i decided to go to the Skytree.It's a 20 minutes walk from Asakusa temple, and the price for admittance in around 15U$$.The view is amazing and after i went to the mall that is located in the ground level.

Very Crowded. We waited 2 hours to get our tickets which were expensive for what we got to see when we got up there. There were so many visitors up there that it was very hard to get around to all the areas and see the beautiful view of Tokyo. Would suggest to go during the day or just before sunset so that you can see more of the other attractions that are visible only during daylight.

Photographers only. We didn't feel this was anything to go crazy about since it's somewhat expensive to get in unless you're really into photography and city views. Our family of 4 paid about $60 to get to the top. It was crowded and had to be patient for a spot to open up near the glass to get a view of Tokyo. You can get similar city views from Roppongi Hills where it's free. The tower itself has shops and restaurants but again nothing to rave about that you can't find elsewhere.

The most comprehensive view of Tokyo. My wife and I, as well as two kids, visited the Skytree earlier this month and enjoyed every minute of it. Yes, it is on the expensive side, but the 360 degree view of Tokyo is unmatched by any other, especially on a sunny day.

Best View from The Top / Tokyo Sky Tree. Always loved to visit high towers in many Asian cities, but Tokyo Sky Tree was really special. There was a food fair in the parking area, nice food and beers. After that, you purchased our tickets and started our journey to the top. The view was amazing, they have a big souvenir shop that includes post service and post cards. There was a Coffee Shop with a live music shop (2 Japanese Musician) very romantic and unique! Recommended to visit. This location is close to the subway too.
Expensive. Probably not worth going up. There are other places you can get a free city view in Tokyo. It is cool to visit on the outside though.

Amazing high view of Tokyo. We arrived early because this place is really crowded (around 9am). There were lines to buy the ticket, but nothing terrible.It was a sunny day but unfortunately there was fog, so we couldn`t see Mt Fuji =(Bring your best camera, because zooming on schools, shirnes, cemeteries and so on is funny, and you can spot funny things, like sports classes.There are two observatory levels? 350m and 450m. Since it wasn't a clear day, we didn't pay the extra ticket to go on 450m because the view wouldn't differ much.The elevators are amazing and fast, your ears feel the pressure! The elevator decoration is great too, as each one has a different detail.The glass floor view is stunning, and you realize how tall this building is.When we left it was so crowded that there were lines to arrive at the windows, so bear this in mind.

Best view of Tokyo. The Skytree is a very popular tourist spot, also lots of Japanese school children on a school outing.When you find the door that leads to getting your ticket that is a little hidden away so go with the crowd flow and it generally works well. The entry is up a lot of stairs so take the escalators.The first line to join when you get through the glass doors to your right is the line for international travellers (you don't necessarily have to use it though) but you can buy a ticket (not cheap) that will allow international travellers a 'priority' way to the lifts that take you up to almost the top. If you wish to go to the very top you have to buy another ticket on the first viewing floor and wait in line again to take another lift. There are a lot of staff to show you this way. Cost over $100 Aus as there were 3 of us.Be warned if you do this right away you will miss out on the floor view that the lifts initially take you to. So walk around and see this floor view first. Apparently you can see Mount Fuji on a clear day but it is generally hazy. So no Mount Fuji.The lifts are run by a polite ladies who take you up the lift but the top lift is automatic and take you to the right floor. Also you have plenty of official photographers in cordon off areas, that will take photos which takes a lot of room up on the first viewing area as you are usually already 3-5 people deep at the edges taking photos - but be patient - and a little determined to get a good spot to take photos.Now if you buy a ticket to go up to the penultimate floor - well worth it, but expensive - again the official photographers await. Once there you will go up a gentle ramp that takes you around the top area until you get to the very top where you can take a photo of the height that you are at.Now this is were I was caught as I thought I could go back to the lower deck to retook at this floor but you can't do this so don't get separated from anyone you are travelling with. Once you get into the lift to go down, go down you do to the floor with the shop which is almost at the bottom.Again no seating until you reach the shop floors at the bottom of the Skytree and they are few so wear good shoes and make allowances.

Sunset over Tokyo. I love being up in tall towers and buildings, so I am biased. Waited 40 minutes for a ticket in the late afternoon. The view is fantastic from the first level. We waited around until the sun set, so it was cool to see the lights of Tokyo gradually appear as darkness settled over the city.

What a view!!!. It is definitely a landmark of Tokyo. If you are there, just you must go and experiance this. First tip - there is no ticket offices on a ground floor for an individual guest. Only groups can buy tickets there. In order to but individual tickets you will have to take an escalator to hight floors. Buying tickets is easy. Then go through a check point, show them you do not carry any hazardous itmes in your bag and you will be allowed to take a lift up there to 340 m floor.This is the fastest lift I have ever took. It takes only 50 sec. to go up.Then you may take escalator or a lift to 345 with a niec view on Tokyo area.Take a lift up to 450 m floor and you will be half in heaven ;-)EASY!
Not realy special. Its has a nice view of tokyo with a panorama window and 3 floors in the middle and a higher floor I did not go there though you will have to pay extra

Amazing feat of engineering. Arrived early in the morning to try and beat the crowds - it was still very busy. Quite pricey to get in, but the views were pretty awesome! The lift that takes you up is so quick, your up in no time (with popped ears due to the pressure change!). Be prepared to wait your turn for a spot right up to the window - if it's too busy pop down a level, there's a better chance of getting better photos and there's a small glass floor panel too (with the option of a photo, at a small price). Worth a visit - however I believe there are other towers to see similar views in other areas in Tokyo that may be worth a look especially if your not a fan of crowds or queues.

Engineering Marvel. Be sure to go to the foreigner's desk if patience is not your virtue (unlike the Japanese) since the queue is just mind boggling. Just show them your passport and you're set. The lift ride is ridiculously fast and you would not feel a thing except that thing on your ear when there's a sudden change in pressure. And just when you step out of the lift, the view is just amazing (and unhindered on a good day, you can even see mount fuji). All of Tokyo is presented before your eyes. The price I think is a little bit high but if views are your forte then you wouldn't regret it

Nicely done. Sorry Chicagoans, please don't be offended. But I have to compare it with 360chicago at John Hancock's building. For the same price the Japanese did a much better job. The elevator ride was much smoother and was more interesting. Different color lights were flashing inside the elevator all the way up, making us feel like we were ascending to the sky. We were there on a cloudy day but it cleared up magically in the afternoon. So we got our view and had a smaller crowd. We stayed until sunset to take photos of the city lighting up at night. Then they surprised us with a 15-minute "window cleaning" show when we were about to leave. The theme was some crazy birds attacking the skytree windows with bird droppings and the poor window cleaning crew had to battle with them, with music and dancing. After that we head down and got to stand on the glass floor. Then we took the elevator down as the male and female attendants made their perfect 45 degree bows to us as the elevator doors were closing. Feeling like some special VIPs we descended. Our eyes were wide opened when the elevator doors opened again to a huge food court with all kinds of yummy food! We were really impressed how they put the whole package together.

worth visiting and going. worth visiting and going to the second stage but too expensive . very near to travelers staying in ASAGUSA Area. Although nothing very spl, other than it being built in steel to such a great height. Instead if you are interested to go to a great height i suggest you to go to Government Twin tower near Shinjuku railway station which is absolutely free till 7.30 p, If you are lucky and if the sky is clear you can even see the Fuiji Mountain on a clear sky .The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (東京都庁, Tōkyō Tochō) in Shinjuku is often visited by tourists for its free observation decks which provide good panoramic views of Tokyo and beyond. The 243 meter tall building has two towers, and each houses an observatory at a height of 202 meters. It had been the tallest building in Tokyo until it was overtaken by the Midtown Tower in 2007.With favorable weather conditions, famous landmarks such as Mount Fuji, the Tokyo Skytree, Tokyo Tower, Meiji Shrine and the Tokyo Dome can be seen from the observatories. Each observatory has a cafe and a souvenir shop. The North Observatory remains open later at night, making it a popular spot to catch night views of the city.

Really cool views. If you really want to see all of Tokyo in one day, this is the viewTo have! It's beautiful. A couple reasons why it's not 5 stars. 1. There are tons of people and it can be a bit over crowded. 2. It's a bit pricy. But, we went on a week day & the crowds were not too bad. I also love all the shopping available under the Sky Tree too.

Great views, lots of shops and restaurants. You can easily spend half a day here, going up the tower to 350m and for an extra JPY 1,000 another 100m. I strongly recommend the Fast Pass option (separate counter) which greatly expedites the entire ascension process. I would say avoid if it's not a clear day, but even so, if you decide to go there are plenty of restaurants and shops that you can spend some hours in.

Not an ordinary Tower. This is an icon of modern Tokyo.. With my family, I visited Tokyo Skytree on April 2016. Previously, we have been to Macau Tower. But for us, Tokyo Skytree is not an ordinary tower. I believe the best view is visiting Skytree at night. Yet, breathtaking views could easily be found at daylight as well (morning and noon).Connected with Skytree Aquarium and Tokyo Skytree Town, this site offers an remarkable experiences for your family trip.Take a picture at the evening alongside Sumida river with Skytree as a background, then you will see how Skytree has become an icon of modern Tokyo that never sleep.

Impressive views. We visited the Skytree for the second time, this time with our almost 2 year old son. We only stayed 1 day in Tokyo on our way back from Japan, but thought it was a good way to get a full Tokyo experience that way on the single day. It really worked out well I can say. You need to bear in mind that you have to book your ticket in advance. We arrived late, but reception staff was very nice and let us in anyway. Ticket price for the top section (450m) is on the high side, but worth it. Only thing we noticed: although lift staff wears "English" badges, they explain everything in Japanese if majority of passengers is Japanese, so you need to make them aware if you don't understand.

Go at night shop in the day. A fantastic experience to get a 360 view of Tokyo right to Tokyo Tower and Disney Land. Right infront of the Sumida River and the lights of Asakusa. We went up around 8:30pm after spending the afternoon at the mall below. Take your passport with you and skip the queue to go up. I would not recommend paying for the photos they take as you can still take really good photos. I will also recommend to not spend your time at the first floor the elevator stops you in and take the escalator to the floor below (same floor to where you exit). This floor was emptier and has the glass floor look out (which is average). The glass floor is small so don't have too high hopes for this. Also, there is no need to go higher by paying more. The view is more then sufficient here and you can get some really good spots for photos. Please do not use flash. Ruins a lot of your photos.Afterwards we got our bags from the lockers below (near the entrance of the mall which was still open for access to lockers). Keep in mind most of the places by the time the tower closes is also closed. So all we did was take some night photos near the tower.

Lots of restaurants and shops here. We came here to go to the Tokyo tower but we were a bit too late and the line ups were too long so we didn't get up to the tower.However, you can still enjoy the tower from the base and also enjoy the many shops and restaurants inside. There are some popular restaurants here and many little stores selling souvenirs to bring back home. I had one of my favourite meals here and I'd definitely go back.

Don't bother. Went in midweek in April 2016 and while there were no queues at ground level it was still very busy at the top. It was hot, crowded and noisy. There is not a lot of room to move about and it felt like were were shuffling behind mobs of people the whole time. We stayed 10 minutes at the most and couldn't wait to get out. The Skytree is far from the center of the city and it took us 1hr 15 minutes and three trains to get there from our hotel near Shinjuku. The views of the main clusters of skyscrapers around Shiodome, Tokyo Station and Shinjuku are all quite distant as a result. The Mori tower in Roppongi is a better bet - it is not as high but it is centrally located, has more room at the top plus it has an open air deck. It also has better views since it is in the middle of the action, so to speak.

Fantastic city views. Well worth a visit if you are in Tokyo, easily the tallest building in the city, also the smoothest lift I have been in!.Amazing 360° views with coffee bars and a restaurant as well. A great way to spend an afternoon, also amazing at night with the city lit up

Don't miss it. If you're in Tokyo, wait for a sunny day because the view is amazing! You get a chance to look at one of the most largest cities in the world. The additional cost for the 450m deck is worth the money, and these 100m make a difference.

Busy but great views of Tokyo on a clear day. As a big new attraction, it is very popular with tourists. Having said that, staff is very good at moving people along and you will get great views of the massive expanse that is Tokyo city if you have a bit of patience. We only went to the first floor and that was enough for us. You could presumably also get good views at the Tokyo Met Government office but we enjoyed it!Afterwards, it's a quick walk to Sumida Park and from there it's not far to Senso-jii temple. A fine day!

Amazing Structure - Amazing View. The first thing that gets you is when you actually see this structure up close, you see it from a train ride or while you are on a bus or from another part of Tokyo but up close it takes your breathe away.Firstly make sure it's a clear day, no good on rainy or foggy days.We were in Japan for 14 days, the first two were not good viewing days so we admired the building up close and enjoyed everything else the Skytree had to offer on the lower floors.Just a big shopping center where you will see things and foods unlike home. We had some UDON noodles from one of the food galleries on the west side for only one reason that they were making the Udon noodles fresh there and then behind the counter. This was just a take away counter not a fancy restaurant where you would expect fresh noodles to be made on the premises.Anyway when we come back to Tokyo 11 days later the weather was better and we headed up to buy the tickets on the forth floor.We already knew the prices and they don't have a ticket where you can view during the day and come back for the night view.So we timed it about two hours before sunset and then stayed another hour or so after sunset.If you are keen photographer be sure to bring you tripond even for day shots, just to get clearer pictures especially if you use you zoom setting a must. Only downer is it can be expensive and you need to pay more if you want to higher than the main viewing area. The view beneath the tower outside is also amazing.

Great views! . Went at night about 7pm. We waited in the ticket line for about 15 minutes, not bad at all! The elevator on the way up went pretty quick. We had to yawn and swallow to relieve the pressure in our ears. Once we reached the 350 meter stop the view was breathtaking! We could not see the end of the city of Tokyo. Our children (7 & 8) also enjoyed the view. Pictures didn't turn out great due to glare, but in person the view was amazing. There were a lot of students there when we went, probably middle school aged. They were not misbehaving, but there were hundreds! We did not want to pay the extra 3000 yen to go up to 450 meters, I am sure that would have been spectacular though.

High above the sky. The Tokyo Skytreeis a great observatory tower to visit while in Tokyo. You definitely want to go on a day that it is clear outside. I was there when it was cloudy out, preventing us from going all the way to the top of the tower. Be sure to try the ice-cream at 63o on the inside of the mall area. It is delicious!!! My favorite was green tea and strawberry mix. You will also have the option to take pictures for purchase or use your own camera.

Fantastic views on a clear day. We waited 15 minutes in total to get tickets and to go to the top at 450 meters.Easy access to the windows and the amazing views.Best to go on weekdays around lunch and before the summer season starts.Very friendly staff as everywhere in Japan.

See Arial View of Tokyo. I visited on a clear, sunny Friday, and even on a weekday, the wait to purchase tickets was 45 minutes. There is entertaining animated visuals on monitors with information of cultural landmarks visible from the tower, that help to pass the time. Hint: purchasing tickets on-line, ahead allows one to reduce the wait at the tower. I initially went to the 350m deck. The view is amazing, and is already higher than the top deck of the older, Tokyo Tower. I paid the additional fee to go up to the 450m deck, (an extra $11) and the crowds were thinner there. A 100m ramp arches along the edge in a more "tube" like structure, so visitors can see up and down. For photos the slanted glass in the viewing area is better, as there are fewer reflections in the glass. Mt. Fuji was faintly visible in the distance the day I visited. Great 360 degree views Tokyo. It is convenient to Narita Airport, as there is a Keisei train that will go directly to the Airport from the station at Tokyo SkyTree (Oshiage Station).
Worth it. Very fast lift, chose fast ticket as a long waiting line for normal ticket... worth it. Stunning views, great window washer performance.

Worth a visit. Went on a sunny April day and really enjoyed ourselves. Took the metro and made our way to the ticketing by the ample signage. We saw a line for visitors and skipped the big general line at a premium ticket price. Was fine with that as we had a short stay.Did both levels. When we were there the first level was packed and a bit crazy, the second level, while smaller, was a lot less crazy and worth the extra time and money. Total time in lines was 5 minutes.Worth a visit if you have time on a nice day.

Great Place to visit in Tokyo!. All fun starts in the elevator that is one of the fastest in the world. After that you have the best view of Tokyo. In a clear day, you can see for hundreads of miles.And when you finish your visit you still have some nice places to eat and shop, and an unusual aquarium.

Great view, pick your day if you can. We didn't try any of the other towers in Tokyo as this one was recommend by someone who went up a few different ones. The only advice I have is (if you have the option) try to go up on a day that's clear, a bit cold and windy as the smog from the city can have a big impact on visibility from the tower. Air quality may not seem too bad on the ground, but when you're trying to get 10, 15 or 20km of visibility even a little bit of air pollution can make a big difference. Also, if you have a foreign passport you can pay a bit more and cut in front of the line. Something to think about if you don't have much time or aren't too price sensitive.
Amazing Views. What an amazing experience the views from the sky tree are amazing.I would highly recommend going up to the observation decks at dusk , watch the sunset and see Tokyo light up.

Wonderful view by day and night.. We had prebooked tickets to go up to the viewing platform and arrived in the ground floor to find it extremely busy. The organisation for going up in the lifts was excellent and before long we were at the platform. We walked round , visiting souvenir shops and taking pictures of the city and the river. We had a very good meal in the restaurant ( 364) as darkness fell and enjoyed seeing the lights of the city.The descent by lift was again well organised.

The best view of Tokyo, but not by much.. As many people have said already, Skytree really is weather dependent. If you go on a rainy or foggy day, you definitely won't see much. I went on a sunny day and still couldn't see that far because it was kind of hazy. And like all major tourist attractions, be prepared for massive crowds. But value wise, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building offers a similar but perhaps slightly inferior view for free(!) and with smaller crowds. Seriously, the amount of people at Skytree is no joke. If I had to choose, I would be rather save money and time, and choose TMGB. But if you absolutely need to go to the shiniest and newest place, Skytree is the place to go.

Nice view . It's nice to visit sky tree if you have time during your stay in Tokyo. Nothing special about the tower but the worst thing is the show they do every hour !!!! Don't waste your time and wait it's very silly .nice view over Tokyo try to go during night and check the weather before you go and be sure the sky is clear .

Glass floor 450m up is a must. As you come out of the subway and look up it's dizzying. About a 20 minute queue when we went. We went to both decks. I loved it. It was a bit misty when we went, but we still could see for miles. The bit that freaked us out was standing on the glass floor and looking down. Worth it.

Amazing view with more to do!. We went for the nighttime view...only wish we had arrived earlier! Beyond the amazing view (don't miss the glass floor viewing!), there were restaurants galore and shopping and probably more that we missed because we didn't arrive until nearly 8:00pm. Our wait was only about 20-25 minutes but we spent nearly an hour and a half just exploring around the observation deck. Only left us time to have a very late dinner. But, there were lots of shops and what looked like other activities that we missed out on. Definitely give yourself enough time to see it all!
All that you would expect. The Tokyo Skytree is all that you would expect from a tall tower in a major world city. In reminds me most of the CN tower in Toronto.

Incredible views from the tallest tower in the world. The Skytree provides breathtaking views of the sprawling metropolis that is Tokyo. With two observation decks at 350m and 450m for you to look in amazement at the bustling city far below.A single adult ticket to get to the 350m deck costs about 2000 Yen, with the 450m deck costing an extra 1000 (you purchase a separate ticket for the 450m deck once you are on the 350m deck). The 450m deck is definitely worth the extra cost, as it gives some incredible views of the city on a clear day.There is also a variety of shops, cafes and restaurants at the base of the tower, which you can visit without needing to purchase a ticket to get up the tower.

If only, on a clear day. Great and imposing tower. If it is. It a clear day though, you will only see what you can see from other towers but from a different vantage point. Save this sight spot for a clear day if oissible or you will. It get to see the much purported distant view of Mt Fuji.
My first time been here!. I visited the skytree with my family to see great things in Japan! But it was awesome from the building in the evening. I am surprised that the line is quite short to go in!

Great views. This afforded wonderful views especially as we were there on a very clear day. Interesting shopping and cute mascots are also part of the experience. There was a special deal/faster line for visitors with international passports that cut the wait time significantly.
Amazing Night view. Went during the night hours, had a great night view, along with souvenir shop, cafe and glass floor. Able to view 360° of tokyo night sky was totally amazing!!

Needs to be a Clear Day. This was fantastic to see but to make the most of your experience you need a clear day to see the sights. Unfortunately it was not a good day when we visited but we still enjoyed the experience. Tokyo Skytree became the tallest structure in Japan in 2010 and reached its full height of 634.0 metres (2,080 ft) in March 2011, making it the tallest tower in the world.

Amazing View. We visited the skytree after enjoying a few beers at the base in the beer garden near by. The line is long and it can be very crowded, but once you get to the top it is worth the wait. You have a 360 view of the city and it is really beautiful to experience at night.

Best seen at night. My girlfriend didn't like heights, so like the lonely English man I went up on my own! It's beautiful at night, and when I went up it was REALLY quiet, I only quee'd for 5 minutes for tickets.The views are outstanding, there is a small cafe, and some seating here and there! Great to sit and just watch the night go by.

It's not a long visit.. As foreign visitors, we were offered tickets at an extra cost but to avoid the queues, to go to the viewing floor. The queue for everyone was long so we took the 'fast pass' option. It's not that large an area and the cafe didn't offer any other option to ice cream or hot drinks, but the Windows and information boards are very good and it's an amazing experience, albeit at a high price. There's a small shop at the top and a larger shop selling souvenirs, (which helped us to fulfil our obligations) which is at the bottom of the attraction. We were there for less than 2 hours, so we felt it was not that good value but it did help me deal with a slight anxiety of heights so that was positive.

"Nice Colors". When I went there, my friends and I wanted to go up to the top of the Sky Tree to watch the sun set, but the lines were too long to get to see it. That is why we decided to go up another time. However, once it got dark, the Sky Tree lit up and danced with colored lights. There was also a beer festival at the entrance, so we still had fun. If you go, I would definitely try to see if they are having any free events, just in case your plans get altered like mine did.There is also a full mall under the Sky Tree, so if you like shopping I would definitely make time to look around in it. The mall and event areas are free to enjoy, but you must pay to go up the Sky Tree.

Great view of Tokyo!. Now, first things first: this isn't the single most impressive view you'll ever see of a city from the towers of the world, and it's pretty darn overpriced at about 2,800 yen or so per person. However, the view is gorgeous at night, and it was especially nice for us since there was no wait at all; we must've come at a really good time at night. We went to the 350, 345, and 340 meter levels and enjoyed them all, and they even have a glass floor at the 340 m level. Also, as soon as we went up the tower, they played a little play for us called Wipe Up, which was cute; the employees dressed as window washers and danced and sang.Oh, another thing: the food and gift shops here are, like the entrance fee, ridiculously expensive, and Tokyo Skytree has the dubious honor of having fed me literally the worst doughnut I've ever had in my life. Seriously, do they make them out of rubber? How do you even mess up a doughnut? Come on now.Recommended only if you have cash to burn just because of how incredibly overpriced it was. Take away how needlessly expensive everything was, and the experience itself is really nice. I also hear the view is better than Tokyo Tower, so there's that.
Tokyo Skytree. Best view in the evening. All lit up it looks great. In the daytime the views from the top are just great. Best view of wonderful Roppongi which is the night time playground in Tokyo.

It is a very average Observatory deck. I had a choice between two observatory decks. Tokyo Skytree and Tokyo Tower. I had heard and read not so good reviews about the latter and so I went for the Skytree with my family. The tower is just beside Oshiage station so travelling is very easy. The height of observatory deck is also good. Just that the view from the top isnt that great. After going to Sky100 in Hong Kong, Guangzhou tower, Empire state in NYC the view from this observatory deck was unsatisfactory.Hving said that, if you still want to view the city from the top then I recommend Skytree tower. Do not go for Tokyo Tower

Long lines . There is a faster line for foreigners. But still be prepared to wait. The view was good. By the time we got up there it was nighttime. You also have to wait in line to get down. There are shops and restaurants at the bottom and there was also a small Bavarian Christmas village and lights set up.

Long queues, but worth it to see the views. If you can pre book your tickets online, I strongly suggest you do so. We waited about 30mins in the line up for tickets and then had to contend with similar crowds on the first observation deck. Luckily we are tall and could look over most peoples heads or else we wouldn't of seen much. The views were pretty cool though and it puts it into perspective of how huge Tokyo is. The city seemed like it never ended. We couldn't see Mt Fuji due to cloud/smog coverage.

Tokyo Skytree. it is really an impressive structure and you can enjoy the lovely view of Tokyo. Its one of the major tourist attraction. There was a queue to go up but it moves very fast. It is the tallest structure in Japan. On the ground floor there is a souvenir shop where I bought a few ball pen key chains of the sky tree. From the observation deck you get a breath taking view of Tokyo. A must see.

Long queues and lucky if see Fijiyama . Impressing structure, you do not have to go up to enjoy it, book your ticket or you will find a huge queue. If you finally felt in Skytree spider web, enjoy the big shopping mall underneath. For those who suffer seasickness, it moves and you may realise feeling a little dizzy.

Great view. Well, sky tree was definitely a great tourist attraction. The view was simply amazing and we did not have to wait to long to go up the observation deck.If you have not been, I would recommend this place.
New Landmark of Tokyo city. This is the tallest building in Japan, you can view all around tokyo, even up to Fujiyama. I think this is the must visitd location when you are in Tokyo .....

Skytree. We had a great experience here. Thought frpm some comments from here that it might be crowded but it was only 10min queue for the tickets and then immediately to elevator at friday evening. Recommend to go there when sun is set and getting darker.
Fantastic Viewpoint. Great views all over Tokyo from the highest vantage point possible.We got there at twilight so were able to see the city at night - will go back sometime for a day view.

An amazing view, so high up!. For visitors from overseas, there is a a West entrance where you can get in without queuing for an extra 800 yen. You need to have your passport with you and you only need one foreign passport in your group to qualify for the express ticket. Handy if you have local friends in your group. We looked at the weather forecast for the week and picked the best day to go. We could see about 10-12 km which gave us a good idea of how big the city is. The shopping in the shops underneath the Tokyo SkyTree are all new and a great place to buy your souvenirs from. The higher level was less crowded than the lower level and offered a relaxed, great view. Well worth doing on a clear day.

Must visit for first time in Tokyo. This tourist attraction was awesome. The Tokyo Skytree is currently the TALLEST tower in the world. There are 2 levels you can visit while you're at the SkyTree. There's a mid-tier where most people go (via elevator) and it takes you pretty far up. Everyone gets in line and you're whisked up some very fast elevators to the viewing platform. You get off, and wander around the viewing area, to see 360 degree views of Tokyo and surrounding areas / waters, etc.If you're in for some more height and thrills, you can get in line to buy another separate ticket that takes you to the TALLEST viewing platform, which is about 10+ floors higher than where most people get off.Grand views all around, and plenty of photo opportunities too. Be sure to visit the "glass viewing area" in the mid-tier area, where you can walk on top of glass and take a look down to the ground floor of the sky tree (you can see cars driving, etc.). Incredible views and kinda scary for those who are afraid of heights! Well worth a trip and highly recommend for 1st time visitors to Tokyo!

Oustanding. There is too much good to say about Tokyo Skytree. I don't know what I was expecting, but whatever it was, Skytree blew me away. Oshaige station is super close so not a lot of walking...the shopping in the station had some unique places with unique gifts you will not find anywhere else. The view from the tower was amazing, the quality of the photo's from the photo service was excellent, the staff was super-friendly, etc, etc etc. I cannot say enough about how totally cool this experience was!(I hope I can add photo's to my review later-on)
nice place. great food, nice shops, beautiful place, almost visit everyday during stay in Oshiage Richmond hotel. great place to go.

Good combination. The place is beautifully designed, purpose built and buzzing with shoppers all day. I enjoyed walking in the centre, Watching ice skating outside on the third level, eating places and nice seatings outside.
Amazing. The view is priceless view. was that lucky day to see Fuji Mountain as it covered by fog. but still, the view up there is showing how big is Tokyo is.
My visit to Skytree . The highest I've ever been; I could reach the sky. The view was just outstanding. I could not believe the line for tickets.
Great view at night. Great view in the evening/night. But not worth to pay extra 1000 to get to the very top - less visitors though. 30min waiting on Sun evening.

excellent place for the whole family. really enjoyed my visit here , the view was fantastic, the restaurants and the shop was exciting. I cisited on a tuesday but it was very crowded , enjoyed the whole experience.

Great view. The view is undoubtedly amazing and if you have a clear day and can see all the way to mount Fuji absolutely worth it! We ended up on a cloudy day so while the view was still amazing I didn't get the distance I thought was worth the price. There is a 'fastpass' available for foreign tourists which does cost more but we skipped about an hr of the normal queue. Upto you if you are patient. There's some good food places to eat and a small gift shop but nothing to rave about. There isn't really much else in this area besides the 'skytree town'. No easy access with a JR pass you will have to purchase a metro ticket. I would say this would be something you could skip if you are doing the roppongi hills city view observation deck and the Tokyo tower.

Good views of Tokyo.. Thats about it!. This place opened 3 years ago, and promised spectacular views of Tokyo. It does that, but that's all it does.. No more, no less. There are some minor engagement activities that the management is trying to do, but there are just value-added efforts.

Great views, not cheap but worth it. I visited just as it was getting dark (after looking round Senso-Ji temple) so benefitted from both day and night views. Got a priority pass (as we were from overseas) that meant we skipped the queues and pretty much got straight up.Staff friendly, views fantastic and its a lovely way to spend a few hours. SkyTree also has great shops and restaurants.

Fun but not exciting . Like any well-known tall monument, it is very exciting to take it all in. However, the little ones can get quite bored. There was quite a bit of walking and a lot of long lines during busy travel time. However, the view from atop the spectacular.
Nice view . We had not prebooked the tickets therefore purchased the priority pass which gave us a real quick access. View from Skytree is really awesome. Lots of shopping and eating area.

Great View, Good Info Boards. It appears that going first thing in the morning is the best time to go as there were no queues but plenty of staff indicating that it was going to get busy later. The lift is mind-numbingly fast and the electronic info boards are very well done.

Queuing. Tokyo Skytree first I would like to say it is a fantastic place to visit. But. The queuing system leaves much to be desired. First you gave to work out that you have to queue in an outside tent to obtain a ticket that allows you to get into another queue at the second queuing point you gave a half hour time slot. Confusion ensues at this point as the staff direct the ones without any ticket to the outside tent. This can only be described as total disorganised the staff saying the same thing over and over again. Then as your half hour time slot gets closer a mad rush begins. Only to be allowed in to queue for a third time

Not worth the money. Do yourself a favor and save your 28000 yen for a nice dinner at the observation deck at the Tokyo metropolitan towers; (which is free ) Its not as high as skytree tower but just as nice of view.

Breathtaking View. Tokyo Skytree is the tallest tower and second tallest structure in the world ensuring that it will give you the best birds eye view of Tokyo from anything still connected to the ground. It isn't cheap, but is quite worth it. It does take some time, so don't plan to pop in for half an hour. The upper deck is also well worth the money. I was shocked, that from the height I was able to see a soccer ball flying around a well lit soccer field far below. Somehow, the city looks closer up at the higher observation deck than the lower one, but it's only an illusion. If you're looking for a way to grasp the magnitude and size of the largest city on earth, this is definitely the way!

Just like any other tower visit, great view but that's about it. Just like any other observations towers we've visited, highly commercialised and you have to pay extra to get to the highest level. Which we didn't. There's a ¥2800 special ticket with fast tracked waiting time instead of normal ¥2000 which they say could take up to 40 minutes wait to go up. As with family with young children probably best to take the fast track ticket so they're not waiting too long in the queue...Provides good view of Tokyo 360°, but that's about it

Well worth the time and expense. You end up 350 metres above the ground with amazing views. You would probably only do this once, however it is worth it. You should book online though as the lines of people waiting for tickets was very, very long.
Awesome view. This is the best view in Tokyo I have seen yet. If you are in the area you should definitely visit this tower.

Skip it - save your money for drinks at Park Hyatt lol. Seriously the worst thing we did in Japan. AMAZING view to be sure but seriously crowded. I dint mean, crowded like all of Japan is crowded; I mean stupid claustrophobic crowded. Plus you have to book days in advance- don't even think of going on the day! And when you book you have to go that time and if the weather isn't good- tough luck. There are shops underneath, a rabbit Warren of never ding shops and queues don't go I warned you!

Tokyo Skytree. I went with my 2 teenage daughters and we had a lot of fun! We recommend getting their early because it does get packed when the restaurants open. But, other than that the view is amazing and the shopping is great

A great experience. The tower is the tallest in the world.I was worried about the lift, having had difficulty with the Sears tower in Chicago.This was magical. So quick and didn't feel any problem with air pressure on my ears.There were shops and facilities to eat and drink.
New spot for hangout. Spectacular view of Tokyo, with shopping and nice restaurants. Next to a transportation hub and convenient .
Another Tower that need to be seen. Beside the Tokyo Tower, Tokyo Skytree is also need to be seen. If you don't have time, you can see this from the Senso-ji (Asakusa Kanno Temple) Temple.

Worth it. As the tallest broadcasting tower right now, you will be amaze of how tall and extravagant the tower. We are not able to go up because of time constraint but its worth a visit and a picture perfect!!!

Tokyo Skytree on a clear day!. So, Tokyo Skytree for a european its a bit complicated, you will have to go to the 4th or 5th floor to get your ticket. There are two types of tickets, slow or fast lane. I took the fast lane, so I cannot advice for slow lane, but they were saying it will 30 mins waiting time. For the fast lane it will 10 mins waiting time.After buying the ticket will be directed to a line, to a lift. The lift it self its something that I never seen before. I wont tell you as you have to go and see it youself. One more thing, you will feel the pressure on your ears.As you reach the 45 floor there is an option to go for a higher floor. And i will say its worth it. World becomes smaller! Ticket to the last two floors can be bought at the same place were you buy the tickets for Tokyo Skytree (the place with slow lane and fast lane). I will say you should go and see the city somewhere before it gets dark, so you will have the best of the two worlds, day time and night time.Ah one more thing, dont forget to look for mount Fuji!
Good view. There is a good view at 350 metersI don't think it's needed to go to 450When foreigners you can go to the fast track and go up without queue

On a clear day. my visit was cloudy and its a little expense. Had a better time at the Tokyo Tower, it had rained the night before and the view (from the first level) was magnificent. LOTS of people, be prepared to wait 45 minutes....just to get your ticket.

Best view in Tokyo. Went up here on a rainy and cloudy day, we only visited the lower deck as the TV screens showed that nothing was visible from the higher level. They do warn you about this as well when you buy a ticket, they also told us as it was quiet we need not pay the extra for the fast entry. Very honest and great customer service from the start.The lift up is great fun, you go very quick and it make your ears pop more than once but the views are amazing. It is massive upstairs with 3 levels on the lower deck including the glass platform. Walk around and take it all in, it has a cafe also but you pay for the view there, it is not cheap.The one downside is that it is quite expensive, but it is worth it I feel.

great trip. another iconic building of Tokyo is Skytree and visiting it is quite interesting although a bit painful because of the huge queues for getting the admission tickets. nonetheless it is a must place to visit when on trip to Tokyo.

Crowded but the foreigner ticket helps. On a Friday in March, the normal queue was 60-90 minutes long, but I found the Fast Ticket counter for foreigners, where you pay Y800 more, and I was at the top 15 minutes after getting in line (I didn't go to the very top level, which costs more and requires another 15-30 minute queue). Many people at the top but it's the best way to appreciate Tokyo's incredible sprawl, although definitely try for a sunny day (I couldn't see Fuji but I saw other snowcapped mountains). The bottom two levels may have fewer people but I'm not sure if you can easily go back upstairs.

Well worth the visit. The views are great from the platform, and if you are lucky - and we were - you may glimpse Mt Fuji from around column 8. There is an excellent food court here, we ate there twice it was that good. If you are a coffee snob, you will likely have been avoiding all coffee in Japan. But within a stone's throw of this attraction is Unlimited Coffee Bar, and it offered five or six mild roast choices, many were obviously single origin, perhaps all were. My espresso was fabulous, the only mild complaint is it did not serve mineral water with the espresso. There is interesting food here too.
Definite must in Tokyo for views of the city. Great place to view the whole city of Tokyo. Get there before sunset and watch the whole city light up. Highly recommended.
Best view in all of Tokyo. You will get the best view (360 degree view) of all of tokyo. It is well worth the wait to get all the way to the top so that you can see how HUGE this city truly is.

Great tower . They claim this as the tallest "tower" in the world at 2080 feet. There are taller buildings of course but as a tower alone this is the highest. Great layout and awe inspiring views. Having multiple decks and layouts is a plus. You can go to the lower deck for an affordable price. Overall a good value and great orientation of Tokyo from above.

Amazing views and efficient passage up.. Went up here at night to get a view of the city. 350 metre deck was fine for me, would have liked to go to top but needed to get down to eat. Queueing was ok at 7.30pm, took 20 mins to get to ticket office then straight up. Believe can be much worse so c;early hit and miss. Worth it for the views though.

Awesome view!. This is a really nice attraction. Foreigners have to option to use the fast lane for a few more Yen. The shopping mall underneath is top class. the food court is excellent. rail connections are good and the staff is very courteous. clean, safe, friendly environment.

More than a tower. The building in the basement is a great place to spend time if you like food and traditions. The old japanese food refurnished or not, traditional sweet for take away or to eat just there, while walking to the next shop is a fantastic experience. There are some bentos (lunchboxes) made in the old-style boxes with old recipes and was very nice to me to have the chance to taste all those great, delicious delicatessen before going up to the Sky Tree. Recommended to have breakfast, lunch or dinner and plan the visit including one of the meals, 2 or 3 hours minimum!

But only if the sky is clear . It is an amazing structure (sadly not a single translation on the construction aspects).But the view and the glass floor need no translation.However the line to get up can exceed 2hrs and if the sky is not clear your views are severely restricted.

Enjoyable Visit. I went at 3 pm on a Tuesday for a walk-up ticket and there was no line-up to go up the Skytree. I only went up to the three floors of the Tembo Deck. Since it was a bit of a cloudy day and the views were limited, I didn’t bother to go up to the two floors of the Tembo Galleria.I had also gone up the Tokyo Tower and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. The views are similar but you see more of the Sumida River from the Skytree.The three levels of the Tembo Deck are connected by escalators. There are two photo services available where you can buy a photo that they take of you with a view of Tokyo in the background or with the glass floor. There are eateries on the Tembo Deck.Around the base of the Skytree, there are various food outlets and shops. There is also an outdoor skating rink.I had combined my visit to the Skytree with a visit to the nearby Edo-Tokyo Museum.

Less is More Part 165 - Sky-High Boredom. While this is fundamentally designed as an NHK communication tower, the developer Tobu Railway Co. is exploiting it to anchor its commercial development below. The direct rail connection to Narita is obvious in its intentions to make it highly accessible even to visitors on long transits such as I. And so I got to Skytree very early in the morning from Narita after arriving on over night flight with 10 hours to spare before catching another outbound. The early hour meant that the treacherously long queues had not yet materialized. Aware that an express line for foreign visitors was available (at a premium) I headed to the obscurely (I wonder why?) located counter. The reception there was kind enough to advise me to buy a regular ticket since the wait was only 5 minutes at that hour of the morning. Soon I was speeding up the tower to the 350m level. Another ticket is necessary to ascend to the 450m tier. The difference in the views are negligible and the question does arise on the rationale other than deriving more revenue sources. Indeed right throughout this attraction are more than ample opportunities to do so from the touristy gift shop and cafe to chargeable photo ops on transparent floor sections. Admittedly the young enthusiastic crew is super efficient in crowd management and cheerful a la Disney; almost. They do try to make the entire visit enjoyable but am afraid to say that the experience is as sterile and uninspiring as the sparkling clean white dull-looking tower that rises over the banks of the Sumida River. While this is a highly visible icon, it is not IMHO not a high priority "must-see".
Trip to skytree. Very nice place very good connectivity for there also dining places children were so excited View of Tokyo very beautiful so many people come there

Amazing. An amazing view of Tokyo. The queue was quite long when we arrived but they offer an express ticket for more money. A bit expensive but well worth it if you're in a rush. I would recommend going in the evening just before sunset to see the city change from day to night
Simply amazing!. We went there during the night and it was light up beautifully.. sadly didnt go to the higher floors though as we were too late and it was already closed.

3rd Anniversary . Tokyo Skytree has its third anniversary this year. The tower has several floors from the ground up. Then it's four high speed elevators will take the paying visitors to the primary high Floor 350 meters. Additional height at Floor 450 meters is possible with additional admission. Overall the experience at the Tokyo Skytree was very positive since it provide different attractions for kid and adult. The whole exercise from queuing for ticket purchasing, waiting for high speed elevator, spending time on various high floor, and eventually the final exploring of the lower floors will take around 2 hours if not more.

Try to go early for less of an crowd, a but pricey. I think it's a bit pricey to go but still worth it. You have to go get a ticket first and then they'll hand you another ticket telling you what time the line will begin to start accepting people (to control how many people they let in at a time). Make sure you go earlier to get the time slotted tickets. Once you go and start lining up, it takes a while because there's more lining up inside. I think about 30mins later you will take the elevators up there. The view is spectacular, Tokyo city is an amazing place; if you're on a budget, go to Tokyo tower as it's just as nice in terms of the view (simply not as tall) and it's a bit cheaper at Tokyo tower.

Great Views. Very surprised with the Skytree. As with a lot of towers and observation deck style attractions the crowd and the queue was massive. Almost an hour of queuing to go to the top of a building? Almost turned me off. But the elevator to the top was done very stylishly and really built up a kind of anticipation for what the view would be like. Luckily the day I went up you could actually see the outline of Mt. Fuji in the distance, and at 106 km away? That was really impressive. After being to the top of the Empire State and other buildings, I didn't expect to be as blown away from this as I was. It may have just been the combination of the clear day and my last day in Japan, but to me, it was really worth a visit.

誕生日!! my great birthday. the great place ever in Tokyo. this tower is my number one favourite!!!and for the first time I came to this place, last year and on my birthday!!!I got skytree birthday sticker.everything here is special!!solamachi, stand for tickets, elevator, observation deck. tembo deck. galleria deck!!great view. there a special exhibition about star wars when I came. and lucky me, I can see mount fujithe place must visit when go to Tokyo.and I am one of big fans of skytree tower. スカイツリー大好き!!!

Party At 400 mts above the ground. This is an amazing place to visit when one visits Tokyo. Party at the lower observation deck is Insane. but one might have to wait for a couple hours to get a ticket. But this place is worth the wait and worth evey yen spent.

Very very long long queue on weekends. I visited there with my grandma who walks with a limp. I thought she couldn't wait in long queue, so I bought online tickets in advance at their home page. Prices of online tickets were more expensive than usual tickets at the entrance. However we entered without waiting time at a long long queue. An advance ticket price was 2570 yen, and usual ticket was 2060 yen. Average waiting time on weekends were over 1 hour. Online ticket pages is in Japanese language only, so if you do not read Japanese, you ought to buy tickets through travel agencies or Japanese friends.

Great View!. Tokyo Skytree was built for a tourist attraction but they did a great job in planning. We went at night and the skyline was absolutely gorgeous. I'm sure during the day is just as breathtaking. The queues weren't as long, as our friend had pre-booked our tickets. Walking around the Skytree inside only took us about 45 minutes but the fun part for me were the shops on the main level. When we were waiting to go into the SkyTree we shopped around for trinkets and snacks. They had a great deal of stores which I enjoyed.

Good view on the night. I went there at night time. It is expensive, around 25 usd more or less for the visit, but if you want to have a good view of the tokyo city, I think it is a must visit. Most awesome views you may get from tokyo.

Impressive. Enjoyed spending time to see a great night time 360° view of Tokyo. Enjoyed all the information displays on the deck. Disappointed that there was no beer to be enjoyed with the night sights. To avoid the queues we went about 7.30pm.

Beautiful Tokyo view . Tokyo Skytree is main tourist attraction in Tokyo. Have beautiful view on Tembo Deck floor and I recommend pay more 1000 yen to Tembo Galleria floor more peace and you can walk and enjoy the view. On weekend so busy and had to wait really long queues and long time. Better to visit more early and late afternoon.

Cool. Nice view.. I went to the Tokyo Skytree on my first full day in Tokyo. It looks very cool and you need to spend quite a bit to go up but I figured I would go for it. The line is pretty long, then you take the elevator up. The view of Tokyo is very cool and you get to see how big it really is. They have the class floor where you can take a picture. I ended up ordering a coffee and drank it while admiring the city. On the ground level there are a lot of shops and such where I ended up wandering around afterward and getting a quick lunch. It really is just another tall building. It was alright.

Nice scene!. If you don't want to wait at the ticket line for a long time,you must go there early in the morning. The upper deck was nice , I took a photo by the skytree service,it's cost me 1,300 Yen but good to have it. The scene up there was so wonderful. Don't forget to take a picture with the glass bottom floor. It's cool!

Plan ahead to visit this bold symbol of modern Tokyo. If you try to visit Skytree on a whim you may find it frustrating and you might actually miss some parts. I suggest you do some advance work just so you understand the flow when you arrive.The lower floors of Skytree are a shopping mall. You can bypass them to get to the ticket level where you buy an elevator ride to the Tembo Deck at 350 meters. Here you can get a nice view of the city and have various opportunities to have your picture taken. Here is also where you buy tickets to the Galleria Deck.At 450 meters you are up there pretty high. The people flow takes you on an inclined path around the tower before you exit via elevator back to the Tembo Deck. The views, of course, are spectacular as is the structure itself. They control the number of people that are up there at any time so it is crowded but never so packed that you can't get an extended look at whatever you want to see.I am glad we did it and would do it again...this time during the day.
Was ok. For the amount paid, it was just ok. Go early to avoid the long lines, and try to go on a clear day when you can see alot.

Great views of the city. The views are really great from the Skytree! The queues tend to get quite long sometimes, and the ticketing system for the different elevators is somewhat confusing, but the staff is really helpful.Worth a visit!

Tokyo is HUGE. You really get a concept of how big tokyo is up here! Was great! Didnt go up to the top level that was an extra charge- but deffs recommend having a tea looking out over the city over dusk
panorama. the view was amazing, like expected but little overpriced. Very crowdy and long queues but view compensated this.

great view. this is also a must see in Tokyo, I went at night, around 8pm (last entry was at 8.30pm) and I did not have to queue at all. It offers great views of Tokyo. And they also did a little show with music while projecting pictures onto the glass.

Breathtaking view of the city. Definitely worth a visit. One of the iconic tourist attractions of the city. Take a ticket only for the 1st level viewing deck. The view from the top cannot be much better, and you end up paying double. Visit preferably during twilight hours, you would be able to see the city as the lights come up.

Nice place but too crowded sometimes. The new Tokyo Skytree is a nice place to visit but avoid weekends or holidays. It gets too crowded sometimes. It has a lot of stores in your way from the train station for all kinds of souvenir shopping. There is also an aquarium that is worth the visit.

Don't Go To The Top. Breathtaking experience: views are stunning, but restricted right at the top, and nothing gained (we thought we might see Mt Fuji, although there was clear signage saying it wasn't viewable - we did wonder if it could ever be, since we chose a fantastically clear day). Very efficiently run and easy to negotiate, with plenty of staff on hand to help. It was very clean (typical Japanese) and one of the highlights of the whole trip.

Amazing. We went as it was getting dark as we had visited Tokyo Tower in the day, they have a fast pass for foreigners which costs a bit extra but lucky for us it wasn't too busy in the lobby so didn't make use of this the views from the top were amazing seeing Tokyo lit up, only problem was having to pay again to get to floor 450 after already paying to get up.

a view of the city. The Skytree is the highest point in downtown Tokyo. It costs ~$18-20 to go up most of the way, and another $9-10 to go to the top. You can see 360degrees. February is an overcast month so our views weren't as spectacular as they are at other times of the year. They have visuals pointing out famous/important buildings and landmarks. They also had the history of the area displayed by old pictures. Lots of people go up but it was not unreasonably crowded. There is a cafe on the main viewing platform but it offers little selection and was pricey. We were there in the afternoon and stayed through dusk so that we could see the city lights. Well worth doing. The only downside is there is NO seating; I'm sure to have people move on instead of lingering all day. But after a day of sightseeing my feet were tired. I looked to purchase at the cafe so that I could have a seat but there were only 4 seats and were always unavailable (probably people like me who would buy an ice cream just to have a seat.)

Town with a Tower. Located in the districts of Narihira and Oshiage. Feel the Edo culture in this modern era. It is a broadcasting tower with facilities such as Tokyo Solamachi commercial products, an aquarium, planetarium, offices and etc.Advisable to take public transportation such as train or bus for your convenience travel experience (Tokyo Skytree Station) From the observation decks, you can view the entire Kanto region including Mount Fuji on sunny days. No need to worry on where to eat, lots of shops, cafes and restaurants inside and food stalls at the park around the tower. Worth it... Recommended!
Long queue. I came in 2013 it has a very long queue, and i came again in 2016 and still it has a very long queue, they really should do somthing about it

Great way to see Tokyo . Very nice way to see Tokyo. The sky tree has several floors on the main viewing platform. There you can find cafes shops and other small attractions like glass floors.From this first stop you can also go 100m further up to reach the second platform at 450m height. I would highly suggest to pay the extra 1000 yen to get up to that skywalk. There are not so many people on these high-floors and you can enjoy the view much better and relaxed!The only drawback of this attraction are the long queues and waiting time. I would recommend to go early morning and or late afternoon to avoid the long waiting times.

Sorry, but it didn't impress me.. Unfortunately I just didn't get the wow factor at all here.
