There are excellent 360 views and they've done a great job but I just felt that the skyline of Tokyo doesn't lend itself to this kind of tower as other cities do.For me I preferred more local sightseeing where we could enjoy Christmas lights or temples.

Do your pre-reading to avoid the queues. It’s a big observation platform; there are several in Tokyo including a free one at the municipal offices in Shinjuku which is a few kilometres closer to Mount Fuji. But, this is the tallest one so if you are into such things then at least follow the TA research to avoid the queues; there is a way if you are a foreigner.

Superb view from Tokyo. 350 meter high above Tokyo provides you with a superb view over tokyo and the surroundings. From there you are also able to see Mt. Fuji. You also have the possibility to go up an additional 100 meters, you get to go the additional 100 meters in a glass elevator so beware if you are scared of heights (Even thought the 350 meters might be tough this will surely test your will). It costs 2060 Yen for the first deck and 1030 extra for the second deck. Be sure to go on a day where there are no clouds and the wind isn't blowing too much

THERE IS MORE TO SEEN THAN THAN JUST A VIEWING AREA. This tower has several levels of viewing, they also offer several different actives. The lower floors are connected to another building (Sky Tree East Tower) which offers shopping and a huge food court. There are also several restaurants to enjoy. This is a fun place to go and you can spend as little time as you want or many hours. There is also a skating rink and an Aquarium between SkyTree and the East Tower.
Excellent Views. Excellent views over the city and chance to appreciate how big the city is. Staff very helpful and attentive. Lifts are very fast!

Tokyo Skytree should be on your "Trip to Tokyo" bucketlist. In 2012, Tokyo Skytree was unveiled to the public. A broadcasting, restaurant and observation tower in Sumida, Tokyo, the tower is the “tallest tower” in the world and the second tallest structure in the world.Tokyo Skytree also serves as the primary television and radio broadcast site for the Kanto region.As of 2015, Tokyo Skytree now has free Wi-Fi service and the location has a great view of the city via being on the first observatory deck (350m, Tokyo Skytree Tembo Deck) and the Tokyo Skytree Tembo Galleries (450m).I thought the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building had fast elevators but Tokyo Skytree is fascinating because of how quick you can move from the bottom floor all the way up to the Tembo Deck.While you can get advanced reservations through Tokyo Skytree Web Ticket, you can purchase day tickets from the 4th floor ticket counter but it’s best to get there early because its often crowded.But right after visiting Tokyo Sky Tree, definitely check out the shops, especially at Tokyo Solamachi.
Tokyo Skytree is beautiful and modern. Tokyo Skytree is beautiful and modern which is different from Tokyo Tower. There is a huge shopping centre beside here with lots of restaurants

Fantastic. We went on a rainy day and they did warn us visibility was bad. It was fun however to watch the rain squalls come across. It did clear slightly at one stage and we got a good view but not very far. The glass floor was great. Looking down from that height was really weird. Definatley go but hope for a good day!!

Views amazing . Looking up at the structure was amazing, once you get up inside the tower it gets even better.We went early morning and the skies were clear so we had an amazing view of Mount Fuji, nice relaxing drink in the coffee shopThe view of the whole of Tokyo was unbelievable you could see everything Definitely worth a visit

Birds eye view. We only had a day in free to take in the sights of Tokyo, we made our way easily on the subway to the Skytree station. The ticket level was all clearly marked in English from the subway to level 4. It was all very organised and a pleasant enough experience. Sadly the poor weather prohibited any great views but it was a good way to see the vastness of the City.

Fantastic views of Tokyo - a must see to appreciate the size of the city. We went in late afternoon on a cold and overcast day - no queues. Staff at entry very helpful and they found someone who could talk to us in English as we wanted to know what the views were like - apparently if you can see Yokohama then it is good to go. Such amazing views - we saw both the daylight then the night views. You get a great sense of how big Tokyo is. We didn't go to the highest platform as we thought we wouldn't get much better views than what we did. The glass viewing platform was fun. We thought the ticket price was very reasonable for such a great view and experience.

Great at dusk. Not the cheapest thing to do in Tokyo and it's definitely a challenge to find it using the underground, but it is a beautiful way to see the lights of Tokyo come alive in the early evening. The afternoon we were there, we were lucky enough to see across to Mt Fuji which was pretty cool. The kids get pretty bored rather quickly so get in and get those shots before the glass section of the floor looses its magic!!!

Perfect view of the whole Tokyo city. Went to top level it is a perfect place to see where in Tokyo you are and great view of the Tokyo city
It's better to take a binocular with you as it is always busy lots of people that you won't get to use the binoculars of the tower,( didn't see any)

Very nice better on a clear day. We visit on a rainy day which affected the view.
The tour to the tower is very well organized, greta place to take good pictures. The second platform is optional, put for us was worthy. The elevator has a glass roof, giving an interesting experience.
This tower is surrounded by a very nice shopping mall.

A must-do / must-see during Tokyo stay. This is a must-do / must-see during your Tokyo stay! We bought the international visitor express tickets to get in front of the line. Awesome views over the city if you go there on a clear day.

Must do it once while in Tokyo. The view was amazing from above, if the weather was good. Finding locations in Tokyo from the observation deck was fun and challenging. The glass floor part was thrilling for someone who's afraid of heights. To get up, you need to get in waiting line to retrieve a tie slot certificate first, and then come back at assigned time slot to get in. Or, if you're foreigner, an express ticket counter is available to put you in front of the lines with extra fee. To get to the observation deck requires one ticket from the lobby. Once up, you can buy another ticket to to further up. It was worth visiting, so make sure to plan enough time up there especially if need to wait a couple of hours downstairs.

Atrocious English standard by "English speaking" guides, loads of "blue" tape and staff who are very lost. Visited on the evening of 15th Feb 2016. Counter staff spoke very little comprehensible English, had absolutely no idea where the gift/snack shops are despite working there shops only 2 floors down (I realised this afterwards) and assisted by 2-3 of her colleagues. One of the dedicated English translators (she had a sign that says English) only spoke marginally better English.Advised me that it would be better to buy the snacks first before going up as it might be closed by the time I come down only to be hit with this ridiculous rule that visitors MUST go up immediately after ticket purchase. Do not pass go, do not collect $200, go straight up and refusing to lift the blue queue marking tapes to let me pass.

Magnificent tower in the heart of Tokyo . It's magnificent. It's worth visiting. A bit pricey though and could be quite a long queue. The shopping is interesting, with TV characters related items here and there.
Great place to view Tokyo. Wonderful architect and friendly staffs. I think this is a-must-see spot when you visit to Tokyo. Dont come if you fear of heights.

Simply Spectacular!. I visited the Tokyo Skytree with a friend in September 2015. As it is the 2nd tallest viewing platform in the world I was keen to experience what it was like to be that high above the city! It was breathtaking! What particularly surprised me was how cheap it was, only around 2000¥, (about £10). You get a guide book and the whole place is lined with information boards. The only problem I have with it is how hard it is to take good photos at night, but that's going to be the case in this sort of environment. Absolutely recommended! Go just before the sun set, that way you can see Tokyo by day and by night! On a clear day you can see Mount Fuji!

Very good views of Tokyo. We visited the Tokyo Skytree on our first day in Tokyo. We purchased tickets in advance which was a good idea. The lines were quite long. The advance ticket holders had a fairly short line to get on the elevators. Once on top, it was not as crowded as I expected given the long lines below. The views of Tokyo are incredible from that height. You really get a sense for how big the city is as the buildings just seem to go on forever.There is a small shop at the top that sells coffees and snacks where we had some ice cream. They put corn flakes in the bottom of the vanilla ice cream cups which was quite tasty.The Tokyo Skytree is attached to a fairly big shopping mall. We spent a few hours in the shopping mall afterwards and also had lunch there.

Good but entrance fee is bit too pricy. One of the must to go place now in Tokyo! Well built attraction. Basic entrance fee can climb up to 350m high, if you want to go 100m higher then pay extra when you are at 350m label. View was very nice and even beyond Mt.Fuji can be seen if the air condition is good.

Lankmark full of restaurants and souvenir stores. In my opinion, skytree tower is nice looking outsides. Besides, I feel surprised there are many great stores in Solamachi, a shopping mall connecting with skytree tower. We one day enjoying Japanese food and buying souvenir here, and really had much fun. This is a must-visit if you are visiting Tokyo for the first time.

Breathtaking view of Tokyo. This is the best place to see all of Tokyo from one location! Amazing to see the ocean, rivers and so many high rise that don't look so high from the top of the sky tree. Not for those with fear of heights!

Shy high . We are generally not such a big fan of towers and their observation decks, but we were hopeful to see My. Fuji. We could only make out the faint outline of the mountain but we at least got a nice view of the city. As with most towers there was a long line to go up and limited space to look out, and the price wa even fairly steep for an attraction in Tokyo (considering so many of the best are free.). As with any tower it is best to go up when you actually have an idea what you are looking for, so it is better to go later on in one's time in the city but even then it is not really worth the time or money.
Amazing Engineering. Observation tower, restaurant and broadcasting tower all rolled into one impressive piece of engineering. At last check, it was the tallest tower in the world.

another shopping centre. There is a big supermarket inside the shopping area. If you have children below 16, especially girls, this is a place which they love very much because it has all kinds of Japanese cartoons shop inside. Lots of gifts items for quests to choose. If you want to go up the skytree, do not forget to buy ticket from internet beforehand to save your time of queuing up. Sometimes, if there is a crowd, you cannot buy ticket and enter. You may be required to get a number and wait to go to buy ticket at a certain hour of a day.

Great view on a sunny day. We arrived about 2pm. It was very crowded, but I'm sure that was because it was a sunny day. Splurge the extra Y800 per adult for the fast pass. That probably saved us an hour or more wait. Views were amazing. I want to go back on a clear night!

Great view!. 風景超美，還有一些有趣的拍攝小站讓遊客攝影留念。最高樓層的風景對我來說沒有太大差異，不過這裡的人潮比較少，可以放鬆一點等待日落。（但是沒有椅子）通往最高樓層的電梯也有景觀可看，但是電梯跑太快了所以只能看幾秒鐘。逛街的地方滿多不錯的店，像是利久牛舌，還能買電視台的官方周邊。我們平日下午兩點多去買票不會排很久，大約15分鐘而已。但是要看日落的話這時間太早了。Great view and interesting photo shooting stands bring you the greatest memories in Tokyo. The view in the highest floor doesn't look different than the other floors to me, but it's not so crowded there. The elevators going up to the highest floor also provide great view, but you can see them just in few seconds because the elevators are going very fast. In the shopping mall down there, you can find a lot of great restaurants, like 利久牛舌.
Great view of Tokyo - make sure you get up to the top. Great views of Tokyo from Above, especially at Sunset. Make sure that you pay an extra $8 to skip the line - it is well worth your hour.
Tallest structure in the world.. The line might be long but its worth it. Ideal for oberservation deck lovers, the skytree doesnt disappoint. The panoramic views of the city are incredible.

Awsome views and piece of engineering.. This new landmark will become a must in everyones visit to Tokyo. Something very nice is that they have screens with cctv showing the actual view at 350 mts, so you can actually if the view is fine to buy the ticket. Remember that tickets for the 450 m platform need to be bought at the 350 m deck. Views are nice and as every attraction in Japan, staff is extremely friendly, and all is neat and clean!

An afternoon at Skytree. Went with the option of "fast lane for international visitors" to reduce the waiting time to get to the Tembo deck (350m).After going around taking photos and having a snack, proceeded to purchase additional tickets to visit the Tembo Galleria (450m).There was a Star Wars Sky Walk exhibition that was ongoing at the time of visit to the Tembo Galleria, which is a nice plus for Star Wars fans.Personally, I preferred to take photos of the scenery from the Tembo deck, although there were some views that were obstructed because of the photo booths and snack outlet.The Tembo Galleria was enjoyable because the view was from a higher elevation, and there was a glass floor section where you can walk on, look through, and see the bottom of the tower (the glass floor only occupies a small section).

One of the tallest building. Came under the guided tour and was brought to one of the tallest building... It was so tall that I find it difficult to take the whole tower with my camera. Did not manage to go up to the observation deck as I would if it is sunrise or sunset. Beautiful structure and it looks as if it is slant sideway as due to human eyes and standing location. Beside that, there is a mega mall where you can shop around

I am at the top of Tokyo!!. I visited Tokyo Skaytree at the end of my trip.. last day before i am going back to the airport.. It is just like saying goodbye to Tokyo.. Deep inside my heart... i am going to miss Japan and their people.. This land changing my view.. opened my eyes and gave me so many experiences.. that i will not forget for the rest of my life..

TOKYO SKYTREE - A MUST IN TOKYO. Tokyo Skytree is an exciting place to visit if you are a regular visitors to towers around the world and Tokyo is no exception. There are several towers in Tokyo that we can actually see Tokyo City from a high point. The famous one in red colour is of course the Tokyo Tower. The popularity of Tokyo Tower is severely affected by the coming into being - Tokyo Skytree which is higher and almost double that of Tokyo Tower.There are 2 levels at Tokyo Skytree. The first level, entrance tickets could be purchased through on-line whereas the second level it can only be bought at the first level when you are actually there and not offered for on-line purchase. Purchasing the tickets on-site is cheaper than buying them on-line. Depending on the month and day we are visiting, basically it is quite easy to purchase the tickets on-site. The main problem of buying tickets on-line would be the weather at that time. If the weather is cloudy there is nothing much to be seen. But buying the tickets on-sight will offer the flexibility to wait for a clear sky.It is advisable to spend a little bit more to visit the second level which by far is not that crowded and we can take better pictures than from the first level. The structure at the second level is also different from the one at the first level and it is much more better looking and a better view. Dont missthe second level just because we need to pay extra, as it is definately worth it.The best view of the whole building of Skytree could be taken once we reach the Asakusa Nakamise shopping district where the famous Temple is located. Due to its height we could not take the photo from the underneath of the buildind but have to be slightly far away to have a good view.The Tokyo Skytree is connected to a big shopping mall and they have good selection of local and international brands and we found them much cheaper than at Ginza or Otomesendo Hill . In fact we took the advantage to shop here instead of the City Centre. There are a variety of eating places around the Tokyo Skytree and it would take a whole day trip from going to the Tokyo SkytreeTower followed by shopping around it and then proceed to Asakusa Nakamise shopping street.We cannot imagine going for the first time to Tokyo without visiting the Tokyo Skytree. You can miss the free tower at the Government Metropolitan Building or the one at Ropponggi or even the Tokyo Tower but not the Tokyo Skytree. So if you are in Tokyo make an effort to visit Tokyo Skytree as it is a MUST when in Tokyo.Saharudin & MariamReporting 10.02.2016Visiting November 2015

OK but pick a clear day. We had kind of a hard time finding this via the subway due to having to change trains twice so we got there around dusk. Between an overcast day and being dusk the views were not the greatest. Actually the electronic display which you can control was almost as much fun as the tower views themselves. We did not go to the top viewing platform due to the weather conditions. The good news about the timing was the lines were very short. We had a restaurant reservation in Shinjuku so we were a little pressed for time. I think with better scheduling and weather this would have been great but as it was for our trip it was just OK.

Worth the view. So I read lots about the lines, and perhaps just lucky, but we were able to secure tickets after only a 10 minute wait. Being from Canada, we asked about the jump the line option with passport, but the girl was rather fair and said that it may not be worth the extra 700Y as the wait was only 10 minutes. It was, and it was SOO worth going. This structure (only 3 years old) is soo nice it blows the CN Tower away. But the views are outstanding and it really puts into perspective the size of the world's largest city. Did the additional high deck and would go if you are there. We went at around 4PM and were able to hang out and see day views, but also the turn to dusk and night. Impressive. Note the Star Wars exhibit is not too much to write home about (but think this installation is ending soon)
Tokyo Skytree. Wonderful views from the observation level - can walk all the way around to see 360° panoramas. This attraction is a must visit if in Tokyo.

Great Views!!. If you have extra time in Tokyo on a clear day, it is worth the 2160 yen to go to the 350 meter level. Great views. If you can, get there early before the lines get long. It opened at 10am last Saturday. Not sure of everyday schedule. There is a small cafe on the viewing deck. Limited options and a little pricey. I did not try the cafe. I would do the SkyTree again on a future trip!

brilliant view. Amazing view, beautiful surroundings and the restaurant was a fantastic experience.Highly recommended to visit and if you have the time and money definitely attend the restaurant for dinner
Go! Go!. Amazing views!! Well worth it and not too many people! Also a Penguin aquarium and tons of places to eat! This was a pleasant surprise as we were transiting to our hotel!
Upper deck was just ripp off. Went there and lower deck was ok but upper was just waste of time. Upper deck was filled with star wars crap and blocked all the city view.

Make Reservations!. This is a must see adventure while in Tokyo; the shopping and the experience is well worth the effort. The subway station is actually located inside at the base of the Sky Tree. Make internet reservations at least a day or two in advance; if not you will be waiting in a long line to get a time to purchase your tickets, then wait for your ticket time... While you are there, visit one of the excellent restaurants and do some shopping!

So many lights!!!. A great way to take in Tokyo! It is a great experience at night. Very beautiful!The line up was huge but amazingly quick to buy a ticket and go up!Not cheap but worth it!Go all the way up to 450m!! The lift from 350m to 450m is see through!!!

Best of the tall towers .... I've been up all of them, Eiffel Tower, Petronas tower, Empire State Building etc. but this was the best one, good views on different levels and there was a Star Wars theme when we were there for added savoir faire. When you get up to the first level at 350m or so there's an option to go another 100m which was more loot of course but worth it. If it's clear enough you can see Mt Fujii, but the force will have to be with you for really clear conditions. Night view would be a whole different experience for sure.

On the way to the top . I went on a sunny day, which makes it a lot better, because the view is a 1000 times better and you can see along way out. I also visit the sky gallery which had an Star Wars thing, which also was great if you are into that, all in all a great day. A I can really recommend this, just check the weather for maximum effect.

Amazing place to visit. It is a new but a great place with surrounding park and river. With the existing Tokyo Tower, Skytree is really nice spot for everyone. It is alsk great to have its night view from Asakusa area.

Birds Eye View and lovely when the sun goes down!. I have lived in Japan for over 3 years now and previous efforts to get into the Skytree on a weekend did not materialise as I had to buy a ticket in the morning and return late afternoon just to get in due to its popularity. Admittedly the Skytree was completed in 2012 so still relatively new at the time. Some 3 years later the ques are not as bad. This time around we went on Friday around midday and did not have the same problem. We waited in line for tickets for about 30 minutes before going up into the Skytree. Tickets can be purchased on the day at the 4th floor Ticket Counter or they can be bought in advance online for a fixed date and time or from Seven eleven stores which costs more. If bought at the venue, the tickets cost ¥2060 for adults, ¥1540 for 12-17 year olds, ¥930 for 6-11 year olds and ¥620 for 4-5 year olds. This ticket price takes you to the Tembo Deck. (Advance purchased tickets for a reserved date and time cost about ¥500 more per ticket for each age group). There is also a Fast Skytree ticket which costs ¥2820 for an adult. The Tembo Deck takes you about 3 quarters of the way up the tower. If you want to go to the Tembo Galleria which is higher, you need to buy an extra ticket when you get to the Tembo Deck. For an adult, that costs an extra ¥1030 for an adult and can only be bought on the day when you get there. So for an adult wanting to go to the top (Tembo Deck) you pay ¥3090 for a ticket- not cheap!Is is worth it? You still get a pretty amazing view from the Tembo Deck but we forked out the extra and went to the top. At the moment there is a STAR WARS themed display going on in Tembo Galleria. The Galleria also has a nice sloped walkway that winds itself around the tower. The views are incredible and really give a great sense of how huge and concentrated a city Tokyo is. I have been up the free Tokyo Metropolitan Building in Shinjuku but the perspective from Tokyo Skytree was more impressive with views of the Sumida river and Tokyo Bay. On a really clear day, you can also see Mt Fuji.We got there in the afternoon and waited until sunset to take amazing photos of the sunset and also the views at night when the lights came on. There is a bar and restaurant on floor 345 which has some of the best views and would be a great place for a romantic dinner. There is also a Tokyo Skytree cafe on floor 350 that sells a limited selection of drinks and icecream.However I would suggest eating before or afterwards at the incredibly large food and shopping complex below the tower which has an extensive array of food choices and souvenirs. One of the best places to buy Japanese souvenirs in Tokyo!The Skytree is right next to OSHIAGE train station and apparently there is a Skytree Shuttle bus available from Haneda Airport, Tokyo station, Ueno Station and Tokyo Disney Resort.The Skytree is opened from 8am to 10pm every day. I suggest combining a visit to the Skytree with a trip to see Sensoji temple in nearby Asakusa.

Only way to see ALL of Tokyo!. I knew that the SkyTree would be a valuable visit but we didn't book tickets ahead due to weather concerns. We woke up early on Sunday morning and saw blue skies and decided to hot tail it over to the SkyTree. There wasn't a line and we were able to get up to the upper level in a hurry.WOW! What a view. Tokyo is just an enormous city and the SkyTree allows you to see the mammoth scale of it in a hurry.There were some cool features including a touch screen display that detailed the locations that could be seen out of the windows.

Great view. We almost didn't go because it was Sunday and knew it would be crowded but since it's open until 10pm we made a late run around 8:30 pm. There was a line for foreign visitors that got you in a little faster for about 300 yen more and save 20 minutes of your life. Great views of all around Tokyo and one more really big building off our bucket list, worth the trip and don't forget the shopping downstairs.This is obvious but I heard some comments at our hotel, if you go on a cloudy/rainy day your going to get a great view of the clouds... If you can't see the tower from outside just go shopping etc instead.

Great Vista of Tokyo and beyond !. What a great experience ( even with vertigo ! ) fantastic views but not 360 degree on lower platform.. Photo boots and coffee , and gift shop set against outer glass tend to obstruct the view and concentrate the crowds into certain areas.. extra cost to go to the top level,,,

Outstanding!!. Very easy to get too using the subway and amazing to see from the outside. The views from the top are incredible, a great way to see some amazing engineering and a good way to spend part of the day.

Amazing view . Almost didn't go here, but I'm glad j did. The view is amazing. You can see all around Tokyo from here. Try to go on a clear day with now clouds. At the bottom there is also great shopping. I recommend taking some time to shop here. There are two restaurants at the top but they are fairly expensive. I'm sure the view will eating would be lovely, but not sure if it's worth the cost.

Six Day Trip to Japan. This is a must visit attraction in the incredible city of Tokyo! The Skytree Tower has the distinction of being the tallest tower in the world, standing some 634 metres (2080 ft) tall. You can go to the Tembo Deck on floor 350 and enjoy the spectacular views across the city, or come down a little to floor 340 and stand on the glass panels if you are good with heights! There is also the Tembo Galleria which is on floors 445- 450 but you do have to pay a second time to go up to the Galleria. One piece of advice, if you are thinking of visiting this iconic tower, try and avoid the weekends, otherwise you will have to join the long queues of Japanese also wanting to take in the spectacular views.
Exciting tower. Its an exciting tower to be on. However its quite expensive if you are trying to reach with your wholr family... but you can reach from Ashakusha very easily.
Nice Skyline. at 340m, you can see the whole of Tokyo. Went there in the evening to witness the beautiful nightlights of Tokyo. beware, its kinda of a long queue!

Incredible View. This is a must when in Tokyo. Very good view from 2 observation decks. Also, has a floor where you can see directly below you. Also if lucky like me, you can have a clear, unobstructed view of Mt. Fuji.
Breathtaking views. The Skytree provides incredible views of Tokyo, weather permitting. The lifts that carry you to the top are so fast they make your ears pop!
Fantastic view. Worth paying the extra to get right to the top, view is breath taking and couldn't believe how large Tokyo was ... Must see!

If the weather is bad and you don't like blingy shops, avoid. On the plus side is that, for internationals, the Skytree has a fasttrack opportunity (for an additional fee). Otherwise, the wait can be long. There was zero visibility the night I went there, but there were still crowds. Getting up to the Skytree entrance requires going through a crazy maze of Japanese touristy shopping.

Great view, great mall. Me and my partner went to Skytree on the Tuesday right after the Coming of Age Day holiday, which probably explained why there was no line up at all at the ticket counter. We got our tickets in 2 minutes and was ushered to the elevators. The view up at the deck was outstanding, although the day we went was cloudy and windy with a few light flurries. We did not pay any extra $ to go up one level or enter the Star Wars attraction there. Since there was only a few people visiting the deck, we were able to take pictures to our heart content. We finished our walk in less than 40 mins and the came back down to earth, where we visited the mall. The mall was filled with many great looking eateries. We had lunch at around 11:10am at a Chinese food eatery, which was excellent. All the places began filling up by noon, so if you don't want to wait, you need to go early. We then hung around a huge and spacious Starbucks, where we were able to order a hot tea (you have to really point exactly at the menu as to what you want!). I don't think i will go up to Skytree again next time I am in Tokyo, but for sure I will visit this mall again and spend more time and energy (and money) there!

A costly experience that may not be necessary. You have many options, but if you want to go to the highest it's here.. Cost was around 3,800 Yen for the "fast" ticket. (If you don't want to wait in line for 45 minutes on a less packed day, this is your only option unfortunately. Even with the "fast" ticket we still waited 15 minutes for the elevator.) We then paid another 1,000 Yen + to go to the next observatory higher up to see the new Star Wars themed area. Cost of transportation, ascension, and wait is near 5,000 Yen. I highly suggest other alternatives such as the Bunkyo Civic Center, Tokyo Tower, or the Tokyo government building observatory. They are far less costly and give a clearer view. (Obviously less high up.) So unless you absolutely must be at the tallest point in Tokyo, I highly recommend saving your money and going with the free / nearly free options listed above.

Enjoyed some magnificent views. Decided to visit the Tokyo Skytree spontaneously on a clear sky morning.Reached by 9 am. Few visitor, I did not have to queue at all.Great views all over Tokyo, unfortunately there was some fog over Shinjuku and could not see Mount Fuji.I paid both tickets (Tambo and observation decks). Some impressive views in the last elevator. Currently there is a Starwars exhibition on the top which is quite funny.

shopping mall better than tower view. i have que for 1-2 hours to buy ticket for see viewbut too many people i only can walk with people, did not have some time to sit down and enjoy viewin the skytree 1/F to 5/F, there have many japan famous shop and convenience to try food

Great views. Great views from the tower -first level, but we did have to wait for an hour to get up and 20mins to get down. Cost AUD$75 for 1 adults & 2 kids. Also it was incredibly packed, which was expected over the New Year period. Also as it is so large it is difficult to panaromic photos due to the windows and rails keeping you off the windows. Might be better further up but at another cost and more time queuing we had reached our limit.Good during the day but i enjoyed it more at night with the lights.

Not a tourist trap.. This has a reputation as a tourist trap. I'm not sure why. The view is exceptional, forget the Parliament Buildings view, this is the one. I was very fortunate to see Mt Fuji from up here, the skyscrapers you see at ground level are far below. This view is something I will not forget and I've travelled the world. Get here first thing in the morning, there will be no queue to get in, but even then you may have to queue at the top to get down again.

Busy. Go early, this place gets very busy with tour groups. You have to pay to get up to the observation decks but the lower levels are open access.Heaps of shops and restaurants, good views. Shops include the flagship nanoblock store - worth a stop for fans. Lights up at night.

A must for any first timer in Tokyo . If you come to Tokyo and not go up the skytree something is not right. If you don't go early the queues can get ridiculously long, but for tourists (if you don't mind paying a little more) there's a fast skytree ticket counter available so you can skip the queues and go right on up immediately. Fantastic 360 degree view of Tokyo.

SUPREME. Wow!!!!! Over 300 metres above ground and a stunning 360 degree view of the entire city.... How can you not come??? I kept taking pictures of the entire panorama..... So mesmerising and memorable. I think the crowds should convince you to visit this marvellous architectural and technological beauty :)

Crowded... Still worth it. . One of the most popular sites to see in Tokyo...with that expect crowds like in Disneyland. Lines for the ticket, lines for the elevator, and once you get to the top, crowds of people occupying all window space. Yet, it's still worth it. It is very well organized, clean, with staff escorting you all the way through. On the bottom, there is tons of shopping, and I mean a lot. Lots of traditional Japanese stores. Recommend going during the week if possible. Can't miss this one when visiting Tokyo. Walking distance to Asahi HQ for the Sky Bar.

Breathtaking. We went there after our last tour, evening, it was full! My suggestion is got there in the early hours when they open, so it wont be too crowded, thats what we did in Tokyo Tower. And worth it!
Great view!. Highest place in Tokyo, if you thinking to visit this city, that is place to start, amazing view! Tower is 650m high, first viewing floor 350m, second 450m. Lift is really fast ;)

If you in tokyo and don't visit this then make sure you learn the art of kicking yourself. It's a must visit when you in tokyo The architectural Beauty and the height is just phenomenal and it completes tokyo the same way Eiffel Tower completed parisOpen till late at nigh And according to me it's more beautiful at night but I cannot commit to the statement as I never went in the morning Try to go to the top and just enjoy the view the 360 degrees view deck is beautifully constructed

Be prepared...to wait. Tokyo Skytree is one of those "must do" attractions, given its height and the fact it's in such a buzzing city. Once you get up there, you can see very far into the distance, and even at night the city looks spectacular. On our visit there was a Star Wars exhibition, which was superb.The only drawback is the Skytree's popularity, which means you can wait two hours or so to reach the ticket desk, then more time to reach the elevators, and then have to wait to get close to the windows for photos, and then have to wait to get back to ground level. If you're aware of this beforehand, then you shouldn't be disappointed.

Long waiting time to buy ticket but the view is worth it. Tokyo Skytree is one of the well-known landmarks of Tokyo and was actually built to be a television broadcasting tower. It’s design is said to be a fusion of traditional Japanese beauty and neo-futuristic design. With a height of 634 meters and 450 floors, it is also the world’s largest free standing broadcasting tower. Admission to the lower observation deck is priced at 2,000 yen. Tickets to the upper observation deck will cost an additional 1,000 yen and have to be purchased on the lower observation deck. Be prepared for to wait in line for hours though!

Amazing views but were tricked into spending more! Watch out!. In Japan, 99% of the things run perfect. People are educated, proud, service oriented and very friendly...that is why the Tokyo Skytree may be an easy trap. When I arrived with my family, at the moment of purchasing the tickets to visit their top floor, the lady at the counter told me I should by the VIP Fas Access tickets (Obviously much more expensive) because the waiting time for "normal people" was around 30 minutes. No doubt. We purchased the expensive fare and to my surprise, the normal waiting line was...like 30 seconds. We boarded the elevator at the same time. This was the only case in Japan were a sales clerk lied. Watch out!

A great way to see Japan. This visit proved to be a really fantastic experience and you'll get to see so much of Japan in an instant.One tip I would share is to pay the premium to get onto the express queue. It costs more but would you rather queue for five minutes or 90 minutes?I only planned to spend an hour up there but time flew by and the fascinating views kept me up in the Sky Tree for three hours.A very worthwhile experience.

Great but too many people. It has an awesome view from the 4th floor where you buy tickets to get to the top of the tower. It has many souvenir shops with the sky tree picture, beautiful clothes, samurai toys and foods. It is worth your time to visit here but then the queue to buy tickets are always long, regardless during the morning or evening. So if you have the patience, I would bet it would be an even greater view. It also has an ice skating rink for everyone to play. It is a great place to visit.

Tallest Building, Best View. The Skytree is the tallest building in Tokyo 634m (2,080ft) as of 2015, and this make it the de facto place to see the panoramic view of this great city. On a good day, you can see Mt. Fuji from here. On a cloudy day, it has a different atmosphere. You may not see far, but you can still feel like you are on top of the world / or Tokyo rather. Besides the sightseeing, Tokyo Skytree is connected to a big shopping / dining structure which one can easily spend a day. This should be a must visit, if you were not afraid of height.Go early in the morning or late at night to avoid the long line. Make reservation / advanced purchase if possible.

Amazing views!. Great attraction! It is very crowded but the chaos moves efficiently and quickly. Like any typical major attraction, the food isn't cheap. It was dusk and clear when we went so we were able to get a shot of Mt. Fuji. It was much clearer than what my iPhone could capture.
What a view!. If you want views, then go up the Tokyo Skytree. WOW!On a clear day you can see Mount Fuji. The views from up here are spectacular!You can pretty much see all of Japan from up here.

Sky is the limit. We got to the Skytree early in the evening, bcoz it was our last stop after our Tour, and it was full, i would suggest that you go there in the morning, maybe there wont be so many people.

Incredible views of Tokyo. This is a great place to see how incredibly big Tokyo is! If the day is clear, you will get a chance to view Mount Fuji over the city.We went there early January and it was busy since a lot of people were on vacation. It is not always clear where to get tickets and they orient international travelers quickly towards skip the line tickets which are a little more expensive than regular tickets, be aware of that.

One of the best!. I loved this place so much!Good shops, but not so cheap.Great view, clean and people there are beautiful too!We could find the tokyo banana, finally, and there's a station (Oshiage) right under it.Great!!!

Worth a visit. Even on a cloudy day we got good views. Recommend a coffee in the cafe where you can sit and look out over the city. Also think visiting at end of day so you get night views too would be worthwhile.

Great Views. I went to this in the evening shortly before closing time and was able to enjoy views all around. There are 2 levels to visit. the first level you buy a ticket for on the 4th floor. The second level you have to buy way up top and it takes you even further up. I paid for both and was excited to see the Star Wars tie in on the second higher level.

Fabulous views and no queue's !!. We went on the 31st December and luckily we had a Japanese tour guide as she made a point of obtaining some ticket type pieces of paper that allocate a specific time to purchase the real tickets. We walked around the shopping mall for a while before heading back to buy our tickets. There was only a few minutes wait to get in one of the lifts and up we went. My grandchildren were delighted with some sort of Japanese children's character that was posing for photographs for free. The viewing floors were not crowded and we could easily move around and also take photo's on the glass floor section. Our visit was around 11am I think so if you're considering going, go as early as possible to avoid the crowds we saw starting to build up when we exited. The views are just great and we took many photo's. Definitely worth the time and money.

Overpriced but interesting. We were there during December. There was a very long queue. We bought some tickets which gave us priority. The view was interesting. Almost the same though can be seen for free in the City Town Hall.

wonderful view. Going up the tower to 350m high you get a 360 view of all of Tokyo and you can see Mt Fuji in the distance on a clear day.The lobby has a very interesting display of the concepts of the tower if you're into that. There is a huge que to get to the tickets and elevator so you've got to be patient. Many attractions at the base of the tower and restaurants and a mall for entertainment.

View From Sumida Park (across a canal). We only view the skytree at Sumida Park, which is across a canal on the other side of the Tokyo skytree. We just take a brief walk to this park after visiting Sensoji Temple. Hmm... I still prefer Tokyo Tower.

Fantastic view with high price. We visit this place on New Year's eve. It has very long queue for buying tickets. We experienced the night view of Tokyo and if you come at day time you can see Mt. Fuji from this place. There is the higher level of the tower but cost you another ticket. So if you want to access all area you have to pay about 4000 yen. In my opinion, it's worth the money.

An Incredible View of Tokyo. The highest radio tower (634m) in the smack centre of Tokyo. If you want to take a look at the whole city of Tokyo metropolitan area, this is the place to go. It definitely worths a visit!

Awesome view of the city!. This place really puts into perspective the size of Tokyo!! When we arrived the line looked massive!! It was a public holiday so we did expect it! Then someone mentioned there was another entry for foreigners. So you can go to the next entry and pay another maybe $8 AUD equivalent. Then we pretty much went straight to the front and into the lift. This takes you to the first viewing platform which is pretty impressive. But we came this far may as well pay an extra $10 and go right to the top! The view was amazing! Could see right to MT Fuji whem it's clear. Then another short line to head back down. There is a cafe on the first deck but we didn't try anything. All up it cost around $30 Australian I think. Worth it for sure! Tallest tower in the world an all!!

Vaguely disappointing. We really were looking forward to going up the Skytree and paid 2100 yen for each ticket. That only takes you up to the first viewing level. If you want to go to the second level you have to queue again and pay more!

Magnificent views. I chose this tower instead of the Tokyo tower as this one is much taller.There are huge crowds but if you are a foreigner there is a special queue where you won't wait long to buy tickets,there you buy tickets to the lower deck, tickets to the second and higher deck are sold in the lower deck and are optional. Once you have bought your ticket you'll be guided by the polite staff and jump the long queue (another perk for foreigners) the lift.I recommend going an hour before the sun sets, find a location to take some amazing pictures when the sun starts going down, you'll see the sun setting right next to Mount Fuji, people go bananas with this setting, after that the city starts to get lit up, ready your camera again and take pictures of the magnificent night views of tokyo. The lower levels of the first observation deck are much more quiet and not crowded.This is not a cheap attraction but it's worth the expense.

A must go place in Tokyo . As a foreigner you have the option of showing your passport at a corner entrance and skip the lines, but it costs extra. Up there you have the most beautiful view of Tokyo. Don't miss the stores on the lower floor.

AWESOME FOOD HALL. There is a small fee to go up the Skytree. My husband and I chose not to pay it but saved the money for the great food that were sold at Tokyo Solamochi, the giant food hall at the bottom level of Tokyo Skytree. Recommend the Tokyo Banana cakes (original Tokyo Banana, Chocolate Tokyo Banana, strawberry flavored Tokyo Banana, and Strawberry cakes), green tea Kit Kat, strawberry cheesecake flavored Kit Kat, and so many more! Besides packaged gift sets, the Solamochi also offers a great variety of food (real food). Recommended time spent - 1-2 hours.

Fantastic, out of this world view. The view during the day was breathtaking. It also looks magnificent from all directions. Circular observation deck allows panoramic views of the city.The lift taking you to the top is fast, quiet and jerk free, a real pleasure.

Great to see, but huge crowds.. Very impressive Skytree with amazing view up top. Do yourself a favour and go all the way to the very top (extra 1050 yen). They have displays and exhibitions up there and you get the best view. Be prepared for a very long waiting period though, about 60 - 90 minutes. I believe there is an option to buy web tickets on their website which would significantly cut down the waiting time.

With a height of 634m; be at the World’s Tallest Tower. A visit to this Guinness recorded landmark can be exhausting especially on a very busy weekend because this is one of the spots that are really flooded by tourists. If you want to get away of dreadfully waiting in long lines, you could always opt to purchase a “Fast Skytree Ticket” which only cost addition JPY780 from a regular walk-in ticket price of JPY2060 (ticket prices quoted are for adults). The “TEMBO DECK” tickets can be purchased at the 4th floor, while the “TEMBO GALLERIA” tickets, which will costs additional JPY1030, can be purchased at the 350th floor. The elevator ride was really amazing, where other building’s elevators goes up by floors; this one, goes up by 5 to 10 or more meters. Should you wish to have a good view of its surroundings, including Mt Fuji visit the tower during the day. Or, if you are more into city lights visit the tower during night time. There are a lot of things that you can do inside the tower, aside from shopping for souvenirs at floors 1, 5 and 345, you can eat your hearts out at Skytree Café at floors 340 and 350, or have a cozy cuisine while enjoying an astonishing view from the the 345th floor. Take an “air walk” from 445th floor up to 450th on a 110-meter sloped with audio effects that changes together with the weather and season. Upon reaching 450th floor, be a little more adventurous by trying the “SORAKARA POINT” that will give you a sensation of floating, with its ethereal lighting and mirrored walls. Make sure to savor your time and capture all the moments before leaving since re-entry is not allowed. Just sway with the building and enjoy!

Great views, but too crowded.. Since this attraction was not included in our package tour itinerary, we decided to check out the "tallest building in Japan and 2nd tallest structure in the world" on our free day. Coming in you go through lots of small shops and would have loved to browse through the merchandise, but it was just too crowded for comfort. Very long queues for tickets and the lift up (Tembo Shuttle), but waiting time was not too long as crowds are moved with typical Japanese efficiency. Impressive 360-degree view of Tokyo, with acrophobic glass floor at the 350-meter deck. Then you need to pay extra to take lift up to 450 meters where it is less crowded. Quite an experience, but wished there were less people to enjoy it with.

Good area to.walk around.and dine. Many small shops, many restaurants, food court with higher end places to eat. Theres a store that sells great japanese cheese cakes (i never was a fan till i tried this one). Connected to train station. Nice to visit at night
View from my hotel window. Loved the lights on the Tokyo Sky Tree. Definitely colorful and interesting, but even at night, it felt friendly and non-intrusive.

Overcrowded and long queues. We visited Skytree on a Saturday and it was so busy. It took us 2 hours to finally get to the observatory deck due to long queues to buy tickets and long queues to get into the lift. The observatory deck was overcrowded, we had to wait til people on the front were finished taking photos & selfies before we got the chance to move forward and enjoy the view of Tokyo. It took us another hour to line up to get into the lift on our way back to the ground floor. It was a very exhausting day.

Stunning views . This is of course on your must see list of Tokyo. This is beautiful. I work close by and see it from my office window. It can be ready admired for its size when seen close. View from top is breathtaking. Both levels. If you are visiting Japan you can through express counter. It's fast and is explicit for foreigners. And don't forget to relish a cofee in sky restaurant with Amazing views. Go in late afternoon and stay until night so that you can enjoy great city views of daylight and night through twilight. I totally recommend this place. Weekends are crazy crowded. Try weekdays if there is a chance. ✌

Definitely worth a visit. I had always avoided visiting the Tokyo Sky Tree because of the long lines, the crowds and because I had always thought it would be a giant tall tourist trap. But on this last trip, we decided to finally visit on Christmas Day. Because we got there about 10 a.m, it took us less than 10 minutes to line up and get to the Observation Deck. The views are fantastic and since it was a bright and sunny day, we really enjoyed seeing Tokyo spread out before us. There are many small shops and restaurants in the Sky Tree Complex and there is even a small but good aquarium. The Sky Tree is worth a visit particularly to repeat visitors of Tokyo who have seen the other more famous tourists attractions and would like to try something new.

Great view. Tokyo Skytree is fairly new and because of it the lines are long. There is a line for foreign tourists that is a lot faster but there is a fee I don't believe is worth it. Faster or not, in the end it is all the same. My advice is to arrive early to buy the ticket. The view is great, you can see everything from the top and even, on great weather, it's possible to see Mt. Fuji.
Amazing!. Since it's just a walk away from Asakusa, me and my wife decided to take a look at the Skytree.Amazingly it's is all worthy.

Loved the Star Wars exhibit at the top. We didn't book any tickets in advance but when we got there, decided to just buy the ticket which allowed us to go up to the top the fastest (no waiting time). I think as a tourist, this is worth it if you don't have much time. There was a nice Star Wars exhibit at the topmost section. We had a lovely view that day although we could not see Mt Fuji. Lots of places to have a meal/coffee at the bottom of the Skytree as well.

nice view. We can see the whole view of Tokyo on the tower. I was very happy to see Mt. Fuji. However, it is difficult to take photos with people and view together because of the light. It is worth to pay for a professional photo. It is interesting to stand on the "glass floor" even the area is much smaller than I expected. Our family took a photo there by the professional photographer. They gave us a small 2R photo as a small gift. Lovely treat! The lift is very fast but stable! you won't feel much except your ears would feel the pressure changes.

Impressive View. Go really early...long ticket lines started almost from the moment they opened at 8:00 a.m. We got there at about 8:30 and waited 20 minutes in line for tickets. Then wait for elevator, then wait in another line for tickets to the upper observation deck, then wait for upper elevator, then wait for elevator to come down. A LOT of people visit. Also recommend getting tickets online, then going to Will Call (NO LINE!) to pick up tickets...wish I had known that! Prepare to spend ¥4000 to get to first observation deck, ¥1500 to take the "nice" official photo, then another ¥2000 to top observation deck. There's another 2-3 photo vendors each at ¥1500. There's also a souvenir shop up at the top, and another at the bottom. If you shop at top, ensure you look for a sticker that indicates "this item is only sold up here". Kinda crowded, lots of lines, but the breathtaking view on a clear day to Mount Fuji and around Tokyo makes it worth the time and money.
Amazing views. Easy to reach but in my opinion the ticket price is a little bit too expensive. Amazing views, even though we did not make an additional trip higher than the observation deck.
Amazing structure. Amazing structure outside. Me and my husband didn't go up because it was really crowded! But we have lunch and it was nice!

Recommend to go on clear sky. If you plan to go to Tokyo skytree. I recommended you to go on clear sky day or else you cannot see the Mt. Fuji and other in far-sight. And prepare money atleat 4K yen, to go to the highest point.Visit at night also be a good option,

Fantastic view of the city. We opted for the additional trip to the top level and were not disappointed. At 450m you are higher than the observation deck of the Petronas Twin Towers with a greater view. We went on a clear night and the city was beautiful.

Breathtaking Views On A Clear Day. I went to the Skytree on my first day in Tokyo. The view is breathtaking and thankfully it was a clear sunny day. I bought the foreigner's ticket to skip the queue and went to the first viewing platform. It really gives you a sense of scale at how vast and enormous Tokyo is. I paid a little extra on the 1st viewing deck (350m) to go to the second viewing deck (450m) which si called Tembo Galleria. The difference in view is not noticeable and I think that it's not overly worth it. I would recommend buying the more expensive queue jump ticket for convenience but just stay on the 1st viewing platform.

THE place to enjoy metropolitan Tokyo area from above!. Towers seem to be a must visit in every city, but this one offers excellent views towards the vast metropolitan area, Tokyo Bay and the multiple citycenters. It may be pricy and a surcharge applies if you want to reach the upper top BUT it is worth it by all means.The tricky modern architecture gives it a future touch.Be aware that Non-Japanese can use a separate entrance which allows them to bypass the cuing masses for a little bit higher fee - definitely a recommendation as you may save over an hour!It can easily be combined with a visit to Asakusa and the Senso-ji temple which is located just accross the river.

Beautiful. Beautiful place to watch the view of Tokyo. However you have to prepare to wait in a very long line for at least an hour in regular day and maybe a couple hour in special occation. Shopping mall also has many good shops.

Aussie first visiting Skytree!!. We visited Tokyo in December 2015 and were keen to visit the Skytree. From the outside it didn't look tall until we waited to enter. It is a very busy place which on the say we went had lots of Japanese students in front t of us.Staff were very efficient.Was a little squashy going up the lift packed with 20 plus ppl but everyone is so respectful it was fine. The level we arrived was great with views forever.. We decided to go up the next levels for an extra $10au each and worth every cent to see Mt Fuji clearly and the theme of Star Wars everywhere from figurines to rein acting sabre sword battles and having photo taken. Go early morning or just in sun setting for best views and experience.

Just ok for Me!. We visited the Skytree in Tokyo with a tour.This is tall structure with a view overlooking Tokyo.Ours was an afternoon tour and the Skytree was at the end so we did get to see the lights of Tokyo from a high floor. Impressive! I think if you wanted to go higer you would need additional tickets separate from the tour. The view is great to see but the crowds toget up to see takes away from the event. The crowds of people arelarge and the elavators can take so many people at a time. And coming down is just as bad.We visited at Christamstime so imagine the crowds of local people and tourist.If you want to look out over Tokyo from a high view point then this view is for you.

interesting. You can see 360 degrees of Tokyo from this tall building.There is an international counter for visitors that charges a higher rate but will provide a faster access to the lifts. Please note that if you wish to go higher floor there is additional fee.

Worth the View. A good thing to do when arriving at Tokyo. We chose to do the Sky Tree instead of Tokyo tower as it was higher. Getting there from Shinjuku was fairly easy with a JR rail trip and a one stop Tokyo Metro ride.We paid extra to be in the short line to go up the elevator - which was well worth it. The top level viewing deck was more money so we didn't go up there. Only go on a clear day - we were very lucky to have amazing weather!
Great view. This place is well worth going up just for the view! We spend half an hour looking out over the sky line. There is also a glass floor you can walk over!

360 View of Tokyo. I strongly recommend buying the fast track tickets because the queue for the ordinary tickets is way too long. We didn't go to the 450m observation deck though because we thought the views were good enough. It is nice to experience it once but if you have been to other countries' tall towers, here wouldn't be much different I suppose.

Incredible view, Tembo galleria is worth it! Check the weather forecast in advance if you can!. We walked to Tokyo Skytree after having visited the Senso-ji temple. We were lucky enough to have clear and sunny weather when we went there!Purchasing tickets is easy. There's also a special foreign tourist ticket sales on the fourth floor where tourists can buy tickets. However, when we there, there was almost no queue so we didn't need to. After purchasing tickets you are being led to the elevator that will take you up. Before going up there will be a mandatory check of your bags etc. However, this doesn't feel intimidating at all since the staff are incredibly polite and helpful and always with a smile.The view is just absolutely stunning! I gasped and could hardly believe what the my eyes were seeing. (That's exactly the reaction you want when visiting the tallest tower in the world, isn't it :) ) You can walk around 360 degrees and basically see entire Tokyo. We also saw a few helicopters flying around below us which was interesting. The observation deck is actually made of several floors and there is escalators. On the lowest observation deck floor there is a part of the floor that is made of glass which you can stand on and look down. This is scary but fun.. the people on the ground look like ants!You can go even higher by purchasing an extra ticket for the Temo galleria. I would recommend doing this. And there is one interesting difference about the elevator when going up to the Tembo galleria: you have an outside view unlike the elevator to the observation deck. So just going up there is fun.Tembo galleria is 450 metres above ground and nothing beats the view from up there. It's so high up that it feels like you're just in the middle between the clouds and the ground. Just to see the ground beneath you, you gotta look at basically a 90 degree angle!Be aware of that Tokyo Skytree will be closed if it's too windy, and rain doesn't help the view of course so I would check the weather forecast in advance! Other than that, there not so much to think about. Bring a zoom lens, or camcorder with a good zoom and you will get some great shots :)

All in one destination (afternoon/rainy day visit?). If you don't know what to do on rainy days or just want to escape the afternoon heat, you should definitely check out the Tokyo Sky Tree. We went here as a family to visit the observatory (our goal), we didn't know there was also a shopping mall and an aquarium : we were pretty surprise. Lots of restaurants for different budgets and lots of shops and department stores where you can find an abundance of souvenirs. There are two observatories : one (the lowest) is free & the 2nd (the highest) has fees. There's also a nearby river/stream to take pretty pictures. Go check it out when you visit Tokyo!
Amazing views of Tokyo. Really impressed with the views of Tokyo from the Skytree. Highly recommend coming here at night to experience it! Gives you a perspective on how big the city is

A Great View of Tokyo from Above. If you are in Tokyo, you might want to drop by Tokyo Skytree in Oshiage. You can go up the tower for a fee and go up higher floors for additional fee. There is an international counter for visitors that charges a higher rate but will provide a faster access to the lifts. The view is spectacular but can be a bit crowded during holidays.

Good place to see Tokyo from great heights. This was a good place to go if you want to see Tokyo from great heights - not advised for those who are afraid of heights. Otherwise a great spot, and some good shopping and food (especially the sushi restaurant) in the centre below.

Interesting . Reason we went there was to visit the planetarium (which as I wrote in another review is nothing to write home about). The skytree is impressive, has several shops and restaurants and a buffet place that you can have all you can eat cookies. You can get there by metro easily. Does it worth a visit? On a rainy day and if it happens to be in the area why not for an hour or two
Huge Building. It was the highest building I've been in my life.It has an amazing cityview.The staff are quiclky and polite.I highly recomend this place to everyone who will visit Tokyo!
Awesome Spectacle. Wonderful views, clean and well run. Book in advance and take the VIP tickets in peak season. Cost a little bit more but you avoid the long queues. We loved it !

Skytree. The Skytree is very tall and beautiful. It's worthy to go up and see the view of Tokyo. You will enjoy observing around tokyo. You can also see Fujisan in a clear sky day. It's easy to go there because it connects with train station. Things to do are shopping, eating in good restaurants, see the view in two different levels with different fees. Also, Tokyo Banana is in Skytree building for people who like sweets.

Walking from Asakusa temple to Tokyo sky tree. If you visit Asakusa temple,do not miss to walk to Tokyo sky tree. It can reach by walking across Sumida river and can reach the tower only 15 minutes. You can see how beautiful of river and how clear water of the canal near the tower.

Great place for taking photos!. There are lots of dining options with a variety of Japanese cuisine. A couple of bakeries that offer a lovely range of cakes and pastries on 2nd floor with prices as low as ¥150 Many shopping outlets with our favourite Disney Store on a 3rd floor. Great experience for kids with many products that are not carried by Disneyland Tokyo.

one of the world’s tallest tower.. หอส่งสัญญาณดิจิตอลทีวีของญี่ปุ่น ไฮเทคล้ำมากๆ กับวิวสูงที่สุด ที่สวยในยามค่ำคืน มาโตเกียวต้องไม่พลาด Discover two of Tokyo’s must-see destinations on a guided tour of the Asakusa district and the Tokyo Skytree. Sit back and relax on a sightseeing tour of central Tokyo. You'll drive through Imperial Palace Plaza, National Diet Building, State Guest House, Ginza and Akihabara. Next, you’ll visit the famous Buddhist shrines and temples of Asakusa, then have Tokyo at your feet when you take in views from the Tokyo Skytree, one of the world’s tallest tower.Pls, follow usfacebook:Japanaroisudsud

Skytree a breath taking view . Have been to Tokyo skytree during Chirstmas time.The Christmas market was amazing.The place is quite romantic and nicely organized.Then we went to the second floor of skytree.Consider 3000 yen to go one top ( second floor ) a bit expensive though... but the view was breath taking.We didn't regret our choice.The best spot of Tokyo to have panoramic view of the megalopolis.

Good view, as expected.. We went earlyish in the day, 9am, and there was only about a 20 minute wait. It was crowded, and the day wasn't clear enough to see Mount Fuji, but I was happy for the experience. Such a view of such a city always gives me a feeling of awe, a wonderment of how many people live in Tokyo, and how they might live. If I go again, I'll go to see the city at night: it would be magnificent lit up. We didn't bother with the extra trip to the very top, as the view was just fine. On a previous trip, I went up Tokyo Tower; which was also beautiful, though not quite as high up!

Take a pass. . The sky tree is incredibly crowded and expensive. You can go to the Tokyo Metro Government Building and go see the skyline for free! I've seen the Tokyo skyline from a number of perspectives, this one is not worth the money when you can go free elsewhere.

Beautiful, inside and outside. The place is prone to holiday rushes, and is increasingly getting popular, so two important things need to be factored in for a visit - Timing (early start is better), Ticket Choice (High speed or regular queue / Lower Level or Upper Level). It is highly advisable to check for visibility in the city before visiting, while it is said that on a clear day you can see upto 10 kms out, it can get far worse on some days. It is an expensive attraction, and you need to pay more for a shorter queue and to go higher. Going higher would be more of a can-do rather than a must-do as the lower level itself offers great views. Prominently the upper level features better markings and a tropical panorama shot on every window, helping to identify structures. If height is what you are looking for, then upper level is the way to go. The place is easily accessible via public transportation (tobu line)

Beautiful beyond words. Tokyo Sky Tree is a must visit place in Tokyo. Standing 634 M tall this mammoth tower is an important land mark and tourist place in Tokyo. You can easily get to it from any place in Tokyo by using the underground train. Do consider sparing enough time for it, at least two hours, out of which 30 minutes will be spent in getting a ticket as the queue is quite long on any day. The ticket to Tembo Deck which is at a height of 350 M costs like 2000 Yen. The super fast lift takes you to the top in seconds, which is really a wonderful experience. The view from Tembo deck is beautiful, as you can see up to 87 km in any direction. Do check out the glass floor by standing on it and giving yourself a dizzying experience :-)From Tembo Deck you can get tickets to Tembo Galleria which is 450 M. The Tembo Deck has a coffee shop, photo session stand, souvenir shop and a number of electronic touchscreens providing view of complete city. You just have to place your finger on any building or landmark on the touchscreen to get info about it. You can take pics and walk around. Overall a breathtaking experience.

Great view. The views were amazing and it really shows you just how big the city is. It was very crowded but we were able to get several photos. It was quite pricey for the short amount of time we needed up there. We paid the extra for the express entry as the wait was 2hrs otherwise. We didn't feel the need to pay to go up to the 450th floor.

Not That Special. I have visited the likes of CN Tower in Toronto and Tokyo Tower just near by. Sky Tree really isn't that special if you have been to a couple of other "towers".It's costly even to go up. More than 2,000 yen to get to 350th Floor & $3,000 yen to go to the observation deck on the 450th Floor.There is a restaurant and a snack / beverage bar up there and the view is nice. That's about it. All the gimmicks are found in other places such as a VERY SMALL glass flooring section.If you are visiting with kids, I think it's worth a look, especially if this is your first time in Tokyo and haven't been to Tokyo Tower. If you have, it's not really worth it.

i suppose because it's there. This was really standard tall tower fayre but with a few Japanese twists. The lifts were the smoothest of any similar attraction I have been to around the world, there was a special queue busting line for foreign tourists although it cost ever so slightly more and the whole place was spotless. Yes it is worth doing but is it a highlight of a Tokyo trip? Probably not.

Worth Seeing. The Tokyo Skytree gives you a good perspective of Tokyo from up hight. We did the Skytree and passed on the Tokyo Tower as the views from what we heard were very similar. Best spot for a photo of the Tower was from Rapongi Hills.

The elevator makes your eyes pop . If you're like me, one of the first things that you quickly discover is that many businesses in Tokyo don't open until 10 or 11 AM-- and while still reeling from jet-lag, you're hard-pressed to find something to do until then. The Tokyo Skytree is that. It's fairly hard to miss (you know, with it being 2000+ feet and all), it's just a stone's throw away from Oshiage Station. The admission fee is a fair price for the experience. As soon as you arrive at the top floor you're immediate captivated by the breathtaking view of modern Tokyo. The breathtaking and picturesque scene provides the perfect opportunity to overlook the city. However, there's usually a crowd of equally eager tourists, waiting for the opportunity to take the perfect picture so be on your toes. There's are a few gift shops on each floor of the observation deck as well as a few paid professional photo services. I highly recommend this attraction for first time travelers to Tokyo. Happy travels!

Very cool observation deck. Tokyo Skytree is a very cool observation deck but it gets crazy busy! I would high recommend going during the week and try to get a time slot around sunset so you can see the day and the night.

I see heads and nonstop flash >.<. i believed in rumors that nobody visit skytree anymore, so i didn't buy tix online. at the end i waited for 45 mins on the queue, missed the sunset moment.quite disappointed. super crowded, unable to stand quietly and enjoy the view. it was xmas time, therefore few xmas lighting installations at the windows, occupying the space and become a light pollution. briefly walked a circle and pushed by crowded to downstairs. got into the cafe immediately, no queue. not overpriced. if u want to see nightview of tokyo, tokyo tower is better.

Must do view of Tokyo. Going to the Tokyo Skytree is easily missed if you opt for the free Tokyo Tower view - but although there is a cost & a pretty long wait - it is well worth it.Easy to access via the nearby Oshiage Train Station the Skytree is well worth the trip as it gives an unsurpassed view around Tokyo combined with some fairly decent shopping as well in the attached levels.It takes around an hour in line to get tickets but this is minor when compared to the exhilarating trip up to 350 m in one of the four fast elevators to the Tembo Deck. Make sure you walk all the way around & use the interactive screens to better view the vast sprawl that is Tokyo. There are also a couple of viewing floors directly below the Tembo Deck where the crowds are a lot less hectic - try to pick a time when no public holidays or weekends are on - that should make the trip a little quicker. Also don't miss walking on the glass floor situated near the ice cream shop - a bit scary but well worth the risk! If you want to pay extra you can go up again to the 450 m Galleria Deck for even better views.

Not worth it.... Since we were in Asakusa to visit the temple we decided to make our way to the Skytree. Had to buy the "fast pass" option to bypass a long wait as it was very crowded. When we got up to the top floor we were greeted by a huge crowd. Although some efforts were made to make the visit informative through the touchscreens, I didn't find this place worth the trouble and cost. It was not very big up top and the "glass floor" a level below the top (near the lifts to exit) was a joke. Give it a miss.

Foggy night. We went during the evening . It was foggy and only half of the tower was visible but it still looked grand.We did not go to the viewing deck because we were told the fog was blocking the view. The architecture was exceptional and the structure looked very sturdy. We opted to go to the mall. My cousin bought me a bag at a CecileMcbee shop. There was an aquarium but we did not have time to go in.

Fantastic View at night. After trying to go up in January 2013 we thought we book a tour through JBT Sunrise tours. Worth the money as we did not have to wait in line to get to the 350th Floor, however it was very busy with people everywhere up on the viewing platform. You had to push to get close to the window to get a photo. The place was crowded, maybe as it was Friday. The mall around the tower is fantastic, great food court for food etc.

Nothing spectacular. For the tallest tower in the world it leaves a lot to be desired in terms of views. Got the queue skip which is useful for saving precious trip time.The windows having grid like patterns on them so taking pictures are hard enough not to mention not being able to get up close to the window cause of the wall. The day I went they had xmas picture spots therefore even less viewing area.Very crowded up there however will say they got people down very quick. Overall only would go up if you want to say you did it else better spots for views.
Beautiful place. You can see beautiful night scene of tokyo city and there is a big shopping mall just beside it . There are a lot of restaurants and shops to eat and visits.

Not worth it - 4 hours to queue. I started to fall in line around 11am and I was finally able to get in at 3pm! What you can find on top is a good view of the entire Tokyo and that's it. I suggest you to take advantage of the shorter queue for tourists as this attraction will eat up most of your day. The cost you pay and the long queue does not give a good value for your money. I could have visited some other temples and shrines for free in other parts of Tokyo. Food is overpriced too!
Beautiful. There were so many things to do here, its huge! The observation deck was beautiful especially with the whether during my visit.

Great a couple hours with young children . Beautiful 360' Sumida River. Got complimentary tickets from my great friend who lives in Japan. Still had to line up to get the ticket exchanged. Be prepare to be in line for at least 20 mins esp at the peak time( 10-2 pm) Got a free photo picture. Wallet size but can purchase for 1300 yen for 4X6 Overall, good experience.

Great view of the city!. Before visiting the Skytree, I kept my expectations down as I figured it would be another tower with an observation deck. However, the whole experience was quite entertaining. You first enter into an ornately decorated elevator that gets you up to the mid observation deck within a minute. The view at the observation deck is pretty amazing. The tower is so high that you can see its shadow cast over a large swatch of the city. I spent the extra money to go up to the top observation deck that was much less crowded and spent a good half hour just looking at different directions of the city. There was a slight haze when I went, otherwise I'm told you can see Mount Fuji in the distance.Afterwards, I decided to eat curry at the cafe there and got to sit right at the window so I can peer out endlessly at Tokyo while eating. Overall I enjoyed my time in the tower.

Great Views near Asakusa. Wow, amazing views from the top. We went to the planaterium even though it wasent in English it was an amazing show. The shopping in the mall was over priced but still a great place to go. We watched people making candy downstairs and loved trying samples from all the food outlets.

Nice 360 views of Tokyo. Had a nice visit to top of SkyTree tower. Walked to the tower from Asakusa Temple, passing the Asahi building on the way. It was a 20 minute wait for tickets; a little pricey imo. The elevator ride up was fast and very quiet. Kind of wondering whether this thing was moving!! Although it was a gloomy, rainy kind of day the 360 views all around were still pretty awesome. The place was packed with tourists and locals alike. We took the train back to the city.

A bit over-priced, but an excellent view. I've been to the top of Roppongi Hills, Tokyo Tower and Sky Tree. Definitely, Sky Tree had the best view. With that said, my experience at the Sky Tree was not a 5/5, but a 4/5 for the following reasons.1. PriceThe price of 2,500 (About $20) is a bit overpriced. You could go to the top of Roppongi Hills instead for about 800yen cheaper for almost the same view.2. LineI don't mind waiting in lines. But waiting for a full hour during the "non rush-hour period" for 30 minutes at the top of the tower was a bit painful.With that said, among the major high rise areas to watch the great city of Tokyo from, the Sky Tree is probably the right choice. Just be ready to wait in line whether you go during the rush-hour or non-rush hour.I also strongly recommend to check out the cafe. The quality of the food and drink are not amazing, but drinking a latte from 100+ floors high, looking down at the big city is an awesome experience.

A Shopping Mall. The Skytree is located on a Shopping Mall. It is also just a 30minute walk from Sensoji Temple (Asakusa).
We were attracted at 2 things, the glowing changing lights of Skytree (night) and famous Tokyo Banana Outlet. These two reasons are enough to make this place a worthy visit!

Great Views of Tokyo. The Tokyo Skytree offers fantastic views of Tokyo and the surrounding area. Unfortunately, it was hazy when we were there, so we couldn't see Mt. Fuji, but it was still worth the visit. You get a 360 degree view of the city, and enjoyed spotting the attractions that we had visited or were planning to visit.It's easily accessible by train, and it's reasonably close (we walked) to some of some of the oldest temples and shrines in Tokyo.
