It's also close to a water taxi, which we used to take us to a Japanese garden later in the day.For international visitors, be sure to take advantage to the fast pass option to skip the lines. During our visit, that saves us A LOT of time.We visited in December, and we were surprised to see it decked out for Christmas (and Star Wars: The Force Awakens, which was to open later in week). It made for a very festive atmosphere.

If ineterested in skyscrapers and sightseeing of all the city. Tokyo Skytree have very good views of all Tokyo. First you go up 350m, where you can have a great view but in you want to go 450m, you have to pay more. At 450m you are able to see Mt Fuji.Bad thing it is pretty expensive. If you are a tourist or basically foreigner, you can have quick access by paying more if not, you have to grab a meeting ticket in order to be able to buy your tickets at the designated time and enter the building.

Average visit. Not really that impressive. Very crowded and over priced. Views were ok at the top but Tokyo is just a big city. Nothing really to look at.Save your money and visit Yokohama. Much more beautiful.

Average visit. Personally think the visit entrance fee is a little expensive, compared to the free entrance of Tokyo Government Building. Nonetheless it was a good experience. Good view. Will perhaps recommend visit in the morning as I went in the evening, pictures taken was not recommended as there tend to be reflections. Overall okay. Worth the extra money if u have during the trip to Japan, Tokyo.

What a view!. It was great to visit the Skytree to get a better understanding of the areas & layout of the amazing city that is Tokyo. The tower is awesome & the view (even on a cloudy day) is incredible. We went at dusk so a great time to go as the city lights start to shine & sparkle in many colours. You can spend as much or as little time as you want visiting the tower & the shopping mall that is part of the complex. Very easy to get to via the subway. Happy we made an effort to visit this tourist attraction on our short stay in Tokyo.

Impressive view. Plus point for this place is its impressive view from high above. Minus point is its expensive entrance fee, especially if you do not want to join the long wait because of time constraint.

Beautiful setting. Walked from Askusa, about 1.5km. Very pleasant walk through a neighbourhood park with plenty of beautiful ducks in the pond (cannot get taking the train). The skytree is atop a mall as are most attractions. Pleasant visit. 2 metro lines here.

Worth the experience. We went to Skytree on a public holiday (think it was sports day or something) at around 5pm. We didn't anticipate to go up becos we thought the queue might be crazy. Once there we saw a sign asking people to comeback after 6pm. But luckily we were tourist, So we went and queued for a while (20mins or so) at the tourist ticket counter (I think) and decided to get the express tickets. People were really nice explaining things to us. The express queue was significantly shorter. We queued for like 10mins? And we're up. It was pretty packed but the view was awesome! There was this see-through bottom glass which was exciting to stepped on. Got tickets and queued for less then 5mins to go up to the final deck. The elevator up was see-through! It was amazing! The final deck was not as crowed and there were very "hi-tech" looking washrooms too :) Though the view was pretty much the same as the lower deck but we get to see more due to less crowd. There was quite a queue when we were leaving (no express queue for leaving haha) but it was really fast. So no complaints.Overall a very good experience. The queue was not as bad as I had thought. We spent probably 30-40mins there just looking around and taking some pictures.
Excellent Views. Visited with girlfriends. Amazing views of Tokyo. We were fortunate to have a clear view of Mt Fuji.Also spectacular views at night.

Tokyo Sky Tree. A world class engineering feat comes to mind as I circle the base of this incredible man made landmark. There is a line of people with kids all patiently waiting for their turn to get into those incredible elevators that will propel you 350 meters in about ten seconds! Those elevators are so quiet and movement free that you wonder if they have actually started- and you have arrived. To see this incredibly sprawled out city called Tokyo is a sight to see.Plenty of opps to buy water or coffee but do get in early before the crowds show up!

Queue or Less Queue.. When is weekend or holiday peak season, there will be a long long queue, even for tourist who can purchase tourist express ticket at slightly higher price than normal ticket, the queue is still long but much more faster than normal ticket queue.At ticket purchase counter, staff will point to the TV at the back of their counter, telling you thats the live feed of current view at the top of Skytree beforea asking you to purchase ticket. If you are happy with the view, you can purchase the ticket as sometime due bad weather (mostly raining) it is hardly possible to see anything at the top floor, some might just walked away and come back next time.There are 2 cafes on top, but most of the time is full of people.Only go up when the weather is good, otherwise it will be a waste of money.
Killer queue. The queue is just a killer but when you get there, it will all be worth it. Window 8 is my personal fave. Amazing experience!

Astonishing! . This was a great experience! First we went to 350m, which is achieved within no time. Very nice view! Especially when standing on the glass floor! Then another elevator to 451m, great ride with fabulous view. Arrived we had an astonishing view over Tokyo city.

Incredible View. Enjoyed going up the Skytree whilst in Tokyo. It's well worth the money for a queue jump ticket, and if you can I'd recommend going up around dusk. There you'll get a good enough 'day' time view, whilst also getting the evening view. The views are fantastic!

Fun and nice views!. It was what you would expect from a major tourist attraction! prepare for long lines, but they move quickly. Tours from overseas can get a express pass for 80yen more and it's probably worth it! The views are incredible and on clear days you can see Mt Fuji!

Best view of the city. We enjoyed going up the Skytree to get an outstanding view of Tokyo from up above. 360 degree view is impressive and unlike any other. Going up and down was fast enough that we didn't waste hours of our day to visit just one attraction. Worth the stop.

Great attraction, not too busy!. Visited the Skytree on a Friday night, no queues, straight in and straight up. Views are amazing and with a clear night it is very impressive. You can stay for a while to eat and drink. Definitely worth going up to the top level, views are better!

A line 50min long (in the tourist quiet season) and a crowded, average view from the top.. Very anti-climatic. We waited close to an hour just to purchase our (expensive) tickets, then another line for the lift (20min), crammed in with as many people as could fit, shot to the top (the only cool part), to arrive at the top with an (average) view of Tokyo and an overpriced set of shops. The glass floor was tiny so we had to wait for a bunch of the other visitors to move. Once we had seen all that we just wanted to start climbing down thinking the walk down might be enjoyable but each floor was just packed with shops and people. The types of shops weren't of any interest to us (expensive deserts, christmas shops, Japanese TV culture, clothes etc..). It seemed like the Japanese people there were enjoying it but for us foreign tourists it was a swing-and-miss.

Majestic Tokyo Skytree. Spent almost half a day at Tokyo Skytree. It has a decent shopping mall and minutes away from the train stations. Wanted to go up to the observation decks but it was closed due to strong wind. Quite unfortunate. Definitely worth revisiting

Long queues, out of the way, and limited explanation. We visited Asakusa and during our time there, went up the Tokyo Sky Tree. Queues were long and tickets were relatively expensive. Once we'd reached the 350m point, the views were good but there was little English explanation as to what we were seeing. It makes sense if you're familiar with the city and want to see the landmarks from on high, but otherwise, I'd skip

Better than I think!. We went by chance due a heavy down fall thinking that it is just another tourists shopping mall.An outlet called Loft specialised in Japanese made items were going on a sales. Do bring passport for further discount.The food court @ 3rd floor comes with a twist especially if you have tried Japanese restaurants and sushi bar, this place has everything that you may have missed while away from home.

On a sunny day you have a beautiful clear view. I'd been in line with the Japanese for about 20 minutes, when I found out there was another place to buy tickets quickly, as long as you're not Japanese. Somehow, nobody mentioned it on arrival at the long long ticketline. Ask for it! Once up on the first floor (350m) the view was amazing. I couldn't see Mt. Fuji, because the sun was shinig so bright from that direction, but the other side was beautiful. Go up one more floor (450m) for even further views. Tickets are for sale on the 350m level. Everything is very organized and smooth. People wait in neat lines for everything, and there is plenty staff to direct you. They even speak english, mostly.

Don't go up too high. Must come if you visit Tokyo as this place is the newest landmark. Enjoy shopping, dining around before or after the tower visit. Famous shopping such as big Tokyo Banana and Hello Kitty are here as well. It would be better to come one hour before sunset as you can see both day and night scene. I do recommend not to go until the top floor; just the lower one is good enough and you can take nice picture of the town.

First level okay. The sky tree is good to get your bearings. Like all tall towers it does get busy. We went late afternoon in December and it was fine. It was quite cloudy but still worth the price. We then paid another 30% to go up to next level and didn't think this was worth it.

Nice Tower. Although not considered a traditional Japanese attraction, the tower offered the best views of Tokyo City. The staff were polite and all the informative signs in the tower were also translated in English. We enjoyed our visit.

MIsty Weather. Was there on a early afternoon. Weather was so misty and could not even see the first and second observatory deck from outside the building tower. The working crew advised to go up the tower on a clearer day to get a better view. With the current misty weather, unlikely to see much of Tokyo.
Vacation. We saw this while at the Temple and Nakamise Market although did not get a chance to go inside as we were on a tour at the time.

Beautiful and Impressive Views. If you want to see the Tokyo Skyline, go to the Tokyo Skytree. The cost to see the skyline of the city will come at a price tag of about 20 dollars and even more for the second tier view. I believe that it is another 10 dollars.

Up up and away! . It's a good place to visit. Definitely a tourist attraction! The views up top are great, especially if you go on a nice clear day. We were fortunate enough to have had that. Also, we came on a weekday so the line to get the ticket wasn't bad. We waited about 5 minutes or so. Apparently, if it gets really long, there's an international line for tourist but you'll need your passport and it's more money. Don't forget to take a picture on the glass walkway!

If you are a foreigner: take the fast pass . I felt bad for being such a tourist and taking the easy way out and buying the fast pass but saving an hour (or more!) on my trip was worth it. The view is great (be sure to check out the one from Mori tower too!) and it's all very straight forward, I didn't pay the extra 1000 yen to go all the way to the top and in hindsight I might have done it.The food court and shops at the bottom are surprisingly good (the udon with curry was great!)! Maybe not something I would recommend on a first day as the subway ride is long from everywhere and it's pretty tricky to get back on the subway unless you've got a hang on how the signs work.

Sooo high up. Alright the skytree is crazy high up and you can see 360 degrees around the city. The only downside is the price. The higher you want to go the more you have to pay. Of course I paid to go all the way up, but honestly that extra height isnt needed to enjoy the skytree. Its a must to put on your to do list for your visit

Great views in good weather... A bit of a must while in Tokyo if you haven't been before... You can skip the queue (which can get a bit long during busy times) if you pre-order tickets, but this is not essential. Great souvenir stores too.Take a decent camera for some great shots of the city!

Give a little more time. We would love to spent a few more hours at this place if possible. Check weather report before going so that you can have a clear view from the tokyo skytree looking out to the Tokyo towers the connecting famous Tokyo bridge and the Large ' Lodon Eye ' type ferry. Take the express q, paying a bit more for fast track. If you want to have dinner on one of its tower, book in advance. We went there and there was the Star Track theme on the highest tower 450m. You need to buy another ticket at the standard 350 m floor. I am impressed by the speed of the lift and also i dont feel any major ear block going up. There are lots of eateries and shopping at the mall. Great place for a full afternoon and evening. The train stop is Oshiage.

Great views. Love the views from here. Been to the sky tree twice. Please note they have opened a kiosk to purchase tickets up to the deck for foreign passport holders. It costs a bit more but if the regular line is crowded this is a good option. I have been up to both decks. I'd say it really isn't worth the extra to go to the highest deck. (View doesn't change much) don't miss the attached mall, great unique shopping and good food.

Great view of Tokyo. Bought the express queue and managed to get to the 350m viewing gallery. Sky was clear so we managed to see Mount Fuji from up there. Wait time down was about 15 minutes. Must go if you are visiting Tokyo for the first time!
Beautiful sight to see... When we reach, it was like hiding from us and finally it open up to us and it was a great sight.. too bad as there are just too many people queuing to go in.. very sad..

Very crowded at morning. The place downstairs is so crowded especially with schools visit, but it is charming especially walking through shops pass way where ice cream shops is the best to take a break or even a meal.
Fantastic Views. Great views of Tokyo, the bay and the distant mountains. Pro tip: go on a clear day for the best possible views.

Amazing view. I'll start by saying: Price: approx. 2000 yen for the first level (350m), an add'l 1000 yen for the gallery above (450m).Based on weather, it can be a hit or miss. I've gone when the weather was clear, but the wait times to buy the ticket and ride the elevator, was excruciating... I've also gone, when its partly cloudy, the lines went quickly. Both times, I've been able to see far and get my money's worth in just the view of Tokyo. From that height, you truly get a sense of how densely packed Tokyo is.P.S. It's the World's tallest broadcasting tower

Fantastic views especially at dusk. Get there a little while before dusk so you see the city transition from daylight to night. The city transforms itself - it's magical. I went right to the top gallery but you don't have to as it costs extra. You can get a souvenir photo at 1500 feet if you do.I sat in the restaurant with a window view watching the change from day to night. Brilliant views. Highly recommended

Best view ever!. If you want to see how enormous tokyo really is, you should definitely visit the Sky Tree. As a tourist there is a special 'fast entrance' for the same price, which will save you about an hours wait.Awesome view, also the glass floor is an amazing experience. You could choose to go up higher to a second, but considering the height you are at i doubt it's worth the extra 1000 yen.

Great 360 view of tokyo. I visited Tokyo Sky Tree around 7pm and I found no queue. You get really nice views of the city and you realize how big it is. I don't give 5 stars because they ask you to pay another ticket if you want to go up to the 450m floor.

Great view of Tokyo . I and my 6-yr old went up this tower during the busiest time in summer. Since we reserved our trip in advance, there was no wait. Everything was so smooth and very organized just like most of the things in Japan. The view from the top was very nice.

Good view from the top but pricey. We arrived Skytreet at around 8:30am, there was no queue and not many visitors.You need to buy another ticket to 450m floor, the price of the ticket is not cheap, but it is worth it as the view at 450m is more spectacular.It was very crowded when we left before 10:00am.

Overrated. Very long queues, the only way for tourists to skip the queues is to pay more, there is a counter where you have to show your passport and then pay the ticket plus the additional fee. Tokyo is huge and from the deck you'll see the whole city but for me it is just a huge cncrete jungle. I would prefer to explore and see buildings on foot because buildings in Tokyo have unique design elements that you will only appreciate when seen up close. Probably it could have been better experience if Mt. fuji was visible, they said on a clear day, you can see from the Skytree, but I was unlycky it was a cloudy day when I visited.

Nice view from observation deck!. Once you reach the observation deck you can get panoramic views of the city. In addition, you can visit the little shops and dining areas for something else to do after your done taking in the sights and visiting the museum. Good place to walk or tour through and take some pics.

2nd tallest tower in the world. Very easy to get to with the subway. We went about 1 hour before close and were very glad we did for 2 reasons - the lines were non existent and the beautiful night time view. Probably the best view in tokyo is here.

Best place the view the whole city. It is the new tokyo tower, works as a transmission station in tokyo and usable as an observatory. It is really high and really really crowded! It is better to buy your ticket online, however it is more expensive if you have a prepaid ticked. Usually it tooks 1-2 hours to get in if you dont have the ticket.Good to carry your camera stand if you want to take good pictures.

Not so good as I expected . Despite the fact that the views are good (if you have a clear day), the queues made the visit too long. Almost 40 minutes to buy the ticket and around other 15 to go down. If you do not have many days in tokyo I would not visit it.
Japan 2015. It was very busy on a Sunday afternoon there. Although you are higher than Tokyo Tower, the view was obscured by smog. It was much more commercialised than Tokyo Tower.

Really cool but that expensive price tho. I would have loved to go up the viewing deck, but the price was too expensive for us! I was content with just seeing the view from a worm's view point (we saw it from the Sumida Aquarium garden area). It's really crowded so I kind of wish that I visited other areas in Tokyo instead. But I'm still glad I got to see the Skytree up close.

Wow, what a view! But what a price!. A very expensive view of Tokyo. I was disappointed with the lack of explanatory descriptions of what I was looking at, save for one excellent interactive map provided in English and Japanese. This map was surrounded by many people and is only in one spot. I also did not enjoy the huge number of kids running around the place. Very noisy and aggravating. So for approx $25pp, I would opt to skip this tour again and spend the money elsewhere.

Great views of the huge expanse that is Tokyo. Best way to understand the scale of the huge expanse that is Tokyo is to get to higher ground and you can't get higher than Skytree. We didn't bother getting advance tickets, just turned up on the day (around 11am midweek) and didn't have to wait for too long. We fitted it in on the same day we took a trip round Asakusa as it's pretty close by.

Expensive for a view. It is like any sky tower, you have the view of the whole city if the fog allows you. Just too expensive for a view (even being expensive is always crowded - a true money machine). I wouldn't say a must see - just interesting to verify that the city was mostly planned.

A view to behold.. Do not let the price stop you. Yes you can see the view feom Metropolitan Building but the view here is just simply unbeatable. Come here early in the morning to beat the queue (there WILL be a LOOOOOONNGGG queue if later) and enjoy the picturesque wonder that unfold before you. Did not go up the special deck cause its a bit too expensive but I kind of wished to go back now. Come here for day view and Tokyo Tower for night view!

Amazing views a must if you visit Tokyo.. The views from the tower are spectacular. 360 degrees of amazing skyline and you can see in the horizon the Mt. Fuji. A lot of people visiting the tower so the line may be a little long but it doesn't take too much time to reach the elevator and go up. There is a fast track for tourists in the west entrance, you just need to show your passport or ID! Go in the afternoon and watch the sunset, you will not regret it.

Skylight of Northern Tokyo. It is definitely a must visit if you happened to drop by Sensoji Temple and Nakamise Street. It is still within walking distance across Sumida Park and the River from the temple. The queue to go up to its observatory can be very long though. But I enjoyed my time more by walking around this tower and also Tokyo Solamachi (Tokyo Skytown).

Top of the World. Long Lines. Go early- 2 levels to ascend to with price increase to higher level. Lines controlled & move like Orlando Disney. Worth the price. Check if there is a school or national holiday. The building complex can keep you occupied for many hours with other activities as well. Can book on line (in Japanese) if you have a local contact. Those patrons did not have to wait.
Smoothest elevator ride in the world . Very easy to visit and with great views. But if a con that you have to pay again for last 100m summit but not so much. It was quiet when we went yet still busy.

Overcrowded to the point of being inaccessible. We took probably 2-3 hours to get in, whereas Tokyo Tower had no lines at all. Mind you, the line to the ticket counter is just the beginning... there's another line to enter the elevator area, then another one to enter the elevator.Do you like to snap panoramas? Forget them here. The windows have vertical bars every half a meter or so, which makes shooting panoramas impossible. If you buy the extra ticket to Tembo Galleria (450 m), there are even more vertical supports there (but it's less crowded).Skytree is also very expensive when compared to Tokyo Tower or to the free Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. I hate to leave a bad review, especially when the staff there was very friendly, but our visit just was not very good.

Best city view you will ever get!. Absolutely breathtaking views at both night and day! At day you can really see how big the city really is and how small you are in comparison. At night the view transforms into something really quite different! The view transforms into a sort of light show as the cities lights twinkle at night.Worth every penny!

Amazing Views, but Crowded. Definitely worth the effort to get here. Best views of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji (weather permitting). The lines to get in can be long,but the staff does a good job of managing the crowds. The elevators going up are super fast and you will hardly notice any movement. Lots of shopping and restaurants around the area.

Excellent Views. A very modern tower in Tokyo with excellent views of the city. It is very crowded with long queues waiting to go up but saying that it is very organised and crowd controlled to minimise congestion. There are restaurants, cafe's souvenir shops and a much larger tourist complex below the tower itself.

Sky Tree of Tokyo is excellent !!!!. The view from the Tokyo Skytree is a must watch to all the tourist. I recommend going there around 3:00pm and spend time till 6:00pm so that you can watch both the day view and the night view. Both have their own feel of viewing. It took us 60min just to buy the ticket and enter the building. So plan well in advance.
Can be seen from far away. It may be spectacular view from above. Maybe extremily beautiful at night, but I only went there during day. Souvenir shop is available.

Views are unreal - watch out for the crowds. I highly recommend purchasing tickets before, we arrived around 5pm and didn't get through until 8pm. Lots of attractions within the building, food I would suggest eating before hand everywhere was packed with massive lines. Views are unreal, definitely worth a visit.

Tallest tower in the world, worth a visit for the views. Supplanting Tokyo Tower as the new tourist attraction in Tokyo for awesome views, the SkyTree is brand new (3 year old anniversary in November 2015), spacious and VERY tall. It's touted as the world's largest tower, and you can see all across Tokyo Bay, Mt. Fuji, and all of the city of Tokyo. Worth the extra fee to go to the very top!! Bring a camera!

Spectacular view of tokyo. Replacing the tokyo tower as one of the highest building in tokyo, is a big shoe too fill, but tokyo skytree lived up to expectation.Towering hundreds of meter above tokyo and offers a specatular skyline of tokyo and the amazing skyline of japan is trully remarkable.I personally would recommend that you go the upper observation deck, not just the general one and you could glace even further above the busy metropolis. There you could enjoy the calmness and unobstructed beauty of the city skyline.Words of caution, since the site is quite popular, even for locals, purchasing ticket in advance via online is trully recommended, to avoid queing time in the ticket booth.

Shopping and Tokyo's amazing view. Tokyo Skytree is accessible via Oshiage Station. Upon alighting from the train station, you enjoy seamless connectivity via Tokyo Solamachi Shopping mall. We bought the tickets for "TOKYO SKYTREE TEMBO DECK (350 m)".The queue took approximately 30mins. You will be greeted with the view of Tokyo’s city. If you’re lucky, you might be able to spot Mount Fuji. The shopping mall provide a collection of products from clothes, food and desserts, footwear and souvenirs. The variety of products that most shops have to offer will sure entice you. I particularly like the Ganso Shokuhin Sample-ya shop for its unique products. We had our meal at Café Coconoha that serves pastas and dessert. If you’re not intending to visit the skytree tower, the shopping mall should keep you busy.

CONTEMPLATE SKYTREE AND THE SUNSET ON THE RIVER. I came to Skytree in the afternoon and had a look at it, waiting for the sunset. As my friend said it would be very beautiful to contemplate the sunset on the river in Skytree.

Shopping!. You can do a lot of shoppings in there. also the ''Gudetama'' shop is in there.
Love it!!!! :D people were so nice as well!

Amazing view of Tokyo. This place was great! There are tons of shops and restaurants on the bottom floors. I got more than half of my Christmas list shopping done here. There's Sumida aquarium on one of the floors, which we plan on returning to see.It costs about ¥2000 to go to up to the first viewing deck of the tower. It's 350 stories up. There's a higher deck with another ticket price but we didn't feel it was necessary. You take one of the fastest elevators in the world up to the deck and it makes your ears pop as you go up. The view is breathtaking. Tokyo literally goes out farther than you can see. GO AT NIGHT when everything is illuminated. You won't regret it. You can get your picture taken for free with your own camera or pay about ¥1000 for a professional photo with a frame.

View for miles!!. A trip up the Tokyo Skytree is a must for any visitor to the city!! It displays views for miles around seeing buildings as far as the eye can see!! You have the option to pay to go up one floor higher which on the day was worth it for us as it was far less busy.

The most beautiful view of Tokyo city. The Tokyo Skytree is the tallest tower in the world. It offers a 360 degree view of Tokyo city from the observation deck. There are display units on the observation deck that can show you the day/night view of the city. What I found interesting was that you could also view how certain parts of the city looked 100 years ago! To add some thrill, you could talk a walk on the glass floor at that height. Overall, a must-do experience when in Tokyo.

View from the top !. We visited Tokyo Skytree during a business trip to Japan. We had a free day via a National Holiday in Japan (Culture Day) and visited this new and prominent landmark on the Tokyo skyline. Well worth the effort and the crowd bedlam we expected because of the holiday did not eventuate - sure, it was busy but not to the point of jostling for positions. The views are truly outstanding and remind you just how many people live around Tokyo Bay.

Views views views - people people people !!!. Was a public holiday day we ventured here and boy there were people everywhere so unfortunately we didn't go all the way to the 459m Mark but still had a great time...

Excellent views of Tokyo and out to Mt Juji. At the 350m (higher than Empire State Buildg) lower viewing platform you have excellent views of the vast con-urbated space that is Tokyo/Yokohama. On a good day Fujisan can be seen clearly.

Great views. The Skytree offers great views of Tokyo and beyond. Very busy though, and not cheap.I’m sure that it’s a technological marvel, but frankly we found it a bit sterile and boring. Give me the Blackpool Tower any day, where you can hear and feel the wind whistling through the rivets!

The views!!!. Amazing 360 views of Tokyo, on a clear day you can see Mount Fuji but obviously it wasn't clear when we went. We got the fast track ticket so we did not have to queue to purchase a ticket and went straight up to the 350th floor. The tower is busy but you still get a chance to view everything. Once there you have the option to purchase another ticket to go to the next viewing deck which is higher up.I would recommend coming here just so you can see the birds eve view of the whole of Tokyo.

Great view of the city. Great view of the city, both during daytime and at night. You buy tickets for the first observation deck, and once you're up there you can buy tickets for the second observation deck (which is not worth it in my opinion - the view was great from the first deck, so no need to pay for just a few more floors). We used the international visitors fast track and only had to wait for 2 minutes, which was very nice!

Plan ahead!. Turned up here and once you work out the process for buying tickets and waiting we decided it was too hard. 3 hour wait. No thanks. Head to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building for a free view instead with no queue!

Great view of whole Tokyo. It is a really good experience to go to the observation deck and walk around. You can get a 360 degree view of whole Tokyo.The price is a little bit high, but this is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

Very nice view but boring as hell. The queue moves as slow as wind erosion. It will take you about 2 hours before you get into the lift. This during the weekend. I have honestly no idea about weekdays. Both views are good, but the highest one is breathtaking. Every building below gets so small. It takes you a while to really comprehend the height.Do not go during the summer. Tokyo is very humid, you won't be able to see anything. Go instead in Winter. That's when you will find the sky clear.

A nice place for a nice view of Tokyo. I highly recommend that you go there with around 2-3 hours before the sun sets due to the long time waiting in a queue line. I find it kind of expensive all by all and I did not like that for a certain amount of extra money you could choose for a fast lane in order to access the tower. I also find it not that nice that you have to pay another fee to access the second platform situated at 450m. The place is also very overcrowded and you hardly have space to have picture of your own with the view, a think that is quite annoying. You can choose to have a picture with the camera of the Skytree team in an organised place for a photo session but that will add to the all by all costs. What I also did not find nice was that I asked a staff member whether I could have 1000 yen changed for coins to use the lockers for the stuff I carried with me, I was told that I could better buy something to have my change although there was a change machine just around the corner from the place I asked exactly near the lockers. It is a nice experience overall but rather expensive and kind of disorganised. If you can overlook these things you will probably have some nice views and pictures taken there. On the first platform there is also a glass floor where you can walk and see 350m down.

Extremely beautiful, but expensive. I highly recommend going at night so you can see the lights of Tokyo spreading out across the horizon. Also as an added bonus the later you go the less of a line there is. Tickets are expensive ￥2000 to get to the first observation level and then it cost another ￥1000 to visit the upper observation deck. My friend and I opted to only spend ￥2000 and visited the first level. It was very pretty and we were able to have our photo taken with our phones for free or by a professional for money. I highly recommend Tokyo Sky tree as a must see if you are looking for a view.

The view of Tokyo. I've been to Tokyo many times and I use to go to the Mori Tower for the best view of the city. I believe the Skytree has trumped the Mori tower for the best view of the city. There are two levels you can pay for the Tembo Deck and The 100m higher Tembo Galleria which the price includes the lower deck. If you're unsure about paying for the higher view upfront, there is a ticket counter on the Tembo Deck if you feel it's worth going higher. I've gone to both, and felt the higher Tembo Galleria wasn't worth it, the views are very similar. The complex at it's base is a shopping center and has many restaurants. It even has a zoo, but I decided not to check it out. I recommend going early to avoid the crowds, it you haven't bought a reserved ticket online.

Tallest look out in the world (so far). The Skytree is probably one of the top 5 things to check out when you Tokyo. The ticket costs about 2k yen to go up to the tembodeck (350m) but the wait time can be 2 hours or more depending on when your visit is. You can also pay 2.8yen for a fast track ticket and get in within 20min. Ticket to tembo galleria can be purchased at tembo deck at a cost of around 1k yen. The benefit of the galleria is that your look at is at 450m. The day we visited was very sunny and beautiful. We had an unobstructed view of the entire Tokyo and we can almost make out Mount Fuji towards the west!

Play God and look down on Tokyo from the heavens.. We arrived at lunchtime and nearly left, when we were told we had to wait until4pm. But we accidentally found that thereis a Fast Skytree ticket for overseas visitors.It is more expensive (at 2820yen) than thestandard ticket (at 2060 yen) but with onlya 20 minute wait, as opposed to nearly4 hours, well worth the premium.Well within the 20 minutes, we werewhisked upward at high speed to abreath-taking view from the Tembo Deck.It was a beautiful sunny day, so nearbyTokyo was clear to view. Unfortunately,there was still a summer haze, whichmade it impossible to see Mount Fujion the horizon.Avoid the wait, take the fast route andenjoy incredible views of Tokyo.

Amazing View.. one of must visited things to do at Tokyo. very valuables view from here.. it cost 2000.. but the locket queue is very long.. you need to patient of that.. the place it can be reached at "tokyo subway route map : oshiage " many food and snack atound there you can try it...
Worth a look. Great views, Take your passport and you get to jump all the queues for the elevators. We just rocked up bought a ticket and were at the top in ten minutes.

Great view... Not on a cloudy day. I'm not sure if June is rainy season in Japan but I went up Tokyo Skytree and it was cloudy and a bit foggy. There's a dedicated train that stops close to the tower. I went first thing in the morning (8 am) and bought my ticket there. There was no long line up with just a few tourist. I was amazed on how the staff greeted the visitors (in Japanese) to welcome in Tokyo Skytree. It was a nice experience to see Tokyo above. Too bad it was cloudy outside as it made the inside level where I was kinda dark (not enough light to take a photo inside). Still this is a must see when you visit Tokyo. It's an amazing structure. I recommend visiting the Tokyo Skytree with Asakusa Shrine.

Stunning view. Queuing for an hour plus but worth to wait. There's a super fast elevator that brings you up to 300+ floors on the first ride. Then on the second ride, it brings you up another 100+ floors. Thrilling and exiting I would say.

Excellent views, the first level is good enough!. The Skytree is impressive, especially at night! The views are awesome and you can even see the cars moving along the streets which was one of the highlights for me.There's a shop inside, a restaurant and some interactive panels which give information about the different areas in tokyo.The tower has two levels which are accessible to tourists for sightseeing. You have to pay to get to each level.First level - Tembo deck (2060 yen)Second level - Tembo Galleria (1030 yen)I visited both levels and the first is good enough! The next level isn't worth the additional 1000 yen.

overcrowded. Overcrowded since arriving the ticket counter floor all the way to the tower 350 and 450.After arriving sky tree station, no obvious information instructing where the ticket office is. No automated ticket machines, a tourist spot accepts only domestic credit cards accepted for online ticket purchase.After arriving 4th floor, the ticket lobby, saw tons of people. Not clear which lines for ticket, for elevator or not even knowing there is another corner for fast track. All queued up with lots of people.Arriving 350m, the view should be stunning, but overcrowded to get close to the window. The sky shop is so small, can't get in with too much people.Arriving 450m, the scenery is more worse, the scenic view is blocked by frame right visitors' height. Not worth the extra charges.Visited twice, on weekday and holiday, both levels are occupied by crowded. Less people on weekday, but still overcrowded.There are maps, but insufficient to identify the views right in front, you need to refer back to your paper leaflet. Old school!I prefer Mori Tower in Roppongi Hills, cheaper and easier to get tickets, lesser people, more spacious, better facilities, more clear instruction.Sometimes, its not just the height can give you fun.

Great View. we went by the Asakusa Line to Oshiage station in the basement and took the escalator up floor by floor.Window shopping and dinning was great and spend half a day and in the late afternoon we decided to watch the sunset from the Skytree Tembo Galleria ( 450 floor ) but unfortunately it was so crowded.By the time we reached the top,we had already miss the sunset however the view was still great and can even see Mt. Fuji and Tokyo Tower.It was even better than the N Seoul Tower ( Seoul )
Awesome view. Recommend to go there at night. Avoid rainy day as you can see anything if it is cloudy. The fee is 2000yen++ to go higher must pay more. Worth going

Plan it!/Zaplanuj to!. It is one of the MUST SEE, absolutely amazing and inspiring view from top of the world.Plan it carefully though. Go 3h before sun set. First you take a leaflet with written time (+3h) then you go in the SkytreeCity (shops, restaurant, aquarium), come back at pointed time to buy 2080 JPY ticket (0,5h line) for 350m level. Then you buy another ticket 1030JPY, to go the top. There are also other ways to spend money on the top (restaurant, pictures, coffe, souvenirs).To trzeba zobaczyć! Niesamowity inspirujący widok. Zaplanuj to jednak. Bądź na miejscu na 3h przed zachodem słońca, weź ulotkę z godziną (+3h) i udaj się do centrum handlowego. Wróc o danej godzinie, stań w kolejce, kup bilet i wjedź na górę. Tam kup kolejny bilet na szczyt. Niesamowity widok zachodzącego słońca i zarysu góry Fuji.

Great views. This is a popular and busy tourist attraction.Purchase tickets online beforehand if possible, as the queue to purchase tickets at the counter could take you more than an hour.Recommended to go up to both levels, particularly during sunset. The view will be worthwhile.

Ridiculously high up!. First there's Eiffel Tower high, then there's Empire State Building high. Finally there's Skytree high! Immense views of Tokyo which will keep you entertained for a while. Easy to travel to on public transport and very easy to find! A definite recommendation!
Its very tall.... Went to both observation decks. You can feel the building move with the wind. I hate heights, but had to see the views this offered. It was worth it!

Excellent View!. Great view here. Arrived early in morning to find no crowds which was excellent.
Managed to go straight in and had a good bit of free time to observe the view
Would be back!

In the cloud !!!. I was really in the cloud..not joking. Once you go to the top, you can really be on the clouds. I visited in Nov and it was raining and cloudy. See the photos.From the top, you can see the city and the river, whenever the clouds allows. You can take photos there, an audio-video is also played about the construction of the skytree. There are coffee shops and souvenir shops and a bar too (If I recollect correctly).

Good view but be prepared to wait. Plenty of options to spend more money once you have paid the basic price. Tourists get access to an (optional) priority queue for an additional fee, nonetheless still expect a fair wait and everybody gets to wait coming back down. Way-finding not too intuitive once upstairs. Views depend on the weather. Not many toilets once up the top. A clean, modern facility with good staff but not sure I would go back.

Great view but it is expensive to get to the top!. First about getting tickets.You get to the fourth floor and get your ticket that tells you when to come back to purchase your tickets.However if you are a international foreigner (with passport) you can go to the side entrance and get in by waiting in line. First come first serve. Usually less than 15 minutes wait. One foreigner can bring up to two Japanese friends with them. Note that the tickets are 500 yen more expensive per ticket than going the usual route however you save hours of time.After you get to the 350 meter mark, you have to purchase another ticket to get to the top 450 M mark.We waited until it was a hour before sunset so we got to see the sunset and the city lights turning on. It was well worth it. Beautiful sunny day however the pollution was pretty bad so you only saw a silhouette of Mt. Fuji. Regardless the view is still spectacular and you can spend endless amount of time just looking at the surroundings.It was 3800 yen per person to the top including the 500 yen extra for the foreigner lineup bypass. Would I do this again? Probably not but it is worth doing at least once so say you were on the highest tower in the world at this time.
Great View. We love this place as it gives you a great view of Tokyo! We walked to this place and got surprised by different places that captures our interest.A must-visit for anyone!

Great views! . We didn't go early as recommended and had to queue for about 30 mins, thinking it would be crowded once we got there. But somehow the crowds disperse. Good perspective on the size and orientation of Tokyo. Close to Senso-ji and the river cruise, both of which are also good.

Sky Tree. It is to me just a random structure that doesn't really need to be there. It does have a good view on clear days and lots of shopping. There were so many tourists it was way too busy for me. I like to see it from underneath and far away.

Tokyo is endless. You get a great picture of Tokyo while you go with the super fast elevator that speeds two digits per second. A bit disappointing though that it costs some extra to get all the way up. Anyway, you get a great view of how endless Tokyo really is.

Best views of Tokyo and much much further. This stunning new tower is an essential stop for anyone who likes to see great views of Tokyo and the surrounding area. I was there at sunset and saw stunning views of Fuji. It takes a little time to get there but is well well worth it.

Best view of Tokyo Metropolis. This is a memorable experience for us. We visited there on weekday evening and was not crowded. We were in the queue for less than 15 minutes and finally get in to the deck during sunset. It is a magical view that you should never missed in Tokyo. We stayed there until become fully dark and enjoyed the sparkling view of Tokyo city from night sky. There are two observation decks in 350m and 450m heights. After get in to 350m observation, you have to get another ticket (1030 yen per adult) to go to the second observation deck. However, my personal opinion is that there is nothing much to see in second deck and the view in there was totally disturbed by the outside structure of the tower. The best is 350m deck for me.

Great place to visit, amazing view if the weather is right!. The Toyko Skytree is a great place to visit, assuming you have a nice, clear day to do so! I was fortunate enough to visit on a cloud, haze free day which provided me great, clear views of the Toyko Metropolitan area sprawl as well as a reasonable, albeit distant view of Mt. Fuji. You can look at maps and pictures that show Tokyo but until you go up the Skytree and see it for yourself it is almost impossible to imagine how big the Tokyo area really is.The views are truly amazing, I believe it to be worth the price of admission to both floors to be able to say you saw the urban sprawl of Tokyo. If you were in a hurry you could quickly go up to say you did but it takes a fair bit of time to really understand and respect how dense and sprawled Toyko really is. My suggestion is to visit on a clear, haze free day to get the best views. I was fortunate enough to be able to catch a glimpse of Mt. Fuji, however I was told that is quite rare.There are shopping and eating areas at the base of the tower however I did not explore them in great depth. I am more than happy to advise anyone to go visit the Skytree, however it should be a clear, cloud free day for you to enjoy it at the most.
Best view of Tokyo. The best view of Tokyo,although a little expensive to enter, skytree is very beautiful by night and the is amazing

Futuristic experience! . This towering futuristic structure is an amazing feat of construction.It can be seen from all over Tokyo and on an exceptionally clear day it boasts views of Mount Fuji....For those of you who are not interested in this sky tree, there are plenty of food shops, clothes shops and loos nearby. Close to the metro too.

Great views & interesting food. We celebrated our engagement in the restaurant here with my family &a young niece & nephew. The views are amazing & they did a special kids platter for the little ones as well as being very attentive. They even decorated our dessert plates with wedding messages! There's a good range of browsing shops too but be warned that if you have kids with you,you will be tempted to part with your yen!

Most latest Landmark in Tokyo. Very interesting and amazing site. Many eating places & shops on the 2nd floorA must see place in Tokyo especially for kidsView from top is breathtaking Easy access by train. Asakusa Line & other Tokyo Metro lines go direct to Sky Tree.

A bit pricey, but a great view. The elevator ride to the top was one of the best parts for me, it went so fast but was so smooth. The view at the top was great and if going on a really clear day I can imagine the view of Mt. Fuji would be brilliant. The queues to get up were LONG so we brought the queue jump ticket. I wouldn't say there is much here other than a lot of people and the view, but if you are in the area and it is a clear day then it is a nice thing to do.

On good days long queues and on bad days not worth going for. We went on a day with poor view, but had booked the restaurant up top so thought that it could be worth it anyway. It wasnt. The food was absolute rubbish and lousy service too.

Very tall tower...that's it!. Its a very tall (tallest 'structure' currently), not so good looking tower within a large mall of American proportions. Rates are $30 each with express access for foreign citizens at $15 each. On a good clear day the price maybe worth it based on what interests you. On a clear day you can see Mount Fuji (tallest in Japan). If you don't plan on visiting Fujisan, then the tower might be worth the price. Otherwise if you still love to climb towers you can try another unimpressive tower, the Tokyo Tower (modeled after Eiffel) for less. I was surprised that a metal souvenir of the Skytree or Tokyo tower is not easy to find. Visit Sensoji temple 5 story pagoda, the adjacent Shinto temple and the Big Lantern nearby in Asakusa. Get some souvenirs. I prefer the Miyajima pagoda in Hiroshima, though.

Best views of Tokyo. Went in aug 2015 with my boys aged 11 &12, it was very busy!Lots of things to see and do. My sons wouldn't go up the tower, so we went in the aquarium. My husband went up and said it was amazing! There is a fast track for international visitors, which is more expensive but otherwise you may have to queue for at least an hour. He paid and got straight in the lift that takes you up 330 floors in around a minute. The lift is enclosed and not glass, he said you couldn't really feel it, but the views were amazing!He even saw mt. Fuji popping out of the clouds, which we didn't see when we went on Lake Ashi due to cloud cover. There is also a restaurant up the skytree, and 2 different viewing towers, the higher one is more expensive.Cafes and shops on the lower floors. Must see for the views of Tokyo and beyond

Tokyo Trip October. I read reviews about the great views, but with the long lines and the crowds of people that one encounters at this place. I decided to take a chance and see if I could beat the crowds to Sky Tree and enjoy the place before everyone else showed up.I left Shibuya at 6:30am and got on the Honzomon LIne subway, that goes direct from Shibuya to Oshiage Station. The subway didn't have too many business workers on that train, but I encountered a lot of school kids going to school early in the morning.I arrived at Sky Tree, walked around the area and then got in line about 7:45am. I was on the first elevator up and I had the building to myself for most of an hour. I ate some pastries at the coffee shop and then took some pictures, stood on the glass floor and looked down and went to the 450 meter level.I made an effort to get to Sky Tree as early as possible, since I knew that there would be lots of people and I do not like crowds. When I left about 10:00am, the lines were not too bad, since it was on a Tuesday morning.I thought the tower presented great views of metropolitan Tokyo and the glass floor was really cool. For me, the cost of almost 4000y was worth the effort. After that, you can catch the subway to Asakusa and Senso-ji Temple, which is just across the Sumida River.

Nice landmark. We didn't actually go up this as we decided to go up the Tokyo tower instead which seemed cheaper and less busy. It is a nice land mark but from reading the comments I think Tokyo tower would be better for seeing the sights as it isn't as tall so isn't above the clouds. You can also go to the Tokyo government building which is free to see a good view of Tokyo.

Excellent panoramic view of Tokyo, if you have time. If you have a spare couple of hours in Tokyo, you consider visiting the observation decks of the Sky Tree. On a good day, you can have a great panoramic view of Tokyo and beyond. I visited on a sunny, but hazy day. The view was very good, but the distance was limited. Going up in the elevator at 600 m/min is fun, but the trip is quite short.
Nice view. Tokyo is really nice, but only when there is a sun and u can see what is tokyo about. Lot of modern building. Lot of people queuing but its fast, thanks to the staff who is really helpful

350 meters high is too high?. Another engineering wonder to go so high up but one needs a bit of luck to go on a nice, clear day, free of heavy clouds, rain or misting, or even smog which severly limits the view. Heavily portioned out for 'picture taking' which takes up much of the viewing windows. Still wondering if it was worth price of admission.

Good to see but the queues are a night mare. Went here and you a given a ticket outside with a time to come back and purchase your entrance ticket.Unfortunately we went at 11am but our viewing time was 4.30pm so couldn't stay as we had to much to do. My advise is pre book if you can.

Amazing view of Tokyo from above. We have paid to go up to the highest floor (450m) and it was so worth it! Skyscrapers look like normal buildings. Tokyo is so beautiful, even from above... what a great experience! But go when it's sunny!

Not bad but extremely crowded. . Queues were around 45-60 minutes on a Wednesday around 2:30pm. There were a lot of people around. Views are great but there is also a lot of people here which makes it feel too crowded to enjoy. I think it's more worthwhile to check the views from the free government building or Asahi beer tower which has a small fee.

The Best View. The Tokyo Skytree tower is like no other. Of course it is a very tall tower where you can look at spectacular 360 views of Tokyo, but it is also a complex that contains a big grocery store, restaurants, bars and other shops - so much stuff that it is easy to get sensory overload. This is a great place to take kids, with lots of things for them to see and do.

Amazing place and views!. This place is a must see if you're visiting Tokyo. Aside from the tower itself, there's also an aquarium, mall shops and restaurants on the ground level. Depending on when you visit, expect lines to be long. We went early in the day (around 11:00) and still had to que for 40 minutes. When you arrive, there's a sign that will tell you how long your wait will be. We went to the Tembo Deck (mid section) and still had amazing views of Tokyo. This is a great place to spend an afternoon.

Worth your money. If you can navigate the huge crowds that you will certainly find here and you can find your way to the right entrance and the right box office (there is a separate box office for foreign visitors so you don't need to have a reservation and can bypass the local tourists), it is worth your big dollars. yes, it is quite pricey but again, it is well worthy. You have magnificent views of the entire city and if you are lucky also of Mt. Fuji (we weren't quite so lucky!!). To access the higher observation deck (Tembo Galleria) you have to pay an additional fee which we did not do. You could visit the Skytree on a rainy day but chances are you won't see much so I would not recommend it.

What a great experience!!. This is the tallest tower in the world at 634m but even the views at 350 or 450m were out of this world! The visitor lines were well managed and less than a half hour wait. There is even a foreign visitor pass you can obtain at the information desk which made the wait only about 5 minutes. The elevator cruises up to 350m in 50 seconds and it is so smooth you can hardly tell it is moving. There is a glass bottom section of the floor at 350m looking straight down the tower to the earth below. Definitely go on a clear day for the best views. Views are 360 with flour to ceiling windows. Well worth the trip to see this tower and fabulous views.

A most tall telecommincation post of the world.. To go up to the top floor should be arrive early in the morning due to the very very long long line for ticket booking that takes you for hour waiting, but it is good experience to visit. not only a hop up by the very fast elevator in minutes, also the view point deck for you to see the far off as your eyes can see , that says about 70 K.M. away! So the early morning is the best time to visit.

Absolutely beautiful!. An absolute must see... all of Tokyo from one view. Easy access by metro. Sky tree line to sky tree station. Top floor 640 meters up. During the day you can see Mt Fuji, but the evening view is breathtaking. Have a drink or a bite to eat from one of the most gorgeous views in all of Tokyo.

Breaktaking Tokyo views. Visited the Tokyo Skytree on a bright sunny day and the views were superb! The queues looked extremely long but if you hold an international passport, there is a fast track queue although this is slightly more expensive. Make sure you visit when the weather is good, as they tend to close during really adverse conditions. It is slightly disappointing that you have to pay extra to visit a slightly higher observation tower and there isn't much more to do when you get there. Otherwise, the tower is situated within a retail complex, with an aquarium and large retail complex so there's plenty of other things to do there other than visiting the tower.

Kind of cool; overpriced; make sure to go on a clear day. We went to this attraction on a day when it was a bit hazy so it was very hard to see farther-away things such as Mt. Fuji, which was disappointing. However, the view was otherwise pretty impressive.VERY VERY crowded. Do not go if you get claustrophobic.If you are a foreign visitor you can get a more expensive ticket up that lets you skip part of the wait.

Average tourist attraction. Obviously the Tokyo Skytree is magnificent to see and was not an entirely regrettable experience; however, I did not find it to be as thrilling as I had hoped. The line, while it did move relatively quickly, was still around 45 minutes, plus a short wait onto the elevators, and then another wait to get back down. The views are incredible, but they are difficult to experience with the swarming mobs of people present. It was too busy to enjoy, and we went midweek, midday, so unless there is a better time to go, I would assume it's always quite busy. Not to mention, it costs money that I didn't find worth it. We went to the tower at the government building (which is free) and had similar fantastic views, so I would personally recommend that instead.

Great View. If you can prove that you are a foreigner you get to wait about 20 mins to go up rather than an hour that the locals wait. There is a special entrance to do this.View was stunning. You can pay extra to go to a higher level once you get to the main viewing deck. I didn't think it was worth the extra other for the reason that there are less people at the higher level.

Great view if not cloudy. We went here on a Saturday and it was extremely crowded. There are two observation decks. The lower one is about 350M high and the upper deck reaches over 450M. It costs extra to go to upper deck. The views would be spectacular if it is a clear day. It is said that you can see Mt. Fuji if it is clear. The day we visited it was very overcast but the view of the city lights was great anyway. I would suggest visiting on a week day just before dusk.
Beautiful views. Beautiful views in both day and night. You can have a photo taken up there for around $12 aus. You can pay an extra $10 to go even higher up.

Great views . Visited the sky tree whilst spending a few days in Tokyo. The views are great and the glass floor experience is fantastic. If you are an international visitor, take advantage of the fast track entrance, it costs 800 yen extra but will save you an hour waiting for the lift

Not my favourite attraction. We've been to plenty of observation towers in our travels, my husband loves the experience of seeing a city from above. Tokyo is so large and I much prefer personally to experience it from the ground amongst the locals. There aren't all that many amazing architectural sights from this view of Tokyo in comparison to other cities. Many many tourists, long lines, and an expensive entry fee. There's two observation decks and you're stung again for more yen if you want to head up to the highest point. If you are headed to sky tree, keep an eye out for the separate express queue for foreigners. If you're foreign you can skip the long line for an extra few yen (45 minute wait upon our visit). Fuji is rarely viewable from the observation deck. I'd personally miss the sky tree in favour of other attractions.

Amazing views especially at night. Great View of the City! A must see when in Tokyo. Go at nighttime. Make sure you set aside at least 2 hours to do the attraction. The mall below is filled with many great shops that are a must see as well. This is a very busy attraction so make sure you have the time to spend

Cool view!. If you're in need of a 360 view of the Tokyo skyline than this is your place! The elevator takes to the deck quite fast. The view is simply awesome. There is also a little coffeeshop and a restaurant located at the first deck. The skytree is a cool place to visit.

Go for the fast ticket!. We visited late afternoon with 2 young children, if you have kids (or even if you don't) the fast ticket option is worthwhile. It's for international visitors only, costs about 2800 yen instead of the usual 2000 approx., but gets you straight to the lift to the 350m deck. A short line to buy the tickets but very straightforward, then escorted to the lift. Saved about an hour wait on a Monday afternoon. At the 350m deck you can buy a ticket to go to the 450m deck, stand at the back of the lift and look up to see the way! This was another 1000 approx. yen for adults. Kids 3 and under free, older kids pay reduced rates, a few different age brackets on the website. Our kids age 3 and 5 loved it and the views were terrific! Although it's pretty pricey, for me it was a highlight of Tokyo, really glad we went up the extra 100m for the full experience.

Journey into the sky!. I would say Tokyo Skytree is one of my newer favorite attractions to visit. I've already been a couple of times and enjoy it thoroughly each time :DThe good thing is if it's busy they offer and express lane for visitors with foreign passports. It's a bit extra to use the pass but if you're visiting from overseas your time is limited and I think it's well worth it.Aside from ththe wonderful views you'll get from ththe top of the tower ( a 360 degree view of Tokyo! ) you can also enjoy their cafe or restaurant, souvenir shop and various picture opportunities that are available! When visiting Tokyo don't miss this place!

Great views - fantastic restaurant. Take the time to find the international visitors line to buy your ticket- it will save you a lot of time. I was lucky to go on a clear sunny day so the views were amazing. Then went to lunch at the restaurant at the top. This was a highlight- the food was absolutely amazing- highly recommend taking the time.

nice to visit on a clear day. Tokyo sky tree is worth going up to the observatory on a clear day, there's 2 observatories, the first observatory ticket must be bought in order to go up and then once up there you can then buy the ticket to go up higher. The ticket for the 1st observatory can be bought on the 4th floor you must exit the door which leads you unto a deck with chairs and a garden area to get to the ticket counter. The tickets are pricey but if you are there on a super sunny day, it's worth it to soak in the view of Tokyo. If not there's plenty of shops and food to keep you busy in the Tokyo sky tree town!

Up, up and away!!. Having done the Tokyo Tower and Kyoto Tower, we thought it only right and proper to check out Skytree.Good God what a structure, 634 metres (over 2,100 feet) of tubular steel that gives a view of Tokyo that will surely never be bettered. It allows for a glimpse of the size and location of Tokyo, as the bay is clearly visible - but the overriding impression is the reach of the city - an impression that I will hold for many, many years. If you have a head for heights - including standing on the glass floor!! you cannot leave the city without going up there. My Wife cannot stand heights so she waited down below where there is more than enough for her to busy herself with judging by the number of shops to visit.Only down side is the queue to get up there - we waited in line for around 45 mins and you get the feel this could be organised better, but hey! the final result was more than you could ever expect - A visit here should be compulsory unless you have a doctor's note!!

Nice thing to do early on a clear day. It was a little cloudy when we arrived at the Skytree. The line appeared to be short and we got to the top within 15 minutes of arriving. When we got to the top we got a nice view of the city but due to the clouds Fuji was not visible.There were a bunch of teens running around which made it difficult to navigate around the area. We found that you could go down a level and that proved to be a much better experience as the kids stayed in the top level.By the time we got back to the street level we found that the lines had significantly increased at it now showed a wait time of 45 minutes. Definitely glad we made it there early so we didn't have to wait to go up and then feel crowded.They provide information in English and the shops have gifts available. The mall area has more variety so we opted to make our purchases there instead.Overall it was a nice visit but the clouds made it harder to find the views for pictures of the city.

Worth the visit. It was a fun experience.. You can see the tower from wherever you are in Tokyo.. Fee was kinda expensive but it was worth it.. Try going in the late evening coz you will get the view of sunset which is nice.. Kinda crowded even in weekdays..

Great view - go early!. A great starting point for your Tokyo trip as it gives you a sense of the scale of the city. It is well worth getting the extra ticket to go right to the top - it's very high! One piece of advice: buy your tickets online before you go as the queue was VERY long.

Was entertaining even on a rainy day. You must fit this into your vacation. This isn't very far from Senso-ji temple. We almost didn't visit because of the weather. There were quite a few school groups that day. The exhibits are informative, interesting and well thought out. Afterwards, we had lunch at the mall. This is a great photo opportunity and a chance to get a feel for the city. I highly recommend.

visit to the skytree. We were very surprised and would defiantly visit again on our next trip to Tokyo. The staff so friendly even spoke good English. The place was clean easy to reach and well managed.

Incredible view. I am afraid of heights, but this was worth the view. We could see everything except Mt. Fuji that day. We paid the extra money to go to the gallery as well. We also had our picture made while standing on the glass bottom. I did not look down and did ok for the quick picture. It makes a nice souvenir! As an international visitor, you have a special line that takes you right to the top with hardly any wait. We got there at 4 pm and saw a sign saying all the tickets had been given out for the day, but that does not apply to the international visitors. Our Japanese friend was also able to accompany us. I would love to go back when Mt. Fuji is visible! We stayed for sunset and got both types of views. Very nice!

celebrating its 3rd anniverary. The attraction is celebrating its 3rd anniverary. Despite it is already celebrating its 3rd anniversary, tourist and locals are still pouring into this attraction. Foreign travellers may pay extra to have a priority queue - may worth it if you don't want to line up for an hour before getting to the observation deck

Surprised by the number of quality shops in the mall. I was here 3 years ago when it first opened its doors to the public. I am back again for the 3rd time and am pleasantly surprised by the number of quality stores it is housing. A really nice place to shop! Love that it features mainly Japanese labels and not shops not originated from Japan.

Great sights. Great way to see Tokyo. Elevator is so smooth, you almost don't realize you are travelling up or down. Beautiful sights. You can pay $20 for the first level and another $10 for the next higher. Tourists should always visit this sight.

A fantastic view, with great shops and attractions.. When we visited Tokyo, this was a must on our list, as it is the tallest of its kind. Prices are a bit high, especially if you let yourself fooled into buying the tickets aimed for foreign tourists (we didn't :) ). After you buy the tickets, and go through a security check, you will be taken to the top with a 600m/sec speed elevator, which is a kind of a unique experience. From the top you can watch over Tokyo, as its borders dissapear in mist. It's magical, and the panels here are really informative. A lot of shops here, also glass floors etc. to maximize the experience.To summarize: unique experiences for a bit high prices. Worth to visit if your budget enables it.

The view was stunning but pricey!. The best view of the city. Fullstop. Extremely expensive though and i was resetnful of the queues and hustle. Try the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observation deck on weekdays instead as it is free!

A view to remember. Paid the extra, skipped the 30 min entrance lineup. The 350m floor was crowded, so paid more and went to 450m floor. Spectacular view, not so crowded. We were able to see the ferris wheel at Tokyo Disneyland. Went just before twilight so was able to see both floors in the daylight and at night. Timed it to eat at the Sky tree restaurant to enjoy the beautiful nighttime view. Highly recommend this attraction for the sheer amazement of the view and the part window ceiling of the elevator going up.

Tokyo SkyTree Sunset Visit. Excellent views of Tokyo City. We were able to secure pre-purchased tickets (arranged for our local guide to obtain them - good idea as the queue was long - we did not need to queue) and visit the observation deck at sunset. The views of the city as the sun set and the lights came on was lovely. It was however, very crowded being a Saturday night and obviously a very popular destination. If possible, would recommend visiting during a less popular time of evening so that you don't have to elbow your way to the window for a view. In all, worth the visit.

Tokyo Skytree - A sight to behold. The place to go where you can see the the whole of Tokyo. There is no need to go to the highest observation deck to enjoy the view, though. The view is just stunning at the First Observatory (350m)! However, found the entrance fees a tad too expensive. Many shops can be found there for your souvenir hunting. A place to go if in Tokyo for the experience.

Amazing views, great shopping and food.. It was easy to spend a whole day here. The sky was clear so we decided to go up to the top of Skytree before it became too crowded. We were rewarded with fantastic views all over Tokyo! We then had the difficult task of choosing somewhere to eat. The options are huge in the Solamachi shopping mall. You can eat in the food court areas or choose individual restaurants. The shopping here is great too! This is where we bought most of our souvenirs for family and friends.

Must go Landmark!. Our hotel is very near to this Landmark and thus we spent a night time there. Everything is new and wonderful and the night view is excellence. The price is worthy and we can hang around there to enjoy the beautiful night view!

Night time is the best time to visit . Its better if you go at night time, the view from the top is amazing ❤Waiting on line could be bit boring but that worth the view. Staffs are really helpful and even if they cant speak english.

Very impressive. Easily accessible from Asakusa station, just go to the top floor to get to Skytree. Highly recommend buying the foreigner pass which lets you skip the queue to get to the 350m. Worth paying more to see from 450m

Great view. We decided not to go to the foreigner's line, regular line was long, but moved quickly. The view from lower deck is impressive. We went for a higher one, 450 meters, and it doesn't worth additional 1030 yen. Windows there are smaller, a lot of lights reflect on them, and it's hard to make a decent photo. But the crowd is much thinner there. All very organized, a little bit expensive, but still very worth a visit.

Incredible. Unbelievable structure. Worth the fee to the first stop at 350m. Incredible views of Tokyo and Mt Fuji if you are lucky. We were not; however it only took 20 minutes to get through the ticket line..can be a lot worse. Arriving at dusk we were treated to the lights of the city turning on. A.wesome shopping at the base..turned out to be a fitting end to our day of touring

This is a must!. The view is well worth the wait (queues can be guite long)! The beautiful Skytree itself is staggeringly massive and in addition to that you'll get a better glimpse of Tokyo's astonishing size.

A display of great Japanese engineering . The cheapest way to get here is the metro
Very impressive tower
You have to buy the dearer foreigners ticket or you will be waiting 2 hours
Only ten minutes with ticket
Great fast huge smooth lifts
Excellent views although u are unlikely to see Mount Fuji
Nice shop
About 20 euro for fast ticket
A must in Tokyo

Great views of Tokyo. Went there at night. It had gorgeous views of Tokyo. Didn't take long to get to the top and even though its packed, its very well managed (but then again what in Japan isn't) There is an area with a glass floor where you can take pictures of the bottom of the tower from all the way up top, quite dizzying. The basement of the tower has some nice quick-eat places. Just get a quick bite there after your visit if you want. Highly recommend it, and I would suggest, the night view is probably better, adding to the actual expanse of the gorgeous city view. Right on top of the subway station too. You really have no reason to miss out on this engineering marvel.
Super Mega Tallest Tower. Extremely tall. Definitely worth a visit. Tourists are able to skip the line for a small fee, which makes for a very painless visit.

Lot of things to see for young children.. My daughter enjoyed the planetarium, we watched the show about the stars, they have shows like every hour with different titles. Interesting for young kids and at the same time they learn something from it. But it's only in Japanese.

Great views!. For some reason I love going up to high-up observation decks when I am in a new city to get a broad overview. SkyTree was therefore on my to-do list for Tokyo. We got there the moment it opened on a clear day, and were rewarded with no lines, and fantastic views of the city and surrounding area. We paid the extra to get to the very top level, because why not. I really enjoyed it.ProTip: if you are a foreign tourist, bring your passport and you DO NOT NEED TO WAIT IN LINE. There is a special entrance for foreign tourists on the basement level where you can buy an express ticket that will bypass the lines and take you straight to the top of the tower. (If you're waiting in the snaking lines for the ticket counters at the courtyard level, you're in the wrong line.)

Paid the money, but saw nothing. We paid the money and got to the Observation deck at 350 m. But we had no view at all. It was too cloudy and misty. We left after waiting there for an hour, bitterly disappointed. We were not informed of the poor visibility problem when we bought the tickets.Better and frank communication is needed. We could have gone back the next day, or even later that afternoon.
Iconic Landmark in the Skyline. The Skytree is visible from various directions. It's an iconic landmark in the skyline. We photographed the Skytree from the river.

For some of the time we had clear skies but other attractions in and around tower made up for it. First thing to do when you get there is to get your time tag for going up the tower - then there'll be plenty of time to look around - otherwise you may have to wait all day to go up! Views are fabulous, but you need a clear day otherwise there won't be much to see! Loads of shopping and restaurants to keep you happy all day long. Very easy to get to as well...would definitely recommend to do when in Tokyo.

If you come to Tokyo a must do attraction. Take the subway to the Oshiage exit and voila you are there. If you are a foreigner go to the foreign ticket counter, a little more yen, but saves a very long wait just to buy a ticket. We came at night and the city lights were wonderful, unfortunately the weather was still unstable from the recent rains so long distant views were faded. work your way around the crowds to get a full 360 view and if you angle your camera can get pictures that don't have window reflection or distortion. For a few more Yen you can go up to the upper level, but when we were there the wait and the crowds we very clausterphobic, if the evening would have been very clear we would have gone up. After wandering around the level, eventually you will work your way down a couple of floors to the exit elevators. the wait time to go down is not that long, and then you have 7 floors of shopping to experience.The Good: great views even on a semi cloudy nightThe Bad: Lots of pushing and shoving from the crowdsThe Ugly: The wait time if you don't get an express ticket.On the scuba bubble scale of 1 to 10, I give this tower 8 bubbles for a great view

Great views in one of the tallest tourist traps in the world.. Great views of Tokyo. As expected, lots of people lining up to go up the tower, on the observation decks, and going down. Prices are a little steep but it was quite worth it.
Nice view of Tokyo on a clear day. Be sure to visit on a clear day, otherwise you might be disappointed. Queues can get quite long, however they move fast

the line was to long but had good shopping time. I was expecting a good view of tokyo but i couldn't climb because the line was 3h. The aquarium was beautiful i was able to see many marine life. they have many shops inside which is cool to see many Japanese goods.

Fantastic View of Tokyo. Need to buy a ticket to get to the first platform and another ticket to the second platform. I only get on the first one with a restaurant and a cafe. Food and drinks are expensive on the top while hard to find a seat for rest. However, the view is great. You can see the whole Tokyo from above. Perhaps more beautiful in the night. Traffic to there is convenient with subway.
