Fantastic view from above Tokyo. Although it can get quite crowded up there, it definitely worths a visit and the view is amazing. I went there at evening and the night view of Tokyo is impressive.Afterall, it is a must-go in Tokyo and I am sure that it will be an unforgettable experience.

A Must Do - if the weather is OK.. Didn't manage to see the tower outside, from the base until the end of the visit as enclosed building from underground station to the tower. You can avoid the queues to get up the tower if you have a foreign passport & pay extra. Have a good look around the lower deck before deciding if you want to go higher, we did & it was worth it, because of clearer views. Lots of shops in the mall at the base, like nearly everywhere else in Tokyo.
Fantastic Views. Worth it for the views, but a bit pricey. On crowded days, it will take some time to get up, but non-Japanese get to use a separate entrance. This is worth it.

Oh dear yes!!!!. Your ears will def pop!!! The elevator goes super fast and super quiet. You cant even feel it! The views are spectacular and everything is so organized and all the employees are so nice! Great quick stop in Asakusa after the Sensoji temple.

Good way to orient yourself in city. We visited Skytree at 8.30am on a Friday morning in September. The long lines in readiness for the crowds told us that we had made a good choice to get up early and go straight to Skytree. We just walked straight in and got a ticket. It was a great way to get our bearings in Tokyo as we could see in all directions and recognised key landmarks. We walked back to Asakusa Station from Skytree. This 20 minute walk through regular Tokyo neighbourhoods was really enjoyable on a nice day with good views of the river, houses and local life.

Visited 2 times during my 2 weeks trip. Shopping was massive fun indoor. The skytree was great and excellent, memorable romantic trip. Words can't really describe my wonderful trip here. It is highly recommended to go during sunset and clear skies. Plan it in advance and you will never regret.
Tokyo Skytree. One of the top attractions when visiting Tokyo. Go on a clear day for the best views of surrounding Tokyo and then head to Sensoji Temple afterwards one railway stop away.

The top of the world. Wonderful view of Tokyo and great photo opportunities from the top level. Lifts were so smooth you didn't realise they were moving. Very helpful staff. Definitely worth a visit just to see how large a city Tokyo is!!
Skytree. Exclusive shopping and nice birds eye view. Luxury shops, good shopping. Bit expensive. Nice restaurant at higher levels. Super cheese cakes, train station down below

Super high tower, and amazing view on the city!! . Good place to bring a girl for a date, bring some professional camera if u coming at night time the view completely stunning.
Tickers around 3500yen to highest tower.
They have two kind of tickets 2000 and little more for 350 meters and they charge another 1000 for 450.

Amazing View!. An amazing view of what seems the entirety of Tokyo! Great opportunity for a photo or two too. Lovely, welcoming staff. Reasonably priced gift shop as well for all your tourist needs. Futuristic, modern tower that is sure to make your day!

Amazing, just make sure its a clear day. The view is amazing and breathtaking. Would have been even better if the day was more clear.
Conveniently has it own metro station so you can get there fairly easy. If you can decipher the spagetthi loop subway system.

Not the best weather but still some decent views. Visited on a very overcast day so knew the views wouldn't be the best but as I was only visiting for a few days I figured it would be worth it. Still a fun visit and reasonable value and an impressive view of the city though shame about the weather. I imagine it would be much more impressive on a nice day!

Awesome place, not just the views. Great place to visit, definitely worth a visit. While the tower it self is imposing and provides great views of the city; is much more than that.The bottom of the tower is actually a shopping center, very cool stores, not your typical mall, more of a novelty, gadgets and souvenir shops, with restaurants, etc. very, very cool. Also when you come out to the terrace in the 4th floor (where the actual entrance to the tower is) there is an outdoor bar/restaurant that is super cool at night. You can have drinks/ food at the foot of the tower, with great views. Best time to visit, definitely at night. Climb to the top, then drinks at the outdoor bar. Very cool place, worth a visit.

what a view. We went up just before dusk amazing view of the city and great time to visit as we slowly watched the skyline change .The left up is an experience in its own right.dont forget to try standing on the glass floor but not for the faint hearted. Well worth the cost.

Incredible views from a futuristic tower!!!. Tokyo Skytree offers breathtaking view of the city!! I spent over an hour and half admiring the city below me. It was incredible! Highly recommended attaction in Tokyo.

Don't go if it's raining or cloudy!. Went with my boyfriend, we were told it was poor visibility but we had already taken a long train ride to get there so we brought a ticket anyway. It was still a cool experience because it had a lot of information ect about the skytree. We went at night so we could see the city lights, you could still see the lights and the city but if you wanted to take photos they don't come out very well in the bad weather. If you are going to go to the skytree make sure it's a clear day/night for a full experience.

Check the weather before going. I checked the weather before heading there (it was raining) but I didn't think visibility would be zero (just gray). The lady at the ticket counter was awesome. She showed us the view from the top on their real time monitors (the screen was a solid gray - couldn't see anything) and asked if we still wanted to buy tickets. I really appreciated the gesture and customer orientation (no surprise in Japan but still impressive). We decided not to go up. The view of the tower from outside, at night with the changing colors, is still worthwhile.

Awesome view from an awesome tower. got there late about an hour before closing and was able to walk right in and up to the first observation deck in minutes.... no crowd or line..... made our way around and then up to the next level near the top of the highest freestanding tower in the world!!!!

Worth a visit . Went to the tower today and used the express lane so we did not have to wait. The view would be great on a clear day but it was not today. Good free alternative is the government building towers and much less busy

Reasonably nice. Gotta go once in Tokyo.. If you're a foreigner it's totally worth the fast line for international tourists. Costs like $7 more per person. We had no wait and went straight up. Relatively clear day in September and we went up around 6 PM so got a peek at the sunset and got a glimpse of Mt Fuji (not exactly a clear one). There's another fee (about $10) to go up even higher. We went up - what the heck! The advantage is there are very few people up there relative to the main deck.The cool part was seeing the glittering city emerge in the darkness. IMHO, Tokyo in the daylight from here looks ugly. A massive concrete jungle. Much nicer at night. We stayed and had a drink at the SkyTree Cafe – again it's a bit overpriced (a drink is about $2 more than elsewhere) but not unreasonable IMHO for the location.The mall underneath is also quite good.

Great views of the entire city!. As far as observation decks go this was quite a nice one. The price was just over 2000 yen each which compared to other major cities seems reasonable, and although it was hazy and thus Mt Fuji was not visible the rest of the city was quite visible. I think to see Mt Fuji it would need to be a very clear day as it is quite far from the city.There are a few basic cafes up there and a restaurant, I was looking for a bar though similar to the Seattle Space Needle but couldn't find one. One cool feature besides the views is the large touchscreens that let you zoom in on various parts of the city and view them as well as get information.The line to get a ticket was almost an hour which was a bit tiring but there was free WiFi which allowed us to catch up on posting updates from earlier in the day and look into food places in the area.

Higher is not always better.. Went there on our last night in Tokyo. Paid over 2000 yens to ride the fast and smooth elevator to the observation deck. Fancy display offers magnified view, day view and historical view of the skyline of Tokyo. However, being rather flat and spread out, the night view felt a little underwhelming. Day time view on a clear day that allow you to see Mount Fuji might be more interesting. Having walked around the observation desk once, I didn't think I need to pay another 1000 yen to go even higher up. In fact, I think the view from the base of the skytree on the 5th floor looking up was more breathtaking. Could have saved that 2000 yens for a nice drink and dinner at the al fresco restaurant on the 5th floor. Is the view always nicer from the top? I beg to differ at least in this particular instance. Been there, done that. Nothing more. High elevation, high price, low satisfaction.P.S. I was waiting for my godson on the 6th floor of Solamachi (the shopping mall at the base of the Skytree) and it offered a rather interesting view of trains passing by. I bought a macha softserve over ice matcha at an outlet on that floor for just over 500 yens and I think I enjoyed that almost just as much.They do offer free wifi at Solmachi but I can't keep track of how many times the connection was reset. Very annoying. They have to do something about that free (but almost useless) wifi in the mall.

Overstated tower. I had gone to the Tokyo Tower last year, and so I chose to go to the Skytree this year, but I was very disappointed. It was definitely not better than Tokyo Tower even though it's newer. It wasn't over the top pricey, but I felt it was too expensive for the view. But I might have been unlucky with the weather. Do not go there unless it's a cloudless sky, because you won't see Mount Fuji from there otherwise. However, the shopping center surrounding the Skytree was very good. Lots to see and lots to eat and experience. So there is more to do at the Skytree than just admire the view. There is no student discount, everyone over the age of 18 pays the same price. I would recommend buying tickets online, since the line can get pretty big, although it was quite effective.

Sleepless light 🌕. Nearby Asakusa from walking distance 35 minutes depend which street you use , is beautiful tower deco by colourful light or LED but sorry I forgot entrance fees and for those Tokyo banana lovers , pls refer ground floor and purchase direct from their shop beside shopping mall .
Amazing Tower to visit!. Latest state of art Japanese construction, Simply stunning!An elevator ride to over 300m in less than 60sd...unmatched view over Tokyo surroundings....A worthwhile visit

Make sure to pack light if you are going there on the weekend. Wow, I was there on one of the most busiest day of the year. The small Solamachi (Mall) they have was so crowded that we were moving inch by inch marching like ants throughout the mall. Finally got to the tower and the wait was 2.5 hours which is the only reason why we did not go up to the observatory. There is always a next time for me but when will that be..... They bottom of the Skytree had a little lounge type of restaurants where you are able to gaze up the tower to a point you need to get a massage on your neck the next day. Oh one thing you should definitely do is to buy a ticket for the day you are going in advance. This way, you probably don't have to line up to get the same day pass which we tried to get and felt defeated with 2.5 hrs of waiting line. Lot's of Japanese type of shops and eatery. A good recommendation for people who are visiting Japan.

Nice View. I went here as part of a crazy day in Tokyo, if you bring your passport you can skip the massive line for an extra fee, I wish I did as the standard line took a good hour to get through.The journey to the 350m level is quick once you have your tickets, there is a few places for a nice view, a glass floor and cafe. To get right up to the top there is another line and an extra fee around $10 I skipped this option and had a cake in the cafe instead. It is incredibly busy at school holiday time so be aware but a nice little activity.
Nice expirience. Nice view, nice stores, nice food, I like it, and it is one of highlights of Tokyo. It was no crowdie...

Tokyo from the sky. We took the sky tree and asakusa sightseeing package through trip advisor.Our visit to the sky tree was a lot easier as we could skip the long queue. The view was spectacular from the top. Highly recommended for tourists.
Top of the world. I visited Tokyo skytree in 2014 with my wife, the view you get from this tower is incredible. you will feel at top of the world.

Room with a view. Even though it was a murky day the views from the tower were magnificent. The lift to the top travelled at an incredible but undramatic speedThe price of 2060 yen (circa £10) for an adult was as expected and the viewing platform was large enough to accommodate the many visitorsOf course were plenty of shops both at the top and bottom of the tower and I've never seen so many guides around all wiling to help. I guess the unemployment in Tokyo is low by keeping so many busy in these menial positions, repeating mantra ad nauseam. Sounds like some childish computer game
Amazing Views. I was so impressed with this tower. They didn't just do a simple observation deck. They made it fun. You didn't just go up there and see the sights.
Tokyo from on high!. Going 364feet in 15 seconds to the viewing area was an experience in itself. The views were great and although it was a bit smoggy on the day still some good photos.
Just wow. Absolutely amazing way to see the sheer scale and size of Tokyo. Would highly recommend to anyone who is visiting for the first time!

Good experience. If you have a credit card issued by a Japanese bank buy your ticket online. You will be skipping the whole queue and treated like VIP. We saved easily two hours queuing and for the same price. You must bring the card you used to make the purchase to claim your ticket.The view at sunset is wonderful, especially if in winter time when the air is drier and visibility is at its best.The first stop at 350 meters was good enough for us.

After go to Odaiba by fantastic boat. Odaiba is an artificial island in Tokyo Bay.Fantastic. You can enjoy All day. And take the completly automated train crossing the Bay. Tip : try to be in the 1st car on the 1st row. You will cross the so beautiful Rainbow Bridge 756 m long 100 m high above the Ocean. Vertiginous !

Great views and worth the trip. As the second tallest building in the world it is worth the visit although they do squeeze extra pennies out of you by putting a surprise charge to get to the very top.I would advise visiting during the day as at night many pictures will be spoiled by the reflection off of the windows, some good fun, couple it with a visit to a good local restaurant.

stunning views from the tallest point in Tokyo. stunning views from the tallest point in Tokyo. the admission price is not expensive and you get to have the express check-in if you are an international visitor (make sure to take your ID with you, passport not needed)

Stunning views!. We hummed and harred about going up the tower as we both suffer vertigo. An attendant advised us it would be a 3 hour wait but for an extra fee we could get an express pass as a foreign visitor. (If you want to do it this way you need to have your passports with you). There was no waiting at the 'foreign visitor' ticket desk. We were then ushered to the front of what was a massive queue and after a cursory security bag check we were off in the lift. The lift whisked us upwards at a fair rate and our ears popped. The views were just breathtaking and really brought home just how big Tokyo actually is. The helpful leaflet we were given along with the numbered pillars allowed us to recognise the various landmarks and helped me get my bearings.We visited the cafes on both floors of the first station. For an extra charge you can take a second lift to the uppermost deck. We didn't bother! There are lots of opportunities to have professional photographs taken and there are also a couple of souvenir shops on the deck. Back to the entrance level there is a huge beer garden and a shopping/ leisure/ food complex. It you arrive by Metro you can enter the complex direct via a number of escalators.Note: as this is a relatively new attraction it didn't appear in a number of older guide books.Well worth the visit.... the other option would be to visit as dusk falls and watch the city light up.

Great View. I can't say that the lines were a problem since my friend got them for me in advance. I went to the tower in the evening on a clear day. It was beautiful to see all the lights of Tokyo. It was spendy and I would probably only do it once because of that, but I am still glad that I went.
Impressive tower.. I have to say the shops and eateries are more interesting than going up for observatory. I suggest to check it out at late afternoon, stay till evening when the tower light up.

It's really really high!!!!. Great view, it's a little pricey but sure isn't that japan for you. It's well laid out. Don't think they should charge extra for going to the highest point though, should be park of the main price. It's well laid out and thought about, which you would expect from a modern attraction.

Not worth the money. It may be second tallest building in the world, but it is not worth going up. For the 2000Y you just go to the first observatory which is full of touristy crap blocking the 360° view. if you wanna go higher you have to pay another 1000Y and I doubt you can see something better. There are better observatories around Tokyo for less or free.

Impressive View. This is a very impressive structure. I paid the fee to go up to the first platform (not all the way to the top). It was a Saturday and it was crowded but not overwhelming. Great place to see the city and take photos. Don't go if you have claustrophobia as they really pack you into the elevators. If you can buy a ticket at your hotel or online you can skip the long line to buy tickets at the venue. Definitely for tourists but I'd recommend checking it out.

Sky tree rip off. After trekking for ages - eventually found the sky tree and massive queues - I was asked if I was a foreign holidaymaker as if so there was a special queue - great fantastic - join a small queue and get to the front to be told it's £25 to get to the first level plus a further £15 for the second one - £80 for two of us -no thanks !Go to Tokyo tower instead - maybe not so high but the views are amazing and 1/4 the price

Breathtaking view. I arrived around 10 AM on Monday so it was not too crowded and the waiting time for tickets was only about half an hour. The view from the first observatory is stunning, but I'd definitely recommend going all the way up to the second observatory - there is an additional fee for that, but it's worth it. Due to the haze it was not possible to see Mt. Fuji, but the view of Tokyo from the top was breathtaking.

Best views In tokyo . Went here after visiting both tokyo tower and gobernent office building.
Tokyo Skytree has better views and has much better energy. Activities to do
And shopping

Worth the trip to the top for a great view. We pre-booked tickets for late afternoon and therefore avoided queuing which was great. We arrived just before sunset and also paid to go to the top level. In reality not much of a better view although less people at that level. It wasn't the greatest of weather while we were at the top but the view was great and a good way to get the enormity of Tokyo.

Prepare for a hazy shade of Tokyo.. If you're into tall towers, this is worth a visit. However, be prepared for haze and set aside plenty of time for a visit. We arrived on a Monday morning at 10 and couldn't line up for tickets until 12pm-12.30pm. There is a big on-site shopping centre to chew up time, though. Overall, I thought the view from Taipei 101 was far superior.

A must-see in Tokyo. Don't miss this one out on your Tokyo to-do list! The view over the city is breathtaking, even when it's not such a clear day. It wasn't very busy during our visit but the "foreigners que" (look for the right entrace) makes it easy when it is. We didn't pay for the extra highl level because it wasn't a clear day. Also the mall below has an excellent food court.

Check the weather before you go!!!. Tokyo is beautiful. It's a given. Its urban grace, the river, the mountains in the horizon. Very appealing. This is why you would want to take a look at it from the ~400 meter high Tokyo SkyTree tower. HOWEVER - - - Tokyo is extremely hazy many days a year. If you don't go there on a very clear and bright day - don't bother, because you will only be able to see the near environment. I must emphasize: the tower itself is a masterpiece. The inside of the facility is amazing. The service and information is excellent. It is a well crafted touristic attraction. Even the elevator ride is well done. BUT there's really not much to do once you're up there and the fee is a bit high for a well-done elevator ride. And one additional important tip: Bring your passport with you. foreigners have a separate line, with short waiting. to compare - when we visited there - the locals line was 60-90 min. ours was 10.

An Outstanding Attraction . The Tokyo sky tree is wonderful, a gigantic, modern metal structure sprouting out of the ground- and almost touching the clouds! The Skytree is flawless, the price is decent, the queues weren't too long, and the end result was a stunning panoramic view of arguably one of the words most beautiful cities.Thoroughly recommend, visit when in Tokyo!

Great view of Tokyo, shame about the haze though.. Great views however as is typical in summer for Tokyo, the air is hazy and limits how far you can see.We bought tickets at the "Fast Skytree Ticket" counter which has been set up for international visitors only (ID required). This gives you priority over normal ticket holders. However you will pay a premium for the privilege (¥2820 as at Aug 2015) to go to the 350m level.(Tembo Deck).We only waited 15mins on a very busy day.If you want to go to the 450m level (Tembo Galleria) you need to buy an additional ticket whilst you are at the 350m observation deck which from memory cost ¥1020.The elevator is amazingly smooth and fast, reaching a speed of 600m per minute.When we were on the Tembo Galleria level 450m, clouds were passing below us which was an amazing sight.We used an "Über" car (got a cheap rate!) to get there from central Tokyo (Marounouchi) and caught the Metro back.

Tall, Magnificent view, but not really much to do up there.. From outside, Tokyo Skytree looks very beautiful with its modern design. Before I entered, I was very excited to go up. Since I was a foreign tourist, I had a access to the tickets for foreign people and didn't need to wait in a long line. I went straight to the elevator which wasn't that fast compared to other skyscrapers I visited in the world. The view from up the was magnificent. Every single places (except Odaiba) were visible from the top of skytree. There were some cafe and restaurant up there but there really wasn't other things to do. I spent only around 15 minutes up there and came back down to the ground. Although I didn't have to wait in line, I am not really sure if it is worth going up for other Japanese people who have been waiting in line for approximately two hours. Don't forget to bring your passport to not wait in line if you are a foreigner.

Big, Large, and Beautiful. You can go there on foot from "Asakusa" because the sky tree is near to Asakusa. Tokyo Sky Tree is very big and beautiful at night. If you don't book the ticket to go the observation deck, you'll pay about 2000yen (20 dollars) and you'll have to stand in line. This area has many shops and what we call "Soramachi". Soramachi has many shops and restaurants and you can enjoy yourself fully. Also, you can buy souvenirs about sky tree and Japan. So if you visit Asakusa, I recommend to go to Sky Tree and Soramachi!
Breathtaking. Very cool perspective of Tokyo, unfortunately I wasn't there on a day where it was clear enough to see Mt. Fuji, but nevertheless it was an amazing experience.
Tokyo's "Eiffel Tower". A photo op at this place, to bed honest there's really nothing special about it in the morning. But at night, it is quite beautiful.

Scenic view of Tokyo from the top. Go in the afternoon if you want to have a better view of Tokyo.
Go at night if you want to see all the lightings of Tokyo.
However, weather will determine if your scene would be nice or not.

Excellent view. Unfortunately visited on a cloudy day so couldn't see Mount Fuji but the view was still very good. Great time to visit is just before sunset but it does get very busy up here and people will push in to stand closest to the windows.Good cafes on the viewing decks, and watch out for the glass floor 350m up, not for the faint hearted!

Beautiful views of Tokyo.. Amazing views at night time. Remember to take a camera!There is also a little photo area set up by the staff where they will take a photo of you with their camera and yours. They will print out a small photo from their camera right on the spot or you can purchase a bigger one for a small price. This place was not very easy to find the entrance - for us anyway.

Worth it!. We took the last elevator to the top and we were impressed by the night time view of the city. It's beautiful to see all the light of Tokyo and the river and such, it puts the size of the city in perspective. We found some great food and shopping near by as well. I recommend grabbing a drink at the cafe and enjoying the view while at the top!

DEFINITELY A MUST!. I enjoyed going up the Skytree and seeing Tokyo from above. The weather was perfect when we went up so we got wonderful views of Tokyo and of course, I took a lot of pictures. I circled the viewing area to make sure that I got to see everything. Just a suggestion though that there should be some guide who will point out some of the basic sights of Tokyo because really, we did not know what we were looking at. But still a 5-star because the Tokyo Skyline was just beautiful!

Expensive but worth it. Since it is still a new attraction, I recommend going there on a weekday and early. The wait there was like a Disney attraction - at least it is indoor.Once you are there, you might as well go up the second level, which is at an additional cost.Hope the weather is nice (summer is hazy) so you get a complete/clear view; as far away as Mt. Fuji...

Bird's-Eye-View of TOKYO. One of those things you need to do in cities with "towers". Not everybody's cup of tea but it gives you a bird's-eye-view of a big metropolitan area. It makes you think along this line --- "holy cow, how can I explore this place in just 5 days!".
Interesting and worthwhile. Great views and helpful to see the whole of Tokyo laid out around you. Interesting interactive maps and displays. Cafe with equally fantastic views.

A must see when in Tokyo. Owing to pollution and being a little over-cast, the view wasn't brilliant when we went up the sky tree. It would also be useful to know more about what you are seeing. However it was nice to be able to get a feeling for the city from above.

Fantastic experience . A fantastic part of my first ever visit to Tokyo. I couldn't believe the shear scale of the building. The views from the first viewing deck was incredible and whilst the smog stopped the views of Mount Fuji it was still very stunning

Got to go up the Skytree when in Tokyo!. We visited here on 22nd July - our first full day in Tokyo - to help us get our bearings. Easy to reach by subway. We found a long queue so bought the extra expensive tickets for foreigners to avoid the queue. These are 2800yen - about 700yen more than the normal price. This gets you to the first stage and it is a further 1030 to go the top. So not cheap by any standards - far less Tokyo where most attractions are fairly cheap. Japanese people can book time slots on line - not available to foreigners. Good views from both levels - we saw Mount Fuji briefly through the clouds. Great views in general.

You absolutely must visit the Tokyo Skytree. Unparallelled 360 degree views over the Tokyo skyline from this amazing feat of construction and engineering. The main observation deck sits 350m above the ground below, the entry cost is 20 yen per adult. For an additional 10 yen you can go up higher to the 450m observation deck. Very easy to reach by public transport and the main building has great shopping and restaurants.

Best view of Tokyo. This should be on every tourist's itinerary. You get a great view of the city.Yes it's crowded. Yes, there are a fair number of lines (that all move fairly quickly).I think it's priced pretty fairly, and the view is spectacular. If you can time it so you get there close to dusk, you can get a great view of the city during the day, plus the twinkling splendor of Tokyo at night.

So tall. I loved this and you could go so high and see so much. The queuing system could be more efficient or something to look at when queuing . I didn't like having to pay again to reach the real top .

Special Lines for Foreigners -- take advantage of that. One can get in on a special line for visitors that is different from that used by locals. My wait was about 5 -10 minutes compared to the lines for locals that was 2 to 3 hours (well the next available tickets were 2 or 3 hours away)there are 2 levels one can go to and I would suggest you go up to the lower level and based on the view and the board (which says what can be seen -- including Mt Fuji on a clear day) you can decide if you want to go higherAfter having been on the Burj and in the Empire State and John Hancock - this is just another tall building view so it s ok and hence my average rating
Skytree. It was ok. Probably not worth the money or queues. Stayed about half an hour, then left. A Japanese man said not to use anything but the official ticket stalls.

Very nice but hazy view . Great experience, especially the elevators! The long wait in line as not too bad, but I was really hoping to see Mt. Fuji when I got to the top. There was too much haze to see the mountain but seeing the city from atop was still great. Strongly recommend paying the extra ¥1200ish to go up to the next level. Not as much for the view as for the lack of as many people.

Best to go at night. Amazing views of Tokyo but can get crowded to choose your time carefully. Regular admission allows you to go 350. Meters up and if you pay an additional fee you can go as high as 450m. The elevator takes 30 seconds as is a nice thrill. Pencil it in before or after meal for an hour.

Busy!. These towers are always a bit boring to me but we thought well as Tokyo is such a huge sprawling city why not go up and get a overview.Unfortunately for us the view was marred by a hazy sky so the view was limited. We chose the international visitor entrance pass by accident which is substantially dearer than the regular but did cut some two hours or so off the wait time! Worth it as we had planned for a visit over the sunset time to get the best of both worlds.I think the tower is reasonably new and so understandably was incredibly busy. You really had to be patient to wait for a spot near the glass to see out.All in all the experience was exactly as expected not great but not awful either.

The tallest building in Tokyo. The title said it all, the tallest building in Tokyo, overlooking the whole city, with a shopping mall, supermarket and restaurants. It is a place where you could spend the whole day for a date, to with your family. Did I mention that is also an aquarium within the building?

The system could be better. I would give 5 star for the view from above and 0 star for all the hassle to get in and the bad system management. We went there first on an early morning and got a note which told us to come back 2.5 hours later to get into the ticket line. We gave up. We then came back two days later in the late afternoon and luckily waited only 1 hour this time to get into the line, which took us another 40+ mins to finally get the tickets. We went to the 350m deck. It's a little crowded but we expected that. The time was around dawn, and needless to say, the view was one of a kind. I later learned there was a reservation system, but it seems it's mainly designed to serve local visitors. It's clear that the capacity is far overwhelmed and the system should be improved. It takes too much trouble and time to get in, and the overcrowding hurts the experience. Many things can be done. For example, they could classify visitors based on, say, their staying time, and price the tickets accordingly. Improvements like this may make Skytree an even better place to visit.

A great experience with beautiful views!. Apparently, when visiting large international cities the thing to do is go to the top of highest building you can find, in Tokyo, that's the Sky Tree!My husband was not thrilled with the prospect of going up one of the tallest buildings in the world as he does not love heights. Just last summer we went to the very top of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, and the ancient elevator almost did him in. The new beautiful Sky Tree Tower with it's perfectly smooth, and ridiculously fast, elevators made the experience slightly less terrifying for my husband, and completely exhilarating for me. My husband and I planned on utilizing the foreign visitor line in order to visit the Sky Tree to reduce wait time, but found it wasn't needed on a Wednesday night in June. The regular wait line was only about ten minutes. We had to pay two times, once to get to the Tembo Deck, and another to go to the top observatory, the Tembo Galleria. The Tembo Deck had multiple floors attached by stairs and multiple cafes providing drinks, snacks, and meals. This is also where the gift shop can be found. The Tembo Galleria was less crowded and afforded some beautiful views. Both decks had bathroom access.Throughout both decks you'll find a clean, futuristic, very colorfully lit, environment with multiple picture opportunities. On the Tembo deck there is an area where the brave can stand on what seems to be plastic and look straight down to the ground below. I loved this, my height conscious husband declined to join me. I truly loved the views from both decks and the clean environment provided throughout the tower. I would happily visit again.
Amazing!. An amazing view of an amazing place!A must see.Very reasonable price and you can show your passport to get an international ticket, making it cheaper.

Free Street View. When I visited my Japanese friend who lives in downtown Tokyo, she showed me Tokyo Skytree from several spots: through a narrow gap between the tall buildings, between the electric poles on the narrow street, from the bank of Sumida River, etc. I also have seen it from a limousine bus from Narita Airport. It’s a new landmark in Tokyo. It was opened in 2012 as the primary TV and radio broadcasting tower for the Kanto region (i.e., Tokyo and surrounding prefectures), as Tokyo Tower could no longer provide complete digital transmission.  We were not sure if we wanted to spend more than 3,000yen: 2,060yen to the 350m-observation-deck and additional 1,030yen to the 450m-observation-deck. So we settled for the free street view of the tower.

Breathtaking. You will fall in love.. My partner and I enjoyed every single minute of our trip and visiting the Sky tree just made it all the more magical. The queue wasn't that bad considering this tower is a famous spot for tourists to go to. Everything was organized. It's not that expensive either. We definitely recommend for anyone visiting Tokyo to visit the Sky tree. When you first walk out of the elevator you will just be amazed at the view. I think it's much better to go there in the night so that you see the amazing Tokyo neon lights below. If you want to see Tokyo's view in the day go to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building instead. When you go there and see all the lights it's just so breathtaking and you will fall in love with Tokyo, the world and you will just fall in love with everything. It really just felt so magical being up there. Go! Go! Go! Plus there's shopping too!!!

Such an interesting view of the city. The city looks so small from the top of Skytree and reminded me of lego blocks. The view is impressive but obviously best on a clear day so go on a day with good weather.After the view we headed back down the lift and walked around the shops - lots of interesting little quirky stores as well as mens and womens fashion.Food was good too - all you need in the one place.

Amazing View - Wheelchair Friendly. Went to Tokyo Skytree, amazing views and you can really appreciate the expanse of the city. A really well put together attraction.Having my travelling companion in a wheelchair, in pure Japanese etiquette we were whisked past the hour long line to the front and received preferential access to the elevators while travelling through the attraction.

Tokyo from the sky. Skytree is a must if you go to Tokyo so you can see just how big the city of Tokyo is. I would recommend going some time just before the sun sets and watch it come down behind the mountains and see the city start to come alive as if it were a computer city. The warm orange glow in combination with the lights coming on gives it an interesting color and atmosphere to the entire city that you never could grasp from being on the streets.The Skytree itself is a wonderful structure and very well organized and easy to maneuver through even if you are only an English speaker for the most part. They have people who can speak English at the booths to assist you.

Spectacular view of the city. If you come here on a night that is clear - the Skytree will beg for a picture- the surrounding restaurants close around 10pm so if you are on a date you must plan accordingly

Sky tree. Went there with my friends. The elevators were super fast and amazingly high tech. The staff were nice. Just like any sightseeing spots, everything sold there is highly overpriced. Yet, the view from the 450meters was worth the money.

Skytree really sky high!. The tower dwarfs anything in Tokyo. Immediately below the tower are food stalls which cater to anyone's whims.
The adjacent Tokyo Solamachi, Sumida mall complements the attraction.
Go to the tower ALSO during the night for a fantastic lighting display in the tower and vicinity.

Amazing view. An amazing view of the city. Was cloudy when I went but still worth it! There is also an express line for foreigners too that helps shortcut the line a bit. Costs a bit more but worth it

Stunning view. We had some time between flights in Narita and decided to checkout the Skytree. Comparing to other observation points in New York City, the price was reasonable and the wait was short. Although it was a bit cloudy, we could see Mt. Fuji. Kids and we got excited to stand on the glass floor where scenery from 345 meters high is available. Overall it was a great family experience.

Amazing tower and mall!. Arrived without tickets but there were no queues and the weather was quite miserable. We were warned beforehand that the lift might be shut without notice due to strong winds which was a little off putting but luckily this never happened. The view is good, although you can achieve almost as good a view for free at the Government building. That said, there is also a mall and food hall underneath the Skytree which makes it worth visiting. Plus its the second tallest structure in the world so who wouldn't want to go up it?
Stunning views. Great views of Tokyo, worth going before sunset. If the weather is good there is a very nice view of Fuji.

Efficient handling of crowds. I took a chance - no reservation - and had to stand in line for 30 minutes. Not bad considering the line constantly moved. Good views from both viewing decks, although if you know a bit about Tokyo it means more than for those who don't. I didn't feel rushed while on the upper decks and stayed until I had my fill. The glass floor area is definitely not for those with a fear of heights. Lots of shops and eating establishments in the mall at the base of the Skytree. Two requests: First of all, if they are going to make announcement on bullhorns while standing in line, they should also do them in English. The fact the announcement is being made on such a loudspeaker makes one think it must be really important. I understood what they were saying, but other foreigners were asking "What are they saying?". As the announcements were not a special alert, just a repeat of what was on the multi-lingual signboards (about using the bathrooms and undergoing a bag check) those messages were sufficiently covered by the digital sign boards. I also wish they had photos or drawings of what the views would have looked like over the years. They do some of this at the Edo Museum so there are some photos to work from. I think it would add to the educational value to see how the city has changed over the centuries.

Not just a tower but a big shopping mall!. It was closed because of strong wind. So we can't get up to the tower. Then we went to the shopping mall instead. There were lots of shops with unique stuffs, such a salt shop, TV souvenirs shop. The most attractive was the cultural exhibitions about the area around - Kamagata Bridge, Kitajukken River, etc...You can also book a table to watch the Sumida River Fireworks Festival in July with the best view. It is one of the big firework events in Tokyo.

Amazing. have to go. very good amazing experience, the tower open at 8:00 in the morning therefore I recommend to go there nice and early as I went there at 11:00 and was incredibly full, I think they should be more prepare for touristic places like this in order to manage better the pick times because they only one desk with 2 employees selling the tickets, unfortunately took a little while.

Good views over Tokyo. We visited Skytree on a little bit cloudier day. The regular lines were quite long, so we decided to buy the Fast Skytree Tickets for international visitors. You have to have your passport or other ID with you to buy this ticket from the separate ticket counter. This ticket is little bit more expensive (2820 JPY vs. 2060 JPY), but we didn't have to wait in line for our tickets and also got a shortcut for the elevators (little bit waiting here though). The views were great even though we didn't get to see Mt. Fuji. But even on a cloudier day you can see how huge Tokyo really is! We went during day time, but the view is spectacular during night time too (have seen it from Tokyo Tower on earlier trip).

If you are first time in tokyo, Go!!. It was my first time in Tokyo, rather I had visited Osaka, Okinawa and Kyushu, I wanted to see whole tokyo city view. so we decided to go Sky tree rather than Tokyo tower. But it really high and new everything was like new world. the city view was amazing. The Elevator was super fast, the height and tower itself was amazing. But because it was new, I guess, the price of entering was too much. (We felt.) It's like similar like other cities. if you are not interested in city view, then it will be just OK.

Amazing views, but pick your day. We visited on a whim towards the end of our Tokyo holiday. It's relatively simple to get to via subway, and the lines weren't too bad - possibly because of the weather. We managed to time it for the tail end of a typhoon and the structure was closed/elevators were delayed due to high winds. Views at first were non-existant, but luckily the could cleared and we got some great views of Tokyo. we couldn't see Mount Fuji however it was a pleasant enough experience. Coffee and souvenir prices as well as entrance fees are a bit exhorbitant but it's your call if you want to eat/buy. Well laid out and organised and plenty of other shopping available nearby.

Excellent view of Tokyo!. We went to Tokyo SkyTree on a whim one day. After standing in line to go up the elevator for about an hour we arrived at the first stop, about 350m up off the ground.The view was tremendous and walking around on the glass floor was quite unnerving.We spent twenty minutes to half an hour on the first floor and then decided to go to the top. That meant standing in line for another thirty minutes or so - but it was worth every minute!The top floor was a bit surreal. The design resembled a space station. Five minutes after stepping out of the elevator we saw people gathering along west side of the tower. When joining them we realized that what we had managed to do, quite unknowingly, was to perfectly time the sun setting over Mount Fuji. A most humbling and beautiful experience.

OK - a bit like all the others. I really hate heights - but looking out from the observation deck it really didn't feel that high (a similar sense of detachment to that felt on the much higher deck on the Burj Khalifa or the lower Shard). The queuing process was a bit slow but ever so efficient and not as chaotic as the Burj. The views are pretty much what you'd expect of Tokyo and its not so clean air.

reach the sky. an amazing place. the view over the city was breathtaking. just going up inside the elevator was an experience in itself like being inside a rocket. Once at the top take the time to walk around and see the view

A WONDER. its the beautiful place with the combination of different lights during evening.lovely place to take photos. I have been there many time and still love to go often with my friends and click as many photos we can.
Famous photo spot. This place is the famous photo spot and the perfect background for the couples and the tourists to show that you are in Tokyo!

Beautiful view of Tokyo. I visited the Tokyo Skytree around 6:30PM when the sun was starting to set, due to strong winds the elevators were delayed for a while, but in the end we could go up.Around 6-7PM seems to be the perfect time as you can still enjoy a view of Tokyo by daylight and see the sun setting and get a splendid night view.After visiting the tower I went down to the 6th floor and grabbed something to eat, there's a foodcourt on the 3rd floor too with delicious food.

Best views of the highest freestanding structure in the world. We visited this great tower at the end of the afternoon/beginning of the evening to see to see the sunset & have views during the day & during the hours of darkness. Best views of Tokyo, not expensive & really well executed viewing platform :-)

The Top of Tokyo. This tower built recently is a masterpiece which shows the technology and economic might of Japan.Just a 5 minutes walk from Ueno Station, the structure is easily accessible. A 634 Mtrs tower, it gives a fantastic 360 view of Tokyo. The tickets buying is easy and the tower boasts of the quickest of the elevators, which land you at its top in 60 seconds. An experience to remember for a long time.

Tanabata at Skytree Tower. I got lucky because there was a Tanabata festival when I visited Skytree. This tower is exactly the new landmark of the modern side of Tokyo. Don't forget to capture your moment around this tower at night because this tower is more beautiful with its colorful lights.

Most expensive view in Tokyo?. We arrived at 20:00 on a Sunday, and there was a 60 minutes wait. We found a fast-lane for international visitors with 20 minutes wait, but price was increased from a wobbing 2.000 yen to 2.800 yen / person! (appx. $30)We lined up anyway, just to find out that you have to pay an EXTRA 1.000 yen (appx. $10) to go up the last 100 meters. The 2.800 yen would only take you to the "lower" deck which is 350 meters above ground.The total would be more than 11.000 yen (appx. $120) for three persons, which made us step out of the line and skip the attraction. If you like the views of Tokyo by night, you can go to Tokyo Metropolitan Government building - it's free, and you'll have a nice view of the city from here. No need to pay a fortune to visit Tokyo Skytree, which is basically just a tourist rip-off. It is a nice sight and the attraction is very well organized, just as the rest of the city.

High in the sky!. We paid to go all the way to the top of the Skytree, and were rewarded with a fantastic view. Hard to fathom how high it was! Very cool experience. Lots of shopping areas down below, and even an aquarium!

Amazing Structure and Views over Tokyo. Enjoyed very much our trip to the Tokyo Skytree the tallest tower in the world. Even though it was busy they offer a fast track ticket for international visitors, slightly more expensive but well worth it to avoid long queues. The speed of the lifts were amazing and once up to the 450 m level the views were stunning. It was a little hazy the day we visited but still great views. You can purchase another ticket at this level to go even higher if you wanted to. Easy access from adjacent train stations.

Amazing Views of the City. Long queue but goes down really fast. We went during the day but you can also go at night which is probably just as nice with the city lights. We could just see Mt Fuji despite the haze which was a nice highlight!
Observatório of urban plan. This is one experience that make You ask if life is something live in This social space, And reason of life. Its Nice view.

Nice view, lots of tourists. Skytree is an amazing building, new and with large capacity to bring people up and down. There are four large elevators, and even though there are many people, the waiting time is only a few minutes. Once up, the view is fantastic. The only disapointing was the glass floor where you can see down. It was small and not so exciting.

You Can Really See How Big Tokyo Is. I was amazed looking at the sky tree from the ground and couldn't wait to see the city from the top. It's like any typical attraction where they move you along like a herd, but the process to go to the top was fast. Once there, you will be amazed! You can walk around and see the whole city from all the windows and they give you a map so you know what your looking at (match the number on the map to the one posted on the wall inside). There are opportunities to purchase a snack, take lots of pictures, and stand on a glass bottom floor (yikes). I suggest going early in the morning to avoid long lines. If you are a tourist from another country, they have a purchase booth for international travelers.
On the TOP of Tokyo. Must see place in Tokyo if you want to see Tokyo from the TOP. YOu feel as if you are on the TOP of the world.
Unforgettable. It's wonderful!You can see Tokyo, but also the mountain and Fuji!If you arte there, you must go on because it's amazing!!

Worth visiting . If you want to see how big Tokyo really is this is the place. I recommend that you take fast lane,it's a lot faster and only cost few pounds more. We visited Skytree about an hour before the sunset so we could enjoy view in the daytime and in the night... Both amazing. Make sure the weather is nice otherwise no point going up.

Did not get into the tower, but looks lovely from afar. I stayed nearby Kuramae station, so I have cycled around this are quite a few times from my accommodation. The building itself looks interesting, but I'd prefer for free views from Tokyo Met.

Amazing Views. An amazing structure both far away and up close. Really easy to get there. We visited the Skytree on a Monday which was really busy, the queues were a little long so we paid a bit extra to skip the queues. It certainly was worth the few extra $$. (JFYI Apparently Fri - Mon is busier than the rest of the week) The views were fantastic and gave you an appreciation of how vast and compact Tokyo actually is. Very much worth being your list of things to do if you go to Tokyo.

Interesting and fun day.. Visited the Skytree in March, went from Ebisu to Asakusa and walked across the bridge, plenty to see on the way.We just lined up with everyone else and had no trouble getting tickets.The view of Tokyo when we got out of the elevators was magnificent, the glass floor was fun if you are not uneasy with heights.There are the usual shops selling souvenirs, which we though were really nice. As you go down the escalators, there are more floors with shops (really good ones) and there is a food hall where we had lunch, nice food too, not just Japanese, for all tastes.We had a really enjoyable day, I can recommend.

View over Tokyo. The sky tree is amazing on a clear day you can see the whole city stretched out before you, sadly on our trip it was too hazy and we could not see Mount Fuji however the views we did see where amazing. We stayed until it went dark and it was wonderful to see the city in lights. If you do venture up the sky tree and stay until the evening take a sweater as the air con makes it a bit chilly. All in all a very worthwhile trip we paid the extra for the fast track ticket for foreigners, so we got to the 1st observation deck in approx 25 minutes. The queues for the ordinary pass were huge We didn't feel the need to go higher not sure what more you would see for the extra. The free wifi is a bonus.

Good to visit, but not necessarily for the view. One night, my husband and I decided to visit the Tokyo Skytree. We had no idea there was basically a huge shopping complex attached to it, but it was actually pretty cool. There were tons of great restaurants to try, and we picked up some nice gifts for ourselves and family back home. Also, visit the chocolate shop on the street level; so good! We happened to be there around the holidays, so we got to see their version of a German Christmas market. The decorations were really nice. We tried to see if we could get to the observation deck, but the line was out the door. If you're going to do it, I'd recommend buying tickets online. We were on the fence about it because tickets to the deck are quite pricey. I'd say, if you're in the area and not on a really tight budget, it's a fun place to visit. I wouldn't say it's a must-see, though.

incredible view of Tokyo. Being very scared of heights, I was very hesitant to go up the Skytree. But, the view, it made it worth it! incredible! On a clear day you can see very far into the distance, Mt Fuji, Mt Tsukuba, Chiba etc. food indide isn't cheap (obviously) but there are many places to meat in Solamachi (a mall under the Skytree) and the surrounding area. Be warned, it does get VERY busy!

Nice view and fast to get in. Why to go there? For the view, of course, because if the weather is with you, you can see the Fuji-san during the day, and the city itself is so big that it is a good place to embrace it. Then, you are very close to Asakusa and Senso-ji (walking distance).Yes, the queue is big but there is always a way to make it shorter. First, you can buy your ticket in advance (ask to your hotel), and now, there is also a special counter for the foreigners to make it shorter (I have not experienced it, just read about it in the news). Second, you can pay a bit more and you will have access directly (or almost) to the tower (ask to the staff in blue, they will guide you). Yes, you pay more, but hell, when will you come back ? And it can sabotage your day to stay the whole day in the queue.Last point, for the kids, you have the Sumida (it will make laugh any Portuguese speaker) aquarium.

Only for the view.... The view on a clear day is amazing. You can see all of Tokyo on a good day. However, my suggestion is to eat well before you head to the sky tree because the food selections are limited and expensive once you head up those elevators and once you head down you cannot return back up. The shops below the "tree" offer quite a variety of things but are at "tourist" pricing. We went outside and ate at some hole in the wall ramen shop for a 1/4 of the price. Probably won't do this again except in the evening if I get a chance.

Nothing too exciting, save your money. If you're on a tight budget I wouldn't outlay the money to go up the SkyTree. Nor expend the effort to get to the place. I'd recommend observation decks that are more centrally located. We only went up as we were in the area and had a few drinks so thought it would be a good idea. That being said the views were still great. I'd probably recommend going during the day. I didn't get much out of it seeing Tokyo at night. It tends to look like any other big city at night. However, I believe the queues are massive during the day, just guessing by the amount of rope they had us weave through (there was no queue as we visited 30 mins prior to closing).

It's a big tall tower. With a very long line.. OK, it's expensive and the line is long enough that you'll really wonder if it was worth it - but it kinda still is. Use the early ticket buying option online if you have some time to plan - will save hours. The view from the top is truly impressive. Note - if you just want to see a great view, the view from the Landmark tower in Yokohama is better (amazing view of the ships and harbor), and the line is more or less non-existent there, so if you're planning a day trip to Yokohama anyway, it's a better option... if you are only planning on seeing one big panoramic view.

30 min Walking to Sky Tree.. From my hostel Tokyo Sky Tree looks so close. I decide to walk. I get another place before reach at Tokyo Sky Tree. A monument for reminder a big raids in Tokyo, Sakura Square, Water bus landing. Finally here it is Tokyo Sky Tree. There is a shopping mall and train station also bus station.

One of the best. This building is the best if you like to see all of the city at once. Has two observation points that you can see. You will have a chance to step on a glass walkway where you can see the street beneath your feet.

Excellent view!. Like everyone else has said, Skytree has a magnificent view of Tokyo. Best time to go is around sunset so you can see both Tokyo by day and Tokyo at night. Elevator ride is pretty quick and will pop your ears a bit.

Great views of the city. Having been to the Willis Tower (Chicago), and the Empire State Building observation decks in the past, this was a very similar experience. The elevator ride was the coolest of the three with the glass panel ceiling and the beautiful changing colors of the stained glass mosaics. Overall a stop you want to make to see the city of Tokyo in a 1st class way.
It has great view of Tokyo. You can see the day and night of Tokyo. Elevator lifts you up by 400m/sek and it is so surprising. Watching Tokyo night is incredibly beautiful.

An entertaining visit - but show up early. I was in Tokyo with a few hours to fill before my flight. The Tokyo Skytree was very easy to get to via the Metro so it was a simple choice. Choose a day with good weather otherwise the view might be disappointing.I had the advantage of going early in the day - there were no major lines or crowds. An Express Pass is available for purchase to allow you to skip the long lines, but it was not necessary. It is worth knowing that there are two tickets you can purchase: the Tembo Deck only goes 350m up; the Tembo Galleria is an additional purchase if you want to see the view from 450m. I purchased the Galleria ticket and thought it was worthwhile only because I had made it this far, I was not going to miss out on the view from the top. But it is worth knowing that there are two tickets to buy.I am glad that I went. It was an entertaining visit but I am not sure I will do it again. The view does not change terribly much over the years, I suspect

To me, Just Another Super Tall Building. I've been to Taipei 101, the Sears Tower, and other "tall" structures, and they have all sell themselves in similar ways - an awesome panoramic view up top, with lackluster souvenir shops/ shopping areas inside. Its a beautiful structure, but for the price (around $35 USD) I would say its a better deal to simply walk around the town and feel it for yourself.

Nice view over the city. From the upper deck you can see how huge Tokyo really is, it just keeps going beyond the horizon. I went there on a sunny day and I could even see Mt. Fuji. There were allready lots of people at 10am but there was still room to move around and the lines weren't too long.It's a bit pricey to go all the way to the top, but I think the view was worth the money.

Go at night - see the lights and avoid the crowds!. We came just before closing and walked right in without waiting. Stepping out of the elevator was a "WOW!" moment. The lights and views of Tokyo were incredibly beautiful at night and we didn't have to share the view with too many others. Stepping on the glass floors where you can see all the way down to the street added an interesting twist and heart-throbbing moment to the visit of Tokyo Skytree.

Pricey but good way to see across Tokyo. We went up Tokyo Tower 10 years ago, and the Sky Tree wasn't built then so it was interesting to try the newer tower. There isn't much to do up there other than enjoy the view (the Landmark Tower in Yokohama is better, and the lift is faster). However, it's great to be able to see across most of the city (I say most, as the view is impeded by the smog/clouds). It would be great if you could see Mt Fuji, I suspect you have to be lucky for that to happen. You have to pay more to go right to the top (another 1300Y) which we didn't bother doing. Not sure how much more you'd see another 10 metres higher, it's just to say you've been that high!

Not a place to visit if you don't like crowds. Interesting place to visit as you get to see how the structure was created and what it is made of. Also has diagrams of other towers in the world as you make your way in. It was really crowded when we got there with locals and tourists alike. Did not go up the tower as the fee is much higher as compared to the entrance fee at Tokyo tower. You can get up to the highest level that is free and see a bird's eye view of the surrounding area. Other than that it was really nothing much unless you decide to buy some souvenirs from the different shops there. There are also several food places you can eat if you ever get hungry.

Only worthwhile on clear days. And maybe not even then. There's a sizeable charge to go up to the midway deck, and then a similar charge to go a bit further. The views are good if the weather is clear, but you could do as well at several other locations, for less money. If it's crowded, the wait just makes everything worse.

Top of the World!. Amazing views of Toyko and beyond. There is a restaurant located on the top deck, but advanced bookings are essential. Otherwise there are a couple of cafe's with average food and drinks. We wre there at night on a weekday so the crowds were not too bad, but Tokyo is generally a very efficient place and geared for tourism, so don't be put off by long lines - it's well worth a look from the top.

Go early to avoid waiting. I went when it opened at 8 am. Walked straight in. Very well organised and a great view. A little expensive but it is a must do in tokyo. Coffee at the cafe at the top was excellent.

Expertise Design. A must-visit place of you ever get you hands on a ticket to Tokyo! The Tokyo Skytree is about half a mile up, as you know. Well, above 1/3 of a mile, that we know. The lines on the ground to get up on to the top were long, and the highest view-point level is a lot smaller than other attractions. It's smaller than the Burj Khalifa.

total touisty spot , like empire state. It is crowded with tons of people over the weekend. But ppl are fairly well mannered, unlike NY. It is def a great experience when you're in the country for visit.

A 'must do' if you visit Tokyo. You must pay the extra to go onto the top deck and get the 360° view of the city. You won't believe how big Tokyo actually is. It was a great experience having a snack and a drink looking down through the glass to the ground below.
Top of the world. we felt like we are at top of the world..view is incredible.Must visit place in Tokyo. you can go by Metro and walk to this tourist attraction..

Pretty awesome. First I'd like to say foreigners get up there quicker than non-foreigners. And I pity the non-foreigners, for the line is truly crazy.When that is said, then it is truly a spectacular view. I definately recommend visiting in the evening, when the city lights are on, or on clear days, when you can see to Mt. Fuji.The extra to get to the top-top is also worth it. Less people and more terrifying.

World tallest tower to ride on. I have visited Tokyo for the second time & this was first time for me to see & travel through Sky tree. For non Japanese, the rate for ticket is very high, but we can visit at any time unlike Japanese who has time restriction.The view from top was amazing. They have some restaurant in the tower but very costly. The lift moves to height of 350 mtrs within 15 second.
Amazing structure !!. Amazing 360' views of Tokyo.Ticket will get you to the lower deck, if you want the top deck is some extra money.There is an aquarium as well.
Scary but Amazing!!. Tokyo Sky Tree just celebrated its 3rd Anniversary. This is currently the tallest Tower in the world. You will enjoy everything from the Elevator up to the highest peak.

Very organized & efficient system. There's an express desk for foreigners which gets you to the shoppes level, then you can buy a second ticket to get to the top. Incredible views of Tokyo without the painful lines of the Eiffel Tower. We ate nice shabu shabu on the shoppes level afterward then walked outside and took pictures from a distance. I love that Tokyo is so safe so you can wander around at any time of day without worry.

What a View !. A Japanese friend took me there on a Saturday morning. It was not too busy despite being a Saturday. The lift has a long way to go, but it is a fast smooth high-tech ride. The 350m floor was fascinating, the 360 view took a long time to take in, there was so much to see looking down. Then up to the 450m floor, with a glass floor, you can stand on the glass and look straight down, nearly half a km... dramatic ! Most people seemed afraid to stand on the glass :-) There is of course a commercial photographer, so you can buy your photo on the way out, with an interesting mount around the photo showing info about the tower. The views are really good on a clear day, don't bother going up if the cloud is low. Take a good camera, it is designed for photographers.
Fantastic. Amazing views over Tokyo, use fast track to avoid the queues, my only complaint is the bar wasn't great.

Perfect for mid week, afternoon visit..... I highly recommend to visit Skytree during the week and late afternoon. We got our tickets without queuing up and we were at the top of the tower within 10 min walking into the ticket lobby.They charge additional 800 yen if you choose to purchase ticket for foreign visitors. We saved a lot of money being able to purchase tickets normal way. View up the top is great, good spots for photographers. There is caffe there but to our surprise there are no tables or chairs to enjoy snack or drink. You have to lean against the high table and my two young children missed out as they had to seat on the sofa. Not the best set up so you might skip the coffee part. Good experience.

Walking on clouds level!. The place is really interesting, you can walk almost half a kilometer altitude above the ground! View around him barely open and unhindered! You should visit this place when in Tokyo.Tower looks unique, because it is built with a steel frame that stands firmly with style tripod. Known as the tallest structure in Japan, and is the highest tower in the world.There are 3 main floor which can be accessed by visitors, the ground floor of places to go in and purchase a ticket (about 2000 yen price), then the floor as high as 350m, and the highest at an altitude of 450m floor that can accommodate up to 900 people visiting simultaneously.Cool!

Empty near closing, bring a tripod at night.. For me, a viewing deck has several objectives:1) Ease of photography.2) Space for romantic couples.3) Entertainment for children.I arrived roughly 45 minutes before closing, because I got caught up in the Torigoe Matsuri, and ended up at Asakusa Station waiting for the wrong train. Anyway, when I got there--no line. I had zero wait time, on a Sunday evening. Outside, many couples were already doing their follow-up cuddling, staring up at the tower, etc. There is honestly a fine opportunity for eating and shopping below the Skytree, so you can take your time. Although, I'd recommend going to see a sunset up there, night is just as good, kind of.1) A mixed bag. There are a lot of background lights, from signage to interior lighting which really makes it hard to get a good shot except at certain parts (but the viewing deck is labelled by where you are viewing), so basically, you take photos with glare to get the full 360-degree view. In this sense, it's better to go at daylight. Also, a technique I learned in another country copying a girl next to me, you can use the glass to stabilize your camera, but here, the ceiling to floor windows are somewhat out of reach. Using just your hands to take a steady night shot is nearly impossible--as my shots showed. If you want to expand your photos and print larger sizes, bring a tripod. Even with the background lights, at least you'll get a steady shot.2) This deck definitely caters to couples, with the ability to lounge, and even camp at a certain spot with your love so easy to do--basically, everyone is doing it. If you aren't a couple, you'll find it hard to squeeze into viewing windows to get a shot. In that case, forget the tripod.3) They have many interactive touch-screens, you can even magnify what you're looking at and know exactly what's in front of you. The kids use it more like moving lily pads on water, but some people can appreciate it.There is food and drink, which close about an hour before the viewing deck closes. And there is a gift shop full of many Skytree themed items. I myself collect coins from different towers around the world, so it was nice to see these available. If anything, this is probably easiest to take photos earlier in the day, with bright sunlight outside; less clouds, more visible distance. At night, bring a tripod, but be patient for spots to open up to take photos. If you have a date, go at night. If you have a family, the daytime might be better.Anyone coming from the Tokyo direction will have to pass through the Asakusa area. If you are coming back, it's a good place for eating and drinking later than the Skytree operating hours.

Loved it. We ended up going to the Skytree around 7:30pm on a Tuesday. We hadn't read any reviews on it, nor had we even looked into the area, we just decided to go at the end of the day. It seems that it's very crowed during the day, and many reviews I have since seen mention an extremely long wait time.We had no wait whatsoever. Obviously with it being a weekday in the evening, there were not a lot of people there. There were a few people sitting outside or taking pictures, and there were only 3 people in line ahead of us. The elevator wasn't crowed, and everything moved quickly.The view was amazing. One of the best I have seen. The view of the city at night was breathtaking. With relatively no crowds, we were able to take our time and enjoy the view. We didn't have to worry about finding space to take pictures, or to stare out at the city. If you plan on going to the Skytree, I recommend making it your last stop, as to avoid all the crowds and hassle. The shops and mall at the Skytree were closing by the time we got there, but we came back on a different day around 10am, and were able to get a little shopping done.

Great experience with no vertigo!. I was rather concerned this would be a traumatic experience for me suffering from vertigo however I am pleased that this was not a problem and I even managed to stand on the glass floor (not for long however).You really need to get here early morning as the queues can be unbelievable.Despite it being a lovely, bright sunny day, the view across the city was too hazy to see Mount Fuji (sad face) however overall, this was well worth it.The interactive display screens are brilliant. Touch screens that you select a building of interest and it will tell you what it is and any history linked to it.The lifts are all enclosed and very quick. Word of caution, if you suffer from ear infections or problems, this may not be recommended as one of our group had "blocked ears" for the remainder of the holiday after this. I would love to have returned to visit for a night view.

Nice way to see a bird's eye view of Tokyo!. Wanted to go and see Tokyo Sky Tree and it was certainly very cool! When we went to buy tickets, we realized there was a 60-90 min wait but then we found there's another queue for international visitors and we managed to get to the top of the tower in less than 15 min! The tickets for the international visitors are about 800 yen more per ticket but well worth the price since we were a traveling part of 3 adults and 5 kids under 10! It's great to go up and see the view but it was a little cloudy the day we went so we couldn't see Mt Fuji in the distance so that was a bummer.

Go on a weekday. We went on a weekday late in the afternoon and managed to avoid all the crowds most people seem to encounter, ours was a last minute decision to go so we never looked into on-line bookings etc. Only waited for 5 minutes in the line and it wasn't very crowded up the top so we had ample opportunity to get photos. I would definitely recommend going at night if possible, the view after dark was more impressive, aside from seeing the extent of the smog in the daylight. It's expensive, and costs even more if you want to go to the very top, but if you have the cash it's worth a look. If you don't then you're not really missing an essential Tokyo experience

Long Wait. I wanted to visit the Skytree and tick that off my list, and we got there, and as we were leaving that day we didnt have a lot of time to waste, and when we went to buy a ticket, the wait was 90 minutes just to buy a ticket! So we did not go up this attraction sadly. Tip: I guess would be to go first thing in the morning to avoid the lines

Must see if in Tokyo. Day time pay attention about weather, clouds hanging too low and you cannot see much upper level, but lower level is still okay. Also it is worth of paying extra to have a vip pass to elevators, otherwise you will end up standing in queue for an hour or more.

Potential for a great view. I couldn't resist visiting this new landmark. The day was hazy, but it was still worth the trip. The elevator is motionless. The only way you know you are traveling is the meter counter...quite fast. There are lots of assistants available and many speak just enough English to communicate. There is an exquisite French/Japanese restaurant. It is not inexpensive but the food was lovely. All in all worth the visit.

Good for shopping. Amazing experience. Came here just after sunset, and the tower lit up magnificently! The shops inside the mall were all one of a kind, boutique style and selling stuff you'll not find anywhere else. 5 star experience!

Expensive, long lines for views of Tokyo. We did not go up to the top since lines were too long so we just went to the shopping mall under the Skytree. This mall is large and has everything including restaurants, cafes and bars. We heard the views at the top are great to see Tokyo. So arrive early or expect a long wait.

Yep, you go really high up...tallest tower in the world. The Skytree was an amazing experience. While it may seem like it is just another tower that you go up to great heights, they have nice views and a second level that takes you even higher. Amazing construction and truly a worthwhile experience if you happen to be in the Asakusa area.

Nice view but expensive. ​It's the observation deck for Tokyo. You can see full skyline and how big Tokyo is. It's a good vantage point to see full city. There is a mall in the same building. There are lots of different restaurants to eat drink etc.

Great views. My sister and I went to this on a very busy Saturday. In order to get a ticket to go to the viewing decks you need to get a ticket which gives an allocated time to attend the ticket booth. When we arrived tickets were being issued to access it 1.5 hours later. However inside there is a fast track desk for foreign visitors which allows you to get tickets there and then and gives you priority in the lifts. This does cost extra though. If you are prepared to wait there is lots to do at ground level with numerous shops and a variety of street entertainment. Once at the top it can be very crowded but the views on a clear day are breathtaking. There is the option to pay an additional fee to go even higher but we didn't bother with this as the views were sufficient from the main observation area. There are also areas where sections of the floor are glass - there are the floor below the main viewing deck and are not for the faint hearted. Recommended.

Nice view but the queue and price was little too much for top scores. Nice views and a great experience if you haven't been in other high observatories. The fee was quite high (~2000yen) and you always had to queue if you wanted to get somewhere.I would recommend visitors with low-budjet or no queuing urges to head for a drink to the 40:th floor which gives you a nice view while you can drink different beer or have some bite to eat. It that is not enough, buy a ticket to the elevator and head to the top.

Spectacular view. Some global capitals offer views of their metropolis atop their highest towers. Tokyo SkyTree is no different except that there's a sense of pride of getting on top as this is the WORLD'S TALLEST. It's amazing how their elevators take you up at 350 meters in seconds. Just be patient though as lines can be long during peak tourist season. On a clear day, you can see Mt. Fuji and Tokyo's skyscrapers. On a cloudy one, like on our visit, your patience will definitely be tested.

Amazing architecture!. This tower took my breath away. You can get a sick view of it from the fourth floor of the Solamachi Mall at Oshiage!We went on a Saturday afternoon and was given a pass so we could come back at 7.30PM later that day. There were so many people who wanted to get up this majestic tower! Waited for about an hour to buy our ticket from the regular counter (they have a separate one for international visitors, but that costs twice as much) and another twenty minutes to get on the lift. The lines moved quickly so it wasn't that much of a deal. I expected a lift like the one at Tokyo Tower where you can see the outside as you get up, but there wasn't such a thing, sadly.
