Once we got out of the elevator, the third earthquake struck Tokyo and things were a little shaky, but the staff had it all under control. They just told everyone to sit down on the floor and let it pass, and I gotta say, I was quite fascinated by how everyone was taking it quite well.Afterwards, we toured the Tembo Deck and took some pictures. The night view with the city lights was just stunning. *u* It must be quite romantic if you get to go up with your special person when there aren't too many people around and you can enjoy it by yourselves! ;) I think the 2,060JPY was worth it. I loved this tower and I would definitely come back for the daytime/dusk view!

What a view!. The view is the most spectacular that you will see of Tokyo outside of an airplane. The observation decks are well designed to allow a 360-degree view for the most people possible at any given time. The elevator travels at astounding speeds, and your ears will pop on the way up and down. Be sure to stand on the glass floor on the lower deck to get a "bird's eye" view. Little pricey ($30 per person for both decks) and the line can get long in the evening.

It's a place you must visit if you are in Tokyo. Went on a Sunny day.There was lot of rush.And had to wait more than 3 freakin hours if I waited in line. But only foreigners get to skip the waiting line for few extra bucks. So I could get into Elevator within 10mins. As usual all the staff were so polite and cute.. It's advisable to get to Tembo Galleria. the top u can reach. You can find Free Wifi called Tobu Free wifi-Unlimited. Important TIP:- I stayed in a really Good,but Cheap Guesthouse called "Guesthouse 1965" in Arakawa-ku,Tokyo-Owned by a nice guy named 'Ryota Kuga'. He accepts stays more than 1 week I guess. I visited many places like Sky tree, Ueno, Akihabara.. from there by Bicycle.

Must See!. Visited in afternoon, we didn't wait in the normal queue. So had to pay a little extra.Anyway it was a nice experience. Can see the fascinating view of Sumida river below through crowdy Tokyo.There was a glass bottom floor as well.So beautiful at night!

Too much time on waiting for Skytree's elevators. We visited Tokyo Skytree as a part of our tour. You have to take elevator up and down to visit the Skytree. The time we spent on waiting line was just too long. It was nice to see Tokyo from 350m above. However, in my opinion it is not worth the waiting time. There are a lot of other attractions in Tokyo you can visit without wasting 2 hours + wait time.

Nice view. A huge tower with great views over Tokyo, take the subway train to get there. Try to visit the different levels for a different experience. Sunset and early evening provides some great photos

Best high tower I visited. Best tall building i visited. I've been to Burj Khalifa of Dubai and Taipei 101 of Taiwan. I like this experience the best. Elevator was beautifully design with Japanese artwork themed to the 4 seasons. unlike the former 2, elevators was blacked out and flashed with lights and club music until it reached the top. This one is really classy, a class apart from the others.The tembo viewing deck is great , we did not went up to the Galleria level deck anymore. Best to visit it is late afternoon, so you get to see the beautiful day view and night view.At the 4th floor , there is a big food court with lots of things to eat and the 1st 3 levels are choked with shops called the Solamchi. Could easily spend 6 hours here at the Skytree buildingAnd upon disembarking from the train station, on its ground level, there are also interesting street performers to watchWe were there inside the Skytree during the May 31 ..... 7.8 magnitude earthquake that hit Tokyo, Everybody was so calm as if nothing is going on, no hysteria at all. seems everyone has great faith in their structural integrity of their buildings, and I believe it is a just faith

Foreigners skip long lines!. The Tokyo Skytree is well worth the expense. Plus, if you are not a Japanese citizen and bring your passport with you, you can skip the long ticket line and get your ticket at the foreigners' booth. There were only a few people who were ahead of us!We went on a rather hazy day and could not see Mt. Fuji, but could see Tokyo and other features for miles. The facility itself is a marvel of Japanese engineering, and we enjoyed seeing it. Go on a weekday, bring your passport, and it is a great experience!

Better to go up in a sunny day!. ... so you might have a chance to see the Mount Fuji. Otherwise, the views of the city of Tokyo are amazing (the 634 m. tower is the tallest of Tokyo; no need to go up to the second observation desk, views from the first one are already very good! It costs 3000 yen and you have the possibility not to queue by paying an extra fee.

Wait for a clear day. You absolutely cannot miss this! We had an amazing time. The view is beyond words. You just can't believe a city so utterly massive can exist until you see it from up there! You don't need to pay extra to go up higher. The glass is really clean and brilliant for taking pictures. I would recommend the professional photographer. They take a pic on their camera and then take one for you on yours with no obligation to buy the pic they have taken. We ended up buying their pic though because it was amazing. There is an old drawing/map of how Tokyo would once have looked from the SkyTree which I found absolutely fascinating. Go earlier in the day to avoid the worst of the school groups.

Amazing view at a price. We visited the sky tree on Sunday May 31st at about 6 o'clock. We went up to the first deck only due to foggy weather. We used the fast track for international visitors, paying an extra ¥800 each. It saved us a few hours at least (my guess is 2 to 3) and we were able to get on the elevator within 30min of entering the international line. So we ended up paying ¥2860 (~$26) each for a really beautiful birds eye sunset view on our last night in Tokyo.

Worth To Visit. One of the highest towers of the world. If you like to see new towers, worth to see. For me, I dont like that much and only spending very short while for such modern buildings. Worth to see but I advice you to spend more time for Classical Tokyo Places like temples etc.

Amazing Views of Tokyo!. We were lucky we went on a clear day and you can see every part of the city. Unfortunately we couldn't see Mount Fuji, but the rest of the views were amazing. Get there early because the lines get long. Worth the price of admission!

My top recommendation to visitors of Tokyo. I highly recommend visiting the Tokyo skytree for first-time visitors of Japan/Tokyo. The cost is about 3000 yen to go up to the first observation deck. There is a second fee to go higher, but the first observation deck is sufficient. There is densely populated city in every direction, and is fascinating to look at.
Beautiful view!. Tourists can top up about 600 yen for express queue. Definitely worth going. A mall and a tourist centre at ground level if you need maps and money changer.

So much better than I expected, definitely recommend!. There's not a lot I can say about the Tokyo Skytree that hasn't already been said or written about. But as a long-term resident of Japan, I will admit that I was blown away by seeing this technical marvel first hand.Zipping up hundreds of meters in seconds is an incredible feeling, and seeing the sprawl of Tokyo from the top of country is even more amazing.To get the most out of your trip, I recommend the following:* Go on a weekend, not the weekend - and go in the morning if you can to avoid the crowds. You'll also have more time for shopping later on.* Reserve your ticket online: http://www.tokyo-skytree.jp/en/reservation/Again, this is to avoid waiting - possibly for hours - in queues and crowds. It'll cost you a few more coin, but it's totally worth it.* Bring. A. Camera.* Pay the extra 1000 yen to go all the way to the top. You'll be surprised what an additional 100 meters can do to a view. Also, the walking around in the galleria is far more fun than the lounge deck.That's about it. Have fun!
Amazing view.. You have to pay for it but anyway the view is amazing. There are restaurants, cafe and shops with souvenir. In Tokyo Skytree Town is also planetarium and huge aquarium.
View of densely populated Tokyo. A must see. Lines are shorter for international tourists but you have to pay an additional 800yen. It is worth paying if you want to make the most of your day.

Awesome view of city from some height. It is amazing to see such big tower in the earthquake prone country. it was fun to see entire Tokyo city from this tower.Advise for visiting: Go whenever there is clear sky. little bit foggy weather may spoil distant viewing. Even Yokohama landmark tower can be spotted from this place.Tickets are little bit expensive and has to buy ticket for each deck separately.
Beautiful view.. Very interesting elevator with a beautiful decoration of the ceiling, over all is a nice place to visit.

Nice experience but very long queue. Initially, we were quite put off with the VERY LONG queue, at least 3 hour-wait....We then went to the International Visitors booth to get the premium tickets, worth paying the extra in exchange of the 3 hour- wait !!!This should be the 'newest' tower that we 've ever been... and elevators should be the 'fastest' with minimal discomfort to the ears...

Views across Tokyo. We encountered long queues when we arrived so opted for the international travellers queue which charged extra but meant you could jump the queue. 360 degree views of Tokyo and interactive maps plus a glass floor made the experience more interesting. We chose a lovely bright sunny day for our trip up the tower so we weren't disappointed but it's not cheap.

Amazing views, amazing crowd. Yes, this place is amazing. The engineering, height, and views alone make it worth the visit. The elevators are no joke fast. Seriously, most 3 floor hotel elevators move slower. The elevators are also very beautiful with each season being portrayed in the 4 different cars. We were lucky as our lines weren't too long and the observation deck wasn't obscenely crowded. I could see how the lines just to buy a ticket and go upstairs could be off putting. Had a nice choice of dinner on one of the commercial floors and hopped on a VERY close train immediately afterwards.

Go to one of the other tall buildings. Waited there for hours one time and gave up. Another time we paid a premium for a combined tour with express pass to the top of the skytree but his trip was cancelled due to windy conditions and we got back just 17% of our ticket price. OUTRAGEOUS! We decided to scrub the sky tree off out 'to do' list. We went twice up the TMG building instead which has a higher observation level than the sky tree and it is free. Even better than that was the 'Tokyo City View' which must be the best placed building for views of the essential Tokyo and costs around 1,000 yen, with extrance to the excellent museum as well.

Nice place to plan a romantic afternoon.. If you are around Asakusa subway station,it is easy to find the Tokyo Skytree.The Solamachi city is a nice place to shop and can easy spend couple hours to stroll around stores.Couples can also enjoy the Observation deck (Tembo Skywalk) which is 350m above the ground.You can also visit the 30F of (Solamachi Skytree view)where all the nice Japanese restaurants are; I personally enjoyed the "Jojoyen" a yakinku place(Japanese BBQ) where served high quality beef n pork.

Wonderful!. It's one of the main attractions, so don't miss it! Opened in May 2012, gives you a fantastic opportunity to watch Tokyo from clouds. Views are perfect, but it' not really worthwhile to go to the second deck. It's pretty same like the one from 350 meters - not a big difference. Tickets are damn pricey, but you can save by not buying the expeess one (800 yens more, but don' have to wait in queue) and not buying additional ticket to the higher, 450 meters high deck. It's pretty enough to go with the "basic version". Come early to avoid crowds. With a good weather (especially in winter) you can see astonishing Fuji mountain.

Sugoi !. Put this to the first think in my never visit before Japan and it's just WOW! Love it and absolutely worth visiting. Don't miss if you go to Tokyo. And if you are the international visitors you can gain the "fast ticket" so that you don't have the wait for the queue. Just use your passport. The fast ticket will cost more 800yen from normal price. Skytree is a true land mark and I love it !

beautiful in the evening & night. admission charges applies. different amounts for deck & galleria view. if you do not plan to pay, then go in the late evening where the skytree lights up. it is quite pretty. surrounding area is rather peaceful, good photo opportunities. there is shopping in the vicinity too.

Tallest tower.....overlooking a grand view of the city below and betind.. Very impressive building design and technology..to stand this TALL. It is 634m high at the top. There are 2 observatories to enjoy the view...at 345m and at 450m. Very popular! A lot os people go in and out. Some lines and waiting required but they do move people quite quickly and efficiently.

It's just ok. Just ok. Don't get me wrong, it's a must see but if you miss it, you won't actually have missed anything. The queue at the entrance is middle-age long. Once you get on the top you have aged so much you cannot actually see anything more. Kidding. The is great though. Tokyo is not so bad with pollution so, you can actually see everything. I have taken great shots from there. Go during the winter months. In summer and Spring it's so humid you won't be able to see anything.

Long wait, quite pricy but the view is indeed amazing.. Located in Sumida easily accessible Tokyo Skytree is the highest tower in the Tokyo area commanding a view of the entire city. Bear in mind that if you plan to come you'd better do it early as the waiting time to go up can well be over 4 hours. You can spend that time in the adjacent mall or the Sumida Aquarium which is also there. Those who wish to wait less and pay less can settle for Tokyo Tower which is smaller and as such less crowded, the view from there is also well worth the visit.Skytree is quite pricy (like any other well-known attraction) but it would probably be the best photos you will take in Japan (plan your visit when it's clear and not raining). All in all the Tokyo Skytree receives the rank of 7 out of 10 on the Daniel Scale.Enjoy!
So well organized. Great view. Wonderful organization ! You can have a coffee on the 35th floor also if you don't mind the waiting list.....
Long lines, great views. If you're okay standing in line (two hours for me) it's one of the best views you can get of Tokyo. If you go at night it's even better with lights as far as you can see.

Great visit for guests to Tokyo. Took my parents to Sky tree and they really enjoyed. We went for sunset, which was gorgeous.We bought our tickets online, ahead of time -- which was key and made everything very smooth. My wife said that the website is a little confusing, but still, getting the tickets ahead of time saved us a lot of time and confusion.

Great view and excellent to get your bearings. I'm afraid of heights so was quite hesitant about going up the tower but it was our first day in Tokyo and I was confused and a bit tired. The line was long but moved efficiently and then you're crammed into elevators with mood lighting and suddenly you're 350 stories up! It's so high I found I didn't get nervous. And then I was able to see where we were staying in Asakusa in relation to the rest of the city and that was really interesting. Huge mall underneath which we didn't really bother with but it was a pleasant way to spend a hour. Oh and yes I guess it's pricey but these things cost don't they and comparable to others I've been up.

Expensive, but it's a "been there, done that"... Wish they have "SkyJump". Ok... 2,060 yen is by far the highest tariff I've paid in my life just for a view. However, it's very much a "been there, done that" thingy when in Tokyo. Also gives you a good reason to visit Oshiage.It was a fine day but so cloudy... Good thing I packed my binoculars and was able to at least glimpsed an outline of Mt Fuji... and witnessed a gorgeous sunset... Think I'll let my photos do the talking. ^_^....now if only they'd allow me to jump off like how I did the SkyJump in Auckland.....hmm...

Brilliant!. A trip to the Tokyo Skytree is necessary. Very reasonable price to go up, and once you are up you have spectacular views of Tokyo. (My profile photo was taken in the Skytree!) A beautiful building and well organised.

An expensive view. I would say that going up the Skytree aint worth that much of your money. It's really expensive and you won't really get to see much of and buy anything. If you're gaga over a view of tokyo, this will be worth it for you. (Of course plan your day well. Make sure the weather is great and you might just get to see Mt Fuji) However, being on the Tokyo Tower, this isn't really that different. Also, lines are crazy long even if you are there early.

What an experience on a clear day. Because Tokyo is so big it's hard to get your bearings, well the skytree will help with that. On a good day you can see Mt Fuji and the area directly under the attraction has lots to do including temples, shrines, markets, food stalls and to get around you can take the rikshaws and get a personal tour of the area.The skytree has a separate line for international tourist which is great as our wait time reduced to minutes not hours like the locals had to wait, so big thumbs up to the operators for doing this, take note other attraction operators. Allow at least a half day in this area to take it all in.

Great view but way overpriced. Lines are VERY long...just to get a ticket. When I was there, there was a 70 minute wait not including the 20 minute wait to get through security and then for the elevator up...and I was there on a weekday afternoon. For an extra 800 yen (regular tickets for adults are 2000 yen), I discovered the fast ticket, which allows me to cut the ticket line...so my wait was just 20 minutes. Anyway, I was on vacation and didn't mind the extra fee to avoid the horrible ticket line wait. The views at the 350 meter level were spectacular. You can truly get the sense of the size of Tokyo (reminded me of the Death Star (buildings out to the horizon). I was curious to see what the 450 meter deck was about. They charge an extra 1000 to get up an additional 100 meters. That deck has the same views but less people but there is nothing special about it (not recommended). If you are ready to pay big bucks for some great views, this is the place for you.

a tower. maybe I've been on too many of these towers but I found this one just the same. It is quite tall, and if you're a foreign tourist you get to skip the 2 hour waiting queue and get up there in 10 mins, but I found it quite expensive. It was interesting but...

It was ok.. I was really looking forward to coming here. Unfortunately, the time we were in Tokyo, it was Japan's Golden week. It was EXTREMELY busy. We ended up paying for the "tourist line" because the normal line was over 2 hour wait for the elevator to go up. Once at the top we had to pay again for go up to the galleria (AND wait in line again). The view was nice, but it was a very short time that we spent up there because of all the people. THEN we had to line up again for 20-30mins for elevator down.My highlight would be the ice-cream with vinegar lychee syrup (YUM!!!) Overall, I would rather spend the amount of money we spent elsewhere, BUT we can now say we have been there.

turist. many turists, waited a long time to get it. Up to 350m in 50 seconds! the Tower is 600 m tall. We could get up to 450 m, but thought it would be the same as 350 m , just smaller. Wonderful wiev over the big City

Awesome. This tower was different with other highest tower in the world that we ever there before. Magnificent view (especially at night), attractive digital panel for looking other object with big screen monitor, photo booth, cafe, merchandise store and many more. Valuable moment that never forget

Espensive veiw of Tokyo. Most places in Tokyo are free of charges making this a affordable visit. This is not the case with Skytree this one of the more expensive places. The view are of course fantastic on 350 meters height!

Really fun. As the highest tower in the world, and the second highest structure in the world, we had to go up it. For 2,000 yen you get to 350m, and and extra 1,000 yen to get to 450m. (Around $30 cad all the way to the top). You can pay more (I think $8 more) to get a fast ticket, but we only waited about 35 mins before we got into the elevator. I've heard people waiting a really long time, so may have been lucky. We went in the evening, was great to see the city lights. Closes at 10pm. Great little shops in that area as well.

Real Steel. Amazing steel structure and definitely a welcomed piece of architecture in the overcrowded Tokyo skyline. If you find the entry cost too high, you can stick around the shopping mall or visit the Skytree Planetarium. A 15 mins walk from Asakusa if you happened to visit the Sensoji Temple.

Worth it but choose your day and time.... This attraction is only 3 years old.It is very well organized, but I would avoid peak times like holidays and weekends. We chose Monday and got there about 6pm. The queues were not long and we were processed quickly.There is one fee for getting to 350m and then you pay a little more to go to 450m = total cost 3090 yen for an adult slightly less for a child. Views are great with a close to 360 degree walk around view. On the top level there is better windows for viewing and photography further away from the lifts.To dine at the top restaurant requires early booking.Lots of shops near the bottom, and a food court.The lifts are so fast and smooth.The top lift has a clear roof to view the trip up the last part.After you come down from the top most viewing deck, there is a glass floor to stand on and film yourself.A good time to come is before dusk, so you get a daylight and night time view.

Pricey but Amazing View. It will run you in the neighborhood of ¥2800 per person just to get to the first observation deck (it's ¥1000 more to go to the top), but it's worth the cost just to skip the 1-1.5 hour line locals have to wait in. Once you reach the observation deck, you'll be blown away by the view. City stretching forever!
Nothing fancy. Just a tower. Maybe can see fuji if you are lucky on the observation tower. All in all, a huge tower but nothing impress me.

Great for shopping but disappointing night view. Shopping & Food: 4 starsViewing deck (at night): 3 starsThere are a lot of great shops here, some that you must visit are: Tokyo Banana Shop (for limited edition Tokyo Banana Tree snack), Uniqlo, Donguri Republic (for Totoro, Spirited Away, etc. stuff), Giants Official Store (for baseball fans), and character stores (Hello Kitty, Rilakkuma, Ultraman, etc.)I've only had food at their Tabe-Terrance food court. If you like noodles, Ippudo (ramen) is there and Miyatake Sanuki Udon (get their tempura too). Both were delicious!The entrance fee for the lower viewing deck (Tembo Deck at 350 m) is a whopping ¥2,060. The wait to purchase the ticket on a Friday night seemed endless and appeared to have at least a hundred people in line at any given time. When we finally arrived to the deck, as you'd expect, there's a swarm of people taking photos. We looked for Tokyo tower, as that was seemed picture-worthy. Unfortunately, Tokyo tower is quite a distance away from Tokyo Skytree and almost blends in with other buildings if it wasn't for its color and shape. The issue with being so high up is that everything down below is tiny and blends together. You can take the escalator down a floor or two and there's a lot less people taking photos.Tokyo Skytree was actually our second option for a night view spot, the first being the "Tokyo City View" at the Mori Art Center in Roppongi. Tokyo tower isn't too far away from Mori Art Center and the night view there certainly seems much more impressive than Skytree's. They were closed for renovations at the time, but next time I'm in Tokyo, I'll definitely head there instead.

The Best View in Tokyo!!. This attraction is one of the best in Tokyo. The views are incredible and worth the entry cost. One tip would be to book an excursion including the attraction, as this will give you priority access going up. If you try going up by arriving without a group booking it may take anything from 1 to 4 hours to gain access, due to the large crowds that seem to always be there.

Great views of Tokyo. We spent a few hours here at the Skytree. We enjoyed our ride on the elevator to the top and then the amazing views of Tokyo. For a little more money you can buy tickets to go even further up to the next level on the Skytree. It is a nice way to spend an hour or two when in Tokyo. There is a spot on the highest level with a glass floor that you can look down. A great picture opportunity!

Good night time attraction. Lovely option for me and hubby to do on our last night in Tokyo. Amazing views from 350m and at night it's quite beautiful with all the lights - we went up the government building in the day so did Skytree in evening.

Very crowded but beautiful view of the city. We went there in the evening towards closing time. Even then it was very crowded. Specially because a lot of school kids were present. Getting into the lift you will go through a long line. Once in you are whizzed away to the top floor (Tembo deck at 350 mts)Though we got some lovely views of the city at night.

Well worth the queue.. Wow, lookout from the upper observation deck @ 450M, the 360 view shows you just what a sprawling metropolis Tokyo is. A little tip, book online before your visit or get the fast ticket option on the 4th floor as you jump the queue. (I queued for an hour). 2000Yen to the first jobs deck (350M) another 1000Yen to 450M.

Amazing experience. We arrived about lunch-time on a Sunday, and opted for the Foreign Visitor Express ticket, and we only had to wait in the queue for 15 or so minutes. While you're in the queue a lady comes to check your documents to ensure you're foreign (our Australian driver's licences were sufficient) so it's pretty quick to pay, then they usher you over to the express lifts. You wait a little longer there, but the whole process is very well organised considering the sheer numbers of people wanting to go up. The lifts are so well-engineered you can barely sense that you're accelerating upwards at quite high speed. The view from the first deck is so amazing we didn't even worry about going higher up. It's a fantastic way to get a sense of Tokyo's layout, and the incredible density of the city. We had lunch in the restaurant up there, and while the food was pretty good, the view was of course what you're there for and that was a knock-out. Highly recommended.
The chance to go to the sky. It worth to see, in good weather you can see the Fuji. In our visit we could not see it. If you are not local you can take the priority lane!

Worth the trip if you like that sort of thing. I like going up towers in big cities to get a birds eye view, so this was right up my alley. It is pricey though, and despite going on a clear day (I was hoping to see Mt Fuji), it was actually quite poor visiblity.They told me there would be a 5 hour wait to go up, but if you are a foreigner (or Japanese accompanying foreigners) you can go to the foreigners section, pay a bit extra and the line was only around 20 mins.

Engineering Marvel. I really enjoyed our time at the Skytree. We took advantage of the Fast Ticket option that is available to foreign tourists. You purchase at the fast ticket desk on the 4th floor, and the ticket allows you to bypass the main line for the elevators. You do pay a premium for this benefit, but lines for Skytree can get quite long so we decided it was worth it in order to make the most of our time. You'll have to assess the crowd situation on the particular day you vist to determine if the extra cost is warranted. We purchased our tickets from a helpful employee who then escorted us past the main elevator line and to the security check. Once you're up in the first observation deck, you must wait in line with everyone else if you want to continue up to the top level, as well as when you head back down. The elevator shoots you up, reaching speeds of 600 meters/minute. Once arriving at the first observation deck (350m), views of the city are fantastic. There appeared to be some jostling for space at the windows, but as we walked around the floor, we managed to find plenty of open spaces to pause and take in the experience. We opted to pay the additional charge to go up to the highest observation deck (450m). It seemed as if many people choose not to do this, as the next level was quite a bit smaller space-wise, but was much less congested. Skytree was probably the most expensive attraction that we visited, but it's a rare opportunity to look down on one of the great cities of the world from one of the tallest structures in the world. The Skytree is lit up with blue and purple lights at night. It's a pretty sight and worth checking out if you're in the area.

Great view. Visited with my son on recent trip to Tokyo. Had to wait in line for over an hour to get tickets but apparently it can be worse. We came prepared with something to read to while away the time. We were lucky to strike a lovely clear day and you can literally see for miles over the city. Went up to the second platform after queuing to buy another ticket. You can't buy the whole trip from downstairs and actually I probably wouldn't bother again. Apart from saying you've been to the top the view is still much the same.

Small Tokyo from 350m height. Honestly, I was not impressed more than after visiting Berlin TV tower. And fyi, observation floor does not move around. Still, it is always a pleasure to observe the city from such height! Also, when we came the first time, it was foggy and staff recommended us to postpone the visit.

Good for bragging rights. This is billed as the second-highest free standing tower in the world. It's only three years old and seems to be immensely popular. We arrived at mid-day on a Friday and found the 40-minute line to buy tickets was more than we wanted to deal with. We inquired about coming back early the next morning. A guide told us that if we arrived at 8 a.m. when the doors open the line would be only 5-10 minutes. He was right.We were not the only ones who had this idea, and the place was crowded if not jam-packed. Once up on the Tembo level, we had a 20-minute wait to buy tickets for the highest observation deck. The view there was even better and less constricted by the structure itself. We were surprised that the trip up to the top was not very expensive. Seattle's Space Needle, at less than half the height, costs more. Staff members were invariably polite and cheerful. The view was wonderful although it was limited somewhat by Tokyo's pervasive haze. This gives you bragging rights for height, although the SkyTree's labels of "Floor 350 floor" and "Floor 450" are a bit silly. If you go: Plan some time for the very upscale SkyTree Mall at the base of the tower. Even if you are sick of standard shopping malls and think you've seen it all, this one will probably prove you wrong. All manner of fresh foods and plastic food join stores selling books, clothing, hats and much more.

Lovely view of Tokyo at night. A lovely place to see the sun set over Tokyo. I arrived on spec and purchased a fast track ticket, which is available for international visitors on the day with no pre-booking. The lines were long otherwise to get through security and up in the lifts.Lovely view from the top - if a little overcroweded and busy.

Great view of Tokyo. It was a pleasantly surprise visit to the Skytree tower. We read about the long line and expansive tickets. We were there around 10am on a clear weekday. The line was about 15 minutes long. When we were up on the tower, the view was just amazing. You did have to buy another ticket to go up to the top level. The view from the upper level was equally great. I bet the night view is awesome too. There are shops and a food court in the lower level. I highly recommend the Skytree, only on a clear day. We spent some time to walk around the side streets around the tower next to the river. It was a nice neighborhood, but not touristy.

Great Tokyo View. We stayed in Tokyo few days during our Japan holiday and after our Asakusa distric visit we decided to go to Tokyo Skytree with the direct metro line. The view is superb and in a sunny and clear day you might be able to see Mt. Fuji. We arrived at the observation deck at sunset and it was amazing seeing Tokyo slowly lighting up. At the observation deck there are two cafes available. A bit overpriced and with little choices but still a comfortable option to enjoy Tokyo view while having a snack. Please note that there are two tickets option: 1) regular ticket 2) fast track ticket. Bear in mind that the fast track allows you just to skip the line to buy a regular ticket but you will in any case have to wait for the elevator. The second option costs only 800 Yen more. When we came there was a very long line at the regular ticket entrance hence we were able to skip more than 30 minutes line. But it really depends by how busy is the day when you decide to go. Regular ticket is 2,060 Yen. If you are not so keen to spend that amount of money, there are some free of charge view points of the city even though not so spectacular.
Stunning views. On a clear day, the 360 degree views of Tokyo from the Skytree is spectacular. Totally worth the wait for tickets.

Walk the Tokyo sky. Going up the Tokyo sky tree in the night is a giddy experience to say the least. The elevators -Tembo shuttles, that take you up there are amazing. They are themed. I travelled up the Sakura one, possibly because I was there in spring. All it takes is 50 seconds for you to reach 350 meters , the Tembo deck , travelling on these elevators!!! We were uncannily lucky as there were no lines that evening. Enter the sky tree building and stroll around some nice shops on the ground floor. Take the escalators to the 4 the floor for buying tickets to go to the top. Buy a coffee or ice cream for yourself at the sky tree cafe on the Tembo deck before boarding the next shuttle to reach the Tembo galleria at 450 meters! That's even more exciting. I have seen quite a few towers. But this is quintessential Japanese technology in all it's glory. It's worth every yen you pay!! Don't forget to sit on the glass floor on floor 340 and take a photo looking down onto the traffic that whizzes by !

Besides Tokyo Tower, there is Skytree. You can have another Tokyo night view besides Tokyo Tower, but there is shopping mall and souvenir shop at the first floor that Tokyo Tower does not have.However there is a step away from the glass such that we cannot set the tripod for better photo shooting.

Cloudy day not recommended. I visited Tokyo Skytree on what could only be considered as a cloudy day. This was of course my biggest mistake, but no fault of the venue.I paid ¥2060 and waited anxiously for the lift. There was absolutely no queue, so if you are willing to sacrifice your view for less waiting time, go on a cloudy day. I arrived at the Tembo Observation Deck, and despite the weather, the view was still enjoyed.There was an option to pay an additional ¥1030 to go up to the next deck, a further one-hundred meters. I think that it is terrible that this was never advertised to me until I was already 350 meters in the sky(tree); a sneaky trick to try and make me pay more.I decided not to bother, admired the view for a while longer, and then took an escalator down ten meters. There was a glass viewing point where you can freely stare at the traffic on the street below, and another area where you can actually stand on a glass platform and have your photograph taken by the staff, although you can’t use your own camera. Instead, you have to pay more money to buy the photograph from the venue.The lift back to the ground exits onto the 5th floor, which is littered with gift shops. To get back to the train station, you have to walk through three floors of souvenir goods, before having to walk through a huge indoor food market.Overall, Tokyo Skytree is a nice experience, and the view is okay, but there are much cheaper options in Tokyo, and some places where a better view can be seen at no cost (Tokyo Metropolitan Government Buildings). Not good for people on a budget.

Total Rip-Off. Incredibly Expensive, immense queueing, Basic ticket only gets you half way up, partly unfriendly and unqualified staff, a shame for Japan. We paid for premium ticket and were put into the regular queue, complaints were ignored. Can't recommend it.

LOVED IT!. On our last trip to Tokyo in 2013 we visited Tokyo Tower. This time we tried Skytree- it was AWESOME! Kinda busy on a beautiful Spring Sunday afternoon but opted for the Fast ticket (not exactly fast still took over an hour to get into an elevator) great views from both Tembo Galleria (of course) and Tembo Deck. After we grabbed a snack and hung around to see it illuminated at night (well worth the wait). Definitely worth the cost. I highly recommend visiting Skytree.

Fantastic views. The views from both the 200 & 250 metre observation floors were amazing. The direction stickerson the glass was very helpful in determining where the main buildings in Tokyo were. The glass viewing floor on the top level gave an amazing view from above. The admission price was very reasonable with the extra to go to top level also reasonable. One of the best views I have seen.

Tall. In classic Japanese fashion, they built the Tokyo Skytree in order to lay claim to the tallest self-supporting structure in the world, and made it a tourist attraction to raise revenue. Celebrating three years of existence this month, it is a breathtaking sight to behold from the ground. You can pay 2,060 yen to visit the observatory at 350 meters (higher than the 333m Tokyo Tower, which used to be the tallest artificial structure in Japan), and for an additional 1,030 yen you can go to 450m. It's cool to go all the way up but the view isn't much better. If the day is hazy or cloudy (as many days in Japan are), you will not be able to see past the vast city of Tokyo in all directions. The visual distinctions in the city structures are few, thus it is hard to pick things out. Displays help orient you and point things out but it might be a good idea to bring binoculars if you have them. Recommend visiting early in the day and during the week if possible.

Great views when clear. We went up the skytree with a family of four. Luckely we came accross a special counter for fasttickets. A bit more expensive and overpriced, but skipping a lane of at least one hour (monday morning) was a good choice! Now we were up in less then 15 minutes. View is good to see how big Tokyo is. No great views in terms of beautifull buildings etc. The mall under the skytree is crowded but do-able for some regular shopping and food.

Highest point in Tokyo. Only two years old, this worlds highest tower is slightly becoming a new Tokyo landmark. With it's 636 meters, it is the highest building in Japan, and the second in the world after the Burj Khalifa in Dubai.Try to get there early to avoid the lines. There's a metro station right beneath it. First you climb to the first deck at 350 meters for little less than 20 USD. The views are impressive, you see the entire most populated area in the world. If you have luck to visit it on a perfectly clear day, you could see Mt. Fuji as well.After, if you want, for additional 10 USD you can climb 100 m higher, to 450 meters, but I don't think it's worth it (I saw very few people going up there).
Amazing views! . Amazing views! If you're an international visitor, get the fast pass ticket. Only 200 yen more and will cut your wait time from about 60 min to 45 min.

Can't see anything. Yes, we understand that depend on luck, you can or cannot see the tokyo area due to fog. So just our luck that morning it was covered with fog. We spend some time going around and about 45 mins we went down.We went at about 9am and there was no queue at all. We heard about having to queue for hours before so we were glad there is no queue but the minus point was that, the observatory deck is covered so not much view. We went up anyway. There are 2 level one at 350m and the other at 450m. You can only buy the tickets to 450m at the 350m deck. but since there is no view, we don't bother going up. The best part came after that when we went to the souvenir shops at the ground floor at the mall attached to it. Sadly we don't have much time there so can't shop much.

Buy Something You Will Cherish. I always struggle with buying gifts that will be meaningful and were not made in China when traveling. Unless I am in China of course. In Japan you have the same issue, you never know what souvenirs were made in Japan or China or somewhere else. I also want to buy something that was hand made by local people that will help the local economy. Problem solved in Japan. I found this great hand-crafted chopstick store that offers a wide variety of prices and styles: (EdoKibashi). These will be cherished gifts and remembrances of you trip to Japan. The store is hard to find, but well-worth the trouble, it is in the neighborhood just under the SkyTree. Take CASH they do not take credit cards. Chopsticks range for $10.00 USD to over 100.00 USD per pair. Have you Hotel translate the address and call first - they are open limited hours. www.edokibashi.com/

Great experience - well worth the money. I went to the Skytree with a group. Luckily our guide booked the tickets ahead of our visit so that we only had to queue for a couple of minutes - both at the base and on the first observation deck. The view far over the Tokyo area is simply breathtaking. Was it worth taking the second elevator (and paying quite some money...) and check out the view from the upper observation deck? Definitely yes! All in all a very memorable experience!

Highest structure in Tokyo. This is the highest structure in Tokyo and the second highest structure in the world. The first thing you'll notice when you approach the Tokyo Skytree is that it's MASSIVE. I mean it complete towers over the Tokyo skyline more than the Tokyo Tower ever did. Only downside is that you'll have to queue for hours just to take a visit at the top but it's really worth the visit. I recommend going to the top of the tower at night to see the beautiful Tokyo skyline. A friend of mine suggested to go back around Hanabi. Third Saturday of July because that's when the Sumidagawa river festival is usually held and you have a birds eye view of the city with the the beautiful fireworks display of hanabi as you usually see them at anime shows.

Well worth your time. We weren't sure if we wanted to spend the money doing this but we are so glad we did. The view is truly awesome and on a clear day you can see everywhere. Walking on the glass floor is fun. Enjoyed the cafe for an ice cream break. Well run and efficient not much wait for lifts up or down. Do go early though as it was much busier at lunchtime once we had finished.

so so high, the highest thing to be seen in tokyo except Fuji. The sky tree is extraordinarily tall, it towers over everything else in the city by a lot. Go at dawn or dusk if you can that way you can see the city in both lights. Fuji can be seen some days - mainly in the fall. Or after a big rain storm. In the middle of the day the smog can disguise things but it gets better as it cools off towards the end of the day.

Worth the visit - even when it's foggy. We arranged tickets in advance through our hotel because we wanted to avoid the lines and make sure we could get in. This was a major plus. The downside was it was very, very foggy when we arrived and they had signs stating that the views would be limited. We were on a tight travel schedule so we really had no choice but to go up anyway. There were fewer people which actually made the experience better. It was true that the views were limited but frankly you can still see just about everything you want to see and the place is great. My kids even enjoyed the elevator ride and all the interactive stuff at the top. We shelled out a little more money and went to the very top. I don't mind the extra $20 bucks or so and therefore it was worth it to me. If you are looking for better value then no reason to spend the extra money and just go to the first observation tower.

Breathtaking view of Tokyo. This tower offers an amazing view of Tokyo at night. I imagine it would also be beautiful in the morning but you can easily go to the Tokyo Metropolitan Govt Office for that. It is a little far as it is located at the Asakasa station which is the end of the rail (maybe an hour total from central areas). However going there at night, where there is almost no more queue is worth it. Once the elevator opens, you will be amazed at the beautiful lights because they made it in such a way wherein the moment you step out the elevator, you will be blown away by the city lights. They also have this google maps station that lets you click the sights near the area. If you have extra time to go to here, then might as well.

Skip the long queue. I've been there a couple times for lunch and dinner, choose a restaurant on 30/F or 31/F, sit down and relax, you could also see the wonderful view while enjoying different cusine during day and night

Expensive...nit the greatest views. We did this as part of a tour. There were no queues when we got there, even though everywhere said that there would be a long wait! The observatory deck is much like all the others I have been on, the Shard, Eiffel Tower etc. Only I would say that the view is not as distinct, due I think to the sheer size of the city. It is difficult to pick out specific areas. Also there is a huge part of the circular view cut off to you u less you want to buy coffee and sit inside the seating area. The shops sell the usual overpriced tat that...as as tourists..we wanted to buy! Luckily we were there at 6.30 when they turn on the pink light up the side of the building. You need to be outside to see this, as we were. It is pink for a limited time to reflect the cherry blossom season

80 minutes in a queue to buy the ticket? No thanks.. The place is insane - the day I was there the sign told me that I have to wait 80 minutes in the queue to get my ticket, and after that there's a queue for the elevator too. I'm sure the view up there is spectacular, but spending almost 2 hours in the queue would be crazy for travellers with limited time. So I followed the advice from my Japanese friend, who told me that I could actually go to the tower next to the SkyTree, get up to the top floor where they have the restaurants, enjoy my meal there and still have a good view of Tokyo. Just a tip for travellers who can't afford to waste 2 hours in the queue.

Awesome!. We visited the skytree at midday yesterday (with no reservation) and the line was 80min + but we were recommended to enter through the west tower for "international" line of which the line was only 15min!! Awesome!The staff at the tower are so friendly and helpful! The elevators have a theme and are so beautiful!Once you are finally up the tower (350m) the view is awesome, although there was a lot of smog so we didn't see Mt Fuji, but that's ok. It was ¥2820 per person to go up (more expensive than the "non-international" line but worth it for the time saving)After we had a formal photo taken (¥1300) we went up to the next level (450m) which was an additional ¥1000 or so! At first I didn't like the 450m floor as there were bars but as you moved around there were no bars! View was amazing and it was pretty empty.After that we came down and stood on the glass floor which was cool!Overall, highly recommended!Tip: go to the west tower for shorter line if you're a visitor. Also if you reserve tickets in advance it must be 3 days prior!

Go early and miss the crowds. Arriving early seems to be the key to this tower. On a Thursday at 9:00 there was no queue to buy tickets, get up the tower or get down again. Once up, if the weather is good, then the view from the Skytree really puts the size of Tokyo into perspective. It was useful to orient yourself with parts of the city from above. We went up the the higher observation deck as well because it wasn't busy, but you could safely miss this unless you just wanted to say you had been to the highest level as the view was not really as good due to more restricted windows. The glass in the Skytree was very good for taking photographs through, it did not reflect or interfere with the picture at all. School groups might be you're only company if you go early enough. Worth a visit if in Tokyo.

didnt go up - line too long. we visited the skytree in Cherry Blossoms season so we knew it would be busy, but there was an hour line just to get a ticket for a timed entry which wasn't for another 4 hours so we decided not to go up! the ticket was expensive also. The shops in the sky tree area though are awesome - we spent 2 hours walking around just shopping under the skytree!

A must do in Tokyo. Din't be out off by the long queue.. This huge tower is easy to get to on the Tokyo metro, the station Oshiage, which is at the opposite end of the purple line to Shibuya. When we arrived on a Staurday afternoon, the whole area as heaving and we were nearly put off by the huges queues. The tower is 634 metres tall and is the second tallest building in the world behind the Burg Khalifa. At the bottom is a huge seven storey shopping mall, so this is an attraction in its own right, there is also an aquarium, and ice rink and other attractions - hence the crowds.The waiting time for the tower was showing as 60-90 minutes but we decided to bite the bullet and join the massive queue - I have to say it was actually very well organised and fast moving - we joined the queue at 3.25pm and bought our tickets at 4.20pm. Tickets were 2060 yen each ( just over £11.) Once we had bought them we were whisked up in one of four very fast lifts to the top. The view of the city is, as you would expect, stunning. At the top it was busy but it wasn’t a problem. The area at the top is divided into 12 sectors with a very good guide to tell you what to look out for in each one. Unfortunately it was too cloudy to see Mount Fuji.It was great looking out and spotting things we decided to stay a bit and let it get dark. You are not at the top, you are at the 350m mark called the Tembo Deck could pay extra and go up to the 450M mark to the Tembo Galleria , but we didn’t bother, this was high enough to see a LONG way! A great way to pass an afternoon in Tokyo and it lets you know just how massive the city is.

AMAZING view, quick to get up (U.S. long as you're a tourist!). The fast track ticket available to foriegn tourists got us up there in less than 20 mins and it would haven been quicker, except high winds meant one in two lifts had to go up empty. Truly stunning views of the city, but if you don't like views, there's not much else up there.Sadly the high winds then closed the lifts completely and we were stuck up there for a bit, but at least there was a lot to look at while we waited.
Beautiful scene.. It's very nice. The scene on the top was sooooo beautiful. It's amazing. I really had a great time there.

On a clear day ........ Wow - 350 meters into the sky, be you can even go higher (at an extra fee). Lotsof people here, buy the queues move along quicklime. On a clear day you are supposed to be able to see Mt Fuji, no such luck for us, but still worth the effort. We cruised up the Sumida River and then got the train from Asakusa.

Great views!. I love to visit the towers in the cities I visit and the Tokyo Skytree didn't disappoint. Jetlag had me up at 5:30 in the morning, so I took a cab and arrived at the ticket office 15 minutes before it opened. There were 7 people in line by then and a hundred or more by the time they opened. The staff great the first arrivals and getting to the top is done efficiently. Being so early, it wasn't too crowded and the clear day meant we could see Mount Fuji in the distance. The main section has three levels at 340, 345 and 350m but you can also go up to 450m which has an exterior walk way that spirals up on the outside. The views are not much better but the walkway was pretty cool. Since I was so early, that level was virtually deserted. There are staff everywhere and they are very helpful.

A bit pricey, and surprisingly boring. Had it not been for the Fast Skytree Ticket offered to visiting foreign tourists, this experience would've been incredibly difficult. As non-Japanese citizens, we were able to purchase the Fast Skytree Ticket and go up the tower within 40 minutes (an incredible time difference from the standard 4 hour wait). We were jam packed into the elevators after waiting in a queue and rocketed to the Tembo Deck. It was a hazy day with decent visibility but the experience was far from spectacular. After a 15 minute walk around the tower, we were completely finished and verging on bored. Glad I experienced the height, but next time I would visit any of the other towers in Tokyo.

Pretty good view. My husband and I went up the Skytree on a wet and cloudy day. Despite the weather, we still got a pretty good view.We were keen to go up here earlier in our 4 night stay to get our bearings for the rest of our trip.We opted for the basic viewing package and didn't pay the extra to go up higher as we didn't think it would be worth it considering the weather. You can still get a good view from the basic level and get access to the glass bottom floor which is fun to go on.This tower is walking distance to the famous temple in Tokyo and there is a really good food court nearby with affordable options for lunch.

Overrated and Pricey. Nice views but too expensive and crowded. Elevators are super fast but once at the top there's not a whole lot to do. Mori observation tower is better because is has open air area and is in a livelier area (Roppongi)

Overrated and Expensive. Went at night. Long lines and expensive. There are some positives: Views are expansive, elevators are super fast and it's earthquake resistance engineering is a marvel. I like Mori tower lookout better because it was open air and in Roppongi district.

Great View. This place has an astonishingly great view of the metropolis of Tokyo. There is a very enjoyable see-through part of the floor which is fun to stand on. Try to arrive in conjunction with the sunset-you will get to see the sun setting alongside Mt. Fuji. The four elevators are each themed around spring, summer, autumn, and winter. During the festive seasons, they usually have special attractions. We went to the Christmas one, and enjoyed a good projected animation running the walls of the building. However, the price is expensive, and the waiting queue was long. I think it's worth visiting for the view, though.

Great views - take advantage of the Fast Tourist pass!. It was a clear morning and jet lag had us up at 430am! So after a brief sushi breakfast at Tsukiji, we headed to the SkyTree! I hadn't been there before, but it was easy to find from the station and there was plenty of signage. The Oshiage station will lead you directly to some escalators that take you through the SkyTree shopping area and from there, you can get to the ticket counter after a brief walk through a raised walkway (or outside to get a picture!).Depending on the time that you go, you'll see a long line (1 hour + in our case), but if you're visiting Tokyo, just ask for the Fast Tourist Pass and someone will direct you to another desk. It costs about 800 yen more, but it's totally worth it since you skip the line!We were up in less than 2 minutes (fast elevator to 350m!)! I think this level was good enough and the windows were cleaner allowing for better photos. Once you're up at 350m, you can pay an additional amount (around $10?) to get to 450m via a separate elevator. From there you just follow a gradual spiral upwards to the highest manageable point, then take an elevator back down. I didn't feel like it was worth it, but to each his own!Great little diversion on a clear day and then you can shop and eat (as you can in most places in Tokyo!) to relax!

Entirely too expensive . We were there on a cloudy day and had already been to the government building (it's free), so we did not go up. No matter what we would not have paid because it was very expensive and the government building was just as nice and not nearly as crowded.
The view!. Best view anywhere. The scope of Tokyo from this vantage point is breathtaking. If you've never been to Tokyo, this is a must do!

Gorgeous view of the city. It's always great to get one of these sky high viewpoints in a city. There are 3 popular options in Tokyo: Skytree, the fairly new Tokyo Tower (Eiffel tower look alike) and for free, there's Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observatory (http://www.tokyometro.jp/en/attractions/metropolitan_govt_bldg/).I only did Skytree and the view was pretty awesome. We were there in the evening although we had hoped to get there for sunset (which I would recommend if you can make it because then you get day & night view). We had a coffee and just relaxed and let the view sink and it was a pretty awesome place to have a break.The thing about Skytree is that it's a fair bit out from the city. The plus is that you get to see how truly massive Tokyo is, and it is MASSIVE. The downsides are that the view is pretty much the same from anywhere up top and it doesn't give you the bird's eye view of the city you probably get from Tokyo Tower, which is in the midst of it all. A friend who has done both said she preferred Tokyo Tower. Had we planned our days/time better I would've done a free trip up the government building and a paid trip on either Skytree or Tokyo, and one at day and one at night. All in all though, you probably can't go wrong and make sure you do at least one!

Amazing tower but the experience was not that good. I've been wanting to come here since it opened up and the Fast Ticket option for foreigners made it accessible for me this trip. Unfortunately, there were some issues. First of all, its not so fast as there was one person working the counter for a while until a 2nd person finally started to assist. Once I got the ticket and went up, the sheer number of people pushing to get a space near the windows to take pics was ridiculous. I've been to other places like Tokyo Tower and the Shinjuku Govt Bldg Observatory which also have excellent views of the city and it was a much more pleasant experience. Then when you go back down through the shopping area, the large amount of intense shops all crowded together are a bit too much and can overwhelm you with sensory overload. Finally, the train that serves the specific Skytree station was having problems and stopped working so I had to walk a long way to Oshiage Stn. which really put me in a bad mood. While there is not doubt the views of Tokyo are very good, there simply are better options that make for a more enjoyable experience.

Best views of Japan. There was a long line there so the lady at the counter sold us express ticket to get to the front of the line which would have otherwise taken an hour or more. The views were breathtaking and they have display simulation of what it use to look like a long time ago.

Great views from the top. A great place for anyone to have 360 degrees views of Tokyo. It gives you the different perspectives of Tokyo and appreciate the transformation the city have gone through over these years.It was an experience taking the super speed lift to go to the first stop at 350 metres gallery view. You need to pay more to the higher level gallery.There are time schedules to go to the top but you can beat the queue by taking the express line..but you need to pay extra.After the visit you may opt to have lunch or refreshments at the food court or go for formal dining at the upper floor of the mall. While there you may also opt to visit the aquarium just next door. It's not a large one comparatively to other aquariums that I have been to.Once done you may take the train to Asakusa which is just one stop away.

Very high tower, great position. We visited the first level of the tower, at over 400 meters above sea level. The view is amazing, althogh you need a very clear day to ser the city limits and Mount Fuji. The organization and the indications are not very good, unlikely the rest if the city. There's a nice fast lane for foreigners, but it could be better organized. Normal waiting time is hours. I prefer the 1o1 in Taipei!

A Dizzying 360 view of Tokyo. The 360 view of Tokyo was amazing. Unfortunately, the day was not clear enough to see Fujiyama. If you have a passport, you can pay extra and go up to the observation deck instead of waiting in line for an hour. If you are afraid of heights, be prepared for the subtle swaying you will experience.

Best view. Visited last october, definitely worth visiting. Can get crowded & need to wait for some time.On a clear day, you get awesome view of tokyo city. If lucky can see Mt.Fuji from the top. Has the option of taking photos from the observation deck. Night view is awesome.

A 360 degree view of Tokyo. Personally, I think panoramic views of a city from above is over rated. That being said. The Tokyo skytree provides a 360 degree view of the city for an exhorbitant fee riding a high speed elevator..

Agood View of Tokyo from the Top. Tokyo Skytree is a very well known tourist trap, but given that I was not going to be back in Japan for many years, decided to visit it in any case. It is located very near the Oshiage metro station (Asakusa line). Even in the early morning, the queue was long, but the counters worked fast. After spending ¥ 2060, I boarded the elevator which was lighted beautifully. Like any observation tower, one can spend as much time as one likes on the deck. The views are good, especially the view of the structures around Sumidagawa river. Being a cloudy day, I could not see Mt Fuji. The view gives an idea of how big the Metropolitan area of Tokyo is. There is a separate ticket for the upper deck but I did not feel the need for it. The glass floor on the deck below allows one to view the streets below directly and that was great. Overall, worth one visit.

It all depends on the weather. I visit as many high observation decks as I can and this was the first time I'd been in Tokyo since Skytree opened for international visitors. I was staying close to the tower so I was able to time my visit to match reasonably clear weather. You still can't make an advanced booking unless you have a Japanese credit card. However, international visitors are now able to pay a premium to avoid the queues. When I went, the queue was signed as being about 30 minutes so I paid the premium which got me in a lift straight away. Once you get to the 350 m level, it doesn't give you any priority in getting to the 450 m level. Luckily, the queue for that was only about 5 minutes. Once at the upper level, the views were great although the weather wasn't crystal clear.

Really good views, but be prepared to travel. The sky tree has really impressive views over Tokyo and is defiantly worth a trip. It is in the older area and does take a while to get there. We had the JR rail passes but still had to buy a local metro ticket as well otherwise its about a 20 min walk from the nearest JR LINE. the price is 2060 yen per adult but you can stay up there for as long as you like. Go early morning or be prepared to have to go back at a pre allocated slot.

Worth a visit. Luckily we were foreign tourists and had the option of paying a little extra and jumping the 3 hour queue. Felt sorry for people who didn't have this option as I personally would not have wanted to wait. It is a great way to appreciate the scale of Tokyo but it is basically a 360* view of a concrete jungle. If you want to go to the highest level you have to pay again. Be warned, you may also get stuck in a line coming back down again. I wanted to see the view during the day and at night, but your ticket only allows once up so you have to pick which one you want. Would probably not visit again, and was probably a bit expensive but was an interesting experience.

Awesome tower, okay view.. An impressive tower with two great observation decks that allow for an impressive birds-eye / miniature view of a large part of Tokyo. There's an almost 360° view possible, a couple of payed photo oppertunities, interactive displays, a restaurant, a shop and a bar. Staff is super friendly and helpful and generally speaks good English.For ¥2060 ($20) you can visit the lower deck (floors 340, 345 and 350). This'll allow you regular access to the tower. To speed up the access to the deck tou can buy a fast-track ticket for ¥2800, this let's you skip the waiting line of over an hour for the elevators. Finally you can buy a ticket for the upper deck(floor 445 and 450 which costs an additional (¥1030).International visitors have a seperate queue to buy their tickets which is way shorter.I'd suggest considering visiting the sea-side top tower. It's less high but has a more awesome sky-line view (especially at night), no waiting lines, is less crowded and is cheaper (¥620).

Magical at night. We went to the sky tree on a Tuesday night in November 2014, no line at all we pretty much walked in paid and went up. It's truly magical at night with all the lights of the city. Still lots of people when you get up but you can still walk around and go right up to the windows.  The best part was when we had a drink at the bar (¥900 a beer with nuts) and sat right at the window and chilled out for half an hour looking at all the lights. One thing I would have liked to bring would be binoculars as the city is so vast and you are very high. Big shopping centre underneath with lots of shops (but your in Tokyo so finding shopping won't be a problem)  I would recommend to anyone visiting and wants to get possibly the best view of Tokyo.  Other places are also good like Shinjuku government building however you can see much further and more up in the sky tree.

Spectacular!!!. The trip up is quick and fast. The views are amazing even on a cloudy day so I cannot imagine what it would be like on a totally clear one. We wanted to eat lunch there but our timing did not work.
Well worth the cues. Well worth the effort. Really enjoyed it. Great panoramic views. But why oh why make public pay twice to get to the top ?

Skytree for all. Tourist can expect faster queue time at a slightly higher price. If not queueing up for the regular tickets might take a long time as many locals are queueing up with you also. The view on top is beautiful. 360° panoramic view of tokyo. However there are other free alternatives to see a birds eye view on tokyo. Recommended to go near sunset. Earlier will be too bright, not ideal for pictures. Sunset till evening is the best timing.
Nice view. Offers a nice view of Tokyo and the surrounding mountains. The fast track line for foreigners is great to cut the time down of waiting.

Smog can cloud views. Beware long queues, you will need to allow over an hour. From top viewing platform you have to descend 2 levels on stairs before you reach the descent lifts, queuing all the way.

Amazing view and wonderful experience. Everything was amazing about this visit from beginning to end! There was only one person in front of my family for the ticket line, and we went around early evening. The ride up there was gorgeous, though a little scary, and if you have a serious fear of heights, this is obviously not the place for you. If not however, this is a must if you come to Japan. The sight is surreal, and really brings out the best of Tokyo, and though the food is a little overpriced, but very satisfactory, and along with the cafe, the attached restaurant boasts of very high quality. In all aspects, with pricing, food, and view, my experience was breathtaking and my favorite memory from my travels in Japan.

Lots of money for a standard urban area view. Okay- I got suckered a second time. The first time I got suckered was in Toronto at the CN Tower. Now, the Tokyo Sky Tree. The reason this attraction is a "don't bother" on my list is the cost coupled with the time you waste waiting in line. I did not keep my receipt bu I believe we paid about $25 US or so- similar to the CN Tower in Toronto. The view is great but it is hard to relate to in terms of where you are or what you are seeing if you are a visitor. There are some displays that help but it isn't enough. You can see Mt. Fuji from the tower but I would not say that that is the worth the price of admission. In my opinion this "experience" should not cost more than $10 US. We did find a real local place to eat lunch near the tower called Cafe Tokyo that was very good. We walked around the area of the tower and just took a chance on the place and it ended up being very good.

Great view and good eats. Get ticket early or get time card early to buy ticket. Must try Nana's green tea. Great dessert!If you would like to dine in the Tappanyaki restaurant on top of Skytree- make reservation in advance

Great views and a stunning commerce center.. It's no small task building one of the world's tallest structures in Tokyo. The engineering which allowed construction of the Skytree in earthquake prone Tokyo was awesome. The result was well worth the effort. The views are dazzling. But the logistics are even better. The design serves to move people through the viewing decks efficiently and comfortably. The Skytree anchors a huge retail complex that consists of dozens of retail stores. These are not shoddy souvenir stands; they sell quality merchandise of all kinds. The Skytree is worth the trip. It far exceeds the experience at the Tokyo Tower.

A "must-do" while in Tokyo.. Skytree tower costs around $16 per person plus and addition $8 if you want to go to the very top. The queue moves quickly and the employees are very friendly for the most part. They don't speak English very well at all but they are generally very nice. Your ears will pop several times during your ascent. On a clear day, you can see everything. I recommend going at dusk so that you can see mount fuji and enjoy the city lights simultaneously. The base of the tower is connected to a shopping mall.
massive queues. Worth going just to look at the tower. Queues are monstrous though and the shopping centre at the base is all is all tourist stuff.

Tokyo Sky Tree Tower. Visited the Tokyo Sky Tree Tower. Some call it The New Tokyo Tower. If you like structural wonder and a view from the tallest building in Japan, this is for you. I took the express elivator to the top observation area. 350 meters into the sky, just under 1/4 mile straight up. From there you can see it all. Off in the distance you can see the original Tokyo Tower. And they say on a clear day you can see Mount Fugi. In front of the observations there are high tech table maps. If you touch an area of interest it zooms in close so you can get a better view of what you're looking for. There's a restaurant if you would like a snack and plenty of shops on the lower levels. Great fun for families, a group of friends or by yourself, especially if you enjoy photography.

Good view, but Tokyo is best from the ground!. The view is obviously good, and you get a nice overview of the city - it's size, layout etc - but it's not a spectacular city from above. I think the visit is worth it - but it's not a top attraction. Do it when it's quite - not on weekends if possible

Get the foreign visitor ticket. Day tickets force you to queue up between a designated time. Foreign visitor tickets (counter on the inside, 4th floor) gets you up instantly. I think there is a premium paid though for this privilege. Ride up was good, but to get to the top, there is an additional ticket that had to be purchased. Overall, good experience. Pity it was foggy. Would definitely recommend this palace! Walk here from Asakusa for good views of Tokyo neighbourhoods.

go early to avoid long lines. I went before noon and only had to wait a half hour before purchasing a ticket. Took an hour to walk around the 350th floor. Didn't opt to go higher. It was a cloudy day so couldn't see Mt. Fuji but could see the Tokyo Dome and Tokyo tower.

Enjoyed the Height, but Crowded and Foggy. I climbed up to the viewing area at 350 meter high with my family. Since I booked the restaurant named 'musashi' at one floor down from the viewing area, I could use priority lane to take high-speed elevator where I had been queuing just for a few minutes, although the people at normal lanes seemed to wait for the elevators more than 30 minutes on Saturday afternoon.I was impressed with its height, but unluckily, it was a bit foggy on that day. Moreover, in my opinion, the view itself was a bit boring since this tower is located at relatively residential area and there were less outstanding sceneries or architectures comparing to Western side of Tokyo.If the air and sky were much clearer, we could enjoy Mt. Fuji or Mt. Tsukuba, far away from Tokyo, though.

IS THIS REAL?. Are actually my feet attached to a structure that's bound to the earth and not space?? Because, I am actually in space. No, really; when you are up and look down it feels like you are on a plane. You look not at houses but at small squares of neighborhoods just like it's freaking Google maps. I promise you will not forget! Sure it's full of people but all great places are. Definitely not to miss, even if you went to Tokyo tower and other kind of observatory (which I did, & completely not regret going to them all!) because each is different!Also the mall downstairs is pretty good, you should go take a look!!

Great time here.. It is a great experience to be here while I am in Tokyo, I guess the lift is the fastest I ever experienced before, the other one I noticed is the toilet that is the tallest in the world as per the tour guide informed. The place to stand on the mirror to look to the ground seem to be great design and feel that I stand on the cloud. Don't forget to be here when you visit Tokyo. There are also many shop here if you wish to buy something for souvenir.

TOWER BAGGING - EVERYONE IS A TOURIST. Liked the views and interactive displays. IT is the tallest tower in the world (right now) and for this reason, everyone (Japanese included) is a tourist and is visiting. We arrived early (good thing, as wait for tickets was 0 min), but still a lot of people in the towers at all levels (hard to get a window location), and when we left, the wait was 45-60 min just to get a ticket (cannot imagine the wait for the lifts OR the crowds in the actual tower).

Overpriced and rubbish. Not very good. Not worth it. Can't stand close to the glass and there's alot of people and reflections in the way of the view.
Can only go to 350mtres with ticket purchase need a second ticket to get to 700mtres.

Nice night view for couple. I never go there at day, but when I was there at night time it was very nice view, me and my husband not go to the at very Top of the tower, we only did go to the first level of the tower, but the view is very good enough, the theme on the inside of the tower in LOVE, so there are a lot of young couples visiting this tower.The city lights from above are very beautiful....

Tokyo Skytree, Pricey but worth it.. Tokyo Skytree is currently the largest tower in the world at 640m. It is quite an attractive piece of engineering and architecture. There is more to Skytree then just the tower. At it's base is a massive shopping complex with many great stores. Best to go at night or when it is not at height of say or season as que lines to go higher in the tower can be long. It was about $20(can) to go half way and $30 to go to the very top when I went. The views were spectacular and on a clear day Mt. Fuji is clearly visible. The area that the Skytree is in (Asukusa) is also good for sightseeing as it is Old Tokyo, but I will save that for other reviews...

It's ok but nothing special. Went here it was ok, and as others say pick a clear day to get good views, once your up their and spent 10 - 15 mins I'd had enough, once you've walked round not much else to do, we had good views and could see a fair distance. Have a look at layout of floors when up their we wanted a drink so went to skytree cafe but nowhere to seat ! , on way out came across another skytree cafe on a lower floor which had seating, so check floor plan. I thought a bit expensive but others may say different, bit of advice try to book on Internet before you go so your not stood in a queue. A lot of things are not clear, for example they have an overseas visitors desk which you'll come across on your way out after been up the tower !! And it costs more couldn't work out why ??. It is worth doing despite what I've said but make sure it's a clear day,

WORLDS TALLEST TOWER - CHECK. Skytree tower is currently the worlds tallest non-commercial tower and as such, has become one of the perverbial tourist musts when visiting Tokyo. We waited to visit until the sky was clear (after 3 days of rain) and made a point to get there early (by 10 am via Metro). It was a mega-project and continues to be such given the massive crowd control effort in place. The views from the top are outstanding, especially on a clear day when you can see Mt. Fuji and utilize the interactive maps to locate various points of interest. As some have noted, this is a very crowed attraction and you just have to wait your turn to get close to the windows to get your shot. There are 3 levels, and in requisite glass floor (again, just have to wait patiently while everyone takes their turn as well). Noted that while our wait in the various lines was ~5 min, at 10 am, by the time we left at noon, the waits were ~45 min to 1 hr, and this on a weekday.

Nice but crowded. Tokyo Skytree is nice. You have to visit it at least once if you're ever in Tokyo. It is however quite crowded which makes it hard to get a glimpse of the view. To get tickets to reach the highest observation level is another 30 mins of queue time just to get into the lift. With that said, the surrounding areas around Skytree has many things to see like Solamachi and even a neat Ghibli store with a good selection of merchandise. Use the Otemachi station. You will get an unobstructed view of the tower for great photo taking opportunities.

Best (and biggest) city in the world. Tokyo is awesome and the high rises makes my town (London) look like a village. The view from The Sky Tree is breath taking and whenever you are up high you will be taking pictures.

WONDERFUL VIEW - ALL THE WAY TO MT FUJI.
