TOkyo's latest attraction - 450 m high - 2 stations in the elevator - can pay by credit card - views all round - even saw Mt Fuji - better than the previous Tokyo Tower - worth the money - also convenient to river cruises on the nearby Sumida River back to Ginza - close to Asakusa Shrine - good for a day visit - convenient trains station too

Worth the money, but go at night!. For the low price of $20 (roughly), Tokyo Skytree was certainly worth the visit. There was a huge queue but it surprisingly went very quickly. I believe we only waited about one hour, which I think is reasonable for how popular this site is. Unfortunately, we went during the day and I think going in the evening would be way more spectacular. It was quite busy and at times hard to get a spot by the window. Overall, I think it's a great spot to tick off your list when you head to Tokyo!

Fabulous views on a clear day. Pick a clear day to visit the Sky Tree. We had a perfect day and the views across the city were incredible. Mt Fuji was clearly visible in the distance to top it off! Definitely worth the money to visit this rather than the other attractions that boast views - this one towers about everything else!
What a view. Well worth making the effort to visit if nothing but for the view! There's something surreal having a coffee at 350 metres above Tokyo

An amazing view.. Tokyo SkyTree can be seen almost anywhere you are. I saw the tower from my hostel in Taito-ku. I asked the workers what it was, and made a trip there in the morning. It was obviously rather easy to find. They have pamphlets in many different languages. I only purchased a ticket for the deck, I didn't find it necessary to go to the galleria. The deck has a gift shop, cafe, restaurant, lounge area, and even a small glass floor area! The glass floor had a line for it, so guests can take photos. I have to be honest, I was too scared to stand on it! I hope the next time I come, I can visit at night. Definitely a tourist spot, but it's an experience you can't miss!

'High-up in the land of glittering lights'. We went up the Skytree in the night and was awed by the Tokyo night lighting. We had seen the skyline in daytime from the Metroplitan building, so decided to visit the skytree at night. I think, one should see both - the day and night as it is difficult to decide which is better. Glittering lights all over with a inky-black Sumida river is a sight to see. The restaurant is quite pricey. The lifts have themed music and displays on the walls and ceilings. The area around the ticketing office have some minimalistic yet beautiful displays.

Great view if you manage to avoid the queue. Tower operates a two stage ticketing whereby you can only purchase a ticket for the top level (450m) from the main platform (350m). Can be quite surprising but I guess this was implemented to transfer part of the queue to another location.The pros : great view in particular from the second platform (worth the extra cost even if you are more distante from the window than on the main platforms.The cons : queues can reach 2 hours to get a ticket at peak time, so a visit early morning is recommended to avoid that.

Great views of Tokyo. The size of Tokyo is immense. To get a view of the expanse, the Tomyo Skytree is a great way. As I'm from Toronto, we have a similar tower (CN Tower) that provides a great view and gives you a sense of where you are, relative to the surroundings. The Skytree is new, and there is a mall attached to it. It was crowded but we were able to see everything.

Go on a clear day!. I was there in the morning on a weekday, it was raining. There wasn't much queue. It was almost no visibility at height of 350m viewing deck; however, the staff did warn me it'd be low visibility up up there when purchasing the ticket. The price was a bit high as it didn't include the entrance to the 450m viewing deck. There is a cafe/ restaurant which you could chill over a coffee and dessert. I would come back again on a sunny day to have a better experience.
Mesmerizing. Being the 2nd tallest building in the world is attracting enough but its unique design, fantastic views and some great places to eat and shop makes for a great day out here.

You have to go on a clear day. Great view I were on a sunny day, the only problem was, so did a lot of other people, so if you're going book the ticket over the internet or go on a guided tour, then you don't have to wait in line for about 2 hours, like I did, but you go on a fast track to the sky. But it's still worth the wait, the view is amazing.
Loved it, crazy view. Went up the skytree and could see for what seemed like forever! We were slightly disappointed due to it being a bit foggy, so choose a nice clear day, but definitely worth it!!

Tokyo Skytree a visit worth waiting for!. I went to Tokyo Sky Tree in 2014 and it was a lot of fun. I have been to Tokyo once a year for the last several years and have waited Tokyo Sky Tree being built. I wanted to see what it was going to look like inside once it was finished. It was worth the wait it was a great experience from the elevator showing how fast you are going up to the many views of the Tokyo area and beyond. If you are in the Sumida area of Tokyo it is worth a trip.

Excellent view of Tokyo. I went here with my mom and dad, and at first we were just gonna check it out from the outside but they really wanted to go up the tower. We went around the afternoon and the view was really nice. There wasn't that many people when we came so that's a plus point. My recommendation is that going there at night. They also have a restaurant up there so check it out if you're interested.

Like watching Super HD live but lack the personal touch. It was a one time is enough experience. The view was spacticular but the queue was not. Noting much to do once you finish looking at the view thus for young children it would be a waste to bring them up The Tokyo Metropolitan Building View was as good but with 2 good advantages. 1. Its free. 2. They have guide to take you around. Skytree just leaves you alone and not really know what you are looking for unless you were local and familiar with the city.

lots of fun and fantastic views. we were taken by our guide so had an easy time with queue etc. Loved the view,saw Mt Fuji, gave us a good idea of the extent of Tokyo on our first day of sightseeing. The views and what you are seeing is very well laid out. Lots of shop options and cafes. An intesting look at a Japanese supermarket on the lower floor. Akasura was near by ( we took a cab) and visited the shops and shrine as week on this trip.

Tourist spot, so what?. If you have some time to kill in Tokyo, Tokyo Skytree is a place to visit. It is vast and massive, full of stores and restaurants and massive wave of people. But there's reason why there are so many people, that is abundance of things to do and see. If you are in a hurry, don't bother. But if you have some time in Tokyo, this new tourist attraction is a place to visit.

Breathtaking!. Amazing view of the city's contrasts!It was a beautiful day so I've been able to see Mount Fuji as well from up here!!Everything is organised with the famous Japanese perfection! The lift ride is so fast! Almost unbelievable! A bit shameful all the story during the ride was only in Japanese!Would definitively recommend!!

Not very good view but honest staff. We went to the Tokyo Skytree on a rainy day, so of course the view was not that good. The price was also a little bit on the high side, more than 2000 yen for an adult. However, I think that the staff there are very honest, they don't only want to earn money. When we bought tickets, they told us that the view might not be so good. In overall, I think that I will come here again on a sunny day for a better view.

Great way to see the rest of Tokyo. Pros: The lines went quick and getting up to the first landing is very fast; great views of the rest of the city from there.Cons: It's a bit more expensive $35 US (as of Feb. '15) for two adults; no senior discounts were available for my retiree father (another great spot to view Tokyo from up high is the Tokyo metropolitan government building in Shinjuku; it is free to go up to the observation deck)The Skytree is quite a site-it was only constructed a few years ago (2012) and everything is as you would expect in a new tourist trap. They have tons of shops downstairs before you can even get to the level to purchase tickets. You can pay additional money to get to the higher level. There is also a full restaurant and cafe in the first, lower level area to dine at.You can reach the Skytree by taking the Asakusa (Toei) or the Hanzomon (Metro) line to the Oshiage stop. It brings you out right under the Skytree.

Amazing views over Tokyo and beyond !. The views over Tokyo from the top of Skytree are breathtaking to say the least and it should definitely be on the the top of any visitor's list of places to go to without a doubt.Skytree is located near Ueno, which is another famous and popular place with visitors to Tokyo, with its big beautiful park, its famous temple and it's also where you can take a cruise on the Sumida river from.I did have to wait in quite a long line to buy a ticket, but I think that was mainly due to the fact that it's one of Tokyo's newest tourist attractions and it had been open for just over a coupleof months when I went there,It was certainly well worth the wait when I stepped out of the lift and saw the amazing views,from a couple of different levels. Although I must admit that the layout ( floor plans ) were a bit confusing to begin with and there definintely wasn't enough good, clear signs and floor maps to help visitors where they were and how they could get to where they wanted to go.They say you never really understand or appreciate the actual size and layout of a city if you don't see the city from above and this is 110% true about Tokyo and the "jaw-dropping" views of Tokyo you get from Skytree certainly makes you fully notice and appreciate just what a huge and amazingly vast city Tokyo truly is. Some of my friends have told me that they found it difficult to believe that they were looking down on an actualcity when they were at Skytree, as to them it looked like they were looking down on a huge 3-D model of a city or a huge and vast ant farm. Skytree is definitely worth a visit and it's certainly an experience that you will always remember, but to be honest I don't think that I will go up Skytree again, except when I go there with friends and family, as it's not one of favorite or enjoyable places to go to, to get amazing views of Tokyo from. If you do go to Skytree try to make and take some time to have a look around all the various shops, cafes and restaurants around the base of Skytree and I really recommend that you try the delicious burgers at Kua Aina Bruger restaurant, near KFC, which serve the best burgers in Tokyo.

Fair price for a spectacular view.. If yu have some time to kill in Tokyo this is a fun relaxed option. The entry procedure is well organized and the price is fair for qhat you get in return. An AMAZING view of the city. Recommend to do it after a few days in the city so you can pinpoint previously visited places.

Skytree. you have to wait for a long time in line to get up Skytree, and some of that is outside-but eventually you get up there in a very rapid lift. and when you walk out you can get another lift to go higher but i was freaking out because it moves...but no one else seemed concerned about that, There is a much better view than Tokyo tower,, its so high up..the supports are also really huge and impressive

Bird's eye view of city. Spectacular view of city from top of the tower.Usually crowded, so make sure to visit well in advance or buy tickets in advance.Make sure to visit in the evening before sun sets, so that you can enjoy both the day and night time view.When inside the elevator going to the upper deck, don't forget to see up.Also there's an nice illuminated mirrored space where you can take good pictures.

Tokyo Skytree. It was a bit pricey but on a clear day definitely worth it. If you want to eat in the restaurant then you will need reservations long in advance. Get there early to avoid the long lines.

Breathtaking views and completely worth the wait!. I was lucky and went all the way to the top of the top! It was fun. Try and get a picture standing over the glass on the floor. Makes a huge impact! Leaves you with a professional pic that lasts a lifetime memory!

Awesome nightview. My friends and I visited there at night time. The nightview spread below was awesome. You cannot tell how many lights come into your eyesight. So many of those!! And switving car lights add the beauty. The displays set at the tower are interesting. One of those is a huge touch screen on which you can zoom in/out the Tokyo view of day and night. In addition, there's a glass door where you can look down the ground which is about 350m below. If you are not afraid of height, you can take a photo or a short video of jumping onto the glass floor.

Impressive tower, a potentially long wait to go up. We viaited the Skytree and its surrounding facilities without going up, as the wait was too long for us. The mall inside is pretty nice, so are the eatery facilities. Signs are good and there is an outdoor balcony on 4th floor.
Wow. State of the art and amazing views. We really enjoyed checking out the view of the city and Mount Fuji in the distance. The mall and restaurants on the bottom levels were fun to explore, too.

Nice place to visit. (vsited in early Dec-2014)We had reservation at the Musashi Restaurant at the top of the SkyTree, it provides special entrance lane to lift that lead to the viewing floor where the restaurant is located also. Webpage introduces the menu n guidance to reservation which highly recommended. Time limit applies. The glass bottom part is only for those who are willing to take-buy photo session special. A queueing lane forms closed to where lift for the 2nd stage is. Becareful of which one you are in queue for. There is a small gift shop on the 1st stage floor. Most of the souveniors there are available in shops in Solamachi area also. There is a nice photo (free) corner as you walked the whole round of the floor. Take your time n you'll notice some incredible architecture of bridges n buildings. The view is superb n should be mostly under clear sky during late autumn n winter months. As some others have noted, ticket price is not cheap n if you are not a fan of panaromic view, may be it is better to spend the day at other places that offers real JP culture. The whole area can easily use up your whole day if you allowed the shops, events in the area to capture you.

Skyview. The glimpse of Mt Fuji from 106 km away was the perfect prize for this 3600 yen summit! But the long queue is a debacle. In fact went back the first day. You should book online previously to avoid long lines. 450 meter atop in this modern tower.... quite an experience!

Weekend visit to the tower.. This was a very enjoyable visit, if you plan to go, earliest is the best time. We arrived at 8AM, and were able to go up in the tower very quickly. By the time we left, the line to enter was very long, so arrive early! When you go up, your ticket will get you to the first platform, it is about 500 to 600 yen to go to the very top..but it is worth it. The view is stunning!

Awesome View of Tokyo. Must see attraction in Tokyo, you can find the awesome view of Tokyo City, best time is to visit after 3PM since we need to wait to go up minimum of one hour, we can see with Sunlight, after 6PM it will be lot more spectacular with Lights are turned in the City. but lot of crowds,

High Tower, High Prices. Keep a credit card handy for the city's newest major attraction. Opened in February 2012 to tremendous fanfare and long lines, the 2,080-foot-high Tokyo SkyTree on the northeastern side is the tallest tower in the world and second only to Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates as the world's tallest structure, period. An elevator ride to SkyTree's top observation deck costs $44; discounts are available for younger non-acrophobics.

Spectacular Views. Lucky for me the sky was clear when I went up - 350 meters in less than a minute and then another elevator up another 100 meters to 450 meters. Below you lies this incredible city of 30 million people living in clusters of well designed apartment buildings intersected by ribbons of water and parks. The only mountain not visible at least to me that day was Mount Fuji - which was covered with cloud. The views from here are more substantive than other towers I have visited and the tower experience itself is well laid out and managed. Recommended.
totally worth it. best view of Tokyo youll ever see!! best to go at night though. Watch out for the elevator, goes ridiculously fast (which for the life of me I cant remember now)

Fantastic views. Visited early Sunday morning and the queue for the lift wasn't to bad but was very busy later. It was a clear sunny morning with great views of Tokyo and the mountains and Mount Fuji in the distance.

High as the sky!. I agree with what other have had to say. It is a great experience. We went one day but the line to buy a ticket was long. We were told that ist would be 1.5 hours in the line! Asked if you could book on line for another day - No but is you wnt to the 7Eleven shop on the other side of the road you could get a ticket reservation there. Did this but the machine is Japanese. Through signs and with persistance from the Japanese girl we achieved success. Went back the next day and entered the prioity line to get the ticket with our slip. I would suggest you do this and you can spend more time at the top than in the foyer.

Splendid view but too crowded. I was in tokyo for the very first time. Sky tree was the attraction I been waiting for. If you are architecture freak like me this tower you will not regret to visit. Tho the price is a bit exp for just a view, but I gotta say up there it's really wonderful. Check the weather first before you bought the ticket. You can purchased the tickets in 7-11 or what they called there "ConBiNi". Too crowded especially at the ticket counter. Great elevators with the decoration of different seasons in Japan! Enjoy!

All the lines, lines, LINES!!. 2,000 yen per person and a 5 hour wait. Once we got to the top there were too many people packed in there to even look out the window. Couldn't get out fast enough. The epitome of a tourist trap.
Must see in Tokyo. This one is must visit is its one of the tallest towers in the world and view from highest level is breath taking. Worth every yen and time in line to get in.

Incredible views--for a Price. This all depends on when you go. I strongly advise against going on a weekend. Tourists of all types--locals, Tokyo visitors, and foreigners alike--will be waiting in line to buy a ticket and take the elevator up. When we saw the lines and how slowly they were moving, we took a raincheck. Coming back on a Thursday morning just as the Skytree opened meant we waited only 15 minutes compared to what I can only imagine would have been hours on a Saturday. An incredible view of the city, but the trip up is pricy. If you're on a budget and still want to see the city laid out in front of you, you can skip the upper deck. I didn't notice that much of a difference between the Deck and the Gallery. Keep in mind that the ticket you buy in the lobby doesn't get you to the top.

One of those things tourists just need to do. The Sky Tree is convenient to get to from the subway. There is a charge and a bit of a line depending on what time of the day you go, but it is still very much worth the trip. I would recommend setting your expectation for 1.5 hours of time overall from the point you exit the subway to the the line, ticket purchase, photos you may want to take outside, the ride up, photos from the glass enclosure, finding the glass floor viewing area, restroom and getting back to the subway. If you are easily distracted with shopping malls or don't have a great sense of direction in skyways or escalator areas, make that 2 hours.Winter is a beautiful time to visit. There was an outdoor Bavarian style holiday market outside the day I went. The view from the tower will be dependent on the weather of course, but you can see Mt. Fuji, the busy streets, river and bridges, etc. Americans, this is similar to seeing the Space Needle in Seattle or the Stratosphere in Vegas so when in Tokyo... As with everything in Tokyo, this is also impeccably clean.

Sky Tree Tokyo, Japan WOW!!. A view that can't be compared to anything Ive ever seen! 450 floors above Tokyo, 365 degree view. Clear enough day to see Mt. Fuji-San and a plane flying lower than us. Glass floor to see view below you. Food and drink and of course souvenir shops inside the tower. Before you go in and purchase ticket, get a beer and a snack to eat and check out the view! Make sure everyone is together when purchasing tickets as everyone must be present. You can only buy tickets to half way point and if you want to continue to top, purchase tickets there. Elevators super fast!!! Worlds tallest tower. Lots to see and do here.

Wow!. The tower is beautiful, the lift is so fast, the floor is so high, with optional extra fee to get right to the top, you really can see how busy Japan is and you can see for miles. Expensive, bit worth it. You take a ticket which gives you an hours time to queue which is a fab idea. Whilst waiting there's an indoor market, restaurants etc but needs more as we had to wait two hours for out turn to queue and queues for a further hour to get into the lift. The telly in the queue teaches you japanese and all about the different culture which helps to pass the time.
Worthwhile a visit. Took the advice from another reviewer and went at sunset. Well worth it, beautiful view and no queues.

Great way to see all the precincts of Tokyo. Enjoyable experience and a great way to see the precincts of Tokyo. Went on a Saturday morning about 10am and was not as busy as expected as we were told to arrive early.

Good shopping!. The Skytree is truly the landmark of the Sumida River area. It is great to see it night or day, when jogging along the Sumida River. Other than jogging past it in the day, I have also taken the Tobu metro line to the Skytree for food and shopping. There is a food court, a big supermarket, restaurants and little specialty shops. When bored with Skytree, you can pop over to Solanmachi, another mall which is just next door and linked to the Skytree for more shopping and dining options.

ผิดหวัง. ฉันคาดหวังมากๆที่จะได้เห็นวิวมุมสูงในโตเกียวและภูเขาไฟฟูจิ. เนื่องอากาศไม่เอื้ออำนวย เมฆและหมอกมาก มองลงมาข้างล่างไม่สวยน่าปรถทับใจ งั้นๆไม่เหมือนปารีส และถ้าอย่างขึ้นไปสูงกว่านี้ต้องจ่ายเงินถึง2ครั้ง และพนักงานก็พูดภาษาอังกฤษไม่ได้ ฉันไม่เข้าอะไรทั้งสิ้น. ดีอย่างเดียวคือห้องน้ำ! I was here coz want to see Fuji mountain but very cloudy and not nice view in Tokyo from high, it is soso and must pay extra if want to go highest part and staff cannot speak English just japanese

Pretty Great. It was definitely a great experience, to be at such a height etc. But, it was kind of boring but maybe it was just because I expected more. There was also a bit of a rush so we couldn't really get to see much but, it was pretty good.

An engineering marvel. We visited mid January on a overcast day so vision was a bit limited (chose not to go up to the higher deck because of the weather) We were there at 9.00am on a weekday and it was not crowded at all Gives a great perspective of Tokyo

Wonderful views. Visited on Christmas morning and there was no line-ups and little crowds on the observation decks. Great to visit on a clear day, you might even see Mt Fuji in the distance. The solamachi complex attached was good for lunch and light shopping as well.
Nice view. I suggest you to visit it when sunset. So you can see the light of sunset and then the light of Tokyo in the night.

Fantastic night view!. Morning skyline at Tokyo Metropolitan Government building, Sunset at Tokyo Tower and finally night view at Sky Tree. Each location has their own uniqueness but equally awesome. Just that i find the price a bit steep at Sky tree compare to Tokyo Tower and Metropolitan Government (Free!!)

Great view, long cue, nicely managed. It was a good experience seeing Tokyo from the Top.For those who afraid of the long cue and the crowd, if you want to avoid that, please come early. We were there at the opening time and the cue is not crazy. Everything is professionally organized.Tips! Cafe at the ground floor where the bus stop has very nice breakfast set (500Y for nice coffee, toast salad and egg) so you may wanna come early, have nice breakfast and then go to the ticket booth with less crowd.

Tallest Tower in the World. Just want to say .. this is one of the best landmark created by men ... bit pricey but worth to see and visit ... the elevator is so fast and the view is so fascinating even you can see top of Mount Fuji from the 450 meter stage ... great!

Great views. Definitely worth a visit. We went on a week night and it was not at all busy - some friends went on a weekend and had do to quite a bit of queueing. The night time view was fantastic, but as a previous reviewer suggested, arriving an hour or so before sunset would give you the full experience. The touch screens showing enlargements of the view were great. We paid the extra to go up to the higher level, which was good, but if you are on a budget you could skip that - the view is pretty much the same. Lots of places to buy food in the vicinity. We somehow ended up on a local bus rather than the official Skytree bus, and that was much cheaper (but not a hop-on hop-off deal).

Incredible. I went about an hour before closing and there were no queues. It was dark when I went up but I ready wanted to see the city lit up. The minute I stepped out of the lift and saw the view I was gobsmacked, it was amazing. The facilities were clean and the food and drink in the cafe were reasonably price considering where you are. If I lived in Tokyo I'd probably end up here at least once a month.

One of a kind view of the entire city-Don't miss.. First, I would highly recommend going an hour before sunset so you can see the city in the light and darkness. We went on a tour and the guide planned more than an hour and a half for the Tokyo Skytree which I thought would be too much. It was actually good. I would suggest giving yourself 2 hours to accommodate for lines and all there is to look at in this very large tower. If you go on a tour you don't have to wait in the long ticket line to get in but will have to wait for elevators. You go to the first platform at 350 Meters and can buy a separate ticket for a few dollars to go to the upper platform. There is an area with a glass floor so you can see just how high you are and the view is absolutely incredible. One glass wall all the way around with a full view of the city and water. There are also monitors which show you the area you are looking at and when you touch an area on the screen tell you the name of the building. Want to know if that is your hotel you are looking at? Touch it on the screen and it will tell you. I recommend going up the second elevator to the top. It is the second tallest building in the world where you can do this. Build in 20 minutes or so to go to the shops in the bottom as there are some interesting things. There are also a couple of fast food places. I think this is a must see in Tokyo. Compared to the Tokyo Tower (which looks like the Eiffel Tower but is red) it is higher, there is more to view, more information on what you are viewing, more shops and food. It is a much larger scale than Tokyo Tower if you are comparing the two.
Massive structure. Wonderful tower, but queues are crazy to get in! Lots of shopping around it and close to the Asakusa.

Beautiful View at Night. We did not actually go to the place itself but we were staying in Sumida-ku. We would see the Skytree every night that we went out and it was just beautiful. It definitely decorates the skyline of TOKYO especially when it changes colors. It's a really beautiful view.

Great view in Tokyo. I don't particularly care for how the tower itself looks, but the view of Tokyo on a clear day is great. Very well managed; price was a bit steep but it is a very well managed experience compared to other observation decks. It's also very close to Asakausa and the tourist trap areas!

Early birds save time. This is a must see attraction in Tokyo. We were lucky that we were in line by 9:00 and the queue was no longer than 20 minutes. The view is amazing plus the glass floor area is pretty cool too.

Amazing view. Not for those afraid of heights to say the least, it is one amazing building with a great 360 view of a city that never ends, one side reaches the sea where the other just paves over miles of land as far as you can see its crazy and something you have to see if you like unbelievable scenery!

Amazing view!. If you ever want to get a quick understanding of the size and scope of Tokyo, take a ride to the top of the Skytree! The second-largest structure ever built by man, the view is simply stunning. The elevator ride is smooth, the decor is eclectic and futuristic, and if you go early in the day it is not overly crowded. It is also worth enjoying the high-class restaurant on the mid-level, or the many restaurants and shops in the attached shopping center.

Crowded, but nice views. I went up to the upper tower in the middle of the day and it was a good view. I visited in March, when access to Mt. Fuji is restricted still, and I visited just before the cherry blossoms sprouted, so my view was primarily of city life. It was still very pleasant.The time it takes to exit is kind of long. I think I spotted the Riddler on the way out. It turned out to be a cleaning lady. It's a cool tower, but at the same time, it was among the least memorable moments of my trip.

Worthwhile for the view. The view was lovely...if you're willing to wait and pay. You have to get a timecard for a 30 minute time slot....and they fill up quickly. We got there at noon and couldn't get an earlier time slot than 330pm. Once we had the timecard, we killed time around the area shopping and sight seeing. The shops here are quite nice and on one floor it is a huge cafeteria style area with some amazing foods. I could have spent hours on that floor alone trying all the different Japanese foods, drinks and pastries. Once your time is up, you head to the 4th floor with your time card and wait in a very long line for about 30 minutes to get your tickets to the first level. In my opinion this level is all you really need and you can get better photos from this level as there aren't as many beams in the way. The cost is about $17 USD. If you decide to go the 2nd level it is about another $17 USD This level isn't noticeably different from the 1st level and in my opinion is too crowded and you can't get a good photo anywhere. On the first level there is a Sky Tree cafe. Not many options but the sundae was very unique and I would recommend trying it. It's nice to eat while relaxing and taking in the view.

Worth Visiting. On a glorious bright and sunny day at the end of November, I visited the Tokyo Sky Tree. The views from the first observation deck were incredible and Mount Fuji in the distance looked beautiful with its snow capped peak. I've heard some stories about long queues to get tickets but I can honestly say I was only in a queue for 5 mins or so before reaching the ticket booth and this was 9am on a weekday. The ear popping lift zooms up to the observation deck and what you get is a fantastic 360 degree view of the entire city. I didn't pay the extra to go to the 2nd observation deck which is 100 meters up from the first. I would advise you to do as I did - pick a clear day before you go and visit. There would be nothing worse than going on a cloudy day with your views being obscured. I would definitely recommend going up the tower.

Expensive. Very expensive by its standards, very long queue and one might have to wait for hours to get up. The view from the top is nice and best time to get up is dusk, when you can get a glimpse of both the day and night views.

Get a Fantastic View of the City. We were there on January 1st. The subway from the airport was almost empty at 8am, since it wasn't a work-day. Also, the ticket line was pretty short (10 minutes), and the elevator line was just another 5 minutes.The view from the main level (350 meters up!) was just FANTASTIC. We walked around and enjoyed the view for quite awhile. Just didn't feel like heading back down!!If you're a tourist who doesn't speak Japanese (like us), just be ready to have to hunt around to be sure you're getting in the right line for returning to the ground floor. If you're not careful, you end up in a line to buy a ticket to go to the higher floor, or even in the line for the bathroom :-)

Great views. we only had to wait 50 minutes to get a ticket, worth the wait. You are taken to a lift, and as we were english we're given a leaflet which explained about the lift. which has an interior made up of glass, we were in the fire lift, we watched as it went up in seconds. we walked around the first stop and purchased another ticket to go to the top.It is worth the wait the views are tremendous.

great view of Asakusa area - long lines - long exit that needs improvements. make your way to the new Tokyo Skytree in Asakusa - after a great walk in historic Asakusa - go to Tokyo Skytree at the Oshiage Asakusa station - great view - come here to pick up a schedule time ticket and come back at your scheduled time - expect to wait at least 45 min for entry. once you get pass the lines... expect crowds enjoying the amazing views. pay extra $10 for the higher observation gallery deck. after you are done.. you need to exit.. and the system they had was very poor and need improvement to avoid a fire and crowd control hazard situation. you need to exit via the only 1 escalator and line up in a space that is not enough to hold more than 1 line.. for only 3 elevators. times when people are over top of each other and congested in tight space.overall, it was a good experience and good views.

Worth the queue. Security is shocking for such a busy, prominent building, however that has much to do with the Japanese immigration policy being strict, unlike us in the west whom let in anyone. Too many people allowed up at anyone time so a struggle to get a window space, however when you do it shows how huge and impressive this modern city is from all around.

Beautiful view. Lines are for ever anywhere in Asia. So don't expect this place to be different. This is a must see when in Tokyo and it was a fine day when we went. We got to see Mt Fuji from the tower and the beautiful night lights too. So endure the wait because it is worth it.

Enjoyed the view and experience! . We went on the one rainy day we had in Tokyo. We weren't sure what we would see but decided to give it a shot! The view was spectacular. We went to 450 meters without any wait!! We enjoyed all of the special events for Christmas. Lots of shops to explore as well.

Expensive and a very long wait, but maybe worth it just for the view. Once you get up the elevator, you're going to have to stop to catch your breath. The view is amazing. It truly is. However, when I visited here in February 2014, it took 6 hours from when I arrived to when I was allowed in the queue to buy a ticket!The system is pretty strange. You arrive and are given a ticket with a time and a letter on it. This is your queue ticket and you need it to be able to join the queue to buy your ticket.My slot for the ticket queue was 4 hours from when I was given it, so I explored the rest of the complex. It has an interesting small shopping mall, some exhibitions, and a fantastic Studio Ghibli store.4 hours later, I joined the queue to buy my ticket. An hour later, I was still in the queue.After queuing for an hour and a half, I had my ticket and was waiting in another queue for the elevator.6 hours after I first arrived, I was up at the top of the Skytree! It was amazing! The view was breathtaking.Was it worth the endless queuing? Perhaps, but I'd seen Tokyo from up high before, so after 6 hours of waiting I only spent about 20 minutes on Skytree. I left feeling a little disappointed.
Wow!. I went up just before sun down so I got a day and night view of the city. 450 meter deck is nice for a different view but the extra $ is only worth it if your into heights.

Skytree Tokyo. This is a must for all to see if in the Tokyo area. The view is amazing and also the elevator going up in 50 seconds. The inside of the elevator is decorated with the seasons. The thing to do in advance is get tickets online and go as soon as it opens. The queues are very long to purchase the tickets and to get on the elevator. We got through very fast with our advanced tickets. It gets very crowded, but the people in the observation deck are very courteous and move along. A definite value for the ticket.

A Must. The Sky Tree is a definite must and you should go all the way to the top. We were dizzy for a few hours! How often do you get to go up 450 floors? The pictures are unreal and give the friends who have never been to Tokyo a good idea of just how big and crazy this beautiful city is!!!

Expensive, but great view. I went up to the 350 meter Tembo deck. I had the option to go to the 450 meter deck, but I doubt it would have been worth the extra money. The 360 degree view is great, however I wouldn't put it first on your must see list in Tokyo. I went at night so I didn't have an issue with crazy crowds or lines. The attached shops are pretty good. I recommend the takoyaki (fried balls of octopus) at Gaidaco in the food court for a cheap dinner.

A "must-do" to get a true idea of Tokyo's size. The queues for tickets were long but they kept moving and staff were clearly very organised, doing their best to keep them that way. If you don't want to queue then buy online in advance. I visited both the main deck and the galleria. I didn't mind paying the extra for the galleria as there were a lot less people up there and i was able to spend longer looking out over the city. The views are incredible. Even if you just visit the main observation deck and it's really busy you normally don't have to wait long for someone to move along and give you a change of a great view. The Japanese people are incredibly polite and friendly, making this a much more pleasant experience than similar places in the US or Europe. Would be happy to visit again.

Amazing view and great shops down below.. Pick the Skytree over Tokyo Tower. I love the thrill of heights but Tokyo Tower didn't do it all for me, let alone they charge 1600¥ for their main and "special" deck (understandingly, they have much cheaper options like 900¥ to 150M but this is Tokyo we're talking about, no need to be so cheap). For about 2060¥ at the time I write this to just the 1st observatory, you can see alot more of Tokyo along with some other cool things to check out, like the panoramic Tokyo touchscreen. The panorama will give you facts and details on each part of Tokyo along with a 24 hour fast forward view of the city. There's also interesting facts to read while up there, photo ops, and as you descend the stairs, you can come upon the glass floor where you can see your feet in accordance with the Skytree down below. It's really neat. The Solamachi shops are another thing that I vouch the Skytree over Tokyo Tower. There's all sorts of shops down there along with a slew of restaurants serving ramen, takoyaki, udon, and more. P.S. when going up and down the elevator, be prepared for your ears to "pop." The Skytree is very high up :PTip #2 you can get free wi-fi at Skytree by presenting ID.Tip #3 don't bother paying additional 1000~ ¥ to go to 2nd observatory. It's not really worth it.

Great view, not worth it for 2000¥. Well, tokyo skytree isn't in my plan when i visited Tokyo, but the people's there said if we didn't go to the skytree than we never been to Tokyo. So i use to go there by train and shocked with the queue line for ticket admission for the sky tree entrance. While i waiting to buy the ticket i found that the ticket price is about 2000¥! Well a lil bit expensive for me if we compare with tokyo tower that the ticket price is about 500¥ (cmiiw) then i used the high speed elevator that travel me up til 350 meters. Well the view from this high was great but its not worth for 2000¥.. Sorry tokyo sky tree, but i rather choose to spent my 2000¥ for shopping than get back to this place
Great views of the city - fun shopping/food. enjoyed seeing Skytree, shopping and shops. Fantastic views of the city - especially on a clear day. If in Tokyo, it is a must see.

Landmark..... We had a short time time to see the skytree. We were not able to but tickets for upper viewing since we have limited time for the visit. The tower is so high and this is definitely a landmark when you visit tokyo.
We got good photo shots of the tower from the ground.

Views ok. Lines are a nightmare.. If you like waiting in lines, you will probably like Tokyo Skytree. It cost about 2000 yen which is what we expected in a place like Tokyo. Pretty much we waited in line for about half an hour for a ticket, waited in line to get in the elevator to go up, where we waited in mini lines to get a view out the window. Leaving was a nightmare, where you wait in a chaotic never ending line just to get on an escalator where you then join a another line to get back in the elevator. You then join another line to use more escalators. And it's slow. Really slow. Of our hour and a bit spent at the Skytree, probably 5-10minutes was actually spent looking at the view. All of the rest was spent waiting in lines. This was on a Sunday night in winter so I imagine summer is a nightmare.Yes, the view is really nice and probably worth it as a once off. The speed the elevator travels at is quite impressive. But I would recommend wearing comfortable shoes and maybe not doing it on a day where you have already spent a lot of time on your feet. There are very very few places to sit up there and anyone with weary feet may struggle with all the waiting and standing around. It's also really hot up there, so if going in winter be prepared to carry your layers as you wait around in lines. The view was good, but all the waiting and lack of seating kind of overshadowed the experience for us. Having to wait about 40 minutes just to exit the Skytree was a very frustrating and something we weren't expecting (not to that extent anyways).  A bit of a 'meh' experience.

Maybe once is okay. I went on the weekend and it took one hour in line to buy tickets. I recommend buying tickets online or on week days when there aren't so many people waiting. Weekdays are better anyway. When you get to the top there are some kiosks where you can get food and drinks. It was really expensive and there's seating for about 8 people. Once you buy your drinks or food you can't take the food or drinks out of the eating area. You shouldn't expect being able to take a rest once you get up to the top. There's not very many places to sit down. The view is amazing though. If you go to the first section it's around $20 per person and if you want to go up to the higher part you have to pay $10 more. To me it was too expensive.

Incredible views of a HUGE city. If you want to get the best possible idea of just how massive Tokyo really is then Skytree is a "must-do"! Definitely better if you choose a clear day & don't expect to see Mt Fuji (a security guard told us that only happens a few days per year). Although it costs more the view from the top observation deck is strikingly different to the lower deck so go for it if you can.

Not so impressive. There are so many more interesting things to do in Tokyo. Do it if you have extra time and don't know how to fill it. Otherwise, if you skip it you won't miss much. Yes, you have a panoramic view of the city but that's about it. Better go down, get lost and explore the city itself.

Pretty Expensive but worth it on a good clear day. Plan to get here early or expect to wait. We got here around 2pm and they handed us a ticket to come back between 4-4:30 to get in line to buy the ticket. That was a little unexpected and delayed our itinerary for the day. Then we waited about 30 minutes to buy the ticket but was able to take the elevator up pretty soon after that. It's pretty crowded on the floor that the elevator drops you off at. You can walk around this floor just to enjoy the view. But if you want less crowd and a chance to be by the window, go to the floor below via stairs, and you will find less crowd. There is also a glass floor section that the kids loved.

Recommend to make a reservation for ticket. If you go there without your ticket for observation platform, you have to standing in long line to wait for your turn to get a ticket(especially on weekends and holiday). I strongly recommend to make a reservation of it.On the other hands, there is an beautiful aquarium(Sumida Aquarium) . It's a worth visit.

Great for a bird's eye view of the city. We waited an hour or more to visit the skytree on our first full day in Tokyo and we weren't disappointed. What an absolutely stunning view from the top. I'd recommend going all the way to the 450m observation platform - you could see for miles and miles and miles. We went on a clear sunny day, and I imagine that why the queues were so long. But seeing Fuji poke through the clouds made it all worthwhile.

My favorite!. My most favorite site in Tokyo , Japan. We went the at night so that we can see tokyo at night. Best decision! Not many people around so there's no queue. The guides were very polites, as usual. We even had time for coffee , and chit chat.

Elevate 350 floors in like 50 seconds!. I tried counting and it was barely a minute to elevate up 350 floors ! To make the best worth of your visit to this attraction, choose a CLEAR day to see all the buildings and bridges/rivers, and other key landmarks of course.The highlight for me was the glass floor (available on Tembo Deck), and a few other visitors squirmed when standing over the glass. I on the other hand was busy trying to get a good picture:) Tip: Good idea to arrive say mid-afternoon, and stay over till early evening when it gets dark so that you views in daylight and night... with sunset lighting the best moments seeing silhouette for Mt Fuji and the city skylines.The ticket costs Yen 2,060 for entry only to Tembo Deck, with additional Yen 1,030 if you want to go further up to 450 floors where it is said to have 2 lines of Tembo shuttle elevators with see-through front panel for raising your hair further !Tip : If you plan to visit on a weekend, try online reservation but probably costs more by Yen510, at Yen 2,570 per ticket. The last visit I missed Skytree because the wait time was like 90mins with additional wait time queuing to enter the lifts. Alternatively, visit on a weekday, which for me getting tickets was like 15mins and wait time to go up another 15mins or so.

You need a perfect day to be able to enjoy. Very easy to get to via public transportation. Try to go during the week and hope for nice weather. The signs from the train station are not super clear so you may need to ask. Worth doing once albeit expensive.

pretty expensive but worth it. The ticket price of Tokyo Sky Tree is not cheap, but it's all worth it. Even to pay another 1000 yen to go to the higher level, still worth it. Since the view on a clear day are spectacular
Nice!. You have to pay to go up and you cannot go up on Mondays, but there are lots of shops on ground level and the view from the top is spectacular.

It is an ear popping ride to the top. As the tallest tower in the world a marvel, amazing views and smooth and speedy as in seconds ride up 650 metres. Lots os shops and terrific food court. Close to a lot of other attractions too like Senso Ji.

art galery on the top. It is one of the towers to see Tokyo from the top. Entrance fee was 15 USD. Plus art galery ticket .Free option is : The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (東京都庁舎 Tōkyō-to Chōsha?), also referred to as Tokyo City Hall[who?] or Tochō (都庁?) in Shinjuku. Bring your passport for entrance The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building.

Not to be missed. The worlds highest tower has breath taking views, just make sure you pick a clear day. We could see Mt Fuji clearly and all of the sprawling metropolis. The glass floor was interesting and clearly wasn't for everyone. Queues weren't too bad but you can see that the queues can get quite long. A must in Tokyo.

Impressive. Every Japanese will tell you that Tokyo tower is nicer but but I agree to disagree. It's impressive to look at and you can take a rest and have a good burger at Kua aina if you have been wondering around Asakusa for to long that is. It's just one stop away ... Not worth a full detour but to consider for a selfish selfie.

Disappointing ugly tower. very disappointed. Nothing compared to Tokyo tower. not worth going up. I didn't queue at all. went there on a friday morning about 10+/11 am. luckily. but the building didn't look nice at all.

Excellent 3 hour excursion. We had to go to the tower itself, in the morning, to purchase tickets. I understand that you can either pre-purchase through a travel/tourism office or online but only if you have a Japanese issued credit card. We decided to make this a morning excursion to beat the later-in-the-day lines. We took the metro - stop was Oshiage.Lines were short, all personnel who spoke English were easily identified with a badge, and actually sought us out, to assist. Most excellent service. The elevators were fast and kaleidoscopically fabulous. Our plans were to stay on the 350m deck; not only were we awed by the views (a faint image of Fujiyama included!!), but we found the interactive screens to be highly engrossing. Please spend time in front of these screens, as you will be rewarded with different images of what you see before you - time lapse views, zoomed views, night views. All different aspects.If you plan to go higher, then I suggest that you do so immediately upon arrival at 350m, since the lines to buy tickets for the 100 meters higher deck got longer during our visit. You can always come back down to the lower deck (I was told).You can snack or lunch at a couple of cafes, there is a gift shop and a couple of photo vignettes. In our case, the photos were decorated for Halloween, which the Japanese relished dressing for.

Great Views and Wonderful Architecture. I visited here during a business trip to Tokyo. We had some extra time during the day so we had lunch in the lower shopping mall and then went up the tower. The first level gives a great view of the city, and second level is even better. The observation areas are very spacious and you can see the geometric patterns of the tower construction from anywhere on the deck. The attached picture shows the tubular nature of the deck.

Wonderful views!!. I visited the Skytree at night and it was beautiful! The view was extensive over tokyo, I loved that they took photos of you at various locations but not just on their camera but also your own :DHowever it was very busy on a Friday night! I recommend going a week night to beat the crowds :)

Take advantage of your jet lag, come early. We came here on our second day in Tokyo while we were still recovering from the 9 hour time difference - this meant we didn't have to wait for our ticket at all! It didn't take long before the schoolkid groups started getting in though, so we saw it was a really smart idea. The weather was great so the first view we got after the elevator door opened was Mt Fuji. Everyone in the elevator just went OOOOHHHH in unison, because Fuji is unexpectedly majestic and beautiful. The views of Tokyo are obviously also amazing and I imagine visiting at night is probably also beautiful and atmospheric.

Astonishing views. Obviously, great views from even the first deck (we did not go to the second one as it costs extra). Quite a long line, but it moved quite quickly, and it was definitely worth the wait. I would go there after discovering Tokyo for a bit, because then you have a bit of an idea where everything is.

Amazing Sky Tree Tower. There are several towers in Tokyo. However, I think Tokyo Sky Tree offers more amazing views from the bottom to the top of the tower (e.g., the surrounding parks, shopping malls water fountain etc...). It is recommended to get your ticket a head of the time to avoid standing in the long line especially during the holidays.
Wonderful views. Beautiful views of Tokyo especially at night. Shopping and dining choices, an aquarium and lots of good spots to take pictures. Not to be missed,
overview of Tokyo. When you are at top u can view the overall tokyo and enjoy the panaromic sight. It has fee to enter. You can enjoy picture clicking while at the top of the city

Go in the Morning on weekdays...smaller lines. The Sky Tree is a must if you are visiting Tokyo. We went on a Friday morning at about 11 a.m. and only had to wait in line for about 5 minutes. It was a hazy day when we went but the experience was still excellent. Plan to spend a of couple hours there.

The view here is excellent, especially on a clear day. I visited on a cloudy morning and visibility was limited. However, it didn't detract from the experience of seeing the entirety of Tokyo, especially after seeing it 450m high above ground level. I loved the elevator ride going 600m/min and you can't even feel it rise. The only way you notice is the change in pressure with your ears popping. I wish I can get back here and see Mt. Fuji from there on a clear day.

Amazing Views!. We had planned to go to Skytree before even arriving in Tokyo and had read other reviews etc before our arrival. This really helped us know that it can be really busy so we went there as our first stop of the day and arrived around 0810 (we had woken up early due to jet lag). This was great in that there were no queues and very few people so we were able to walk straight up to the desk to get our tickets and straight onto the elevator. The fact that there weren't many people also made it great when on the observation decks as we didn't have to fight to see the view.Although it isn't very cheap (this was probably the most expensive attraction we visited in Japan) I would definitely recommend paying for the two decks.

Worth a look. We walked from our hotel, about half an hour to the sky tree in the late afternoon, After going to the sumo tournament.The only place , you'll really appreciate the scale of Tokyo and it's size.$75 for 4 of us which wasn't too badNot much other than the view so not much more than an hour to be allocated

Do not miss this view point!. The whole experience is exciting from beginning to end. I arrived at around 5pm and had to wait around 20 minutes in line to get my ticket. The lift up was awesome and the second lift was even better with its top station viewpoint worth the money!

Awesome . We had a great time at the sky tree, even tho we were quite hungover. There were very little queues, we simply walked straight up to the counter. The views were fantastic, and it's impossible to see where Tokyo ends, it simply doesn't, just an endless sprawl of buildings. You can't prepay tickets for the top observation deck (450m) you have to purchase that one the first observation deck. I would recommend this to everyone.

If you don't have Japanese Credit Card expect problems. Without Japanese CC you can not reserve a ticket for the tower. The queues are enormous and the staff are extremely unhelpful. Don't waste your time coming here. It will stay with me a long time how staff here laughed at me when I asked for help, I was left to work out for myself the only way I could reserve tickets as a foreigner was at 7/11. If you're Japanese and come to Australia, don't ask me for help. The answer will be sod off.

Amazing view - worth queuing for ... We read about the long queues at Skytree and decided to get there as early as possible in the morning. We arrived just after 10:00 am and were amazed at the length of the queue which was meandering a long way outside the ticketing area. However, the system was very efficient and it took us about an hour in the queue to purchase our tickets. (Unfortunately we weren't able to advance purchase online as the system would not accept foreign credit cards).We bought our tickets to the 1st observation deck (at 350m height) from the main ticket office on 4th floor of the building. For those interested to get to the next level observation deck (at 450m height), the additional tickets are sold from the ticket office on the 1st deck. It was worth paying the extra and get to the next level.There were a few eating places at both decks - cafes & restaurants. We had lunch in one of the casual café - reasonable price and good quality.The are a lot of other attractions in the lower floors of the large complex - interesting shops, cafes, aquarium, planetarium, and other entertainments. One can quite easily spend a leisurely day here.We were staying at The Asakusa View Hotel over the other side of the river. So it was very easy for us to get to the Skytree. The shuttle bus to the Skytree (costing 220 yen pp) had a bus stop just in front of our hotel. All in all it was a wonderful experience and the queues were not as bad as we first thought. The views were amazing and also interesting. It was a fine and clear day in Tokyo, unfortunately it was not good enough to see Mt Fuji in the distance.

Awesome.. I'd read about the queues and that you can only prepay for tickets online with a Japanese Credit Card. We decided on a Tokyo tour that included Skytree and skipped the lines. We got to the first level (350 mtrs) at dusk and as we left the elevator it was day to our right and night to our left. Amazing crystal-clear views all round including Mt Fuji. Definitely worth spending the extra 1030 yen ($10) to visit the top level because it's not as crowded. We didn't try the cafe because of reports we'd seen and we only bought a couple of overpriced souvenirs.

Expensive View. Reaching this attraction was confusing. We started in Ueno and eventually caught the sky tree shuttle run by Tobu bus - cost is 220 yen/person. Each time you get back onto the shuttle, its another 220 yen no matter how short the drive distance. We got off several times - skytree town, sensouji temple, kappabashi district and then back to Ueno. In Ueno, this shuttle stops outside of the Ueno Park exit of the JR station - when you exit the station,cross the street and walk about 50 feet to your right - there is a shuttle sign. The pay box in the shuttle does give change but its easier if you have the exact amount as you enter. Additionally, not all the drivers speak English. When it reaches skytree town, it stops literally at the door to the attraction. Catch the escalator to the ticket counter; fee was around 2000 yen. We went to the Tembo deck. The day we attended, there were at least 100 students. The attraction has a digital monitor to self read the history of the surrounding area. There's also a gift shop on the deck. The lower levels have more shops and restaurants. While the view is beautiful, I can't say I would give this attraction a score of 5 because I think its an over priced entry fee.

Great View. In most cities I visit I like to find a high vantage point to see what I can of the layout of the city.In Tokyo I was recommended by a Japanese friend to try the Sky Tree, as this is much higher, at 634 metres, than other vantage points such as the Tokyo Tower.The first time I visited was on a weekend, when I found it to be very busy, with queues having an estimated waiting time of over an hour. I decided not to go up the tower on this occasion. However, I returned a few days later, on a Tuesday, and it was much less busy, with no queue to speak of. So my first hint would be to come mid-week, if you can.There are two levels of observation deck and I would recommend paying the extra to go to the highest level (between 500 and 550 metres). It was much less crowded at this level and the views were fantastic. The only drawback on my visit was that there was a bit of a heat haze, which prevented seeing beyond the city boundaries to, for example, Mount Fuji.As with most attractions of this type, there are clear panels in the floor, so you can look straight down, although these were relatively small compared to, say, those in the Willis (formerly Sears) Tower in Chicago, so are not quite as daunting to those with mild vertigo.Overall, I would recommend the Sky Tree to anyone who, like me, likes a good high level, panoramic view.

Fantastic view !. The skytree view was fantastic ! You can view the whole Tokyo in a 360c . The whole structure of the skytree was massive .Love it that they even have a small part that you can look down to the ground level from way up to the top floor of skytree .

Great View. I was skeptical about going to this attraction as it seemed to be to be a typical tourist trap. But once I was able to get on the elevator that took me up 350 meters, I found the view of Tokyo to be breathtaking. What I didnot like was the long wait. You had to get a piece of paper that told you what time you could get in line to purchase your ticket then you had to wait in line for 45 minutes to purchase your ticket. There was a $20 fee to go up to the first stop and then another $10 fee to go up to the top stop. Once you had your ticket then you had to wait in line to get on the elevator. The elevators were very efficient and you did not feel the rapid ascent. Around there SkyTree there are a lot of shops and restaurants. You could spend a whole day here.

Like being in an airplane above Tokyo. Tokyo is massive and several of its neighborhoods are cities in and of themselves. Even the tallest buildings in the city do not provide a complete, 360 view of this sprawling metropolis. The Tokyo Skytree provides exactly that - located just outside the city center, from its decks you are able to see just how vast and developed the city is. It is breathtaking. I can only compare it to being in an airplane just after it takes off - the photos you take from the Skytree will look like airplane photos without the annoying wings in view. It is pricey to get up there but absolutely worth it if you want an unparalleled view of one of the world's most vibrant cities.

Modern skyline of Tokyo. We visited Tokyo Skytree this July. Tokyo has several skyview attractions, and this is the most modern one overlooking the newly developed side of the city. Much larger than the Tokyo Tower, but less appealing. What was good around it was the outside area for food and drinks, and the nextdoor shopping mall. I would recommend visiting the place.

Lovely view of Mount Fuji at sunset!. We didn't know what to expect but were pleasantly surprised at the views over Tokyo from the top of the sky tree. We were lucky as the sky was clear so we were able to see Mount Fuji in the distance and managed to time our visit (unintentionally) at sunset to get pretty spectacular views. It's worth the money if it's a clear day! We didn't realise you could book tickets with an allocated time in advance so would recommend you do this as it meant we had to wait for 90 mins before getting chance to even queue for a ticket! Just in time for sunset though :-)

Just OK. Unfortunately when I went up the sky tree is was an extremely cloudy day so I did not get to see much. However when the sun set and you saw the city at night it looked beautiful. The ice cream there is nice too! :)

On top of the world. Recorded as one of the tallest broadcast towers in the world has attracted a lot of people to come and experience the view from the top.In order to reach the observation decks (Tembo Deck on 350m and Tembo Galleria on 450m), you need to pay appx. 3,000 yen in total. The high-speed elevators will take you there in less than a minute.Like: The view from the top (especially sunset), you can see Mount Fuji and Tokyo Tower from a distanceDislike: Overcrowded and a bit pricey
Tokyo Skytree. Must see in tokyo, good place to spend for an excellent view of Tokyo and a nice mall...good contrast with Asakusa near Sumida river
plan ahead, avoid waiting. The view is, of course massive. Hard to even take it all in. the structure is a marvel of engineering which should be appreciated as much as the view. Avoid windy days!

Visit skytree on a clear day - fantastic sunset. I typically do not like to go up in high towers and look around. especially if there is significant waiting time involved. However, this was an awesome experience: visited in early November and had a 4pm queuing card. By the time we got up to the first deck (350m) the sun was about the go down behind Mount Fuji and it was one of the best sunset I've ever witnessed.The main deck floor tends to get a bit busy, walk down 1 or 2 floors on the stair - there are much less people and effectively you enjoy the same view (and can take much better pictures as you can get closer to the glass. There is a nice bar on the second floor below the first deck - get here on time to have a good seat to enjoy the sunset, while sipping your green tea.I was not in the mood to queue again on the first deck to get up to the second (450m), but have no regrets at all. The perfect view and the sunset made my day...

Amazing Views. This is currently the second tallest structure on the planet, and the views are amazing.We went as part of a "Viator" tour, so we were able to skip the long lines.There is an airport type security check at the tower you must go through prior to entry. The price of the tour covered access to the lower of the two observation decks (350m).For an extra (about) 10 dollars you can access the higher observation deck, and we were glad we did. It takes you up another 100m. There is a gift shop on the lower deck along with a pricey formal restaurant whose menu changes four times a year. If you're thinking about taking pictures be sure to go during the day. Going at night produces poor pictures with interior reflections.I would visit this attraction again were I to return to Tokyo.

..meh. The view from below is fabulous, especially at night. However, ① had to wait to even get in line to purchase tkt (this depends on the day you go it appears) ② it costs 2060yen for the Tembo deck tkt (level1) and 1030yen for the Tembo Galleria tkt (level 2). ③ depending on the weather you can't even see Fujiyama. -To me, this experience wasn't really worth the money. My experience browsing the shops surrounding the tower was actually better.
Nice view.. You can choice 350 meter height or 450 meter. I always prefer to be on the top of ghe building. Anyway, definitely gd when u are at 450 meter height skyscrapper building....

Slightly disappointing. I have to admit I was a bit disappointed by the Tokyo Skytree. OK, so the view is great, but I find the whole thing a bit pricey to be honest (especially since you have to pay a 2nd entrance free to go all the way to the top - a bit cheeky I find). I preferred Tokyo Tower, for example, more easily accessible and cheaper.

Tokyo as far as the eye can see. The Tokyo Skytree serves as a broadcasting, restaurant, and observation tower. When the structure was completed in 2012, it was the tallest structure in Japan at 2080 feet. We went as high as the Tempo deck which is 350 meters high and offers 360 degree view of Tokyo. Sean and I were both impressed with the size of Tokyo. If the day had been clearer we would have paid the extra money to go to the 450 meter deck. For more info check out http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e3064.html
Awesome tower.. Massive tower. Well worth the money to go up and absorb the incredible view of Tokyo. The surrounding view is just amazing.

Worth the visit just to get upto 451m. Top notch, not cheap. But on a clear day - if you pay the extra to go up to 450m viewing platform, the enormity of Tokyo is viewable. So is mt. Fuji, though not clear enough on the occasion we visited.

Great panoramic views!. I arrived here at around 8:30am and the line-up was already quite long, I don't recommend taking the West Entrance as that where everyone flows in from, as I moved up the line, I realized I could've taken the North Entrance (closest to the ticket booth) and would've shaved a good 30mins from the line as people were entering from the North Entrance and put in a separate and shorter queue with was actually less time consuming than redeeming tickets purchased online.Once you purchase the ticket, you go into another line that's about 5-10 minutes long to wait for the elevators. You'll spend about 20 minutes walking and soaking in the scenery, then as you decide you want to go to the upper platform, you'll realized that the line-up is roughly two hours long (a lady walks around advertising the average queue time), so instead you visit the lower floors and take the elevators back down.All in all it was a good experience, it's not overly crowded and moderately priced.

The best city view. Tokyo Sky Tree is the tallest tower and second tallest structure in the world with 634 meters. It is very modern tower view a incredible view. You need to buy a ticket to go to the 1st (350 meters) and 2nd ( 450 meters) observatories. There are a cafe and a very good restaurant - Sky Restaurant 634 - I highly recommend to make a reservation to have dinner or lunch in this restaurant. The food is delicious and the view is amzing. I can't get the dinner reservation so I had lunch in here. Loved it....You can take pictures in the glass bottom window by yourself or have it taken by the Sky Tree personel in a very special spot with a bottom and sky view but you need to pay for this.

Great views of the city. Definitely a good place to visit for amazing views of Tokyo. We took our two children aged 4 and 7 and they were fascinated. It was well worth going to the upper-level too. It was a case of ears popping when the lift went up!We paid to get a photograph which I thought was reasonably priced.We went on a Sunday and it was quite busy but we were able to get good positions and take the pictures we wanted. It is well worth reserving tickets in advance where you will be given as specific time to enter. This cut out the huge queue for tickets. We took a friend who lives in Japan and she booked the ticket for us as I do believe you are unable to use an international address to make the reservation. We were lucky that we had this option although it would have been better if we had made the reservation before leaving the UK.
Very good Experience !!!. Tokyo Sky Tree is an opportunity to see all the Tokyo. Even though there was a big queue the result was excellent. You could see every small detail of Tokyo from so high.

Visit at night . We turned up about 10am on a Sunday morning and there was about a 2.5 hour wait just to line up to get a ticket. Came back later that night the wait was much shorter. Would highly recommend paying the bit extra to go right to the top it was quiter although at night there was more reflection than the lower level making photos difficult.

No queue @ 8.30pm on a Wednesday . We loved our trip up the skytree and were only sorry we couldn't do a day time one too. We had no queues and found the entire experience memorable, informative and very modern. The lifts are decorated by artists, and the interactive tool up top is awesome. We went just before HAlloween and the decorations were fun and we got a great souvenir photo over the glass floor! We didn't go to the higher level due to time restrictions. I only got a brief glimpse on the shopping below - if you go in the day when shops are open my advice is to go here with either empty suitcases or wallets, depending on your budget and intentions!
Great views. Impressive views form the top of here all of tokyo can been seen. The price is high but it is worth the money underneath some great shops and a great foodhall

up above the sky so high!!!. The Tokyo Skytree is absolutely worth a visit. It might seem a bit expensive but its totally worth it. We went to the first level and had a good one round of viewing Tokyo from all angles from up above n the fun part was the picture sessions and the cafe'. As we went beforé the Halloween the whole decor and the feel was different and lovely. Due to the time constrain we couldnt go on the higher deck but definitely had a great time. NOTE - please wear comfortable footwear as its quite a walk.

a bit over priced. I found the price a bit too high. There were no lines when I was there for a night visit, but it was still a bit crowded on the viewing platform. It was only once I tried to leave (which involves goes down 2 levels) that I noticed that these two lower levels had a lot less people on them. So if you paid to go up, and there are too many people try going down a level and hopefully things improve.

Didn't go up, but the shops and view from below was really nice!. I visited Tokyo Skytree on a whim after visiting Asakusa and was pleasantly surprised with the surrounding area. I'm not a big fan of paying money to go up observation towers/skydecks, so I didn't go up. I imagine though, that the view is realy nice and while most tourists can't buy their ticket online (need a Japanese credit card), the line is not long to wait at night. (around 20 minute wait on a Saturday evening)The Skytree complex has a lot of many cool shops and a massive food hall below. Definitely take the time to browse. My favourite shop was the Calbee shop were you can order hot Calbee items, including a potato churro for 200yen!Definitely worth browsing through after your Skytree experience!

Must See in Tokyo. The Tokyo Skytree is a must see while in Tokyo, but make sure you allow enough time. We went on a Saturday and it took over 1.5 hours just to get that tickets. Once at the top the crowds were crazy, but once you get some free window space the views are amazing.

What a View!. We had heard all about Tokyo Skytree from many sites and from friends who had visited saying it was a good place to go. The views of Tokyo are absolutely fantastic! There are 2 different levels you can visit. The first level is at 350m high, and you can only pay to go up to the first level from the lobby. We didn't have to wait long to purchase tickets, but we came during the week when they weren't quite busy. We were told you want to try and purchase tickets online normally as you won't have to wait as long and typically it can get very busy. You go up to the first level and there is glass all around with spectacular views of the city, and interactive touch-screen picture displays that tell you what you are looking at when looking out the windows. When up in the 350m level, you can opt to purchase tickets to go up further to the 450m level with even more spectacular views! This is one of the tallest towers in the world, and if you aren't too afraid of heights, hey this is definitely worth a visit at least once in your lifetime if you are in Tokyo. The visit can sometimes last a few hours, and there are many restaurants and shops in a multi-level mall adjacent to the skytree that you about have to pass through to get there, especially if you are coming by subway as it goes directly there. If you think you are going to get hungry during the visit recommend eating before as there aren't really many food options at all inside, with the exception of a couple of high end restaurants (typically need reservations). The shops and restaurants before you enter the skytree in the mall are understandably a bit more expensive than outside the area, but there is a wide variety of foods and even another section of restaurants about 40 stories up or so that you can eat at with incredible views as you dine as well! Prepare to be there about half a day at least for travel, the skytree and if you want to go through the mall area. If you get the chance, go!

Great view even on cloudy day. One of Tokyo new super attractions... worth visiting even on cloudy day... we went only to first observation deck on 350m... and it was amazing even we were in clouds part of the time... it is a bit pricey especially if you like to visit both decks but still I think it is worth visiting... anyway whole complex of buildings is city within the city so there is enough fun for the whole day - tower, aquarium, planetarium, shopping mall, restaurants... oh yes and Ghibli Studio's shop too :)

Well worth it on a good day but... Don't bother going to the highest point..not worth another 1000YEN. Other than that it is an amazing view and especially lovely if you stop for food with a view but be warned its a very limited and overpriced menu in the cafe. Ordered the 'beef curry' which had one piece of beef no bigger than my thumbnail in it. The restaurant has a set menu which is about 5000YEN.
Outstanding Monument. Located in Tokyo and One of the tallest building in the world.The top view is fantastic and there's food galore.Always crowded.
Nice location. Skytree,Sola-machi ,Aquarium and Planetarium...That is a very fun place.Both kids and adults can enjoy this place.
Great View. Great view, This city is really an amazing city. Great mall also connected to the sky tree. I recommend spending half a day here.

Amazing view!! This city is so big.. You can really see all of Tokyo when your in the sky tree. Really amazing view and very very tall. It went on the week day so it wasnt so busy. The area also has a nice shopping center. Great place to spend half a day.

Worth the visit - Amazing view of Tokyo. Fantastic view 350m high - even better at 450m. You can only purchase the ticket to go up to the extra level once you are at 350m. We weren't going to go further up but decided it was something worth doing once. You would not be disappointed! We went first thing in the morning and to our surprise there were no queues.

Highest Tower in Japan. Arrived on an evening to this wonderful tower building with a fantastic observation deck. You can go to the observation deck to view Tokyo by night. Up the tower you can see the actual view which at that time was not so foggy, so visibility was great. There is also a photo screen of every section, where you can electronically zoom in to see actual photo of the street. There is also a mall with stores leading to this commercial tower. As compare to the Tokyo tower, the Tokyo tower was a landmark ahead of its time, but has no commercial space available like the Skt tree. Sky tree is also much bigger.
SkyTree and Sola-machi. Very much worth a visit. Huge HUGE crowd though; better to purchase advance tickets to save waiting time. There's a nice Halloween theme going on right now.

Amazing views and so much to do. You will come here for the views but there is so much more on offer. Eat, drink and make sure to visit the aquarium! As with the rest of Japan, staff will be impeccably mannered and I spent a whole day here before going shopping for kitchenware nearby. Amazing.
