Excellent view of Tokyo. If the sky the clear you can see Mt. Fuji from the tower during the day. Aside from that you can the entire Tokyo metropolis from the top. The only downside is the line. Took us around 30-40 minutes to purchase ticket. The mall below is also superb, lots of shops and restaurants. Make sure to drop by Food hall, there's a lot of free samples of Japanese Sweets and goodies!

Check the weather. The line was long (45 minute wait) and it was hazy with only about 5 mile visibility. It is expensive (about 4000 yen/person) so check the map with a forecast of the view. We decided it was not worth the wait to only see the western part of Tokyo. The mall beside the SkyTree is very nice. They had an official Yomuri Giants shop and a lot of great places to eat.

neat to visit. lots and lots of stores just to get to the tower. no bad on the price. the sights on top were great - reminds us of Shanghai tower and Taipei 101. crowded but the Japanese people are very polite and helpful

Fantastic View of Tokyo. Considering it is in Tokyo, this isn't badly priced for what you get (around £20 for an adult ticket). We went in the evening and had a beautiful view over the neon glow that is Tokyo. The atmosphere is very good, and it didn't seem to be too busy.

Great views, but with long lines. The visit was great! However, there was a long line to buy tickets and before getting in to the elevators... also, you need to get to another line if you would like to go to the highest floor... View was gorgeous, but not as nice as City View!

Nice View scary glass floor. We went on a beautiful day that left us with an amazing view. You can see all of tokyo and get an amazing shot of mount fuji.The glasd floor that you can walk on is also very nerve racking even for those not afraid of heights. A must see if in Tokyo.Also on the lot is a beautiful aquarium.

Nice Tower!. We went to the skytree on a nice sunny day. I enjoyed walking from Asakusa over the Sumida river to get there, since you have some nice photo opportunities at the river bank. Also standing very close to the tower was very impressive when you look up and this massive tower is in front of you. We went on a weekday at around 15:00 into the queue and we were at the 350m observatory at around 15:45, we went around a couple of rounds and took a lot of pictures and decided at around 16:30 to go to the top (which you have to pay additionally in the middle station). We decided there then, since we had a nice viewing spot onto downtown that we should stay and watch the sunset, which was really impressive, since you can see all the lights go on at night. I enjoyed the trip up to the top, but a) it was very crowded and it was sometimes very stressful to maintain a nice viewing spot and to enjoy the view, b) they dont sell beer before 19:00. I just wanted to sit on a chair, drink a beer and enjoy the view - next time I will have to bring my own, and c) the tower is a little bit too far away from the downtown area, it would have been more interesting to see the building from closer - but otherwise it is really impressive!
Superb view. best place to see all of Tokyo. easily accessible. Do try the glass floor & higher levelsfantastic view!

Amazing view. Luckily we had beautiful clear weather the day we went here. We made reservations two months in advance thus did not wait on any lines. It is good that they control the number of people going to the observation floor. The view is probably more interesting to the locals because can relate to the streets, landmarks, buildings. However, being able to see Mt. Fuji is awesome for anyone. The view of Tokyo and its surrounding areas is impressive. If you are a first time visitor to Tokyo, this place is a good place to start or finish. For additional fee, you can go to a higher level. We didn't because the view is probably the same; the only difference is the distance of objects making everything smaller and more difficult to discern. At the bottom of the tower are shops. The first several levels are restaurants and more shops. However,these areas can get very crowded. We took a taxi here, but I believe you can use one of the subway lines. Afterwards, we walked for about fifteen minutes to Asakusa temple area.

anime maniacs, your home right hereee. i'm not a fan of anime and japanese cartoons myself, but for those who are, this is the place! They have japanese cartoon merchandise, Doremon biscuits , Shin Chan cookies and more! But lovely view of the tokyo sky tree, a photo with the sky tree itself is a must!!

Tokyo from above.... For ¥2060 you get to go up this tower and enjoy 360 view of tokyo. For another ¥1030, see all of tokyo at 450m...not bad. it was cloudy when we went up this tower, they say on a clear day, you can see mt. Fuji from afar. FYI, this is the tallest observatory tower in the world.
Great view of Tokyo. . The observation deck has a great view of Tokyo. It might be a long wait but the shops and aquarium will keep you busy.

Great view but a long wait. We got to the tower around 1400, and it was very crowded. The what to go up was about 3.5 hours. We decided to walk around the area and visited the aquarium and shopping area. When we got to the tower it was sunset and almost night. The view was amazing. We have never been to Tokyo and this view was amazing. Probably better to visit at night. We were able to view the fireworks from Tokyo Disney as well.

Had a lovely time at Tokyo Skytree!. Definitely plan and visit the sky tree during lunch/sunset, I can’t adequately describe the beauty and ambiance of this place, its calm, fun loving and peaceful ( even though its crowded)! I went up the sky tree after it was dark and Tokyo lit up like a Christmas tree and boy what an amazing sight from above, be warned though you will be waiting in a queue but since its time managed into groups the wait was not that bad probably thirty to forty minutes at most. There are plenty of shopping/dining options both inside and outside the mall/around the Tree, was surprised that there was a Studio Ghibli Shop just at the foot of the sky tree big surprise and bought a ton of stuff!Tickets cost around Y2060 which is pricey but worthy of a view of Tokyo at night! You’ll be wasting money if you elect to go further up to the second observation deck ( an extra 1000 yen) as the views are essentially the same . Loved Tokyo Sky Tree and everything around it would highly recommend!
Timing is everything. Go around 2pm to be upstairs by sunset, or go after the rush around 6pm and avoid the queues. Trust me, the lines can be excruciating.

Awesome Perspective of All of Tokyo. Queued for about 45 minutes before ascending to the first level at about 350 meters. The elevator is so smooth and their is hardly a sensation of upward movement (50 seconds to the first level). The views from the first level are sensational, even although I felt rather dizzied by the altitude (I stayed well clear of the glass!). The sheer scale of Tokyo is revealed and Mount Fuji was easily discernible even although it was slightly hazy in the distance - must be brilliant on a clear day. We than paid the extra fee to ascend to the very top viewing level (forgot how high....but it was high). Again the elevator is smooth with little sensation of movement. The views are even more spectacular and I felt even more dizzied as I made my way around the wraparound tube that winds upwards and around the tower from the elevator.....walking (more like hugging) the inner wall for security, Despite my unease with heights....I'd done the Tokyo Sky Tree. I enquired about eating in the 64 Restaurant but it was fully-booked all day...but that was my excuse to descend to terra firm.

Beautiful Place. Every city I visit I love to visit observation decks at evening time or night. I love to see to see the sunset and the drowsy city awaken for nightlife. This is a great place to view the city.

Initially underwhelmed but then the sun set!. This was part of our Grey Line tour stop, initially I was under whelmed as I didn't recognise any particular sights as Mount Fuji was obscured by clouds but then the sun set and the sky changed to the most glorious red. Go down one floor from the main gallery for more space to take photos and away from the crowds

closed. Unfortunately the skytree was closed due to typhoon (they shut down the lifts because of the wind) but still the skytree is an impressive sight (from the downstairs terrace) and there is lots of shopping and some restaurants.

Great views. The worlds highest communication tower was awesome, we watched the lights coming on from 5pm to get even greater pictures & that was really good, the sorakara point with the lights is a great photo opportunity, the interactive street made are really good.The glass floor is also another good feature. Great value for money.
Shopping, View and Totoro shop. great shops a very fast lift to the top with a great view, but the highlight for us was the shop selling Totoro, Ponyo and other Japanese movie memorabilia.

Admire Tokyo from the sky. highest tower in Japan and one of the tallest in the world, the skytree is a nice place to visit to enjoy the view of Tokyo. It tends to be popular so it's likely you'll get to queue for a while, but it's impressive once you reach the observation deck - 350 mt high.

Overlooking a fab city. The tower is impressive.If you're not afraid of heights, get to the top plateform.The lifts are just excellent and the views from up there are great. Especially at night as you get to fall in love all over again with Tokyo

Tokyo Skytree worth a visit. We went to Tokyo Skytree on Tuesday 30 September around 2.30pm, caught the subway to Oshiage. Spectacular building from below, did not take long to enter, the lift (elevator) appeared not to move but in less than a minute we were at the first level. Unfortunately there was a lot of haze between the buildings which made the skyscrapers look eerie. We did not go to the next level, but it would look fantastic on clearer day. Reasonably priced. There is a glass floor that is worth walking on and watching the reaction of other people. After the Skytree, Asakusa Senso-ji temple and market area is worth a visit. There is a nice tonkatsu takeaway shop to the left of the markets. Also think about catching the ferry from Asakusa to Hirode or Obaiba, if possible.

Beautiful view, done Japanese style (which is a really good thing)!. For Ll of the large towers and skyscrapers I have visited this was my favorite layout. The moving cartoon city boards that line the walls before you even get to the ticket area were amazing by themselves, but the whole way the queue, elevator, floors, etc were organized/decorated were beautifully done. The view can be blocked a bit if it is a cloudy or particularly smoggy day, so we were not able to see Mt. Fuji, however the view we did see was gorgeous. I would say this is worth the money to go and see. Partake in the fun tourist pictures too, the photographers/attendants had great energy and allowed us to be silly Americans in our pictures. :)

New landmark of Tokyo. Take the subway to Asakusa, you can visit Senso-ji Temple before visiting Skytree. You can take Skytree picture with Asahi logo from the bridge, take the cruise along the Sumida River and enjoy the scenery.I found there are some western fastfood (KFC, Burger King, McD) in this area. Some eateries price are cheaper compared to other areas.

Overpriced !. When visiting the skytree make sure the visability is good and the sky is clear with no cloud covering. I arrived before 8am on a Monday morning and I waited only 10 minutes to enter. I paid additional to visit the higher deck and it was not worth it,the view was pretty much the same,however overall it was a good view,but my recommendation is Tokyo tower which is less expensive and offers a different viewing angle in a different location giving you a better vantage point and the nighttime view is awesome !

A marvel of modern engineering in hi tech Japan.. The Tokyo Skytree located in north eastern Tokyo is one of the world's engineering marvels. The tower stands at 634 metres and showcases the talents of the Japanese nation. The tower was built as a communication transmitter for the people of Tokyo. It is also a tourist attraction that is a must see when visiting Tokyo. The tower and its shopping and food complex is very easy to get to being about fifteen minutes from GInza. There is a need to get on to the Z line to get to Oshiage station. There is a charge to get to the lower tower observatory at 350 in height and a further charge to travel a further 100 metres higher. The views from the tower is unbeatable and on a clear day (a rarity in Tokyo unfortunately) Mt Fuji can be seen. There are souvenir shops located up on the observation deck as well as at level 5. Must see in Tokyo.

Be prepared for a long wait. There is no doubt that from below the Skytree is impressive, but if you go up on a hazy day then it is probably not worth the long wait. I went on a Tuesday, a supposedly quiet day. But the wait to buy tickets was 45 minutes, then a further 30 minute wait to catch the lift and once up there a long wait to get the lift down. No doubt that on a clear day the wait could be worth it.

Definitely worth going. We went to Tokyo Skytree based on recommendations. We weren't really sure what to expect and the queues. We arrived at around 11am and was given directions and maps in English. The queue was slightly long but took no more than 20 minutes to get tickets. Japanese efficient made sure that ticket lines were quick and people were ushered into the elevators up to the viewing deck. It was really a great way to get our orientation of Tokyo and to see how vast the city is- on a clear day visitors can see Mt Fuji but unfortunately this was not our day. We paid the extra to get up to Tembo Galleria at 450m which is the highest point visitors can get to. It was definitely worth paying the extra and we had a really lovely time. We sat at the cafe to have a quick break to plan our our next stop in Tokyo. One of the cafe staff noticed this and came over to ask if we needed help..amazing staff and so friendly. Definitely worth visit for any first timers in Japan!

Nice trip, go early to avoid the queues. The first day I went, I got there about 11.30 and the queues were really long. It's frustrating that as a tourist, you cannot book tickets online as you need to pay with a japanese credit card - how daft is that? I went back another day and arrived about 9.30. I only had to queue for about 10 minutes to get to the front desk. The views were pretty although if you do go early, it can be a little hazy. I always like buildings with views so it was fine. You can go for a free view of Tokyo from the Metropolitan Building which is a bit more central, but the Skytree is still worth a trip. There is a large shopping mall with lots of food stalls as well. i sat outside after my trip in the sun with a bento box and an ice cream.
Worth to go.. Tokyo Skytree is beautiful. Many restaurants and shops inside the shopping mall.

Great Mall, lots of food and shopping!. We stayed in an apartment next to the mall for a week and only manage to explore the mall at the end of our trip. Regret it, should have done so much early! The shopping is great, lots of shops and restaurants. Food hall is very good too. The famous souvenir snack shop in Ueno is also there, but I think the price slightly higher than the original shop. We did not pay to go up the tower but it's good enough. There is good photo taking spots across the river next to it to capture the entire tower. It was beautiful at night.

Fantastic view of Tokyo. Nice views in all directions. Glass windows angled so as to minimise reflections.
Very popular attraction. I waited about 35 mins to purchase a day ticket, but I understand this could have been MUCH longer on a busier day!
Easy to get to and well worth visiting - if you go on a "clear" day! :-)

Spectacular. Very well organized. Great views although we did not get to the highest floor because there was no point as the furthest visible point was seen from the 350m floor due to the summer haze.
Try going in the late afternoon.

Very Impressive. We visited Tokyo Sky Tree a few hours after we arrived in Tokyo so naturally we were blown away. There were no queue's what so ever and the staff were ever so friendly and helpful. Unlike other observation decks, its very dark at the top and you can take really good pictures because there's no glare from the windows. Only down side is there was no option to book online and we would have preferred to have reassurance that we could definitely visit rather than just turning up and hoping for the best.

Go at night. I've been to the Tree in the daytime and it's great but, at night it's magical. Tokyo is so very, very big and at night you can get a feel for the scale. It just goes on and on. We went on a Wednesday evening and it was not busy. No wait at all. As a result, the top was not crowded. It's worth paying the extra for the second stage +100m on the first. Try the vinegar drinks too. Weird but pleasant and they fix the moment in an odd way. The staff rattle off in Japanese and one even did her thing in English, but so quick and high pitched that we could not understand her. Sweet though. Afterwards, we found a great local sushi place on a side street. Worth getting off the main drag.

Good view. Another tower in another city.I was fortunate enough to avoid the hour long queues this place is famous for, and was upwards bound within 15 min of arriving.Yet still, even with good weather and reasonable visibilty the view really just repeats itself in a 360 vista. The buildings begin to merge in to one another and there are a few great camera shots but as far as entertainment goes it provides a coffee shop with a great view that requires some jostling to get around.Probably a nice filler if you're in the area, otherwise the Aquarium below has a lot to offer.
Tokyo Sky Tree East Tower. This is a good place only if you want to see the Tokyo from top and also it if for free. Otherwise there is not any other good things about this place.

Expensive but breathtaking view and fun ride. Very expensive to travel first to level 345 with the gift shop and restaurant including walking around with the views. There are also glass floor views and touristy-photos by vendors available. You are not allowed more than one trip up or down if you leave. You then must purchase a second ticket if you wish to visit the highest level, some 645 meters/levels high and worth every yen! The cost for an adult could run over $30 but it is still worth it because of the views and the exciting ride up. You can step back in the elevator/lift and look at the track as you go up for a real thrill. Probably the highest observation tower with the best view in Tokyo. There are gift shops also at the bottom level, and items throughout the shops in the walkways below if you want souvenirs, including 3D postcards. The items are quite expensive and typical souvenir items. You can take great photos of the Skytree from the base, and there is a restaurant outside that appears to have cook-yourself grills and champagne. It is important to know that you could obtain an advance ticket if you have a Japan-based credit card, or tickets from a hotel or agency BUT you may buy tickets at the site. Again, the tickets like the Empire State building in New York, require purchase to the first level where the lift/elevator stops, and then from there up to the highest level which did weed out a lot of the visitors. There were loos/toilets on the first level and they appeared to only be for physically-challenged people or parents with babies, but the guards allowed all visitors to line up and to use them.

A Must See!. You can spend days in this place and still not see everything. Tons of stores and places to eat down below. Along with shopping and even an aquarium. The elevator ride up the tower was epic. Don't leave Tokyo without stopping by.
Best at night. This is one of the best place to visit in Tokyo at night especially. The panaromic view of the beautiful city is jyst amazing from the height of 350m

Amazing Must See in Tokyo. While visiting the Tokyo Disney Resort, my wife and I took a day with friends to visit the skytree. It has its own mall with shops and resturants to keep everyone happy. Got there about 4pm and line was about an hour. Line moves quick and is inside with air conditioning (something you don't find used a lot in Japan much anymore after the earthquake of 2011) First observation deck at 350m is wonderful. Breathtaking after the 50 second elevator ride at 600m per minute. Spent some time here and knew we had to go higher. Went up to 450m and WOW just so amazing. Great photo op up top for only 1,300 yen. Some have said it is expensive. At $30 USD per person to go to the top observation deck, I think this is a great investment. I agree with others that day and night are different experiences. We were lucky enough to accidentally be there for sunset and experience both. We spent 2 hours without really noticing. Must do while in Tokyo! Also, if you are planning to do Disney, there is a shuttle from Sky tree direct to Tokyo Disney Resort. We took train all around Tokyo during the day, but this shuttle might go to skytree from Disney, not sure. Shuttle was 720 yen. Hope this information is helpful. We had friends that are locals with us that made it very easy and I thought I would try and share the information.

Beyond a Tourist Trap. For such a new attraction, SkyTree was not the tourist trap I feared it to be. When you arrive, you can get a slip of paper telling you what time to start getting in line It works sort of like the FastPass system at the Disney parks, so you shouldn’t need to stand in queue more than a half-hour before buying your tickets. In the meantime, you can spend time in the shopping mall directly beneath the tower. The mall is vast, covers multiple floors, and should have something to capture everyone’s interest.As for the tower itself, it does get crowded at times, especially when everyone’s at the window trying to take pictures, but the traffic moves along nicely. If it’s too crowded, the main viewing deck offers several touch-screen panels. I went in the evening; visibility was limited by the darkness, but Tokyo is a magnificent city when lit up. In fact, I would recommend visiting Tokyo SkyTree twice: once during the day, and once at night, because both times present their own special experiences.

Best from Afar. Warning: take all your pictures from afar, when you come near it it's practiacally impossible to fit it into your camera. Unless you're a pro or something. Also, go at night if possible, that's when you see the true beauty of Tokyo! :D

A must go place. A must go place, it's really nice seeing such a great night view at such a high place, 350m is good enough, no need to pay another 1000 yen to go to 450m, don't really think there will be too many differences. Lots of worth seeing shops and restaurants and there was never enough time for them, but always good for those who loves shopping. Again, a must go place but once is enough, I would rather visit other places next time when I go to Tokyo, as the ticket is kind of expensive.

Breathtaking panoramic view but ticket fee so dear.. This stunning observation tower is undoubtedly one of the top attractions of the city. I'm sure all over Tokyo there are many other scenic views but this is the best. In my life I have visited the tallest skyscrapers in the world and lookout towers as well but the cost of a single ticket is way too expensive. Obviously, the service offered to customers is outstanding, a very fast elevator leads up to the top of the tower to the top floor in a matter of seconds, an innovative design and futuristic. For visitors there are available 2 floors, from which the view of the city is fantastic. Obviously it's all covered and surrounded by thick glass windows which are slightly inclined to allow the visitor take perfect photos without the reflection of the glass. Panoramic 360 in this large penthouse 300 meters above the ground. Expensive but unique experience.
Excellent advneture. we all enjoyed the Skytree, great view amazing technology and just a great way to see the city. It didn't hurt to have our own guides, thank you Mooneyes for that.

Great panoramic view.... The entrance to reach the Tokyo Sky Tree tower in the east it is still easily identifiable and well signposted. I admit to being increased in many lookout towers but this is definitely one of the most expensive. Reach the top of the tower was easy via a lift ultra modern, arrived at the top of a terrace fully protected by a thick glass turns around 360 degrees, the view is certainly exceptional, but I believe is unmatched, Tokyo from that height is magnificent. My advice is to take advantage of the sunset to admire both the light and the colors of the night (maybe a lot nicer).Too bad the price of the ticket is too expensive.

Okay, but couldn't go up!. I went to the Skytree on a windy day and unfortunately wasn't able to go up to the top. Even at the bottom though, you still had an okay view of the tower and the city. There were lots of restaurants inside the base which was good and there were some souvenir shops as well, however they were a bit more pricey than other places since it is a tourist attraction. Definitely make sure you go on a clear day so you don't miss out on the observation deck!
great views. Great view over Tokyo. Best to go early (before 10am) to avoid big queues as Japanese don't seem to be getting up early. Or book online.
Amazing view. The view of Tokyo SkyTree from afar always amazing but the view from in front of your eyes much much more amazing!
just a few great photos. it was good just for a few nice photos. beautiful view of tokyo. if you are looking for a great place to just hang out, this might be an ok choice

You are up in the sky, but it takes forever to get there!. Such a cool tower, topping 634 meters, musashi, and what amazing views can be seen, even Mount Fuji on the cleaner days. Highly recommended, but the word of caution is get your tickets in advance or you will be in a line that goes forever...

Best place to visit, don't miss it. Was a 45 minute line to get in but worth it. Amazing views of Tokyo that will always be with me. Tokyo from the sky is like a painting, the streets, roads, homes, roofs are so pristine it looks like a model. Then there is a great mall next store you can grab food and relax. Across the river are many places to see.
Abit pricey. Long lines most of the day probably avoid on weekends and during summer views arent great due to smog an haze

Nice view but Too Busy. After waiting almost an hour in the long queue with screaming kids everywhere, we proceeded to a crowded lift to venture to the observation deck to endure more crowds. Whilst the view is pleasant enough, I much preferred the Tokyo Tower or return at a quieter time as popularity diminishes & out of the school holiday period.

Great panoramic view. You can see how Tokyo huge!!! Take a good photos of all city! in a bright day you can see more than just a Tokyo city. But take a time, in a peak season you can wait in a line for tickets about a hour, but it worth it!

Average, but go to the Tokyo Government Metropolitan Building instead for great views.. It's a fantastic building with loads of great places to eat and lot's of things to do. This review is with regards to the observation deck: It's good, but....It's expensive comparatively to other attractions in Tokyo - Y2500.It's slightly out of town, so the view is more an observation of the city, rather than from within it (like you experience if you go to Empire State). You see a lot of buildings and lights off in the distance, but there aren't really any particularly amazing sights to see from this point. It's crowded and the cue takes ages (or this was the case when I visited in August). Instead, go to the observation deck in the Tokyo Government Metropolitan Buildings. Open until 10pm. Free entry. Fantastic views from the middle of the most happening part of town. Plus, there's no cue.

Magnificent Musashi !. This was my first time visit to Tokyo Sky Tree. I was very amazed at the time I entered the lobby, watching the animation on the wall. Buying the tickets was easy, despite the long queu. Going up to the observatory decak, there was a interactive display that showed us the 360 degree scenery. We can take pictures at the glass floor with your own camera or just simply buy a framed photo from the Sky Tree Shop. Shopping at the Shop was enjoyable, that you can buy anykind of snacks, sweets, stationaries, with of course packed with their characters. If you are hungry, just go to the food-court where there were various foods stall. At the basement level, you can find Tsukiji Fish Market's stalls and many sweets stalls. It was really an interesting and magnificent Musashi !

Great but be prepared for a long wait!. I arrived at 12pm on a weekday in July. Big mistake. Had to wait over an hour to get to the lift. But it was worth the wait. The staff are helpful and the view is amazing. Definitely a must do for visitors to Tokyo. Not expensive either really.

Clouds and queues!. The view from the top is stunning and it was a shame we picked a day when it clouded over by the time we went up. We arrived at 12 and got a ticket but for 3:30pm. We then queued for over an hr to buy a ticket and spent another hour queuing in the lift and around the viewing stations. Overall it was very expensive and just a day of queuing. If it had been a clear day it may have been worth it!

What a view!. This was on my top ten list of things to do during our stay in Tokyo. We went on a Saturday and were aware that the lines may be long. Not to worry, though. The line was long (we waited about 45 minutes), but extremely organized and quiet. The staff are uber-polite and very professional. We rode the elevator up and it was so fast that our ears popped. We then took a second elevator to the very top of the Sky Tree . . . what a magnificent view. It was just a phenomenal view of the entire area. Tokyo is chock-full of temples/shrines in the middle of the city/residential areas, and you can see them all from this vantage point. The glass floor gave me pause, but I took one for the team and stepped on . . . and off very quickly.Definitely worth a visit.

You have to experience this tower!. To get from the lobby to the first stage takes less than a minute and you are able to see views from all directions; you take a second elevator to the top. You can have your photo taken by a professional photographer while standing on one of the Lucite platforms that forms part of the flooring; it gives you a strange feeling standing on something so clear with almost a 2,000 feet drop beneath you. Lines can be long, so be patient! The experience is well-worth it. The tower dominates the skyline and dwarfs the skyscrapers surrounding it. It is lit at night and changes different colors. We saw at least three different variations while in Tokyo.

Incredible Night View of Tokyo. We always wanted to visit this new, tallest landmark since it opened in 2012. We also learned that it was so crowded that we might need to wait for hours to buy tickets. The main purpose for this new tower is to replace the Tokyo Tower for television and radio broadcast due to the high-rise buildings preventing the Tokyo Tower from providing complete digital television broadcasting coverage. Tokyo Skytree was built based on a fusion of traditional Japanese beauty and neo-futuristic design. The color of the tower is a special “Skytree White"; it is a color based on "aijiro", the lightest shade of Japanese traditional indigo blue. The height of the Skytree is 634 m (2,080 ft) and is the tallest, free-standing broadcasting tower in the world. The sound of the number "634" in old Japanese is "mu-sa-shi" which is a reference to the Musashi Province that once covered a large area, including Tokyo, Saitama, and a part of the Kanagawa Prefecture. It reminds Japanese that the Skytree's current location belongs to the ancient Musashi Province. It is also designated as a tower with a disaster-prevention function during times of natural disaster.We actually went there twice. The first time we visited was before the sunset, and the weather was cloudy. After we had dinner and was ready to go up to the Tembo Deck (observation deck), it started raining. We decided to visit it again on another day. The 2nd time we went was a clear night. We were surprised to find it not as crowded, and we easily purchased the tickets and went to the elevator without waiting. We purchased the Tokyo Skytree Tembo Deck Day tickets and went directly to the Tembo Deck (350 m/1148 ft height). Although it was not so crowded, there were still too many visitors around to take good photos. The night view from the deck was incredible with the entire greater Tokyo in front of you. We could easily see the Ferris wheel at Odaiba. In the beginning, I did not use the tripod because the other observation decks we visited wouldn't allow tripods. After half an hour or so, I saw one man using a tripod, and the security guard did not stop him. I was so glad that I brought my tripod with me. I took some good and clear photos. The only drawback was the window reflection; I had to find the correct angle to shoot good photos.You can go to Skytree via the subway to TOKYO SKYTREE Station or Oshiage Station. The on-site day ticket for audit is ￥2,060. You can visit their website for more information.
Amazing Tree. Amazing Tree..highest.attractive light in the night, this can be unforgotten memories..thank you my friend...

Nice place to visit. If you like to see the Tokyo from the sky this is the best place to do it. Try to go there in the middle of the week, then it is not so busy. There is actually nothing to do, just see.

Nice!. Beautiful tower to visit. A little pricey but worth it for the view alone! I was lucky enough to visit the tower during a thunder storm. I due to immense luck, i was able to take a photo of tokyo with a massive lightning strike above it. Absolutely stunning!

A must on a visit to Tokyo. I went to the Tokyo Sky Tree tower with some work colleagues, it was very busy and admittedly it wasn't a clear day, none the less the view was quite incredible and the general layout nothing short of amazing! certainly a great experience to see a 360 view of Tokyo. "IF" you get a clear day, you should be able to see Mt Fuji clearly from the tower.

beautiful engineering. very beautiful at night in all its glory with the different lights on...a cool and happening place at night...easily accesible by tokyo metro...has a decent shopping place for souveniers for visitors..A MUST SEE!!

Great view on clear day. Went there in november on a clear sunny day, view from the Tembo deck (350m) was spectacular (Mt. Fuji was clearly visible), queue was short (couple minutes max, went there early in the morning) it is fun experience. Lots of people on the Tembo deck, but very manageable (you should be accustomed to lots of people when in Japan though :)

Amazing! Absolute must for a visit to Tokyo!. I must say the view from up there at 350m and 450m is incredible and mind blowing. We only had a few hours to spend in Tokyo so we went here and I can say that I saw the whole of Tokyo because you can literally see the whole of Tokyo if you go up this tower. If you do go you should definitely pay the extra 1000 yen and go to the 450 m level. Even more of a view. You may have to give it a miss if your scared of heights or get funny feelings at heights. Coming back down in the left I got that pressure feeling in ears you get on a plane. And was feeling a but dizzy. But it was a great experience.

Views and queues. Great views of Tokyo and (if you are lucky) Mount Fuji, but the queues to get in are long. We beat the queue by booking a table at the restaurant - a little expensive perhaps, but great views and good food.

Great orientation on a clear day. On a short visit to Tokyo, the Skytree is one way to see a lot that you'll never be able to visit on the ground! We enjoyed the panoramic views and gained an appreciation for the size of the metro area.

Nice views, but long queues. Being the highest observation point in Tokyo could be a good reason to pay the Skytree a visit, though the long queue can be a bit too much, and there is now way of avoiding this unless you have a japanese credit card to buy the ticket in advance.There are 2 different observation levels, with 2 different tickets. To get to the 350m (Tembo Deck) the tickets are ¥2060, but if you want to get to the highest point, at 450m (Tembo Galleria) you need to queue again, and pay an extra ¥1030, that I did, although the views are not much more spectacular than in the lower level.Worth the visit if you are trying to tick the highest standing tower in the world (634m) in your list. Otherwise get to the Metropolitan Government Building, where you can get to the observation decks on both towers for free and the views are stunning too.

unimpressive. We went there in april 2013, I think just few months after the big opening.Well... when we get there, we had to wait for about 2 hours, because of a huge amount of people with the same purpose.The good thing is, japanese people are extremely organized, which makes everything easy.When finally the time came, we have to take a huge line, and paid a significant amount of entrance fee (around U$20-25 as far as I remember).So, we took the elevator. I think the tower has something around 650-700m from outside.The 'regular visit' actually enables you to the halfway, a floor located around 350m above the ground. Paying an extra fee, you can go to a floor 100m above.I didn't get to pay the extra, since you can see the city pretty well from the regular floor.Also, you should consider the weather and climate if you plan to visit,Anyway, the view was nice, but too crowded and expensive for a short visit (Really don't think you need more than 45 minutes to see everything there).

Amazing view of Tokyo from 350 met observation deck. The elevator takes you with a very smooth ride up to 350 m above the ground, on so called the "TOKYO SKYTREE TEMBO DECK". It is covered in huge 5 meter-high glass for a 360-degree all-round view, allowing visitors to see on a clear day many kilometers away in the distance. There is a small glass floor deck also on which you can step and experience the thrill...!! Worth experiencing this iconic structure.

If you can, go on a day with clear visibility. I visited this attraction in mid July 2014. Getting here was pretty easy and is close to the Asakusa Temple about a mile away, We waited a in a bit of a queue to purchase tickets, but it did not take that long. It was clear that they were set up for bigger crowds as well. We were able to go up the elevator immediately. The ride up is impressively quick. The view from the 350 meter level was good, but not awesome as it was a very hazy day. If you have the opportunity, wait until it's a clear day so you can see further than the 10 miles we could see. We did not see the point to going up to the 450 meter level, which is an additional fee. We did enjoy the shopping mall at the tower's base.

Good view, nice for a coffee. I went on a Sunday afternoon to find the sky tree incredibly packed. We decided to leave out the long line for the elevator and enjoyed the still nice panorama from Starbucks on the sixth floor.

The new and improved Tokyo tower. On first view my thought were: why did they leave it that darn awful institutional grey colour, and not paint it like the Tower. But it glows after dark and is quite pretty. And massive. Decent food offering, good shopping: gift selection very good with lots of traditional Japanese stuff along with great food hall. Lots of regular shopping too. You could make a day if it. Tonnes of entertainment for kids too. If you do make it a day, visit a cash machine first as this won't be a cheap day. My suggestion would be dash there late afternoon in time for a quick trip up before the light fades, shop before dinner then grab an ice cream if o-yatsu/ dessert and hit the outdoor area or bar for a lovely view of the tower in all it's after-dark glory.

Crowded, but good view!. This being the newer version of the Tokyo tower, the whole world is queuing to go up. Once on the platform it really is a squeeze to get a slot of unobstructed glass to look out from or take a picture. But the view and the see through glass floor is really quite a good experience!This is also in a very active retail area, and there is a mall below for good souvenir shopping!

Pricy, but nice view.. Need to walk through 23094572903 shops to get to the skytree area. Waited about 15 minutes to get a ticket, the line to go up was quite fast. It's a nice view and I'm happy I went, but I wouldn't go again. At the bottom there are many tables...Can get a coffee, beer or snacks from any of the shops nearby and enjoy the area. There was an outdoor restaurant but the line was quite long. You can also grab a coffee at the top, or there's a very expensive restaurant. You need to buy a second ticket to go all the way up, but we were fine with just the lower deck.

Nice place to shop. It took me nearly the whole day to wonder around in this large shopping mall. Lovely and good for adult and children!! there is a small anack shop at the food court which is perfect for souvenir. A must visit place when you travel in Tokyo.

If you have great patience. This is more an informative message than a review. We were under the impression we could simply buy a ticket and head up to check the view from the skytree observation deck, not true! If coming from the subway you first need to battle your way through 5 floors of over crowded shops to find your way to the entrance (allow 20 mins) you then need to take a time slot ticket which willgive you the time slot you are allowed to line up to buy a ticket. Ours was 2 hours later. Once your time comes you will need to line up for approximately 1 hour to buy the ticket. Im not sure exactly what the next step was because we gave up after 10 minutes waiting in the claustrophobic line but i assume it would only be a selection of subsequent lines, overcrowding, pushing and shoving etc. we went at 1 in the afternoon on a sunday so im sure this is worst case. Good luck to those patient ones of you who are still keen :) cheers

Worth going to the tallest tower in the world. Pick a nice clear day and visit this beautiful new tower which is only 2 years old. Skytree is not as well known as Tokyo Tower, and of course the Eiffel Tower, but it is twice as high as those two and Skytree is the tallest tower in the world at 634m/2080ft. During weekends and clear days, there are long lines just to buy tickets. Expect to wait from 30 minutes to 2 hours. Try to get there at 8:00 AM just when it opens. You can buy advance reservation tickets only if you have someone in Japan with a Japanese credit card. Luckily we knew someone living in Japan and had tickets ready the day before. We probably waited only 5 minutes because of the lines to get on the elevator. Costs about $20 to get to the first floor at 350m/1150ft. Additional $10 will get you to the top floor at 450m/1480ft. The view of Tokyo is unimaginably beautiful but it's actually too high up to see the details. It's like the view from an airplane. We had a binocular which really helped. There are lots of shopping and restaurants in the tower building below.If you do not know anyone in Japan and you don't want to wait long lines, you can take the JTB's Sunshine Tour and take the English guided bus which includes sightseeing of Asakusa areas and end at the Skytree. The tour costs about $65 per person and includes the admission to the first floor of the tower. You will have to buy your own additional ticket to the top floor. But this is much easier because the Skytree is not in central Tokyo and little hard to get to by subway if you are not used to it in Tokyo.
a bit pricey but... but realy breathtaking views and you are up up the sky. there are lots of people so it is better to come at arround 6 pm -you can have as well coffee up there...

Waiting time? Not really..... I received an entry ticket for the Sky Tree Tower from the hotel, so I could spare the waiting time for the admission ticket. Therefore I can't comment on the ticket prices.Even on a public holiday in Tokyo I was able to get on the Tower in less than 15min. The view from 350m is amazing and you could see how wide Tokyo and surrounding areas really stretch. Look out for the spot, where there is a glass bottom floor! Nothing for people with height issues.....You need to judge by yourself, if you want to go 100m higher, but that elevator has a straight look outside and if you go in first, you can see up and see the construction of the inner tower (see photo). Great view from up there as well.

all worth. we went there early in the morning (opening time). There was no wait, no crowed. The view is speechless. worth the money. And I also suggest to go to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building on the other side of Tokyo. It is free and give you a different view.

the view of the worlds megatropolis. crowded? yes, worth the money? yes, at sunset it is stunning! I was almost in tears watching Tokyo light up as day turned to night. It has always been my favourite city and seeing the spectacle of Tokyo at night from Skytree cemented it.

Good enough to give it 3 stars. Move over Tokyo Tower. This relatively new landmark has quickly became an attraction for tourists and local alike. If you have been to Oriental TV Tower in Shanghai well this one is similar except Tokyo Skytree is taller. Located on Oshiage, Tokyo Skytree is actually a sprawling area consisting of the tower itself, shopping center, office building and a hotel. To purchase a ticket go to level 4 where the whole floor is dedicated for the entrance of tokyo skytree tower. Entrance fee for adult (that is anyone 18 years old and older) is Y 2.060. Age 12-17 the fee is Y 1.540. However this entrance fee is entitled you to go to Tembo Deck only (350m). If you wish to visit Tembo Galleria (450m) there is an additional fee of Y 1.030 for adult and Y 820 for those age 12-17. The ticket to Tembo Galleria is located on Tembo Deck. Less than an hour is more than enough for you to spend your time here.
Impressive tree. We went to check out the skytree, it is very large. Did not go in it or up it. Next time! The outside area has many places to hang out and grab a bite to eat.
Top of the world!. It's really pretty cool and if it had been a clearer day, alot better view. If you're afraid of heights I would not recommend it because it's definitely got some sway.

Not worth the wait and the $20. We went today -Monday but unfortunately today is a public holiday in Japan, thus, the line was over 45 minutes long. Once you get to the area, you had to go towards the tower to get a piece of paper with a time to come back to buy your ticket (and go up the tower right after). We got there at about 3 pm and was given 4:30-5 pm time slot. When we returned at 4:30, we had to stand in line for 45 minutes to purchase the tickets, then had to stand in line again, luckily not for too long, to get up the elevator. The elevator was super fast yet steady, it climbed up to 350m in no time. The observation decks were very crowded, especially the main floor, 350. There were 3 floors that we could roam around, there were cafe, restaurants and gift shop. For the time that we had to stand in line and the time that we actually spent up there, I did not feel it was worth the money. The view was good but today was hazy. Definitely either purchase your ticket online or go on a (non-holiday) weekday. We loved the mall next to it, plenty of interesting shops, restaurants, snacks, etc. It is right off of Oshiage station.

Almost got blown away. No, not when we were on top of it. We were not not allowed for sometime as because of the wind they stopped the tour which takes you to the top to have a 360 degree view of tokyo. We waited and we finally managed to get up to the viewing deck. It pretty much gives you an idea of the places to visit across tokyo. Apparently during winters one can actually see upto Mt Fuji. We werent so lucky as humidity was quite high. The most eye catching viewing from my perspective were the sight of the zooming in and out Shinkashens (bullet train).

The only way to see Tokyo - get there early. The views are AMAZING. Unfortunately, we couldn't see Fuji as it was a bit cloudy but it was still well worth the visit. Make sure you go early! We got there around 9:30 and had NO wait. When we left around an hour later the que was around 2 hours! Go in the morning and take the 30 minute walk west to Senso-ji for a well rounded morning of sight seeing!

Hope for a clear day. My partner and I enjoyed our visit here, though there certainly wasn't any chance of us spotting Mount Fuji in the distance on the day we visited, and I suspect the chance is pretty slim most days of the year!You pay at ground level for the first section, and ascend in a lift, where you then can see a small exhibition / pictures of other 'Sky' associated buildings and places. Should you wish to go up to the second level there is an additional fee. We decided that we didn't think we'd see much more from that height given that the slight haze meant we'd not see Mount Fuji :-)There is a small cafe, and small range of goods in the shop, and clean toilet facilities.There is the opportunity to have an 'official' photo taken at several points in your visit.Given the accessibility of the building, this attraction is suitable for a range of ages, and we certainly saw young to older age the day we visited, including people using wheelchairs.We didn't have a lengthy wait on the day we visited but given the large waiting area I imagine that on busy days there could be a long wait.

Only saw it from outside. I was not well and didn't want to spend 2000Y on a visit to the observatory so instead stayed at street level and viewed it from outside. Interesting design and some pretty good pictures can be taken. There is a huge shopping mall underneath with lots of dining options. To go up there is often a wait of 30 plus minutes but you can pre book on line. I have rated this attraction as average simply because I did not see it all. It does seem kind of expensive though. The skytree station is not well signposted so when you go through the ticket barriers you should go right everyone makes the mistake of going left, skytree entrance will be signed if you follow the right side.
The best way to see Tokyo. A group of friends and I went to see the Tokyo Skytree. We were just blown away by the view (and the glass floor)!

Worth the trip. We went on a Wednesday in July and had less that a 20 minute wait. View was spectacular. Art work,was spectacular. Stopped at 350 meters and walked around. A little smoggy on a hot humid day. Definitely worth the trip since it is the tallest needle in the world at 600 meters tall.

Not the best, but good. My review to this attraction is not the best, unfortunately... View from this tower is nice only in the night time, after sunset. Day time is a real smoke even when the weather is perfect. The round 360 degrees floor is very small, once you step start going around, you're again at you first spot... Not nice. Yes, Tokyo is a city with buildings..., only roofs you see from the heights... So, my suggestion, come just few minutes before sunset and stay until you make best pics and may go. Sorry, but not the best marks...

The tallest tower worth visiting!. It's my first time to see the grand view of Tokyo skytree. You could easily spot lots of gift shops there. Though people informed me that the cheapest Tokyo banana can be purchased at Haneda airport (in Tokyo), still you can find different flavors at a shop in Tokyo skytree. Indeed, a visit to Tokyo would never be complete without a paying a visit to Tokyo skytree and Solamachi mall.

Spectacular view of Tokyo. We visited on Saturday afternoon. Tickets were bought online so did not have to wait in line for tickets. Went to 350m first, the views are spectacular. Then went up to 450m. The views are the same, not worth spending extra.

Definitely worth the money. This is one of the attractions you need to make time while in Tokyo to visit!A broadcasting tower.The height of Skytree is 634 m.It is named after Musashi, historical name of the area.It was also certified in the Guiniss World records as the tallest tower in the world.In 50 seconds you will reach the height of 350m in the elevator.As the height progresses upwards, it morphs into circular cross section.The tower has a vibration control. 375m in length reinforced concrete pillar, in the center of Skytree allows to absorb around 50% of seismic vibrations. Vibration control mechanism is known as Shinbashira seishin.You would be surprised not even people who live in Tokyo visited Skytree.Be prepared to wait 20 minutes to buy ticket.Also, TEMBO shuttles have different decorations of 4 different seasons.On the 350m you will find time-space navigation.

Well worth it, but come early.. Arrived around 9.50 on a Friday and there were no queues anywhere. Thrilling but smooth elevator ride and spectacular view met us when we exited the elevator. Spectacular views, but the most thrilling and memorable part was to walk over the glass floor on the 340 level - with a clear view under my feet.Avoid the Sky Café if you want quality, the sandwich was tasteless and the curry contained two tiny bits of meat and lots of filling - however it was worth it considering the opportunity to just sit down for a while and admire the view to the south.

Fast to visit on a weekday. I went to Tokyo Skytree on a Wednesday at around 2pm and there weren't too many visitors around. I didn't have to queue at all for my ticket or formthe elevator. It was a beautiful view from 350m (didn't see the need to go higher) and you get a great overview of Tokyo. Unfortunately you rarely see Mt Fuji in July since it's so cloudy all the time.

Spectacular to look at but difficult to visit. You can see the tower from much of Tokyo and that part is free. However, beware the booking process. Online reservations are in Japanese only and will accept Japanese credit cards only. I was there late on a Saturday and they told me the queue to buy tickets would be more than an hour. The sheer volume of people in the line was dispiriting.The lower deck (free) is actually quite pleasant but is really a glorified shopping arcade - punters must pass loads of shops to get up. Tickets 2570 yen to 350m and extra 1030 to 450 metres. Without even having been up, would have to agree with a previous review. An extra 100m at that point is not really relevant for extra cost and hassle.

Great View but Don't Pay Extra for Top Deck. The Tokyo Skytree is a modern facility that offers great views over all of Tokyo. If you do not have a credit card issued by a Japanese bank you can not purchase tickets on the Internet so wait times can be formidable, however the day my family went it was only about 15-20 minutes.The way it is set up is you buy tickets for the 250 meter deck at the bottom, then if you want to go to the 350 meter deck you must queue again at the 250 meter level and pay additional money. It is not worth it. The view is exactly the same and you'll save the extra money and time.That being said, do go to the first deck because the views are incredible and it is a wonderful facility.
Amazing view!. One of the must-see attractions near Asakusa, the giant tower has a wonderful view of Tokyo. They also have a restaurant on top of the tower.

Amazing Views. The Tokyo sky tree is the perfect place to visit if you are into observation towers and spectacular views.One negative is that there is a lot of waiting involved before you can actually enter, we got there early in the morning and still waited 1.5 hours.So be early.

It's nice, but not amazing. Tokyo skytree is worth checking out if you have some extra $ and some time to kill. It costs a bit to get up to the 450m platform, and if you have a family the costs can get high fairly quickly.If you do go i suggest go in the early morning, or at at duck. If you go in the afternoon the city can get quite hazy making the view not as nice.The aquarium is nice, but in my opinion not as nice as the one in Osaka, if you are also traveling to Osaka just go to that one instead.
beautiful sightseeing. it is great to visit Tokyo tree and know the history of this tall building but it was so cloudy that day made the view unclear.
Beautiful city view. If you like paranomic/bird's eye/city views, go (to the very top). Else, skip it. A nice walk from Asakusa station -- simply walk towards the tower.

Its amazing to be standing at the tallest broadcating tower in the world. I read it somewhere that in Japan you see a lot of things that are copied from the world. Like they have they have their own statue of liberty and Tokyo tower which is like the Eiffel tower ;-) having said that a visit to the Tokyo sky tree is worth it..They say it is the tallest standing broadcasting tower in the world. You need to buy a 1000 yen ticket for the first entry which is from the 5th floor till 350 floors. The lifts are themed of various seasons in Japan and are beautiful..what is even more interesting the ride up and you will reach the 350th floor in 60 seconds...Its an amazing feeling to be watching the clock moving and you are covering floors so swiftly. The view from the 350 floor is nice..and if you are lucky you can even see the Mount Fuji from there on the clear sky night. I was visiting during the rains and wasn't lucky enough. it will cost you another 1000 yen to go to the 450 floor ...costly I must say!. Well ..in how many places can you go to the 450 floor and watch how the world outside looks? so it does make it worth a visit.

better to look at. Tokyo has so very much to offer, I'd not suggest spending the time and money to experience Sky Tree. Tokyo Tower is cheaper, easier to access, and though a bit cheesy it offers a good view... as do many buildings in West Shinjuku, for little or no price. Tokyo Sky Tree offers a mid-height viewpoint for Y2,000 (about $20), then one can purchase a ticket to the highest viewpoint for Y2,400. A bit dear. The outstanding aquarium is certainly worthwhile, though also not inexpensive. Shopping is lovely, if one can spend the day and enjoy the shops, cafes, etc. it is a good time. If your time is limited, we all agreed one should spend the day in Asakusa or Ueno instead!

Expensive and crowded, but incredible views. Visiting the Tokyo Skytree is expensive, and you most likely will have to deal with large crowds no matter when you visit, but the views are amazing and make this a must-do attraction in Tokyo. We arrived just after 0800, when it opens, on a Saturday, and there was already a 20-minute wait time to buy tickets for the first observation deck. By the time we got up, the line to buy tickets for the second observation deck (which you can only buy once you arrive on the first deck) had over an hour wait. The views from the first deck are incredibly impressive and even though it's very crowded, the views make this a worthwhile experience. You truly get a sense for the size and layout of Tokyo. You can only buy advance tickets online if your credit card was issued in Japan. When we asked our hotel for assistance purchasing advance tickets, the concierge said we could buy a package that included tickets to the Skytree. The package we were offered was 3,700 yen per person, almost twice as much as a regular ticket (2,060 yen per person).

Saves time if you plan ahead. Made our way to the Sky Tree on a Saturday and was disappointed at the extremely long queue to go up the tower. The board shows 70 min wait to get your tickets, and I estimate it'd take another 30-40 mins additional which is a separate queue again to take the lift up. Decided to forgo and perhaps try it on a separate trip. Probably will be less of a wait on a weekday, but the TIP will be to book online for the tickets.. Note Online booking must be made at least 1 day before.... Being well planned will save you time for the shopping in the same building... a few hundred stores to tempt your wallet/purse !

Cloudy day, but the view was still amazing!. Unfortunately, I'd chosen to go to the tower on my last day in Tokyo, which happened to be quite cloudy. Still, the view was great from above! I was lucky enough to not have to brave a queue at 6.30pm, which is close to sunset time. I guess it was because of the weather. Was up on the 350m deck ten minutes after buying the ticket at the counter. Stayed until the view turned the twinkling city lights. You can see Tokyo Tower from the deck too, even when it's cloudy. So, lesson learnt - remember to choose a sunny, clear day so that you can see a better view and Mt. Fuji!

Go for sunset. We tend to go in the late afternoon to see the day view and then city lights.Skytree is an amazing structure, and the view is spectacular. Tokyo for above is interesting but flat, and you can see how little open space there is apart for the imperial compound and Yoyogi . It was too hazy to see Fuji. One gripe is that you cannot buy online tickets with a foreign credit account so must line up for tickets.Views are spectacular and the viewing decks quiet spacious , it was rather empty when we went. It was worth paying the extra to get to the top deck, though you don't see much of a difference at that height, but the crowds are thinner.Bring binoculars if you have some.Most interesting is seeing the structure itself, the layout of the observation decks and walking the spiral ramp,on the top deck.

A must see Japanese attraction!. Went here with my husband and best friend. We visited on a Monday afternoon, which was awesome, there was no wait time to purchase the tickets and it was about $21.00 per person. All the explanation was given in Japanese which sucked, because we didn't get any of the history. There were signs and murals in English, which helped. The view was amazing, you can see all of Tokyo. There is an extra fee to go all the way to the top. We didn't feel like you needed to go any higher. If you go to the lower level, they will take a picture of you with the glass floor as the background, I believe you pay $13.00. We took some great photos. Apparently, you can see Mt. Fuji when it's not too cloudy. I would recommend anyone visiting Tokyo to go up on the highest tower in the world!

Great views of the city. You have two options: Either just go up to 350m for ~2000 yen, or pay an additional ~1000 yen to take a lift up from 350m to the 450m. I only went to 350m, but the views there were enough :)If you go on a weekend, prepare to queue for more than 40 minutes. Go on a weekday if possible. At the top, don't miss the glass bottom area – even though logically you know everything is safe and sound, standing on a bunch of transparent glass 350m above ground should at least give you a chill or sweaty palms!

tokyo skytree....the proud of japanese. went to tokyo skytree on 31st mei 2014.... there were so many people queing to buy tickets. had to wait about an hour before could get tickets. went untill 350m high the tembo deck ...saw many older japanese people very proud of the hugh tower....could see tokyo city which is so crowded from the top. better dont go on the weekend cause so many people and have to wait for a very long queu to buy tickets.

Amazing View - See-through floor. The Skytree is incredible. You can see the expanse of Tokyo. If you look very hard, you can see Tokyo Disneyland. Bring binoculars, as much of the city is small that high up.Also, be prepared for long lines to get in.Make sure you find the see-through glass floor. I didn't stand on it because it was too unnerving, but many others seemed to be enjoying it.

Just..... Wow.. Being from Melbourne, I thought the Eureka Skydeck was high, And was looking forward to check the Tokyo Skytree out.Very easily to get to, Taking a JR line then a Subway line to get here was very easy if you can understand the Japanese Rail system.Upon arrival, We were faced with what we thought was a 20ish minute wait/line to get tickets. This "20ish minute" wait in line turned into just over an hour in line waiting to get Tickets, Then another 25 minute wait to get into an elevator; Don't get me wrong, Not complaining, We went on a weekend and at an hour that generally meant tourists and locals a like would be here.There are two levels you are able to purchase; First stop is 350m, And second is 450m. You pay separately for both; If you want the very top, You pay more and if you just want the 350m, You pay less; We paid both anywho and took the elevator to the first stop. Just wow is all I can say. Being a clear day, We could see all of Tokyo! Beautiful views and lots to look at. It was remarkable. On this floor, You have a small takeaway place you are able to get coffee and treats; We lined up for 10 mins to get a table and had a time limit; None the less, We loved every minute of it, Taking in the views whilst looking out over Tokyo.Then we "Attempted" to trek up to the 450m level; It was way to busy and crowded for us to even contemplate going up to the top so we just sat back and looked out over Tokyo from the 350m mark. What a sight.If there were three things I'd tell first timers to Tokyo to do, This would be the 2nd on the list. Don't miss this, You'll regret it!

Great view! . It is a great view, you really get to see and feel how big Tokyo is! Its also very cool that it is the highest tower in the world. But its like any observation deck, its fun to have been there, take a few pictures. But thats it. There is heaps of fun little shops and restaurants in the other parts of the building as well. Not even that pricey!

First thing to do in Tokyo. Visited the place mast may 2014 and this is the first thing I did in Tokyo. Named as the second tallest structure in the world next to Burj Kalifa, Tokyo Skytree will give you a perfect glimpse of the whole city.

Excellent , a must do , but at a price. We visited the Sky tree on a Tuesday late afternoon. We were fortunate enough to obtain tickets to the Sky Tree with no line and just walked up to the counter. Cost per ticket was about $20 USD or 1950 JPY. It proved to be a very memorable part of our Tokyo experience, and I would rate it as an absolute must do for any visitor to Tokyo.The views were just breathtaking and you get a good chance to see different aspects of Tokyo from the 350 meter tall first viewing area. Yes FIRST viewing area.(I will explain later). It was a overcast day when we visited and no doubt the luck of the weather will play a role in any visits as the so so weather we had meant that we couldn't see vast distances very clearly.The whole operation of the Sky Tree is very slick, with the uniformed staff (the Japanese love uniforms) uniforms themselves are very unique, almost comical fashion statement! Very professional, friendly and also very efficient in moving the crowds through. It was not crowded when we visited. The Sky Tree is celebrating its 2nd anniversary and obviously the locals are extremely proud of their new landmark. The elevators up and down were amazingly quick and smooth. As you ride to the top you can feel the pressure in your ears change! There are a number of great photo opportunities including the glass floor that you can stand on ( if you dare!) and also have your group photos taken by the photo staff at a reasonable cost (1200 JPY) for a printed photo with souvenir folder and they will also happily take a picture for you with your own camera.Once you wonder around you can use the larger interactive maps to see landmarks around Tokyo, then look out in the distance to find them. Be sure to stamp your brochure when you get to the bottom.So your ticket gets you to the main viewing area, but..... Yes for a few yen more you can go even higher! The highest viewing area will cost you an additional 1200 JPY. Lol, well, we opted not to go higher. If in Tokyo go and have a look at the Sky Tree and if you can, go up to the viewing area. If not the complex has a ton of shops, restaurants, and activities to keep you busy. The train station at the complex makes it easy to access . Have fun!

Around the Skytree. We wanted to get a nice view from the top of the Skytree but to wait for more than 2 hours to get a ticket , that was what put us off. So we wandered off to the surrounding areas. We tumbled into Sumida Park and visited the Ushijima Shrine. Not a bad outing.

Not as good as Tokyo Tower. Of course it is much better in quality. But all in all the experience and the feeling is less exciting then Tokyo Tower.OK view is pretty nice but if you have to choose only one - pick Tokyo Tower.

PRE-PURCHASE YOUR TICKETS. My family and I went there for the first time this week. You have to be aware that on any given day, you would have to wait more than 1 hour to buy the tickets. However, if you pre-purchase your tickets online, (http://www.tokyo-skytree.jp/en/reservation/), you do not have to wait whatsoever. The view from the top is very nice and everything is well organized like everything else in Japan. I do recommend you going up to the Second Observation Deck (costs about 10 dollars more for adults) because the view is great and there are less people! Also, take time to walk around Solamachi and go eat some lunch there, too.

Well Run Observation Tower. Even though the line looked long the elevator and ticketing system at the Tokyo Skytree was very well run. There are definitely a lot of people but it is still pretty easy to see Tokyo. I would suggest going to the upper viewing level because there aren't as many people and you get a great view without the people.

Captain Birdseye!. We hadn't bought tickets in advance and went on a Friday. I would say we queued for between 10-15 minutes but the queue was constantly moving and it didn't seem that long! Once you've got your ticket (Y2000 for 350m), the queue for the lift is only a couple of minutes. A 59 second ride and you're there and the view is spectacular. We were very lucky to have a clear day and went just before lunch. The view is superb and on really clear days you can see Mt. Fuji. I would highly recommend it and on your way down (if you dare) stop off at the glass floor!

nicely appointed tower. Somehow whenever we end up in a new city, we inadvertently go up the tallest tower available (it as if, in some Assassin's Creed situation, doing so revealed more of the city map to us - we should learn that maps are far easier to obtain). In Tokyo, this is that tower.To start with it is prudent to know that the elevator has a glass door and people who are scared of heights (what are you doing going up a tower anyway) may feel ill at ease on the way up.The wait for the tower is a lot shorter if you purchase tickets online, that being said, going during the week ensures the line for tickets isn't excessive anyway.When up top, at no point do you feel rushed, the viewing deck is wide enough so that (during the week) you don't feel cramped, however, I would say that the traffic (even during the week) makes extensive photo sessions (with tripod, etc) a little harder then preferable - but you won't get this view elsewhere....Overall a very pleasant experience - definitely do this when in Tokyo.

Great views but at a price. The queue to get up to once of the tallest structures on the planet is very long and it's not cheap either but the views at the top are spectacular. The aquarium is also nice but once again, not the cheapest

Definatley worth going!. We were very lucky that it was quite a clear day when we went so could see a lot of Tokyo, and wow it's very very very high!You pay to go to the observation tower which you can easily spend hours just sat there people watching. You can pay extra to go to the top observation tower which also consists of a window floor to stand on which is breathtakingly scary but enjoyable!I would recommend going as it really is amazing what you can see!

Landmark. One of the newest landmarks of Tokyo. Visible from many areas in Tokyo, even from my hotel room near Ueno. A shopping centre is below the tower, not particularly outstanding, although it is possible to take the lifts up to the restaurant floors for spectacular views of Tokyo and the Skytree!

A very worthwhile experience. On a clear day you can see for miles! If you want to get to grips with the enormity of Tokyo, go to the top of this amazing structure. 360 degree panorama in a nicely managed environment. For those who are nervous of heights, this is a very sturdy structure. It's madly tall, of course, but it feels secure. If you cannot go to the top, then the shops and cafés at the base should keep you amused.

A Must See. While we were not fortunate enough to be able to go up the tower (the observation deck was closed due to strong winds), I highly recommend that you visit if you are in Tokyo. Even if you do not go up the tower, the first four floors are home to all kinds of shops, restaurants, and even an aquarium. Also, you can purchase the famous Tokyo Bananas here. This is a must see while in the city!

Tower. Ride the subway to get there, get there in the morning, must be a clear day, if not dont go. Has a fee, one for lower level and one for upper level take the lower level. Walk around and see how big Tokyo is.After you come down is the shopping complex.

Amazing view!. Tallest tower in the world. It's really worth to do it. The view is just breathtaking. The only thing reason I didn't give it 5 star it's because there are too many people and have to wait for a while to see the view!!

great tourist spot. That is the first place I visited when I arrived Tokyo, we went in there not so late, but it is great it was nice at night, looking at the city, didnt go in just being outside is quite nice already. Lots of places to eat, great shops.

Worth a look. The views from this very new tower (2 yrs) are incredible, and I think worth the entrance fee. The many efficient workers help keep everyone moving, filling elevator after elevator for the rise to the observation floor. Once at the windows you may jockey for position to get a good view, but it is immediately impressive from all directions. (There is also an option to pay more to take another elevator higher, which we chose to skip.) Make time for the shops/mall on the bottom floors -- they are quite varied and interesting.
Amazing panoramic views. The tallest tower in the world. Boasts magnificent architecture and breathtaking views from the top.Shopping centre beneath was worth a look with a variety of stores.
Great View!. Great view of the city at night, we went close to closing time so it wasn't very crowded. There are a few shops and places to eat on the main floor which was nice!
One of the tallest tower in the world. when we were there, we cant go up to the observation deck due to strong wind so they closed early. So we just kind of enjoying it from outside with nice breeze.
Good shopping centre. Tokyo Skytree is a good centre for shopping etc. I did not go up the tower but I think it would have been worth it. Very clean and well laid out

Awesome structure with amazing views of the city. Definitely worth visiting this tallest tallest tower in the world, at twice the height of the eiffel tower. Visiting on a weekend was a bit of a challenge as the line was massive, however, it moved fairly quickly given the size of the queue. Once you take the elevator to the top of floor you have 360 degree views of Tokyo as it extends beofre your eyes. Luckily we arrived about 30 minutes before sunset and we were treated with the dazzling colors of the setting sun beyond the mountains, then Tokyo lit up and again we were treated with night views of the city. From that experience, I would say do visit in the late afternoon to experience the views on Tokyo during the day and after dark. The fee is not cheap, but not overly expensive either, it was worth it.

wow. if you are going to Tokyo, you must do if you are not scare of high, going to the sky tree, what amazing to see the all city from 350 mtr high. best time during the week, avoid the weekend, gets very very busy. Best time to go about 10 am and will be easy to get in, from the 4th floor.And without any doubt do the glass floor, you will feel the fear.

Very long queue but stunning view. Had decided that we would like to visit but wouldn't go if the queue was excessive.On arrival we were advised that the wait was 40 minutes so we went for it, in the end the wait was a little over an hour, and I have to admit that I didn't enjoy the wait.We thought the view was fantastic so are glad we went up, we even paid the extra to go to the higher deck, and were glad we did.Whilst it was a sunny day we couldn't see Mt Fuji because of the haze, bit disappointed with that but not an issues.

Incredible!. This attraction is incredible to see! I never went to the top as I had limited time but it was still incredible to see. It's the tallest tower in the world to put into perspective it's an amazing site especially at night time! Recommend going to anyone that asks!

SKYTREE - modern day Eiffel Tower?. LOVED my visit to the Skytree - it was an AWESOME spectacle - particularly admire the way it sits between the old and the new!! - We couldn't go up the tree this day - as winds too high - we could go back any time/day with our amended pass - and - we got a STICKER!! (tongue in cheek)

Return time system on weekends. I went on a Sunday and I figured it would be crowed and it was. However, they issued a return time slip outside the main entry in a tent which was for a 30 return slot 2 1/2 hours out. I left and went to another area of Tokyo and returned near the end of the designated time slot. I walked right up and the total wait to the first level was no more than 5 minutes. The wait for the second level was also no more than 5 minutes. The elevator rides were great - incredibly smooth even though it was a fast trip up. The views were great. A bit hazy so no Mt. Fuji but great view of the city and surrounding areas.A must do when in Tokyo.

Amazing view. We turned up in the evening and found a 2 hour wait so we managed to book a special pass for the next day that would let us up the tower without waiting at any time of the day. Well worth the extra cost.About 4000 each but you get a free rail pass from the Tobu company subway and 1000 yen to spend in their department store as a credit. ( crap store but still managed to spend it.)The view from the tower is best at dusk then you get to see all the lights of tokyo come on.We went on a rather hazy day so not the best daytime viz unfortunately.Main deck was busy so it can be a fight for a space to look out the window. Also the cafe and bar take some of the 360deg view away bit of a shame.Taking good long exposure photos is not going to work, too many vibrations and lights reflecting on the glass.
