No tripods allowed anyway.All in all very touristy experience and hyped buy thousands wanting to get up there day and night!!!! But still it's and experience..Not my best tower in japan.

Neat.. It was a very nice experience. It was so high that once you got to the very top you could feel the building swaying! The Vinegar ice cream was amazing at Sky Tree cafe & they have an adorable gift shop :)

Tallest tower in the world. This is a new attraction in Tokyo, open just 2 years. It has two viewing levels where you can walk around seeing all of Tokyo spread out before you. Half hour wait to go up in speedy elevators but worth the wait for the view.

Fantastic view from a very sleek and modernistic structure. Our friend who lived in Tokyo booked the entrance tickets for us on the net and saved us a lot of hazzle. In fact, the day we were there, it was not as crowded as I anticipated and the Japanese staff were professional, very organized and made things happened in an orderly manner. The Tembo Deck at Floors 340,345and350 gave one a panaramic view of the City of Tokyo and since we fortunately had a rather clear day, the visibility was unparalleled. In fact, from my humble experience, for observation facilities like this, weather is crucial for one to decide if a visit is worthwhile. I never got tired of standing on glass floors which are getting rather common on this kind of super tall structures and you can test your courage on Level 340. In retrospect, rather than the views afforded, I was most impressed with the asthetic architecture of the tower and their ability to install vibration control to protect it from high winds and earthquakes. The developer was also clever to build a range of facilities surrounding it including aquarium, planetarium and a sizeable shopping complex with plenty of shops and eateries. Tourist can easily spend at least half or even one day on what they coined as the Tokyo Skytree Town.
Good view. It's worth a visit, good view and nice to walk around in the neighborhood direction of asakusa. There should be also shuttle buses available though I have not used them.
Outstanding Attraction. This is one of the world's tallest towers. It is an awesome structure with amazing views and superb presentation. The urbanisation stretches to the horizon. Amazing!

Awesome views of this sprawling metropolis.. Yes it's touristy but don't be put off by the queues, they rattle you through double qik. Can be misty and probably not worth going up the extra level. If your lucky you will see mt Fuji.Staff just fantastic at get everyone through.You can walk from Asakusa station, there are a few interesting shops, then take the train back.

Awesome view. Need to make reservation at least 3 days prior to the visit.Going a bit prior to dusk has some advantages:- you can enjoy the sunset- it's possible to enjoy the day light view and the night view- possible to enjoy dinner up there

Excellent view of Tokyo from above. Skytree, opening only a couple of years ago is a great spot to see how large Tokyo really is but make sure you pick a nice day for it. The attraction, like most in Tokyo is corned with long queues, almost on a daily basis. However, they do take 'bookings" akin to Disneylands' fast pass system (pick up a pass that allows you guaranteed entry at a pre-defined later time).

Tokyo Sky tree worth to see. Really its a very good experience to see worlds tallest tower and its observatory. When you enter the lift for 350th floor, it takes only 1 min to reach that level. Really mind blowing speed. And City view from there is marvelous. Specially in the night. And must see glass bottom.

Tokyo Sky Tree. It is a good enough for a visit. Think of it as a mall with a very tall tower. I live in Tokyo and although this tower has been up for 2 years as of May 2014, I have never made the time or effort to visit. It's a tourist trap. Japan and Tokyo has far much more cultural, historical, and beautiful places. The price is a bit high but the view is worth it on a clear day. There is a line and a wait so booking ahead of time online is recommended. I would include this visit with other events. I went in the daytime so likely at night it could be a much more colorful experience. It's a tourist trap but not a disappointment.

Fantastic view, but get there early. The view from the Tokyo Skytree on a clear day of Mt Fuji is worth the cost of admission alone. Make sure you get there early as the queue is very long, but persist as you won't be disappointed. Take your time when you get to the top and have some lunch at the cafe and enjoy the view, a must see for anyone visiting Tokyo whether it's your first time or not, to see the city from that height is truely amazing. Don't bother going to the very top, the view is just as good at the first level and it's not worth the extra JPY1000

New and shiny but definitely touristy. Probably no surprise to anyone; this is a tourist attraction. It's new, clean, and offers fantastic views of Tokyo. The area around the Skytree (the mall) has a lot of people watching and food to offer. I think there is also an aquarium but overall we didn't really see much of the mall just because we weren't interested. The Skytree is probably a one-time thing and I doubt I would go back unless I was showing someone else the area. It's a bit crowded...we had a 40 minute wait which wasn't too bad although I would not wait any longer than 1 hour for the Skytree. The operation is smooth; the line kept moving and we were given a heads up about the 40 minute wait before getting in line. Between the Skytree and the Tokyo Tower I'd choose the Tokyo Tower. Less wait and the same views.

Reach out to the Sky. On our way to our hotel upon arrival to Tokyo at the night time, we could see this TALL and spectacular monument from far away all lighted up and offers an amazing view. Since the following day was raining all day long, we went to this place on another day. It's strongly advisable to purchase tickets either online or with the help of a good concierge to avoid the long line unless you have plenty of free time. But be aware that the top of the tower won't be opened on a very windy day as for safety precaution. Anyway there's an Aquarium on the site and needs also to purchase tickets for entrance. It's the biggest aquarium in Tokyo.Back to the Sky Tree Tower, the architectural construction is combined with traditional and futuristic design. It raises from a pretty quiet area of Tokyo and has became the newest and hottest tourist point which offers a brand new aspect of view of the Tokyo and her suburbs . On the second part of the observatory, visitors can walk around the Tower through a 360 degree corridor which allows a feeling of walking in the sky within 0 distance.At the bottom of the Tower, there is huge market place, Solamachi, which consists three parts, the West Yard, the Tower Yard, and the East Yard. Inside there are hundreds of shops, restaurants which offer super nice souvenirs and gourmet foods. Please allow yourself at least half a day or more to enjoy this newest visiting point in Tokyo. It's easily accessible by subway to Oshiage Station and the monument is just at the exit .
nice view. nice place to enjoy the shopping downstairs a lot of things to see you get a nice panoramic view of the city !bathroom inside are really clean I recommend!

Spectacular view. Spectacular view of almost entire country Japan from 1st stage @ 345 m & second stage @450m. Over all 634m high. Try to be at the right time Just before sunset for a better view and remain till sunset and Japan glows at night. It really awesome , must visit if near Tokyo. Mt FuJi is also visible on clear day.First stage 2060Yen (Rs1750/-) & second stage 1060 yen (Rs650/-) (available on 1st stage only if u wish)Ticket counter starts at 4th floor. Speed of elevator 600m/min (takes less than 50s to reach first stageHave restaurants/coffee shops on 1st stageNext to BhuJ Kalifa

Amazing!. My friend and I visited this on our first night and we loved the colors. The tourist info brochure we got hyped this attraction so we didn't visit Tokyo Tower. We didn't go up but just admired the view from below. It's accessible from the Oshiage Station so we didn't have problems going here. There were a lot of shops, souvenir shops, and restaurants here. There's also a food court where we ate takoyaki at Gindako.

Stunning view but boy did I queue for it. Took a chance and turned up early lunch time. Early afternoon I was finally up there. As they all pretty much say this has the ultimate city view. Well executed setup and hats off to them for processing so many people to go up and down. Stayed up for an age to get every pic I could get. Just wow. Shops and restaurants nearby in building for after.
Fantastic View. The view you have there is fantastic. You can see Mt Fuji from there and also has a nice aquarium in the same building.

Experience Tokyo City View. Some tips for all traveler without group~ due to there are 2, Entrance which is Group entrance 1st floor of Tokyo Sky Tree and 4th floor of Normal Entrance which is for Ticket Counter only ~ due to who travel via exit of train station at Tokyo Sky Tree Station or Oshiaga Station ~ why i will say this due to there are Separate 3 Area that's West Yard (Tokyo Sky Tree Station) , East Yard (Oshiaga Station) , Tower yard (Tokyo Sky Tree Tower) which is middle of both East & West yard, so for who going the tower please go to 4th floor and walk to the "Sky Arena" which like a garden area of building~ and you can find out the 4th floor main entrance via to the Ticket Counter ~ 1st we purchase admission ticket which is direct to 350M deck only that offer with panoramic view of Tokyo City and for other option if you like to travel to the highest deck you can go 445M/450M, that are offer purchase other admission ticket which is the counter at 350M deck~ although as we know this also a famous attraction so when we travel will bit crowded but no worry because the deck is big and even thought is full on 350M you still can down to 2 more floor which is also offer the view of Tokyo ~ as well the last deck floor of 340M also offer Glass Floor that which also can step on top on it ~ nice experience ~

amazing views, obviously. there's the queueing up...lining up....etc. but while you wait for your group time slot, you can wander the mall at the base of the sky tree. as expected the views are stunning. you can see how vast the urban areas in tokyo spreads.

A must do when in Tokyo but go early. The Skytree being the tallest tower in the world at 634m and the second tallest structure only behind the Burj Khalifa makes this a must do attraction. With its iconic structure it represents modern day Tokyo at its best and just the view of the tower soaring into the sky from ground level was worth the visit. After reading other reviews and warnings of long waiting times I arrived at 8.50 am on a Monday morning (via Oshiage metro Stn) and was pleasantly surprised that there were no queues and after purchasing my ticket (2060 Yen) was able to board the lift to the first observation deck at 350M. The lift was in itself quite an experience moving at 600 M / minute even though it did not feel it, despite my ears popping!Because they control the flow the observation deck was busy but not overly crowded and there was no problem getting a space to take photos from the floor to ceiling windows. The views were incredible with the whole of Tokyo laid out in front of you. You are given a pamphlet which depicts the notable landmarks making it easy to orientate yourself with the different districts of Tokyo from the view. Despite the weather being sunny there was some cloud which obscured Mt Fuji which was my only disappointment. If you want to go to the second observation deck at 450m you need to purchase another ticket (1000 Yen). Having already been up the Mori tower and the Metropolitan Govt building I have to say both the views and the whole experience was far better all round and well worth it. If your going to do one high rise view of the city then the Sky tree should be it! Enjoy.

Must do attraction in Tokyo but go early. The Skytree being the tallest tower in the world at 634m and the second tallest structure only behind the Burj Khalifa makes this a must do attraction. With its iconic structure it represents modern day Tokyo at its best and just the view of the tower soaring into the sky from ground level was worth the visit. After reading other reviews and warnings of long waiting times I arrived at 8.50 am on a Monday morning (via Oshiage metro Stn) and was pleasantly surprised that there were no queues and after purchasing my ticket (2060 Yen) was able to board the lift to the first observation deck at 350M. The lift was in itself quite an experience moving at 600 M / minute even though it did not feel it, despite my ears popping!Because they control the flow the observation deck was busy but not overly crowded and there was no problem getting a space to take photos from the floor to ceiling windows. The views were incredible with the whole of Tokyo laid out in front of you. You are given a pamphlet which depicts the notable landmarks making it easy to orientate yourself with the different districts of Tokyo from the view. Despite the weather being sunny there was some cloud which obscured Mt Fuji which was my only disappointment. If you want to go to the second observation deck at 450m you need to purchase another ticket (1000 Yen). Having already been up the Mori tower and the Metropolitan Govt building I have to say both the views and the whole experience was far better all round and well worth it. If your going to do one high rise view of the city then the Sky tree should be it! Enjoy.
Fantastic view of the City - Can see Mount Fuji. There's a bit of a line-up to get in, but the views are worth it.Do not go if you are afraid of heights.

View is amazing. We didn't experience any of the queuing drama others have mentioned so I guess we were lucky. We went after dark and when we got to the top of the tower and walked out onto the observation platform, it was a moment I will remember for a long time - the panoramic views of Tokyo are spectacular; every cliché and superlative you can imagine. Well worth a visit and not far from some other amazing sites. Would thoroughly recommend!

Sky Tree Afternoon. Sky tree was a wonderful way to experience Tokyo in a beautiful new building. I was there just a month after it opened and it was so busy. With that, people were still friendly kind and children were there to see this marvel of a building. I was unable to get tickets to go up because at that time with it being so new, they were sold out months in advance. I would try to get tickets before your trip so you can be sure to experience it. The shops were fun to go through and if I had my kids with me they would have enjoyed it greatly. Recommended!
Get there early. . The lineups are huge after 10am. Good for a quick visit. Keep in mind you have to buy tow tickets. One at the base and one at mid level.

Hurdling cattle comes to mind. After collecting a ticket for the next available slot, we came back an hour later. We then queued for 40 minutes to buy the ticket. Another 10 minutes later and we were on our way up the tower. What a shock when we got out of the lift, the people were 4 deep to see out of the window of the observation deck. To see anything we had to muscle in at every point to take a look at the amazing view and it was amazing.It felt uncomfortable because there were far too many people up there, they need to limit the numbers going up so that the people on the observation deck have a better experience. I'd be interested to know if they have a limit for health and safety reasons.We went up on the 7.00 to 7.30 slot. When we did see the view it was amazing but I felt uncomfortable due to the numbers up there, we had to que for 15 minutes to come back downed couldn't even get into the shop as is was so full.Lita

Superb view. Visited during November 2012. A chilly day, but a beautiful sky.Depending on time of day and day in particular, the queue to just get into the tower can be rather long. Patience is a virtue! Try and have something with you to do whilst you wait. Once inside, the lower observation deck provides for a decent view over the surrounding area. However, it is the top observation deck that you really need to visit!With good weather it is possible to see Fujisan. I did; and at sunset, too. The sun actually set into the cone of Fujisan! Everybody cheered. Quite surreal seeing that. The overall view was fantastic. It's also dizzying to look down!As for the tower itself, it is just a tower. A superbly crafted tower, stuffed full of the usual trinkets, though there is a good supply of dearer and more worthwhile gifts. There is nothing else, other than the alcove on the top deck, raised ever so slightly to be the highest point visitors can stand at. It is just a tower; and that is why I can only grant 4 stars.It isn't cheap but, then again, what new visitor constructs are? On a good day, for a wonderful clear view of the whole of Tokyo and beyond, it is a great opportunity to stand in awe. Just be prepared to wait.

Not worth the wait. We sat in line for almost two hours on a weekday waiting to buy tickets that were very expensive! While typically the efficiency in Tokyo is second to none, this was not well planned. The view was amazing, but after about 20 minutes, it gets a little old. I would not recommend it unless breathtaking panoramic views of Tokyo and Tokyo Bay are too much for you to miss. You're better off spending your time in nearby Asakusa where the shopping and food are pretty amazing.

Definitely should be on your must do list if visiting Tokyo. We went at night and the view was spectacular. We had no problem with queues( in April). It is busy( everything in Tokyo is busy!), but well worth any reasonable wait. Hard to believe you are ascending so fast( there is a read out that informs you what height you are at etc) . There are two viewing levels, I didn't go to the higher level. It really wasn't as scarey as I had anticipated and could have gone up further without a problem. One section of the floor is glass and that is quite an experience. There are eating and drinking facilities available.

Spectacular view. Although it was a little hazy the views were wonderful particularly from the second viewing platform, which was worth the extra charge. The queue was long but quick moving, typical of Japan. Worth a visit.

Magnificent view of Tokyo. It's just celebrate their 2nd anniversary. The queue is quite long but fast. The ticket for tembo deck is 2060yen and for top level tembo galleria is 1030yen. The view is magnificent and you can see all over Tokyo. We really enjoy our time here and took lots of photos. You can also took photo with bottom glass floor where you can see the view top down. There is also a sorakara point where you can take photo with mirror both on your left and right (it create a double sequence images). Definitely recommend this to others.
Must go. This is the place you must to go. Very well organized and the waiting time is ok for the amount of things you can do on the shopping/mall you have on the building beside Sky tree..

Wish I could have gone up. My son moved to Japan 18 months ago and waited to go to the Sky tree with me when I visited. We were really looking forward to going. We arrived at the location at about 11:00 a.m. - there was a three hour wait. We opted not to wait as we had a really busy schedule. I was totally disappointed. The structure itself is magnificent! I would definitely say its a must see! I was also visiting during a holiday, so I'm sure that there were "more than normal" visitors at that time. Next time I visit, I'm definitely going.

Great panorama. This place is great if you want to pay to see the city's panorama. They even have some huge touchscreen displays you can interact with to get an alternate view of the city (depending if you arrive there during the day or after sundown). I wouldn't call the experience pricey but it's not cheap either.

Do come earlier..... Firstly I came at ard 4pm and I was given a slot to come back at 8.00pm. Tokyo Sky Tree is joined with a shopping mall so it's not too bad. So when i came back at 8.00pm, i had to queue for another hour to buy the tickets at 2060yen each. There was a quick bag check before we can enter the hall to use the lift up to the observation deck.The night view was quite amazing because you can see Tokyo night lights. There is also a café up at the observation deck. Maybe I was annoyed with the waiting time but I was expecting a lot more. I spent around just 30mins before decided to go back down...the're nt much you can do up there. It's definitely an experience but would I come back? No.

Check the weather before you go!. It turns out that in strong winds the elevators close - so even though I picked a good time of day to go with small queues (Thursday morning, I probably queued for 30 minutes unlike some people here who seem to have queued for hours) by the time I got to the front they announced that they were closing all entry for the day. I was bitterly disappointed, Sky Tree isn't in a particularly busy part of Tokyo so if this happens to you it's a long trip back to anything else you want to do. Also worth mentioning that there are very few English speaking staff. Fortunately I speak Japanese so I could understand the announcements, but many other foreigners were left in the lurch.

Insanely high, great views.. They give out tickets with a return time if you want to go up the sky tree, so we decided to wait for a later ticket so we'd have more time to go to Shibuya and back. Once back at Skytree, we waited in a queue to get our tickets, then up we went. It was busy, as are most attractions in Tokyo, so you get used to it. The views were incredible. We went at night so they city was up in lights. You can see for a great distance, and it makes for some great photo opportunities. The crowds do get annoying though, so I'd pay the extra 1000 Yen to go to the higher deck as it's got less people up there. Deffo worth the wait.

Expensive, and a long queue, but worth it.. The views of Tokyo are unrivalled from the Skytree, especially in the morning. The endless sprawl of buildings is breathtaking, and on a clearer day with less haze and cloud, an amazing view of the majestic Mt. Fuji can be seen in the distance.I went quite early in the morning, and encountered a lengthy queue, although it was the New Year's holidays (2nd Jan). There was also a relatively high ticket price, but nonetheless it was definitely worth it for such excellent views.

Superb views of Tokyo. We queued for about 30 minutes on our mid week afternoon visit. Superb views of Tokyo but the weather was hazy so no views of Mt Fuji. Huge and differently decorated lifts whisk you 350m in an ear popping minute. As the weather was hazy we decided not to go to the very top.

Worth a visit. Like any other towers , the sky tree is another one that is for the experience. To be there before. It is nothing too different from other towers like Tokyo tower, 101, etc. that said, it view is actually quite astonishing. It is crowded but expected. The queue moves pretty fast though.

Kinda cool, fast lift.. lots of people. After getting into the line, thought I lined up for good 30 mins before getting into the lift.Lift is dam fast, the view from top is nice. Just fingers crossed you went at a good day. I had to visit a friend in the evening so i didn't go to the top of the top floor. Transportation a bit annoying cos you had to take an extra line on the train to get there and the walk to it seems like good 10 mins.. Not too short.. but feel a tat long..

A striking tower that is worth visiting. We went midweek and we arrived at approx 9:15a.m and it was queue free however 30 mins later on the observation decks was starting to get busy. The Sky Tree is further out and as such the views of the city aren't as good as those seen from the Mori Tower in Roppongi, which has a more central location. That said we still enjoyed the views, both towards the horizon and downwards, from the Sky Tree and for us the fact that it is the tallest 'tower' in the world made it even more worthwhile.It's an amazing structure to look at so make a point of going outside to look upwards. There is nothing else in the immediate vicinity to see but it's only a 15 min walk to Sumida River and Asakua.

The tallest tower in the world since 2012. For those who ever been to Tokyo Tower, they must be feeling nothing different even Tokyo Sky Tree Tower is the tallest tower in the world with height 634m while Tokyo Tower is only 333m. Tokyo Sky Tree was established since 2012 which also made this tower the youngest of all. However, I don't know why but i feel the same when i was in the top (350m) and see all over Tokyo. Its almost the same like Tokyo Tower, you can see 360 degrees of Tokyo, restaurant, glass floor, etc. However, even Tokyo Sky Tree is the tallest tower in the World, Tokyo Tower always be a landmark to take a picture with.

Nice view and good shopping. It was cold, raining and it was evening so the view from above was only ok. As usual, you don't expect anything less in Japan except for clean and modern designs. We went during christmas and it was nice to have some christmas theme events. The big screens at the top of Sky Tree to view a close up and switch from Night to Day of the buildings were really cool. The glass floors in some spots were also quite cool. However, since the weather was not good, we did not stay long at the top. The place was not crowded at all and the shopping above was ok, but a bit scattered with different variety of shops, and not much theme. I preferred the shopping mall on the ground floor instead.
Great views . This place was v popular at the weekend. I suspect it's easier midweek. Good views around, justifying the price but maybe not the queue.

Great Experience in Tokyo. Arrive early to avoid long lines or purchase a 'reserved' ticket as the wait can be long. Either way, the view, experience and activities available on the top make it well worth your time and effort. Spectacular views, even on a hazy day (couldn't see Mt Fuji when I visited). Significantly more impressive than Tokyo Tower. A definite 'must see/do' item.
Wow, I mean Wow. makes the london eye feel small, what an amazing feat of engineering and not anywhere nearly as expensive as the Shard or the London eye

A line to get to the line. This place is sort of like a mall with the sky tree as a main attractionIn order to get up, you have to go to the back of the main waiting area in order to get a slip of paper that states a time in which you're allowed to get into the queue. When that time comes, you go to the regular queue with that slip (could be an hour or two).

Worth to see. It is a fantastic place, a must see and experience landmark in Tokyo, with view of unimaginable quality, especially on a clear day. when we went there the weather was a bit foggy but still amazing views, they say when it is clear you can see the Mount Fuji.And the entrance is surprisingly cheap, so that was a good thing too. The lift takes you to the viewing level with the speed of the light, each lift has different themes,,,

Go early to make sure you get up the tower. I arrived at the Sky Tree only shortly after 9am but still had to queue for approx. 1and a half hours to get up. Admittedly it was a Sunday and the queuing itself was quite fun - a Japanese family (gracious as always) were very chatty and shared their sweets and drinks with me. There are the usual screens with information etc. videos to watch as well. It is well worth the wait.Be aware though that a fellow traveller who arrived a couple of hours after me was turned away and advised to return much later in the day. Pre-booked visitors, quite reasonably, go to the front of the queue. They have of course taken the risk that visibility will be good - it was crystal clear when I went.The view of this enormous, immaculate, city is spectacular to say the least. It certainly provides you with a great overview of all the different tourist areas of the city which are clearly distinguishable from this height. I did not go to the highest observation floor as there was another long queue and frankly it is hard to see how the view could have been any better.The Sky Tree was the first place I visited whilst in Tokyo and made me feel that navigation was going to be easy, which perhaps surprisingly it is. My tip would be to go there before you do anything else.The Sky Tree is a must go attraction in my opinion especially if you are lucky enough to have clear weather.

Good - but be prepared to wait.. We arrived around 3pm - but before you can go up, you have to first get a ticket for an allotted time. The earliest allotted time we could get was 6.30pm - which meant we had to wait around for a few hours (there's not huge amounts to do in the vicinity - and not really enough time to go and do something else then come back). It then took an hour of queuing before we finally got up to the top. By which time it was dark - I think it would have been better to go up during the day, or sunset. To be honest - a free alternative is to go to the Shinjuku Sumitomo Building, where from the 49th floor onwards there's a viewing area and several good value restaurants.

You Must go to the Top, loads to do. Big queues to get a ticket and you can't book on line without a Japanese credit card.Two options to climb the tower, take both as you go nearly as high as you can in Dubai/Burj.Great views, choose a clear day if you can and you might see Mount Fuji.

Being on the top is exciting but plan for plenty of time queueing. I wanted to go during the day but the when I got on level 350 it was already dark. The city underneath was amazing. I did not use the service of a travel agent, so I do not know if it is better to use one. Perhaps having it booked upfront saves time.  The fee is 2000 JY but it is up to the first deck. Thereafter if you wish to climb to the top, another fee and another waiting time.I do not regret at all, only the waiting was a bit too much.

Must go to attraction in Tokyo!. If you're visiting Tokyo you have to visit the Tokyo Sky Tree. The view is quite great and gives you a sense of how big Tokyo is! We went there in the late morning can't remember exactly what time but I would say 11ish... and the place was packed and the line was long! We had to wait for about an hour. The place as you may have read from other reviews has two levels the 350m and 450. Yes there is a fee and to get on to the 450m level you have to pay additional (Which we didn't because we were already satisfied with what we had seen on the 350m). If you're lucky (We weren't) I hear that you can even see Mt. Fuji! You can get pretty nice pictures of the view... but if you're expecting to have yourself in the picture with the view it can be a bit tricky, you'll most likely get silhouette pictures instead (unless you use your cameras flash)The place itself has souvenirs and other shops. Make sure you take pictures from the ground level too because at an angle you can get the entire thing as seen in my pics. Suggestion : It is a great place to visit but lines can be very long... so try to get there early

good to check off the list but super busy..... we waited in line on a Thursday for an hour to get tickets and then were herded like cattle into elevators. It was cool to say we did it but I would not say it was fun.

Only if you have plenty of time. To book a ticket online, you need a Japanese Credit card. Otherwise you need to queue up to take a ticket, which will tell you when to return to purchase the real ticket. Whilst waiting, there are a lot of shops, and food outlets to visit. We set out on a sunny day with clear skies- should have been great to see Mt Fuji. By the time we got to viewing platform, the weather had changed a few times, but it was too dull and cloudy to see Fuji. There was a good view of Tokyo, but a similar view can be had from a number of places, for free.I think Tokyo locals have the time to spend the day there, and to return another day if the weather turns poor, but for me, as a tourist with limited time, i would not recommend this.

Great location for 360 view of Tokyo. You have to go early(open 9am) to visit Tokyo Skytree, the first viewing gallery is 350m above ground, to me the unique experience is taking the Skytree Lift up to the viewing gallery, it is really fast and vibration-free, the travel time is 350m in a minute.The other, is the big shopping center next to Skytree, very well conceived. My favourite is it has a Studio Ghibli's (Hayao Miyazaki) character store where I could buy Totoro character items.

Recommend going at night. Tokyo Tower? Who cares about this, Tokyo Skytree is a definite must if your in Tokyo, the views are spectacular here. I went around 8am cause I knew I wouldn’t have any time later, but I imagine it’ll be better at night. Also there are so many things to do at the tower, and there’s even an aquarium.

Huge tower in Tokyo!. It's amazing to go up to the tallest tower in Japan. The view was memorable and we can't stop taking many photos. And there is a great shopping mall in lower floor, and we went crazy shopping afterwards. What a wonderful and enjoyable day! Highly recommend.

Spectacular View, Time-Consuming Experience. If you're looking for the best view of the city (on clear days), this is definitely the place to visit. The lines and cost, however, are steep, so don't waste either if you're not entirely interested (aka if you're only going because it's on someone's To-Do-List). Other options (for less cost and time) are Shinjuku's government observation towers (free), Landmark Tower in Yokohama ( between 1000-1500 yen), Sunshine City in Ikebukuro (between 500-1000 yen), and my personal favorite, Mori Tower City View in Roppongi, which includes the Mori Museum for the admission (between 1500-2000 yen). Happy viewing!

Sky Tree At Sunset Is Best. You are best off getting reserved tickets from the internet. Otherwise you will be given a number with a time on it and thus will have to come back at that time. Sunset gives you day and night views. Be sure to go to the top observatory, the difference is amazing!!

Interesting place. It's a nice place to visit. They have built beautiful aquarium. There is beautiful park downstairs. Kids will love this place. You can eat cold stone ice cream there. It's very delicious.

Overlook whole Tokyo and Mt.Fuji. It costs much but the view from the top is amazing and there's none like this in Tokyo. Better go there at about time of sunset, then you can see sun sets into Mt. Fuji's shoulder. It's unforgettably beautiful! Shopping area is very good for getting souvenir. Don't forget to try green tea icecream and parfait! There are also very good Japanese restaurants in Soramachi.

Great to look at...especially at night!. Having been to the Burj previously, I could not help but compare with it. Especially when I was going up the lift...I was reminded of the Burj and the excitement the music brought. Here the music is subdued but you have 4 lifts for different seasons. And yes of course both are different structures, this being a tower.Comparisons apart, if you are in Tokyo as a tourist and it's a clear day, you should not miss this. I went only up to 350m (why should I pay twice for 100 m?). We went up in the evening and Tokyo looked beautiful. Though I did not try, but I wanted to sit in the cafe up there, should be a nice feel.

Definately worth the time and money. This is a place to go if you are looking for a spectacular view. For me it was something I had never experienced before, eventhough I have visited quite many high towers/buildings before. One of the highlights of our trip to Japan.However, this is not a place for a quick visit. There is usually some waiting time, but if you are not totally agaist shopping and dining, the waiting is not a problem. We picked up our timeslot ticket at 14:00 and got a slot at 16:30-17:00. Went to have lunch an did some (window) shopping and then it was time to go and buy the actual ticket and head for the elevators. The weather that day was very windy and we had to stand in front of the elevator for some 10 - 15 min, when they were test driving empty elevators up and down. No one got up at that time and for a while it was a possibily that we can't get up at all. But we got up there and ended up staying there almost 3 h. View was just unbelivable. We saw daylight, sunset and night lights. During sunset we were sitting in the cafe and got seats directly facing Mount Fuji. Just magical.Kids went all the way up to 450 m. They said like many others that the view itself was not much different than at 350 m, but still worth going.When we first got up there, plenty of good spots were available by the windows and it was easy to move around and view different directions. After sunset the place was packed and not so easy to move around anymore. It was a Sunday and we expected Sky Tree to be crowded, but it was not too bad. Maybe because of the cold, windy weather. There was no standing in lines for us at anypoint. However we saw the space and arrangements reserved for massive ques. So, I assume sometimes there could be a lot more waiting than we experienced.

What A View!. If you are looking for a spectacular view of Tokyo this is the palce to go. Go early in the morning before the haze blocks the view of Mt. Fuji. We were there during the school holidays and could not go up until 2pm. The ticket line and the elevator lines move quickly. Really no need to spend the extra money to go to the very top. It was worth the wait and the cost. We walked from Sensoji Temple to the Sky Tree in under 30 minutes.
The best view of Tokyo. Fantastic views of Tokyo in all directions, fastest elevator on earth(?) and well organized and explanatory.

Such a long wait, but up there is fantastic. It's a conspiracy for the management to issue "waiting vouchers" - they are trying to ensure that you are going to spend at least 2 hours at the shopping mall downstairs before they allow you to queue for the "privilege" to buy a ticket to go upstairs. It takes another 45 minutes to queue up to the lifts.Overall I wasted 3 hours at Skytree town before I'm upstairs at the deck.The view is spectacular. Exciting. Do try to get up there around sunset so start queuing up around 1:30pm. As a photographer, they forbid usage of tripod, and the windows are all fenced off so I had to shoot through thick glass. Annoying. It is a very nice place, just I hate the queuing.

Don't miss it. Going all the way to Tokyo and missing the Sky Tree is something you should not let happen. Go all the way up to 350 meters and have a wonderful view of Tokyo with Mount Fuji further away. If you can, plan your visit for sunset time and bring a nice camera along. Pay 10 dollars more and climb up to 450 meters. It's worth it. Then have a drink at the Sky Tree cafe at 350 meters and relax appreciating Tokyo's landscape. Just be prepared to wait 30 min to 1 hour in line. :-)

Awsome view. We had to wait for about 15 min. The price of 2060¥ for the main platform and an additional 1030¥ for the higher level were totally worth the view. We went at around 17:00 so we could warch the city ar night, which is absolutly astonishing.

Great. Was a great experience going up the tallest tower in the world . Was very busy and had to queue for about an hour once up there we paid to go to the higher point and the views were great up there also got some pics on the glass floor which was pretty scary as I am quite nervous of heights. It's a shame they don't run an online purchase of tickets system like the burj khalifa as we found that a bit more organised. Overall a great experience of seeing the views in Tokyo.

Worth doing but get there early. Definitely worth doing as you won't get a better view of Tokyo than this.Be advised to arrive early as you will most likely receive a ticket with a later time to come back....maybe 3hours.As for going up the extra 100 metres to the Galleria i wouldn't bother, it looks exactly the same. Only difference is there are way less people up there.

Nice to see---if not overcast. The day we were there, the weather was overcast and the people at the Tower were trying to get people to go in. Few went due to the weather. I think this would be very impressive if the visibility was good.

Well worth the wait. Try and go on a clear day and mid week if you want to avoid the crowds. There will be a queue of some kind but the booking slot arrangement is well organised and works well.Its a stunning view from the top and does feel REALLY high. Whilst waiting there are plenty of eateries in the shopping area on lower floors, but again Japanese don't mind waiting for their food so I would go early or late.

First snowfall at the highest. It was raining that afternoon. However, when I was at 451.2m, I saw snowfall. It was very light and fluffy. The wind was blowing it in a circular direction. It was indeed a nice feeling - kimochi ne. An awesome experience!
A must see and do experience. An awesome experience. Worth waiting for. We only stood in line about 20 minutes and they really move you through in an effecient and friendly manner.

DON'T GO ON A WHIM!. So we were moderately excited about seeing the Tokyo Sky Tree, see as it's a massive great tower in the middle of town.We rocked up at 11 am and lined up to get a pre-ticket which advised us to come back to purchase the actual ticket at 1:30. So, we dutifully returned at 1:30 and entered the pre-queue. This queue was the queue to queue in before we could queue up to purchase the actual ticket.After about 45 minutes we noticed that we hadn't moved and there were actually another two queues in front of us. The security queue and the lift queue. At this point we gave up and went home.My advice to people hell bent on going here is to go on any Tokyo guided tour which includes Sky Tree admission. Even if the tour sucks, you don't have to line up like plebs.

Once In A Lifetime Experience. I've heard from so many people who have hiked up to Mt. Fuji that they will never do it again. I feel that way about the Skytree. It was a great experience--to see Tokyo from 430+ meters high. Views were amazing. The con to this is that the overall waiting time and the lines to buy tickets, to go into the elevator, to go even higher, make this a once in a lifetime experience for me. Very touristy. Overcrowded. People and lines everywhere, but absolutely incredible. Food vendors and shops are everywhere, so killing time waiting for the time on your exchange card is easy to do.Notes on the whole process: If you do not book in advance, proceed to the fourth floor upon arrival. Find the tent of employees handing out flyers for time slots. Take as many as there are guests. At the time marked on your card, or slightly before, proceed to the entry way to stand in line. You may be in line for 30 minutes or more. Initial tickets are ¥2000 per person. If you decide to go to the upper deck it is an additional ¥1000 per person and this fee is paid when you're up in the tree. If you do book in advance, wait time is much shorter. Plan on spending the whole day here. The Skytree grounds have many shops and lots to eat. Multiple souvenir shops can be found as well.Additional notes: decide whether you want to see Tokyo during the day or the night. It makes a big difference. We were in the 4:30 bracket so we were able to see the view of day, night, and sunset.

Go and see (but be aware of crowds). It's one of the places that doesn't really need a recommendation. You know what to expect being on the observation deck, 350m or 450m below see level in the huge, modern metropolis. So I don't want to write about impressions while being on top (views are just simply amazing), but more share some thoughts about organizing the trip there, as it could be tricky.So, I've been there today. Was planning to reach the top around 5pm., to see this amazing city during the day, sunrise and night. Reached SkyTree at around 4pm. and ... get inside around 6.30pm, just after sunrise. I knew that it'd be crowded, especially if the weather is good. But it's more about the system of entering. First you have to pick an exchange card with the details about an hours, when you have to be at meeting place. At 4pm I get the one for 6-6.30pm. It's good to stay around the meeting place just after entrance of the group before (in this case 5.30-6pm). But even then, you still have to wait inside the building, before all people from previous groups get their tickets. So all at all. Was there at 4pm. Got the exchange card for 6-6.30, was around the meeting place all the time and was one of the first in the queue. My group started to enter the building around 5.50 (was one of the first in the queue), collect my ticket at about 6.20, reached the top at 6.30. So calculate good if you want to reach the place at certain hour :) I think it's really worth it (I'll try once again:-).
Must-visit landmark !. The outlook of the building is good. The weather was bad when I visited there in Feb. Hope I can visit the observation deck in my next visit

Artfully Statuesque Must See Attraction. We visited the Skytree during evening evening hours so we enjoyed the added ambiance of the colored lights as they spiraled the tower. I was glad that I had chewing gum during the 50 seconds in the elevator, traveling upward to the 350th floor. The breathtaking view from the deck was well worth the wait in the long line to buy our tickets. Then go down to the 340th , stand on glass floor and look straight down. The view from there affects my equilibrium but I highly recommend this experience to anyone who is not afraid of gravity.

Go at night for beautiful views of city lights.. We ended up here at about 8pm after a lengthy but enjoyable walk from our accommodation in Asakusa. Thankfully there were no queues at all and we were able to buy our tickets and go straight up. We bought the cheaper tickets and went up to floor 350 - the views are pretty amazing. Seeing the city lit up like that at night is fantastic. I'm sure the views of the sunset would be phenomenal up there too, but i hear the crowds are pretty crazy at that time, while we had the place largely to ourselves. I felt that the glass floor bit was a little overrated - the glass section is not very big - but it might be better during the day when there's more light to see beneath you.If you're looking for great places to view the city, this is the place to go. The views are much better than the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building in Shinjuku, and for 2000 yen for the basic experience, it think it's reasonable value.

Wow!. Visited mid week at sunset. Crowds were predictably large at this time of day, be prepared to wait 1-1.5 hours. But totally worth the wait!! I understand why visitors compare it to a helicopter ride, you feel like you can see the whole city, which is very impressive. A must do, even if you are in the city only for one day.
Worth a visit. Went midweek so queues were not too bad. Loved the super fast lift! Fantastic view, tallest tower in the world!

Closed when we went... We made our way out to the Sky Tree, but weren't able to go to the viewing deck because of strong winds. We were a bit disappointed, but it's understandable. We enjoyed the massive food court instead.

Amazing + a couple tips. The SkyTree is AMAZING. Went with my Parents was definitely worth the price of admission which is 2000yen per person. You usually go early or late and if your lucky can go straight up but for the most part like when I went - lines were massive!! You go and get a card that allows you to come back at a certain time period which is really good so you don't have to sit in line forever!There is a shopping mall attached next door which is perfect way to kill time.The view is 360degrees and they have like these interactive screens to help navigate and get your bearings of what's what.. The elevator is really fast and is like getting in a spaceship.. Pretty cool.I'd recommend going at night, we went around 4pm and got a ticket for like 7pm or something so it was dark when we up the top. The city is beautiful and all lit up. Paying the extra 1000 yen is worth going up coz your already committed at 350m but personally I would skip it.. The view in my option was worse. At that height your so much above the city that all you see is roof tops. So if your got a family or budget conscious I wouldn't feel like your missing out too much if you skipped it! But for novelty factor I can understand.If its real busy do what we did and a good way to get a photo is buy a cheap coffee/drink from the cafe and they have a area cordoned off to customers only which is pretty much empty compared to the 3 deep perimeter around the windows..Enjoy

Overrated. The elevator ride was enclosed, so it did not give you the feeling that you're going up to the world's tallest tower. In a matter of seconds, the door opens, and you're at the observation deck. The observation deck is smaller than CN Tower (the previous tallest tower). There is also a glass floor, however it was so small! The view through the glass floor was also not impressive. The only cool thing about the Sky Try was the interactive computers that you can touch to identify landmarks and buildings.

The tallest tower in the world, amazing view !. No wonder it will become one of the top attractions in Tripadvisor.The tallest tower in the world (634m) opened in May 2012 and can be regarded as Tokyo's greatest symbol of modernity and futuristic design. It is located near Asakusa neighbourhood.You access the tower by getting down at Oshiage station (Tobu Skytree line, Tokyo metro Hanzomon line, Toei Asakusa line, Narita Sky Access Keisei Line) or Tokyo Skytree Station. The ticket counter is on the 4th floor.We came by the end of the day, around 5pm to be sure to watch the sunset. It was excellent to see it by day and by night as well. We queued up during less than 10 minutes, and finally got our ticket to the Tembo Deck (2000Y). Add 1000Y more to get to the highest floor, Tembo Galleria (450m). They charge 500Y more for "Advanced Purchases". Taking the elevator is an experience by itself. You feel the pressure as if you were on a plane.Once arrived, the view is breathtaking and spreading around 360°! There is a map to help you identify all the buildings surrounding you. Tokyo looks like an urban ocean...But for those who hope to see Mount Fuji, remember that its top remain cloudy around 200 days a year...Good luck ! There are usually many visitors, so be patient as well. I was a bit disappointed by the glass floor because it's quite narrow. But still interesting though. From there, you can watch the very clever anti-seismic system than consist in a big, central pillar suspended above the ground - it absorbs the energy of the earthquake.Is Tembo Galleria worth a look ? Definitely ! Feels like being in a spacial spacecraft...Unforgettable experience.After the tour, you may go to the mall, with many fancy shops and restaurants around.

A unique experience, must see at night, and from 450 meters. Trust me, I have been to the Tour Eiffel, Burj Khalifa, Tokyo tower... It has nothing to compare to the sky tree. An amazing 360 view of all Tokyo, that you can see better with the lights at night. Worth it to go to the 450 meters, since you pay only 1000 yen additional to the 2000 yen you already paid for the 350 meters view, and on top there is less crowd, and the shape of the outside glasses are round and very freaky. You should also try the glass floor at 359 meters, this one was great but not unique... We didn't have a lot fo traffic, we went there At 7.30 p.m and entered directly.

Gotta love that sunset. Very lucky to be able to go on top of the tower during the sunset. As expected, many people were crowding the sides, so you need to be patient and slowly work your way to the front of the deck. It was really a breathtaking view, especially during the sunset, as the yellow sun slowly went down, taking all lights with her, and the night lights slowly came to life. There is a section where the floor is made with seen through glass. It was only a small portion, wasn't really scary. There was another small glass section where we could view through without shoes blocking the way, but the view was mainly of pillars, a let down.There is a cafe on top of the tower, a souvenir shop at the bottom, near the exit area.

Recommend to go at night!!. The night view was extraordinary!!! Tokyo Tower and Roppongi was amazingly beautiful from Sky tree! Definitely worth to spend 3000 Yen to the top of the observatory. And also it is not too crowded if you go at night! The only inconvenience point is that you can only buy top floor access ticket at the normal observatory, not the ticket boxes at the entrance.....Don't know why they decided to do this.
Tokyo "must see". If you ever go to Tokyo this is one of the places you have to visit! Breathtaking view and a cool experience if you like it in the heights.

You need to be here to know the feeling. There are two levels. Level 1 is at 350 m and the upper level is at 450 m. You can buy tickets based on your requirement. They have also made a glass walk thru at the 350 m level. It is one of the scariest thing i have done. It is not easy to step on that glass and look down while your brain is telling you it does not trust the glass to take your weight.

Simply Amazing!. We visited the sky tree in the evening, it was dark out, so all you could see in the distance was lights, they stretched so far away. It was so beautiful, and it gave you such an amazing feeling. It is well worth paying extra to visit the top floor, its much quieter and you can see everything. We must have spent at least an hour just staring out the window.The glass section of the floor was terrifying yet brilliant. You could see the entrance beneath you, and it really emphasised how high up you were!

A must see attraction and a must see from the highest point. I'm not a big tourist attraction type person but I really enjoyed this. It is REALLY high and view is amazing. I was not disappointed and glad we went. If you are in Tokyo this is a must see. There is a small fee but my hosts paid so I don't know what it is to get in. But pay the extra and go to the higher level. Don't forget to take a photo from the base looking up. There is also a cafe and fine dining here.

Not to be missed.. Ultra modern lift which is huge by Japanese standards will whisk you up to the viewing floor without any sensation of speed. Winter is the best season for viewing the sprawling city with unobstructed views all round the tower. The glass floor is another interesting feature. It takes a steady nerve to stand on the glass blocks and look down all the way to ground level. The food court has a good variety of Japanese food and the prices are not higher than normal.

Worth It. I wasn't sure how much of a must see this really was, but it was close to Asakusa and I figured I could probably speed through when they opened if it wasn't for me. With that said I was determined to dodge any lines and showed up at around 8:05AM. No lines at that hour, but looking at the signs and queues they have organized it seems like it could get really bad during peak hours and the weekends.That said all my doubts were forgotten once I got to the top. It really is a powerful view, to see just how expansive and dense this city is and what populations really look like. It was initially overwhelming. This was all despite it being a somewhat hazy morning, I'd imagine seeing it on a clear day or night would be that much better. They did a good job of providing info on the decks and adding some good ambiance. I paid the extra 1,000 yen to get to the highest deck,and I thought it offered a good contrast and was glad I did. I was out the door in around an hour and a half, feeling like I'd taken my time, but I definitely felt like I got my monies worth. It's also one stop away from Asakusa, so combining the two in a morning worked out really well.

star light. star bright even though it's been overshadowed by its bigger brother...but still worth a visitgreat way to get an overview of Tokyo and attempt to take it all in.... such an expansive city with so many wonderful sights
Loved the view. I loved the view from the top of the sky tree, especially the fast elevator and the thick glass where standing on it gives you an imagination that you are floating up in the sky
Awesome view. Tokyo is an enormous city and if you want to appreciate the size of it you need to go up the Skytree. We want up late afternoon and got to see the sunset and the city lights come on.

Stunning Views. Stunning views combined with typical Tokyo ultra modern facilities and amenities (malls, restaurants etc.). Easy to access via subway. Two viewing platforms, worth paying the extra to go all the way up (450m) and look out for the laser graphics which make for great photos.

Great view and easy to reach. The new sky tree is connected directly to a metro station so easy to reach. Although busy when we went (Monday 11am) the lines moved quickly with a wait of about 30 minutes. The view was spectacular and well worth the 2000yen ticket price

Tokyo Sky Tree. This was part of a half day city tour, we arrived around 4pm, the line for the elevator was Short. There are 2 ticket options you can pay to go up to floor 350 for 2,000 yen and and if you want to go to floor 450 you have to purchase a separate ticket for 1,000 yen. Since we were there late in the afternoon we were able to see the daytime and the night time view. We paid for the second ticket and went to floor 450 the view from the top was pretty good, not fantastic, this was due to the weather and thats something you can't control. It was very interesting stand on the sections of glass floor looking all the way down to the street. We thought it was worth a visit and it was exciting going from floor 350 to 450 since it was a glass elevator and you could see outside. there are quite a lot of eating and shopping options. One of the things I love about Japan is that the people are so polite and they have the best customer service.

Top of the World. We visited the restaurant at the top of the Skytree with our friends who live just outside Tokyo in Yokohama. It was an amazing experience especially in the fastest lift and the view from the top was unbelievable. The food was good although I think we were paying for the location more than the quality of the food. The service was good and we took lots of pictures at the end with the help of a lovely waiter. It's a really great experience - don't miss it- but book early - we booked about 2 months before as we were a large party.

Great views from Tokyo Sky Tree. We visited Tokyo Sky Tree and were thrilled by the views of Tokyo. Even though it was cloudy, the views were excellent. The scary part was the glass panels in the floor that allow you to see all the way to the ground. I actually got the courage to stand on the glass, but sure didn't stay long. It is generally pretty crowded, but there's window space enough to see out without looking over people's shoulders.We didn't pay the extra fee to go to the top, so I can't comment on that.Don't miss the night view of the tower to see the different colored lighting. I think there are 4 different patterns with the patterns rotating each night. It was blue the 1st night we were there and purple the 2nd.

Perfect Observatory. We went here at night time. Perfect to take landscape photography. Entrance costs 2000 yen and if you wish to visit the tembo deck you have to pay for another 1000 yen. Japanese have excellent customer service.

One of the tallest tower I've been. So far, this is the tallest tower I've visited, we've reached only up to 350m viewing deck and i would say that this is really awesome experience. We went there at almost 6pm and it has spectacular view at night, as you can also see the lights from different places. You just need to pay 2000 yen for the first level and additional 1000yen if you want to go up for more. They offer souvenirs and photoshot for free, unless if you like the picture taken by the staff of Tokyo Sky Tree you just need to pay 1200yen if Im not mistaken. We got one for souvenir. The tower itself is great with one of the fastest elevator. My ear aches as it reaches on much higher floors, but I dont mind because I know at the end of it, it would show me the spectacular views of Tokyo Metropolitan area.

Awesome view to Tokyo. I visited the skytree Sunday. I arrived by foot from Asakusa, it took about 20 minutes but worth to see all the perspectives if the Skytree. When you arrive closer and closer it is really impressing!!Try to get there as early as possible because after 10 am the crowed is really impressing. A lot of Japanese tourists and foreigners of course. Go just up the the first observatory deck, you have 2 floors here to see Tokyo and surrounding area, mountains and if you have the chance, even Fujisan!!!!Really. Be patient, with the position of the sun all around views are changing.The Skytree functions like a town, up to the train level you have money exchange, tourist office and many shops including one dog shop, meaning everything you need for your dog. The view from the 45th floor is a real wonder. Tokyo is if you were in Sim city....

Impressive Tower. The tower is truley an engineering marvel. It is the tallest tower in Japan. It is in a complex with lots of shops and restaurants. The only negative is that you have to be Japanese in order to book a time/date to go up the tower. That is because the web site is the only way to do it, it is only in Japanese, and to reserve you must use a Japanese issued credit card. The only way that foreigners can visit is to join the line and take your chances. Most world class sights don't impose such restrictions, the Sky Tree should join the 21st century.

Sky Tree. Quite literally as the name says. The view from 451 mtrs is quite something. On the really clear day, one can see Fuji San (active volcano) from the Sky Deck. The tower also boasts of one of the fastest large capacity elevators in Japan.

Tallest in 2012. Tokyo Sky tree built in 2012, tallest structure in Japan. You have to purchased your tickets in advance,if not you can't get a ticket at the counter. view of Tokyo is beautiful, must go.

worth the price. There's no better place to have a view about the gigantic city. The queue was extremely long, I think that we waited for almost an hour before getting to the elevator.There are two levels from which to gaze down on Tokyo: I would recommend buying a ticket for the upper level too. You don't get to Asia's highest tower every day!I would also recommend picking a day where the weather is clear so that you can admire the magnificent Mount Fuji.Access is extremely easy with the Oshiage metro line. There's plenty of lunch / dinner options in the shopping mall at the feet of Skytree.If you want to eat at the Skytree restaurant, you have to make a reservation at least some days in advance.

Appreciate Tokyo's scale from 450m up!. The line was massive, and we found out it was just the line for the reservation, which would be for two hours later. Distraught and ready to bail, a kind man approached us and gave us a reservation card for ten minutes later. We enthusiastically accepted it, and got in another big line. We were super lucky - my advice is to plan to swing by early for a reservation, then to come back.The ticket for the 350m viewing deck was 2000 yen.The elevator that took us up had a glass ceiling, which allowed us to look up and appreciate how fast it was traveling. There doesn't seem to be much between the 5th floor and the 350m level, and the entire elevator ride was less than a minute.I believe the glass floor was on this level. You can stand over 350m of nothing and look down. Pretty chilling!After spending an hour on this deck and watching the sun set, we decided to go up higher. This cost an extra 1000 yen, and involved waiting in line again, but it was completely worth it.The elevator takes you to 445m and you walk the climb the last 5m by ascending a ramp that rings the structure. The night viewing was amazing.I'd spent quite a bit of time in Tokyo, but I'd never appreciated its true scale as one of the ant-like people below, crossing streets and exiting subway stations. From here, you could see that the tall buildings just keep going off into the distance. It really is a sprawling metropolis!
Amazing Tower!. We had gone to the skytree a few months back and when you go up you will stop for a few minutes thinking that huge Japan/Tokyo is! Had to make reservations but well it was worth it!
Sky Tree tower. Loved the view at night and the shopping was pretty awesome too! Little pricey, but the views are amazing!

Awesome. When I planned my trip to Japan, this was one of the things that I wanted to see the most. It did not disappoint. The views of the city are incredible, and put in perspective just how massive of a city Tokyo really is. It's definitely worth paying the extra 1000 Yen to go to the Tembo Galleria deck at 450m. I didn't experience any wait to get inside when I went there (around 9AM on a Wednesday), but there were still a lot of people inside. While in Tokyo, I also visited some of the other towers and observation spots, and while they were great in their own right, in my opinion, they don't quite measure up. If you go to Tokyo, you have to check this out.

Tokyo's Must-see Attraction. Tokyo Sky Tree is about five minutes walk from the Station of Oshige (Sky Tree). It is the tallest man-made structure in Japan (Second tallest in the world) and from the top of the tower you enjoy the best view of Tokyo City. It is absolutely a breathe-taker, it is definitely worth to pay to climb all the way to the top.Google search "Sky tree view" and find out what to expect!

A long wait. I qued for 3 hours but it was worth it to say ive been on the tallest tower in the world, easy to get to as its like a minuite walk from the subway stop once you master the underground which took me three attempts. you do have to pay to get on it but its not that much and kids go free so all in all a good trip

Worth for 3 hours wait. I was there around 8:00AM, due to Japanese public holiday, I waited for 3 hours to Sky Tree. I am not lineup for 3 hours, I got a queue card at 10:30AM for purchasing ticket NOT entry, so I shop around the gift shop and had a breakfast. I believe you will not need to wait for that long, as long as you are not visit there during public holiday. Note: Recommended length of visit is not include queue time.

A Part of the New Tokyo. If you are a tourist to Tokyo, it is definitely worth a visit to look over the entire vista -- after all, if you make the trek all the way to Tokyo, why not visit one of its newest landmarks. But beware of the lines to enter; you can get some tickets in advance online but not to the very top platform. But the line moves, and if you know about it in advance, it won't take you by surprise to know you have to allow for it. There is a restaurant at the 350 meter level (Skytree Restaurant 634) that takes reservations, and it would have been a pleasant way to end our visit had we known. But the day we went, the restaurant was fully booked. However, there are several restaurants on the lower levels (6th and 7th floors) and we found a very good tempura spot. If you don't know Tokyo, it is difficult to pick out specific landmarks, but the views give you some idea of the magnitude of the city. We waited in line a lot longer than we actually spent on the 350 meter and 450 meter levels, but we all thought it was worth the trip. It is easily accessible via subway so make that part of your adventure!

Tokyo from above. The Sky Tree in Tokyo is an impressive building that offers an amazing view over Tokyo. But it is also a bit pricy and the queues builds up really fast. On my visit I naively thought that I saw the whole queue when I arrived as I was early, so I decided to queue up. I was wrong, there actually was one second hall of queue, but then it was to late to change my mind i sensed. Going tot the top floor you actually need to stand in another line to buy a second ticket. And as said is quite pricy, as modern Japan tend to be.If you're in to this type of attractions of course you should go, but it comes at a price.

Overrated and Not Worth the Price and Wait. The Sky Tree is one of the landmark buildings in Tokyo. The view is supposed to be spectacular. Unless you check in advance, you don't realize that if you show up without an advance reservation, you will be have to wait at least two hours before you can get to the top. In the meantime, there is a mall just waiting for you across the plaza. It was packed with people, many of whom probably didn't realize that they needed advance reservations. By the time we got to the top it was close to 4pm and the sun was greatly affecting getting any good photos of major parts of Tokyo. It wasn't worth the $20 each we paid...and we didn't even get to the very top...another $10 we refused to pay.

Great city views. If you are sightseeing in Tokyo i recommend to visit here. The procedure is that you arrive at the ticket gate and collect a token to come back at a set time. Both times i have done this i have not waited more than an hour to go up when returning to buy the tickets. If you arrive at around 2pm i think you will be allocated tickets around 5-6pm. Sunset is definitely the time to be at the top. It might be a good idea to collect your time voucher to go up the sky tree and then visit Asakusa shrine and return after that to go to the top. There is also a good Hawaii burger restaurant in the shopping mall.

Great View long lineup. The view is simply amazing. The overall atmosphere is beyond any other modern observatory, you can sense the joy and amusement from foreign and local traveler. Only problem is, its a VERY long line up just to purchase tickets. We went on a public holiday, the lineup to get ticket was well over 80 minutes, and them there is the line to get up to the observatory. Do make ticket reservation online to avoid the first lineup. Not recommended if you are traveling with small children, due to the same reason.Gift shop is very very busy, there are items that you can't find anywhere else, but its just typical tourist souvenir gift shop, don't spend too much time here, instead go to the Skytree shop on the main floorDo plan for at least 2 hours due to the line up, the worse that could happen is you finish in less than 2 hours, in which case, you can just hop over to Asakusa/Kappabashi

Great view, but excruciating wait. The Tokyo Sky Tree has an amazing view of Tokyo hands down. It was really great to see the sheer size of the city from that high up and I got a bunch of great pictures.However, the experience was soured by the stupendously long queue to get tickets. My friend and I waited in the queue for nearly 2 hours before we got our chance to go up to the viewing deck. The queue snakes multiple times through the lobby and really makes you wonder how inefficient the ticketing process could possibly be to result in this. If you want to visit, I'd recommend trying to find a time that's least crowded, so your experience isn't impacted by the queue.

Loved the walk there more than the Sky Tree itself. It is impressive to look up at it from below. And I'm sure it's more impressive once you go up, but being as it was a cloudy/rainy day we figured there would be little visibility so we decided not to.However it was still worthwhile to put it in our itinerary because it allowed us to see all kinds of interesting things on our way there. We got off at Asakusa metro station and instead of making a B line to the tower we took a detour though the side streets. Check out the pics. Official tower website : http://www.tokyo-skytree.jp/en/

Overpriced with long, long queues!. At 350M above sea level the views are amazing, but expect very,very long snaking queues. We visited on a slightly overcast day which detracted a little as the clarity was not great, but we could just make out Mt. Fuji on the distant horizon. We didn't wase our money on going up to the 450M level due to the overcast day. Try and get there early to avoid the queues (it's amazing that you can't purchase tickets in advance or online to speed up this process. We waited in the queue for 55 minutes around noon. Also, it's not too far from the 'Golden Poo' (Asahi Brewing Company headquarters) and we walked there after out Skytree visit - about 15 minutes, to have lunch and enjoy an Asahi ! If you visit the Senso-Ji and Gojunotou (five tiers) temple complex and shopping area around Nakamise St in Asukusa, it's also a nice 20-25 minute walk from the Asukusa area along the Sumida River over to the Tokyo Skytree.

Loved Sky Tree!. We were on our way to Asakusa and saw Sky Tree when we came out of the train station. We visited Asakusa previously, so quickly changed our plans and walked over there -- there is a train station to get there and we did take it on the return -- there was a very long line to get tickets, but it moved very quickly -- maybe a half an hour to get the tickets. Then a line to get on one of the elevators but they come often. You can spend as much time as you like there -- there is a small snack bar for drinks and ice cream. There are restaurants as well. Sky restaurant 634 needs reservations. The Skytree Cafe is first come first serve we -- we had to wait about 10 min. to order our curry lunch and it was tasty. Highly recommend a visit. Oh, and there are a lot of souvenir shops.

A great way to get a feel for the geography of Tokyo. I can never get over how sprawling this city is! Had a great time with my dad figuring out the layout of the city and trying to spot his hotel and my apartment. I'd been told there might be a long wait but we only had a ten minute wait for tickets then went right up so I guess wait times depend on time of year. Easy walking distance from Asakusa so it's great to couple a trip to the sky tree with a visit to Asakusa and the temple there.

Mount Fuji at Sunset. I missed Sky Tree during my last visit, but not this time.Wondering why they called it "Sky Tree", not "Sky Tower"Its definitely higher than Tokyo Tower, and longer queues as well. But worth the wait. Inside the elevator, you can read how high you are.. 350m above the ground for the first viewing deck. If you visit during sunset, and you are lucky enough, you can see Fujiyama from the distance with red and gold cloud during the sunny day.. amazing view and felling….Try the restaurant on top, great view...Definitely a must go. Don't forget also the Sky Tree city, food and shops that you don't want to miss. Be advised, don't eat during the dining time.. long queue…

Excellent view, but long queues. Be prepared for long queues to get in.
It is a shame that you can not pre-book with non Japanese credit cards
The view from the top of the Skytree is excellent. It is worth paying the extra 1000¥ to go to the 450m level from 350m

Amazing view, definitely worth it. Go on a clear day, then the view is more than spectacular. We were able to see as far as Mt. Fuji. Being up there really makes you realize the size of the city. I have read that people feel it's overpriced. I say it's definitely worth it, at least the observation deck at 350 m. (2.000 Yen) If you're looking to save a little money, skip the deck at 450 m (1.000 Yen extra), it's nice but not that different from the lower point.Also, really do get there as early as possible to buy tickets. It gets really crowded very fast, we got there about half an hour after opening and there were already a lot of people there.

worth a visit. is quite a long queue at the ticket counter, but did not take long time to wait for my turn. the elevator speed is impressive, reach the viewing deck in a blink of eyes. i would suggest visit there during the sunset time and you can see the metropolitan slowly glow in the dark.

Don't Miss It. Queue was about 70 mins but well worth it with amazing felling and views from first and second viewing platforms. You can have funky memento picture taken on top level, to collect at ground level.TIPS- do the food/drink/wc runs before queueing- allow an hour for shop looking- subway is the best way to get there, right underneath

Various interesting shops and restaurants. I didn't go up to see the view of Tokyo due to inclement weather, but the shops and restaurants at the bottom of the tower were all interesting! I got to buy some traditional, hard-to-find goodies, and relaxed having a green tea ice cream.

Great View!. An impressive view of greater Tokyo unfolds before you from the main viewing deck. I didn't apy the additional money to go up higher in the Sky Tree. This is definitely worth doing once - nighttime is a great time to go.

Neat experience spoiled by crowds. I had been looking forward to visiting since it opened up and having been more than a year since its opening, I had incorrectly assumed the wait times would have improved. They have, but the lines are still long. We arrived at 8:20am and waited about an hour to make our way to the elevator line, which then took another 20 minutes. The views were pretty amazing despite the crowds. There are large touchscreen monitors pointing out various landmarks but they were often occupied. The whole time, I felt like I was in a herd. I didn't bother going to the higher observation deck so I don't really know what I missed. The glass floor tiles were interesting but smaller than I was anticipating. Bathrooms at the top are the clean, Toto toilet equipped facilities, that unbelievably were empty (for Men's at least).At the bottom of the tower, there's a lot of shops to go through selling every imaginable Sky Tree-related paraphernalia. Needless to say, we dashed for the exit to escape the crowds.Overall, it was an interesting attraction. Granted, it's not cheap, but the views are fantastic and it's a pretty cool tower. It's a shame that you have to hold a Japanese credit card to reserve and purchase tickets beforehand. Hopefully in a couple of years when the crowds die down, the experience will be more enjoyable. Also, bring a book, a 3DS or something to do while waiting in line.

“Smashing” place of Tokyo. Tokyo Sky Tower, is also known as “New Tokyo Tower”. This is the majestic monument in the world. It is tallest free-standing tower of the world, which offers stunning sights to behold your breath. You can purchase tickets from there as well as book your tickets online in advance to enjoy the picturesque views from the Tokyo Tower.Apart from, sightseeing, this place also consists of several restaurants so that you can enjoy anytime meal. They are considered about your comfort, so they are always willing to help you. This tower is the broadcasting and observation tower as well, which is designed in metamodernis. This place is worth the visit.
