burp, did I just spend 4000 yen. okay this place will hold better times in the future but not just yet. still being a new attraction its over populated and no fun standing in line. we stood for an hour and 45 minutes thinking it has to be worth it. on arrival to the top it too was overly crowded the entire 360 degrees. your photo's at night wont come out well unless you have a decent camera. if you think you will be back to Tokyo in the future I would wait it out.  reading other reviews I see the way to go is purchase tickets on line. we did the Sensoji temple and said lets go there pointing at the Sky Tree. we also didn't find the convenient train to the main station right at the Sky Tree till we arrived. walking is healthy but from the temple took about 30 minutes.

Fantastic view!. We went to Tokyo Skytree as part of the Hato Bus Tour. The place is a very popular tourist trap. It was quite crowded as expected. Expect long wait and lines for the elevators. However at night, the view of Tokyo is amazing at 450 meters up in the sky! The second tallest structure in the world. You do have to pay an entrance fee to go to the 350M then another fee to go up to 450m at the observation deck. There is a glass floor area(small) where you see all the way down. You have to take a few elevator or escalators from top to the first floor. They want you to spend money at the restaurants and gift shops.Overall it was decent experience to go there once.

Pricey but Fun. My husband and I enjoyed the Sky Tree in the morning (probably around 10 AM or so) on our recent visit to Tokyo and loved it. The sheer size of the city is just not understood until you see it from these heights-- it's phenomenal. We spent a good hour up there, enjoying the view (and people-watching- another awesome part of the experience). On clear days (particularly in the late Fall and winter), you can see all the way to Mt. Fuji. We lucked out-- and what a sight it was. That alone was worth the price of admission, which is admittedly high. Don't pay extra to go to the secondary observatory, as the base itself is good enough.

What a view. An amazing experience and a perfect example of Japanese engineering. We went in the evening. long queue to get up to the top, but well worth it. It was dark by the time we arrived at the viewing platform, but the views of Tokyo at night are stunning. A must see for Tokyo.

didn't go up the tower....but it was still great.. We didn't get a chance to go to the the deck and catch a view because the tickets where sold out for the times we had available....so we made the most of it and visited the other spots. surrounding the structure is a mall about 6-7 stories. it's broken down into restaurants, retail, and entertainment spaces. lots of things to see, we went on the night that they where lighting up the christmas tree....so it got pretty crowded.

Long queues. Understandably the Japanese should be and are very proud of this mammoth structure and you can't deny it, it offers spectacular views across the city. Try and get there for sunset and take in the bay and Fuji in the distance with its changing moods and hues. Unfortunately everyone else will have the same idea. The day we went the queues were horrendous, we waited over 2 hours and perhaps they should have put a little bit more effort in entertaining the lines, Disney style, to alleviate the boredom and built up the anticipation. You don't actually get to the top on the first go, you are about three quarters of the way up at the main level and you get the opportunity to buy tickets to the highest level. Again the queues here were shocking. The whole operation to go up and come back would've probably taken us 4 hours or so and a good few quid. Not cheap.It's also located on a slightly outlying area of Tokyo a fair walk from the Metro station though it does have its own premium line that links it to the city.Saying all that it's a must, after all it is the highest tower in the world though the Burj Khalifa in Dubai is nearly 200 metres higher

Over-rated & Overpriced. I feel that it is not necessary to go to the observatory because it is too expensive (2500yen). I went up once and I only spent 10 minutes there because there is nothing much. If you want to see the night scenery of Tokyo, you can go to Tokyo Tower instead(not so crowded and is cheaper). Nevertheless, it is good to visit there to shop for tokyo banana and do take a photo with tokyo skytree.

Tallest tower in the world. The Tokyo Sky Tree is a must see! For the cost of 3000 JPY you go up to the observatory deck (a little more if you want to go to the very top). It is the tallest tower in the world and is more than twice the height of Sydney tower (Centrepoint) just to give you some idea.We went on a Friday night after having dinner in the shopping mall below and the weather was pristine. It was a little crowded as most of Tokyo is but the view is breathtaking. I recommend either going as a couple or with family. Must do romantic activity for couples visiting Tokyo.

One of the best Towers. This is one of the best towers I have been to around the world. One word of advice, it gets BUSY! Make sure you go early in the morning to get a ticket which will tell you a time later on when you can go in. Lots to do around the tower so you can make a day of it :)

Huge Engineering Marvel. Tokyo Skytree is a broadcasting, restaurant, and observation tower in Sumida, Tokyo. It is located about a half mile east of Asakusa and the Sumida River (five to six miles northeast of central Tokyo.) The Tower is about 2,100 feet high and is the 2nd tallest structure in the world (it’s the tallest tower in the world).I went about 5 PM on a Sunday evening and the place was very crowded. The process to buy a same day ticket was very confusing as there appear to be several lines. I stood in a couple of lines and gave up as I was not sure what I was doing. Plus I heard the wait could be 2-3 hours long and for me it was not worth the wait. The Skytree website says you can buy advance tickets if you have a credit card issued in Japan (that is not very helpful). My US AMEX card worked every time I tried it in Japan but for some reason it won’t work on the Skytree website. If I ever go back I will go early in the morning when the line is reported to be very short.Even though I did not have the time or motivation to go to the top, I enjoyed my visit and think the Skytree is nice to look at from the ground. The structure looks very complicated as you can see the inner part of the Tower from the ticket office level. I am not an engineer but think this is an impressive engineering marvel. Overall I enjoyed my trip to the Tokyo Skytree and recommend it if you are visiting Tokyo for more than one or two days. My only complaint was the overly complicated process to purchase a ticket.

A must do whilst in Tokyo.. This is somewhere everyone must go to whilst in Tokyo.It cost 3,000Y, around £18 to go to the very top but the view from there, (450m up) is unbelievable.I'd say this is the most incredible view I've ever seen!There is also so much information available whilst there with staff everywhere!!A great experience!

Tokyo Sky Tree. I visited Tokyo Sky Tree on my one, which I probably shouldn't have done, cuz I missed my boyfriend and all the other visitors were mainly couples :(. It took about two hours from I came to I finally got into the tower. But when I finally got to the 340 floor, it was all worth it. The view was so beautiful, especially from 450 floor where I saw the sunset. All in all a great experience, but I think the ticket (3,000 yen in total) was a bit too expensive.
Tokyo Skytree - wonderfull. This attraction is a must see in Tokyo. I recommend to go there before opening hours in the morning to beat the queue. It is quite crowded during the day.
Absolutely mind blowing. Words can't describe how the view makes you feel. You just have to go, if you find yourself in Tokyo. It's a must.

Tokyo sky tree. I gonna show you Tokyo sky tree near the Oshiage station. I would like to recommend three Things. First of all, Tokyo soramathi, which is a lot of shops. So I walked with eating. This is good idea. Try to do it!Secondly, Sky view. Actually, there were so crowded. But more than that, sky view was so romantic. The atmosphere was special. If you take a date, that is good place.Finally, candy show. We can watch how to make candy. Men in candy shop has magical hands and technic . I was really interested in it. If you like pretty candy, please go there . You must enjoy it! That's it. Thanks.

Interesting speciality shops and lots of restaurants. Worth a visit, did brunch there in a cute little curry place, the shops are cute, you do tend to stare at the set up, amazing. The view is incredible, easy to get to as metro line takes you straight there. What was worth seeing is the way in which people commute here...keep left in every way, and there is a LOT of people flowing like a rapid .... Amazing

Crazy busy. Be a warned that you need to either get here really early or buy tickets online before you arrive. If you do what I did and nturn up after lunch expect a 3 hour wait!! That being said there are a lot of shops around to keep you amused during that time but it can be drag. Its because of this I didn't bother going up. The building itself though is stunning. Engineering losers like myself should defiantly go as it really is a fantastic building that deservesnsome admiration. If you want some nice photos I suggest walking moved the bridge towards Asakusa where you can get some stunning shots
Yes there's a que, but.... It really is a remarkable feat of engineering, worth seeing at least for the spectical. The views at night make waiting in the que worth it.

BE AWARE OF THE QUEUE!. Be aware; there will always be a queue, so get in EARLY or you may have to come back later. You can also book tickets online before you go, I am aware that this may cost an extra fee but if you value your time I recommend this option. The wait time for us was an hour and a bit, but for the people at the back of the line it must have been closer to 4 hours wait. There are no amenities available within the queue either - so this would not be ideal with Children. On a clear day you are able to see all the way out to Mt Fuji! However it was not that clear for us, but we were happy with everything that we saw because we were already going to see Mt Fuji on another day. So I do not recommend going up if the weather is not the best. There are neat little trinkets and gifts that you are able to buy at the top of the sky tree or if you do not want to make your way up there but still want gifts, there are things available within the shopping plaza at the sky tree.

Weekday sunset. I went up top on a weekday, so it was much less crowded than weekends. Once you get up top there actually is no time limit, so if you head up before sunset, and stop at the cafe for a drink, you will get the day and night views!
High in the sky. Get in early, be prepared to queue. Take lots of pictures and have an ice cream. Don't rush if you don't have to. Hope for a clear day, as the views across Tokyo are just brilliant.

Highly Recommended but do pick an off-season timing!. Queued for tickets & to go up for about slightly over 2 hours. Was anticipating the view, and being a clear day, we were hoping to see a different view of Mt Fuji. Once you get into the queue to purchase tickets, there is no sitting down or breaks you can take without losing your spot. I was glad my parents were able to get through ok. I must say that crowd-control was executed well, because when we finally get up to 350 metres, it wasn't as crowded as what it was like downstairs, and we didn't have to squeeze to have a proper view of the skyline. We were able to walk around without any pushing or shoving. The view was breathtaking, particularly on a clear day, but was very disappointed not to see even a vague silhouette of Mt Fuji. We were able to identify some key spots with the help of the map, but otherwise, we would never had known. We had wanted to go up to 450 metres, but was discouraged by yet another queue to purchase the tickets (you cannot buy this at ground floor) and we figured the view would be similar so we went back down. To get down, you need to walk down a few flights of steps (2-3 floors), which is fun, as you will be able to step on the "glass corridor" to see the view right down. While it's a little costly to get up I would still recommend it. I'm just not sure if waiting more than what we had waited was worth the while. During the queue I did some search and it seems you can buy tickets online or via travel agencies - if this is possible, would highly recommend it, as the queue would only be limited to going up, which would be no more than a 15-30 minutes wait.

Beautiful, but I expected more.... Two days prior to visiting Tokyo Sky Tree I have visited the Suspended Gardens in Ossaka. I was impressed with the height of the tower and the amazing view!After more than 3 hours wait to finally reach the elevator that takes me 350 meters up, I was a bit disappointed. The view (déja vu) is all there is to it. Ok it's quiet an experience to be this high in the sky, you actually feel the air pressure in your ears. It's also nice to be in the tallest tower in the world. But to me definitely not worth the wait and the fatigue that queuing for so long caused.
Wow! I thought the Seattle Space Needle was tall! This thing is HUGE!. You will not be disappointed. a MUST see.Too much to even try to put into words. The views are overwhelming.

Great view on a sunny day. Incredible view of Mt. Fuji , it was so clear and everyone was taking pictures. A wonderful panoramic view of Tokyo. But unless you know famous buildings in specific cities very. hard to figure where the cities are. Makes the old Tokyo Tower look small. Best to go before 9:00am when all the group tours start to arrive. Once they arrive the lines start to form for the wait to buy tickets and get onto the elevators start. Also the decks become quite crowded and you have to make your way around to see anything, as all popular places are in Japan...lots of people. Be careful not to go on a windy day, because they shut the tower down...might get stuck up there for awhile.

Amazing view of Tokyo!. I had so much fun while at the Tokyo Sky Tree. I had a little trouble finding how to actually get in. Hopefully in the future they will have some signs directing people. I also really wish I had bought tickets online. It was a good two hour wait just to buy a ticket. You first have to find someone handing out a piece of paper stating to come back at a certain time before you can even enter (I went to the Sumida Aquarium to kill time). Also, make sure you pay extra to go to the Tembo Galleria. It's less crowded. Don't miss this attraction!

Nice view through modern innovation, but lack of basic signage. We came here on our third trip to Tokyo. We felt very comfortable with the tokyo train system, with money, with asking for help, with navigation, with everything. Yet this is one of the few places that felt amazingly difficult to get to, considering it's visible from 10 miles away minimum. I like that they made a train station stop specifically for this place, but the train that goes here is not in the main JR station and is confusing and not well marked. Even many people who spoke Japanese had to ask if they were on the right train. There were people on our train from: China, Malaysia, Japan, Vietnam, Thailand, America, as well as others. The fact that there is not signage in more than Japanese and English is astonishing- do they want to make money or not? Upon exiting the train there is almost no signage on how to access the main entrance to the Skytree. We walked around for a good 10 minutes before finding it; keep in mind the station is UNDER the Sky Tree, there is no doubt where it is at any given moment. The wait was very small and it was very efficient like most things in Tokyo. It was $20/person. It was very cloudy the day we visited but we still got a good view. I personally wanted to go up to the next platform for the extra $10 but the wait was very, very long. There are many places to eat here, both on the ground and above. We had a good time taking pictures and then walked around the extensive mall and ate in the very passable food court. You can get a Sky Tree baumkuchen, or a waterbottle, etc. I think this is a good place to come because it's technically *the* tallest tower on Earth (Burj Khalifa is not a tower) and they have great descriptions of what you can see and where, and what the area looked like in previous Japanese historical eras. It takes a good hour to get here from most areas of the city, so do this in the morning, take a break for lunch, and then go see the historic temples in nearby Akasuka.

Amazing view all over Tokyo!!. This was just really amazing! Definitely worth the price. From the top of the Sky Tree you can see all over Tokyo. I especially recommend going in the night time when you see all the lights all over Tokyo. In the day time you're supposedly able to see all the way to Mount Fuji. The Tower gives a 360 view all over Tokyo City. It's really a must!

First Sky Time Experience. Great and fun experience coz I was with friends , but since it's too crowded on a Sunday we didn't had a chance to see the Observation Decks (you can choose which deck you wanted to see , prices varies around ¥2000-¥2500 )It'll take at least 2hrs just to buy a ticket! I suggest that you buy tickets in advance Online purchase is available on their website.Since we didn't go UP, we just decided to take pictures I recommend( tourist and locals) to bring DLSR Cam instead of iPhones,ipad,or digi camSince DLSR can capture the view and the tall tower itself. it's also connected to Sumida Aquarium which is quite expensive if you ask meAside from that there's a lot to see and explore The souvenirs is way to expensive than the ones being sold at Tokyo Tower.. Food won't be a problem because there's a lot of restaurants and fast food chains within the areaWe went by car and again on a Sunday , not a pretty good idea because of trafficPlus add the parking fee (we paid ¥1050 yen) for just an hour and half exploring the placeWill come back but not anytime soon..

A trip to the future. We went to the Tower in the evening. The entrance fee was U$D20 and we would have paid much more for this experience. The elevator that takes you up 400 mts in only a few seconds is an experience on its own and the view from the top is absolutely breath taking. It is a MUST in Tokyo. Don´t miss it!

How High?? - A Must Do In Tokyo!!!. If you think the Tokyo Tower is high, then this takes it to a new level.The tallest structure in Japan and the most impressive. It's the 2nd tallest structure in the world. It pays to book in advance as the queues can be long at weekends and public holidays. If you have the time it's well worth going to the second level. You'll need a decent camera as I went up wig my iPhone which lets be honest was useless taking photos of this nature.One of the most impressive things are the lifts. They move at an incredible speed and are smooth and motionless (all you feel is the popping of your ears). It's probably a once only visit, but if you are in town you must go up there!!

Awesome Japan. Great and unforgettable experience riding on high speed elevator just below 47 seconds and you'll travelled 350m (Observation Deck No.1). Then we travelled another 100m to reach Observation Deck No.2 which is the highest you're allowed to go. From there I can see the whole of Tokyo, the view is awesome! After viewing, we went to souvenir shops on the 4th and lower floors. There are a lot of visitors but totally this is a great experience on Awesome Japan.

Amazing view. We tried to go the Sky tree on a Sunday, and we arrived there around 14.00, they given us the ticket to start to queue at 19.30, so, knowing that we went there the day after, and we arrived there around 8.45 and the “ticket” to queue was for 10.00, reasonable.So, if you are planning to go there, I can suggest to go with some guided tour, that are more expensive but you will not have any problems!!Going there is an experience that start from the elevator, really fancy and really fast!! Once up, the view is fantastic, and is my opinion that worth spend other 10 euros to go to the real top (452 meters), if you would like to do that, it’s better that you start to queue immediate after going up with the elevator, the queue is every time around 30 minutes.We was there and the weather was good, so we was able to view all Tokyo, unfortunately the Fuji mountain was covered buy clouds!!So, as you can understand the only bad side of this visit was the time spend on waiting, but if you like the towers and going up, this is one of the best views you can have, breathtaking!!!One note for the restaurants, we didn’t eat there, and if you will book for a table in the really expensive one, remember that you have to queue as all the other person, you can’t go there at the last minutes!!

Great views. Wanted to go during the day, but the lines were especially long so I went back at night, and the lines were much sorter. I'm a big observation deck fan. Nothing too special here, but of course since it is the tallest building, you get great views. I enjoyed the Tokyo solamachi mall connected to Sky Tree. I stayed in the area so went to the food courts to grab food often. Tokyo Sky Tree is a nice building, especially the closer you get. I liked the night views, but I think you would see much more during the day. I know Tokyo Sky Tree was built in the area to attract more attention to it. I enjoyed the surrounding areas around Sky Tree.

amazing views!. It was amazing to see the views of the city from the Sky Tree. The lights were sparkly and landmarks stood out from the 350th meter stop. This site is very efficiently managed. The lines moved very quickly, handling hundreds! Of course, the hostess' were beautiful and very polite. I would recommend a night time trip, unless you're hoping for a view of Mt. Fuji. Then go during the day.

Great View of the City. We went to SkyTree on weekend at about 10 in the morning. There's a shopping area and food court at the first four floors of the building. When we arrived at the ticket booth, the line is already long but it was moving. We paid about 2000 yen to get in. The guide said that if the sky is clear, we can see the view of Mt. Fuji but we were not able to see it since it was bit cloudy that day. We stayed just about 30 minutes in the place. It would be great maybe if it would be seen during night time where viewers could see scenic tokyo lights.

Amazing views of Tokyo. We got to the Sky Tree at around 10:00 in the morning on a Friday (10-18-13). The line was reasonable, but not fast. We did notice that the later it got, the longer the line got. General rule of thumb for going to see the sights in Japan is get there early! The crowds don't show up right when something opens. Due to jet lag we were usually up at 6:30 AM every day and thus got to locations when they opened. This saved us waiting in long lines and dealing with crowds. Once at the top we walked around and took some amazing pictures of Tokyo. It was great to see ALL of Tokyo from a bird's eye view. We didn't pay the extra $10 to go up to 450 meters. The view at 350 meters for $20 was great all on its own.

Incredible !. One of the most incredible views in the world. Main observation area is 350 meters up. For about $10 more you can go up to 410 meters. It's amazing to see how huge this city is.  Warning lines are very long. If you stay at certain hotels known as friends of the Sky Tree you can get a bypass admission and it's free. You still have to pay the extra $10 to go to the higher level. We stayed at the Courtyard by Marriott Ginza which is one of those hotels. Plus it's a great hotel!
Scenic, beautiful. We were unable to go up and could not get reservations for restaurant, however, it was a beautiful sight, great pictures, worth the stop.

Thrilling. The only thing I didn't like in the Skytree is the 90-minute line to the tickets desk. You can avoid it if you come with a tourist group or if you have online ticket reservation. Also, time your visit late in the afternoon so you can enjoy day and night scenery. If you consider commuting by public transport, take Yamanote or Keihin Tohuko train to Ueno JR station, take the exit to ueno park. Just in front of the information office you will find the Skytree shuttle bus stop which will take right to the Skytree.

Quite a sight! :). The world's tallest tower to date. What amazed me the most was the elevator that took us up to 350 meter which was so fast, it took us just a few minutes to reach the Observation Deck.Though there were a lot of people the day we've visited tha place, still the experience was incomparable, as you get to see Tokyo in an aerial view, breathtaking!

Visit it from the top. I could not see it from the Top because there was a lot of rush and waiting time was about 2.5hours. Although expensive but if you like to see the tall building and city view, pay for it. I was lucky to get a room on 20th floor in my hotel to see almost a similar view :)

Amazing View and great shopping. Very nice place to visit! The sky tree is tall, gorgeous, newly constructed! This place gets really busy, but we got there right when it opened! Definitely recommend going there when they first open, however, the skytree opens at 8am, but the shops don't open until 10am. So you may have to wait around, but it's not bad at all.
Great place to visit. Sky Tree is the tallest tower in Tokyo. ultra modern in construction. The view from the top is absolutely fantastic. Certainly worth a visit.

Book early!. I foolishly decided to visit on a warm weekend - not a good idea as it seemed half of Tokyo had the same idea, and there was a 3-hour wait to go up the tower. I ended up just exploring the shopping mall at its base; good, but not quite what I intended.
Awesome. Sky tree tower, tall and beautiful. A beautiful sky look of the city of Tokyo. Glass top much fun to stand on it. Halloween perfect time to play and have fun. Do visit.

WOW is it tall!. We walked from teh Buddist temple to the Skytree. It took about 15 minutes, along the river then along the street. It was easy. The actual tower is HUGE! Plan well in advance if you plan to go up in the tower. We arrived around 1:00pm and there were easily 200+ people in line ahead of us. we decided to just look and not go to the top.

Go for the architecture!. Tokyo's sky tree is worth a visit, not only for the views - on a clear day you can see forever - but for the very interesting architecture of this free-standing tower. Trains run right to the tower but do walk around the outside to get a great feel for the structure.We found the walk back to Senjo-ji temple doable and one can stop for a meal or a beer at the Asahi headquarters...another worthy stop.
Best view of Tokyo, Hands down. It took over an hour to get to the top because of the long lines, but well worth it! Try and make advanced reservations.

Early morning - too cloudy!. Great trip. Arrived at 08.30am no queues. However, a little cloudy, but fun anyway. Yen2000 adult. You pay Yen1000 more to get to second level. Might be good later in the day in good weather, or at night with all the lights!

A bit boring and very crowded. A very crowded and complicated procedure that on average takes an hour to get from the ground to the top of the Sky Tree. The views are amazing, but obviously the photos don't come out very well due to the glass barriers, persistent crowds, and excessive altitude. I think it would be better to look for stars at this altitude above all else in Tokyo.

Expensive but worth it. We went to the tower at nighttime and missed the long queues and got to the top within 20 minutes. The added advantage of seeing the tower at nighttime is that it is lit up with a beautiful powder blue light and the views from the top are pretty spectacular. The cost is very high at 2,000 yen to go to the 450 storey and a further 1,000 yen to go all the way to the top. When standing at the top You can actually feel the sway and we were told that it moves 10 metres either side and it felt a bit like being on a cruise ship. Well worth it as you actually get an understanding of how big Tokyo actually is.

View = 5 Star ! Queuing a pain !. This definitely has the Wow factor when you step from the elevator to the 350M level and see Tokyo ( and beyond that, Mount Fuji ) sprawled out before you. Having been confronted with a 6 hour wait on Sunday, turning up today at 7.15am was a wise move. The Q had already begun in earnest ; very happy to be able to get up the Tower today but the procession to do so still took over an hour. ¥2000 to get up to the first level, a further ¥1000 to go to the next ( and final level ). If you're going to go the extra mile, I would immediately start to Q for the next level ( rather than look around the first level ). The Q for the second stage can be 30 mins+. Do a detailed tour of the first level on your way back down.....
View of Mt. Fuji at sunset.. the long line was worth the wait to see the worlds number one mountain from the secon tallest free-standing structure.

Fantastic view. We went up to the Tembo deck at 350m and the view was amazing. Buying tickets and queuing was easy as we got there early, but I got the impression that the staff thought it better to reserve tickets rather than just showing up. Definitely worth it for the view of Tokyo on a clear day. We were even able to see Mount Fuji.The downside was that once we were on the Tembo deck, it soon got very busy. There were long queues for photo spots, and you couldn't really take your time. It also seems silly that you have to buy your ticket for the Tembo Galleria at 450m while you're up there. There was a long queue, so we didn't bother as we had other things to do that day. I don't understand why you can't buy your ticket for the top level at the same time as your main ticket. Every other city view I've been to has this option.

Overcrowded, overpriced. came there in April midweek day, no holidays, had to wait for 5h to get ticket and another almost 2 in line for elevator..So interesting Tokio night view....such a shame, as it was nice clear and sunny day before. And its so expansive almost double of the Tokyo Tower which has far better view....and is sooo much nicer. I did like the shopping center around the sky tree tough, smartly made, while waiting you will surely spend some money there

Not worhthy during the day. I should have gone to Tokyp Sky Tree during the night. I'm not sure if is allowed and open during this period, but if it is I bet that the view is much better. In my opinion, the view you have is not value as the price was more than 30 dollars andd the time you have to wait. Between spend more time walking in Asakusa and going back there (during the day) I rather the first option.

Asakusa and Tokyo Sly tree. That place is really awesome. I started my journey at early morning. Visited the sky tree and asakusa. Later took space ship to Odaiba. It gives the charm of river cruise in Sumida river and Odaiba is nice to walk around, having tea in the restaurant, trying the mono rail, ferry wheel etc. Lots of fun!!!

Brilliant views across the city and no queues at 9pm!. When we planned our trip to Japan the main thing my boyfriend wanted to do was visit the Tokyo Sky Tree! I had read reviews and information online saying that the queues are hours and hours long and you couldn't prebook tickets unless you have a Japanese credit card. So we decided to go at night at about 9pm, we got there and there was no queues at all, so we got up to the first deck and then when straight up to the second one too. The views were incredible, you could see for miles and all of the lights of the city. Also because we went up late there weren't many people so we were able to enjoy the views without interruption.

See it to believe it. Not only is it worth it to see the structure itself, it is worthwhile to pay the admission to go up the tower. This is the tallest tower in the world and the elevator travels at a speed of 600m/min! You can barely tell you are moving! Crazy! The queue is long but moves pretty good. If you plan on visiting, go on-line. This view gives you a good perspective on the size of Tokyo, and an appreciation for the amazing city.

Didn,t Get In , but still had good time !. Had 1 afternoon in Tokyo prior to flying home, having previously stayed for 3 days earlier in tour. Decided to try the Skytree having done the other 2 views - Roppongi is the best. However it was really all about the journey as we loved the buzz of travelling on Subway and JR trains. It was a Sunday afternoon and on arrival at 4 we were told earliest ticket available was 7 , never mind, the structure is awesome to look up at from below, close up, and Skytree Town is just buzzing on a Sunday , shops galore and obviously the place to be seen for young Japanese . We had a great hour . From what we have heard and our experience , the view from Mori tower is best in Tokyo as from there you can see the other 2 towers and if you,re in 1 of them - clearly you can,t! But would still recommend Skytree Town.

Room with a view and a queue!. This tower is large, very large and can be seen for miles around, as you arrive it looms over you and looks quite intimidating. It feels very much like what it is, an over priced tourist attraction. You enter via a concrete landscape, there's a large food court at one end and a multi level shopping centre, with more food establishments, at the other. You then join a queue, I went during the week out side of holiday season and the first queue was just over an hour, this weaves you around the snaking rope cordon to the ticket desk. Apart from a couple of display screens the only thing to see is the other people in the queue!! Expensive ticket purchased, you then join the queue for the security check. Once complete, you join the queue for the lift!!Ahhh the lift arrives, and brings with it the first part of interest since entering the building! I can only describe this lift as opulent and fast!! 350 meters and an ear popping minute later you emerge onto the Tembo Deck. The views are vast, Shinjuku, the docks and more clearly visible, sadly too hazy to see Fuji san on the day I visited. There's an expensive café and rather pleasant toilets should you wish. There are crowds and you might have to wait for a window space to grab a photo or two, but you don't feel rushed or crowded. I then joined another queue, this was to purchase a ticket for the next part of the trip, thankfully this queue was much shorter than those on ground level, I can only assume only a fraction of the visitors felt it was worth paying out again to go another 100 meters up! Ticket purchased and another short queue later I'm in a lift again. This one whips you up the outer part of the tower and the views from it are quite incredible. Doors open and you enter the Tembo Galleria. Floor to ceiling windows surround this circular walkway, and it may have just been my imagination, but it felt like the whole thing wobbled as you walked!!The views remained fantastic and again there was no pressure to rush around. Oh, and there was a small queue to cross the glass floor. Back down at the bottom, there are plenty of gift shops and food areas available. I also enjoyed walking around the back streets by the Sky Tree, this is one of the poorer areas of Tokyo and it is hoped this development will help with the regeneration. It's by no means a slum area or dangerous but it's certainly not Roppongi Hills! If you want great views for free, head to the Metropolitan Government Building in Shinjuku. However, if you want to experience the tallest tower in the world and don't mind queuing and paying, head here.

Awesome view and more. As the tallest tower in the world, you get an awesome view of Tokyo and, on a clear day, Mt Fuji in the distance. Quite crowded, but I'm glad we did it. We had lunch at the very high-end but wonderful Musashi restaurant and also visited the Sumida Aquarium, which is not too big but a nice entertainment, especially for kids, and if you get there at the right time, you can watch them feed and play with the sea lions, which are adorable. Be aware that there is always a long line--we were lucky because if you go to the restaurant, there is no charge for the elevator ride (which is pretty awesome in itself) and you bypass the line for the elevator up. There are tons of shops--you could get lost there! And getting there is very easy by metro, where it's the last stop on the Asakusa Line. A good one-time spot not to miss.

If they open the platform, you could touch the clouds.. We were in the location but there was strong wind. So, there was warning that the climb up/down may be delayed because the elevator is outside.We were fortunate that we did not experience the delay. But because the weather was unpredictable, we could not see too far.We were delighted when the elevator climbed up so fastttttt. And literally surrounded by the clouds

Very nice attraction with average value price/waiting wise. Unlike some of the other reviews, I like this building a lot both from outside and the inside. It's an observation platform plus some souvenir shops give or take, so you really should know what to expect and whether you like them or not, although the view from this one is certainly not exceptional. (If you don't know whether you like them, go to Tokyo metropolitan building first and save 2000 Yen + 1000 for the galleria.) However, there are plenty of shops and restaurants in the building so this may come handy. If at least a bit possible, make a reservation for a specific time beforehand to avoid long(!) waiting. Without this, I'm not sure it's really worth the waiting time and the price. (But sometimes there are almost no people waiting so you may able to go directly inside.)Besides the price and the waiting time, the only real drawback is that there is no information about the visibility conditions on the bottom floor, only on the intermediate, so be careful, otherwise you may end up with paying a lot for a poor view (at least I didn't notice one).

Nice tourist spot. 2 metro lines reach the Tokyo SkyTree so it's fairly easy to find. The wait time to purchase a ticket may get very long, up to 2 hrs, so schedule your visit to avoid disappointment. It gets more crowded during dawn etc. If you know what time you'll be there, reserve a ticket online the night before,Once you're up there, its heaven, if you're lucky and it's a clear day, you may even get to see mt. fuji in the far distance. You go around the tower and the experience generally takes 30-40 mins. Enhance the experience by having Japanese tea or curry while looking at the beautiful view.Apart from the tower, it also contains a large shopping centre so be sure to have a look before you leave, sushi restaurant there was amazing.

Shopping, eateries, once in a lifetime experience, but nothing more.. There is a direct subway station to this place, but we decided to walk from Sensoji temple from Asakusa, took around an hour to reach. Pretty noticeable landmark with nice lighting effects that sparkles from far away. Forget about going to the tower if you are not one of those Q freaks, because the Q time is horrible. Make sure you come early in the morning to get tickets if you insist on going to the tower. You will be spoilt with a lot of shopping choices, a lot of souvenir stores as well. Make sure you plan your time and journey well, because the crowds are doubled up at night. If you are in a group, it is advisable not to eat at the food court as it is extremely packed and you have to scavenge for seats like a hungry wolf. But oh well, visit Tokyo Sky Tree! Just make sure you can handle the crowds!

Nice souvenir shops, good prices compared to asakusa. Been there in oct 2012 for a quick visit on week endCouldn't climb coz of the long waiting timeBut had a good chance buying lots of souvenirs for good prices compared to asakusaThey also have a hello kitty shop which is my favorite

Expensive, no view, long queue. First there is a subway station to go there. We didn't know so we walk a lot to arrive to this tower. When you arrive, you can't see how long you have to wait...it was not a week end but we waited for 90 mn before to pay the ticket. After that you need to wait to enter into a lift. When you arrive, there are so many people that it's impossible to see anything. Seriously, it is not necessary to go to Sky Tree to have a view of the city. You can go for free at the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building

Tall but not so pretty. Being the stingy tourists we were, we knew that we weren't going to venture up the tower to see the views as we'd already seen the Tokyo skyline for free from the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. We did however want to check it out and see it from the outside.It was a little disappointing to be honest. It is a bit out of the way and if you are trying to avoid taking taxis the walk there from the closest metro stop is quite a way. Added to that on arrival it isn't the most beautiful building in the world, especially after having seen the tallest building in the world, the Burj Khalifa, which is absolutely stunning. It is tall though, very tall. There was however a lovely canal beside it where we stopped up for lunch where there was a bit of funky water feature to entertain us.It is worth going to take a look at but if you want great views for free we definitely recommend the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building.
Amazing views, crazy line. If you really want to go to the top...go early in the morning to get tickets as the line is worsed than Disneyland on a sunday. The views though are amazing.

Amazing Views & A Bit Crowded. * Absolutely excellent panoramic views of Tokyo* One of the best ways to visually understand Tokyo's size and density* 2,000 Yen per adult (as of mid Sept '13) to go up to the first observation deck* Go in the morning when the Sky Tree first opens to avoid crowds and long lines* Good shopping/dining in Sky Tree Town (below the actual tower)* Use Sky Tree Station for easy subway access

Shopping meets Technology and Food. Tokyo Sky Tree is a bit of everything in one place. There is the structure itself which is certainly something to marvel about. This tower is earthquake resistant and a tribute to Japanese technology. It also houses a wide variety of shops ranging from traditional hair accessories, quality leather products, Uniqlo, Zara, Diesel,and more. The 6th and 7th floors house a variety of restaurants and there also is a Food Court for cheaper eats. If you need to buy Tokyo Sky Tree themed snacks, this is the place to do so, and you can get almost everything from cracker Sky Trees to cookies and even cakes. There is a Sumida Place on the 5th floor featuring authentic crafts and quality goods from Sumida City. Try delicacies only available in Sumida or purchase quality products made with techniques that have been passed down for generations (Japanese folding screens, Edo Kiriko style glass, leather products, and more). Admission to the tower itself is 2000 yen and 1000 more if you wish to go up higher to the walkway.

Go on a tour and then stay there ... Went on an organised tour due to the difficulty in buying tickets on UK credit card. Felt bad as we by passed the enormous line to go straight up. Had the best of both worlds as their was an option to then stay at Skytree.A delightful Japanese girl who sat next to me on the tour bus helped me discover that there was a bus from the Skytree right back to Tokyo Station (near my hotel) - there are also subway links - so I stayed, enjoyed the cafe (the sky tree ice creams are very cute) and the higher level.One note of caution there is very limited seating here - had to stand even in the cafe - so have a care if members of your party have limited mobility. Lower levels have an excellent and well priced food court which was extremely clean and he food I had well cooked. There are also more formal restaurants if you wish. Did not try the Aquarium as have done such things many times - but shops were amazing and so many. Also a bargain wine shop. It was a great afternoon out.

complicated online system, waiting time too long!!!. we tried to book online in switzerland but the official site was only in japanese and they only accept most asian based credit cards and visa. mastercards are not welcome. we asked for help at the hotel and they told us it won't be a problem if we buy it right there. so from asakusa shrine, we walked for about 20 minutes to tokyo sky tree. it was packed and it was hot. we reached the reception area at around 12 noon and you have to cue for the tickets for the tower for at least an hour which are valid by 4pm first (4 hours waiting time). we didnt buy the ticket, instead we checked out the souvenir shops. everything was overpriced and the souvenirs were of poor quality. we ended up buying postcards only.

All of Tokyo in a glance. Going up in the summer break meant joining the mile-long snaking queue but it was worth it still! Standing at 643m, tallest tower in the world, the viewing decks are at 350 and 450m. The panoramic view beats any skyscraper observatories and the interactive touch-screen panels are a bonus to identifying the landmarks. On a clear day you can see mountain ranges and Fujiyama but no such luck for me. The glass floor to stand on is rather tiny. If only they had built an entire glads deck to stand on like the one in Auckland. Lots of shops in the gallery to keep the shopaholic happy, too.

Really Great! Too bad the day was not clearer!. I was recently in Tokyo for work and decided to take a walk to the Sky Tree. I had been told that there was weeks long waiting to go up, but I arrived around 9am (they open at 8) and I waited in a very short queue for a ticket that takes you up about 450 meters. The elevator up is so smooth! You climb all the way up so quickly it takes less than a minute to arrive at the first stop and you don't even feel like you are moving! The view from up there is great, the only issue is that the day was not very clear so it was hard to see much, on a clear day you are supposed to be able to see all the way to Mt. Fuji. I was easily able also to buy the second ticket that takes you up another 200 meters. It was worth the money it was a fun adventure and I think most people would really enjoy it.

Great View. Wow! It was great...there were too many school children there when I visited but still a great view of Tokyo, Japan. You can go all he way to the top for (another 1000 yen) but I didn't go all the way up. There's a window on the floor so you can see the depth of the height...pretty cool.

Very cool place to visit. The visit to Tokyo Sky Tree was a part of the itinerary for my 10 day tour to Japan. We had reservation as a group so we went directly to the designated elevator to go up, no waiting. When We walked pass by the line for the elevator for Independent visitors, I think the sign says 53 minutes wait. I recommend booking a group tour for sure if you want to visit. Maybe a hotel concierge can help. We had a very pleasant visit and some free time to shop.

Great views at a resonable price. Done a few towers around the world, given it was school vacation there was a wait, however you were given a ticket with a time to come back. It was a fairly clear day so had good views over the city.

Plan to spend some time here!. I visited there with two family members and a group of family friends from Japan. You can buy tickets to the first "level" which takes you to the 350th floor, for $20 USD. And it gets you there in a flash. Some people had problems with their ears, FYI, if you are prone to that difficulty.If you decide you want to take it further, you can purchase an additional ticket for $10 pp and go to floor 450. Wow. The building visibly sways and some were off balance. It was crazy. It was all my sister could do to keep from crawling on the floor, lol.The building that connects to it is filled with 7 floors of shops, both unique and commercialized as well as food courts, restaurants and fine dining.We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.

Great views. I had a great day out at the Tokyo Sky Tree, but be warned, there are long queues!!! When you arrive, you have to get a ticket which tells you which time block you have been given to actually go into the SkyTRee building - depending on day of week etc will dictate how long you have to wait. However there are plenty of things to do while you wait - shops and restaurants. When it is time to go in, everything is very well organised and you go up in a fast lift up to the top. Once there, you can pay extra to up to a higher level - I felt this was unnecessary as the view from the first level is great. The building is so tall that you feel like you are looking down over the rest of Tokyo, even the other skyscrapers are dwarfed. There is a small piece of clear perspex that you can stand on and see all the way down which is fun. All in all, I really enjoyed my day here and would go again!

just be patient. try to visit Tokyo Sky Tree, but when we arrived at 1 PM we discovered the 4 (!) hour cue of people waiting for access , we skipped, as there are better ways to waste 4 hours in Tokyo :) so if you really want to go up:next time be sure to make reservation in advancealternative is the beautiful Aquarium that is at the same location and when we visited had no waiting line

A great attraction. We had a great time at the Sky Tree. I enjoyed all the shops and restaurants in the complex. There were a lot of people there on the weekend and the staff was very well organized in dealing with large crowds. The day was a little cloudy so we did not have a great view but it was still spectacular. I can't imagine how awesome it would be on a very clear day.A great palce to visit.
Great views. Be sure to get there early to get a ticket with an early time. While you wait there is a nice aquarium and many shops to browse. Once you go up Sky Tree, the views are spectacular.

Great view. It worth the money. I was with my mom on wheelchair and we could access very easily. Ipaid extra to go top and it was nice but if you are in rush or din't wanna pay extra, you can still enjoy the great view of tokyo.

visit day and night and Hint for visiting during "Tokyo Hotaru Festival". I visited the sky tree during "Tokyo Hotaru Festival 2013", different lighting types at Tokyo Sky Tree can be seen in one night. Nice to have a walk along promenade and don't forget to visit in both nighttime and daytime. If you will get a change to visit "Tokyo Hotaru Festival" in the future, my only advice is "There is no need to buy the entrance ticket, all you have to do is to wait and see along the promenade". Wasting money to buy the entrance ticket.

Tokyo Sky tree: Amazing view of the City. The most spectacular view of the Tokyo city. Though the queue was long but it was worth to wait. First it will take to Tembo deck which is at 350 meter height and then you can go to Tembo Galeria which is at 450 meter. The elevator which takes you to the skytree, I call it vertical shinkansen. It reaches 600m/min at max speed, installed by Toshiba. Do not miss this if you are going to Tokyo

Great place for kids and adults. A must visit when you're in Tokyo! You can go to observe the city or browse around the malls... Sumida Aquarium are here too. Many TV character shops on the lower level. A fun place to visit"

Beautiful landmark and surroundings, but crowded. The Tokyo Skytee is located in the Sumida ward of Tokyo near the Oshiage station on the Asakusa and Hanzomon line. The Tokyo Skytree can be reached directly from this station, just follow the hords of people.The Tokyo Skytree is the second tallest building in the world, tallest TV-tower in the world and the tallest building of Japan, measuring 634 meters. On the base of the tower, a complete mall with all kinds of stores is built (Tokyo Skytree Town). This mall is very crowded with lots of people. You can get some good view from the Skytree from one of the various outdoor areas of the mall, which is very nice. The mall features a specific floor in which you can "Experience Japan", it features numerous shops with Japanese souvenirs. The surroundings of the Skytree are nice as well, there is a small water feature running along the side of the Tokyo Skytree Town, which is more quiet than the Skytree Town itself. It is a good place to relax and just walk around. The Tokyo Skytree consists of two observatories at respectively 350 (Tembo Deck) and 450 (Tembo Galleria) meters above the ground. Tickets for the Tembo Deck will cost you 2000 JPY while an additional 1000 JPY is charge when accessing the Tembo Galleria. Note that tickets for the Tembo Galleria can only be purchased at the Tembo Deck. The Skytree itself is very busy as well. I advise you to buy your tickets beforehand through the internet since on most days slips are handed out to people to come back at a specific time later that day to try and buy a ticket, this is due to the fact that the Skytree still is extremely busy. Due to this fact, we didn't access the Skytree, which was a pitty to me. Therefore, be sure to buy your tickets prior to visiting. If you really want to visit the observation deck you have to come back at the time assigned to your slip.

More waiting than viewing. This is what it says on the tin: a very high structure allowing you views over a major city. I reckon all big cities will have one by now. Make sure you pre-book a ticket. I didn't and found myself waiting in line longer than I actually spent on the viewing gallery. So partly my own fault, but unlike everything else in Japan, this seemed less well organised.The views are good, but I'd recommend waiting for a clear day. As for the cost, I thought it wasn't too bad. The Shard in London is only half as high, but costs three times as much. So all relative!

View of Dreams. This is 1 of a few towers I have been in, but by far the most spectacular with regard to the view ! Tokyo , Japan is an amazing city, spread out further than I had ever imagined. But I got a real perspective as to how far out it goes.... Stunning scenery right out to Mount Fuji and on a good day you can see Tokyo bay and the north Pacific ocean.... Top spot to visit !

Some great views but expensive. A good place to visit if you are shopping in and around the mall below in Sumida. However, beware it isnt cheap to go 3/4 of the way up and then you have to pay more to go to the top. If you have a really good camera, you will get some amazing pictures and you CAN say you have been up a really tall tower (its one of the tallest in the world). But my family and I were left thinking "was that it??!?". The queues were really big and waiting times moderate (30-45mins). I have to admit, the efficiency and organisation of the customer service staff was excellent, but it was tiring standing around for a long time (especially for my parents 60+). The observation deck provides beautiful views yes - but as mentioned - have a really good camera (SLR) and you will really get some amazing shots. Id recommend going early in the morning when (as some of the staff said) you may capture views of Fuji and beyond. We went midday and this was not possible. It was also super crowded and finding a nice point for a photo was tricky. As you may imagine, the cafe in the deck is accordingly priced for a tourist.All in all - this is a "tick in the box". If you want to experience it at a price. If you want a view of the city - there are many FREE places you can go and get something a bit better :) :)

Nice!!. Great by any comparison....located in an area normally quite traditional, this tower represents now one of the hype of Tokyo.Great facilities, amazing attractions, shopping, restaurants and coffee bars... a must!
Skytree. Beautiful tower! Loved the shops/market inside the tower. Must pay to get to top or even midway of the tower and the lines were long. Definitely worth it though!

So many people we could not see anything worthwhile. Our family decided to give one of the world's tallest towers a try while in Tokyo. The Tokyo Sky Tree is truly an engineering marvel. Standing high above the city's skyline, it is an imposing sight that beckons to be visited. Unfortunately for us, it seemed every unoccupied Tokyo visitor who was Japanese or every other nationality had the same idea on that day.We went there by train from Asakusa Station to Tokyo Sky Tree Station hoping to get up there and enjoy the panoramic views. It turned out to be that we had to pick up a ticket for a 19.00 hrs. viewing time, which was about 3 hours away. That made us get a sense of how popular this place was. Once the appointed time came, we had to wait in line for 30 minutes more to buy tickets, then wait for elevators. Granted, these were super fast elevators, but were so full we could not move an inch.When we got to the observation deck, it was dark, and full of people. I mean the place was crowded like a train station of passengers heading home for the holidays. I myself could not even find space to see or take photos of the city. What I eventually did see were shimmering lights and roads way down below. I was never a fan of going up high buildings for photos and Tokyo Sky Tree did nothing to change my mind. If you go, allow plenty of time. At least there are fine restaurants and decent shopping in the complex, but even those are jam packed.

Spectacular view of Tokyo at sunset. Make sure to prepare well your visit at the Skytree when in Tokyo: arrive around 2:30pm to get your "waiting line" ticket for 5pm/5:30pm. Then visit the shoppin mall and treat yourself to local delicacies (sweet potatoe and cheese cake were scrumptious).Then you'll have about 30mn wait in the lobby to get your tickets and you'll arrive at 350 meters around 6pm to see the sunset. Even more spectacular is to wait until the lights are switched on all over Tokyo so you can see how spread out it is !!! I really loved it and encourage you to try

Worth the Wait. Beautiful building from inside and out. Wish we could have gotten our tickets on line, as it took a while in line to get them and then to be allowed up. We enjoyed the view of the city and the surrounding areas. The building itself is quite impressive and when the weather is clear there is a great view as well. They have gift shops and places to eat at the observation area. There is also a huge mall with food court attached, so there is plenty to do before or after you go to the top. Very impressive place. We stayed up there till sunset and it was worth the wait - beautiful views.
Majestic Tower. A beautiful tower. Shame you can't book in advance online as a foreigner. They don't accept foreign debit or credit cards.

Excellent View - Get there Early. Stayed in Sumida during part of the trip to get a taxi to the tower without having to deal with all the intricate line changes involved with mass transit in Tokyo. Got there around 10am and found it starting to fill up fast. Great view. Plenty of eateries to choose from on the lower area of the tower. Took us about 20 seconds or so to get to the 345 meter hight. Don't see how there is any better view of Tokyo than here. Pay 1000 yen more to get up to the highest publicly-allowed observable point in Tokyo which is the Galleria. The Galleria spirals upward to an end point. There is a gift shop on the Tembo Galleria (I think) deck where you can purchase souvenirs. There is a glass cage you can have your photo taken with a view looking down to the ground.Wonderful opportunity. Thankful for it.

Don't miss the mall connecting to Sky Tree. This is a new icon. The observatory deck is nice at night. But don't miss the chance to spend time in the mall connecting to Sky Tree. There are numerous shops and quality restaurants to enjoy.

Beautiful view, great architecture.. I went to Tokyo for my birthday last October and my gf from Japan took me to Sky Tree. Beautiful view of the city. I will say the line is very long depending on the night, however it was worth the wait. I suggest to go on clear night/day so you can see the whole city. It was a great experience and the whole top level was big enough for everyone to get a clear view out the window. Great experience I will never forget ^_^

Don't go here go to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building which is free instead!!. We didn't actually visit the sky tree as it was quite expensive. Someone advised us to go to the TMG building instead and we were so glad we did. The TMG building has a higher observation level than the sky tree and it is free. We saw pictures our friend took from sky tree and they were identical to the ones we took and no queues and no fee!

Tokyo Sky Tree; pick the right day and right timing. Went on a weekday around noon and there was no long queue; within 15 mins and 2,000 yen lighter, I was on my way up. Elevator is indeed super fast. However, due to relatively poor visibility on that day (it was quite a sunny day), i find the view neither amazing nor fantastic and what I saw was blocks of concrete (saw the Asahi beer building clearly though). The crowd was rather thin that day so I did not have to wait for long to get a good look of the view by the windows but I can't imagine what it would be like on a more crowded day or the more popular times of the day. I also wish there were some seating areas; maybe visitors are not expected to linger around. I did not stay for long. To have a better experience, choose a bright day or opt to go during the night or to watch the sunset (I have seen some very beautiful shots of the sunset from Tokyo Sky Tree). The tower is accessible from several subway lines or you can consider what I did - combine a visit to the tower with a visit to the Tsukiji market followed by Asakusa and possibly the Ameyoko market in Ueno if time permits.

Great view! But too much crowded!. I went there on weekday in September.But we had waited for 90 minutes to get on lift.I didn't make a reservation.If you are planning to go there, I recommend to make reservation for lift.The view from the top was amaizing!We were lucky the sky was clear.

Should visit.It's better than Tokyo Tower. This place is better than Tokyo Tower. The view is really nice, there are many restaurants and interesting shops selling all kinds of Japanese items. If you want to go to the top, you'll have to buy 2 tickets. And you should! Come at night. I recommend making a reservation about 1 month before coming there! This place I can go more than once!!!

Great View, long lines. Be weary of the lines of people. I think you can pre order tickets online. It is super clean and comfortable. There is a glass floor for viewing. Not many bathrooms up at the top. So beware if you have a bathroom issue or have small children.

Go! Go! Go!. Tokyo Sky Tree is a fabulous destination for everyone. The elevator is superfast, the view amazing, and the price affordable. 90000 yen for three teens and me to go to the top. It was incredible and a must do. We went on a Tuesday night, and the line was negligible.

Nice view, effective queing. On a normal day the waiting time for tickets is about 30 min. Theres a continous flow so you dont't really feel like you're waiting. Adult tickets are 2000 Yen, and 900-1500 for kids/juniors. This will take you up to the Tembo Deck at 350 m. You can then purchase a ticket to take you up to the Tembo Galleria at 450m for an additional 1000 yen, but when I visited the weather was foggy/hazy so I didn't bother going up there. They also had signs up saying that there was poor visibility up there. The view is nice, although I don't think it's nearly as good as The Empire State Building. But you have a panoramic view of Tokyo, and I would reccomend to visit it.

The tallest tower ever seen. this is a mandatory stop, this is one of the most amazing places in the world. It is I think, the tallest tower in the world. This is specially gorgeous during the evening, the lighting is just unique.you better get your tickets with enough time, otherwise you have to make a double line, they are pretty organized so you will climb the tower anyway. I love the shooping center located right there, you have so may options to have fun and spent the rest of the day or evening.Highly recomended!

fantastic views of tokyo, great day out, very enjoyable. this has to be one of the best ways to view Tokyo, once you get by the crowds ,its an enjoyable day out with lots of stores and restaurants, close by you will not go hungry getting to the top of the sky tree is easy the guides speak English and the signs are also in English easy to get to via metro from anywhere in the city, this has to be top of your list if you plan on coming to tokyo

Nice view but expensive. The view is needless to say breath taking. ..the entire city....and if you reach at 5 something you may stay to waych the sub set and the entire city light up. .....downside is the ticket is rather pricy of 2000 yen for adults...im not sure about pre booked tickets

Tokyo Sky Tree. I am a long term resident of Tokyo and have visited Sky Tree on two occasions. Like its competitor "Tokyo Tower" one has fairly easy access by subway. It does "tower" above Tokyo Tower and well worth a visit. It is quite the popular destination these days, even among the locals. As to "towering" and height, I will let you google that, but depending on how it is measured, it is the second tallest structure in the world. Again, this depends on certain criteria (antenna height, etc.) but suffice it to say it is indeed an impressive structure. Beauty? That is in the eye of the holder, however. If you are in Tokyo it is well worth the trip since it is in Tokyo as well. The night view of and from the Tower is impressive as the Tower is well-lighted. River tours are available and perhaps give another fun dimension to a visit. Upper decks of the tower include restaurants. If you would rather save some money, why you can just pick up something to eat and drink at the convenience store in the station before heading to the tower itself. Enjoying Sky Tree itself really requires little money and can be done economically. Those who wish to ride to the "top" will pay a ticket fee however.

Amazing view and great attraction, even if it's not very cheap!. I liked the Tokyo Sky Tree more than Tokyo Tower. The view was amazing and it took no time to get to 450m on the elevator! I read many comments about long queues but I got there on a Tuesday at 9am (they open at 8am) and there was no queue, so we went straight in.One annoying thing is that you basically have to buy two tickets if you want to go to the very top, and they are both quite expensive. The view is amazing and everything looks new and exciting, but I still thought it was a little too much to pay. I really liked the shop too, where you can buy interesting souvenirs and postcards. Also, the whole area around the Sky Tree is a shopping centre, so there are many places where to go and eat afterwards.

interesting but EXPENSIVE!. it is always interesting to go up high; especially, up the highest tower of the world(450m). if you are willing to pay $35, it is quite an attraction. highly recommended to make a reservation on their homepage. very crowded!
Beautiful. Love this place, we stay close to Skytree and we love the view ESP at night very romantic place to lived. I will come back again with my Kids!

Spectacular View, Beautiful Building, Steep Price Tag.. The building's sheer size and magnitude are truly awesome from the outside, and the surrounding facilities provide ample things to do for almost an entire day. The lineup to get into the tower can be a bit long, and the process to get up slow, including going through a bag check and metal detector. But the entire process through i was distracted by a variety of creative info panels, and very nice interiors and lighting. The elevators up are very beautifully decorated, but a wish it was a bit more interactive then just simply displaying your accent speed. Once up top, the view is grand, but to get the best view, you must be very lucky, smog often clouds the distant view. Your best bet is a windy winter day in the early morning, but for me it was summer, and for the 25 days I was there, 1 day was a beautiful perfect day with an endless view, however on an average day the smog of the city wont let you see too far. Regardless its still a great view, which will allow you to see the scope and size of Tokyo. There are plenty of interactive panels to let you identify spots your looking at and the glass is extremely clean, transparent and glare free, so I had no issues taking photos.  Now to get to the very highest level you have to once again pay, wait in line and go up an elevator, this time the elevator being quite boring. I went up just for novelty because up there the view didn't change drastically, and I couldn't see any further. You basically pay to go up this ramp that goes from the elevator to a spot marked "highest point" and aside from a bit of picture taking and waiting to see if the weather got any better we didn't spend much time up there.  Back in the main level, we did use the cafe, which had decent cake and coffee/tea. We took a look at the restaurant, but prices were about $40 for the basic course meal, not outrageous for Tokyo. The merchandise shop offered a variety of things all priced at attraction rates (high). One of my favorite spots was the glass floor which the positioned and created perfectly! We took some very cool pictures with the glass bottom, and the picture service by the staff also worked out well.  All in all it was a very good experience for a tower, although on the pricy side considering its just a tower.
Phenomenal. Whilst this tower absolutely towers over Sydney Tower, the que was a bit dissapointing to be honest. the surrounds though were awesome and the shear size of this thing was impressive.

Very nice night view!. I go up almost every tower and observation deck everywhere I travel, and the Tokyo Sky Tree was one of my best experiences. The view is spectacular at night. I didn't go to the upper deck, but I'm not sure if it's really all that necessary. The view from the general deck (you get access to three levels if you pay the general admission) really shows off Tokyo very well. I appreciated the fact that it was entirely indoors and enclosed with glass, which is a lot better than outdoor decks fenced with wire nets that obstruct the view.There are a lot of touchscreens that help explain and navigate the view of the city and what you're looking at. You can even compare day and night view on the screens. Also, there was also a comparison of a map drawn centuries ago to the view today atop the SkyTree---the historical perspective was interesting.The gift shop was somewhat of a rip-off (typical of most tourist traps). You can find a somewhat better deal for Tokyo Skytree souvenirs in the mall at the foot of the tower, and surrounding areas.

Its just another tower... Having been up the TMGO (loved it), the Mori tower in Roppongi (meh) and Tokyo Tower (loved it), I was dragged along to this by my travelling companions.We didnt have a Japanese credit card, so there was no way of avoiding the crowds. We waiting almost an hour just to buy the ticket. 2000 yen. Another 10 minutes for the elevator. Cut to- an overly crowded observation deck, basically too high to see much and too far from most of the other city landmarks. I guess once you get up high enough past a certain point the view doesnt really get better.. Just say sprawl of the buildings. Paid another 1000 yen to go to the higher one, similarly crowded with people, had to wait a few minutes just to get a spot at the windows. Not much to do up there, an overpriced gift shop, some overpriced food venues, to match with the overpriced view.They have a glass floor, but it was getting dark by this stage, so the effect was not so amazing, you could just see a bit of the tower below and some bright lights shining up at you. Plus you had to fight with fifty other people to get onto it or take photos there.Then we waited another twenty minutes for the elevators down. I dont know if everyone else felt as ripped off as I did as we were leaving. Yes, I can say I have been up the Tokyo Skytree, so if you just want to do it for the sake of doing it, then great. I would recommend the older, shorter yet cheaper and more enjoyable Tokyo Tower.

Best way to get a perspective of Tokyo. This attraction is a good one early in your trip, especially for first-timers to Tokyo. The vastness of the city is pretty difficult to fathom, though atop this tower, one can get a glimpse of the city's scope. The elevator experience is interesting as it shows you your location in the tower. Do check out the glass floor - it's a long way down but not nearly as frighting as it may seem.Do budget some time for this as the lines can be quite long.

Do it!. I planned our visit to Japan months in advance and wanted to visit the Skytree. Found it was difficult to purchase in advance (need Japanese credit card) and heard there could be huge crowds if you just turned up. Decided to book a city tour which included a trip up the tower, It was great and well worth it. There were large queues if you just turned up on the day. So glad I booked it in advance and didn't have to worry about a thing. We payed the extra to go to tip level.

Best tower ive ever been up and probably ever will. Best views ive witnessed.. the incredibly high Tokyo sky tree is phenomenal, has all the means of food and drink on lower deck and can book your ticket for the evening very easily. I went up at night much to my pleasure and got some amazing views of the massive Tokyo city! even got a cracking view of the soccer pitch on top of the building near it. it lights up in the evening to making it for me the best looking tower in the world, ive been up the burj al arab which was also spectacular but this was the one.

2nd tallest structure in the world. The line to purchase tickets was very long yet very efficient. Going up to the 350m floor, I was shocked that the elevator was not see-through but it's a quick ride up. Once you arrive, however, the views of Tokyo are sick. There is a section that has a see-through floor. Of course this spot will be crowded with people wanting to stand on top and take pictures below so you have to be bold and claim a spot when you can. In the basement area there is an expansive food court and food market. I highly recommend it for some good eats. Most of the people don't speak much English but they understand pointing and money. Be adventurous and try it out.

long queue. Took us one hour just to buy tickets! But you have got to admire the staff, it was orderly and efficient. We were lucky to have been part of the 10,000 people limit they set for visitors everyday. Well, we were there early around 10am. The queueing was not as painful as it seems. Once we are on our way to the tower everything went pleasantly and was a breeze. I think we stayed no longer than 30 minutes.

Impressive. We took the city tour bus, which is located behind the train station. On these buses you can't hop off. But you get a good view of the tower and see several other things. Though I must say that the audio guide isn't that good. We were lucky, it was Sunday and infront of the bus terminal is a Park and there was a big flee market on that day. There were a lot of old japanese ítems, from furniture, figures, clothes, kitchen utensils, toys, jewelry and much much more. Very interesting.

645m. That is the height of the tower. This is the tallest building in Japan. Because this is a new attraction it is busy and has new signs etc. You have an option of going to two different platforms of the tower (if you go to the higher level you have to wait another 30 min. (our first line-up was 60 min.) and have to pay an extra 1000 yen) The view is fantastic (even though it wasn't clear outside) The shape of the platform was unique in that it was angled so that it was easier to look down! They have a glass bottomed floor. The tower equals the experience of Toronto tower and the Empire State Building.

Great views but expensive.. Tokyo Sky Tree offers great views of Tokyo. However, admission fee is expensive. As it is always crowded, they have a queuing system that requires you to collect a timed entry coupon. I arrived at about 10am on a Sunday and got a coupon for entry between 12:30 - 1:30pm (if i recall correctly). So about 30mins prior to entry time, you can start queuing to purchase tickets before going up the elevator. Despite the crowds, it was all smooth and fast. You don't have to wait too long in the queue. The timed entry system is excellent in controlling crowd and queue. While waiting for your time entrance, you can walk around Tokyo Sky Tree City which is basically a big shopping mall with lots of shopping and dining options.

Great views, but pick a non windy day. First of all, how to get there. You need to take the Hanzomon line (purple line) to Oshiage. Unless you are in Shibuya, where this line starts, you will need to refer to a subway map to find a connecting line from where you are staying. From the Shinjuku area, take the JR Chou line (free with your JR Rail Pass), to Kinshicho, then change for the Hanzomon line to Oshiage. The Tokyo Skytree is in a big complex also called Solamachi. The most popular ticket is to the Tembo Deck, that is the first observatory, 2,000 Yen, higher up it is 3,000 Yen, adult tickets. We chose a clear beautiful day so as to have a great view, however it was very windy that day, and when we arrived were informed the tower was closed because of the wind. The staff informed us to go to the Solamachi building which is part of the complex, and go up the 31st floor (top floor) and we would get a great view. This floor and the 30th are restaurant floors but one side did offer great views of the city and the entire complex below, including the river that flows thru the area. If you experience long delays for the tower, I would recommend this option as it offers great views and it is free. At the complex there is also the Sumida Aquarium and the Konica Minolta Planetarium. There are literally hundreds of restaurants to satisfy all tastes, and a vast mall for shopping. The Tokyo Skytree is a definite visit for your stay in Tokyo.

Amazing Views. We didn't really know what the Skytree was but you could see it from our hostel so we decided to make our way there & I'm glad we did. We must have gone on a quiet day because there were no lines not even for the elevator, it was a misty/foggy day so that probably helped. We got our tickets and hopped in the elevator *ears popped* up to the 2nd highest floor and wandered around the beautiful area looking down on Tokyo. There were lots of view screens that let you zoom in on static photos of the area at day or night which was fun. Up to the 2nd highest floor and it wasn't a good day to go and even the lady selling the tickets said it was cloudy.Overall enjoyable experience a lot of photo opportunities and even a restaurant.

Awesome View!.
