Got to see Tokyo Sky Tree or the new "Tokyo Tower" on my visit to Japan.For anyone plans to go there, I suggest to set aside 1 whole day of your time as so many things to see and enjoy in one place. I traveled with my 8 yo son and we got to the Tembo Observation Deck on 350th floor. As predicted, the view was spectacular. One thing to note is the elevator. It went up 6 floors per second smoothly so it took less than a minute to reached the deck.Since we arrived around 7PM, we planned to have dinner at Musashi which was located on Tembo Deck. However,we found out later that children only allowed to dine in the restaurant during lunch time only. Bummer!!!But, there were lots of other restaurants in the mall so we can get any pick.They also have a planetarium dan aquarium but we didn't have time to see those. For Rilakuma fans, there was a Rilakuma shop there too.
views. See the extension of Tokyo from here, show me its dimension, and allows to understand his greatness. Besides, its glass floor is breathtaking and interesting

Must go attraction. Go there early!. the Tokyo Sky Tree is a must go attraction, though the ticket price is quite high. To avoid the crowd and long queue, one need to go there early. One got to pay for two tickets to go up, one for 350m, and then pay for another ticket to go up to the top of the tower. It's crowded on 350m, however, it's an impressive view to the whole tokyo. A must go attraction!

Tokyo Skytree is a must do!. Tokyo Skytree is the tallest broadcast tower in the world, so that, by default should make you want to go there. I wasn't sure what to make of Skytree when I first thought about going in it. I didn't know how the crowds would be or how fantastic the view would be because it was a hazy day in Tokyo. You had to get a ticket for a time to stand in line and it was a few hours off, but I didn't care, there are plenty of attractions at the base of Skytree to keep yourself busy (I would recommend the Sumida Aquarium) until you get your ticket for the elevator. Once you get your ticket to the top, the staff is very helpful in getting up to the top. When the doors to the elevator open, I saw the most spectacular metro vista I have ever seen and I couldn't get enough of it. You're nearly 1,500 feet above Tokyo and it doesn't matter if it is hazy, clear, cloudy, day or night, Tokyo Skytree provides a great view for all those who go to the top. For me, the Skytree also provided a once in a lifetime chance to stand 1,500 feet above something and it is an experience that I will never forget. I would also recommend standing on the glass floor and looking down for a pretty crazy experience. Overall, I would highly recommend Tokyo Skytree to anyone who has a few hours to spend in Tokyo.

A lot of fun. Highly recommend this newly built mall. A lot of interesting shops in the mall and you can definitely can spend a whole day there. Many nice restaurants on different levels. But if you want to go to the top level to enjoy the Tokyo city view, you need to book it one month before travel as it is too popular. It was a nice trip and we will go there again.

Terrific view. The basic ticket gets you to the main observation deck which is beautiful. For an extra ¥10.000 you can go to a higher deck which has a glass floor. Didn't see it 'cause it was cloudy, but on a sunny day could be worth it. If you want to eat at the nice restaurant there reserve a table in advance. You won't typically get one as a walk in.

21st century and no option to book online?. I was expecting Tokyo to be exceptionally modern but in fact it is still in the 20th century and SkyTree is the best example. There is no option to book a ticket online unless you have a Japanese credit card - how many tourists actually have one? When you arrive to the spot you can't make a reservation either but instead you have queue up for hours to get a ticket. I don't need to mention that no one from staff actually speaks English so don't bother asking anyone for help.

A must. Amazing views of Tokyo from the sky. Buy tickets online, or go during off peak hours, you will save yourself tons of time and frustration. I went during the day, and it was still crazy busy. But, overall its the best way to see how vast Tokyo is, being the largest metro area in the world. Well worth it!

Exquisite shops, supermarket and souvenirs.. The latest attraction in Tokyo. Besides the observation decks, this place has a very nice supermarket, food court, a well as shops selling all kinds of Japanese souvenirs and character items. The whole place gives you a bright and cheery feeling. Great place for the whole family.

The Queue, The View!. Great experience, if you can time it to be there when the sun is out, sunset and evening - amazing! The queues are crazy, but like everything in Japan, organised. A must do! As you exit, you go down a couple of escalators - still a couple of places to take some photos without the people in the way! :)

Really impressive view of Tokyo at night.. From the ground, we saw how tall the Sky Tree is and I wonder if it woukd shake badly if there is another earthquake. We queued for half an hour befire riding the speedy lift up to the deck. We paid another 1,000 yen each to visit the upper deck. I wish we could spend more time up there. It is a great spot to see Tokyo at night.

Either book online or take a ticket a few hours before you get in. We did not book the tickets online, but not realised we need to take reservation tickets before paying and climbing up. It ruined my schedule as when I first arrived I planned to get inside the tree at that moment, then going to elsewhere afterwards. When we got there we knew we need to take the reservation tickets and came back at the time the reservation tickets show, which is about 3 hours later. So my plan needs to change.Do not recommend going there at night, if you are not familiar with the night at Tokyo, as you will find every direction nearly the same.

Long wait but worth it for the view.. Whether you are talking about the Eiffel Tower, Empire State Building or other similar landmarks, you expect to queue to see them and this was no different. The queue was huge but constantly moving and all operators on deck (as is the case in most Japanese attractions).I absolutely loath queuing but it was undoubtedly worth it. The views from the tallest tower in the world are spectacular and give you some sense of the enormity of the city of Tokyo.Easily accessed by public transport, the cost to ascend to the 350m level was about $20, with a further $10 to go to the 450m level. You could debate whether or not this was worth the extra but we figured that we will probably only be here once, so why not?Staff are again very courteous and the elevator ride is super quick but you barely feel like you are moving. If you are in Tokyo, this is certainly worth a visit.

Worth it, only if you don't have to wait in the line for a ticket. This is a great sightseeing spot to get a true panoramic view of Tokyo, but ONLY if your guide has prereserved your admission ticket. In typical Japanese fashion, your admission time is like clockwork and is very precise. You just arrive 5-10 minutes prior to your admission time and voila, you are inside. Still, be ready to wait 20 minutes or so to take the speedy elevator to the first stop (there are two other stops for additional fees to go even higher). The elevator ride is very entertaining and there are graphics which tell you interesting facts and how long/far it is until you reach your destination (stop). There are four elevators, one for each season and have appropriate graphics for the seasons. Once in the viewing area, you walk around and can look around and there are very helpful maps which tell you exactly what you are looking at in the ceiling to floor glass windows. We stopped at several places to view the skyline and decided we really didn't need to wait in line to see these same sights at a higher and farther view away. Worth seeing if you have an advanced reservation (reserve 60 days in advance -have to pay at reservation time).

Easy Access by Shuttle Bus. It's a special subway station for the Sky Tree but you have to change subway lines. For foreign visitors, it's more convenient to take the Tobu Shuttle Bus for about 23 minutes ride. The bus stop is at Ueno railway station, near the National Museum of Western Art.I visit it on Friday but it's still many visitors. I queue 45 minutes for ticket and wait 25 minutes for the elevator to the Tembo Deck. If you don't mind to give Yen 1000 more to the Tembo Galleria, it's less crowded. To me, the Sky Tree is another city tower, not so special (maybe the crowded visitors and long queuing minimize my interests).

Nice view of Tokyo and surrounding areas. Highest point is 461 metres. Have to pay extra to go to the highest level. Interesting spiral walk way at the top. Fees are pricey. Fairly long queue on an off peak weekday. Cannot imagine on peak periods and weekends. Many shops and restaurants to explore at the shopping mall.

Tokyo Skytree: a view full of wonder!. Tokyo Sky Tree was still under construction during my visit in March of 2012, so upon returning a year later- I had a visit to the Sky Tree on my must see list. Now for some reason I thought I could arrive there, get in line and wait a little while and before too long I'd be whisked away upwards toward the heavens. Well...not quite. the Japanese have nearly perfected the concept of queueing, waiting, shepherding and all around crowd control, meaning that when I arrived (on a Thursday) at 12:30 PM I was welcomed by seemingly thousands of others who had shown up. After a bit of wandering around and acclimating to the new surroundings I was instructed to get a reservation card which dictated a time for me to return in order to queue up to actually buy a ticket-whereby I would get in another line before finally being the aforementioned whisked. My time to return: between 3:30 and 4:00-now to kill three plus hours. I'm not complaining about the process, actually its a marvel to witness it in action, otherwise we have a disorganized mess to contend with. Now on previous trips to Tokyo I have had the occasion to visit the Mori tower, the Tokyo Tower, Sunshine 60 building and Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building, all with their own observation decks and all offering their own impressive views and other niceties. But the new Sky Tree stands apart-not only is it the new standard in height but since it encompasses all the others (in it's own view) and assumes a sentry position on the east side commanding a presence that the others can't achieve. The view is stunning! The $20.00 (give or take depending on current exchange rates with Yen) to go skyward 350 meters is worthwhile. Orienting oneself to the lay of the land is assisted through the use of maps displayed in the viewer's oriented direction. In addition, some offer virtual displays of Tokyo at various times of the day and year-highlighting the visual fest to the eyes that occur in Tokyo during the 4 seasons. There is even a section that has a glass bottom floor for a direct below view, although it is small and a bit underwhelming as a result, but it does allow for a hint at the actual inner workings of the structure itself. Given its location near the Sumida river it is easy to access from most anywhere in Tokyo, and is certainly recognizable for anywhere in Tokyo as well. For those looking for places to go while in Tokyo-the Sky Tree beckons! Resist at your peril or just visit-you'll be glad you did.

Impressive observation tower. If you are pressed for time, skip Tokyo Tower and head straight for Tokyo SkyTree, the newest hotspot for tourist and locals! It's an impressive architectural masterpiece. I couldn't book tickets online and took to queuing for the day ticket to the Temba Deck which was located at 350 meters. The queue was massive but moved quickly and we were able to purchase our tickets within 30 mins. The 360 degree view of the city was an eye opener, unfortunately it was misty on the day of our visit and we couldn't see Mt Fuji from he deck. It's definitely worth a visit!You could purchase another ticket at the Temba Deck which will allow you to visit the Temba Gallery which is located at 450meters. For more information on ticket fees go here http://www.tokyo-skytree.jp/en/index.htmlYou have the option to visit the Sumida aquarium if you are with kids. Refuel at the Tokyo Solamachi with food and more shopping after the viewing.

Cool place to hang out. We didn't get to the top since the queue was too long. It was a Sunday so the place was packed, so we just hung around the open air deck, browsed the mall and enjoyed a hot choco from the cafe on the deck while looking up to the tower brightly lit on a gloomy early winter afternoon. There is a big souvenir shop on all things Sky Tree on the lower floors of the mall. But in case you want to look for some more affordable ones, the small convenience stores down in the subway station also sell some items bearing Sky Tree logos and pictures.

The ultimate view in Tokyo. Getting to the Sky-tree is easy from about anywhere in Tokyo. I got there about 8:30 am and I got in the que outside the building. I waited about 1 and a half hours before I could pay and go up. I Paid 2000 yen and then I made my way to the very fast elevator. When you get to the first level the doors open with a beam of light and your greeted by the staff when you walk out. The view was amazing to say the least. I paid another 750 yen to get my photo taken by the staff and have it printed just for a nice soviernier. I walked around the entire first level to take in the sights. You could pay another 1000 yen to go up to the highest level but i didn't bother. while your there you can have light refreshments from there cafe but this seemed very expensive as you can imagine. Some parts of the floor are glass so you can see the drop beneath you !A must visit if your in Tokyo but because this tower is still very new, it will be busy so get there early if you can.

Awesome at Night and No lines!. Visited Sky Tree on a cloudy May night and it was amazing. The lights of the city are endless. We spent $20 to go to just the first level which is 350 meters high and is plenty. And, best part is that after 8 pm when we arrived there were no lines to go up. This attraction can have waits of over one hour on some days.

Great Views!!!. Should you happen to visit Tokyo - well this place is a must see. Great views from all angles and there are two superb viewing decks. The first deck is 350m high and will cost you Y20 000.00 and the second deck which is at 450m will cost you an extra Y10 000.00. It's very easy to get to site using the extensive Tokyo metro/subway systems from all four corners of Tokyo. Get there early to get a ticket because the place is at times packed. A huge mall is located at the base of the Sky tree with other attractions including an aquarium. By the way the Tokyo Sky tree at 634m is the second tallest structure in the world after the Burj Khalifa in Dubai

loved it. Amazing place, with amazing views! It is crazy busy no doubt about it. Do yourself a favor, but the tickets online and save yourself the hour plus wait in line to buy the tickets. I was upset though they charge you yet another twenty dollars to go to the upper level. There are lots of people in the observation area, but spectacular views. The area around it is also very nice. Asakusa is a great area with shops, restaurants and the Sensoji Temple. Also in Ueno nearby there is large park area, great place to relax.

Second tallest tower in the world. I went here with my girlfriend and after going through the huge mall that the Tokyo Sky Tree is connected to, we decided to go up to the tower itself.The view from Tokyo Sky Tree is amazing, you can even sit down and eat dinner there. I highly recommend to go at night and make sure that it's not cloudy. Amazing experience.

Sky Tree Tower...Doesn't look like a Tree :-). The tower was very nice and I enjoyed going to the top to see the entire city in all it's beauty. Although organized, we were BLESSED that we didn't go on a busy day. First, you have to get a ticket to GET a ticket. The first ticket is the "get in line" with a time on the ticket (our time was 6:30 pm) so at 4 pm we were walking around the many shops and eating establishments. When it was time to get in line to pay, it moved quickly like a amusement park ride. The cost is 10 dollars or 1000 yen to see the 'middle section' section of the tower. To get to the top is ANOTHER 1000 yen; I guess some people don't want to go to the very top for fear of heights, but if you've gone this far, why not continue on? So I paid the other 1000 yen to get to the second set of windows near the very top, and the views were spectacular. There were coffee shops and souvenir stores on both floors, as well. The train station was conveniently located close to the tower which made it much more enjoyable. The train, trolley and subway stations are quite confusing but if you just ask any attendant, they will help you with no problem. Tokyo is so user friendly and I really enjoyed my visit to the "world's tallest tower"

Amazing view from quite an ugly structure. We came here on a rather rainy day, but as we are time limted it was either a 'do it or don't' oppertunity, so we took the gamble. Well worth it. We got up the tower at dusk and by the time we made it to the upper deck (another 1000 Yen) all the lights of Tokyo were on. I'm sure on a nice clear day you could probably see to Fuji and beyond, but just the view of Tokyo itself was pretty amazing.You have to get a timed ticket which will then allow you to queue up and buy the actual ticket. We went on a Sunday afternoon and there was about a two hour gap between the timed ticket and the entry time, so we took this oppertunity to go and get something to eat. After getting the actual ticket there was no delay in going up the tower.Well worth a visit, but do pick a clear day if you can.

Sky Tree is a must see, unless afraid of heights. As tickets are not available to foreigners on-line, go early during the week. Weekends are madness. So is mid-day,so I'm told. We got there around 9am and could have purchased tickets and gone right up; no line at all. However, our husbands were not with us. Came back at 4pm and there was no line for tickets, but there was a minute wait for the elevators. It's worth the price and the extra fee for the highest deck. I was advised to purchase souvenirs at the shop on top because items sold here are exclusive. Yes there are several other souvenir shops but merchandise differs. We got to see the sunset, enjoyed a snack at the cafe (waiting line) and by the time we left (closes at 10pm) we saw the tower lit up at night. Great view and interactive maps.

Get there early to avoid the crowds but worth it. It opens at 8, I arrived at 8.10 on a sunday and already there was a long queue (40 mins), but of course all very efficient so the wait is painless - you buy a ticket to level 350, and then when you get to this level (the main deck) you can then get another ticket for the upper deck (level 450) which needed another 30 minute wait. Views from the top were spectacular (was lucky to get a clear sunny day), but you get similar views from either 350 or 450 - it's just that 450 is a little less crowded. Well worth visiting to give you a good idea of just how dense Tokyo living is, and also an idea of the geography of the whole city. Highly recommend but pick a clear day.

Didn't make it to the observation deck. was here on monday afternoon, but still had so many people at there. Got the flyer to come back and get queue for the ticket later at night for another one hour or more. Usually you even have to queue for the flyer, but at that day there was no line for it. I bet the view must be really good, but the effort was too much for us. So we decide to took some picture from outside and go to asakusa instead. Maybe on next trip will try to go for the observation deck again.

Great view on a clear day. This was a must-do on my Tokyo trip as I can't resist a good viewing tower. Being a bit worried about the long queues mentioned here, I wasn't quite sure what to expect. When we got there not long before sunset on a Thursday night, much to my surprise, there were no queues at all. We got our ticket and took the lift up and were on the lower level viewing deck within 10 minutes of arriving.View is great as expected, and while it was busy, it was not too busy that you couldn't get a good view from a window after a short wait. If you are tight on cash, you could skip the higher viewing platform, as while the views are great and there are less people, I found the lower levels were just as good, and in some cases better if you are trying to take a photo. I also liked that they had a glass floor section on the lower levels where you could look straight down to the group below. Nice.All in all, an enjoyable trip up one of the worlds tallest towers.

It's "in"!. Getting popular. Unique tower with lots of new shops and restaurants. If it's very windy, you cannot go up. And if it's foggy, you see nothing up there. Therefore, when you go up, don't buy the ticket beforehand. You should choose nice weather.

It is man made amazing structure in the world. Tokyo Skytree is an amazing man made stricture in the world. It is directly linked to the subway line. Foot of this structure is the exit of subway line. It is one stop away from Asakusa station. After the exit of the subway station you will be thrilled to see this structure. There is lot of crowd to see this structure. There is long queue to purchase the ticket. It took me 45 minutes to purchase the ticket. There is snake like line to purchase ticket. There are two observatory decks. In the ground floor they give only ticket for first deck for 2000 JPY. It is quiet expensive too. If you want to go second observatory deck, you have to purchase the same from first observatory desk at a cost of another 1000 JPY. High speed elevator took me to first observatory deck. It is observation tower as well as Tokyo broadcasting station. I did not go the second deck. Because, for this purpose there will be another big queue to purchase the ticket. I feel you can find hardly any difference from second deck so far as the view is concerned. You can have breathtaking view of the Tokyo city. All skyscrapers, river, railway line are visible and it is marvelous.It is lovely. Without visiting Tokyo Skytree, your Tokyo visit is incomplete. The day I visited, the visibility was not so good; hence Mount Fuji was not visible from observatory deck. There is big shopping complex and food court at the bottom o the structure. In the third level Sumida Aquarium is worth to visit. I advise to book online ticket (Web booking) to visit this structure. This will save you lot of precious time.

Worth a visit, amazing view of tokyo, but only on a clear day. Dont waste your time if cloudy or raining you won't be able to see anything. It's quite expensive for a family, some tours have group booking discount. If going by yourself get there early before the crowds.

A VISIT TO TOKYO SKY TREE. When we went to Tokyo in September 12, Tokyo Sky Tree had just been opened to Public and from the Net, we came to know that in order to regulate huge rush of crowd , only advance on-line booking was permitted and no day ticket was being given.However, one weekday,after visiting Sensoji temple ,we came to Sky tree station which was only one stop from Asakusa station to sky tree station in Tobu line After reaching ground, we were stunned to see the imposing structure which was about to touch the sky!! On enquiry, I was pleasantly surprised to know that on the spot day tickets were available as rush of visitors had eased out to some extent.I also found that purchasing ticket was made very systematic!First, I stood in a Q behind about 10-15 persons at about 10 am where I was given a time ticket advising to be present in a particular counter from 11-30 am to 12 noon Again I stood in the designated Q behind about 10 persons and got the ticket for the first deck for 2000 Yen. A high speed elevator took us to first deck which had a sky tree cafe, asky tree restaurant and a sky tree shop. After spending some time moving arond the circular deck and appreciating TOKYO sky line, we purchased tickets for the 2nd deck for another 1000 Yen.Another lift took us to the 2nd deck which was 450 meter high whereas 1st deck was at a height of 350 meter. A breath taking view awaited us here and we could wee the whole of TOKYO through the glass lined beck However, Mount Fuji was not visible .After spending some time we came down with a memory worth cherishing albeit expensive.Tokyo Sky Tree happens to be the tallest tower in the World and 2nd tallest structure in the World only after Burz Khalifa.It serves as an observation tower as well as a transmission and broadcasting station.

2nd tallest structure in the world. JPY 3000 for the first observatory. If you want to go to the higher observatory, pay additional JPY 2000 at the ticket booth at 1st observatory. It's a good thing they separated that payment coz it's wasted time and money to go up further if the visibility isn't so good. But the downside of that is you need to line-up again for the 2nd payment and the line at the 1st observatory is long. I was not very impressed with the Tokyo view from the top. (maybe because of the low visibility or maybe because there aren't a lot of interesting buildings/structures around tokyo). There are shopping options at the base of the tower.

Save time book online. An awesome structure, awesome views from Asakusa. Book online and save up to 90 minutes vs. waiting in line. This is still kind of a new attraction, so its always pack with all sorts of visitors, the views are awesome both day and night...

Beautiful view of Tokyo. Never say you have visited Tokyo, if you haven't visit Tokyo Sky Tree (TST).I was visiting Tokyo Sky Tree at 4.00 pm. Luckily, when I was visiting TST, I wasn't too crowded. I enjoyed a beautiful scenery of sunset in Tokyo from hundreds feet above ground.I also bought a TST key holder from the vending machine there (about 800 Yen). You can also engrave your name and date on the back of the key holder with an additional price.You can have dinner on the TST restaurant there.And oh yes.. the elevator is very fast. I think it's the fastest elevator. While we were taken to the above, we can also enjoy the view from the elevator window.

Just wasn't worth the trouble, money or time.. We made dinner reservations via the Imperial Hotel Concierge and were excited for a top notch dinner our last evening in Tokyo. Got there and went way up (very impressive and fast elevators). It was tooooo crowded and difficult to get near windows. We finally went in to sit for dinner thinking we woudl have a great view and relaxing meal. They seated us at a no-view table. Keep in mind it is a fixed price menu for about $175 us. per person. We kindly requested a view table and the manager argued that we had one. We agreed we had a view of the salary men celebratign at the table between us and the window, but that isn't the view we desired. He refused to move our seat and we then departed. Since they won't guarentee a view, I won't waste my time attempting to have dinner their again. Additionally we thought it was a clear day and the view would be endless. That high up it wasn't so clear and the view was quite limited.

Crowded. Go early to avoid the long line for tickets---- gets too crowded but the view of the whole Tokyo beneath you makes up for the long line to get ticket and to get to the elevators. Went there on a Saturday on a long weekend, so there were also long lines for the restaurants; lucky for us, there were outdoor tables at the Tower yard and vendors selling bento boxes for lunch so we had a great, reasonably priced outdoor lunch at the Tower yard!

Breathtaking view. We had been warned that there could be long lines to Sky tree. But when we got there on a Tuesday, we could easily get a time ticket and go shopping elsewhere. Three hours later, it was just to go to the elevator and a ten minute queue before we went up - perfectly organized.The first lift ride is fast, but it is when riding the elevator from floor view of 350 meters to 450 meters, it is really cool. From up there, the view is absolutely breathtaking. You can see the whole city and you get a good overview of how things fit together. This was well worth the money!

Go Early!. Went there with my wife in the morning between 9am to 10am. Was surprised that there was no queue so we were able to go up very fast after buying the tickets. Enjoy the view and its surroundings. Though it was a good and enjoyable experience, we still feel that Effiel tower in general will be better overall.

Beautifully lit-up at night, spectacular views from top. Sleek venue directly linked to a train station and a shopping mall with nice panoramic restaurants and bars on the 30th and 31 floors. The elevated garden of the sky tree is covered with azaleas and the colors are amazing in April and May. The highest structure in East Asia is beautifully lit-up at night and you'll love the sight of it when you take a walk along the right bank of Sumida River.

Amazing views. Yes, its overcrowded. Japan is overcrowded and this is a new attraction, what do you expect? You will be surrounded with people and sometimes you will have to wait your time to be where you want, but the space is very big and they control that the amount of people at the same time is not too high.We went there at 4pm, picked up the time sheet for 6pm and came back at that time. As everything in Japan it was well organized, clean and easy.The views of Tokyo metropolitan area are absolutely stunning. I read a review complaining about the time invested and when speaking about the views it says "are ok". Maybe this person lives 430mt above a city, but this is something you don't get to see everyday. Tokyo is the biggest metropolitan area of the world, so this is one option to have an idea of how big it is.What amazed me most was that Tokyo is a city worth to see from above. They don't have space to waste, so every centimeter is occupied, and still you don't feel too much noise or breathe too much smog.

Good View but expensive for
a "view".. 360 view of Tokyo, aquarium, mall, restaurants but too expensive for a family trip. Subway in the spot and car parking.

Great view. Got there early in the morning midweek queue for no more than 10 minutes for ticket same for the lift. View was very good clear day no clouds paid extra 1000 yen for next level 450m glass floor looking straight down. Spent about two hours well worth a visitAt weekends queue for ticket desk is very long midweek best time.

Worth the time ... what a view!. We reserved and paid (by credit card) online easily (and just a few weeks beforehand). We got to the tower at 7:30 a.m. (we had booked for 8 a.m.) The staff were extremely polite, friendly (always smiling) and helpful ... so, checking in was smooth and efficient. We were one of the first to get into the lifts and go up and up and up. We had a spectacular view of the vastness of Tokyo, and as we had perfect weather (definitely go in winter when the air is crisp and clean), we could see for miles and miles. There were plenty of helpful signs and staff, letting you know what you were looking at and where everything was (i.e. glass for looking down, the loo's and cafe etc.). We spent nearly 3 and a half hours just wandering around and around, snapping away. Luckily enough, we didn't have to wait to enjoy a break in their skytree cafe. We expected to be kicked out after 30 minutes (as the sign hinted at) but, we nearly spent an hour relaxing and enjoying the view. The quality of cakes and hot drinks served were much better than expected and not near as dear as I thought it would ... should be. We even bought the skytree cup (reasonably priced at 800 yen) as our special souvenir, as you can't get it down below in any of the shops (only from the cafe).We made a mistake (misunderstanding the staff's directions) coming down from the very top observatory to the main observatory, before taking our photo ... we explained our mistake to the staff, and they were very accomodating allowing us to go back up again, to take the photo.It did start getting very, very crowded around 11 a.m. and when we came back down there was a very long line waiting ... so, definitely go early, if you hate crowds.We definitley want to go back in the early evening to see the night view, too ...

Stay away for a few months. It's over crowded, you will not see a good view. Be ready to spend the entire day waiting to get to the top. We arrived at 2pm and out Boucher for an actual ticket purchase was at 830pm :(

Ridiculous - don't waste time here. Went, seen, took a picture and left not just disappointed but actually angry. The system is outrageous - foreigners (not in possession of a JP credit card) CANNOT reserve online. Thus your only option is to go, pick up a time sheet (yes, only possible in person for the same day), come back at that very time (roughly 3 hours later!) and wait in line for at least another 30min (to actually purchase a very expensive ticket). Then you get to finally go through this attraction feeling like a herd of catle. View is ok but to be honest Tokyo Tower or any tall hotel in Shinjuku offers similar. There is soooo much to see in Tokyo, it's simply not worth it wasting time with this one.

What a view!. I was in Tokyo visiting family when it was suggested that I should go to the latest attraction in Tokyo.I didn`t know what to expect,but went at around 11am.A little line was forming to get the reservation slips-for the 1pm viewing,which was fine we had 2hrs to look at the other parts of the complex(international brand shops,food court,resturant level etc)At the reserved time we went to buy the tickets to ride up the tower.Another little line up to get to the elevators.It was a smooth,fast,quiet ride to the viewing deck.The view was really amazing,it was a clear day,you can see all the major architecture from that height-tokyo tower,tokyo dome,Asakusa temple etc.There is also a section where there is asection witha glass floor.We also went up a further up in another lift, the view as good as well,less people and congestion.Definately recommend,but go early and during the week day.Would love to go and have dinner in the resturant on level .345

Unique View, Worth the Trip. I went to Tokyo Tower on my last trip years ago, and with the SkyTree now open it was a "must see" according to my Japanese friend who hadn't visited yet either but was dying to go, so we went. We went on a weekend which happened to be a holiday weekend (Coming of Age Day, 成人の日, Seijin no Hi). We called ahead to check on tickets and they were already pre-sold out and only available in person, luckily another friend was able to go to SkyTree earlier in the day and get us 3 reservation slips to ensure we had tickets at our assigned time slot (8pm, last entrance of the day). That day they gave out the last tickets before 2pm so plan ahead on potentially busy days. Also, online ordering was restricted to Japan-issued credit cards only. We finally arrived at our assigned time, turned in our vouchers for tickets, and proceeded to the top. Elevator ride is pretty cool as it's very quick to get so high up and has some surprises for you. View was nice even on a cloudy evening after dark, really gives some perspective to just how massive Tokyo is. Lots of things to see around the decks though, typical tourist things like a cafe and photo opportunities. We paid the extra to go up one more level to the highest possible point. The view doesn't change much but hey, why not, right? A little less crowded upstairs too. Being that we were part of the final timeslot of the day the crowd was manageable. One disappointment was upon leaving everything else (gift shops, restaurants) in the SkyTree complex was already closed. We ended up heading to the Asahi bar around the corner and strolling along the river which was probably a better end to an exhausting day anyways :).

Fantastic views on a clear day. The views from the top of the world's tallest tower are fantastic and you really feel high!I arrived at 10am on a Tuesday morning and had to wait about 15 minutes for a ticket then about 5 minutes for an elevator up to level 350. The views from there are exceptional but you can pay a further 1000 Yen to take another lift up to level 450. There was a queue to buy the ticket of about 10 minutes so, all in all, not bad.There is a shopping mall underneath which has food and drink options.The nearest stations are Tokyo Sky Tree or Oshiage on the Hanzamon Line.Supposed to be earthquake proof but not sure I'd want to try up there!

Go early. Go about 30 mins before it opens. It wasn't too bad and the lines move pretty fast once they open. I can only compare this to the CN tower but the view from the Tokyo Sky tree was better. We caught a glimpse of Mt Fuji that day too so it was well worth it. We went on April 4th which is pretty packed in Japan but still got in without waiting too long. We even took the photo at the top which was like $12 USD. I'm scared of heights so I didn't bother standing on the glass floor. I think the CN tower had a bigger Free glass floor to stand on but this one had one where you pay to get your picture taken.The elevator ride was probably the fastest and smoothest elevator ride I've been in.

good but not great. waited in line 75 mins monday morning at a bit after 10.30 am, glad we didnt take the kids !!once we got up to the floor 350, another line to the floor 450 !! was packed with elderly, and i mean packed, too many people, view was ok but preferred Mori Tower observation deck last time we visited Japan , better cafe and less people, much more relaxing and can sit down and chill there. once we got back down we were hungry and guess what, more queues...aaaaagghh !!apart from the view its cramped, too busy and hardly anywhere to sit and enjoy the view....go to Roppongi and see the sky tree from the Mori Tower and enjoy the art there too.

No Lines and No Wait If You Go Early Or Late. So many people complain about the long lines and hours of waiting. It's all completely unnecessary if you just plan in advance to avoid the crowds. The Sky Tree opens at 8am. We went at 9am and walked right in. No lines at all. We were told that in late morning and afternoons that the wait time can exceed several hours. The Sky Tree offers completely different experiences during day or night visits, so we went back again in the evening to take in the gorgeous night views (and the tower itself is a breathtaking sight at night too, all lit up in gorgeous turquoise blue). In this case, go late. Don't compete with the dinner/date crowds in the early evening when again the wait time can be hours long. Go an hour or two before closing and simply walk right in. We had no lines and no crowds during both of our visits to the Sky Tree, so this is something easily avoided.The only thing we felt was a little "off" was how cleverly they get you to pay twice if you want to go all the way to the top. The initial 2,000 yen ticket only gets you to the first/biggest bauble. If you want to go the highest one, it's another elevator (and another 1,000 yen) from there.Wind also needs to be taken into account. The elevators can't operate in moderate to high winds, so if you're on your way to the Sky Tree and you can see the trees moving briskly in the breeze, don't bother. Come back again later when the wind has died down.

Very long queue to go up!. Didnt manage to go up as the queue was v v long. Perhaps need to go there slightly earlier?Took some photos of the Skytree from below. Very pretty at night.Shopped ard the malls n had dinner there. Nice place to spend an evening..

Sky tree at night. I did not get to up the Sky Tree because of high winds but did go for a walk underneath at nighttime. It was very beautiful with all the lights on and not so many other tourists around.

Atop Tokyo Skytree. Good experience to see a 360-degree view of Tokyo and neighboring cities. This observation tower (height of 634m) is priced reasonably at 1000 yen for the first stop (350 meters). Add another thousand yen and you can reach 450 meters (they should consider lowering the price a bit though). View from the observation deck is fantastic.The better part of my Skytree trip is the convenience of shopping and dining just within the same complex. There is no need to walk far to satisfy cravings for Tempura, curry, ramen and other Japanese dishes. Omiyage shopping can be done here, too. There are also other restos like Denny's and McDonald's for quick bites. I was able to try the famous Tokyo banana tree, a custard cream dessert gaining popularity among locals.

Spectacular views but long wait and queues. Spectacular views but be prepared to wait and queue, maybe even return later to time slot given. Better views if you can visit at night.Total of Jpy 3000 to go to the very top tower (634m total height)plus an additional JPY 1,200 to have a photo taken if you choose.

Amazing view from world tallest tower. i reached there at 11 am and quickly go to the tower entrance to get a slip, the slip will show to u what time u have to come back to queue, i got 4 pm tour to go up. so if u come early, u will get the chance to go up earlier. To spent the time, u can go to nearby Sumida river cruise or Sensoji temple, so if u on your own try to arrange these places in same day. For me i just go shopping at Sky Tree town shopping center, Tokyo Solamachi for last minute shopping as i leaving Japan next day. Around 4pm i went back to queue, very fast i got my ticket (2000 Y)and went up, took about 15 mins, the lift is amazing speedy took us up to 350 m and 450 m (another 1000 Y which is worth visit) i stay until evening, spending time with my coffee in the cafe at 350 m, amazing Greater Tokyo view from afternoon to evening.. Here i posted some photos, hope you guys visit Sky Tree because its really nice.. Enjoy!!

Great view, but long queues. Tokyo Sky Tree is one of the absolute must-see when you visit Tokyo. The view from the top is spectacular and on good days you get to see Fuji mt. However, be prepared to queue for at least a few hours. Show up before 10 AM to get a decent number in the queue. The earlier the better... we arrived 10:15 and had almost 2 hours to kill before getting the elevator.

What a View!!!!!!!. The Sky Tree in Tokyo is the most amazing structure to go up! And 'GO UP' you really do.You have to wait a long while maybe 1 1/2 hours or more depending on the time of day you arrive, and believe me I don't think there would ever be a quiet time to go! But its worth the wait and it was something I had to do, as in my last visit to Tokyo 4 years ago I witnessed the begining of the sky tree building...so to go up it at last was fantastic!If you are in Toyko its a 'Big Must' even if you don't like heights, as I don't, these things have to be done.

Book in advance to avoid disappointment. It took us 25 minutes to get to Sky Tree station from Tokyo CS that sadly turned out to be a wasted journey. We weren't aware before arriving in Tokyo that we needed to book in advance to go to the top of the Sky Tree. We were told that there was a 10 hour wait. Unfortunately, we didn't have that kind of time to go back later on the night and besides we wanted to see Tokyo by day and not by night. Sadly you cant do any of the other attractions on the site either without a ticket so all a bit disappointing really. Got some good pictures of the tower itself but found this to be a small 2nd prize compared to what we could have had.

What a view!. I've visited this place twice and both times were different. First off, Once you know where you are staying call the concierge and get your tickets ahead of time! Day of purchase waiting can last more than two hours. When you pre-purchase beware though, some will sell tickets for a specific time (hour of day), and some for a specific day. I opted for the latter. the draw back to pre-purchase is if you get an unclear day you're stuck. Once you get there show them your ticket and they will guide you to the entrance. Once you get to the top (almost to the top) you look around, buy ice cream, drink coffee, etc. You enjoy a panoramic view of Tokyo. I've been told that on a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji. A glass for to step on and view straight down if you have the stomach for it is available. For an additional fee you can go up higher to the summit (100 meters higher). I did it the first time and was nice but not much more to see or do. All in all it was fun to see and do. you can make a half day out of the place. A Large multi-level mall is available with many dinning options. A subway stop is available there as well. Lockers at the base of the tower are available to store all your stuff.

To go to the top there was a 4 hour wait. If you want to go to the top, you have to go and get a card from a tent on a roof deck. The card says what time you cane come back to BUY your ticket to the top. Then you wait in line to buy your ticket. Then you wait to go up. At 3:30 we received a ticket to come back at 7:30. I suppose if we had known and had wanted to spend time in the mall below, we would have done so. But this was not where we wanted to spend the day. It was impressive to see it from below though.

great place to hang out at night. the restaurants, the miyazaki kantoku shop, the views, shopping mall was great.Travel by subway to Tokyo sky tree is very easy and smooth. It is the last station.Didnt get the chance the enter the planetarium as during that time it was open to adults only(after 8pm theatre)
Tokyo Sky Tree. Nice souvenirs. Not so expensive. I bought ref magnets with Tokyo Sky Tree label. Tea and soft mellows cookies. Taste good.

A trip up to the Sky!. Lift off! Really, once you're in that elevator it feels as if you've left not only earth, but Earth! then, as the doors open here is the amazing view of the night lights of Tokyo! Even though we didn't got to the top-deck we were stunned; it was well worth it! It felt like viewing intergalactic city from a space station. It was about 9-9:30pm on a weeknight, close to closing time, there was no lines, no one there but the staff ready to greet you with a smile. I would definitely go there at night. We've seen the city from above daytime - dramatically different experience!

Go in the morning!. Out of pure luck, because it fit in my schedule that way, I showed up just before it opened (10 am) and consequently the lines were not very long. I was nervous that the tower was so unpopular, until I got down about an hour later and saw the HUGE line. So the moral here is, go when it opens. You get a daytime view, which is very nice. Sunset and nighttime views might be nice too, but might be harder to time.It's very expensive to go up and quite touristy (they sell Skytree souvenirs and take photos of you that they try to sell you, etc). But it's a nice view- you can see the Tokyo attractions laid out in front of you, like the Imperial Palace, Ginza skyscrapers, the Odaiba Ferris Wheel, etc. You can also see Mt Fuji if it's a nice day. Afterwards you can stroll around the shopping complex, which has some souvenir shops and typical Japanese restaurants.

Prepare for long queue. We were told by Japanese friends try to avoid go there on Sat, Sun and Public Holiday. We think we are smart enough to pick a regular day around lunch time. However, once we arrive the ticket office, we know we are wrong, the signage said mini waiting hour to get the tickets would be more than 60 mins. Without much choice, we start to queue. Surprisingly, most of the visitors are Japanese.After 75mins, we got out tickets for Tokyo Sky Tree Tembo Deck ¥2,000, head up to 350m. Again, need to queue for the elevators to get up. The views are breathtaking! We also purchased the Tokyo Sky Tree Tembo Galleria (¥1,000) which took another set of elevators to head up to 450m. Amazing view plus fewer visitors. It would be best if overseas visitors could also enjoy the online ticket reservation!

Very long wait. Impressive tower. I was quite excited to go to Tokyo Sky Tree because I had been to Tokyo Tower in the past and I got carried away in the excitement of the Japanese and a new tourist attraction.However, the wait was over 1 hour for a ticket and to get in, and I was with a toddler. I persevered because I was with a Japanese friend and didn't want to offend, however would have given up otherwise.I would recommend pre-booking tickets on the Internet if you can. For the amount of time we spent up on the observation deck, and the ¥2000 entry fee, I don't really think it was worth it.

Go early or you wont get up. This new tower looks great from a distance but like all Japanese novelty attractions it gets very busy. We arrived early afternoon and the earliest we were able to get a ticket was as it was getting dark. We wanted to see Tokyo in daylight so missed the trip to the top. Not the cheapest ticket either.

Buy the video.... Well, it is cool to say I have been up in the tallest tower in the world, but it did pretty much shoot the entire afternoon. And we didn't see as much of Tokyo as you can from Tokyo Tower or Roppongi Hills, because the pollution (yellow sand from China) was worse the higher you went. I didn't know about getting online reservations, but it turns out that can only be done with credit cards issued in Japan. If you know someone who has one of those, force them to help you out. Advance tickets can also be gotten through some travel agents, says the web site, so I'll look into that for the next time. I note on their website that they are not selling tickets "at the door" during school holidays (22. May- 10. July), so try the travel agent route if that's when you are traveling to Tokyo.Here's the website. http://www.tokyo-skytree.jp/en/reservation/We were told waiting time was abut one hour, but it was nearly two before we got to the counter to buy tickets. From then on fairly smooth process. Elevator ride to the top was incredibly fast and smooth, with minimal ear-popping. But at 350 meters one could barely see across the Sumidagawa, let alone the vast expanse of Tokyo, and of course Mt Fuji was just a dream. Ticket to the higher level is purchased at 350 meters, so if you see a break in the crowd, jump in line. It was worth the extra 1000 yen, if only for the mural of Tokyo, done by a foreigner with a great sense of humour in traditional Japanese style.Food available at the top was minimal, just a coffee shop, as the more formal Japanese restaurant was fully booked already. The mall around the lower six or seven floors had some nice shops in it, but was totally jammed, and we were there on a Wednesday, with school still in session. Unless it's your only chance, I'd give it a year or two for the crowds to die down.
Nice Tower. Much better and taller than the old Tokyo Tower, entrance fee is required if you want to go on the observation deck and be prepared for long lines ...

A Beauty on the Sky Line.... Very impressed and Happy that the Japanese have built the worlds tallest tower (not building, that's in Dubai) in the worlds most earthquake prone country (avg. 1300 earthquakes per year). It's a marvel of engineering, and after one year open, you still can't get up there unless you have 3 or 4 hours to wait. But go up the building just next to the SKY tree, for free views and some food. Nice at sunset, and when the lights go on after dark!

Didn't quite get to the top but still impressive.. We now know you should call and check if the top is open if the weather is windy!. When we arrived the top was closed down due to high winds so we could only get to the bars/restaurants and shops of one of the towers on the 31st floor. There is a bar where you can have a drink and look out at the Sky tree and it is awesome. Huge, high and lit up.We'll go back again next time we go to Tokyo and hopefully get to the top. So call or maybe check the website before you head out there.

Sky Tree Great at Night. Arrived on a not-busy evening but still had a 90 min wait in the shopping mall (better than waiting in line). You arrive, go to a tent outside and receive a time card then go shopping or have a meal. Don't go inside the building until a little before your time card, then you purchase your ticket 2000 yen for adults--- a tad more than $20 at today's rates-- and head to the "shuttles" (elevators) and begin your tour. Since there was not a big crowd (it was a Wed night) everything went smoothly after the initial wait.We found everything about Sky Tree to be exquisitely done. The art in the lobby, the animated displays on the main viewing platform, the lighting and layout...all lovely. You can pay another 1000 yen to go to the upper viewing platform. We decided another ten bucks to see the whole thing was worth it and we were not disappointed! More awesome lighting and atmosphere, a place where you can stand over a glass floor and take a photo, great view of the inner structure of the tower.I would love to go back on a clear day and see Mt. Fuji, but honestly, I think night time is the best.

Stunning view, but priced accordingly. Since this is such an opportunity that you really can't afford to pass it up. The views are spectacular (comparable to being in a low-flying plane) and are the only way to really comprehend the enormity of Tokyo. It's a shorter excursion, but you'll need to set aside a good chunk of time to wait in all the lines. There is an extensive line for tickets, as well as subsequent lines at different elevator stops along the way. Each time, you must wait for another elevator to take you higher, and you will need to pay an additional cost to go past the halfway point. This was pricey, but it's an expensive view, so I'd say I got my money's worth. After you come back down, I would recommend visiting the mall underneath the tower to rest your feet and enjoy a nice treat.

Arguably the best view of Tokyo you can get plus more!. If you think the Tokyo Sky Tree is just a tower you go up to see views, you are wrong! It is situated in a small sort of shopping mall but as I am not much of a shopper I went for 2 things, the aquarium and the Sky Tree. To get there, I walked from Asakusa because I was alone and don't mind walking, but there is a train that does take you there (which I used to get back to my hotel). The aquarium was rather spectacular considering the size of space given, but used the number of floors to their advantage. The biggest attraction was the live penguin show they have, were they feed the penguins calling out their names and watching them dash in the water to get the fish. Also the displays they had where you could see the researchers doing research and their experiments, mainly the jellyfish. The SkyTree is more expensive than the Tokyo Tower but for a reason, you can go higher. I somehow got lucky and got some amazing shots of the sun breaking through the clouds as it was a little late, but not late enough to see the sunset. It was very crowded, I judged it by how easy it was to get a photo of the glass floor area and it was pretty easy. I couldn't go to the second level as I didn't have enough cash to get home (was very sad about that) but I hear that is is even more amazing, and would have probably waited up there for the sunset. If you only want to go up 1 tower in Tokyo, I'd say the Sky Tree is your best option because of it's height and that it is in a small shopping mall, which is helpful for having a lot of things close together and saving on travel.

gorgeous view!. I was so glad I went up to Tokyo Sky Tree! Great view of this amazing city from up there! A definite must-do if you're in Tokyo. Also, the shopping mall is great with a lots of shopping!! Also, you've got to buy the Tokyo Banana Tree!! BUY THEM ALLL! I actually went back there for a second time to buy more to bring back home. Very yummy!!I walked from Asakusa towards Sky Tree. Took me about 30 minutes by foot. Lovely walk and I got to enjoy the wonderful streets of Tokyo. I think it is a good idea to talk a stroll around the area. It isn't as busy as Shibuya etc; but it's nice enough to deserve some of our precious time.Souvenirs sold at the lobby area are quite pricey though. But other than that; way to go, Sky Tree!

Tokyo Sky Tree and its vicinity. The Tokyo Sky Tree is quite a new tourist attraction in Tokyo. You can enjoy an excellent view of Tokyo and its vicinity, all you can expect to see when you are 350m to 450m above from ground level.Apart from the tower, the facilities nearby are very amazing. Wide varieties of shops and restaurants are located and you will definitely need at least a whole day to explore it!Furthermore, as the tower is located in the district of Sumida, which has not been the most popular spots as Ginza, Shibuya and Shinjuku, you can take your time to stroll around to explore the authentic Japanese streets in the vicinity of Tokyo Sky Tree. Museums and old-styled Japanese groceries, gift stores, cafe and restaurants are places to visit and they have very good tour guides which you can obtain from tourist information center.If you know a friend who lives in Tokyo, you may even ask him/her to get a ticket for you online which may save you some time in queuing for the admission tickets OR you may even stay in a hotel nearby which provides accommodation and Tokyo Sky Tree admission ticket package.

The view is great!. The view is way better than tokyo tower. You can actually see entire city. We were lucky to have our business partner to book the tickets in advance. The fee will cost about 2000yen for the standard 350m deck and additonal 1000 yen if you want to go to the 450m deck. We only queued for like 15min to get up the 350m deck and 5min to get up the 450m deck. It is very crowded since it just opened last May.

Fantastic view, but crowded. We were extremely lucky waited just 40 minutes for same day tickets at 9:30am on a Monday. As soon as we got there, big crowds started queuing behind us. Booking tickets online might be an option since there is a kiosk for that. We could only go up as far as 350m due to the strong winds. Regardless, the views of the city and Mt. Fuji were breathtaking. Also enjoyed the exhibition areas which showcased products from all over Japan. The food court was a bit difficult to locate but there are lots of different restaurants serving a range of of Japanese and western style food.

Plan your visit, be aware of the crowds. Tokyo has an amazing skyline you must see it from one tower or the other.The Sky tree is pretty new (2012) so it is very popular also among local travelers.When I got there (11am on a Wednesday) tickets were available for 14pm only and I didn't have the time to wait or to go back. So be aware of this !!!I would recommend going first to skytree see the queue. If you have too long wait hours (2+) you can go and visit Asakusa and the Sensoji tempe, the Nakamise shopping street and then come back. there is also a fancy shopping mall and plenty of restaurants around so another option is to plan your shopping / launch / dinner for your wait period.Best of luck with your visit!Even if you don;t go up it is worth visiting the site, as it is amazing to stand next to the tower ... I've been "up" in other buildings (office in Roppongi Mori tower, hotel room in Shinjuku) so I didn't mind the view that much :)

See Tokyo from the air. The purpose built Tokyo Sky Tree is a great way to see this buzzing city. There are two viewing platforms at 350 metres and 450 metres. We only went as far as the first level - but that was more than enough. Booking and entrance was very well-managed. When you arrive on site head for the first queue you see - which will give you a time slot for your actual entrance. You hold onto this ticket until your half-hour time slot and then join the main queue at the appropriate juncture.In the meantime you can catch some food or shopping at the mall below the Sky Tree.You move forward pretty rapidly to the ticket desk and buy your ticket for the 350m level. This is all handled with the utmost efficiency. At the 350m level there is a 360 degree viewing gallery. We arrived half an hour before sunset and stayed until half an hour after sunset, thus picking up the best of the views by day and night. I would recommend that you plan your visit to do the same. After all, if you've flown 10k miles to be in Japan it would be a shame not to maximise the effect.If you want to go to the 450m level there is an additional payment - payable as you go from the 350m gallery - but, to be honest, unless you are a numbers junkie, I'm not sure what advantage you would get from the view at that higher level. In fact you might have more difficulty in focusing on the ground. By the way - using a smart phone camera as your main tool is more or less a waste of time. Bring your best digital camera.

Disappointed. We got up super early to go to the Skytree on a Saturday.. We got there by 9:30 and went to buy tickets but were told it was sold out for the rest of the day! Very disappointed as we weren't able to go back there, there are some nice shops and eateries at the bottom few floors of the tower. If you are planning to visit the sky tree, maybe don't go on a weekend and get there super early!! We also tried to purchase tickets online, but weren't able to as we didn't have a Japanese credit card which we though was silly!

Too long queue, nice view though. Since it's a new landmark in tokyo; if you are in tokyo with a free time, a must place to check out.I only get to the ground of the place because it will take me to book and to queue up for almost a day to get up there. The lower part is ok. Spend time relaxing and go for a green tea ice cream which is very good.

Good view. The tower itself is very nice to look at from outside, its very tall and magnificent. About the view from the tower observatory, I suggest to go during night. I went at the morning, the view is just so so. Not very special. I believe the night view will be much more stunning. Unfortunately, you have to queue for a long line to go up. Even if you reach the observatory, the sheer amount of visitors might make your trip less enjoyable.

wonderful nite view for Tokyo. It's expensive (2000Yen to Tembo & frm 1st deck another 1000Yen to 2nd deck), compare to the free TMG, not to mention the long queue even on weekday, one have to get a numbered ticket for the time slot then upon time slot have to queue again for the ticket purchase (which i totally feel its a stupid system, they shud hav let u buy the ticket while waitin for entrance timing instead of reach entrance timing then queue for ticket), thn hav to queue & squeeze for the lift thn only reach the ultimate destination. I do not want to pre-book the ticket scaring the weathr might b awful since the adm is so expensive. The 1st deck wide window allows better view, 2nd deck thou higher but have more bars in btw so difficult for pics but will have wider window near end of the route. I recommend goin in the late evenin to see the sunset & wait for the nite view, also make sure to check weather. Also note that there're gaps btw window & safety bar so be careful of ur mobile phone & cameras whn takin pics, i've seen 2 ppl drop their mobile into the gap during my visit & required the staff to retrieve. This is recommended for visit If u hav time & budget & don wanna miss the latest landmark of Tokyo, else TMG and Tokyo Tower will be better option

Stunning night view. 因為害怕訂不到票，所以我們在出發前就事先到晴空塔的官網訂了票。雖然指定日期、時間的票價會比只有指定日期的票貴上500日幣，但是對於時間預算不多的我們來說，還是值得的。我們當日上午先逛淺草寺，再步行至晴空塔(約20~30分鐘)，塔旁邊的附設購物中心"Soramachi"也蠻有趣的，可以消磨一些時間。到了塔頂基本上沒有什麼設施可以玩，就是看看夜景、也可以請服務人員拍照，一張紀念照1200日圓，可選擇買或不買，不過也可以請他們用一台自己的相機幫忙拍照留念(免費)。如果在下午就結束晴空塔的行程的話，也可以考慮搭Tokyo Cruise(水上巴士)到台場去進行夜間的行程。Tokyo Cruise站就在東武淺草站旁邊(非都營淺草站，要注意)，約1個小時20分鐘左右可抵達台場，票價大人為1500日幣左右。I had read lots reviews of "lone queue" and "long waiting time for buying tickets", so I decided to book tickets from its official site. Although it is 500 Yen more expensive for a date & time reserved ticket than the simple one (date reserved), it was still worth for us visitors.We were lucky that after one year's service, there were not so crowded than we expected--although we went there on Chinese New Year vacation! Of course, the reserved ticket also did a good help for us. The night view was stunning (we entered around 17:30), Tokyo City seemed to expend until the horizon, which is the largest metro I have ever seen. There were some shops (cafe, souvenir, photo taking...etc) on the top. Photo service is 1200 yen once (buy or not) and they also take one photo with your camera.It was a good experience, and the shopping mall "Soramachi" was also fun.Worth a visit!p.s. we went Asakusa Temple first in the morning and then walk to Sky Tree. Soramachi was our time-killer in the afternoon. If you finish visiting Sky Tree in afternoon, you can also try taking a cruise to Odaiba for night life! The Tokyo Cruise station is right close to Tobu Asakusa Station (3 min's walk from subway Asakusa Station)!

Over-rated tourist attraction. Tokyo Sky Tree was crowded - long lines for tickets - close to an hour wait until we got on the elevator. Recommend going to the Tokyo Tower. Positive is the shopping on the lower levels (2-4). Food vendors are abundant. You could easily have lunch or dinner here.

Yes, it is tall.. After reading previous TripAdvisor reviews about long queues at this place we decided to 'jump the queue' and book it as part of a guided tour. Bad move. The day we booked was wet and snowing, and after visiting Asakusa (a place we always enjoy, but have been to several times previously) we arrived at SkyTree at around 1630. Yes, we missed the queues and crowds, but also the view. We only went to the first viewing level, and for the 20 minutes or so we spent there had a brief 5 second view (looking straight down to the ground) as the clouds and fog parted momentarily.We won't bother going back. Much prefer the character and charm of Tokyo Tower.I can only suggest to pick a clear day and join the queue if you really want to see anything.

Quite a long queue but worth visiting. It's worth going up this new Tokyo Tower but the queue is a bit long. We were lining up for close to an hour before we can get the tickets up. Also, need to get a booking ticket with time specified for return when we arrived since you can't get in to line up right away. View was good and can see quite far away on a sunny day even at night. We can even watch the old Tokyo Tower from here. The environment was comtemporary, lifts design was good. We were just at the 1st level of the observation floors (around 350m) with ticket charging 2000 yen for one adult and didn't go up to the 450m though since it was close to their closing time at 10pm when we were up there. Still with lots of people before closing and most were local Japanese than tourists. The glass floors looking down to the tower base are pretty too, and shops and restaurants nearby are good and you can spend some time there if you are around.

Just WOW!. The view from the 3500m level of the Sky Tree tower was absolutely magnificnet, I have never ever seen a view spectacular as such. Lineup lasted for about an hour, and the basic cost to the 3500m level is 2000 yen. You can book online 3 days beforehand, but last time I checked everything is done in Japanese only. Whatever, I loved the view so much, such that I returned 2 days later (and went through that 45 minutes line up again) just to admire Tokyo's one-of-a-kind night skyline. Once you are up on the "basic" 3500m level, you can choose to go further up to the 4500m level for an extra 1000 yen, and along with that another 15 minutes wait in line. While I did pay that extra 1000 yen and went right to the top (4500m above ground), I would not recommend that "bonus" level: the view from there isn't really any much better than the one you get at 3500m, and the annoying coloured lights shining on the sides of the walkway actually became an annoying source of visual obstruction. Transportation to the Sky Tree Tower is quite easy for the most part: get off at Tokyo Skytree Station along the Tobu Subway line (from Asakusa Station) or Oshiage Station along the Toei Asakusa Subway Line, make sure you study that subway map before moving an inch away from your hotel room though! If you visit during weekends / holidays, you may be issued a ticket with a specified time of visit when you first arrive. So do keep that in mind, and it might be a smart idea to "check-in" at the tower and grab that ticket first, then go for dinner and take a walk, and then visit the tower about 2 hours after the ticket is issued. If you have to choose between going during daytime or night time, I would recommend the night view over the daytime view.......if you can afford the time and money to do both, that's the best in my opinion!

Not worth it. I went to skytree waited for 45 mins to get up to the first deck, at a cost of 2000 yen, admittedly the view is spectacular but once at the observation deck they further charge you 1000 yen to go up to the higher deck, which isn't explained to you at ground level. We found better views at the tokyo government building ( for free ) an also the observation deck at daimon metro station for 1000 yen, both have good views of tokyo tower an skytree,

Tourist Trap!!. I happened to be in the vicinity and decided to visit the Skytree to see what the hype was all about. Yes, it's super tall but there were no tickets available to go up to the observation deck. I suppose that would be my fault for not making reservations but really, would I ever make a reservation to go up an observation deck? Probably not. Anyway, we decided to walk around the shopping section of the tower since we were already there...big mistake! All the floors were ridiculously crowded and you could barely move. We literally spent 15 minutes there and left. Even had I gone on a less congested day, I don't think I would've found it to be "all that." But, yes, the structure is impressively tall. If you're into tall towers, you will definitely appreciate it. It just wasn't for me and my family.So my advice would be 1) Avoid weekends if you're planning to go or wait another year for people get over the novelty of it. 2) Make reservations if you want to go to the observation deck. 3) If going from Ueno, opt to take the subway rather than a bus. Even if this requires you to switch trains at Asakusa, it's likely to be quicker.

Magnificent View, but book online in advance. Go show will result you to can't go up to observation deck at all (specially in weekend) or can go only hours later. Book online and reserve your time slot before.View was superb, but personally I prefer the view from Mori tower which I feel more compelling since it has Tokyo Tower and Sky Tree in it. Not sure why they design that way, but the window contain frames which avoid you from having clear open wide view. The tower is so tall so simple camera can't capture the detail of things down bellow.Nevertheless, the view with naked eyes is breath taking...Oh, limited (and expensive) food on observation deck, so eat at the base mall (Soramachi) that has many selection before go up.

The sky is the limit, or not.... 450 metres above the ground the view is fantastic. And, after four days of traveling back and forth in the city, you suddenly understand how much more there is to see. The elevator runs like a rocket (fortunately, the sky is not the limit) to the first platform at 350 metres. The next elevator brings you to the 450 metres platform, with some amazing floor sections made of glass. An excellent opportunity to check out who is the bravest in the family.

Expensive and time consuming; but the view is mind-blowing. The Sky Tree is the newest attraction in Tokyo. The thing is huge. 634m in heigt. There are no sky scrapers around so it looks even higher.There is a sight seeing platform at 350m. It cost 2000yen. If you want to visit Tokyo from 450m height you have to pay another 1000en. But the view is awesome. If you are there you realize how big Tokyo is. At night it is a ocean of tiny lights. You definately have to bring a zoom objective or a spygalss with you to dive into this ocean.Getting a ticket: That is the biggest problem. When you arrive around noon, you have to queue approx 1 hour for "waiting ticket". When arrived at 1pm the gave me a ticket for 3:30pm. So I had to wait and the queue again. The waiting ticket allows you to buy a ticket within a 30min time limit. I you miss it, you need a new waiting ticket. At all: Gettting into the tower is very time-consuming. I hope it will get easier, if the hype is cools down.Getting there: The subway station is called Oshiage. There is one Tokyo Metro line and one Toei Subway Line leading to that station. It is 1,5km away from the famouse Asakusa shrine.

Worth a view!. The Tokyo Sky Tree offers you a panoramic view of the whole city area of Tokyo. Two main floors are accessible with an extra cost for the second one (you pay it once arrive in the first floor).Few tips: go there at night 1 hour before it closes (i spent 30 sec in the line..) - i wouldn't recommend specially the second floor as it doesn't really offer more than the first one (no restaurant, no additionnal explanations, ...) + it's harder to take "good" picture at night from there since you cannot put directly the lens of your dslr camera on the front glass cause the gap between the handrail and the window is too large (tripod are forbidden as in all kind of those places).The view is really awesome when sky's clear Sky tree is very easily accessble from Asakusa.

Things to do in Tokyo for weekend. 1/ Tokyo Skytree - get the Subway 'A Line' to A20 at about 13:00, then get a ticket which will allow you to start queuing for a ticket to go up at about 16:00 (a ticket to get a ticket!). This is ok though as the Tokyo Subway system is awesome, really easy for foreigner to use, cheap, fast, and very extensive city coverage, so, once you have the Skytree ticket to allow you to come back for a ticket, get back on the Subway & go to Ueno Park & Zoo at Subway G16 (10 minutes Subway away) to see the park & go into the Zoo (about US$5) which has Giant Panda's. When you head back to the Skytree for 16:00, be prepared to queue for maybe an hour with the other hundreds of people, but stick it out & get to the top of the Skytree, where you'll see (along the crowds of other people in there) the best view of Tokyo there is, including Mount Fuji if it's a clear day.2/ Ueno Park & Zoo - see above.3/ Yoyogi Park - F15 on the Subway. Before you go, buy a small bag of Sunflower Seeds from any seveneleven and go into the small gardens within the park (for maybe US$3) and feed the small birds which will land on your hand. See the Costumed people here too ('Cos-Play') in the Summer.4/ Tokyo Shinjuku Gyoen Park - F13 on the Subway. An absolutely stunning Park that'll make you amazed that you're in a huge city like Tokyo when you're stood in almost deserted silence in what seems the wild countryside woodland & grassed field areas.5/ Nights out in Kabukichu & Roppogni - not so bad places if you choose normal bars with no cover charge. The Nigerian touts are relentless & will annoy you after not too long but if you want a bar with working girls it'll cost you at least 2000 Yen to even get in and then the prices you pay after that may depend on if you've brokered a good deal with these Nigerian guys before you go in, but be careful. Roppogni is the better of the two places. Motown 1 bar in Roppogni was small but 'bouncing' with happy loud dancing people & 80's/90's/00's classic music.6/ Ginza Shopping Street - G9 on the Subway. Get there before 20:00 as that's when the shops close, but if you can time it to be after dark (but before 20:00) then you'll be very impressed with the bright lights. A very clean and impressive street. Also try New York basement bar here, the Beercan Chicken is superb.AVOID: Park Hyatt Hotel, it's a good view from the bar windows but to even order a drink it costs an initial US$20. Also it's not near a Subway, which is rare in Tokyo with so many Subways & Stations. Overrated just like the film the Bill Murray film that it trades its name on.BE WARNED: If you fly from or to Narita Airport allow 2 hours to/from Tokyo (not including check in time). Also - do not fear the Subway, so easy, so clean, so safe, so quiet, so cheap - DO NOT get a taxi from either Narita (26,000 yen) OR Haneda (8000 Yen) Airports into Tokyo, very expensive!

The first deck is enough - don't go to the second (higher) one. Despite what the previous reviews say about having to queue up long, mine was a relatively short breeze to the ticket counter (I went there in November). The queue after purchasing the ticket wasn't that long either - it was just a security clearance check followed by a wait at the lobby for a very big lift to come down and fetch you up.The view of the city from the first deck was splendid and I could zoom in to see cars and people even though my camera wasn't that sharp or powerful. The tower itself was very new (since it just opened recently) and the service provided was really good, something that you'd more often than not expect from the Japanese people. Once in a while two window cleaners would descend from OUTSIDE the building (in an enclosed platform hung by tension cables of course) - it must take a lot of real guts to perform such a job - and they were still ever so pleasant to pose cheerfully for us to take pictures! In fact what made this structure stand out wasn't only its own unique features but the attitude of its staff as well.One tip to save your cash - buy tickets to the first observation deck only (Tembo deck). The second one (Galleria deck) which is located higher above costs an extra thousand yen and I didn't manage to see any difference in the view of the city. There are other features marketed on the brochure to entice you to go (like a room filled with lights) - they are heavily exaggerated and aren't anything special once you see them.
big and shiny. easy to get to by train.attached to a shopping centre with restaurantsviewing deck closed by 10pm, so go early.

The 1st tallest tower in the world (2nd structure). The 1st tallest tower in the world (2nd structure)
Spectacular view and great experiencie day-night!
Great shoping mall there...
Hayam miyazaki fans have a great opportunity for visit its store
Lots of food and souvenirs

excellent view of Tokyo but it's crowded. I was lucky to be invited to visit Sky tree without of much queuing but there were thousand of people and the elevator was packed. There are different elevators to go up - decorated with 4 season-motif on ceiling. Nice view from the top - but it is really crowded everywhere and if not looking outside, you only see people. There is a restaurant on the top but not sure it's worth it as I did not visit. It's a breathtaking view, you can see Sumida river to Tokyo bay, Shinjuku and some mountains.
