On the ground floor, there is a display of all high towers in the world, which shows that this Tokyo Sky tree is the tallest in the world now. The elevator is impressively quick to go up. As it is really crowded, I am not sure if it's worth taking time to visit if you have only few days in Tokyo.

2nd Tallest Structure in the World. If you come to Tokyo then you should not miss Tokyo Skytree. Everybody is lining up to get up the Top deck (450m), so make sure you get there on weekdays, or buy the tickets online in advance. If you are out of luck, you can go to the Lower deck (350m), it's pretty good to see the beautiful scenery of Tokyo, lots of food shopping and sky tree souvenirs.

Stunning view, highly recommended at sunset. Simply stunning view from both decks. Once you did the long queue (I feel length depends on when/which day) to get up to the main deck, the extra (shorter) queue (and ticket) for the higher deck is highly recommended. We went on the late afternoon, so we hit the higher deck at sunset, with breath-taking views of the city "lighting up" and the sun setting down with mount Fuji rendered in vibrant golden colors. Big surprise: the espresso and the cake we got at the main deck bar, while "reasonably" overpriced, were both excellent!

Do you like to queue?. We visited this amazing tower during New Year holiday along with most of Tokyo. I don't know if you can still book on line but try as we queued to get a ticket for a place in the queue for a visit 2 hours in advance, and when we came out the time was 5 hours . Still, there is a big shopping centre adjacent with some souvenirs and mid - range goods as well as food. The view is amazing and pay the extra ¥1000 for the very top, well worth it.

Excellent view, be aware of the queues. Amazing view. We went on a clear day and could see all the way to Mt Fuji without any problems. Queue is a bit of a pain. 1-1.5 wait and we arrived @ 9:00. You get a ticket which tells you when you can come back to queue. Ours was for 12:00-12:30 time slot. By about 13:30 we had reached the Skytree ticket counter. So get there early, wait until about 10 minutes before your queuing timeslot is due to complete (eg for us 12:20) and then enter the queue, that will save you 20 minutes of queuing. BTW it's school holidays in Tokyo at the moment so queue's might settle down a bit soon !

Great view, long queue... Be ready for queuing... You have to queue to get to the ticket counters, and then queue again to get inside the lift that will take you 350 metres up high in a very short time. But the queue was worth it. We enjoyed the view of Tokyo from the deck. You can take another lift to go further up, only if you are wiling to queueagain to buy the ticket. We went there at day time, and my kids enjoyed the view, where you can see mountains that surrround Tokyo, including mt. Fuji. There is also a mall at the base of the tower, so you can spend more time there. Will definitely visit again.

if you like queuing.. This is the worst organization I have ever seen. As others have already reported, you have to queue to get a card telling at what time you can queue again to buy the ticket. We were supposed to get access to the ticket counter at 16:00-16:30, to finally get our ticket at 17:30, missed the day light, the sun set...Thousand of people queuing, only 8 ticket counter open, a mess. The contrary of what you could expect from Japan. We have seen the same at the airports, i.e.: chits Sapporo, where to have to queue 3 times to get through the check in area, Narita, same, you need to get the boarding pass and then only you can check in the luggages, this is really what we were not expecting from Japan, and the Sky tree is another good example. We have seen old peoples having to queue, even one old grand ma was walking with a walking stick and queuing, no priority lines, small children have to be carried....The view is great but not worth the headache! Lot of improvement on the efficiency sides.

What a view. Get there early if you haven't prebooked tickets (you need a Japanese credit card to do this), but getting there before 10am will ensure a short wait. The view from the top (well middle) is amazing, you can see right around tokyo with Mount Fuji in the distance.We didnt go all the way to the top as you have to queue and pay again, and to be honest I cannot imagine you would see anymore!

Worth Checking out.... Waited little over 1.5 hours.... one hour to get in line to queue... another half to line up for ticket.The wait may sound long, but actually is an easy wait because right infront of the skytree is a little mall, with various shop and alot of restaurant and bars and theme store for you to walk around.. yes.. there is even a starbuck too... After purchasing the ticket and taken the lift going up... the time spend in the lift is really very very short.. since they have to elevate you to 350 feet above..The view from the sky deck is marvellous.. I visited it at night time, so only able to enjoy the night view of Tokyo.. definitely memorable... if going to tokyo again... I will choose day time and a day view of whole tokyo !The view deck is really huge, we spend an hour on it without feeling any boring :D (plus there is several cafe on the deck) .. and there is three level... if you willing to spend little more, you can go up galleria which is 100m further up. that is I would like to go in my next visit....overall... its an enjoyable visit as I really like towers!

amazing view. I visited here with a friend in December 2012. While the tower was somewhat crowded, we were moved in very quickly, particularly compared with Tokyo Tower. The view is excellent and not to be missed while in Tokyo. Easy to combine this with a visit to Sensoji Temple which is nearby.

Good but worth it?? Not sure.... We enjoyed the view obviously and took lots of photos but we had to wait over an hour in the queue to get tickets and then again for the lift and when we got to the top there were so many people squashed up against the glass it was hard to get in for a good look at the view. We did go at a busy time though (during Christmas holidays) so my advice is to go at a quiet time if you can! Otherwise the magic is ruined by all the waiting and crowds. (We had a good enough view without the hassle and waiting time from the Mori Art Museum in Roponngi which is worth a visit anyway).

Amazing view from the top, visit at night. It took me 1 hour to queue up at night, which generally I would say that it's much faster than Tokyo Tower and Taipei 101. Was surprised at the speed of the queue. Going up to the 350m would cost 2000yen and a further 100m up would cost another 1000yen. It's quite expensive but I would say it's worth it. Visiting at night would be best, since the night view in Tokyo is just simply breathtaking. The structure of Tokyo SkyTree just blows me away, it's illuminated with beautiful lights at night and there's a shopping mall below that has many food restaurants and shops as well.

Just ok. Nice views, no queues at 8:30 in the morning, expensive entrance ticket (3000 ienes to the first observatory at 350 meters, plus 1000 to the second observatory at 450 meters), lots of shoppings at the building, no more attractions in the neighborhood.

Good view from the top. The view from the top is great. The long queue, even though well organised but can be annoying.Also it is not worth the extra money to go to the higher level, not much difference.

An island of glitz & shopping, shopping, shopping. I went here not intending to go up the tower and save my 2,000 or 3,000 yen, as the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Buildings (Tocho) in Shinjuku has as good a view, but for free. Seeing up close the latticework of pipes that forms the Sky Tree is impressive - and it really does have something of an organic feel to it. However, money aside, the queue waiting to go up to the top is enough to put you off. I recommend just strolling through the massive shopping mall - Sky Tree Town - of which the Sky Tree is a part. It is h-u-g-e, with high-end shop after high-end shop for as long as you can keep walking. In that sense it's a slice of Shinjuku or Shibuya forming an island of glitz in Tokyo's grotty east end. Because, look across the road and you'll see that the drab, suburban landscape that existed here before the Sky Tree maintains its drabness - meaning there is absolutely nothing to do here besides see the Sky Tree and walk through its seeming endless shopping mall. Nevertheless it's a great one-off buzz, especially while it's still new.

hype is subsided, or the queue moves fast, or maybe it's just damn cold now. thought i'd have to give this attraction a miss, since the booking online is closed. nevertheless, wanted to see it, even if just from the outside.so i visited on a cold tuesday afternoon. queued at 4:40pm, long queue, but it moves fast. in the elevator by 5pm. packed, naturally. but since it moves at a max speed of 600m/minute, it's the shortest crush ever. 2000 yen/pax (adult) to the tembo deck.by 5pm, the sky is dark, and the view is fantastic from 350m up. didn't pay the extra 1000 yen for the highest level. i love the night view, cos i could see tokyo tower lit up, some distance away. i have a fear of heights so i didn't attempt the glass see-thru floor section.con: the gift shop needs to come up with some nifty t-shirt designs.

Wait until the hype subsides. Long lines to purchase tickets unless you can purchase on line with Japanese credit card. Once you get up there, another line to purchase tickets to go to the higher level. Lines move fairly fast but having been to Tokyo Tower, Mori bldg and the Metro govt building, it doesn't seem to be too special . But then again I am not fond of heights.

Tokyo skyline enhanced. Although the Japanese government spent a significant amount of donations from tsunami relief area on completion of this structure and left many people still without adequate housing food and water which I believe is a terrible disgrace, the sky tree itself is a dominating and beautiful addition too the Tokyo skyline visible from many Tokyo sights and is beautiful from the Tokyo waterways cruises too the botanical gardens awesome .

The best thing we did on our 2 week trip to Japan. This is the tallest tower in the world, looming over one of the most densely populated cities in the world, with the majestic Mount Fuji on the horizon. It's just stunning.The view is incredible, photographs cannot do it justice. You have to experience it.This may seem obvious, but if there is one thing you do on your trip to Japan that you plan around the weather, it's a trip up the Skytree. Try and pick the clearest day possible during your trip and arrive first thing in the morning. We got there for 9am and only had to queue for about 15-20 minutes. The view was clear with no clouds and we got to see Mount Fuji in all it's glory.We had coffee, cake and sandwiches in the cafe which was reasonably priced (for a tourist attraction).On the way down there's a glass floor. It is only small but it's great fun to stand on.

World Tallest Tower. The building is awesome. Night illumination is very nice! Ticket counter located at 4th floor, in a normal weekday, I spent half an hour to queue for the ticket. The staffs are very efficient and friendly. After purchase the ticket, you will need to queue for the elevator. The elevator is very fast and nice interior. From the view desk, you will able to see the view of Tokyo. I spend my sunset and night time there. Really nice! Recommend you to go during evening before sunset, as you can enjoy sunset view and night view in the same time.

Would be good if I could get up there. Tokyo sky tree is one of the tallest structures in the world and offers fantastic panoramic views. It is a beautiful building and has a great little mall beneath it with live entertainment on most weekends. I have two complaints though. Firstly, I am staying in Shinjuku, it takes two trains and a subway to get to it and it is quite confusing especially during rush hour. Secondly, every attempt I have made to see sunset from it has been denied because during that time it is so heavily booked by tour groups that, unless you book tickets online, there is no way you will get up there because the groups take priority over individuals. I was told when I arrived at 4:30pm that if I purchased tickets then I would not go up until after 7:30pm (no definite time, just "after"). Most online tickets at that time are sold out days in advance as well and if I had known that, I would have booked it much sooner.

Go early to avoid queues. We arrived at about 8.15am to try and avoid the queues that I had read about on here and it was already getting busy! Bought our tickets to the first deck without having to queue and made our way up. By the time we got up there the queue for tickets to the second observatory was already 10 minutes long and it was only 8.30am! Queued for the tickets and up we went. Loved the glass ceiling in the elevator. Good views of the city- makes you realise just how big Tokyo is! It was cloudy when we went but I imagine it would be even better on a clear day. By the time we left just after 9am the queues were getting quite big so would definitely recommend getting there early if you don't want to waste the day.

The smoothest elevator ride - an engineering marvel!. We arrived before 8 am and there was already a line of people excited to go up the Sky Tree. The most impressive experience was the elevator ride to the top. The elevator accelerated from 0 to 600 m/min and the decelerated to 0 again as we approached the 350 meter mark. Except for the elevator screen that informs me of the speed, I did not feel as if I have left the ground floor. It was the smoothest and steadiest ride on an elevator. As an engineer, this was the most spectacular experience for me. The Tokyo sight, of course, was very impressive as everywhere i looked, buildings lined up the land around. The Sumida river was also winding around Tokyo.

The second tallest structure on earth!. I love photographing and visiting tall structures, and when I heard the Tokyo Sky Tree Tower finally opened this May, I had to see it for myself. Our hotel is next to the Tokyo Tower which we went up on our first trip to Japan as students. At 333 meters, The Tokyo Tower is a midget compared to the Goliath 634 m SkyTree. I love the design of the Sky Tree with a concrete central column and a steel exoskeleton. It is very easy to get to- go to the Oshige metro stop, and it is a nice ten minutes walk away. We deliberately chose to go early on a weekday AM in Dec to avoid the crowds. At 930 AM it was a beautiful sunny day and only a 15 minutes wait to get admitted. The Japanese workers do a well organized job to get the lines moving quickly. The cost is 2000 yen or $25 to get to the 350 m level, and then another 1000 yen for the 450 m level. We did both levels but felt going to the first level was probably enough money spent. Afterwards I recommend everyone considering visiting the amazing nearby Senso ji shrine in Asakusa.

Tokyo Sky Tree Town -- just another ragtag collection of shops. Tokyo Sky Tree Town is one of the newest shopping centres in Tokyo. Access is relatively easy, with the subway at the basement.Many people flock to this shopping centre as it is new. Like us, I am sure many of them have been disappointed. It is a motley collection of shops, perhaps appealing only to the younger crowd -- think Shibuya (but Shibuya is better organised). You would do better to visit any of the shopping complexes at Ikebukuru or Shinjuku. The range of goods there is much wider.Many people visit because of the tower, reputedly the tallest in the world. But if you must visit, you need a lot of time. The ticket purchase is fast, with much less crowd than when it first opened, but I noticed that the line to ride the elvator is at least one to two hours long. And as with most cities, the view up there is nothing to crow about.There is also a (rather small) aquarium and planetarium.There are many restaurants in the complex but be prepared for long lines, especially at lunch time on a weekend. Most of these are branches of brand-name restaurants, serving the same food (with the same high prices).My opinion is that you should consider visiting only if(a) you have planty of time on hand (and don't know what to do);(b) you have no idea what to do in Tokyo; and/or(c) you are the young crowd (late teens and early twenties).
Superb!. beautiful view in the night! the light on the sky tree tower keeps circling around like a magical orbs. it was fantastic.

NOT the tourist trap you would expect. Really well produced new tourist destination, highly recommended for people visiting Tokyo for the first time. You have a choice of the Tower, the shopping mall with lots of original handmade Japanese crafts, the aquarium (more for little kids) or just walking around the immediate area and admiring the tower. I highly recommend going to the tourist center outside the tower to get English info on places to see, restaurants, etc. in the area, and also recommend the Foodie Floor on the 2nd floor (great place to get an excellent variety of food and eat outside). The best way to visit would be to take the subway to Asakusa, take a rickshaw to the tower, and then walk back to the station.

Go at Dusk. There is a rather long line ~30 mins to buy tickets if you didn't rsvp. I was hesitant about going, but in the end was very happy we did go. We were lucky to have timed our visit to just before sunset and was a wonderful view. Pictures of the sunset and mount Fuji are worth it... i did not regret going and spending the money.

JUST AMAZING!!. Want to visit the second tallest structure on Earth!! and view an amazing metropolis from 465 meters, well this is it! It is a rush, built super modern and I did not feel unsafe at any point, despite the crazy heights. Simply the best view anywhere. The trick is to get in, on a clear day the place is totally packed with people. I went on a semi clear day in which the lower observation deck was great, but the upper was in the clouds -- even then, incredible experience -- and because of that, we had literally no lines to get it. This is a must on a trip to Tokyo! Leaves you with awesome photos and video, for all the friends who were not able to travel with you to Tokyo.

Nice but not a must. We did not purchase advance tickets so got there at 7:45am on Monday. There was a line but we got our tickets by 8:10am and went straight up to the observation deck. By the time we came down at 9-9:30, the line was very long and they were distributing a ticket to come back to quere again at 10:30. So you should definitely be there before 8am.The view from the lower deck was good, but because the tower is located at the edge of Tokyo the view itself is not very interesting. The view from the higher deck was not that different from the lower deck, and it was somewhat obstructed because of the windows panes. So in my opinion save $1000 and just visit the lower deck.We went to Ropping Hills in the afternoon and the view from there was much more interesting as it's located in the center of Tokyo. Besides there was no line at all. So I would suggest skipping Sky Tree altogether and go to Roppongi Hills.

Better improved version of another Tokyo observation tower. CHAOTIC queuing system.. So this is THE new kids on the block and he is playing hard to get. We arrived around 4pm with clueless vision of how to go to the top. Been trying ways to buy tickets online but not available. Arrived there only to find flocks of people in groups of tremendous quantity. Don't have clear info how to buy tickets or whatsoever.Fortunately a security guard forward us to 4th floor using lift. Up and we found long lines of people queuing for something we don't have clear idea what it is. Is it to buy tickets or to wait for elevator or what? Still clueless. Asking to information ladies only to be asked back, DO YOU HAVE RESERVATION? Of course we don't. Okay, so you will only be able to buy tickets for 7.30 pm. But where should I buy the tickets? You got to have the numbers. She said without smiling, probably tiring answering the same question all day long. So I'm still clueless up to this point even after asking direction from information ladies. Okay, now we decided we just happy to take picture of this tower from below. So we went outside bracing the very cold icy winds to terrace. Upon walking around to get better pics of this new tower I then stumble into new different lines of people queuing in an open tent with several officer shouting things in Japanese while waving some cards. Chaotic. Still lost in translation.I move closer to have a clear picture of what they are doing and what they are queuing for. Apparently THIS IS THE NUMBER things that the information ladies informed. Those officer are waving cards with 7.30 pm written on it. Quickly I gather all our entourage to queue since one person only can have one card. After a while then we have the queuing number which enable us to QUEUE AGAIN to buy tickets at the designated time written in our card. What a confusing system.Since we have like 2-1,5 hours to kill we decided to have dinner. 15 minutes before 7.30 pm we back in different queuing lines than the taking number line. Moving slowly in line finally we approached ticketing counters to buy ticket of JPY 2,000 and ushered to another queuing line to take elevators to top. Finally around 8.30 pm we arrived in 350 meters viewing platform. Wants to go up to 450 meters platform? Please queue again this way to buy another JPY 1,000 ticket. OMG not another queue.So how is the view? MAGNIFICENT. They manage to build a better version of Mori Tower. Slanted the glass outward so no images reflected, only pitch black of gleaming lights of Tokyo night. SPLENDID !!! Will I go here again? No. Not with that kind of queuing system and thousand of people eager to go up. Perhaps later.

Long wait for a sky view. You go here and they give you a ticket to come back at a designated timeframe. There are plenty of shops and restaurants around to kill time. The line wait was about an hour until I got to the top of the Sky Tree. Once you get to the top the views are great. You can see for miles so try and go on a clear day. There's a restaurant at the top along with a few PAY photo ops. Not sure it was worth the wait but glad I went anyway.

Get here early. To visit the tallest tower in the world and see Mt Fuji was a buzz. The views from here show you just how big the metropolis of Tokyo is. The elevator gets visitors up to the first level at 350 metres in less than 1 minute. Amazing! The Skytree opens at 8am so we arrived at 7.30 and waited. Once ticket sales started it was very quick to get in. Total wait time was 45 minutes. When we left at 10am the wait time was 90 minutes with waits becoming longer later in the day. It costs 3000 yen to get to the highest level. Well worth it. It is possible to reserve a day and time ticket but then you take your chances with the weather.

great views. suggests to go as early as possible to avoid long queues. pay 2000 Yen to view 350m view. IMHO, I felt not necessary to pay another 1000 Yen to go higher to see.. the view is the same. I was there at 10am and i had to q for an hour just to get the ticket. wait was worthwhile and very systematic. I alight at oshiage station and exit A2 and walk about 5 min. Upon exit, skytree is behind the exit near to the canal. From here, walk about 15-20mins to sensoji temple. There's a skytree cafe at 350m but its rather expensive.

Good Attraction Infrastructure. Unlike the Tokyo Tower, there is an entire entertainment infrastructure built up around and within the Sky Tree Including store and restaurants of many varieties. Unlike the Tokyo Tower, the night view, while higher, is not as colorful. Still it's an interesting panoramic view of Tokyo. There are thousands of people visiting howler the wait is not boring, well managed and the limes move efficiently,

Has to be done - spectacular views. Well worth a visit. Queueing takes some time but is well organized, allowing you to return at a set time for a shorter wait than would be needed. Not cheap at Y2000 + Y1000 per person for the full 451.2m trip, but has some nice surprises and is a high quality product. Shops at the base are pretty good, too, (and I generally hate shopping).

Sky Tree is Replacement for Tokyo Tower. Super Views of Tokyo. It's the tallest free standing tower in the world (That’s their claim). Long lines (45 Minutes or more) to get tickets to go up. The lines are well organized though. The initial ticket only gets you part way up (great views from there) and you have to pay to go to the top (you're higher but the views are the same). The biggest issue I have is that it's half observatory and half concession stands to get your money to pay for the tower.

Worth doing once but expect to wait in line throughout the whole process.. Skytree opened in May 2012 and seems to be the talk of the town in terms of new attractions. We got to the sky tree area by 10am and we got in line to receive a voucher for 2:30pm. U could go to the aquarium or take the train back to Asakusa like we did to kill time. Once we got back we stood in line for an hour an a half to buy tux and officially get to level 350. The view is amazing! Take lots if pictures. There's a couple cafes (great cakes) and a restaurant where u can pay 5000-7000 yen for lunch and 13500yen and up for dinner. Expect to spend half the day for the whole process. U could buy advanced tix online- prob would recommend that!!! 500yen more but after u see the lines we were in, I think it would be worth the extra money.

Outstanding views of the city - somewhat far away. I fit this into my 5 hour rapid tour of Tokyo on a recent business trip. Stayed at the Sheraton, hopped the metro out to Sky Tree (35 mins) spent 90 mins seeing the tower (plus line times) and then looped down to the Sensoji Temple (10 mins metro).I got there at 10 am and was up in the tower by 10:35, then in second line to go to the top, was up there by 11. All in, I spent about 30 mins up top and the views were fantastic. I was glad to be there on a very clear day. Highly recommended.

Beautiful view but long lines. View was wonderful. Elevator took only 1 minute to get to the top however it took us 30 minutes in line to get a ticket and then we were required to return at another time to get in but then that line was another 90 minutes wait. There are restaurants and stores under the sky tree. You can stay up as long as you want. Not good for handicapped people.

Beautiful addition too The Tokyo Skyline.. while this is a beautiful Attraction and somewhat awe inspiring on the Tokyo Skyline and most likely planned well before the Earthquakes and Tsunami in Japan, I would be very careful about paying money too enter this building after the self admission by the japanese Government of the miss appropriation of FUNDS from Tsunami and Earthquake Donations too complete its Building, while thousands still have no housing and there second winter is here. The Observation deck can almost see as far as the devastation in the North East from the Tsnami and Earthquakes Ironic really.

So crowded we decided not to go up anymore!. After arriving at the Tokyo Skytree, we saw the HUGE crowd. Upon inquiry, we are told we need to line up about one and a half hours just to get the ticket and line up another one hour to go up. Two and a half hours waiting time is just too much time wasted so we decided not to go up anymore and just come back maybe after 5 years when it is not too crowded anymore.

Expensive but unique. It's almost $25 dollars to go to the lower observation deck and $12 more if you want to go higher.View's great but understand as all metropolis goes, there's lots of haze and smog to interfere with your view into the distant.

Skytree: the newest must-do in Tokyo. We reached at Skytree station of Asakusa subway line around 1130am, and on reaching 4th floor, we were given waiting tickets for 1600hrs. This was because we did not have any reservations. This was a blessing, as it enabled us to visit the skytree in evening, but also it meant we lost an entire day. We had a lunch there and went to Sumida Aquarium, just an average place. After that we spent some time in the shopping alleys of skytree and then went to the queue to buy tickets at 4pm. It was long line at ticket counters, at elevators going up, at elevators coming down.. there were lots of people.. but the spectacular elevator, and the view from 450 mt level was breathtaking. If you are brave enough, there is a glass platform, where one can stand and see the view below.. Would have been much better without the crowds, but cant really complain when we were a part of it..

Worth A Visit. We arrived at 9:00 AM and were able to enter without a wait. By the time we completed the visit to the 450 meter level and then visited the aquarium at ground level the line up to get in was massive (about 12:00 PM). Crowd control is impressive here with abundant staff directing visitors. We understand that in the early months the waits for tickets were very long. By now the main thing seems to be to get in ahead of tour groups, who usually begin to arrive midmorning - early is definitely the time to go.We recommend a visit to the aquarium next door, especially if you have children with you. It's a good place for kids to learn about marine life and they will enjoy the penguins and seals.

Great Perspective of Tokyo. Wow, it's massive! I went in the early morning and it was really quiet. We got lucky and it was a really bright clear day so we had a great view of Tokyo and mt fuji which was the icing on the cake.You have to pay another 1000yen to go up another 100 meters but i didn't think it was worth it as we saw everything at 350!The place was very clean and the staff very friendly, i would definitely recommend it!

Amazing views but overall experience not great. Be prepared to wait to see the amazing views from the Tokyo Skytree. When you arrive get a ticket with 30 minute time slot, ours was two hours after we got there. Then go back and queue for tickets when they say to... and boy do you queue! They really struggle to cope with the shear number of people. I have to admit the views are pretty special, but it was very expensive and I felt we wasted a lot of time here on a tight schedule. Instead do what we did and spend your money at the bar on the 42nd floor of The Park Hyatt Tokyo, get yourself a drink, chill out and watch the sunset. This was the real highlight for us.Iain, London

VIEWS ARE BREATHTAKING. Although only opened for abt 6 months. The Japanese have a great system as the site is so busy. They hand you a card giving you a half window to report back to buy tickets. So in that 2-3 hours u can check out all the shops in the Sky Tree complex and/or have a meal and return. All works wonderfully well and the location is well served by train.

views always a winner. think it had just opened when we went, so queues were quite long but organised and moving.at the end of the day, it's the classic views from a high viewpoint that you see in many cities. However, was interesting to really see the sprawl of the city and a good photo point. We also thought that the mall under the tower was good, modern, with a large food hall if peckish!

Size does matter. Its 2000 yen to go up to 350m and another 1000 yen to reach 450m. If you just want to catch the day view, go there really early and you can cross this attraction from your list in an hour time. The tricky part comes when you wanna take pictures of the city with and without the sun. I went to this attraction twice, going up on the second time.The thing is, if you ain't the early bird type, you prolly have to get a queue ticket to purchase the admission ticket. Due to the overwelming number of tourist, once the queue to purchase the admission ticket gets too long, they start to issue out limited "Queue Tickets" that has a certain time slot for you to come back to purchase the admission ticket. Also, you can't ask for a queue ticket with a specific time slot. They just issue in order and change to later time slot when the current one runs out. Here is the breakdown of my schedule (its a saturday so gauge for yourself):1200hrs: Get queue ticket for time slot 1500 ~ 1530 (admission 1530 ~1600)1510hrs: Joins the queue for purchase1530hrs: Purchased ticket for Tembo Deck (350m)1540hrs: Enters Lift for Tembo Deck1542hrs: Reaches Tembo Deck and joins queue for Tembo Galleria1552hrs: Purchased ticket for Tembo Galleria (450m)1555hrs: Enters lift for Tembo GalleriaEnjoy......Imho, it would be perfect to reach Tembo Galleria between 1645 ~ 1700 as you'll have some time to enjoy the sunset and wait for another half an hour to snap that camera after dark. Trust me, those that reach the Galleria at this time will hog around too. You just have to be as thick-skinned as them.

Great views - but be prepared to wait. The Skytree was only opened for the public in 2012 so is very popular both with locals and foreign tourists. The Skytree operates an efficient waiting system where you initially collect a card that entitles you to come back at a set time to queue for a ticket. We arrived at 6pm and received a card to come back between 7pm-7.30pm to queue to buy a ticket. Waiting time to buy a ticket was around 30 minutes.There are two types of tickets, one for the Tembo Deck (at 350m), or for an extra 1000 Yen you can purchase a ticket for the Tembo Galleria (at 450m). We went to the Tembo Deck which is much higher than surrounding buildings and offers outstanding views so we didn't see the need to go any higher.The only problem is that they tend to let in a lot of people at once, so it can take a while to wait to get near the window for a good view. There is also a restaurant and cafe on this level.

Amazing view!!!. Today we went to go up the Tokyo Skytree! We went there very early in the morning. It opens at 8:00 and we were there 8:05 and "only" had to wait for about half an hour. If you go later the waiting can take up u til 2-3 hours. Undortunately all explanations of the ladies guiding you to the lift are in Japanese so we did not understand a thing. When you are up there the view is just amazing!!! We had great weather and could even see mount fuji clearly! We did feel that it does not give you too much more to go up the 450 meter. It costs 1000 extra and we felt that it was not worth it. The view is not so much different. But the skytree is definitely a sight that i can recommend!!! Its great!! Its definitely worth the 2000 yen!

Go early or prepare to wait for hours!. Went there at noon on a weekday and found out that the available timeslot to get to the tower is 4pm onwards. Finally I decided to skipped the tower and just roam around the first floors. If you want a view of Tokyo from heights for free, just go to Tokto Metropolitan Government Building, if you want a view from (currently) the highest tower in the world, go for the Sky Tree. Late afternoon should be great so you can get day view and night view with all those city lights already lit.

Get a feel for the scale of the city. We nearly didnt do the skytower as looking at reviews prior to travelling people said it was expensive and you could get just as good view free from the government building. We went up regardless because one of our friends really wated to do it. The first time the queues were enormous so we left and came back at 7:30am the next day and it was much better and not too crowded. You will NOT ge the same scale of view from the government building. The skytower literally towers above any other buildings and you can see the city stretching for miles in a 360 view. Ths is the highest viewing platform ope tothe public in the world. Photos will not do it justice. If this is your fist trip to Tokyo then I can recomend this attraction to give you an appreciation of the expanse of the city

Great view, but go early!. The complex the Sky Tree is part of has two stations and hence is easy to reach from the rest of Tokyo. Once there you cannot fail to be overawed by the size of the tower you are presented with.I would recommend getting there as early as possible in the morning ... leave it until mid-morning and you'll be looking at very long queues. We got there at ~10:30 the first time and decided that it just wasn't worth waiting. The following day we got there about 20mins after it opened and didn't really have to queue at all.It's not cheap at 2000yen to go up to the lower level and then a further 1000yen to go to the upper level but the view of the city is amazing Having been up Tokyo Tower previously I would place this in a different league.The Sky Tree is also part of a large complex of shops, restaurants, attractions and offices. The restaurants are good to eat in and the shops are well worth a look around.

Big mall attached to the Sky Tree. Easily accessible, right above the metro station. Nice big mall with lots of local produce. Better to reserve time earlier and then spend the time in the mall while waiting for your turn to go up.

Awestruck. It has just opened when I went to see it... Sadly couldn't be one of those chosen few (reservations needed and raffled) who are able to see it. I got to have a photo outside though. It's free and awesome! specially at night when its lighted. You just have to check it out! I just followed the map. Ticket counters for the shuttle going there kind of understand if you say you're going to SkyTree :)souvenirs are very expensive! I settled on magnets! :) and personalized name stamps for my boss :)

Not worth going up. I just went there 2 days ago with my husband and 2 young kids. We get there around 10.30am and we lined up to get a ticket. We need to come back at 1.30pm so we went to solamaci shop centre, we have fun there, lots of things to see, nice food but quite expensive. But taste good. We went back around 1.15pm and inside its a long que. we waited for 45 minutes to buy tickets. My ill one already crack, and we still have to que about 15 min for lift to go up. When we get there it's full of people, so it's not nice nd relaxing atmosphere up there, it's squeeze full of people. So you cant really enjoy the view. And again u have to lined again to go down. Overall I felt its not worth going, we wasted half days for something not really worth going.

Excellent views. Went here on a Friday evening between two typhoons so the sky was unbelievably clear and no lines. A bit on the expensive side - ~40US to get to the top but worth the view. There are two vantage points with the top vantage point having a slightly inclined floor that gets you a little higher. If you like heights then there is no reason to wait.In the elevator ride up or down try to get to the back of the elevator and look up. The light the inside of the tower for the journey. The doorway at the halfway point also sees outside but through the metal structure.

Tokyo's new baby!. Queued for nearly two hours just to purchase an entrance ticket! But again, it was worth it!
My friend and I bought a photo standing on the glass floor and the staff were unbelievably bubbly and animated, we were laughing while the shot was taken. The staff at SkyTree are a delightful bunch.

Wouldn't go again. Went here as felt I had to with it being a new attraction. We got there not long after opening time and it was very busy. We waited over an hour but the queue was constantly moving. We paid £16 each and to be honest I really don't think it is good value for money. Like most towers you have to pay an additional fee to go right to the top but we didn't bother. The view is no better than that at Tokyo Tower, which is much cheaper and has entertainment. I wouldn't go here again but I am glad I can say I have been. There are many shops and restaurants below the tower which are worth a look. Overall I was very disappointed with it.

Didnt climb, good enough outside :). Went there last week! Didnt expext much, and had no plans of getting up since it was too expensive and the lines do get long.But, it is prettier than I expected! I suggest you to go there in the evening, and to get off not at the skytree station but from a station where you will need to walk around 10 min to it. Why? Because it looks very nice from a distance where you're not too close. You get to see the beautiful lights, and the elevator from outside looks like falling stars. And the tower glows!Stations include kinshichou on sobu line, and maybe asakusa as well? I walked from kinshichou to Skytree. It was a pretty 20 min walk. There are maps in the station, it's generally one of the suggested stations to go to Sky tree. Easy to ask! Japanese will help you.And then there is Solamachi right under the tower. It is a huge shopping mall! 8 floors was it? It has all of the things you need for your Japanese souvenirs. Asakusa might be cheaper but you find the same stuff there. In solamachi 4th floor (or was it second?) you have all the decent quality Japanese souvenirs, key chains, shirts, kimono, calligraphy pen, uniqlo, loft, etc. Sometimes I find it hard shopping for gifts to bring home in Takashimaya or other department stores, but here, it's really good. Restaurants fill many floors.Compared to Tokyo Tower: sky tree is twice higher! From afar sky tree does not look pretty day or night, but from a kilometer way at night, it's worth seeing. I went up Tokyo tower, the view is nice if you like tall places and night views. For those saving money: go to the Shinjuku Metropolitan Building or Tochou in Japanese. It is always suggested as a free alternative to the paid towers. :) enjoy the night view!

Sky Tree View - Bottom up and top out. Obviously a clear day helps but if you are near and looking up it is also a marvel of architecture.Just after the huge typhoon the visibility was amazing out to Fuji-san and over to the airport areas.Great facility though a bit expensive it was worth one trip. Very Good but could be better with lower rates.

Okay. I must preface this review by saying that we came to the Skytree, but seeing the enormously long lines with more than an hour's wait to even get a ticket (even for a Monday work day!), we decided not to pay the Y2,000 each to go up. Instead, we spent some time wandering among the sprawl of shops and restaurants below. In hindsight, I was a bit disappointed not to be able to have gone up and really should've bought tickets prior to going (though apparently it's only available to those with a Japanese credit card). It was still very nice to see the tower from the bottom. The complex is also very nice - complete with a Studio Ghibli theme store!If you really want to visit, I'd recommend going very early in the morning, or trying to buy tickets in advance.

Okay for something to do. I'm not a tower fan and wasn't expecting to be able to go up. The lines are huge and people everywhere. Enquiry about buying tickets in advance. They say building the tower in this suburb brought it back to life. It's certainly attracted the crowds. An easy train to get to it and it but at the bottom of my list of everything else I saw in Tokyo. The original built in 1958 was more interesting. Don't rush but if you got time to kill it's alright.

Long lines, but a beautiful view.. We came to visit the Sky Tree on a weekday, because our hotel told us that the lines may be long on a weekend. Well, it still took us an hour in line to get our tickets. When we finally got to the ticket window, we were informed that we can only buy tickets to the 350m observation deck, and if we wanted to go up to the 450m observation deck, we will have to buy an additional ticket once we get to the 350m deck. Another 15 minutes wait for the lift, and we made it to 350m. A beautiful view of Tokyo and surrounding area! A bit clouded for my taste, but we had no problems finding our way to the windows and getting a panoramic view of the area. Absolutely breathtaking.We decided that we wanted to go up to the 450m mark, but then found out that it would be another ½ hour in line to buy the additional ticket. We passed. We had dinner reservations and would miss them if we spent more time at the skytree.Overall, a nice tourist attraction, but I would wait a few more months until the traffic of local visitors dies down before going up the Sky Tree.

Long lines but worth the wait. Stunning views of Tokyo (when the weather cooperates) but this is still fairly new so prepare for a wait. Online reservations are currently limited to those with a Japanese credit card.

Queue, queue, queue, queue, queue.... God this was rubbish. I really anticipated it being the highlight of my trip to Tokyo, but it was completely the opposite. The queue for tickets was ridiculous, and making people stand outside in the heat was crazy. We queued for over two hours to buy tickets. It could just have been made so much more enjoyable with some reading materials, wifi, background music, displays bout construction, comparissons to other buildings etc. Better still, you could just get a ticket and come back later to purchase? Even telcos butchers lets you do that... Anyway you queue for your tickets, then queue for security, then queue for the lift, then queue to get out of the lift, the queue to get a peek out of the window, then queue for the loo which you're desperate for because you last saw one 4h ago, then queue for the cafe, then queue for the stairs/escalator to get downstairs, then queue for over-priced photos, then queue to go into the souvenir shop, then queue to look at the glass floor, then queue for tickets to the next deck, then queue for the lift to the next deck, then queue for the lift down. Honestly, the whole thing was completely in-enjoyable and shambolic - which is unusual for Japan.Can't dissuade you enough... Went to world trade centre for a fiver and it was completely empty. We watched the sun set and honestly, I think the views were better and the experience infinitely more enjoyable.

Too cloudy. I wouldn't go here if it looks like raining or is cloudy . Unless it is a clear day, i don't think you would see much at all. There are a few shops and nicely landscaped river down at the base of the tower though.

Queues huge - buy in advance!. I visited Tokyo's new must see whilst there this summer, it looks outstanding when you first walk up the steps from the metro and see the sheer gargantuan size of the building! However as you approach the ticket area you realise that the chance of going up the tower is slim at best! The queue was 2 hours wait and this was at 9am. Strongly would recommend pre-booking a ticket because I didn't and never got to see it! It is currently an extremely crowded area and was perhaps a bit claustrophobic but this is because it's new in time it will die down. If like me you decide not to go up there is the sumida aquarium in the same complex (also reviewing this) as well as a four floor shopping mall with a large food court as well as some really good shops. The actually sky tree gift shop was PACKED, like to the point of not being able to move, however there was some brilliant bits and bobs in there I got quite a lot! Worth a visit but not the best thing I saw in Tokyo by far!

A new "must do" in Tokyo if you have a day to spare. It's really a brilliant piece of engineering and gives you great views of the city. After the 3/11 Tohoku earthquake it's also an inspirational piece of architecture that confirms Japan's ability to rebound from anything. It was started well before the earthquake but I think it's something to be proud of as an example of how resilient the building in Tokyo are. Now it's not perfect. It does take a while to get to the top. Long lines and all that. Just go expecting them and you will be fine. It's not cheap either so budget for it. I had someone reserve tickets through a tour guide for us before it officially opened but the lines were still there. The restaurant at the top was nice but they do make you wait in lines when seats are open which makes me wonder why that would happen. What are they waiting for? It's a tourist attraction so expect the shops and the various trinkets all over that you can buy. You are there to go to the highest manmade place in Japan. Look out the windows and take photos. Stop and fell the tower sway. The shopping in the building next to the tower is okay. Expensive in my view but I'm more for cheap things. I will say that the spotted banana shaped sponge cakes with banana cream filling are pretty good. I'd prefer to buy a couple on a pate for less than the expensive wrapped ones so I can just eat them with a good cup of coffee but that's not an option. The staff are all very polite and always willing to help. You'll find most of Tokyo to be this way but being in the newest attraction probably makes the work load double and the employees are doing a great job of handling the extra load.To much writing I know but go and experience it and then you can say you have been in the tallest communications tower in the World. Don't forget to visit the other tower and the Tokyo Gov't building but aren't in the Guinness Book for anything.

Worth seeing, not worth going up.. A typically Japanese tourist experience involving standing in a queue for 20 minutes to get a ticket to come back later and then ejoy standing in a queue for a further hour to buy an overpriced elevator ride to half way up the tower.Want to go further? Another hour queue and another purchase required. Want to see out of the windows? Please queue up.All to the smell of curry rice.One good thing is the glass floor, but with so many people crowding to get on you most get a view of other peoples feet. Check out the government buildings (free) if you want a view of Tokyo from the air - its not a very beautiful skyline just impressive for its dominance of the surroundings.Would recomend going to see it though, just stand by the river and look up in awe - its rather less awesome looking down.

Expensive and lots of queues. I understand I visited the Sky Tree only months after its opening but even if I didn't have to queue, I feel it wasn't value for money. Yes, you get great views from Tokyo (make sure you go on a clear sky day) but you might as well go to the Tokyo Tower or the Govt. Building (which is free).My visit included 40 minutes wait to get a ticket and another 40 minutes to get to the top floor. This all for 3000 yen, which could have been spent on great Tokyo food or other more interesting things.The shopping mall below the tower is passable, you should check it out.

Something new in Tokyo. We waited for about an hour to get tickets, the displays in the queue were good, plus the air-con great! Moving cartoons and how the building was erected were very good. Good location for viewing Japan. Yes, it was crowded but we expected that - it's new after all. Restaurants and shops on the way out of the skytree was a little strange. Not too commercialised like some buildings. Reasonable price.

Okay but nothing too special. Its a bit pricey to get up there and even then there is a further level (galleria) for which you need to pay extra.My kids and I got there around dusk and it was very crowded. Not very comfortable to to stand or take pictures. The view was okay but dependant on the weather.Nice...but not necessary.

Very crowded and very expensive.. Although reservations are no longer mandatory the site is so new that it still attracts a great many people even though the price of 3000 JPY to go to the Galleria @ 450m is a little step. Despite the crowds everything was well managed and turning up without a reservation at 1745 we were inside and at the "deck" @350m by 1815. We had to queue another 20 mins for the Galleria.The views were spectacular both daytime and night-time however I think the whole experience is over priced for what it offers.

Awe-inspiring. We visited the Sky Tree on a rainy/cloudy day, but we were still awed by the view down. Even though Sky Tree was built as a radio tower, it really makes you feel as if it's designed as a tourist attraction. inside are dozens of staff members everywhere, dressed in special outfits. They tell you where to line up, when to get into the elevator and will help you out or take your picture. The elevators are very fast, showing their current speed and height on displays. The first one takes you to the viewing platform at 350 metres, the second one takes you up another 100 metres. On a clear day I can imagine the view is even more amazing, and I really want to go back on a sunny day, but even with the clouds it was awesome; we were at the same height as the clouds! There's also a nice cafe where you can get some Sky Tree food and drinks and a gift shop with Sky Tree souvenirs. At the 350-metre high platform there's a piece of glass floor where you can look down the Sky Tree, it's dazzling.

One of the coolest things I have ever seen.. We were very lucky because we got reservations to the SkyTree back in May. We were also lucky because the weather was nearly perfect. We were there right at sunset and we could easily view all of Tokyo during sunset and even Mt. Fuji. This was one of the best attractions I have ever visited. The only thing I could compare it to would be the feeling I get when I view Niagara Falls. It is a great place to end a wonderful trip to Japan. Check it out. It's worth it!

Incredible view!. I went to visit the tokyo sky tree just to see the outside as i thought i couldn't get in. however, in turns out that i was able to go up if i bought these special tickets from a travel agency. I was extremely impressed by the entire thing. There were glass floors restaurants gift shops lookout points and everything. unfortunately when i went up, it was a cloudy day so there wasn't much to see until the sun went down and the city light up at night. It was an excellent experience. I believe it is now officially open to the public? i could be wrong on that one though. If you are in Tokyo the Sky Tree is a must-see

Better to go for night views.. I was fortunate to get my hands on tickets to the Sky Tree before tickets were publicly available for purchase. Our ticket was for 7pm so we were fortunate to have both day time and night time views. I felt it was worth paying that extra 500 yen to be among the first to visit - I can imagine the kind of line-up it would be when it goes on sale for the public. Our wait was smooth - another 10 min of wait before redeeming our tickets and up the elevator we went. With the basic ticket (25oo yen in our case) you do not get to go to the very top. You have to pay another 1000 yen to get to the galleria. I felt it was a rip to be charging people extra. Anyway, the view was cool. I personally prefer the night view. You can see the Tokyo Tower from top. It's definitely worth going after a visit to the Asakusa Temple if have time. The shopping mall should not be missed. We got most of our snacks souvenir there since they have a wide selection. Restaurants there are great, too! We tried a few. Most of the stuff is "Sky Tree" special - so don't miss them. By the way, I do not see big lockers at the metro station or inside the mall for luaggages. I could be wrong but I still would not recommend bringing for lugguages here if this is your last stop in Tokeo.

wow very high. The lift has a fast speed that can bring you to 350th floor in a few seconds smoothly. There is a theme in every lift. I get the spring. You'd better be there when the sky is clear because the view will be better. But too bad that the options of the souvenirs are not so many. The souvenirs are mixed with the souvenirs from TV station.

AWESOME 360˚ View of Tokyo. The tower is beautiful and tickets are a HOT commodity! =) Being up there made my stomach a little weak. When I got down, I felt like I had sea legs. hehe =) The day we went, it was hazy and so we were not able to see Mount Fuji. =( But just being there seeing the massive area of Tokyo was incredible.

Snack + souvenir galore!. Didn't get up the Tokyo Sky Tree, as you need to make advance reservation. You can make that online too, but you need a JCB card. Under the sky tree, is a huge mall. There are many shopping you can do, but I would not advice you to do so as the price is very high. Snack on the contrary, there are tons of them here. Taste them, buy them. It's a very good place to get snack for friends abroad. There are lots of coffee shops around too. We stop at Tully's coffee. Coffee is so so, but damn, that mango smoothy is good! If should take you the whole day if you plan to complete the whole area on a weekend, but if you go on the weekday, it shouldn't take you half day. It is relatively new so people from Japan are still flocking to see the place. That plus foreign tourist(like us), it's like a fresh food market on a Sunday morning. It's worth going as the construction of the mall is pretty nice. Don't rush, just go with what the place have to offer, and you should enjoy it more.

An awesome experience in Tokyo. We were fortunate enough to obtain tickets to the Sky Tree for our visit to Tokyo in early July before they were made more generally available. We managed to do this by booking a "tour package" with Tobu the company that operates the Sky Tree. It proved to be a very memorable part of our Tokyo experience, and I would rate it as an absolute must do for any visitor to Tokyo.The views were just breathtaking and you get a good chance to see different aspects of Tokyo from the 350 metre tall first viewing area. It was a fine day when we visited and no doubt the luck of the weather will play a role in any visits as the fine weather we had meant that we could see vast distances very clearly.The whole operation of the Sky Tree was very slick, with the uniformed staff (the uniforms themselves are a unique fashion statement!) very friendly and also very efficient in moving the crowds through. It was crowded when we visited, but that's Tokyo really, and obviously the locals are extremely proud of their new landmark. The lifts up and down were amazingly quick and smooth with quite a few operating the day we visited to keep the queues moving.There are a number of great photo opportunities including the glass floor that you can stand on and also have your group photos taken by the operators at a reasonable cost (1200 yen I think it was for a printed photo) and they will also take a shot for you with your own camera.If in Tokyo go and have a look at the Sky Tree and if you can, go up to the viewing area. If you get a day like we did it will take your breath away.
remember to reserve tickets. we didnt actually get to go up as they only allowed ticket reservation. you cant actually buy tickets on the spot T.T

Be sure to have a ticket.... We went there in june, during our honeymoon, and we were impressed of the image of the tower at night, with a nice blue and red light involved by some clouds in the tallest section. Awesome under the daylight too, but is not possible to buy tickets there, you should try to reserve before your travel. Great mall under the tower (as everywhere in Tokyo).

Maybe in a couple more years.... Tokyo Sky Tree is an amazing sight to behold with magnificent views of the world's most bustling megalopolis. However, the name needs some work. I'd say tourist-trap death tower might be more appropriate. My initial concerns began when they delayed our elevator ride because of the wind. The wind?! When you get to the top you basically stand in line to get on the elevator to come back down. (Did I mention this is a trap?) There are three stories which make up a giant spiraling line. It's like your at Tokyo Disneyland but you're in line to GET OFF THE RIDE! So we're half a kilometer in the air and the line keeps getting longer and people keep spilling in. But they send send the up elevators down empty. They make you stand in line for two hours so you can descend 10 meters to the down elevators. Why can't we go down on the same elevator I came up on? Is it too windy? If the elevators are too fragile to handle the breeze following last night's typhoon, how is the structure handling the tons of human flesh and Canon cameras pouring onto the observation deck? To anyone considering the ¥2500 ($30) ticket I'd say wait a year. They've got to make this thing work better and the crowds are bound to get smaller if they make this rather expensive ride this unpleasant.

Wishing that we could have gone up in the tower!. We ended up arriving in Tokyo one week after the SkyTree opened. To our dismay, one needs to purchase a ticket via a reservation system until July. However, the reservation system is only in Japanese.That said, the visit wasn't an entire bust! The architecture is very cool, and the shopping park was filled with many samples at their gourmet food kiosks. I felt like I was at Whole Foods in NYC. Maybe during my next trip to Tokyo, the reservation policy will be lifted.

It is worth to visit. I did not have an entrance ticket to the tower but I have visited Soramach (shopping centre alongside of the tower) opening day and flowing day. It was very fun, selection of food-courts and restaurants were good, souvenir shop on 4th floor was very interesting and good for foreigners. They have Coined operated -locker with fridge facility which I have very surprised. It is worth to visit there.

observation tower, aquarium + planetarium in shopping mall. Visited on the opening day but didn't get to go up to see the observation deck - just as well as it was raining and misty on the opening day.beautiful tower though, and nice architecture.Also, there were a lot of attractions since tokyo sky tree is combined with a shopping centre ( and frankly feels like so), so you can eat, shop and do a whole bunch of things with friends and family I reckon to kill time in case the tower is not your cup of tea. Visited sumida aquarium which was nice, as well as the konica planterium (nice but small facility - pity the screening content and quality were remarkably underwhelming... (this is the country which gave us final fantasy, people!)

world's tallest structure?. I am not sure why this thing is getting so much hype. It is newly built and all and is the highest structure in the world I suppose. There's not much you can do here except look at it. Soon you'll be able to take a very expensive ride up to the observation deck.
IT WAS TOO TALL !!!!. Modern,elegant, huge and tall. Surrounded by old,small, plain establishments and shops. Modern vs Old. But the people are nice and kind. Nice place to visit.

Tokyo Sky Tree. Beautiful to see, especially lit up! (For a few weeks, they are alternating the light up every night. There are 2 versions, blue and purple) Couldn't get in as they were not open during my recent trip to Tokyo. I heard there is going to be a restaurant, but booking is already full for months ahead.
A New Landmark. Visited before it was finished and is it ever impressive. Once open would highly recommend. The views from the top will be spectacular.

Wait a few months, if you can. As Tokyo Sky Tree just opened in early 2012, it is the Tokyo flavour of the month, and will be overwhelmed with visitors at least through the summer of 2012. If you have the option of waiting a bit longer, after the newness has worn off, you will have a much more pleasant time.

Not Open Until May. But I've watched it go up little by little. It dwarfs Tokyo Tower. It's going to carry HD and cell traffic as well as being a tourist site and place to look down on the city. Nearby is the Sosenji Shrine with its rows of tourist shops and gorgeous grounds. Visit the old and new at the same time. Also a good jumping off point for a cruise of the Sumida River.

Obsessed!. I have been obsessed with this new wonder of the world, since I first saw the design plans! I'm not always impressed with the modern architecture of Japan but they really hit the mark with this magnificent creation! It hovers over Tokyo like giant Hattori Hanzō Sword and I can't wait to be standing on the top observatory AND the one below for that matter and view the beautiful sprawl of the world's greatest city!

Can be seen from all over. No need to go here as it can be seen from many places.As of writing, the tower is not open to visitors but expect a 2 hour waiting period when it is.Great photos can be taken of Sky Tree from Asakusa.

highly recommended. while it wont be done until april next year, the tower is complete and still worth the trip to see such a mammoth tower from the bottom. i would recommend walking over the bridge from asakusa, only 10-15 mins or so.

Tokyo & Sky Tree, Tokyo. Having recently returned from a trip to Japan, I was overwhelmed by people's opinions about the Sky Tree.It seems most people seem to be rather negative about it - But I have to say considering everything that the country has been through recently, I think it just goes to prove the resolute and determined nature of the people that they are continuing to build such a beautiful piece of architecture.I was lucky enough to stay in a building with a phenominal view looking out onto the Sky Tree and even though it is still not finished, it somehow completes the Tokyo skyline.I would say to anyone who is thinking or toying with the idea of travelling to Japan - DO IT.Do not hesitate. The people are so kind and generous and the country itself is beautiful.And contrary to many people's comments, We found most meals etc between 1000-2000 Yen (which at the time equated to around £10-20) We were very lucky to be able to do our entire trip without the need of staying in hotels which does greatly help with the cost, however if you don't mind staying outside the centre of Tokyo, I can very much recommend a beautiful, smaller city called Kashiwa in Chiba prefecture. Its only about 45 minutes by train (JR Joban line) into Tokyo. We were SO incredibly lucky that while we were there Kashiwa was holding its annual 2-day festival...well worth the humid weather!
